site_title: Fragrance CEO's offer for New Wave lapses
summary: Real estate tycoon Koh Wee Meng's bid to take over New Wave Holdings has fallen through after his voluntary conditional cash offer for all shares lapsed. The offer, announced in October, required a majority stake, but at 19.2% of total shares, it fell short of the 50% threshold. All shares tendered in acceptance will be returned to shareholders, with Koh's offer price of S$0.013 per share being a premium of 44.4% over New Wave's closing price.

site_title: Thai Nov headline CPI rises 0.99% y-o-y, in line with forecasts
summary: Thailand's annual consumer inflation rate rose 0.99% in November, in line with forecasts, but below the central bank's target of 1-4%. The Bank of Thailand (BOT) left its policy interest rate unchanged at 1.50% and is expected to keep it that way until mid-2018. Core CPI, excluding raw food and energy prices, rose 0.61% in November, and the commerce ministry predicts headline inflation of 0.7% for this year and a range of 0.6-1.6% for next year.

site_title: Japan emperor abdication date set for April 30, 2019: Abe
summary: Japan's Emperor Akihito will abdicate on April 30, 2019, marking the first retirement in over 200 years. The decision was announced by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe after a special meeting of the Imperial Council, with the government committing to ensure a smooth transition. The crown prince, Naruhito, will succeed his father, who will step down after nearly 30 years on the throne.

site_title: South Korea's Nov export growth slows, inflation eases, rate hikes seen gradual
summary: South Korea's export growth slowed to 9.6% in November, below expectations, while inflation eased to 1.3%, the slowest in 11 months. The Bank of Korea raised interest rates to 1.50% for the first time in over six years, but tempered market expectations with concerns about job market and geopolitical risks. Economists expect a gradual path of monetary policy tightening due to moderating growth and sub-target inflation. The economy expanded 1.5% in the third quarter, outperforming estimates.

site_title: Google data-saving tool aims to help manage smartphone bills
summary: Google has launched a free application called Datally to help manage smartphone bills by detecting and stopping data-intensive apps that consume mobile data in the background. Developed by Google's "Next Billion Users" unit, Datally aims to reduce data costs for internet users worldwide, particularly in areas where budgets are tight. The app allows users to monitor and control their data usage, providing a solution to the issue of unnecessary data consumption.

images.alt_text: Google is taking aim at the "next billion" internet users with a way to stop smartphone apps from needlessly burning through costly mobile data allowances.

site_title: Backlash grows against new Star Wars video game's loot-box feature
summary: The new Star Wars video game, Battlefront II, has faced backlash over its loot-box feature, which allows players to purchase in-game items with real money rather than relying on skill. Critics argue that this feature creates an unfair advantage, while fans and some politicians have expressed concerns that it may be encouraging excessive spending among children. Electronic Arts has temporarily removed the ability to spend money in-game, but the feature remains the only way to obtain certain items. The controversy has led to an investigation by the Belgian Gaming Commission and criticism from politicians and industry groups.

site_title: Fonterra ordered to pay France's Danone NZ$183m over baby formula scare
summary: Fonterra, a New Zealand dairy cooperative, has been ordered to pay French rival Danone NZ$183 million in damages over a 2013 baby formula botulism scare. The scare led to global formula recalls due to contamination fears in Fonterra-supplied ingredients. The suspect ingredient turned out to be non-toxic bacteria, not the potentially fatal botulism. Danone estimated the episode cost it 300 million euros in operating profit and 370 million euros in sales. The payout was made after Danone's claims at tribunals in New Zealand and Singapore.

site_title: Global giants see Vietnam through beer goggles
summary: Global brewers, including Asahi and Anheuser-Busch InBev, are eyeing Vietnam's privatized beer market, which is expected to be sold in a majority stake sale. The young economy's brew-friendly culture and growing demand make it an attractive opportunity. However, entrenched interests and high valuations of state-owned brewer Sabeco, which is set to be sold, may deter investors. The sale is expected to take place on December 18, with a minimum sale price set at 320,000 dong per share, and a cap on foreign ownership at 49%.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after fresh Wall St record
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday, driven by a record on Wall Street and a weaker yen. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.41% to 22,819.03, while the Topix index rose 0.25% to 1,796.53. This follows another record on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh highs despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Healthway inks master lease agreement with OUE unit
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation Limited has signed a 36-month master lease agreement with OUE Limited's subsidiary Alkas Realty for units at OUE Downtown, starting August 1, 2017, and expiring on July 31, 2020. The agreement includes a rent-free period of four months. The transaction is considered an interested party transaction due to OUE's indirect 40.82% stake in Healthway Medical.

site_title: Gold dips 1% as strong global markets weigh
summary: Gold prices dropped 1% on Thursday as strong global markets and positive US economic data reduced its appeal. The US dollar, in which gold is priced, held firm after upbeat job and consumer spending data. Silver fell to an eight-week low, and gold prices remain stuck in its narrowest monthly range in 12 years, up 0.3% for the month.

site_title: Vietnam Nov factory activity growth slows as output softens
summary: Vietnam's factory activity growth slowed in November as output softened, with the PMI at 51.4, down from 51.6 in October. Weaker growth of new orders led to little change in production volumes, ending a 12-month stretch of growth. The backlog of work dropped for the first time in five months due to easing new orders growth, but manufacturers continued to hire staff at a solid pace.

site_title: A cut above the ordinary
summary: Wakanui Grill Dining, a new restaurant in Marina One, offers aged beef and lamb sourced from New Zealand, despite its Japanese-sounding name. The restaurant is open from 11:30am to 3pm for lunch and 5:30pm to 11pm for dinner, with dinner service only on weekends.

site_title: Cambodia garment makers seek continued support after EU trade access threat
summary: Cambodian garment makers are seeking continued international support amid concerns that the country's access to EU trade preferences could be threatened due to the dissolution of the main opposition party. The industry generates $6 billion annually and employs 700,000 workers, making it a vital part of the country's economy. Garment manufacturers, including those working with global brands like H&M and Gap, are urging buyers not to turn away from Cambodia, despite the risk of job losses if the EU withdraws trade terms.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.75% and the Topix index rising 0.58%. The gains followed Wall Street's rise, as investors monitored economic data and US tax reform developments. Meanwhile, in other markets, Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records in the US despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: US formally opposes China market economy status at WTO
summary: The US has formally opposed China's bid for market economy status at the World Trade Organization (WTO), citing concerns over the role of the Chinese state in its economy. The US Commerce Department had previously determined that China failed to meet the tests of a market economy in an anti-dumping case. The opposition, filed by the US Trade Representative's office, could lead to the US maintaining high anti-dumping duties on Chinese goods if China is granted market economy status. The move is part of escalating trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Falling Sydney prices drive a slowdown in Australian property
summary: Falling Sydney home prices are driving a slowdown in Australian property, with dwelling prices rising 5.2% in the year to November, half the pace of six months earlier. Sydney prices extended month-on-month declines, and a housing slowdown could "have a flow-on effect for other sectors of the economy," according to CoreLogic. This decrease in consumer confidence could further impact the economy.

site_title: MMA promoter One Championship announces 3 senior hires
summary: One Championship, a Singapore-based MMA promoter, has appointed three senior executives: Hua Fung Teh as CFO, Mahesh Subramanian as CTO, and Souvik Dutta as VP of Engineering. The hires are expected to bring significant leadership strength to the company, which plans to stage a record 24 events in 2018. The new team will oversee technology and infrastructure, mobile, and digital solutions. The company's chairman and CEO, Chatri Sityodtong, stated that the appointments will help One Championship continue to scale across Asia.

site_title: Toshiba nearing resolution to Western Digital dispute: sources
summary: Toshiba and Western Digital are nearing a settlement to their dispute over Toshiba's $18 billion sale of its flash-memory business. Under the agreement, Western Digital will drop its efforts to block the sale in exchange for extending their joint venture agreements. In return, Western Digital will receive a guaranteed supply of newer chips from a Toshiba plant in Japan. The two companies are still finalizing details, and a deal may not be reached. Toshiba needs to raise capital to avoid delisting from the Tokyo Stock Exchange and sell the chip business to pay for losses in its US nuclear business.

site_title: Keppel unit, partner bag HK$31b contract for Hong Kong's first integrated waste management facility
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Holdings Pte Ltd and China Harbour Engineering Company Limited have secured a HK$31 billion contract to design, build and operate Hong Kong's first integrated waste management facility. The facility will be built on a 16-ha reclaimed island off the coast of Shek Kwu Chua, south of Lantau Island. Keppel's share of the contract is HK$11.3 billion, with operations set to begin in 2024 and maintained for 15 years. The project marks Hong Kong's first integrated waste management facility for municipal solid waste.

site_title: Argentina formally ends search for submarine survivors: Navy
summary: Argentina's navy formally ended the search for survivors of the missing San Juan submarine two weeks after it went missing with 44 crew members. The navy shifted its focus to recovering the vessel from the South Atlantic depths. Despite an extended international rescue effort, no evidence of a shipwreck was found, and it's unclear if the crew had perished.

site_title: A night to remember for Singapore's top enterprises
summary: The Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards honored Singapore's top privately-held firms on November 21, with the local business community in attendance. The annual black-tie event recognizes the best in the country's business landscape.

site_title: China steel clings to near 11-week high, posts best week since August
summary: China's steel futures reached a near 11-week high, closing 0.5% lower at 3,977 yuan (S$810) a tonne on the Shanghai Futures Exchange. The most-active rebar gained 5% this week, its largest weekly gain since early August, driven by tighter supply and profit margins. Steel mills in northern China were ordered to cut sintering output by up to half from this month to March to combat smog, supporting stronger prices. This is the biggest weekly gain for rebar in four months.

site_title: RBS axes further 259 British branches as expands e-banking
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) plans to close 259 branches and cut 680 jobs as it shifts customers to online and mobile services. The move is part of a cost-cutting effort, following a similar move by Lloyds Banking Group. The bank will retain around 744 branches, citing increasing mobile and online usage. Unite, a labor union, criticized the decision, stating it will "decimate" the bank's branch network and affect hundreds of high streets.

site_title: Better to tread with care on dual-class shares
summary: Singapore's Companies Act removal of "one share, one vote" restriction nearly two years ago has allowed for dual-class shares, but none are yet listed on the exchange. Clarity on how they will be accommodated remains elusive. Despite the potential benefits, dual-class shares are not yet widely adopted, leaving companies to navigate the complexities of this share structure. The lack of clarity hinders the development of a more nuanced market for dual-class shares in Singapore.

site_title: Upgraded Singapore-Australia free trade agreement ratified, comes into force today
summary: Singapore and Australia have ratified and implemented the upgraded Singapore-Australia Free Trade Agreement (SAFTA), which came into force on Friday. The agreement provides updated trade rules, increased opportunities for businesses, and enhanced access to each other's services sectors. Key benefits include improved mobility for business persons, rules to facilitate trade in the digital economy, and greater facilitation for investments. The agreement was signed in October 2016 and aims to promote bilateral economic relations between the two countries.

site_title: Does Europe have what it takes to create the next Google?
summary: Europe is poised to create the next Google, with major strides made to eliminate barriers and foster innovation. The region has thriving tech hubs, record new funding, and a growing pool of technical talent. Despite challenges, top venture capitalists and entrepreneurs are increasingly confident that the next world-class companies could emerge from Europe, particularly in fields like artificial intelligence, video gaming, and music. European tech companies are expected to reach a record $19.1 billion in funding this year, with median venture fund sizes nearly tripling to around $58 million.

site_title: US dollar steadies, earlier rise stalls as market endures US tax bill wait
summary: The US dollar steadied against the yen on Friday after rising to a 10-day high due to Wall Street's rally and Treasury yield spikes, but ultimately stalled as the US Senate delayed voting on a tax reform bill. The dollar index fell 0.1% to 92.956, while the euro was little changed at $1.1908. The pound surged 0.9% to a two-month high, driven by optimism over Brexit negotiations. The dollar-yen pair remained volatile, influenced by US yield expectations.

site_title: Consumer spending in October cools while inflation is picking up
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.3% in October, matching economists' projections, while inflation increased 0.2% and disposable income grew 0.4% for the second month, the highest back-to-back gains since early 2017. Inflation remains below the Federal Reserve's 2% target, but progress toward the goal suggests growth for the quarter. The data may support a Fed interest-rate increase in December, and consumer spending accounts for about 70% of the economy, boding well for the holiday shopping season.

site_title: Uncertainty looms for Pyongyang-backed businesses in China's North Korean hub
summary: North Korean-owned businesses in China, particularly the Chilbosan Hotel in Shenyang, face uncertainty due to looming UN sanctions against Pyongyang-owned overseas businesses. The hotel, North Korea's largest overseas investment, is mostly staffed by North Koreans and attracts mostly Chinese customers. The sanctions, expected to be imposed soon, may impact the livelihoods of those working for these businesses, including the hotel's North Korean staff. The future of these businesses remains uncertain, raising concerns for those involved.

site_title: Australia to hold banking inquiry to quell public anger
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull announces a royal commission into the finance industry amid mounting public anger over scandals, including dodgy financial advice and mortgage fraud. The 12-month inquiry, costing A$75 million, will focus on misconduct among banks, insurers, and financial services providers, but not on financial stability. The decision comes after the country's top lenders admitted it was needed to restore faith in the sector, which has been hurt by uncertainty and global headwinds.

site_title: Lufthansa offers to sacrifice routes to save Air Berlin deal: source
summary: Lufthansa is willing to sacrifice certain routes to complete its 210 million euro deal to acquire Air Berlin's assets, including Niki and LG Walter. The German carrier will submit proposed concessions to the European Commission by midnight, including giving up slots belonging to these businesses. This move aims to cement Lufthansa's position in Germany and expand its Eurowings budget brand.

images.alt_text: Lufthansa is willing to sacrifice the right to fly some routes to save its deal to acquire assets of Air Berlin, the low-cost airline that collapsed recently, a source familiar with the company's thinking said on Thursday.

site_title: Uber's use of encrypted messaging raises legal issues
summary: Uber executives used the encrypted chat app Wickr to hold secret conversations, contradicting the company's public stance on data preservation. This revelation has raised legal concerns, as companies have an obligation to preserve records. The use of Wickr inside Uber upends the high-stakes legal showdown with Alphabet's Waymo unit over self-driving car secrets. The incident sets up a potential test of the issues raised by the use of encrypted apps within companies.

site_title: Snapchat's redesign keeps it personal in a bid to fend off rivals
summary: Snapchat has unveiled a redesign to boost user engagement, focusing on individual users' interests rather than what friends post. The app will rely on computer algorithms to create a personalized content feed, aiming to combat fake news and distractions. The change is intended to help publishers make money from their stories and increase user growth. Following a widening loss and declining user numbers, Snapchat aims to revamp its service with features such as augmented reality and machine learning.

images.alt_text: Snap's co-founder and chief Evan Spiegel says the changes will result in a personalised content feed based on what users want to watch, not what their friends post, and will help guard against fake news on the firm's social networking app.

site_title: Musk to make bid to fund high-speed rail in Chicago
summary: Elon Musk's The Boring Company plans to fund, build, and run a high-speed rail loop connecting O'Hare Airport to downtown Chicago. The system would use electromagnetic propulsion, potentially surpassing high-speed trains in speed. Musk aims to create a faster alternative for transportation in the city.

site_title: China's Nov factory growth unexpectedly picks up despite pollution crackdown
summary: China's manufacturing sector unexpectedly saw growth in November, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 51.8, above expectations. The sector's resilience was driven by government infrastructure spending, a strong property market, and exports. Analysts had forecast a decline, but the data suggests China's economy may avoid a sharp slowdown. However, some economists predict moderation in growth to around 6.6% in the fourth quarter and 6.4% in 2018, as borrowing costs rise and the boost from earlier infrastructure projects fades.

site_title: Lombok airport reopens, as Bali's volcano alert status lowered
summary: Lombok's international airport reopened on December 1, 2017, after a day of suspension due to ash clouds from Bali's Moung Agung volcano. The airport resumed operations at 8:50am local time, with a lowered Volcano Observation Notice for Aviation (VONA) alert code from red to orange. This allowed thousands of tourists stranded in Bali to return home. The situation in Bali has shown signs of improvement, but extreme weather conditions, including Cyclone Cempaka, continue to affect other parts of Indonesia, displacing over 3,000 people and causing at least 27 deaths.

site_title: Uncovering the long history behind NY restaurant Gallaghers
summary: Restaurateur Dean J Poll reminisces about New York's lost restaurants, including Luchow's, Mama Leone's, and the Four Seasons. He mentions La Caravelle, a French restaurant that closed in 2004, and the Cattleman, a steakhouse with nightly sing-alongs. Poll expresses sadness over the loss of these iconic establishments, which are now gone forever.

site_title: Ezion's refinancing illustrates the value of engaging stakeholders
summary: Ezion Holdings, an offshore and marine firm, successfully refinanced S$575 million worth of notes and perpetuals with a landslide vote, offering hope for the company's return to a stronger footing. The deal highlights the importance of engaging stakeholders, open communication, and transparency, crucial in good corporate governance. Ezion's frequent frank dialogue and educational sessions with bankers, financial advisers, and bondholders led to a landmark agreement, slashing annual coupons to 0.25%, swapping debt to equity, and offering alternatives to noteholders. The deal unlocks S$100 million in working capital, potentially reviving the company's fortunes.

site_title: Nokia denies reports of talks to buy Juniper Networks
summary: Nokia denies reports of talks to buy Juniper Networks, contradicting earlier CNBC reports. Nokia stated it is not in talks to acquire the US network gear maker, despite Juniper's shares rising 18% in extended trading following the CNBC report. Nokia has been expanding its telecom equipment business, buying Alcatel-Lucent for $17 billion last year. Juniper's market capitalization is around $11.26 billion.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed on Friday
summary: Malaysia's markets were closed on December 1, 2017, due to a public holiday. In contrast, Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally on July 11, 2025, driven by positive investor sentiment ahead of GDP data. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% on July 10, 2025, despite US tariff uncertainty.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks edge up, won muted
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 1.49 points or 0.06% to 2,477.86 on Friday, marking a six-week low on Thursday. The Korean won slightly eased to 1,088.6 per dollar, while bond yields fell. The Bank of Korea's rate hike reinforced views of a gradual monetary tightening cycle, with export growth and low inflation data supporting this view.

site_title: Apple, Qualcomm trade new patent-infringement allegations
summary: Apple has alleged in court filings that Qualcomm is using its patented technology for extending battery life in iPhones, escalating a royalty battle between the two tech giants. Qualcomm responded by filing additional patent claims against Apple, further intensifying the dispute. The dispute centers on who profits most from society-changing technology and electronics.

site_title: Airlines pile on flights to fly trapped tourists out of Bali
summary: Airlines in Bali increased flights to evacuate thousands of stranded tourists as a shift in wind direction reduced volcanic ash. Despite the increased flights, Mount Agung continued to rumble and a plume of smoke rose above the volcano. The eruption had been ongoing for days, affecting tourist travel to the island.

site_title: Musk's record-breaking battery officially launches in Australia
summary: Elon Musk's record-breaking 100 MW/129 MWh battery system was officially launched in Australia to ease energy woes after a 2016 blackout. The system, powered by Tesla, can provide electricity for over 30,000 homes and meets peak demand amid hot weather. The project was completed in 100 days, beating Musk's deadline, and is expected to help tackle power shortages, reduce intermittencies, and address peak demands in summer. The system is now leading the world in dispatchable renewable energy, according to South Australian Premier Jay Weatherill.

site_title: Japan inflation ticks up but far from target
summary: Japan's consumer prices rose 0.8% year-on-year in October, but still fell short of the 2% target set by the Bank of Japan. This marked the 10th consecutive month of inflation. Household spending remained flat, defying expectations of a 0.3% drop. The unemployment rate remained at 2.8% for the fifth consecutive month. Japan's weak inflation contrasts with other major economies, which are expected to hike interest rates in 2018.

site_title: GLP's shareholders give green light for privatisation
summary: Global Logistic Properties' (GLP) shareholders approved a privatisation bid by Nesta Investment Holdings, valued at approximately S$16 billion, at S$3.38 per share. The scheme, which will take place via a scheme of arrangement, received 96.02% shareholder support and was also backed by sovereign wealth fund GIC. The deal is expected to be presented to the High Court of Singapore for approval, with a payment date set for Jan 19, 2018. GLP's CEO, Ming Z Mei, is a director of Nesta, and the company is expected to be delisted shortly after the deal is completed.

site_title: Singapore shares resume higher on Friday afternoon; STI at 3,460.36
summary: Singapore shares rose on Friday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,460.36, after a 26.82-point gain as of 1:03pm. Gainers outnumbered losers 186 to 150, with 1.15 billion shares traded.

site_title: India posts stronger growth as businesses adjust to new tax
summary: India's economy rebounded in the three months ending in September, posting a 6.3% growth rate, its fastest pace in three quarters. The growth halted a five-quarter slide, with businesses adjusting to the new national sales tax, which has been criticized for its impact on small businesses. The manufacturing sector grew 7% in the September quarter, and analysts have upgraded India's sovereign credit rating, expecting the economy to grow 6.7% in the fiscal year ending March 31.

site_title: Asia stocks pare gains, US equity futures drop on delay in Senate tax bill vote
summary: Asian stocks lost early gains on Friday as the US Senate delayed voting on a tax bill, weighing on S&P 500 futures. The Nikkei 225 index briefly touched a 25-year high, but Japanese shares retreated. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 Index had previously reached record highs, fueled by optimism on US tax reform. The US dollar weakened as the Senate suspended votes, and investors awaited key data from Asia, including China's manufacturing PMI and inflation rates in Japan and South Korea.

site_title: Amazon steps up pace in artificial intelligence race
summary: Amazon has unveiled a range of new machine learning features for its Amazon Web Services (AWS) cloud computing business, aiming to challenge Silicon Valley's tech giants in the artificial intelligence (AI) space. The new offerings include features for training AI algorithms, translating language, analyzing video, and scanning text for trends or key phrases. This move comes after Amazon released 1,300 new AWS features in 2017, and is seen as a significant step in the company's efforts to make AI more accessible and affordable for startups and enterprises.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.4% up on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.4% to 3,447.16, following a similar trend in US stocks overnight. About 125.6 million shares changed hands, with Singtel leading the gains. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened marginally lower on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 4.46 points to 29,172.89. Gains in energy companies were offset by losses in technology firms, following an Opec-Russia agreement to limit oil output. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged down.

site_title: Monster storm threatens Australia's wheat crop after drought
summary: A severe storm is threatening Australia's wheat crop, with heavy rains forecast to intensify over the weekend, potentially damaging up to 4 million tonnes of wheat. The drought-hit crop is already expected to yield its smallest amount in a decade, with 50% of the crop harvested in South Australia but only 30% in Victoria and southern New South Wales. The storm may cause quality downgrades rather than yield losses, leading to higher global prices for high-protein wheat.

site_title: Australia's Jetstar cancels some Bali flights as volcanic ash threat revives
summary: Jetstar airline canceled nine flights from Bali to Australia due to a threat from volcanic ash from Mount Agung volcano. The decision came after a forecast indicated volcanic ash could hit operations at Bali airport, about 60km southwest of the volcano. The airport had previously closed from Monday to Wednesday, stranding thousands of travelers. Airlines avoid flying through volcanic ash as it can damage aircraft engines and cause engine failure. A tropical cyclone in the area may bring heavy rains and strong winds until Saturday, with tens of thousands resisting government orders to evacuate.

site_title: AA Reit's 42m new units start trading
summary: AA Reit's 42.15 million new units started trading on the Singapore Exchange, following a private placement that raised S$55 million at S$1.305 per share. The proceeds will be used to repay borrowings, enhance assets, and fund future development projects. The counter was trading at S$1.34, down 0.74% as of 10:03am. The listing is the result of strong demand from institutional investors and high net worth individuals.

site_title: Australia: Shares headed for 4th week of gains in 5; NZ inches up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% on Friday, tracking Wall Street's gains, and are on track for a fourth week of gains in five. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at a record high, with financials and industrials leading the charge on tax cut hopes. Energy stocks also rose, with oil prices boosted by Opec output cuts. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.1%, on track for a third consecutive week of gains.

site_title: Turkish gold trader implicates Erdogan in Iran money laundering
summary: Turkish gold trader Reza Zarrab testified in a New York federal court that Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan personally authorized a 2010-2015 money laundering scheme for Iran to evade US sanctions. Zarrab, cooperating with US prosecutors, implicated Turkish state-owned banks Ziraat and VakifBank in the scheme. Erdogan denied Turkey's involvement, calling the case a "plot against Turkey." Zarrab's testimony is part of the trial of Mehmet Hakan Atilla, a Turkish bank executive accused of laundering money for Iran.

images.alt_text: Mr Erdogan said earlier on Thursday that Turkey did not violate US sanctions and "did the right thing" in dealing with Iran, CNN Turk reported.

site_title: Allgreen snaps up two freehold sites in Bukit Timah in collective sales
summary: Allgreen Properties acquired two freehold sites in Bukit Timah through collective sales, securing Royalville for S$477.94 million and Crystal Tower for S$180.65 million. The sites attracted intense competition, with 19 bids for Royalville and 12 for Crystal Tower. Each apartment owner at Royalville will receive between S$3.09 million and S$3.76 million, while Crystal Tower's owners are expected to receive between S$6 million and S$12.3 million. The sales reflect land rates of S$1,960 and S$1,840 per square foot per plot ratio, respectively.

images.alt_text: Most of the bids for Royalville were well above the asking price of S$368 million, said Swee Shou Fern, senior director for investment advisory at Edmund Tie & Company.

site_title: Bitcoin could threaten financial stability: Fed governor
summary: Fed Vice Chairman Randal Quarles expressed concerns that digital currencies like bitcoin could threaten financial stability due to their unregulated nature and potential for price volatility. He warned that in times of crisis, demand for liquidity could strain major financial institutions. Quarles cautioned that decentralized virtual currencies like bitcoin may not behave predictably in crisis situations, posing a "large challenge to the system" if they achieve widespread use.

site_title: Stocks to watch: BRC Asia, Manulife US Reit, Cache Logistics Trust, Healthway Medical
summary: BRC Asia resumes trading after a takeover bid by Esteel Enterprise ended with a 95.83% stake. Manulife US Reit's manager issued 1.26 million and 591,384 units as payment for fees. Cache Logistics Trust issued a S$1 billion debt issuance programme for general corporate purposes. Healthway Medical signed a master lease agreement with Alkas Realty for 36 months starting August 1, 2017.

site_title: Olam completes US$110m sale of California orchards to US farmland Reit
summary: Olam International completed the sale of its 5,100-acre California orchards to Farmland Partners Inc (FPI) for $110 million in cash. Olam will operate the orchards for 25 years, sharing annual revenue with FPI. The deal allows Olam to focus on growing almonds, pistachios, and walnuts in California, with plans to further invest in the region.

site_title: US Senate tax bill stalls on deficit-focused 'trigger'
summary: The US Senate delayed voting on a Republican tax overhaul bill due to concerns over its deficit impact. The bill, which aims to boost the economy and provide tax relief to individuals and businesses, was proposed by President Donald Trump and Republicans in Congress. However, fiscal hawks, including Senator Bob Corker, opposed the bill, citing concerns over the large expansion of the federal budget deficit projected to result from the measure. The Senate parliamentarian barred a proposed "trigger" amendment that would have automatically triggered future tax increases if the tax cuts did not boost the economy and generate revenues sufficient to offset the deficit expansion.

images.alt_text: The US Senate on Thursday delayed voting on a Republican tax overhaul as the bill was tripped up by problems with an amendment sought by fiscal hawks to address a large expansion of the federal budget deficit projected to result from the measure.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust issues S$1b notes programme
summary: Cache Logistics Trust has issued a S$1 billion multi-currency debt issuance programme, with DBS Bank Ltd as the sole arranger and dealer. The notes will be used for general corporate purposes, following a 12.8% decline in third-quarter distribution per unit. The issuance does not affect the trust's existing rights units and bonus element from a recent rights issue, with DPU marginally lower than last year. The programme is considered a direct, unconditional, and unsubordinated obligation of the issuer, ranked equally with other unsecured obligations.

site_title: China's debt crackdown hits cash loan firms
summary: China's government has cracked down on cash loan firms, suspending new approvals and restricting business across regions, amid concerns over the industry's risks. The market, valued at 1 trillion yuan, has seen rapid growth in consumer borrowing with little access to traditional banks. Interest rates are high, with annual rates of 36%, and borrowers are often trapped in a cycle of debt. The crackdown follows warnings of financial stress on borrowers and the need for stricter regulation to prevent default. The industry's future remains uncertain.

site_title: Tourism needs more 'cultural immersion'
summary: The tourism industry is shifting towards social sustainability, prioritizing cultural immersion to preserve heritage and deepen a sense of shared humanity. This approach involves authentic experiences, such as staying in a Japanese ryokan or enjoying street food in Singapore, to resist the lowest common denominator and promote local culture. By embracing cultural immersion, tourism can help foster a sense of common humanity and contribute to a more inclusive and sustainable industry.

site_title: France said to press China for more financial market access
summary: French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire is set to press Chinese authorities to give French banks better access to mainland China's securities markets during his visit. Le Maire will discuss ways to increase French banks' role in businesses like initial listings and equities trading. This comes ahead of French President Emmanuel Macron's visit next month. China has recently unveiled financial reforms, removing foreign ownership caps on banks and allowing overseas companies to take majority stakes in local securities ventures. Le Maire's trip aims to accelerate development in China as the market opens.

site_title: Europe: Profit taking saps shares in November after "memorable" gains
summary: European shares fell 0.3% on Thursday, marking their biggest monthly decline since June, as profit-taking kicked in after strong gains this year. Financial stocks weighed on the market, with Credit Suisse rising after promising improved returns and Italian banks gaining on news of delayed bad loan rules. Despite this month's wobble, fund managers expect markets to hold onto their gains, citing strong economic data and tax reform prospects. The Stoxx 600 is up 7% for 2017, with the German DAX index gaining 13%.

site_title: Oil rises as Opec extends cuts to end of 2018
summary: OPEC and non-OPEC producers, led by Russia, agreed to extend output cuts until the end of 2018, aiming to tackle global oversupply and bolster oil prices. The deal, set to expire in March, will continue for nine months, with Nigeria and Libya included in the oil output agreement. The move was seen as a bullish signal, but price reactions were muted as the extension was already priced in. Oil prices rose, with Brent crude futures settling up 0.7% to $63.57 a barrel.

site_title: More clarity in doctors' fees by next year
summary: Singapore plans to introduce more transparency in doctors' fees by next year, with a new independent committee set to determine benchmarks for various surgeries. The committee will assess actual fees, distribution, and procedures to decide on a reasonable fee range. Patients will benefit from improved transparency, allowing them to decide if they want to continue seeking treatment from a doctor who may charge more but is well-regarded. The move aims to keep healthcare costs sustainable, following a long-drawn push to address the issue.

site_title: Green power too costly, so China cities 'may go back to coal'
summary: China's northern cities, including Beijing, may switch back to coal from electricity and gas due to insufficient government subsidies, according to a report by think tanks. The move comes as the country attempts to cut coal consumption and reduce emissions, but faces challenges in providing enough subsidies to support the transition. This shift could lead to increased air pollution and undermine Beijing's efforts to improve air quality.

site_title: Singapore helps boost Japan's expertise in international commercial mediation
summary: Singapore has signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with Japan's Japan Association of Arbitrators to boost Japan's expertise in international commercial mediation. The agreement will help set up the Japan International Mediation Centre in Kyoto, promoting international commercial mediation in Japan through joint events and training. Singapore's Senior Minister of State for Law and Finance, Indranee Rajah, hailed the MOU as a "strong endorsement" of Singapore's capability in international commercial dispute resolution, citing the country's experience in mediating over S$20 million worth of disputes involving Japanese companies in the past two years.

site_title: Trump is said to weigh replacing Rex Tillerson as ties sour
summary: The White House is considering replacing Secretary of State Rex Tillerson with CIA Director Mike Pompeo amid frustration with Tillerson's slow pace of hiring and repeated clashes with President Donald Trump. The potential shakeup comes as foreign policy crises, including North Korea's nuclear program and rising tensions between Saudi Arabia and Iran, dominate the White House's agenda. Tillerson's tenure has been marked by disagreements with Trump over policy, including the Paris climate change accord and North Korea's nuclear program. The White House has declined to confirm whether Tillerson will remain in his position, but officials say he serves at the president's pleasure.

site_title: South Korea says North Korea still needs to prove critical missile technology, expects pause in testing
summary: North Korea's latest missile test places the US mainland within range, but South Korea believes the country still needs to prove critical missile technology. Despite this, Seoul expects Pyongyang to pause its missile testing programme, following the success of the Hwasong-15 missile. North Korean leader Kim Jong Un hailed the test as a "breakthrough" in completing the state nuclear force.

site_title: Cromwell European Reit makes a muted start
summary: Cromwell European Reit (CEReit) made a muted trading debut on the Singapore Exchange, closing at 0.555 euro after offering 428.5 million units at the same price. The Reit's manager raised 866 million euros, with 18.7 million shares changing hands by the end of the day. CEReit aims to provide investors with access to European markets and a geographically diverse portfolio of commercial and industrial properties, becoming the first euro-denominated Reit to be listed on the SGX.

site_title: Explosion at Japan chemical factory kills one, hurts 11
summary: An explosion and fire broke out at an Arakawa Chemical Industries factory in central Japan, killing one worker and injuring 11 others. The factory, which produces chemicals for the paper industry, was located near Mount Fuji. Residents within 100m of the factory were evacuated, and 17 fire engines and 60 firefighters battled the blaze. The factory operator denied concerns of potential contamination or pollution, and officials stated that chemicals produced by the factory would not pollute the environment.

site_title: Modern-day gold rush in west Australia
summary: A modern-day gold rush is underway in western Australia's Pilbara region, with over 25 publicly-listed companies and thousands of individual prospectors searching for gold. Canadian company Kirkland Lake Gold expects to produce a quarter-million ounces of gold this year and is investing millions in the area. Recent discoveries, including watermelon seed-shaped nuggets, have sparked excitement among investors and prospectors, with some making fortunes mining iron ore in the region. However, it may take years to determine whether enough gold exists to start mining on a commercial scale.

site_title: Murder On The Orient Express evokes old-fashioned charm
summary: Kenneth Branagh's film adaptation of Agatha Christie's "Murder On The Orient Express" brings the classic whodunit to life, following the brilliant detective Hercule Poirot as he investigates a murder on a luxury train. The film features an all-star cast, including Johnny Depp, Judi Dench, and Michelle Pfeiffer, and stays true to the original book's plot, which was inspired by a real-life incident. While the film's climax may be somewhat predictable, Branagh's direction and the cast's performances evoke an old-fashioned charm, making for an entertaining watch.

images.alt_text: Hercule Poirot, played by Kenneth Branagh (above), and the all-star cast play their part earnestly while resisting the urge to ham it up.

site_title: Fed backs case to lift US growth potential from tax change boost
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen expressed support for a faster economic expansion from tax code changes, but warned against inflationary pressures. She emphasized the need for sustained growth from productivity gains or labor force expansion, cautioning against short-term demand boosts. The Fed is withdrawing monetary stimulus and aims to maintain a 2% inflation rate. A tax overhaul is being considered, with President Trump pressing for a December 25 passage. Fed officials, including Jerome Powell, have expressed concerns about rising national debt and the economic impact of tax cuts.

site_title: Nasdaq looking at bitcoin futures: source
summary: Nasdaq plans to introduce bitcoin futures in the second quarter of next year, becoming the third major US exchange to offer cryptocurrency derivatives. The contracts will trade on its NFX market and use data from over 50 sources for pricing. This move pits Nasdaq against CME Group and Cboe Global Markets, which also announced plans to offer bitcoin derivatives. The strategy aims to differentiate Nasdaq and make it a major player in the cryptocurrency derivatives market, with Intercontinental Exchange Inc being the only major US exchange operator without public plans to offer bitcoin derivatives.

site_title: Chipotle founder and CEO to exit as investor patience thins
summary: Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc is searching for a turnaround expert to replace founder and CEO Steve Ells, who stepped down after two years of struggling to revive the burrito chain's sales and reputation following food-safety lapses. Investors welcomed the move, sending shares up 5% to $301.99. Ells will remain as executive chairman, and the company has hired executive recruitment firm Spencer Stuart to find a new CEO. Hedge fund manager William Ackman, who has a 10% stake in Chipotle, supported Ells' decision and is "as excited as ever" about the company's future.

site_title: Credit card curbs rein in borrowing binge
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reports that the proportion of leveraged borrowers has fallen following new credit card debt rules. As of August 2017, there were 27,000 borrowers with unsecured debt exceeding 18 times their monthly income, down from 51,000 in February 2015. The MAS is monitoring the impact of fintech on unsecured borrowing and warns that fintech companies could lead to higher credit by reducing loan administration costs. The regulator also notes that Singapore banks could lose up to 5% of their operating income if they fail to address fintech disruption.

images.alt_text: The proportion of leveraged borrowers has fallen following the latest rules to rein in credit card debt, the latest Financial Stability Review report released on Thursday showed.

site_title: Ying Li's RMB3.3b deal: Time for a dividend?
summary: Ying Li International Real Estate sold its Chongqing commercial development, International Commercial Centre (ICC), to China Evergrande for 3.29 billion yuan (S$672 million), resulting in a pro forma gain of S$70 million. The sale price may disappoint expectations, but it de-risks the company and provides a significant gain. Minority shareholders may now receive a dividend, as the company can focus on growth and debt repayment. The sale also comes at a time when the Chongqing office market is experiencing high vacancy rates and new supply.

site_title: Customer service evolves through the generations
summary: Singapore's customer service industry is evolving with technology, but businesses must balance human interaction with technology to cater to multigenerational consumers. A recent study found that younger generations (Gen X and Millennials) are more likely to adopt technology, while older generations (Pioneer and Baby Boomers) prefer human interaction. To provide excellent service, businesses should empower staff, offer excellent service recovery, keep staff informed, and provide a range of options. The government's "Smart Nation" initiative aims to leverage technology to complement human interaction, ensuring a seamless customer experience.

images.alt_text: The adoption of technology - self-checkout counters, for example - is stratified and companies should be aware of the preferences of their target market.

site_title: How do you advertise to a machine? Big oil seeking answer
summary: Big oil companies, including BP, are struggling to find ways to advertise to driverless cars as the industry shifts towards electric vehicles. BP's head of technology, David Eyton, stated that the company is studying possible ways to participate in the electrification of transport, including car charging. Companies like Royal Dutch Shell have already signed deals with carmakers to expand electric vehicle offerings. With autonomous vehicles on the horizon, oil companies must adapt to the changing market or risk losing demand for traditional fuels.

site_title: US dollar rebounds off lows on policy hopes
summary: The US dollar rebounded on Thursday, moving away from a two-month low, as investors anticipated the Federal Reserve to continue unwinding its policy stimulus plan next year due to brightening growth prospects. Despite a predicted biggest monthly drop since July, some investors expect rising US inflation, forcing policymakers to raise interest rates and boosting the dollar.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks barely move; won edges up
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell 2.7% on a weekly basis, its largest weekly loss since early August, at 2,475.41. The Korean won edged up 0.04% to 1,086.4 per US dollar in local trading, while bond yields rose. This marked the KOSPI's smallest daily movement since November 2016.

site_title: PUB to spend S$500m to safeguard against floods
summary: Singapore's PUB will spend S$500 million over two to three years to upgrade existing drains to safeguard against floods due to increasingly extreme weather conditions. This investment adds to the S$1.2 billion already spent on drain improvement works since 2011. The move comes as extreme weather conditions become more common, highlighting the need for enhanced flood protection measures.

site_title: STI moves sideways as tech stocks swing
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore moved sideways, closing 5.45 points lower at 3,433.54 points, down 0.16%. Tech stocks declined, with contract manufacturers and precision engineering firms falling in sympathy. However, Allied Tech rose 17% on heavy trading. Yield stocks, such as banks and Reits, saw significant trading activity, driven by optimism over US interest rates and improving economic conditions. Despite the market's decline, investors remain optimistic about dividend stocks, with Reit valuations expected to recover in 2018.

site_title: Sacked US TV anchor Matt Lauer expresses 'shame' and 'regret'
summary: US TV anchor Matt Lauer, 59, expressed "shame" and "regret" after being sacked from NBC's Today show following a female colleague's harassment allegations. Lauer denied some claims but acknowledged the truth behind the stories, making him feel "embarrassed and ashamed." This incident marks the second US star anchor to be sacked in a week amid a sexual misconduct wave affecting television networks, following the firing of Charlie Rose.

site_title: Another warning on property market puts developers on the defensive
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has warned of "excessive exuberance" in the property market, citing a supply-occupation mismatch due to a looming surge in private housing stock and higher land prices. The warning comes amid a recent surge in en bloc sales and a 0.7% price increase in the third quarter. Market players, including DBS senior economist Irvin Seah and Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore (Redas) President Augustine Tan, argue that the warnings are premature and that the market is not yet experiencing excessive exuberance.

site_title: Funny, fast-paced, free-wheeling
summary: W!ld Rice's latest pantomime, "Mama White Snake," is a hilarious and entertaining production inspired by the ancient Chinese folktale of Madame White Snake and her sworn sister Green Snake. The show features cross-dressed actors Glen Goei and Ivan Heng as the titular characters, with a talented cast, including Andrew Marko, Cheryl Tan, Siti Khalijah Zainal, and Zelda Tatiana Ng. The pantomime combines Singlish jokes, pop culture references, and Chinese opera gestures, making it a cult favorite among both kids and adults. With its message of respect for human diversity and love for family, "Mama White Snake" has achieved great success, solidifying W!ld Rice's reputation as a theatre company pushing for positive change.

site_title: Analysts stress need for well-implemented fee guidelines for public
summary: Singapore's government-led initiative to set new benchmarks for doctors' fees is seen as a crucial step to curb unfair fees and keep medical costs affordable. Analysts praise the need for well-implemented guidelines, citing the potential for "a game changer" in the country's ailing medical tourism sector. However, concerns remain over the committee's independence and the impact on private healthcare business valuations. Experts suggest a complete set of measures, including public health education and disease prevention, is needed to fully tackle the issue.

site_title: US: Stocks end at records, Dow closes above 24,000 for first time
summary: US stocks closed at records, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching 24,272.35, surpassing 24,000 points for the first time. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also hit fresh records, driven by a Senate tax cut plan nearing passage. Petroleum-linked stocks and industrial shares led the gains, with CVS Health and Kroger rising 4.4% and 6.1%, respectively. Analysts expect further gains if the tax cut becomes law, with some targeting the S&P 500 at 2,800.

site_title: Keppel T&T starts strategic review of logistics portfolio in China
summary: Keppel T&T, a Singapore-based logistics company, has initiated a strategic review of its China logistics portfolio. The review aims to optimize resources and potentially sell off its assets, which could fetch at least S$280 million. The company has faced significant losses in its China operations, with a net loss of S$2.39 million in the nine months to Sep 30, 2017. Analysts suggest that Keppel T&T may be looking to sell off its entire logistics portfolio in China, citing interest from potential buyers, including competitors.

site_title: Credit Suisse targets 50% payout plan as turnaround quickens
summary: Credit Suisse has set a target to return half its net income to shareholders through buybacks or special dividends by 2019 or 2020, as part of its turnaround plan. The bank has confirmed its 2018 profit targets for several divisions and is entering the final year of its restructuring after tapping shareholders for over $13.7 billion in recent years. CEO Tidjane Thiam aims to reward investors who have supported the bank during tough times, with the payout plan focusing on wealth management and investment banking capabilities.

site_title: India needs looser fiscal policy to boost growth
summary: India's economic growth rate slowed to 5.7% in Q2 2017, marking a decrease from 7.5% in 2014 and 7.1% in 2016. The slowdown is attributed to two policy initiatives: demonetization, which disrupted the informal economy, and the introduction of the goods and services tax, which caused short-term economic hardship. Experts argue that the country's credit famine, caused by non-performing assets held by nationalized banks, is a longer-term issue that needs to be addressed. The government is under pressure to boost growth, with the next election scheduled for 2019.

site_title: Uber's use of encrypted messaging may set legal precedents
summary: Uber's use of encrypted messaging app Wickr has raised legal concerns, with the company's top executives using the app to hold secret conversations. This has led to a potential precedent in the case against Alphabet's Waymo unit, which accuses Uber of stealing self-driving car secrets. Wickr's ephemeral nature makes it difficult to access deleted messages, and companies may be obligated to preserve records, even if they are encrypted. This could harm Uber's defense in the case, as it suggests intentional attempts to hide evidence of wrongdoing.

site_title: Why PR needs to be done differently for startups
summary: PR needs to be approached differently for startups, as the traditional corporate or established firm methods often won't work. The core essence of PR is establishing a mutual understanding between an organization and its audience, building credibility and attention from scratch. Startups must spread their story to attract users, establish trust, or garner investor attention, making PR a crucial tool for success. By understanding PR's core essence, startups can create a deliberate, planned, and sustained effort to establish a reputation with the public.

site_title: S'pore total market cap rises in November
summary: Singapore's total market capitalization rose 0.2% to S$1.016 trillion in November, driven by stellar performances from banking stocks OCBC Bank, United Overseas Bank, and DBS Group, which saw their market caps increase by 4.6%, 6.4%, and 7.2%, respectively. The rise in the Singapore Interbank Offered Rate (Sibor) and better-than-expected economic conditions also contributed to the growth. Analysts expect a more muted market in December, citing geopolitical uncertainties and the US Federal Reserve's outlook.

site_title: Opec signals oil supply cuts will be extended until end of 2018
summary: OPEC, led by Saudi Arabia, Iraq, and Iran, has agreed to extend oil production cuts until the end of 2018 to rebalance the global market. The deal, which currently expires in March, will be reviewed at the group's June meeting. Russia also supports the extension, which aims to finish the job of reducing oversupply. The move is seen as a positive step for the global economy, as it could help stabilize oil prices and boost investor confidence.

site_title: Pan Ocean bags US$1.8b contract to transport iron ore
summary: Pan Ocean Co has secured a 27-year, US$1.8 billion contract with Brazilian mining giant Vale International to transport iron ore. The contract will begin in 2020 and is aimed at securing a stable source of revenue and profit. The company is investing in building six very large ore carriers to secure long-term cargo contracts. Pan Ocean's earnings rose 57.6% to US$37.4 million in the third quarter, driven by higher demand for iron ore and coal in China.

site_title: Australian shares rise tracking Wall Street; NZ up marginally
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to a record high, tracking Wall Street's gains, with the energy sector up 1.7% and healthcare up 1.3%. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5989.8, while the benchmark rose 0.1% for the week, its fourth week of gains in five. The Australian government's royal commission into the financial sector did not deter investors, with the financials sector rising marginally. In New Zealand, the S&P/NZX 50 index rose marginally, driven by gains in the Industrials and utilities sectors.

site_title: Unclaimed land in Japan reaches size of Denmark
summary: Japan's unclaimed land, equivalent to the size of Denmark, is expected to worsen due to the nation's aging population and increasing number of deaths. About 11% of Japan's landmass is now unclear, costing the nation roughly 6 trillion yen ($72.1 billion) by 2040. Land registries not being updated after someone dies makes it impossible to track down heirs, leading to unclaimed or abandoned land. Experts warn that by 2040, land equivalent to Japan's second-largest island of Hokkaido will be unclaimed, further exacerbating the issue.

site_title: Avis tests fully connected wireless car fleet in Kansas City
summary: Avis Budget Group Inc has launched its first fully connected car fleet in Kansas City, Missouri, with 5,000 vehicles sharing live data with the city to enhance traffic flow models and improve tourist experiences. The company aims to automate manual processes and manage its entire vehicle life cycle through wireless technology. This move is part of its goal to develop self-driving cars and follows a multi-year agreement with Waymo, Alphabet Inc's self-driving car unit, to manage its autonomous vehicle fleet.

site_title: Holland Rd plot to have dual office-residential use component
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a dual office/residential use component in the Holland Road site, allowing for interchangeable use without planning permission. The site, part of the second-half 2017 GLS Programme, has a maximum gross floor area of 59,715 sq m and can yield up to 570 residential units. The dual office/residential use units will be part of the site's commercial use component, with at least 60% of the total GFA allocated for residential use. Tenders for the site are expected to close on March 20, 2018, with forecasts ranging from S$1,200-S$1,900 psf ppr.

site_title: Australia's energy-intensive industries brace for possible summer power cuts
summary: Australia's energy-intensive industries, including mining giant BHP Billiton, are preparing for possible summer power cuts due to the country's reliance on wind power and old coal-fired plants. Despite assurances from the energy market operator that it has sufficient power reserves, including the world's biggest lithium-ion battery, companies are taking steps to mitigate potential disruptions. These measures come as the nation's energy grid faces increasing uncertainty, with the industry worried about the impact of any repeat of crippling blackouts that hit last summer.

site_title: Porsche unveils 'most powerful luxury sedan'
summary: Porsche unveiled the 2018 Panamera Hybrid Sport Turismo, a hatchback sedan with 680 total horsepower and 626 pound-feet of torque. The vehicle achieves 60 mph in 3.2 seconds and has a top speed of 192 mph. The hybrid boost strategy is inspired by the 918 Spyder roadster. The Sport Turismo Hybrid combines a 550-hp V8 engine with a 136-hp electric motor and can go 30 miles on electric power alone. Deliveries are set to begin next spring, with base models starting at $188,400.

site_title: HK private home prices hit record high for 12th straight month in October
summary: Hong Kong private home prices reached a record high for the 12th consecutive month in October, with a 0.53% increase from September and a 12.5% year-over-year gain. The surge is attributed to a supply and demand imbalance, posing a risk to the residential property market. Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam has pledged to increase land supply to rein in prices, which are deemed unaffordable for most ordinary people and threaten social stability.

site_title: Let our 13-year-old child have her own credit card
summary: A proposed plan to issue credit cards to 13-year-olds aims to teach them good financial habits by allowing them to experience the consequences of small-scale irresponsibility. The idea is to let children manage their own money, as early as possible, to help them develop conscientiousness and improve their financial outcomes. The credit cards would carry a low maximum credit limit and require timely repayments, with missing deadlines triggering consequences. Proponents believe this approach could be more effective than traditional in-classroom financial education and could benefit parents, policymakers, and the economy.

site_title: Singtel-backed Thai firm AIS targets tripling in fiber customers
summary: Advanced Info Service (AIS), a Singtel-backed Thai firm, aims to triple its fiber subscribers from 600,000 to 2 million in three years. AIS CEO Somchai Lertsutiwong stated the company's goal is to become the preferred platform for digital services, transforming itself from a mobile operator to a major player in fixed broadband by 2020.

site_title: Golden Energy and Resources shells out A$67 million for 10% of Aussie gold miner
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (GEAR) has agreed to invest A$67.86 million to acquire a 10% stake in Australian gold miner Westgold Resources Limited. The investment will be funded by GEAR's existing loan facility and internal resources. This strategic move aims to widen GEAR's coal-focused business to include counter-cyclical commodities. GEAR's CEO, Fuganto Widjaja, stated that the investment is a key step to expand the company's portfolio.

site_title: US consumer spending slows in October, inflation picking up
summary: US consumer spending slowed in October, rising 0.3% after a revised 0.9% increase in September. Underlying price pressures increased for the second straight month, suggesting a recent disinflationary trend has ended. The Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure, the personal consumption expenditures price index, rose 0.2% in October, undershooting the Fed's 2% target. This increase bolsters expectations of a rate hike next month, despite signs that recent weak inflation readings may reflect "transitory factors."

site_title: Ultimate travel and supertall skyscrapers in BT Weekend
summary: Singapore's affluent residents are seeking luxury travel experiences, driving the growth of high-end tour operators. Meanwhile, supertall skyscrapers are emerging globally, sparking debates about their impact. Other news includes Audi's new entry-level TT 1.8 coupe, the conclusion of the Formula One season, and various lifestyle and business articles.

site_title: No Signboard closes slightly higher on debut
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, closed at 29 Singapore cents on its debut, up from its IPO price of 28 cents per share. On its first day of trading, 76.8 million shares worth S$23.98 million changed hands.

site_title: Maybank's Q3 profit up 13%
summary: Maybank, Malaysia's largest lender by assets, reported a 13% rise in third-quarter profit to RM2.03 billion, driven by higher net interest income and improved Islamic banking performance. The bank's quarterly earnings exceeded analyst estimates. The recovery of Southeast Asia's economy has boosted the banking sector, following a slow 2016.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Financial news updates include US stocks opening lower due to a fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Companies such as Creative Technology and Grab have issued revenue and earnings growth warnings. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. In Singapore, OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, while MAS and PBOC are deepening cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks have rallied for a 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data. Additionally, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Aviation Oil (Singapore) Corp's chief operating officer Jean Teo Lang Lang has quit, effective January 22, 2018. She will be replaced by Chief Executive Meng Fanqiu, who will oversee the trading department, and Vice-President Zhang Xingbo, who will oversee the operations and aviation marketing departments. Lang Lang was appointed to her position in November 2011.

site_title: Mobius stays the course even as valuations soar
summary: Mark Mobius, executive chairman of Templeton Emerging Markets Group, believes emerging market valuations are high but undervalued, despite historical high valuations. The group has a turnover rate of 20-25% and sticks to fundamentals. Mobius notes that many tech companies are profitable and their trends can continue for a while, but warns of a potential digital crisis due to the adoption of cloud and blockchain technology. He also highlights the growth of emerging markets, China's rising importance, and the potential for premiumisation in consumer spending.

site_title: GEAR shells out A$68m for 10% in Aussie gold miner
summary: GEAR, an Indonesian coal miner, has invested A$67.86 million (S$69.29 million) for a 10% stake in Australian gold miner Westgold Resources Limited. This investment will give GEAR a significant presence in the gold mining industry and allow it to diversify its product portfolio. GEAR's CEO, Fuganto Widjaja, sees this move as a strategic step to expand the firm's business into counter-cyclical commodities. The deal will also grant GEAR the right to nominate a director for Westgold.

site_title: Amazon focuses on machine learning to beat cloud rivals
summary: Amazon unveiled new machine-learning tools, including automated decision-making and speech recognition algorithms, at its annual event in Las Vegas. The move aims to solidify its dominant position in the cloud-computing market, competing with Microsoft and Alphabet Inc. Amazon Web Services (AWS) chief executive Andy Jassy announced over 20 new functions, drawing 40,000 attendees. The tools are expected to enhance AWS's offerings and further establish the company's leadership in the fast-growing cloud market.

site_title: Venezuela seizes former oil bosses in graft purge -sources
summary: Venezuela authorities have detained former oil bosses Eulogio Del Pino and Nelson Martinez as part of a deepening anti-corruption purge. Both men held high-ranking positions at the oil ministry and state oil company PDVSA, and their detention is seen as a move by President Nicolas Maduro to sideline political rivals and consolidate power. The arrests follow the removal of another former oil czar, Rafael Ramirez, from his position at the United Nations, and come as the country struggles with under-investment and sliding oil output. The purge is expected to continue with a planned news conference by state prosecutor Tarek Saab.

site_title: Airbus technology head Eremenko leaves to join rival UTC
summary: Airbus technology head Paul Eremenko is leaving the company to join rival United Technologies Corp, a blow to Airbus as it tries to overhaul its strategy and win back business from Boeing. Eremenko, 36, was hired from Google two and a half years ago to foster innovation and radical thinking. His departure comes as Airbus continues to focus on digital technology to change the aircraft manufacturing process.

site_title: China pushing billions into Iranian economy as Western firms stall
summary: China is significantly investing in Iran's economy, with billions of dollars in Chinese-led projects, surpassing European competitors. The Chinese funding, part of Beijing's $124 billion Belt and Road initiative, includes railways, hospitals, and other infrastructure projects. Western firms, including those from Italy and South Korea, are struggling to secure financing due to the risk of sanctions. Iranian officials are seeking sovereign guarantees to protect investors, while also exploring alternative investment channels. China's aggressive investment is seen as a major shift in the region's economic landscape, with some warning that opportunities may be lost if European firms do not act quickly.

site_title: India sees growth rebound as businesses adjust to new tax
summary: India's economic growth rebounded to 6.3% in the July-September quarter, ending a five-quarter slide, as businesses adjusted to the new national sales tax. The tax, launched in July, had caused disruptions for small businesses due to complex rules and technical glitches. The rebound in growth is seen as a positive step for Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who has faced criticism over the tax's hasty introduction. Analysts expect faster growth in the current quarter and the following months, with some predicting annual growth of 6.7% and 7.5% respectively.

site_title: Best World to be added to MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index
summary: Best World International, a Singaporean company specializing in premium skincare and wellness products, has been added to the MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index. The index, which tracks the performance of 57 small-cap stocks in Singapore, includes Best World as of November 30, 2017. The company's shares closed at S$1.22 on the day, down 2.4%. Best World's CEO expressed optimism about the inclusion, citing it as a testament to the company's performance and a potential boost to attracting institutional investors.

site_title: SGX aims to strike a balance in review of dual-class shares
summary: SGX is reviewing dual-class share structures, a controversial concept that gives founders greater voting power and rights disproportionate to their shareholding. The exchange has received wide-ranging feedback, with diverging views on the issue. Chief executive Tan Boon Gin said the review aims to strike a balance between the interests of investors and companies. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Committee on the Future Economy have expressed support for the structure, which is favored by new-economy companies in the IT and biotech sectors, but has been criticized by shareholder advocates.

site_title: SPH Reit studying overseas markets such as Australia for future acquisitions
summary: SPH Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, has been searching for suitable overseas assets for two years but has yet to find any suitable acquisitions. The trust has looked at markets like Australia but has not found a suitable asset. Its management considers factors such as infrastructure tax, retail business environment, and foreign exchange when evaluating potential acquisitions. Despite stable and regular dividends, the trust's share price has been slow to rise, and the company's focus on yield accretion makes acquisitions challenging.

site_title: Lower unemployment among PMETs; monthly income of average worker up: MOM
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower released its annual labour force survey, showing a smaller proportion of professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs) are jobless, with their unemployment rate dipping to 3% from 3.1% last year. The median monthly income for residents in full-time jobs increased by 4.3% to S$4,232, with real income growth at 3.7%. Demand for non-PMET workers remains lower, but overall, the monthly income of the average worker has gone up.

site_title: Lighting up SGIFF with star power
summary: The 28th Singapore International Film Festival (SGIFF) kicked off last Friday with a star-studded lineup, featuring directors Vivian Qu and Daisuke Miyazaki, actress Waheeda Rehman, and cinematographer Christopher Doyle. The festival showcased films such as Angels Wear White, The Great Buddha+, and The White Girl, which won several awards at the Golden Horse Awards. Ex-England national David Beckham made a special appearance at the SGIFF Benefit Dinner, while Japanese director Atsuko Hirayanagi premiered her film Oh Lucy!. The festival runs through this weekend, concluding on December 3.

images.alt_text: David Beckham was invited by Marina Bay Sands to make a special appearance at the SGIFF Benefit Dinner on Saturday.
Model-actress Angela Yuen at The White Girl screening at Capitol Theatre.
Angels Wear White director Vivian Qu and actress Zhou Meijun.

site_title: Market capitalisation
summary: US stocks open lower amid President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warns H2 revenue may be below target, with similar operating loss to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks experience a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and MAS and PBOC to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Alibaba sells US$7b bonds
summary: Alibaba Group Holding sold $7 billion in bonds, the largest sale in Asia from a non-bank issuer, surpassing China Evergrande Group's $6.6 billion offering. The 30-year bond rose to 101.2 cents on the dollar, and investors ordered $46 billion worth of bonds. This deal marks Alibaba's first bond sale in three years and is the longest maturity on record from a Chinese corporate issuer, with yields starting at 4.2%. The sale eclipses previous records and demonstrates the market's demand for high-quality issuers like Alibaba.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's consumer staples and food retailers may see minimal impact from a potential Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike, as consumers may opt for brick-and-mortar supermarkets over online vendors. Dairy Farm and Sheng Siong are expected to be less affected, while BreadTalk and Neo Group's food retail business may see a slight decline. On the other hand, Raffles Medical's hospital services segment may be less competitive due to higher costs.

site_title: IT flaw leaves American Airlines with too few pilots
summary: American Airlines is struggling to resolve a scheduling flaw that has left over 15,000 flights without sufficient pilots during the holiday rush. The glitch, which affects flights from Dec 17 to Dec 31, has been attributed to a computer-system problem that showed the airline had ample staffing coverage when it didn't. The airline is working to correct the issue, offering pilots 1.5 times their normal hourly wage to pick up some flights, and expects to avoid cancellations. The union has filed a grievance, citing a potential violation of its labor pact, and is seeking a remedy that would motivate pilots to give up vacation time.

site_title: French hospital auctions off good wines for charity
summary: The Hospices de Beaune Auction took place on November 19 in Beaune, France, as part of a weekend of charity events. The auction featured 85% of the Domaine's wine, including First Growths and Great Growths, from prestigious vineyards in Burgundy. The wine is produced by the Hospices de Beaune, a hospital caring for the sick and elderly, and is donated by local vineyards. The auction was overseen by Christie's and attracted a global audience, with visitors bidding on barrels of young wine to be matured over the next 12-18 months. The event raised funds for the hospital and supported the production of high-quality wines.

site_title: Credit Suisse targets 50% payout plan as turnaround quickens
summary: Credit Suisse aims to return 50% of its net income to shareholders through buybacks or special dividends in the next two years, as part of its turnaround strategy. The bank has confirmed its 2018 profit targets for key divisions and expects to achieve a cost base of 16.5 billion francs to 17 billion francs for 2019 and 2020. Credit Suisse also plans to implement cost-saving measures through technology, with incremental annual productivity gains of 600 million francs to 800 million francs.

site_title: US threatens to 'utterly destroy' North Korean regime
summary: The US has warned North Korea that it will be "utterly destroyed" if war breaks out, amid tensions following the launch of an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM). The US called for nations to cut ties with Pyongyang, but Russia rejected the proposal, saying sanctions have been exhausted. China, which has backed sanctions, sidestepped the US call for an oil embargo, and Beijing has proposed a freeze of US military exercises in exchange for a halt in North Korean missile and nuclear tests.

site_title: BRC Asia to resume trading on Dec 1 after free float restored
