summary: BRC Asia's shares will resume trading on Dec 1 after its free float was restored to 10% following a takeover bid by Esteel Enterprise. Esteel, a Chinese investment vehicle, initially held 95.83% of the firm but disposed of 12.86 million shares to six independent buyers at 95 Singapore cents a share, reducing its stake to 89.61%. Esteel had intended to keep BRC Asia listed, but now retains the right to revisit this plan if the public float falls below 10%.

site_title: Oil edges up as Opec signals deal extension
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday as an Opec-led meeting in Vienna signaled a likely extension of current crude output curbs until the end of 2018, bolstering prices by 40% since the middle of the year. Opec members suggested a nine-month extension, which could draw out the deal until the end of next year, stabilizing the market. US light crude for February delivery rose 60 cents to $57.96 a barrel, while Brent crude traded 77 cents up at $63.30 a barrel.

site_title: Jason Holdings completes scheme of arrangement
summary: Jason Holdings, a flooring firm, has completed its scheme of arrangement on October 17, 2017. The move was to restructure debts owed to unsecured creditors, following issues with its operations and multiple claims made against the company. Payment to participating creditors was made in accordance with the scheme, constituting a full and final settlement of all liabilities. The completion of the scheme marks a resolution for the company.

site_title: Court gives nod to Marco Polo's debt revamp schemes
summary: Singapore's High Court sanctioned two schemes of arrangement for Marco Polo Marine, extending green light to the first debt restructuring plan with direct haircuts in the offshore and marine sector. The plan, supported by DBS, OCBC, and UOB, tables 69% haircut on S$202 million bank loans. This is the first debt restructuring plan with direct haircuts in the sector, allowing Marco Polo Marine to restructure its debt and avoid insolvency.

site_title: Trump hits out at UK's May over criticism of sharing far right videos
summary: US President Donald Trump retweeted anti-Islam videos posted by Britain First leader Jayda Fransen, sparking criticism from British Prime Minister Theresa May and US Muslim groups. Trump defended the retweets as a means to raise security issues, despite the videos' unverified content. May's spokesman called it "wrong" and British lawmakers demanded an apology. The White House cited the need to prevent individuals posing a public safety threat. Trump's tweets were widely condemned, with many accusing him of promoting far-right ideology.

site_title: 122 to play in 12-hour piano marathon
summary: STEINWAY Gallery Singapore is hosting its first piano marathon on Dec 16, featuring 122 pianists playing non-stop for 12 hours to raise funds for The Business Times Budding Artists Fund. The pianists will play a curated selection of songs across various genres, including classical, jazz, and pop. The event aims to ensure a smooth transition between genres and will take place at ION Orchard Level 1 Atrium.

site_title: Small eurozone inflation rise matches ECB expectations of coming dip
summary: Eurozone inflation rose to 1.5% in November, below expectations of 1.6%, but core inflation remained steady at 1.1%. The European Central Bank expects inflation to dip around the turn of the year, with projections suggesting it will fall below 1% in the coming months. The ECB has used its arsenal to revive growth, but some argue that weak price pressures are becoming a global phenomenon beyond individual central banks' control, making further stimulus less effective.

site_title: Malaysian panel urges criminal probe of Mahathir, Anwar over forex losses
summary: A Malaysian inquiry panel recommended a criminal investigation into former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and his former deputy Anwar Ibrahim over alleged forex losses of up to 30 billion ringgit (S$9.89 billion) in the 1990s. The investigation may help Prime Minister Najib Razak deflect opposition accusations about his role in the missing billions from state fund 1MDB. Mahathir and Anwar may face charges of breach of trust and cheating. The move comes ahead of national polls that must be called by August next year.

site_title: Independent director resigns from Raffles Education; placement proceeds fully spent
summary: Independent director Christopher Lim Tien Lock has resigned from Raffles Education's board, effective December 1. Lim, who has been on the board since 2008, is also relinquishing directorships in unrelated companies, including Hotel Properties, where he serves as group executive director. The resignation comes at a time when placement proceeds for Raffles Education are fully spent.

site_title: Opec signals oil supply cuts will be extended until end of 2018
summary: OPEC's top producers, including Saudi Arabia, Iraq, and Iran, agreed to extend oil production cuts until the end of 2018 to rebalance the market. The current deal, which includes 10 non-member countries, will continue for another nine months beyond its March 2018 expiry. The decision was made at OPEC's meeting in Vienna, with Russia also supporting the extension. The group will review the deal in June 2018 and adjust accordingly.

site_title: Manulife US Reit manager issues 1.85m units to Manufacturers Life Reinsurance
summary: Manulife US Reit's manager issued 1.85 million units to Manufacturers Life Reinsurance Limited, including 1.26 million units as payment of the base fee and 591,384 units as payment of property management fees. The units were issued at a price based on the higher of the volume weighted average price and the Reit's closing unit price. The total number of Manulife US Reit units in issue now stands at 1.034 billion.

site_title: William Tan Seng Koon joins SembMarine's executive committee
summary: SEMBCORP Marine has appointed William Tan Seng Koon as a new member of its executive committee, effective December 1. The committee will consist of four independent directors, including Tan, along with other executives. Tan has over 40 years of corporate experience, previously holding senior management positions at Singapore Airlines and SIA Engineering Company. The composition of other committees remains unchanged, according to the company's filing to the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: SIIC acquires two water treatment plans in Dalian for 205 million yuan
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings has agreed to buy two water treatment plans in Dalian, China for 205.48 million yuan. The company will acquire 52% interest in Dalian Ziguang Water Treatment Co Ltd and 55% interest in Dalian Ziguang Lingshui Waste Water Treatment Co for 108.48 million yuan and 97 million yuan respectively. The acquisitions are part of the expansion of capacity from 80,000 tonnes to 90,000 tonnes and from 60,000 tonnes to 80,000 tonnes per day, and upgrading the water treatment projects from grade 1B to grade 1A.

site_title: Australia to hold inquiry into finance sector after years of pressure
summary: The Australian government announced a year-long Royal Commission into the finance sector, citing mounting pressure and public outrage over scandals involving banks, pension funds, and insurers. The inquiry will examine conduct that "falls below community standards and expectations" and has the power to recommend criminal charges. The move is seen as a response to public uncertainty and erosion of confidence in the financial system, with the government citing the potential for the inquiry to be more embarrassing for the industry than regular parliamentary questioning. The commission must report back by February 2019.

site_title: Sarine Tech rises 5% after block trade
summary: Sarine Tech, an Israeli diamond processing systems seller, saw its stock rise 5.2% after a block trade of 29 million shares at S$0.97. The counter has slumped 50% this year, reporting a net loss of US$530,000 for the three months ended Sep 30, 2017. Revenue fell 35% to US$11.3 million due to high inventories and reduced spending.

site_title: US: Dow opens above 24,000 for first time
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average opened above 24,000 for the first time, driven by a rebound in technology stocks and progress on President Trump's tax-cut plan. The Dow rose 95.62 points, or 0.4%, to 24,036.3. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 reaching a fresh record and the Nasdaq edging past $6,800. The market's resilience was seen as a sign of investor confidence despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: BOE's Carney hints at scrapping banker bonus cap after Brexit
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney hinted that the UK may scrap the cap on banker bonuses after Brexit, stating that the cap is "not necessary" and would be reviewed to maintain high standards in the financial services industry. The UK and EU negotiators reached an outline deal on the Brexit divorce bill, clearing a key hurdle in discussions.

site_title: Malaysia defends tourism role for 'biting' Suarez
summary: Malaysia has defended its decision to sign Luis Suarez, a notorious football player known for biting rivals, as part of a one-year tourism marketing deal. Opposition MP Hee Loy Sian questioned the choice, citing Suarez's controversial track record, but Tourism Minister Nazri Abdul Aziz argued that Suarez's large social media following would attract more foreign visitors. The deal aims to boost tourism in Malaysia, which received almost 27 million visitors last year.

site_title: How do you advertise to a machine? Big oil is seeking the answer
summary: Big oil companies, including BP, are reassessing their markets as electric driverless cars and technologies like hydrogen fuel-cell technology upend energy markets. The industry faces existential questions over the future of diesel fuel and is seeking ways to advertise to machines, such as electric vehicles. Companies like Royal Dutch Shell have signed deals with automakers to expand electric vehicle offerings, while BP is studying ways to participate in the electrification of transport. The proliferation of driverless cars may require oil companies to rethink their marketing strategies.

site_title: Marco Polo gets green light from Singapore court for debt restructuring
summary: Marco Polo Marine has received approval from the Singapore High Court for its debt restructuring plan, which involves forgiving S$258 million in debts and injecting S$60 million in new equity. This move is seen as a significant step in the company's deleveraging efforts, marking what may be the first debt restructuring exercise amid the current downturn.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.2% down on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks closed 0.2% lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index falling 5.45 points to 3,433.54. About 2.87 billion shares changed hands, with Allied Tech rising S$0.012 to S$0.084. Losers outnumbered gainers 287 to 175, indicating a mixed market.

site_title: Europe: London stock market drops at open, eurozone steady
summary: London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.3% to 7,369.55 points at open on Thursday, while eurozone shares steadied. Oil prices gained ahead of OPEC's decision on crude output levels. Analysts attribute the European market's underperformance to the decline in the US dollar, which has strengthened the euro and pound.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Thursday, down 2.52 points to 1,717.86. The index saw a volume of 2.47 billion shares worth RM6 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 500 to 367.

site_title: Outgoing StarHub CEO reduces stake in telco from 0.08% to 0.03%
summary: Outgoing StarHub CEO Tan Tong Hai reduced his stake in the telco from 0.0828% to 0.0307% through two market transactions on Tuesday, selling 600,000 and 300,000 shares for S$2.55 million. The transactions occurred on the same day as the company's earnings release, which saw revenue potentially below target.

site_title: Lloyds Bank settles with couple hit by HBOS fraud
summary: Lloyds Banking Group has reached a settlement with Paul and Nikki Turner, a couple who uncovered a major financial fraud at the Reading branch of its HBOS unit, after it destroyed their business. The couple, who campaigned tirelessly for justice for victims, will receive compensation without disclosing the financial terms. Lloyds acknowledges their "vital role" in exposing the criminal conduct and apologizes for the "significant personal distress" they suffered.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) warned of potential risks in the property market due to recent market developments, including the en-bloc rage and rising land prices. Singapore's total bank lending in October rose 1.4% from September. A study by MAS found that Singapore banks could lose up to 5% of their operating income if they fail to adapt to fintech disruption. Meanwhile, the job market showed signs of improvement, with lower unemployment rates among professionals and managers, and rising incomes.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall sharply as tech shares plunge
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted on Thursday, with the Hang Seng index falling 1.51% to 29,177.35, amid fears that the demand for electronic components has peaked. The decline was largely driven by tech shares, with China's Shanghai Composite index also falling 0.61%. The slump reflects regional concerns about the market's future growth.

site_title: In US, 57% of kids on track for obesity by 35: study
summary: A US study warns that over 57% of American children will be obese by age 35 if current trends continue. Researchers at Harvard University used a simulation model to predict future trends based on height and weight data from over 41,000 children and adults. The study highlights the importance of prevention efforts and early interventions for children with obesity to minimize their risk of serious illness. Obesity is linked to increased risks of diabetes, heart disease, and cancer, with annual medical costs exceeding $147 billion in the US.

site_title: New committee to set doctors' fee benchmarks for greater transparency
summary: Singapore is introducing fee benchmarks for doctors' charges in common surgical procedures, aiming for greater transparency in healthcare costs. A new independent committee will be appointed in early 2018 to set benchmarks, which will be reviewed periodically. The goal is to help doctors set reasonable fees and manage healthcare costs sustainably. The move is part of the government's efforts to address rising healthcare costs, driven by a rapidly aging population and advancements in medical technology.

site_title: US dollar poised for monthly loss, Brexit deal hopes lift sterling
summary: The US dollar is poised for a monthly loss against a basket of currencies due to uncertainty over US tax reform legislation. However, the pound sterling gained 0.5% to its highest since September 26 on optimism about a Brexit accord. The US dollar index held steady at 93.151, while the pound rose to US$1.3471, up 1.4% for the month. This follows recent economic data, including China's expected slowdown in GDP growth and the PBOC adviser's call for a 1.5 trillion yuan stimulus to counter US tariffs.

images.alt_text: The US dollar held steady on Thursday but was set for a monthly loss against a basket of currencies as investors warily watch progress on US tax reform legislation, while sterling stood tall on optimism a Brexit accord would be reached.

site_title: Cosco Shipping Ports to add new berth to its joint venture container terminal with PSA
summary: Cosco Shipping Ports is launching a new berth at its joint venture container terminal with PSA in Singapore, increasing the terminal's capacity to three million twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs) per year. The new berth, which will begin operations on January 1, 2018, will be supported by an automated yard to enhance productivity and service quality. The addition is aimed at meeting new requirements from shipping alliances and mega-vessels, and further solidifies Singapore's role as a pivotal regional maritime hub.

site_title: Ex-managing director to pay S$423,000 penalty for insider trading
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has taken action against former CSE Global managing director Tarek Abdel Tawab Mohamed Abdel Bary for insider trading. Bary agreed to a S$423,000 civil penalty and will also pay S$61,457.90 in legal costs. He admitted to selling 500,000 CSE Global shares in 2011 while possessing non-public, price-sensitive information about cost overruns in Saudi projects. The sale avoided a loss of S$168,955. Bary has also given a two-year undertaking not to be a company director.

site_title: UK consumer sentiment sinks to 16-month low, house prices weak
summary: British consumer sentiment has dropped to a 16-month low, reaching -12 in November, according to a GfK survey. Business morale has also softened, with a decline in economic optimism. House price growth slowed in November, and households' willingness to make big purchases fell to its lowest level since 2014. The decline in consumer confidence and business morale is attributed to economic uncertainty, higher inflation, and interest rate hikes. The Bank of England's rate hike has further dampened consumer mood, and the UK economy is expected to slow down in 2018.

site_title: Australia's Fortescue appoints new CEO, looks beyond iron ore
summary: Fortescue Metals Group, Australia's fourth-largest iron ore producer, appointed CFO Elizabeth Gaines as its new CEO and mine manager Julie Shuttleworth as deputy CEO. The company, led by founder and chairman Andrew Forrest, is shifting its focus beyond iron ore mining for growth. Forrest aims to leverage the company's gains in seaborne shipping and logistics to expand into new businesses, driven by a drive to pay off debt and reduce costs. The move is seen as a significant step towards diversification in the mining industry.

site_title: UK house price growth weaker than expected in November: Nationwide
summary: UK house prices rose 2.5% year-over-year, unchanged from October's pace, according to Nationwide. The median forecast of 2.7% was not met, with prices increasing 0.1% on the month, a slowdown from October's 0.2%. This weaker growth follows the Brexit vote's impact on the UK property market.

images.alt_text: British house price growth, which has slowed since last year's Brexit vote, was weaker than expected in November, according to figures published by mortgage lender Nationwide on Thursday.

site_title: Amazon focuses on machine learning to beat cloud rivals
summary: Amazon unveiled new machine-learning tools, including SageMaker and AWS DeepLens, to solidify its position in the cloud-computing market. The tools aim to make machine learning more accessible to developers, while Microsoft and Alphabet's Google compete with their own AI and machine learning capabilities. Amazon's cloud division, AWS, brought in a record $12.2 billion in revenue last year and is expected to grow to $89 billion by 2021. The company's focus on machine learning further evolves its cloud-computing services, providing tools for developers to use data in new ways and stay competitive in the market.

site_title: Cushman & Wakefield names Matthew Bouw Asia-Pacific CEO
summary: Cushman & Wakefield has appointed Matthew Bouw as its Asia-Pacific CEO, effective Dec 1. Bouw, an Australian, has worked for the firm for over six-and-a-half years and previously served as global chief administrative officer. He will lead a team of over 7,000 employees across nine regional markets, with Brett White describing the Asia-Pacific as a "critical growth region" for the company. Bouw aims to deliver the best services and solutions that meet clients' expectations, focusing on building a business that prioritizes clients.

site_title: As many go ga-ga over royal engagement, China asks: Harry who?
summary: Prince Harry's marriage to US actress Meghan Markle in May has generated significant international attention, but its impact in China is limited. Only three out of 10 people in Shanghai were able to recognize Prince Harry, while none could name his fiancée. State media in China briefly covered the news, but it was overshadowed by reports on Chinese President Xi Jinping's calls to improve the country's toilets. The lack of interest in Harry's engagement highlights the relative obscurity of the British royal family in China.

site_title: Gold holds near one-week low as stronger US economy data weighs
summary: Gold prices held near a one-week low due to stronger-than-expected US economic data and Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's positive outlook on the economy. Despite a subdued session, gold is heading for its first monthly gain since August. Higher US interest rates are expected to keep pressure on gold prices, while investors seek returns in assets other than non-interest-bearing bullion.

images.alt_text: Gold on Thursday held close to a one-week low hit in the previous session, pressured by upbeat US growth data for the third quarter and Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen's bullish view of the economy.

site_title: URA launches plum Holland Rd site on confirmed list
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched the tender for a commercial and residential site in Holland Road, with a maximum gross floor area of 59,715 square meters. The site can yield up to 13,500 sq m for retail use and 570 residential units. The tender will close on March 20, 2018. Additionally, the URA has launched tenders for two private housing sites in Dhoby Ghaut and Chong Kuo Road, and an executive condominium site at Sumang Walk, with potential yields of up to 1,720 residential units.

site_title: Australia industry prepares for possible summer power cuts
summary: Australia's power users, including mining giant BHP, are taking measures to prepare for possible summer power cuts due to high demand and reliance on wind power. Despite assurances from the energy market operator, the nation is forecast to experience hotter-than-normal temperatures, which could lead to a repeat of outages in South Australia and New South Wales. Top miners, such as BHP and Alcoa, are installing back-up power generation systems to prevent asset damage and ensure continuity of operations. The risk of blackouts remains, but analysts believe it is less likely to occur this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on weaker yen
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.57% and the Topix index rising 0.33%. A weak yen boosted Japanese exporters, contributing to the gains.

site_title: Avis tests fully connected wireless car fleet in Kansas City
summary: Avis Budget Group Inc launched its first fleet of fully connected cars in Kansas City, Missouri, with 5,000 vehicles linked to the internet and centralised network. The "connected car" enables automation of manual processes, improving fleet-management services. The connected cars will share live data with the city to enhance traffic flow models and improve tourist experiences. Avis aims to sharpen computerised traffic flow models and collaborate with the city to enhance tourist experiences through its Mobility Lab.

site_title: Japan emperor to cede all public duties after abdication: Prince Akishino
summary: Japan's Emperor Akihito, 84, will cede all public duties after his abdication in 2019, marking the country's first abdication in nearly two centuries. This decision was made by his heir, Crown Prince Naruhito, and his brother, Prince Akishino, to ensure the symbolic status of the next emperor remains unchanged. A special panel will discuss possible dates for the abdication, which is expected to take place in 2019.

site_title: Financials weigh on Australia shares after inquiry announced; NZ rises
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% on Thursday, weighed down by financials amid an inquiry into the banking sector, and resources stocks as metal prices declined. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5969.9, while the Aussie financial index slipped 0.8%. Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group fell nearly 2% and 1.1% respectively. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.6% as the consumer sector led gains.

site_title: Tech stock slide spreads to Asia; Korean won drops
summary: US technology stocks slid, affecting Asia's markets, with the Korean won dropping after the Bank of Korea raised interest rates for the first time in over six years. Hong Kong and South Korean-listed shares fell, while Japan's edged lower. Optimism about Brexit talks and tax legislation boosted the pound, while Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse warn that the prolonged bull market may be nearing its end.

site_title: Singapore banks could lose 5% of operating income from disruption: MAS study
summary: Singapore banks could lose up to 5% of their operating income if they fail to address fintech disruption, according to a Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) study. The potential reduction in operating income primarily comes from disintermediation in the payments space, with cost savings from leveraging fintech technology estimated at 10-20% of Asian banks' operating income. Conversely, banks that adopt a digital model successfully could perform better compared to those that do not.

site_title: Dying alone in Tokyo, the world's most populous city
summary: A growing trend in ageing Japan, "Kodokushi" or "dying alone," has claimed a victim in Tokyo, where a dead man lay decomposing for three weeks without anyone noticing. Experts estimate 30,000 people die alone annually, with many factors contributing to the problem, including Japan's aging population, shrinking family sizes, and cultural tendency to prioritize family over neighbors. To address the issue, experts advocate for increased social care and financial assistance for the elderly, warning that inaction could lead to more solitary deaths.

site_title: Yio Chu Kang freehold site The Stradia up for en bloc sale with S$22m reserve price
summary: A mixed development site, The Stradia, located at 78 Yio Chu Kang Road, Singapore, has been launched for en bloc sale with a reserve price of around S$22 million. The 8,241 square feet site has a gross plot ratio of 3.0 and is freehold. The successful bidder will have the opportunity to re-develop the site with an adjoining remnant state land plot, subject to approval. The tender closes on January 10, 2018, and is considered suitable for budding boutique developers.

site_title: Singapore shares resume down on Thursday afternoon; STI at 3,426.73
summary: Singapore shares resumed trading lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,426.73, down 12.26 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 239 to 131, with 1.3 billion shares worth S$1.15 billion traded.

site_title: Seoul: Won tumbles as markets trim rate hike views, stocks at 6-week low
summary: South Korea's won plummeted 1.1% against the US dollar as investors reassessed the Bank of Korea's interest rate hike, tempering expectations for further domestic rate hikes. The won reached a six-week low, while shares dropped 1.5% on the Kospi index, its lowest level since October 19. Tech stocks were particularly affected, with Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix experiencing significant losses. The won had gained 3% in November, its largest monthly rise since January, following initial expectations of a rate hike.

site_title: Maybank's Q3 profit up 13%, helped by Islamic banking business
summary: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank), Malaysia's largest lender, reported a 13% rise in Q3 profit to RM2.03 billion, driven by higher net interest income and improved Islamic banking performance. The quarterly growth was ahead of estimates, contributing to a turnaround in the country's economy, which posted a 6.2% GDP growth in the September quarter. This follows a slow 2016, and comes after CIMB Group Holdings reported a surprise quarterly profit rise earlier this week.

site_title: GLP privatisation bid gets shareholders' nod
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) shareholders have approved Nesta Investment Holdings' proposed privatisation bid, with 96.02% of present shareholders voting in favor. The bid, valued at S$3.38 per share in cash, has received support from Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC and GLP's CEO Ming Z Mei, who is a director of Nesta. The scheme is expected to be presented to the High Court of Singapore for approval, with the payment date set for January 19, 2018.

site_title: Cromwell European Reit opens unchanged at trading debut
summary: Cromwell European Reit (CEReit) opened flat at 0.55 euros per unit on its trading debut on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on November 30, 2017. The Reit's manager offered 428.5 million units to raise 866 million euros, with a focus on European office and light industrial/logistics properties. The listing brings the total number of SGX-listed Reits to 43, with a combined market capitalisation of S$88 billion. CEReit aims to provide investors with access to improving European markets and a geographically diverse portfolio.

site_title: Pink diamond gets US$32m, Patek sets Asian record
summary: A 14.93-carat pink diamond ring sold for about US$32 million at Christie's in Hong Kong, below the estimated US$42 million. The sale follows a choppy auction season in Geneva, where a 37-carat Raj Pink diamond failed to sell. Meanwhile, a vintage Patek Philippe wristwatch set a record auction price for a wristwatch in Asia, although the article does not specify the price.

site_title: Flights resume as Bali's volcano-hit airport reopens
summary: Bali's volcano-hit airport reopened on Wednesday, allowing flights to resume after a nearly three-day shutdown due to Mount Agung's increased activity. Over 4,500 people have flown out of the airport, and domestic carriers Garuda and AirAsia have resumed flights. However, the nearby Lombok island airport closed again due to ash and smoke drifting in its direction. Authorities urge caution, warning a major eruption could happen at any moment, and tens of thousands of tourists are expected to leave the island if the volcano erupts.

site_title: Alibaba draws US$46b of demand for US$7b bond sale
summary: Alibaba Group Holding sold US$7 billion in bonds, exceeding demand of US$46 billion, in the largest US dollar-denominated bond sale by a non-bank issuer in Asia. The 30-year bond, priced at 4.2%, rose to 101.2 cents on the dollar in after-market trading. This sale eclipses China Evergrande Group's US$6.6 billion offering in June, making it the largest Asian non-bank bond sale. Alibaba's long-term funding is seen as a sign of the company's financial stability, with experts noting that it can afford to pay a premium for longer-dated funding.

site_title: MAS flags risks from 'excessive exuberance' in property market
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has flagged risks in the property market due to "excessive exuberance" and potential supply-demand imbalances. The MAS warns that the rapid development of new housing units, exceeding 20,000 units in the next 1-2 years, may not be fully absorbed by the market, leading to downward pressure on prices and rentals. The central bank urges developers to factor in increased private housing stock and buyers to consider the subdued rental market and rising interest rates, which could impact debt servicing.

site_title: Aspen Group to acquire Selangor industrial land for RM190m
summary: Aspen Group Holdings has entered into a sales and purchase agreement to acquire 71 acres of industrial land in Shah Alam, Selangor, Malaysia for RM190 million. The group plans to develop the land into a sustainable integrated logistics hub with warehouses, offices, and e-commerce services. The acquisition will increase the group's landbank to 334 acres, and the master plan is expected to be finalized soon, determining the gross development value. Aspen Group aims to create a world-class logistics hub with advanced intelligent services, catering to local and international players.

site_title: China Aviation Oil COO quits to pursue other opportunities
summary: China Aviation Oil Corp's chief operating officer Jean Teo Lang Lang has quit to pursue other career opportunities, effective January 22, 2018. She was appointed COO in November 2011. In her place, CEO Meng Fanqiu will oversee the trading department, while vice-president Zhang Xingbo will oversee operations and aviation marketing. Zhang will also assist in overseeing the trading department.

site_title: Apple, Qualcomm trade new patent-infringement allegations
summary: Apple and Qualcomm have exchanged patent-infringement allegations, escalating their billion-dollar royalty dispute. Apple claims Qualcomm's Snapdragon processors infringe eight patents controlling mobile device power management, while Qualcomm alleges Apple infringes 16 patents covering a broad range of technologies. The dispute centers on royalties and the value of fundamental technology in mobile devices, with the European Union developing guidelines to curb the lawsuits. Both companies are trying to inflict financial pain on each other, with courts in the US, Europe, and China involved in the bitter battle.

images.alt_text: Apple alleged Wednesday in court filings that Qualcomm is using the iPhone maker's patented technology for extending battery life, opening a new front in the royalty battle between the two technology behemoths.

site_title: Lower unemployment among PMETs, incomes rose at faster pace this year: MOM
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower reported lower unemployment rates among Professionals, Managers, Executives, and Technicians (PMETs), with an unemployment rate of 3% in 2017, down from 3.1% in 2016. Median incomes for PMETs rose 4.3% to S$4,232, with real median monthly income increasing 3.7% after inflation. Non-PMETs faced higher unemployment rates, while lower-wage workers saw a faster pace of income growth due to initiatives like the progressive wage model.

site_title: Africa's biggest firm Naspers eyes growth in food delivery to cut value gap with Tencent
summary: Naspers, Africa's largest firm, plans to invest in food delivery businesses to narrow the valuation gap with its 33% stake in Tencent, worth $166 billion. Naspers is valued at $123 billion, with CFO Basil Sgourdos stating there's no reason for a discount at this "unusually high level." The company aims to scale its other businesses, including e-commerce, to reverse the valuation gap.

images.alt_text: Naspers Ltd is planning to invest more in businesses including food delivery to help narrow the valuation gap between Africa's biggest company and its stake in Chinese Internet giant Tencent Holdings Ltd.

site_title: The man with a young woman's heart
summary: Christiaan Barnard successfully transplanted the heart of a 25-year-old woman, Denise Darvall, into a terminally ill man, Louis Washkansky, on December 3, 1967, in Cape Town, South Africa. The operation was a groundbreaking first in human-to-human heart transplantation, with Washkansky surviving for 18 days post-transplant before dying from pneumonia. Barnard's achievement made him an overnight sensation, and he went on to become a world-renowned pioneer of modern medicine, embarking on a world tour to share his pioneering work.

site_title: South Korea raises interest rate for first time in six years
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, raised its benchmark interest rate to 1.5% for the first time in over six years, ending 16 months of rate freezes. The move is seen as a sign of the country's robust economic recovery, with the IMF predicting 3.2% GDP growth for 2017. The decision comes despite concerns over North Korea's nuclear threat. Economists expect further rate hikes in the coming year, but warn that aggressive tightening could harm indebted households. The rate hike is the first in Asia since 2014.

site_title: Snapchat redesign keeps it personal
summary: Snapchat has unveiled a redesign aimed at boosting user engagement by focusing on personal interests rather than friends' posts. The redesign features separate streams for close friend messages and publisher content, relying on algorithms based on individual users' interests. The change is intended to combat fake news and provide a more user-friendly experience, while also helping publishers monetize their content. The redesign comes as Snapchat reported a widening loss and user numbers that fell short of market expectations in its latest earnings report.

site_title: Broker's take: APAC Realty earns 'buy' from RHB on initial coverage
summary: APAC Realty has received a "buy" recommendation from RHB Research with a target price of S$1.20, based on a discounted cash flow valuation and 15 times price-to-earnings ratio. The broker cites strong residential sales, a growing pipeline of projects, and an attractive dividend yield of 4.4%. RHB forecasts Singapore's residential market will drive APAC Realty's growth, with the company expected to pay out at least 50% of after-tax net profits as dividends. The stock is trading at S$0.895, up 1.13% from its 52-week low.

site_title: Pan Ocean inks long term voyage contract for iron ore, investing 483b won in 6 new carriers
summary: Pan Ocean Co. signed a 27-year contract with Vale International SA for the transportation of Brazilian iron ore, valued at approximately US$1.8 billion. The contract starts in 2020 and aims to secure a stable source of revenue. The company is also investing 483 billion Korean Won (around S$600 million) in six new carriers to secure long-term cargo contracts.

site_title: Australia dollar lifted by upbeat economic news, NZ$ bruised
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.2% to US$0.7583, boosted by stronger-than-expected economic data at home and from top trading partner China. China's manufacturing activity survey firmed to 51.8 in November, marking the 16th straight month of expansion. Meanwhile, the New Zealand dollar slipped 0.6% to US$0.6840, on track for its worst performance since January 2016, due to a survey of business sentiment plummeting to an eight-year low.

site_title: China Nov factory growth unexpectedly picks up despite pollution crackdown
summary: China's manufacturing sector unexpectedly showed growth in November, defying expectations of a slowdown due to pollution crackdowns and a cooling property market. The data suggests the economy can sustain momentum until early next year, easing concerns about a sharp slowdown. This upbeat news may help alleviate concerns about the impact of Beijing's economic policies on the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tumble in early trade
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 1.19% to 29,272.53, following sharp losses in US tech firms like Apple and Facebook. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.28%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.33%. The decline was attributed to a sell-off in technology stocks.

site_title: Australia calls banking inquiry to quell public anger
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has announced an independent inquiry into the country's financial services sector amid public anger over scandals involving the "big four" banks. The inquiry, valued at A$75 million, will focus on misconduct among banks, insurers, and financial services providers. It will consider how regulators identify and address misconduct, but not other matters. The inquiry will report within 12 months and is seen as a response to mounting pressure from Labor opposition and mounting public discontent.

site_title: Hong Kong private home prices hit record high for 12th straight month
summary: Hong Kong private home prices rose 0.53% in October, marking the 12th consecutive monthly gain and a 12.5% year-on-year increase. The record-breaking run adds to home ownership constraints in the world's most expensive property market. Property prices have been driven by a supply and demand imbalance since April 2016, with the city's leader pledging to increase land supply to address the issue. High property prices pose a risk to the residential market, affecting the city's sustainable development and social stability, according to a senior director at Knight Frank.

site_title: Singapore October bank lending up 1.4%: MAS
summary: Singapore's total bank lending in October increased 1.4% from September, driven by higher loans to financial institutions. Total domestic banking unit loans reached S$649.56 billion, with business loans rising 1.9% and consumer loans increasing 0.6%. Loans to manufacturers dropped 4.1% to S$25.44 billion. The growth is largely attributed to increased lending to financial institutions and modest rises in housing loans, credit card debt, and car loans.

site_title: No Signboard opens higher on trading debut
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a family-owned seafood restaurant chain, made its trading debut on Thursday, opening at 31 Singapore cents and reaching a high of 33 cents. The company's IPO was 23.6 times subscribed, raising S$18.7 million, with plans to use funds to build a brewery in Indonesia, launch a new Chinese casual dining chain, and expand its in-house beer brand. The company's CEO expressed pride in the company's growth and commitment to leveraging its strong brand and industry network to expand into new businesses.

site_title: China November official services PMI rises to 54.8
summary: China's official services PMI rose to 54.8 in November, up from 54.3 in October, indicating solid expansion in the sector. The services industry accounts for over half of China's economy, with rising wages giving consumers more spending power. This growth is seen as a key component of China's economic rebalancing efforts, as the country aims to shift from investment and exports to consumption-driven growth.

site_title: Thakral Corp invests in two Osaka properties
summary: Thakral Corp has invested in two Osaka properties, R Hotels Inn Osaka Kita Umeda and a Namba retail redevelopment site, through its pooled investment vehicle Thakral Japan Properties. The group holds a 50% stake in the vehicle. The investments are expected to generate positive returns for shareholders. The properties have been refurbished and pre-leased, with construction on the retail site scheduled to begin in March 2018 and completion within a year. Thakral's CEO believes the Osaka market is an opportune time for investments, driven by low unemployment and rising tourist inflows.

site_title: US makes push for China to cut off oil to North Korea
summary: The US has urged China to cut off crude oil shipments to North Korea, a move that would deal a significant blow to the country's economy. US Ambassador Nikki Haley told the UN Security Council that North Korea's latest ICBM test "demands that countries further isolate the Kim regime." US President Donald Trump also asked Chinese President Xi Jinping to cut off oil supplies. Haley called for all nations to cut off ties with North Korea, and the Security Council to strip the country of its UN voting rights.

images.alt_text: The United States on Wednesday urged China to cut off crude oil shipments to North Korea and pressed all countries to isolate Kim Jong Un's regime by cutting off all diplomatic and trade ties.

site_title: Stocks to watch: No Signboard, Cromwell European Reit, Keppel T&T, China Aviation Oil
summary: No Signboard Holdings starts trading on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange at S$0.28 per share, with its IPO 23.6 times subscribed. Cromwell European Reit begins trading at 2pm, with its public offer 3.1 times subscribed. Keppel T&T carries out a strategic review of its China logistics portfolio. China Aviation Oil Corp announces the departure of its COO, Jean Teo Lang Lang, effective January 22, 2018.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.2% down on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% on Thursday, closing at 3,433.23 points. The decline was driven by a selloff in US technology shares, including Apple and Amazon.com, which affected major US indices overnight. About 190.3 million shares changed hands, with 60 gainers and 61 losers. The market was influenced by global economic factors, including a Japanese benchmark edge lower and Australian shares sliding due to a government inquiry into banks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 3.59 points to 1,716.79 as of 9:03 am on Thursday, with a trading volume of 78.95 million lots worth RM41.14 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 120 to 87.

site_title: Keppel T&T to embark on strategic review of China logistics portfolio
summary: Keppel T&T is conducting a strategic review of its China logistics portfolio to optimize and focus resources. The review may involve discussions with parties to evaluate options, with Evercore Asia serving as financial adviser. The company owns facilities in Guangdong, Anhui, Tianjin, and Jilin, and cautions that no assurance exists for a transaction or binding agreement. The review aims to position Keppel T&T as the urban logistics solutions provider of choice.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won pare losses after BOK's rate hike
summary: South Korea's central bank raised interest rates for the first time in over six years, citing a growing economy that no longer needs crisis-level monetary settings. The move led to a decline in the Kospi stock index and the Korean won, with bond yields rising. The currency fell 0.48% against the US dollar, while foreign investors sold large volumes of local equities. Despite this, the Kospi index remains up 24% so far this year.

site_title: Apple Mac software has login flaw that puts data at risk
summary: A security flaw in the latest version of Apple Mac's operating system, Mac OS High Sierra, allows anyone to log in without a password by entering "root" and no password. This vulnerability exposes private user data and allows remote access to the device. Apple is working on a software update to address the issue, recommending users set a root password to prevent unauthorized access. In the meantime, users can fix the issue by assigning a password to the root account.

site_title: Porsche introduces world's 'most powerful' luxury sedan
summary: Porsche unveiled the 2018 Panamera Hybrid Sport Turismo, the world's most powerful luxury sedan, at the Los Angeles Auto Show. The vehicle boasts 680 total horsepower and 626 pound-feet of torque, making it faster than the 911 GT3 and Cayenne Turbo. It can accelerate from 0-60mph in 3.2 seconds and reach a top speed of 192mph. The hybrid powertrain combines a 550-hp V8 engine and 136-hp electric motor, offering various levels of efficiency and performance. Deliveries are set to begin next spring, with a base price of $188,400.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks drift lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.14% on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index closing at 22,565.78. Investors searched for fresh leads after mixed trading on Wall Street. The broader Topix index edged down 0.02%. The decline was attributed to sluggish trade, with no significant catalysts driving the market.

site_title: Fed says price pressures rising with economic growth steady
summary: The US economy grew at a moderate pace through mid-November, with price pressures strengthening and the labor market tightening, according to the Federal Reserve's Beige Book survey. Despite a hot job market, wage growth was modest, and most districts reported difficulties finding qualified workers. The economy expanded 3.3% in the third quarter, and Fed Chair Janet Yellen described the expansion as "broad based." The report suggests the Fed may raise interest rates in December to address rising price pressures and a tightening labor market.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on new bank inquiry; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Thursday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index dropping 37.32 points to 5,973.80, due to a new inquiry into the country's banking sector. The inquiry reverses the government's opposition to a commission, amid concerns over bank scandals and performance. The "Big Four" banks declined between 0.5% to 2.1%, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia leading the falls. New Zealand's benchmark index also declined 0.2%, tracking a 10-month losing streak.

site_title: Nokia says not preparing offer for Juniper Networks
summary: Finnish network equipment maker Nokia has denied reports it is in talks to buy US network gear maker Juniper Networks, citing a statement saying it is "not currently in talks with, nor is it preparing an offer for, Juniper Networks." The earlier CNBC report suggested a potential $16 billion acquisition, but Juniper's market capitalization is around $11.26 billion.

site_title: Uber's use of encrypted messaging may set legal precedents
summary: Top executives at Uber Technologies Inc used encrypted chat app Wickr for secret conversations, contradicting the company's claims of not using such apps. This revelation sets a potential legal precedent, as Uber faces a lawsuit from Alphabet's Waymo unit over self-driving car secrets. Wickr and other encrypted apps offer security and anonymity, raising questions about company accountability and data protection. The use of Wickr inside Uber may have implications for other companies using similar apps, potentially leading to changes in how they handle internal communications and data management.

images.alt_text: Top executives at Uber Technologies Inc used the encrypted chat app Wickr to hold secret conversations, current and former workers testified in court this week, setting up what could be the first major legal test of the issues raised by the use of encrypted apps inside companies.

site_title: Nasdaq is said to plan bitcoin futures, joining big rivals
summary: Nasdaq Inc plans to introduce bitcoin futures in the second quarter of 2023, joining major US exchanges in the cryptocurrency market. The contracts will trade on its NFX market, marking the exchange's entry into the digital currency market. This move comes as bitcoin's price surpassed $11,000 on Wednesday, further fueling interest in the market.

site_title: Fed should continue to raise rates slowly, Williams says
summary: US Federal Reserve President John Williams suggests the Fed should continue to raise interest rates gradually to counter falling US unemployment and expected inflation. Williams expects the US economy to grow 2.5% this year and 2% next year, with unemployment falling to 3.75%. Despite inflation remaining under the 2% goal, Williams attributes this to factors like slow-growing healthcare costs and falling mobile phone prices. He anticipates inflation to rise in 2018, following a typical 12-month lag. Williams' views align with Fed Chair Janet Yellen's expectations for further rate hikes.

site_title: US economy sees fastest growth in three years in third quarter
summary: The US economy posted its fastest growth in three years in the third quarter, with a 3.3% GDP growth rate, surpassing President Donald Trump's 3% target. The growth was driven by increased business spending on equipment and higher state and local government spending. Despite this, wages showed sluggish growth, and the consumer spending on services remained at a four-year low. The faster growth is likely to prompt another interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve, but forecasts for the fourth quarter remain mixed.

site_title: Bubble or brave new world? Bitcoin breaks US$11,000 barrier
summary: Bitcoin broke the US$11,000 barrier for the first time, reaching a record high of US$11,434 before dropping 15% to US$9,643. The cryptocurrency, which started the year at US$1,000, has surged 1,000% in recent weeks, driven by the launch of futures markets and growing mainstream acceptance. Critics warn of a bubble, while others predict it will continue to rise, reaching US$50,000 to US$100,000 in the next six to 18 months.

site_title: HDB to transfer industrial properties, land to JTC Corp on Jan 1
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) will transfer its industrial properties and land to JTC Corporation on January 1, 2018. The consolidation aims to better support industrialists in business growth, providing one-stop access to facilities and support services. By January 2018, all 10,700 industrial units and 540 land leases under HDB will be transferred, allowing JTC to match companies' space needs and undertake comprehensive master-planning of industrial estates in Singapore.

site_title: Oil drops for third day, awaiting Opec decision
summary: Oil prices dropped for the third consecutive day, settling at $63.1 a barrel for Brent crude and $57.30 a barrel for US crude. The decline comes ahead of OPEC's meeting in Vienna, where members are debating the extension of their supply-cut agreement. Concerns over a potential extension, particularly if the market starts to overheat, have led to market uncertainty. Analysts attribute the drop to the market's anticipation of an extension, despite a larger-than-expected drawdown in US crude inventories.

site_title: A-HTrust to lease entire hotel in Ariake, Tokyo to Sotetsu Hotel Management Co
summary: A-HTrust has entered into a memorandum of understanding to lease a 790-room hotel property in Ariake, Tokyo to Sotetsu Hotel Management Co from April 1 next year. The property, Hotel Sunroute Ariake and Oakwood Apartments Ariake Tokyo, will be leased under an extended fixed-term building lease agreement.

site_title: Yellen downplays threat of financial instability
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen downplays the threat of financial instability, describing the US economy as "steadily brightening" and expecting gradual adjustments in monetary policy to support continued expansion and job growth. She expects interest rates to rise and the Fed's balance sheet to be trimmed, but notes moderate vulnerabilities in the financial sector. Yellen's term as chair is set to expire in February, and she has announced she will leave the Fed once Jerome Powell, her successor, is confirmed by the Senate.

site_title: Britain 'very close' to agreeing Brexit bill
summary: Britain is "very close" to agreeing its Brexit bill, with the EU stating it wants more progress on the Irish border and European expats' rights before moving on to trade talks. The proposed settlement could be up to 55 billion euros, with the UK's offer now at 45-55 billion euros. The agreement would be a breakthrough ahead of a December EU summit, where Britain hopes to start the next phase of talks on a post-Brexit transition period and future trade ties.

site_title: Toyota showcases humanoid robot that mirrors user
summary: Toyota unveiled a humanoid robot, T-HR3, that mirrors its user's movements, with potential uses in elderly care, disaster response, and workplaces. The robot, controlled by a wearable system, boasts 32 joints and smooth human-like movements. Developed by Toyota's Partner Robot division, the T-HR3 has no immediate plans for commercial sale and was showcased at the International Robot Exhibition in Tokyo. The robot's development costs were not disclosed, but it could be used in Japan, where the elderly population is growing, causing labor shortages.

images.alt_text: Toyota's third generation humanoid robot, T-HR3, at the International Robot Exhibition 2017 in Tokyo. It is the latest in dozens of humanoid models that have been developed recently thanks to rapid technological advances.

site_title: Nomura returns to private equity, seeking stable income
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc is returning to private equity, investing about 100 billion yen (S$1.21 billion) in new business, with plans to initially focus on Japanese companies. The move aims to provide stable income through consulting services and help Japanese firms divest non-core businesses. Nomura will look to take majority stakes in target companies, initially focusing on domestic and small- to medium-sized enterprises, and will also expand overseas. This follows a decade after the global financial crisis, when potential buyers are becoming more willing to take on risky assets.

site_title: US: Dow ends at record again, but tech sell-off hits Nasdaq
summary: US stocks ended at record highs, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.4% to 23,940.45, beating Tuesday's record finish. However, the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 1.3% to 6,824.34 due to a tech sell-off. The S&P 500 slipped from its record close to end at 2,626.00. Strong gains by banks contributed to the Dow's record, despite uncertainty over US trade policies.

site_title: In US, 57% of kids on track for obesity by 35: study
summary: A US study predicts that over 57% of children will be obese by age 35 if current trends continue, with those already at a normal weight having less than a 50% chance. The study, published in the New England Journal of Medicine, found that obesity risk is high even among normal-weight children, and that weight gain in early years is difficult to reverse. The annual medical costs of obesity in the US are over $147 billion. Researchers emphasize the need for early interventions and prevention efforts to minimize the risk of serious illness.

site_title: International schools must offer better value, prep kids for future workplace
summary: Singapore's government has introduced a public tender to develop high-quality, moderate-fee international schools to attract and retain global talent. The move comes as expat packages shrink and housing costs rise, forcing families to choose between home-schooling or leaving the country. International schools must offer better value for money by providing flexible, cost-effective approaches that prioritize quality over quantity, while also preparing students for a fast-changing work environment.

site_title: Surbana Jurong lifts engineering expertise with Aussie buy
summary: Surbana Jurong has acquired Australian engineering firm Robert Bird Group, its fifth major acquisition since 2015. The deal aims to expand the company's expertise in engineering consultancy. Group CEO Wong Heang Fine declined to reveal the acquisition price. This move is part of Surbana Jurong's strategy to become an end-to-end engineering consultancy by filling the gaps in its expertise. The company is also considering its financial arm for potential acquisition in the future.

site_title: Subaru's Ascent SUV tipped to help maker overtake Hyundai
summary: Subaru Corp is expected to surpass Hyundai Motor in US sales in 2017, with the new Ascent SUV being a key factor. The Japanese carmaker trails Hyundai by less than 32,000 vehicles through the first 10 months of 2017, down from a 150,000-unit gap a year ago. Subaru's growth spurt, which includes the Ascent, is seen as a significant challenge to Hyundai's dominance in the US market.

site_title: YouTube sharpens how it recommends videos
summary: YouTube has updated its recommendation feature to prioritize videos users find most gratifying, using a user survey measure to predict and promote high-quality content. The goal is to prevent misinformation and promote satisfying videos, but critics worry it may reinforce pre-existing viewpoints. The new approach uses machine learning algorithms to analyze user behavior and video characteristics, driving 70% of overall watch time on YouTube. This shift comes as the platform faces criticism for failing to police content and shape public opinion, following similar issues with Facebook and Twitter during the 2016 US presidential election.

site_title: Canadian dollar hits near 4-week low versus firmer US$
summary: The Canadian dollar hit a nearly four-week low against the US dollar, trading at 77.87 US cents, as oil prices fell and the US economy showed stronger-than-expected growth in the third quarter. US crude prices dropped 0.22% to US$57.86 a barrel, and the Canadian dollar weakened 0.2% against the greenback. The Bank of Canada is set to make an interest rate decision next week, with data on Canada's jobs and GDP due on Friday, which could influence investor expectations for further rate hikes.

site_title: Lisbon's hot real estate market leaves buyers struggling for a home
summary: Lisbon's real estate market is experiencing a severe shortage of prime properties in the city centre, prompting buyers to bid above asking prices. The shortage is attributed to a lack of housing stock and high demand from foreign investors, particularly from China, fueled by Portugal's tax-friendly regime and tourism boom. As a result, home prices have risen 35% since 2012, and average prices in central historic neighborhoods are over 6,000 euros per square metre. The shortage has led to concerns about affordability, with residents being priced out of the market, and the city council plans to offer affordable housing to low- and middle-income residents.

site_title: Necessary measures to keep developers on the straight and narrow
summary: The Singapore government is taking measures to regulate developers and prevent them from compromising on quality to preserve profit margins. New policies include requiring pre-application feasibility studies for traffic impact and imposing license conditions on developers with poor track records. The government is also making Quality Mark certification scores publicly available to help consumers identify reliable developers. These measures aim to address concerns over rising land prices, intense development, and poor-quality homes, while also encouraging developers to build larger, safer units that can be sold over time.

site_title: Uber's Q3 losses widen as SoftBank launches bid to buy its shares
summary: Uber Technologies Inc reported a net loss of $1.46 billion in Q3, widening from the previous quarter's loss of $1.06 billion, amid strong competition and regulatory pressures. SoftBank Group Corp has launched a bid to buy a large block of Uber shares, valuing the business at $48 billion, a 30% discount to its last private valuation. The deal would involve at least 13.4% of outstanding shares and is expected to conclude by late February.

site_title: Europe: Shares gain, led by retailers, financials; FTSE lags
summary: European shares rose 0.3% to their highest level in over two weeks, driven by gains in retail and financial stocks, despite a decline in Britain's FTSE 100 due to a jump in sterling. Britain has offered to pay most of the EU's Brexit "divorce bill," bringing talks on a future free trade pact closer to agreement. Tech stocks declined, with chipmakers losing 3.6% to 7.3%, while broader market sentiment was lifted by signs of progress on US tax cuts.

site_title: Grab hitches top Visa honcho to lead e-payments drive
summary: Grab has hired Ooi Huey Tyng, Visa Singapore's country head, to lead GrabPay's business in Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand. Tyng will oversee the ride-hailing company's payments drive, aiming to stay ahead in the business. The move marks a significant step for Grab in the e-payments sector, as Tyng brings extensive experience in the payments industry. Her start date is expected to be early next year.

site_title: Gold edges up, near six-week high after Fed chair confirmation
summary: Gold prices edged higher on Tuesday, nearing a six-week high, after US Federal Reserve chair nominee Jerome Powell confirmed the Fed may raise interest rates again next month. The US dollar index rose, pushing gold prices down despite a 0.03% gain to $1,294.56 per ounce. Investors are awaiting a possible vote on the US tax code overhaul and tensions over North Korea, which may impact the gold market.

site_title: Cromwell European Reit's public offer 3.1 times subscribed
summary: Cromwell European Reit's public offer was 3.1 times subscribed, with 4,448 valid applications for 111.23 million units, exceeding the 36.36 million units available. The Reit also oversaw an international placement, allocating 27.27 million units to DBS Bank and eight million units to SeaTown Master Fund. The offer raised 866 million euros (S$1.4 billion), which will be used to acquire 60 properties in Europe and 14 Italian properties. Units in the Reit will start trading on the Singapore Exchange on Thursday.

site_title: HKEx poised to take plunge into dual-class shares
summary: HKEx is set to accept listings of companies with dual-class shares, with CEO Charles Li stating that this move provides market choices and ensures anti-abuse protections. Instead of separate boards, the dual-class shares will reside within the main board, with new chapters for nascent companies and those without voting rights. Li emphasized that investor protections and main board procedures will apply, and that the move aims to cater to "new economies" and innovation, while also facilitating easier access to secondary listings for international companies.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Wilmar International acquired 51.7 million Perennial Real Estate Holdings shares, increasing its stake to 20%. Japfa Limited's Indonesian subsidiary won its appeal against a cartel fine, and Capitaland Retail China Trust priced an oversold placement of new units. Centurion Corp will list 36 million shares in Hong Kong, while Yoma Strategic Holdings signed $400 million construction deals. Soilbuild Construction Group won a $3.9 million contract in Myanmar, and Chip Eng Seng Corp acquired an Australian hotel for $43 million. Mindchamps PreSchool gained a new substantial shareholder, Merrill Lynch International.

site_title: Oil prices slip on Opec deal extension jitters
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday, with US West Texas Intermediate crude futures down 0.6% to $57.67 a barrel, due to doubts over an Opec and Russia deal to extend production cuts. The market had already priced in an extension, and concerns over Russia's ability to comply with cuts amid a planned increase in output from the Far Eastern Sakhalin-1 project. Inventories also rose, and the Keystone pipeline's gradual restart weighed on prices.

site_title: No Signboard Holdings' IPO 23.6 times subscribed
summary: No Signboard Holdings' initial public offering (IPO) received 23.6 times subscriptions, with 65.7 million shares offered and 2.5 million shares sold to the public, resulting in net proceeds of S$18.7 million. The IPO priced shares at S$0.28 apiece, valuing the company at 13.9 times its earnings per share for 2016. This surpasses the 11.2 times subscription for placement shares and the 8 times subscription of rival seafood chain Jumbo Group when it listed two years ago.

site_title: North Korea's missile test intensifies Trump's 2018 dilemma
summary: North Korea test-fired an intercontinental missile, reaching a height of 4,500km and landing 1,000km from Japan's west coast. The US President Donald Trump condemned the launch, stating he would take care of the situation, amid heightened tensions following his declaration of North Korea a state sponsor of terrorism. The missile's range could have struck Europe, Australia, or the US continental states if it followed a standard trajectory. This adds to Trump's 2018 dilemma on how to tackle Pyongyang's provocations, particularly with the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation starting soon.

site_title: Indonesia reopens Bali airport as wind clears volcanic ash
summary: Indonesia's Bali airport reopened on November 29, 2017, as wind cleared volcanic ash from Mount Agung, allowing airlines to resume flights and transport 3,800 stranded tourists. Authorities urged 90,000-100,000 villagers to evacuate the danger zone, with 43,000 heeding the advice. Airlines including Singapore Airlines, Qantas, and Virgin Australia resumed flights, with plans for additional departures. The airport's reopening followed a downgrade in the aviation warning and more favorable winds.

site_title: Brexit settlement more than doubles; sterling rises almost 2%
summary: A UK "Brexit" settlement offer has more than doubled to 40-50 billion euros, paving the way for trade talks with the EU. Sterling surged 2% against the euro and US dollar, with the UK government seeking freedom to negotiate separate trade deals with the US and other nations. However, the main sticking point remains the border between Ireland and Northern Ireland, with the EU insisting it remains open. The UK will pay EU bills for decades, including 30 billion euros in liabilities, as part of the deal.

site_title: SGInnovate to invest in 20 startups as part of deep-tech strategy for 2018
summary: Singapore's innovation platform, SGInnovate, will invest in at least 20 deep-tech startups in 2018, focusing on artificial intelligence, machine learning, and data analytics. The platform aims to attract 15,000 participants to its events and 1,500 learners to its programs. SGInnovate will also expand its deep-tech talent network and partner with industry players to build AI talent and facilitate startups' access to AI technologies. The platform will co-invest in startups alongside venture capital firms, including Jungle Ventures and NSI Ventures, through the S$200 million Startup SG Equity fund.

site_title: A new way for machines to see, taking shape in Toronto
summary: A new AI system, building on the 2012 work of Geoffrey Hinton, is being developed in Toronto to enhance machine vision capabilities. This system can analyze thousands of photos and teach itself to identify common objects with high accuracy. The project, which began at the University of Toronto, aims to revolutionize the way machines perceive the world.

site_title: Shell calls end to austerity with return to full dividend
summary: Royal Dutch Shell cancelled its austerity dividend policy, scrapping the scrip dividend scheme in the fourth quarter of 2017, after boosting cash generation forecasts amid lower debt and higher oil prices. The company will abolish its scrip dividend, introduce a share buyback program, and maintain its capital expenditure forecasts. Shell's cash flow outlook was raised to $30 billion by 2020, and the company aims to reduce debt-to-equity ratio to 20% by 2020, with its asset disposal program nearly complete one year ahead of target.

images.alt_text: Shell's CEO Ben van Beurden says the company has made progress in its divestment programme.

site_title: More satisfied customers in tourism and F&B sectors in Q3
summary: Customer satisfaction in Singapore's tourism and food-and-beverage sectors improved in Q3, with hotels scoring 74.4 points and restaurants scoring 71.5 points, a 1.76-point increase. Locals showed higher satisfaction, especially those visiting attractions with families. However, long waiting times negatively impacted customer satisfaction and loyalty scores in F&B sub-sectors. The study, conducted from July to October, surveyed 6,900 people, including 3,035 locals and 3,865 tourists.

site_title: Microsoft plans multibillion dollar campus overhaul
summary: Microsoft is planning a multibillion-dollar overhaul of its Redmond, Washington campus, adding space for 8,000 workers and areas for collaboration and recreation. The move aims to keep up with the company's growth in hiring and trend towards more open office spaces. The campus overhaul is part of Microsoft's efforts to stay competitive as Seattle-based Amazon.com Inc. searches for a second headquarters in a new location.

site_title: Turning privilege into a force for greater board diversity
summary: A study on board diversity in Singapore-listed firms found a 43% average pay gap between male and female directors. The author acknowledges unconscious bias, a common issue in societies with privilege, where certain groups are unconsciously given advantages. To improve board diversity, individuals can practice self-reflection and seek alternative opinions, while systems can use structured selection procedures and checks and balances. A cultural shift is also needed to value diversity of views in decision-making, with a goal of achieving at least 20% female directors by 2020, as set by the Minister for Culture, Community and Youth, Grace Fu.

images.alt_text: Research on Singapore-listed companies has shown that those with greater board diversity - be it age, ethnicity or gender - are up to five times more profitable than those with homogenous boards.

site_title: Facebook says 99% of IS and Al-Qaeda content spotted by AI
summary: Facebook's artificial intelligence (AI) has successfully detected and removed 99% of Islamic State (IS) and Al-Qaeda-related content, with some cases blocking content from ever being posted. The company's AI system is becoming increasingly adept at identifying and removing terrorist content, with Facebook's head of global policy management and counter-terrorism policy hailing the progress. Facebook aims to expand its automated tools to target content from other terrorist organizations.

site_title: Soilbuild custom builds project for RF360
summary: Singapore property group Soilbuild is constructing a custom-built site, Solaris @ Kallang 171, for RF360, a joint venture of Qualcomm and TDK, at a cost of over S$110 million. The building will house RF360's electronics production, R&D, product testing, and offices, creating 300 new jobs in the electronics industry. The site is expected to be completed in June 2019 and will focus on surface acoustic wave (SAW) structured wafers and thin film acoustic packaging for module integration markets.

site_title: Noble to sell vessels for US$95m to further pare debt
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-based commodity trader, plans to sell four Kamsarmax dry bulk carrier vessels for US$95 million to reduce debt. The sale, part of a debt reduction plan, will generate about US$30 million in net proceeds. The vessels are currently mortgaged to financial institutions and the sale will help pay down these amounts. The deal is expected to close between March and May 2024 and will not significantly impact Noble's freight business operations.

site_title: Air France-KLM extends India reach with Jet Airways
summary: Air France-KLM has extended its partnership with Jet Airways India to offer travel options for 44 Indian cities and 106 European destinations. The deal gives the European airline more access to India's growing aviation market. Additionally, a partnership with Delta Air Lines will connect India to a trans-Atlantic network with hubs in Amsterdam and Paris. This expansion aims to enhance Air France-KLM's presence in the world's fastest-growing major aviation market.

site_title: Singapore interest rates spike on liquidity crunch, likely to go higher
summary: Singapore's short-term interest rates surged due to a liquidity crunch, likely to rise further ahead of the expected US interest rate hike in December. The benchmark three-month Sibor rose six points to 1.183%, the highest since March 2016, while the one-month Sibor spiked six points to 1.067%. Experts attribute the spike to seasonal factors, the anticipated US rate hike, and a tightening liquidity market. Interest rate strategists predict another five-point adjustment for the short-term Sibor rates, with some estimating the three-month Sibor to hit 1.40% by end-2017.

site_title: No clear picture on long-term effect of India's economic slowdown
summary: India's economic slowdown, marked by a 7.1% GDP growth rate in 2016-17, has sparked contrasting views on its long-term prospects. Moody's upgraded India's sovereign rating to Baa2, citing progress on economic reforms, while Standard & Poor's retained its BBB- rating, citing concerns over low per capita income and fiscal deficit. The government has implemented several reforms, including demonetisation and the Goods and Services Tax, but some initiatives have failed to take off, such as the "Make in India" effort. Analysts expect the country's GDP growth to bounce back to 7.2% in 2018.

site_title: India leapfrogs out of poverty
summary: India is rapidly digitizing its economy and power grid, aiming to leapfrog out of poverty and catch up to China. The country's Aadhaar system, launched in 2009, has reached 1.18 billion users, providing a unique ID and linking it to mobile phones and bank accounts, enabling digital payments and access to government services. This has transformed the lives of millions, with productivity gains in agriculture, transportation, and manufacturing. India is also transitioning to a decentralized, de-carbonized energy system, with giant solar power plants and battery storage systems, making it a leader in renewable energy.

site_title: Eight organisations, individuals win 6th PVPA awards
summary: Singapore President Halimah Yacob awarded 8 organisations and individuals for their efforts in volunteerism and philanthropy at the 6th President's Volunteerism & Philanthropy Awards. The winners, selected from 115 nominations, include DBS Bank, Dover Park Hospice, and Kampung Spirit category winner ItsRainingRaincoats. The awards recognize innovative and impactful efforts towards the community, with a focus on sustainability and social initiative.

site_title: To slim as you age, pile on the weights at the gym
summary: A new study published in Obesity found that adding weights to a weight-loss regimen may be more effective than starting a walking program for older adults trying to slim down. Researchers at Wake Forest University studied 249 participants over 18 months, finding that those who combined calorie reduction with weight training lost more fat and less muscle mass compared to those who only reduced calories or exercised through walking. The study suggests that incorporating weight training into a weight loss program can help preserve muscle mass and promote healthier aging.

site_title: STI hits 2½-year high on liquidity rush
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) briefly hit a 2½-year high of 3,449.32 points in November, but retreated to finish at 3,438.99 points, down 3.36 points. The rally was led by banks and Genting Singapore, but losers outnumbered gainers for the third day in a row. Hyflux fell to a 15-year low due to weak earnings and debt pressures, while Tuan Sing Holdings rose to a three-year high as its property business performed well.

site_title: Australian fund bets on US company bonds as tax cuts loom
summary: QIC Ltd, an Australian money manager, expects US corporate tax cuts to benefit investment-grade corporate bonds, with a $1.4 trillion deal potentially passing by early next year. The tax cuts will favor companies with solid balance sheets, posing good credit investments in 2018. QIC's debt funds have beaten their benchmarks in 2017 by favoring US corporate bonds, and the company will consider hedging their bets if the tax reforms are delayed. The tax cuts are expected to lead to a surge in risk assets, including equities and corporate bonds.

site_title: US: Dow higher on tax bill hopes
summary: The US stock market opened higher on November 29, 2017, driven by optimism over tax legislation progress and potential lighter banking regulations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 56.34 points, or 0.24%, to 23,893.05, while the S&P 500 gained 1.75 points, or 0.07%, to 2,628.79.

site_title: Budget airline Norwegian eyes daily S'pore-London flights
