This is faster than the 0.2% rise in September. Prices in the central region rose 1.2% m-o-m, while in the non-central region, they rose 0.3%. Compared to last year, prices are up 2.4%.

site_title: Fullerton Healthcare expands in China on 800m yuan investment
summary: Fullerton Healthcare Corporation has received an 800 million yuan (S$163 million) investment from Ping An Capital and related parties, making it the company's second-largest shareholder. This partnership aims to provide affordable and accessible healthcare solutions in China's growing enterprise healthcare market. The investment will help Fullerton Healthcare expand its presence in the country, offering quality healthcare services.

images.alt_text: Michael Tan says it is a good time for Fullerton Health to expand into the Chinese market, amid the deepening of China's healthcare reform.

site_title: Going digital for better outcomes
summary: Info-Tech Systems Integrators, a Singapore-based software company, has implemented digital tools to improve customer service. The company introduced a phone monitoring system, which has reduced lost calls and improved accountability among support staff. This initiative, combined with a scheduling management app and an online knowledge hub, has resulted in improved service quality, customer satisfaction, and productivity. By leveraging digital solutions, Info-Tech aims to enhance customer satisfaction and drive growth, as stated by its director Dilip Babu.

site_title: Tumblr founder leaving Yahoo-owned blogging platform
summary: Tumblr founder and CEO David Karp is leaving the platform, which Yahoo owns, by the end of the year. Karp cited personal ambitions and a desire to preserve Tumblr's future, while Chief Operating Officer Jeff D'Onofrio will take over. Yahoo acquired Tumblr in 2013 for $1.1 billion as part of its effort to connect with younger online users. Verizon's acquisition of Yahoo has led to restructuring, including the elimination of hundreds of jobs. Karp will depart as Tumblr hosts 380 million blogs.

site_title: Ying Li divests 3.3b yuan stake in Chongqing CBD project
summary: Ying Li International Real Estate sold its 3.3 billion yuan stake in the Chongqing CBD project to Shengyu (BVI), a part of China Evergrande Group, for 3.29 billion yuan. The deal includes repayment of inter-company loans and existing liabilities. Shengyu will take on Shiny Profit Group's liabilities, including 898 million yuan. The transaction is expected to close before the end of November.

images.alt_text: The commercial project, formerly known as the Ying Li Chongqing Financial Street Project, is located in Chongqing's Jiefangbei CBD and currently under construction.

site_title: Narrowing Hong Kong's autonomy may backfire
summary: A senior Chinese official, Li Fei, chairman of the Basic Law Committee, defined Hong Kong's "high degree of autonomy" as joint administration by the central and local governments, with the central government handling "some major matters". This marks a narrowing of Hong Kong's autonomy, stripping away the verbiage surrounding China's Hong Kong policy and revealing a shift towards joint management. The move has raised concerns among the international community, potentially affecting Hong Kong's role as a financial centre and China's interests.

site_title: Evacuation centres, hotels fill up as Bali volcano eruption looms
summary: A volcano on Indonesia's resort island of Bali threatened to erupt, prompting authorities to close the airport for a second day and evacuate thousands of people. The Mount Agung volcano, which last erupted in 1963, is expected to produce a thunderous eruption at any moment, with 40,000 people already abandoned their homes in the danger zone. Over 200 evacuation centers are filled with stranded tourists and villagers, with 120,000 passengers affected by flight cancellations. The eruption could have a significant impact on Bali's tourism industry, with some predicting a prolonged impact on tourism revenue and local businesses.

site_title: Chinese firm wins AI contest amid nation's race for military edge over US
summary: A Chinese startup, Yitu Tech, won a US$25,000 prize in a facial recognition competition by a US research arm, highlighting China's rapid AI advancements. The competition was cited in a report by a US think-tank as an example of China's potential to modernize its military and gain an edge over the US. The report warned of future economic and military balances of power shifting, with China potentially overtaking the US in AI within the next five years.

site_title: Bubbles, busts, investor psychology ... and bitcoin
summary: Bitcoin's price has surged 760% this year, fueled by speculation and crowd psychology. The asset's price is considered bubbly, with investors piling in, driven by rapid price gains and media attention. However, experts warn of potential risks, including the lack of fundamental value, limited supply, and regulatory crackdowns. The price may continue to rise, but a crash is possible, particularly if more investors are drawn in. The author advises caution and staying away from bitcoin, citing concerns about its lack of understanding and potential negative effects on the economy.

site_title: SPA winners are leading the productivity charge
summary: The Singapore Productivity Awards 2017 recognized 10 organizations across six sectors for their excellence in raising productivity. The winners, including companies in the hotel, infocomm, logistics, manufacturing, and retail sectors, were chosen through a combination of quantitative and qualitative evaluations. The awards aim to inspire the wider business community to transform and become more productive. This year's winners have also achieved improvements in areas such as creating higher value skills jobs, raising staff morale, and delivering higher customer satisfaction. The awards are part of a national effort to drive productivity among local enterprises.

site_title: Temasek in talks for US$1b sale of Zuellig Pharma stake: sources
summary: Temasek Holdings is exploring the sale of its 20% stake in Zuellig Pharma, a Singapore-based pharmaceutical distributor, for approximately $1 billion. Interested buyers include Swiss rival DKSH, Mitsui & Co, and private equity firms. This sale comes after the death of family patriarch Stephen Zuellig in January, which fueled speculation about the company's future. Discussions are at an early stage, and there is no certainty that a transaction will occur. Temasek first invested in Zuellig Pharma in 2007, and the company generated $10 billion in sales in 2015.

site_title: Next change at Cathay: Focus on group's property business
summary: Cathay Organisation, a Singapore-based company, has sold its iconic cinema brand to mm2 Asia for S$230 million. The sale will allow Cathay Organisation to focus on its property business, including The Cathay, a national monument, and Cathay Cineleisure Orchard mall. Managing director Choo Meileen will remain on the board of Cathay Cineplexes, and mm2 Asia plans to collaborate with studios, leveraging the Cathay brand's reputation. The deal marks a significant shift for Cathay Organisation, which will wind down its film distribution business under a non-compete agreement.

images.alt_text: At a joint press conference to announce the completion of the acquisition of Cathay Cineplexes Pte Ltd, mm2 Asia executive chairman Melvin Ang said the company is eyeing 'collaboration opportunities' with studios, courtesy of Cathay's brand cachet.

site_title: Oil majors betting big on shale technology
summary: Oil majors are investing heavily in shale technology to improve efficiency and reduce costs, amid concerns that US shale production gains are slowing. Engineers like Oscar Portillo use advanced technology to control multiple rigs remotely, aiming to cut drilling costs by a third. This push for innovation comes as investors seek higher returns on investments in the US shale industry.

site_title: CRCT, CapitaLand to buy RMB3.36b mall in Guangzhou
summary: CapitaLand and its sponsored real estate investment trust, CRCT, have formed a joint venture to acquire Rock Square mall in Guangzhou, China for approximately RMB3.36 billion (S$688.9 million). CRCT will hold a 51% stake, while CapitaLand owns the remaining 49%. The transaction is expected to be completed by Q1 2018, marking CapitaLand's second mall and CRCT's first in Guangzhou.

site_title: Serving up innovations in service
summary: Dian Xiao Er, a Chinese quick casual dining restaurant chain, has streamlined its operations to deliver high-quality service quickly. The chain has implemented a highly efficient work process, clearly defined roles, and rigorous staff training to reduce turnaround time and increase productivity. By focusing on customer service and quality, Dian Xiao Er has attracted a large percentage of regular diners and increased revenue. The company is now exploring digital ordering and table holding functions to further enhance the customer experience.

site_title: CIMB's Q3 profit beats expectations on lower provisions, consumer boost
summary: CIMB Group Holdings, Malaysia's second-largest lender, reported a 10.7% rise in quarterly profit to RM1.13 billion, beating expectations. The bank attributed the growth to higher net interest income, lower provisions, and a robust consumer boost. Loan growth was 7% on-year, driven by consumer banking. CIMB remains on track to meet key financial targets for 2017, with the Malaysian economy expected to grow 5.2-5.7% this year.

site_title: Noble's balance sheet still unreliable: Iceberg
summary: ICEBERG Research has criticized Noble Group's balance sheet, stating its numbers are unreliable and liabilities have been undervalued. The research outfit also questioned Noble's recent contracts with Mkango Resources, a rare-earth exploration firm, and called for a change of management. Noble has been struggling financially, with a market value of S$195.1 million compared to its peak of over US$10 billion in 2010. The company has proposed a debt restructuring plan, but Iceberg claims it will not address the fundamental weaknesses that led to its collapse.

site_title: When cleaner ships may not be safer ships
summary: The International Maritime Organization and industry associations have discussed the need for more technologically innovative ship designs to reduce CO2 emissions and counter cyber security risks. However, new regulations aimed at reducing emissions could potentially underpower vessels, making them vulnerable during bad weather. The industry has agreed to adopt new methods and standards to create more resilient digital systems on board, but the effectiveness of these efforts remains uncertain. Industry self-regulation is seen as a key complement to statutory regulations, and the goal is to develop solutions to big issues before further regulation is needed.

site_title: Is your firm ready for the future of work?
summary: Industry leaders emphasize the need for companies to adapt to the future of work, characterized by bottom-up innovation, automation, cloud, and co-working spaces. To prepare employees, companies should provide flexible work arrangements, tools of their choice, and an environment that unleashes creative energy. Leaders must also foster collaboration and creativity through open communication, knowledge-sharing, and embracing diverse perspectives. Employees should be adaptable, always learning, and prepared to adapt to changes in the market. By adopting these strategies, businesses can stay relevant and competitive in the future of work.

site_title: Minding the skills gap
summary: Singapore ranks 13th globally in the World Talent Report, excelling in "readiness" for the new economy but struggling in "investment and development". The country scores low in public expenditure on education (41st), female labor force participation (37th), and effective personal income tax rate (45th). To address these issues, making tertiary education free for all Singaporeans and raising digital capabilities are crucial. Raising adaptability, creativity, and interpersonal skills, which are not emphasized in formal education, can also protect against automation. Companies like AT&T are successfully reskilling their staff through massive retraining programs, and Singapore can learn from this example to create a culture of perpetual learning and address the skills gap.

site_title: What next for the Capitol project?
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings and Capitol Singapore co-developer Pontiac Land are facing a challenging situation after a Court of Appeal threw out a winding-up application, leaving the two parties with the option of one selling its stake to the other. Perennial had hoped to buy Chesham's stake instead, and the companies had previously been at odds, with their relationship described as "increasingly acrimonious". The dispute highlights the difficulties of 50-50 partnerships, where disagreements can lead to stalemates and hinder business progress.

site_title: China Fibretech's lead independent director ousted from board
summary: China Fibretech's lead independent director, Low Wai Cheong, was ousted from the board after a failed re-election attempt with 84.17% of votes cast against him. The ouster comes amid concerns over the firm's corporate governance, including its handling of damage claims and financial record-keeping. Low had clashed with Wu Xinhua, the former CEO and current non-executive director, over the claims and payments. The move follows a series of events, including the suspension of trading and the emptying of cash and bank balances to pay compensation to three claimants.

site_title: Bezos a US$100b man as Amazon rises on cyber shopping
summary: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos' net worth surpassed $100 billion, according to Forbes' real-time ranking, as the online retailer raked in cash from the holiday weekend's cyber shopping. Bezos' personal net worth rose to $100.3 billion, solidifying his position as the world's richest person.

site_title: Redas proposing formal joint panel with lead govt agency
summary: The Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore (Redas) is proposing a formal joint panel with the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) to enhance dialogue on government policies and initiatives affecting the real estate sector. The panel aims to address growth sustainability, particularly in the prime project market above $3,000 psf. This move seeks to increase Redas' involvement in shaping government decisions, ultimately benefiting the industry. The proposed joint committee is expected to facilitate regular discussions and collaboration between the industry and the government.

site_title: UK banking system can support economy despite disorderly Brexit, says BOE
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) has stated that the UK's banking system can support the economy despite a disorderly Brexit, with none of the major lenders failing the annual stress test. Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland initially failed the test due to increased capital during the year, but the BOE's Financial Policy Committee believes the banks are strong enough to cope. However, lawmakers must pass new laws to ensure financial stability in the event of a disorderly Brexit, and the BOE is considering raising its risk buffer to 1% to prepare for potential risks.

site_title: India wants RBI rate cut before March to lift growth
summary: India's government is urging the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) to cut interest rates before March to boost economic growth, which has slowed to a three-year low of 5.7% in the July-September quarter. The finance ministry expects inflation to remain close to the 4% target and is lobbying for a rate cut at the RBI's next meeting on December 5-6 or in February. The RBI has kept rates unchanged at 6.0% since October, and a rate cut would help revive private investment, which has been anaemic.

site_title: SGX aims to ride Asian wave with new emerging-markets indices
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched emerging-markets indices, MSCI EM and MSCI EM Asia, to cater to the growing demand for Asia exposure from international investors. The indices track 10% of the world's market capitalization, or US$1.7 trillion, with 70% in Asia. SGX aims to provide multi-economy, multi-currency exposure in the same time zone as Western institutional investors. The derivatives market, which accounts for 40% of SGX's revenue, is open 22 hours a day, allowing for faster price formation and increased capital efficiency.

images.alt_text: "We feel there's a great opportunity to create a market for EM in our time zone. We want to swing the price formation to our time." - Michael Syn, SGX head of derivatives

site_title: Big gains from workflow automation
summary: Tacam Steel, a homegrown steel door manufacturer, implemented a Web-based enterprise system, Fitprise, to automate its workflow. The system reduced paperwork, mitigated human errors, and saved the company 30% in time and resources. The implementation process took two months of internal discussions and three to four months of discussions with the software provider. The system has also freed employees from repetitive tasks, allowing them to focus on research and development, leading to better customer solutions. The company's experience highlights the potential of enterprise software for small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore.

site_title: We are shaped by our climate: study
summary: A new study published in Nature found that the climate of a person's childhood significantly influences their personality traits, particularly agreeableness, openness, and emotional stability. The study suggests that growing up in a region with average temperatures close to 72 degrees fosters exploration and influences personality development. The findings imply that as global temperatures rise due to climate change, people may become more agreeable and open, although the study's authors note that the relationship is complex and influenced by various factors.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Marco Polo Marine will hold an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholders' approval for issuing new securities as part of its restructuring plan. EMS Energy's scheme of arrangement has been adjourned until February 12. Centurion Corporation has closed its US student housing fund, raising $89.5 million. EuroSports Global's Prosper Auto has signed a dealership deal with Lamborghini in Indonesia. Lian Beng Group has secured a $136.8 million contract for a condominium development. Perennial Real Estate has incorporated another subsidiary, Peng Xi (Beijing) Eldercare Co Ltd, in China.

site_title: GST hike - by how much and how soon?
summary: Singapore is expected to raise its Goods and Services Tax (GST) by 2 percentage points over two years, according to DBS economist Irvin Seah. The hike, likely to be announced in Budget 2018, aims to cushion the impact on households and raise tax revenues, with a one percentage point increase projected to generate S$1.6 billion to S$1.8 billion in revenue. A staggered hike is recommended to balance revenue needs with a cautious economic outlook, and an offset package worth at least S$4 billion may be announced alongside the hike.

images.alt_text: The labour market seems to have bottomed, but a more pronounced recovery remains lacking. Hence, a sharp GST hike at this moment could result in a double whammy for some households, said Mr Seah.

site_title: Eruption disruption: airlines rush to cut losses
summary: Airlines are scrambling to minimize losses due to the shutdown of Bali's airport caused by volcanic ash from Mount Agung. With no immediate end to the eruption, airlines are offering alternative travel options and redeploying capacity to other destinations. Industry experts predict potential long-term flight frequency adjustments to Bali and a significant drop in forward bookings, which could lead to discounts and lost revenue. The situation is a major blow to the airline industry during peak travel season, with estimated daily losses of $5 million for 42 airlines.

site_title: Partnerships and dialogue much needed to combat obesity
summary: The obesity and overweight epidemic is escalating rapidly in South-east Asia, including Singapore. According to a report by the Economist Intelligence Unit, Singapore has the second-highest overweight prevalence in the region at 32.8%, with obesity rates increasing by an average of 28% between 2010 and 2014. The region's obesity rates have grown significantly, with Indonesia and Vietnam experiencing over three times faster growth than the UK and US. Childhood obesity is also a concern, with some countries experiencing high levels of obesity among children.

site_title: Singapore wins bid to host 2024 Rotary Club global convention
summary: Singapore has won the provisional bid to host the 2024 Rotary Club global convention, which will bring together over 25,000 members worldwide. The five-day event will be held at the Singapore Expo Convention and Exhibition Centre, with workshops, forums, and entertainment planned. This is Singapore's largest association congress to date, and the city-state aims to champion a legacy project focusing on sanitation progress and hygiene awareness by 2025.

site_title: Three firms fined over S$600,000 for rigging F1 bids
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) fined Cyclect Group S$559,297 and two other companies, HPH Engineering and Peak Top Engineering, a combined S$59,153 for bid-rigging in the Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix tender. The CCS also fined Cyclect Group S$12,000 for rigging a tender to supply asset-tagging services to a school. The firms inflated their bids by 25-30% above Cyclect Electrical's, distorting the competitive bidding process. The CCS emphasized the need for bidders to educate employees through compliance programs and open tenders to multiple bidders to prevent bid-rigging.

site_title: How data science can make business travel profitable
summary: Business travel is a $1.2 trillion industry, with Singapore's spending projected to grow to $21.7 billion by 2027. However, companies struggle to measure the return on investment (ROI) of business travel due to its traditional view as a cost rather than a strategic benefit. By combining travel data with HR, corporate finance, and other data sources, companies can understand the true cost of business trips and their impact on revenue growth, productivity, and employee well-being. This shift in perspective can help business travel become a revenue generator, rather than an expense.

site_title: Singapore to lead Asia digital push by CMA CGM
summary: CMA CGM, the world's third-largest shipping line, has chosen Singapore as the hub for its Asia digital strategy, citing the city-state's digital business capabilities and its growing presence in the region. The company, which recently ordered $1.2 billion worth of container ships that will run on liquefied natural gas, expects real demand for capacity and is confident that its growth will translate into higher activity in Singapore. The decision comes as the global container shipping industry slowly emerges from a slump, with CMA CGM posting record-high sales and volumes in the third quarter.

site_title: Singapore shoppers prefer to pay with card-linked apps, wallets
summary: Singapore credit card holders prefer to pay with card-linked apps or wallets, with 40% using mobile wallets to make credit card payments, a 53% increase from 2016. Security concerns remain a major issue, but rewards and loyalty programs also play a significant role, with 79% of cardholders choosing a card with rewards and spending 29% more on average. American Express tops the list in credit card satisfaction, followed by Standard Chartered and DBS.

site_title: Coal, chocolate, and jolly Chinese money
summary: China Evergrande Group, a debt-soaked developer, buys a Chongqing development and land parcel from Ying Li International in a deal worth millions. Meanwhile, Geo Energy Resources, a Singapore-listed Indonesian coal miner, sees its shares rise after a giant off-market trade. Chocolate seller Delfi Ltd also sees its shares change hands off-market. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended the day up 0.17% to 3,442.35, while Yangzijiang, a shipbuilder, fell 4.8%. Market participants remain optimistic about economic growth, with most expecting a broad-based rebound in spending on machinery and equipment.

site_title: Next British royal is American, of mixed race, independent
summary: Meghan Markle, an American actress of mixed race, is set to marry Prince Harry next spring, bringing fresh air to the British royal family. Markle, 36, is a lawyer and humanitarian who has faced sexism and racism on social media. Despite her divorce and independent nature, the couple's relationship has been widely accepted by the public, with some even praising her feminist beliefs. Markle's mixed heritage and strong personality may bring a modern perspective to the royal family, according to biographer Penny Junor.

site_title: OECD sees growth peaking at 8-year high next year as investment lags and debt builds
summary: The OECD predicts global economic growth will peak at an 8-year high of 3.7% in 2018, before easing back to 3.6% in 2019. This growth is driven by the euro area outpacing the US and Japanese expansions, with investment lagging and debt levels increasing.

site_title: Amazon is a potential customer, says Textron aviation chief
summary: Textron Inc's aviation business chief, Scott Ernest, stated that Amazon.com Inc is a potential customer due to the growing ecommerce industry. The company sees the freight industry doubling in the next 15 years, leading to investments in the market. FedEx Corp recently agreed to buy some of Textron's Cessna SkyCourier 408, a new aircraft model.

site_title: Bright outlook for risk assets in 2018
summary: JP Morgan Asset Management's chief global strategist David Kelly expects risk assets to perform well in 2018 due to the Trump administration's proposed tax bill, which is expected to boost the economy and corporate stock gains. The tax cut will lead to higher US deficits and a weaker US dollar, making US corporates more competitive and benefiting emerging market assets. However, Kelly notes that the tax cut will eventually be a drag on economic growth.

images.alt_text: Jerome Powell, President Donald Trump's nominee to head the Federal Reserve, has signalled continuity in terms of how the Fed operates and guides the economy.

site_title: Working greener and smarter
summary: LHT Holdings, a timber manufacturer, has developed an innovative line of environmentally friendly products made from 50-100% waste wood materials, reducing costs and delivery time compared to traditional wood products. The company's Innovative Processed Product Conversion (IPPC) line takes just five to eight steps to produce, compared to 19 for traditional pallets. LHT has also implemented tracking technology and a digital design system to increase productivity and efficiency, with plans to build a smart factory at its new location.

images.alt_text: LHT's environmentally friendly products made from 50 to 100% waste wood materials are in response to changing customer needs. The IPPC line of pallets, crates and boxes do not require fumigation or heat treatment when exported, saving both costs and delivery time.

site_title: Providing quality healthcare solutions
summary: EGIS Healthcare Technologies prioritizes customer needs in its software development and distribution for clinical laboratory and blood transfusion information management systems in Singapore. Its laboratory information system handles majority of non-demographic data in Singapore's healthcare institutions. EGIS believes a regionally integrated clinical environment can improve care delivery and reduce costs.

site_title: US retailers go from targeting deal seekers to those yet to buy
summary: US retailers are shifting their strategy from offering deep discounts to making items easily available, especially with Christmas falling on a Monday this year. Cyber Monday online spending is on track to hit a new high of $6.59 billion, up 16.8% from last year. Retailers like Amazon and Wal-Mart are focusing on quick delivery and convenience, while traditional retailers are filling the void online. Amazon "handily won" online spending on Thanksgiving and Black Friday, capturing 55% of e-commerce transactions from top 50 online retailers.

images.alt_text: As Christmas draws closer, retailers such as Amazon.com Inc and Wal-Mart Stores will focus more on making items easily available, rather than duking it out on price.

site_title: Running machines 24/7
summary: Micro-Mechanics, a semiconductor equipment maker, introduced innovations to achieve nonstop production. A "Pit-Stop" system allows one dedicated personnel to prepare tooling offline, reducing idle time by 90% and freeing up machinists for other tasks. This innovation, part of the company's "026 + R&D" strategy, aims to achieve zero defect, 2-day response time, 6-day cycle time, and innovation. The company also developed a methodology for using correct cutting tools and invested in a system for continuous overnight operation, increasing output by 42%.

images.alt_text: Micro-Mechanics introduced a 'Pit-Stop' system to reduce the time that a piece of equipment is left idle while the machinist prepares it for the next job.

site_title: Tokyo maintains moderately upbeat view on economy
summary: The Japanese government maintained its moderately upbeat view on the economy in November, citing consumer spending and business investment as drivers of recovery. The economy continued to grow, with a 1.4% annualized rate in the July-September quarter, its longest expansion in 16 years. Private consumption picked up moderately, while capital expenditure and exports also showed signs of improvement. The government expects consumer prices to rise, citing factors such as labor shortages and record corporate profits, and aims to vanquish deflation through wage rises and productivity improvements.

site_title: As Brexit nears, new London office construction slows
summary: London's new office construction slows as Brexit uncertainty and high construction costs delay projects. In the six months ended September 30, 25 new central London office schemes began construction, down from 28 in the previous period. The projects would add 1.8 million square feet to the development pipeline, the lowest in over three years. Demand for office space has held up, but vacancy rates have risen, and business has become more cautious on investment. Developers are showing caution due to Brexit uncertainty and rising construction costs.

site_title: State Street's FX business thrives despite competition from global banks
summary: State Street Global Markets' foreign exchange business thrives in Asia, competing with major banks, despite the challenging market. The company has US$32.1 trillion in assets under custody and administration, and ranks number 11 globally in FX market share. State Street was awarded a global five-star ranking in Euromoney's 2017 survey, and ranks fourth in overall Asia for real money and hedge funds. The company's FX volumes in APAC have grown over 50% in the past five years, driven by new client acquisition and deepened relationships with existing clients.

images.alt_text: "Our pool of clients in APAC has grown by 25 per cent over the past five years, and we have also continued to diversify into other non- traditional institutional client segments, such as insurance companies and security houses." - Mr Quek

site_title: CEO of IE Singapore to leave for private sector on Dec 31
summary: Singapore's International Enterprise (IE) Singapore CEO Lee Ark Boon is leaving on Dec 31 to join the private sector. Deputy CEO Kathy Lai will act as interim CEO until the formation of Enterprise Singapore in Q2 2018. The move marks a significant shift as IE Singapore prepares to merge with other agencies to form Enterprise Singapore.

site_title: Rap mogul Jay-Z leads Grammys race with eight nods
summary: Jay-Z leads the Grammy nominations with eight nods, including Album of the Year for "4:44," Record of the Year, and Song of the Year. Kendrick Lamar follows closely with seven nominations. The Grammys, now marking its 60th edition, recognize hip-hop's growing influence in the music industry, a shift after years of criticism about underrepresentation of African American artists. The winners will be announced at the ceremony on January 28 in New York.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: IHH Healthcare's 9M 2017 adjusted core earnings fell 36% year-over-year, mainly due to start-up losses from expansion plans. The earnings beat consensus estimates, but below expectations. The company's share price target is set at S$1.71. Start-up losses continue to impact earnings, despite the better-than-expected core earnings.

site_title: US: S&P hits record at open
summary: The S&P 500 hit a record high at open on Tuesday, driven by gains in technology stocks, ahead of a confirmation hearing for Federal Reserve chair nominee Jerome Powell. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 51.43 points, while the Nasdaq Composite added 12.33 points.

site_title: US goods trade deficit widens in October, inventories fall
summary: The US goods trade deficit widened 6.5% to $68.3 billion in October, driven by increased imports of industrial supplies, consumer goods, and a decline in exports of food, motor vehicles, and capital goods. Inventories fell 0.4% in October, tempering expectations of strong economic growth in the fourth quarter. This data could prompt economists to lower GDP estimates, with some predicting an annualized rate of 2.5% to 3.4%.

site_title: US-Cambodia debt issue raises questions of morality and humaneness
summary: The US-Cambodia debt issue raises questions of morality and humaneness, with the US refusing to forgive its $500 million debt despite its role in bombing Cambodia in the 1970s. Russia has made a gesture of goodwill by restructuring its $1.5 billion loan to Cambodia, while China has cancelled its $90 million loan. The US could take a page from Russia's book by restructuring its debt or follow China's approach of writing off the loan. Cambodia is reluctant to repay due to the US's role in the bombing and China's growing influence in the country.

site_title: Fed chair nominee Powell pledges to "respond decisively' to economic threats
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair nominee Jerome Powell pledged to respond decisively to economic threats, echoing the policies of current chair Janet Yellen and predecessor Ben Bernanke. Powell, a Fed governor since 2012, emphasized flexibility and independence in setting policy, while also committing to congressional oversight. He faced relatively smooth sailing during his Senate Banking Committee confirmation hearing, with Committee Chairman Mike Crapo calling him "qualified to lead the Fed." Powell also expressed willingness to ease regulatory burdens while preserving core reforms, and expects interest rates to rise further and the Fed's balance sheet to shrink.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler denies claims of diesel test-manipulation
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles has denied allegations of manipulating French diesel-emissions tests, stating the claims have no basis and its vehicles comply with the law. The company is cooperating with French authorities investigating "aggravated fraud" charges, which could result in a fine of up to 9.62 billion euros. This comes amid scrutiny of diesel models in Europe and the US following Volkswagen's admission of using defeat devices to turn off emissions controls. Fiat Chrysler has previously been sued by the US Justice Department over similar claims.

site_title: Hong Kong's Link REIT agrees to dispose properties worth nearly HK$23b
summary: Hong Kong's Link REIT has agreed to sell properties valued at nearly HK$23 billion (S$3.9 billion), generating net gains of about HK$7.39 billion. The asset sale comes as Chinese firms continue to aggressively buy land in Hong Kong, a trend seen in 2015, 2016, and 2017. Potential buyers include Blackstone, KKR, and Chinese investors. The sale does not mention any specific buyers, but it is expected to take place amidst the backdrop of intense competition in Hong Kong's expensive real estate market.

site_title: US$ at low on wait to hear Powell's comments
summary: The US dollar is near a two-month low, trading 0.2% higher at 93.03 against a broad trade-weighted basket of its rivals. Markets await the confirmation hearing of new Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, who is expected to signal gradual interest rate hikes. The Japanese yen has strengthened 3% against the US dollar this month, with some investment banks calling for a tactical trade in buying the currency due to stretched positioning and recent economic data. Powell's prepared remarks defended the Fed's crisis-fighting powers and signaled a willingness to move aggressively against downturns.

site_title: At Time Inc, a jittery reckoning on day after its sale to Meredith
summary: Time Inc, publisher of Time, Fortune, Sports Illustrated, and People, has been sold to Meredith Corp in a $2.8 billion deal. The sale has raised concerns among employees about the potential compromise of editorial integrity under new ownership. Despite assurances from Meredith's executives that there are no plans to sell Time Inc titles or move jobs, anxiety persists. The company has struggled to offset declines in print advertising and circulation, and layoffs are likely. Meredith's president said the iconic brands are "underperforming" and the company will review its portfolio, but no immediate decisions have been made.

site_title: Doing good with donated cigarettes
summary: A "Give up for Good" campaign in Singapore collected 2,774 cigarette sticks, exceeding its target of 2,000, to support cancer patients and their families. For each stick donated, sponsors pledged 60 cents to provide food items and necessities. The campaign, organized by local agency Up & Up and the Singapore Cancer Society, aimed to unite smokers, corporates, and cancer patients for a good cause. The event also featured a fitness challenge and encouraged smokers to consider quitting smoking for good.

site_title: SinoCloud signs convertible bond agreements with two separate investors
summary: SinoCloud Ltd, a Catalist-listed company, has signed convertible bond agreements with two separate investors, Lam Cho Ying Terence Joe and Soo Kok Beng Peter. The agreements total approximately S$2.26 million, with the bonds offering an interest rate of 12% per annum. Both investors had previously held SinoCloud's May 2015 convertible bonds and were approached to subscribe for the new bonds, which can be redeemed after a two-year period.

site_title: ETC starts lawsuit against majority shareholder and two companies
summary: ETC, a MYANMAR and China property developer, has filed a lawsuit in the Singapore High Court against its majority shareholder, Luo Shandong, and two companies, Dong Gang Industrial Co Ltd and Hunan Toener Investment Group Co Ltd, over unauthorized withdrawals of $24 million. The withdrawals occurred between July and October, with 118 million yuan transferred from a subsidiary without authorization. ETC is seeking damages, but has not quantified the loss.

site_title: Uncle of UK's duchess Kate sentenced after hitting wife
summary: Gary Goldsmith, uncle of Kate Middleton, was sentenced to a community order, 20 rehabilitation sessions, and a £5,000 fine after admitting to assaulting his wife, Julie-Ann, during a late-night argument in November. The court described Goldsmith's behavior as "like a nasty drunk," and he was also ordered to attend anger management sessions. The incident occurred after a night out, with both parties intoxicated, and resulted in Julie-Ann briefly losing consciousness. Goldsmith is the younger brother of Carole Middleton, the mother of the Duchess of Cambridge.

site_title: EuroSports JV firm enters into dealership to sell Lamborghinis in Jakarta
summary: EuroSports Global Ltd, a Singapore-listed supercar dealer, has announced a dealership deal with Lamborghini in Jakarta, Indonesia. Prosper Auto, a EuroSports-owned company, signed the deal on November 21, marking Lamborghini's entry into the Indonesian market. The partnership will see Prosper Auto market and sell Lamborghini automobiles, parts, and merchandise. EuroSports shares declined 2% after the announcement.

site_title: Pink diamond sells for over US$32m in Hong Kong
summary: A 14.93-carat pink diamond, known as the "Pink Promise," sold for US$32.16 million at an auction in Hong Kong, exceeding estimates of up to US$42 million. The sale, which drew applause, marked the second-highest price per carat paid for a pink diamond, behind the 2009 sale of a five-carat "Vivid Pink" for US$10.78 million. The sale reflects Hong Kong's status as a key center for jewelry auctions, despite an ongoing anti-corruption drive in mainland China.

site_title: German consumers' mood unruffled in December
summary: German consumers' confidence remains high at 10.7 in December, according to a GfK poll of 2,000 people. The result is slightly lower than in September and October, but still considered "good news" for the Christmas period. Consumers are optimistic about future economic growth but have lower expectations for their income and purchasing power. The stability of consumer confidence is seen as a positive sign despite the uncertainty surrounding the formation of a new government in Germany, with the current government expected to outlast the year.

site_title: China to set up system to monitor its firms overseas
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) issued guidelines for monitoring Chinese firms' and individuals' overseas activities to prevent tax evasion, money laundering, and reputational damage. The plan records instances of law-breaking and punishes offenders with penalties such as rejecting overseas investments and access to government subsidies. Records of infractions will be publicly available through the government's website. The guidelines aim to regulate Chinese firms' global investments and business activities, particularly through the Belt and Road initiative.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 5.44 points lower at 1,714.42 on Tuesday, with 613 losers outweighing 286 gainers. Volume reached 1.800 billion lots worth RM2.095 billion.

site_title: BRC Asia appoints Teo Ser Luck as non-executive chairman
summary: BRC Asia appoints 49-year-old Teo Ser Luck as non-executive chairman, effective November 28, replacing Sia Ling Ling, Lim Siak Meng, Lau Eng Tiong, and Foo Sey Liang. Teo is also an independent director of Serial System Ltd and United Engineers Limited. Xu Jiguo is appointed as an executive director.

site_title: Russia launches second rocket from new cosmodrome
summary: Russia successfully launched its second rocket from the Vostochny cosmodrome in the far east on November 28, 2017, marking another milestone in the country's efforts to modernize its space industry. The Soyuz rocket carried a weather satellite and 18 international payloads, with Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev stating that the launch will strengthen Russia's positions on the global market of space services. The third launch from Vostochny is scheduled for December 22, with plans to continue increasing the program's frequency and investment in 2018.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Temasek is exploring the sale of its US$1 billion stake in Asian drug distributor Zuellig Pharma. Singapore's GST is expected to rise by 2 percentage points in Budget 2018, according to DBS economist Irvin Seah. Fullerton Healthcare received an 800 million yuan investment from Ping An Capital, making it the company's second-largest investor. Completed condo prices in Singapore rose 0.6% in October, while the Straits Times Index advanced 0.2% on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.2% up on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.2% to 3,442.35 on Tuesday, with 2.01 billion shares worth S$1.2 billion changing hands. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally. Losers outnumbered gainers 263 to 169.

site_title: Iceberg claims Noble's balance sheet still can't be trusted
summary: Iceberg Research has attacked Noble Group, claiming its balance sheet numbers remain unreliable despite recognizing billions in impairment. The research outfit questions Noble's traders, valuation of assets, and liabilities, stating they are "drastically undervalued." Iceberg also casts doubt on Noble's investment in rare-earth exploration firm Mkango Resources, citing a significant discrepancy between the investment amount and the firm's market capitalization. To recover, Noble needs a new management with experienced traders and a risk management approach, according to Iceberg.

site_title: Credit Suisse's Thiam bullish on economy as regions grow in sync
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Tidjane Thiam expressed optimism about the global economy, citing the synchronized growth of the US, Asia, and Europe. Thiam stated that Credit Suisse is "very positive" about the world economy, despite challenges such as a multi-nation tax probe and activist investor pressure. The bank's shares have risen 15% this year, but are still down 31% since Thiam's overhaul plan was announced in 2015.

site_title: How Sun Park sold for S$81.09m in collective sale
summary: A subsidiary of SingHaiyi Group Ltd has sold the How Sun Park site for S$81.09 million through a collective sale, working out to S$1,092 per square foot per plot ratio. The site, comprising 20 townhouses, will receive approximately S$4.05 million per unit for the owners. The sale follows the recent transaction three months ago, with the last owner expected to provide consent within a few weeks to complete the sale.

site_title: OECD warns markets too optimistic as global economy peaks
summary: The OECD warns that global markets are overly optimistic, with asset prices exceeding expectations for growth. The global economy is expected to peak in 2018, with a 3.7% growth rate, before slowing to 3.6% in 2019. A market downturn could put the expansion at risk, and central banks and governments have limited capacity to react. The OECD Chief Economist, Catherine Mann, notes that financial asset prices are inconsistent with growth and policy stance, and a "sharp" correction is likely.

site_title: China to set up system to monitor its firms overseas
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission has issued guidelines to monitor the overseas activities of Chinese firms and individuals to prevent tax fraud, money laundering, and activities damaging to China's reputation. The guidelines, which were jointly issued by 28 government departments, will record instances of law-breaking and punish offenders. Overseas deals will be monitored for accuracy and reasonableness, and records of infractions will be available publicly. Authorities can reject applications for overseas investments, restrict access to government subsidies, and refuse to sell state land to companies that break rules.

site_title: Ipco expects net loss for H1 FY18 due to translation effects
summary: IPCO International expects a net loss for the first half year ended Oct 31, 2017, mainly due to translation effects on its foreign currency-denominated subsidiaries. The mainboard-listed construction company reported this in a filing to the Singapore Exchange. Translation effects refer to changes in exchange rates impacting the consolidated accounts of companies with businesses in different currencies. IPCO's forecast is based on a preliminary review of the draft unaudited consolidated financial results.

site_title: Water, electricity, McDonald's: Gazans hope for reconciliation
summary: In Gaza, Hamas is set to hand over power to the Palestinian Authority by Friday, marking a potential step towards reconciliation and easing humanitarian suffering. Gazans long for basic necessities like water, electricity, and the right to travel, which have been severely restricted by Israel's blockade. The move aims to improve living conditions and provide opportunities for education and employment, as residents face significant challenges and uncertainty about their future.

site_title: CapitaLand, CRCT in 49:51 tie-up to buy Rock Square mall in Guangzhou for 3.36b renminbi
summary: CapitaLand and CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) have formed a joint venture to acquire Rock Square mall in Guangzhou's Haizhu District for 3.36 billion renminbi (S$688.9 million). CRCT holds a 51% stake, while CapitaLand owns 49%. The mall, opened in 2013, offers international brands and entertainment options, with 96.4% of space committed as of June 2017. The transaction is expected to be completed by Q1 2018.

site_title: BOJ returns to net profit on weak yen, surge in ETF holdings
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) reported a net profit of 550.2 billion yen in the first half of fiscal 2017, reversing a net loss of 200.2 billion yen from the same period last year. A weak yen boosted the value of the central bank's foreign assets, while its ETF holdings surged 62.2% to 15.8 trillion yen, reaching a record high of 4.3 trillion yen in unrealised profits. Profits from government bond holdings fell for the second year in a row due to aggressive stimulus.

site_title: Accrelist offsets outstanding loans to Jubilee against its entitlement for rights and warrants issue
summary: Accrelist has agreed to offset an outstanding loan of S$10.9 million to Jubilee Industries Holdings, the parent company of precision manufacturer Jubilee Industries Holdings, against the cost of Accrelist's S$9.8 million entitlement under Jubilee's proposed rights cum warrants issue. The remaining amount of S$1.1 million will be owed to Accrelist, which may be offset by Accrelist's subscription for excess rights shares with warrants if not subscribed by other shareholders. The rights cum warrants issue aims to raise S$15.03 million for Jubilee, with 40% for working capital and 30% for merger and acquisition activities.

site_title: BOE's Carney says wants clarity on CEO spat at London Stock Exchange
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney expressed his desire for clarity on the London Stock Exchange's (LSE) CEO succession plan, stating he's "mystified" by the debate. TCI has ordered a shareholder vote to oust LSE Chairman Donald Brydon over his handling of the Rolet departure. The LSE is set to hold a shareholder meeting before year-end to vote on TCI's proposal, which Carney believes is in the interest of all parties involved.

site_title: Airbus confirms hiring Rolls-Royce executive to head aircraft sales
summary: Airbus has hired Eric Schulz, the head of Rolls-Royce's civil engines unit, to lead its commercial aircraft sales. Schulz, a 54-year-old French engineer, will replace John Leahy, a veteran dealmaker who has been in the sales post since 1994. Schulz joins Airbus in January 2018, bringing broad international experience and a proven track record in leading complex organizations. The move comes amid uncertainty over Leahy's succession and a sales organization seeking stability amid corruption probes. Airbus chief executive Tom Enders welcomed Schulz's appointment, citing his expertise in the aerospace industry.

site_title: Perennial China Investments incorporates fellow subsidiary
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings Ltd announced that its Perennial China Investments Holdings subsidiary has incorporated Peng Xi (Beijing) Eldercare Co Ltd, a registered capital of 100 million yuan (S$20.4 million), in China. Peng Xi is an eldercare and retirement home developer and manager. This move follows the company's integration strategy. Perennial shares rose 0.6% to S$0.845 on Tuesday.

site_title: Chrysler rejects French diesel test-manipulation claims
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) has denied allegations that it manipulated French diesel-emissions tests, stating that the claims have no basis and its vehicles comply with the law. The allegations appear in a report from France's anti-fraud office, but FCA has not been charged with any offense and is cooperating with French authorities. The probe also includes Peugeot SA, Renault SA, and Volkswagen AG, which were opened in March.

site_title: Crunch looms as house correction puts some Canadians under water
summary: Canada's housing market is experiencing a correction, with some buyers facing "being under water" as home prices drop. The Toronto market, particularly, has seen a 15% decline in average house prices since April, with lenders tightening credit and reducing home equity lines of credit. Experts warn of a potential 5% price decline in 2018, citing rising interest rates and record household debt. Insolvency experts predict a "scary year" ahead, as mortgage stress tests and credit tightening further dampen demand.

site_title: Microsoft, SAP to use and sell more of each other's cloud services
summary: Microsoft and SAP have agreed to expand the use of each other's cloud services, with Microsoft using SAP's S/4 HANA database and SAP running its internal financial systems on Microsoft's Azure cloud service. The partnership aims to encourage joint customers, including Coca-Cola and Coats, to run SAP software on Azure. This integration follows previous agreements to integrate Microsoft Office 365 into SAP and run SAP's HANA database on Azure. The move is designed to promote the use of cloud-based products and services across both companies' customer bases.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise; won reverses on exporter US dollar-selling
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.3% to 2,514.19, while the Korean won reversed earlier losses and edged up 0.4% to 1,084.4 per US dollar. The currency's reversal came after exporters heavily sold dollars. The KOSPI has risen 23.9% so far this year and 0.49% in the past 30 days.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks dip but Shanghai edges up
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index closed at 29,680.85, down 5.34 points, following a weak lead from Wall Street. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.34% to 3,333.66, and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 1.35% to 1,918.32. The dip was attributed to an oil sell-off affecting energy firms.

site_title: Organic chicken boom spurs Whole Foods supplier to triple output
summary: Bell & Evans, a US chicken brand, plans to triple its organic chicken production by opening a new 560,000-square-foot plant in Pennsylvania. The facility, set to open in early 2020, will process 2.6 million birds a week, driven by the booming organic chicken market. American farm sales of organic chicken increased 78% last year to $750 million, making chicken the third-largest organic agricultural commodity. The new plant will also source organic feed-grain domestically and transition all its birds to a slower-growing breed for improved flavor and animal welfare.

site_title: Indonesian tycoon says he has no plans to run for president
summary: Indonesian business tycoon Hary Tanoesoedibjo stated he has no plans to run for president in the 2019 election, and would support current President Joko Widodo if he chooses to run again. Tanoesoedibjo, who founded his own political party in 2015, believes Widodo is the strongest candidate due to his moderate and nationalist stance. He also plans to list a division of his company, MNC Studios International, on the Jakarta stock exchange next year.

site_title: Shell calls end to austerity with return to full dividend
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has ended its austerity dividend policy, cancelling its scrip dividend scheme introduced in 2015, and plans to resume a share buyback program. The move comes as the company boosts its cash generation forecasts and lowers debt. Shell's dividend payouts in the 12 months to September totaled US$15 billion, with the scrip accounting for around a quarter. The company aims to reduce its debt-to-equity ratio to 20% by 2020.

site_title: Philippines' second-biggest bank penalised for US$35m fraud
summary: The Philippine central bank sanctioned Metropolitan Bank & Trust for an alleged internal fraud that cost the lender 1.75 billion pesos (S$47.1 million). The bank was ordered to allocate 4.45 billion pesos to cover higher operational risk and to reprimand or suspend directors and officers who were complacent in their duties. A single official was arrested and found to have funnelled loans into fictitious accounts, with no customer affected. The bank accepted accountability and will implement corrective actions.

images.alt_text: The Philippine central bank sanctioned Metropolitan Bank & Trust after the regulator investigated an alleged internal fraud that cost the lender 1.75 billion pesos (S$47.1 million).

site_title: Saudi 'Matchstick' TV host takes over state broadcaster
summary: Saudi state broadcaster to be led by firebrand TV host Dawood Shirian, nicknamed "matchstick" for his outspoken personality. Shirian, 63, spent six years hosting "Al Thamina" on MBC, known for his hard-hitting style and tackling sensitive issues like joblessness and extremism. His appointment as head of the Saudi Broadcasting Corporation could shake up the country's traditionally sedate state television and radio channels, with many hoping for further scrutiny of officials and policies. Shirian's intentions are unclear, but his past suggests a willingness to challenge authority.

site_title: Jumbo opens fifth outlet in China
summary: Jumbo Group Ltd, a Catalist-listed restaurant group, announced the opening of its fifth Jumbo seafood outlet in China, located in downtown Shanghai. The outlet, occupying 820 square meters, has a seating capacity of 212 and seven private rooms. The expansion is part of the group's strategy to grow its presence in the Chinese food and beverage market, with revenue from Chinese outlets increasing to 17.5% in FY17. The group expects to open more outlets in China in the coming years, driven by the success of its brand in the market.

site_title: Cathay to focus on property business, lend iconic name to mm2 Asia's Singapore cinema operations
summary: Cathay Organisation sold its iconic cinema chain and brand to mm2 Asia for S$230 million. The sale marks a shift in focus for Cathay, which will now prioritize its property business. mm2 Asia plans to collaborate with studios, leveraging the Cathay brand's reputation, and may retain the name for its Singapore operations. Cathay will also wind down its film distribution business as part of the sale agreement. The deal allows mm2 Asia to expand its presence in the Chinese market and grow regionally.

site_title: Shanghai schools fly the flag for China's next generation
summary: In Shanghai, primary schools are teaching the next generation of Chinese with a focus on core subjects, cultural traditions, and extracurricular activities such as sports and dance. The city's pupils have recently excelled in worldwide standardized tests, drawing Western interest in China's education system. As part of this, schools are incorporating unique subjects like tea-making and hip-hop dancing into their curricula. This emphasis on well-rounded education aims to produce a skilled and culturally aware generation of Chinese citizens.

site_title: London homes less affordable than ever at 14.5 times earnings
summary: London home prices have reached a record high, with the average home costing 14.5 times the average annual salary. Despite slowing price growth, the capital remains unaffordable, with prices up 66% since 2012. The gap between average earnings and house prices has never been wider. Chancellor Philip Hammond's attempt to address the issue by abolishing stamp duty for first-time buyers of homes up to £300,000 is unlikely to significantly impact affordability, according to research director Richard Donnell. Affordability remains a significant challenge for first-time buyers in London.

site_title: Brexit means camping as UK leisure stocks get staycation
summary: The UK's decision to leave the EU has led to a surge in domestic "staycations" as Brits opt for camping, hotel stays, and other leisure activities at home. Retailers such as Halfords and Fuller Smith & Turner have seen increased sales in camping equipment and hotel bookings, respectively. Stocks like JD Sports, Cineworld, and Hollywood Bowl are also benefiting from the trend. In contrast, some leisure operators, like Merlin Entertainments, have seen their shares decline due to concerns over terrorism threats.

site_title: Broker's take: Phillip maintains 'reject' call on Cogent privatisation bid after Q3 results
summary: Phillip Capital maintains its 'reject' call on Cosco Shipping International's privatization bid for Cogent Holdings after the company announced its Q3 earnings. The broker advises minority shareholders to take partial profits to avoid tying up capital. If the delisting is successful, minority shareholders will receive S$1.02 per share, but will remain shareholders of Cogent. The offer expires on January 5.

site_title: Lian Beng subsidiary bags S$136.8m contract for proposed development at Potong Pasir
summary: Lian Beng Construction (1988) Pte Ltd, a subsidiary of Lian Beng Group Ltd, secured an S$136.8 million contract for a proposed condominium development in Singapore. The project, located on Lot 06521X MK17 at Potong Pasir Avenue 1, will feature three 20-storey, two 19-storey, and four eight-storey residential blocks with car parks and ancillary facilities. The contract was secured through a tender from UVD (Projects) Pte Ltd.

site_title: Singapore shares resume higher on Tuesday afternoon; STI at 3,432.54, down 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore shares closed at 3,432.54 on Tuesday, down 0.1% from the previous day's close, with the Straits Times Index (STI) marginally higher against the benchmark level. Trading volume was 913.9 million shares worth S$505.4 million. Key movers included Ying Li International, up 6%, and Allied Technologies, up 4.41%, while DBS Group Holdings declined 1.09%.

site_title: Financials, commodities weigh on Australia shares; NZ lower
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index down 0.07% due to declines in financials and commodity-related stocks. Utilities and consumer staples sectors led gains, with Origin Energy and Woolworths Ltd rising 2.4% and 1.9%, respectively. Financial stocks, including Westpac Banking Corp and National Australia Bank, fell 0.9% and 0.8%, respectively. In New Zealand, the benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index ended 0.4% lower.

site_title: Airlines scramble to minimise losses as Bali volcano costs grow
summary: Airlines in Indonesia are scrambling to minimize losses as Bali's airport remains closed due to volcanic ash from Mount Agung. The shutdown has disrupted over 500 flights and tens of thousands of passengers, with airlines offering alternative routes and transport options. Industry experts predict potential long-term adjustments to flight frequencies and losses of up to $5 million per day. Airlines are also bracing for forward bookings to collapse and re-deploying capacity to less profitable destinations.

site_title: Singapore's completed condo prices up 0.6% in October from September: NUS
summary: Singapore's completed condo prices rose 0.6% in October, exceeding the 0.2% increase seen in September. The central region saw a 1.2% increase, while the non-central region rose 0.3%. Small units, however, declined 0.8% after a 1% gain in September. Year-over-year, prices are up 2.4% from October last year, following a 3.2% increase so far this year.

site_title: Bitcoin, an 'Uber' currency, not without risk
summary: Bitcoin, now trading over $8,000, bypasses central bank regulation, making it attractive for financially fragile countries and potentially vulnerable to risks and dangers. Despite its soaring value, economists warn of the lack of oversight, potential illicit use, and speculative nature of the currency, likening it to a "bubble." Regulators, including the International Monetary Fund, have expressed concerns, while some investors see it as a potential alternative to traditional currencies, particularly in countries with weak institutions.

site_title: IE Singapore CEO Lee Ark Boon to step down on Dec 31
summary: IE Singapore CEO Lee Ark Boon is stepping down on Dec 31 to join the private sector. Deputy Chief Kathy Lai will serve as acting CEO from Jan 1, 2018, until the formation of Enterprise Singapore in Q2 next year. The new agency will merge IE Singapore and Spring Singapore to support companies' growth and internationalization.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee Ark Boon (left) will step down as the CEO of IE Singapore, on Dec 31. Ms Kathy Lai will take over as Acting CEO with effect from Jan 1.

site_title: UK banks could cope with "disorderly" Brexit, BOE says
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) has stated that UK banks could cope with a "disorderly" Brexit without needing to curb lending or be bailed out by taxpayers, according to its annual health check. None of Britain's major lenders failed the stress test, with HSBC, Lloyds Banking Group, and others passing without reservations. The BOE also plans to raise a risk buffer to 1% from 0.5% to better prepare for potential financial risks, including Brexit and global economic downturns.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down over North Korea missile concern
summary: Tokyo stocks declined on November 28, 2017, due to concerns over North Korea's missile activity. The benchmark fell 0.04% to close at 22,486.24, while the Topix index dropped 0.26%. The decline was attributed to media reports that Japan had detected signs of activity at a North Korean missile site, weighing on investor sentiment.

site_title: Pressured for profit, oil majors bet big on shale technology
summary: Major oil companies are investing heavily in shale technology to reduce costs and increase efficiency. By adopting automation and digitalization, they aim to bring more wells to production at lower costs, potentially boosting future output and profits. Companies like Royal Dutch Shell and Chevron Corp are using drones, sensors, and advanced software to optimize drilling operations, and some are even using medical imaging techniques like MRI to pinpoint high-potential areas. The goal is to cut the cost of drilling a new shale well from $5.9 million to less than $4 million by the end of the decade.

images.alt_text: Portillo works from a Royal Dutch Shell Plc office in suburban Houston, his eyes darting among 13 monitors flashing data on speed, temperature and other metrics as he helps control rigs more than 500 miles (805 km) away in the Permian Basin, the largest U.S. oilfield.

site_title: Temasek said to prepare US$1b Zuellig Pharma stake sale
summary: Temasek Holdings is exploring the sale of its 20% stake in Zuellig Pharma, a Singapore-based pharmaceutical distributor, for approximately US$1 billion. The sale would be handled by Temasek's advisers, and potential buyers include Mitsui & Co and private equity firms. The move comes after the death of family patriarch Stephen Zuellig in January, which fueled speculation about the company's future. A sale would be a significant development for Zuellig Pharma, which has US$10 billion in annual sales and operates in about a dozen Asian markets.

site_title: Competition Commission fines companies for rigging F1 tender
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore fined several companies for bid-rigging in tenders for the Singapore Formula 1 Grand Prix and an international school. The companies, including Cyclect Group, HPH Engineering, and Peak Top Engineering, were found to have colluded to submit higher bids, distorting the competitive bidding process. The fines total more than S$559,290 for Cyclect Group and S$55,128 for HPH, with Peak Top paying S$21,693. The firms have a two-month window to appeal the decisions.

site_title: Siemens, Trimble, Moody's breached by Chinese hackers, US charges
summary: US prosecutors have charged three Chinese citizens, Wu Yingzhuo, Dong Hao, and Xia Lei, for breaching the networks of Siemens AG, Trimble Inc, and Moody's Analytics between 2011 and this year. The hackers stole business secrets, monitored email correspondence, and targeted specific companies. The indictment, filed in September, does not indicate state sponsorship. Trimble stated no clients were breached, while Moody's said no confidential customer data was compromised. The defendants are not in custody and were identified as owners, employees, and associates of a Chinese cyber security firm.

images.alt_text: Three people affiliated with a Chinese cyber security firm hacked into the networks of Siemens AG, Trimble Inc and Moody's Analytics to steal business secrets, US prosecutors said on Monday.

site_title: Giant block trade made in coal miner Geo Energy
summary: A block trade of 44.65 million shares in Geo Energy Resources crossed at S$0.25, with the stock rising to S$0.265. The company reported nine-month profits of US$33.3 million, up 342% from last year, and revenue increased by 148%. A Phillip Securities Research report maintained a "buy" call with a target price of S$0.44, citing strong coal prices and China's restrictions on domestic coal production.

site_title: Chinese general commits suicide after facing graft probe: Xinhua
summary: A Chinese general, Zhang Yang, a member of the Central Military Commission, committed suicide after being investigated over his links to corrupt former military officers. Zhang was director of the commission's general political department and was suspected of bribery and taking bribes. This is the latest official to be ensnared in President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption campaign, which has brought down 1.5 million Communist Party officials and top military brass since 2012. Zhang's actions were deemed "gravely violating disciplinary protocols and breaking the law".

site_title: GST could go up 2 percentage points in Singapore Budget 2018: DBS economist
summary: Singapore's Goods and Services Tax (GST) is expected to be raised by 2 percentage points in Budget 2018 to help meet growing spending needs, according to DBS economist Irvin Seah. The hike, implemented over two years, aims to cushion the impact on households. With tax revenues unlikely to come from corporate tax rates, the GST is considered the most direct and effective tool for raising revenue. A one percentage point hike could raise tax revenue by S$1.6 billion to S$1.8 billion, equivalent to 0.4% of Singapore's nominal GDP.

site_title: Singapore wins bid to host Rotary International Convention 2024, its largest-ever association congress
summary: Singapore has won the provisional bid to host the Rotary International Convention 2024, a five-day event expected to attract over 25,000 Rotary members worldwide. The convention will be held at the Singapore Expo Convention and Exhibition Centre, marking Singapore's largest association congress to date. The bid was led by Rotary regional leader Chew Ghim Bok and supported by various public agencies and industry stakeholders. The event aims to promote cultural diversity and address global humanitarian challenges, with a focus on sustainability and legacy projects, such as sanitation progress and hygiene awareness.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge up led by Shell, Ocado rally
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Tuesday, led by gains in Royal Dutch Shell and Ocado. Shell rose 1.8% after cancelling austerity dividend plans, while Ocado shares surged 26% after signing a deal with French supermarket Casino to develop its online business. The pan-European STOXX 600 index and oil and gas index also saw gains.

site_title: Artificial muscles give 'superpower' to robots
summary: US researchers have developed cheap, artificial muscles for robots that can lift up to 1,000 times their own weight, giving them "superpowers." Inspired by origami, the muscles are built on a framework of metal coils or plastic sheets and cost around $1 to make. They can contract and expand using vacuum-powered air or water pressure, allowing for a range of movements. The technology has potential applications in soft robotics, space exploration, and wearable exoskeletons, and could revolutionize robotics.

site_title: China Taisan says still awaiting nod from Fujian government to resume normal production
summary: China Taisan Technology Group Holdings, a fabric manufacturer, is awaiting permission from the Fujian government to resume normal production levels after being ordered to cut back in July 2017 due to non-compliance with China's Central Environmental Inspection Group. The company is upgrading its water recycle and air purification systems to ensure compliance. China Taisan has been on the distressed watch list since June and has faced various queries from the Singapore Exchange regarding its financial and operational issues.

site_title: Brazil's scouts search for future Neymars
summary: Brazilian scouts search for young football talent, including potential future stars, at a trial for youngsters at Rio de Janeiro's Vasco da Gama football club. Over 200 children aged 9-17 participated in the trial, with scouts looking for players with talent and the ability to play in a team without individualism. Only 10% of the boys are expected to pass the first set of trials, with the next series of tests taking place at the club headquarters. The scouts emphasize the importance of finding talent in Brazil's favelas, where many children play football on rough pitches.

site_title: China racing for AI military edge over US: report
summary: China is rapidly advancing in artificial intelligence, aiming to catch up to the US and potentially gain a military edge. A recent report by the Center for a New American Security highlights China's growing capabilities in AI, citing its national plan to become the world's primary AI innovation center within years. China's start-up Yitu Tech won a US$25,000 prize in a facial recognition competition, and the People's Liberation Army is investing in various AI-related projects, potentially altering the battlefield. The US and China are now in a "true peer" competition, with potential implications for future economic and military balances of power.

site_title: Asian investors shift tentatively as Shanghai, US tax fuel unease
summary: Asian investors shifted cautiously on Tuesday, with Chinese stocks under renewed pressure due to concerns about valuations and Beijing's crackdown on risky dealing. Shanghai's benchmark index fell 0.1% and Hong Kong lost 0.3% as analysts note a lack of intervention by state-backed firms to support key issues. The US tax reform is also causing unease, with Republican infighting threatening to block the bill and potential failure leading to a global market correction.

site_title: Hot stock: Developer Ying Li up 6% on Chongqing project divestment
summary: Chinese property developer Ying Li's stock rose 6% in early trading on November 28, 2017, after announcing the divestment of its stake in a project in Chongqing's central business district. The company sold its stake in the Ying Li International Commercial Centre Project to China Evergrande-linked Shengyu (BVI) Limited for 3.29 billion yuan. The sale is expected to help realize the capital value of the project and strengthen the company's finances.

site_title: Extension of cuts expected at Opec meeting
summary: OPEC producers are expected to extend their deal to curb oil production, despite Russia's reported hesitation, at a meeting in Vienna on Thursday. The current agreement, set to expire on March 31, 2018, has already been extended once. A prolonged extension would reduce production by 1.8 million barrels per day, supporting higher oil prices. However, Russia's reluctance to commit to the deal could lead to market disappointment.

images.alt_text: With oil prices nudging steadily higher, market expectations are for crude-pumping countries to prolong their deal to curb output at a meeting at Opec headquarters in Vienna on Thursday.

site_title: Amazon and Wal-Mart shift from deal-seekers to procrastinators
summary: Amazon and Wal-Mart are shifting their focus from competing on price to convenience and speed, particularly for procrastinators who wait until the last minute to shop. As Christmas approaches, retailers are prioritizing making items easily available, with Amazon relying on its quick delivery and Wal-Mart on its in-store pickup services. Cyber Monday online spending is on track to reach a new high of $6.59 billion, with Amazon dominating the market, having won online spending on Thanksgiving and Black Friday.

site_title: Singapore chartered accountants body to co-develop accountancy sector in Myanmar
summary: Singapore's Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA) signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Myanmar Institute of Certified Public Accountants (MICPA) to co-develop the accountancy sector in Myanmar. The partnership aims to build capability through training on accounting principles, IFRS, and continual professional education. ISCA will also provide training on the ISCA Audit Manual and Micro Accounting Model. The move is expected to improve financial reporting quality and enhance investor confidence in Myanmar, with about 90% of the country's 30,000 companies being small and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: Singapore is losing home advantage in IPO battle with Hong Kong
summary: Singapore is losing its home advantage in the initial public offering (IPO) battle with Hong Kong, with 14 Singaporean companies choosing to list on Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing this year, compared to 13 on the Singapore Exchange. Despite this, Singapore's bourse raised more funds from IPOs, with US$2.54 billion compared to Hong Kong's US$677 million.

site_title: EU seeks to head off new aircraft emissions dispute
summary: The European Union is embroiled in a debate over the application of new aircraft emissions rules, adopted by global regulators last year. The EU's European Parliament and member states will meet to discuss how to implement the rules, with environmentalists arguing they don't go far enough. The EU's proposal to reform the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) to impose stricter CO2 emission standards is at odds with EU member states, who want to stick to the ICAO agreement. The debate could reopen friction between environmental campaigners and Airbus, which has accused the EU of leaning on the Commission to weaken its policy.

images.alt_text: More than 18 months after global regulators adopted emissions rules for commercial aircraft, the European Union is embroiled in an internal debate over how they should be applied in a row that could have consequences for current Airbus models.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine to seek shareholders' nod for restructuring plan on Dec 14
summary: Marco Polo Marine to seek shareholders' approval for a restructuring plan on Dec 14, which includes issuing 2.1 billion new shares to nine investors and 1 billion shares to creditors. Control of the company will shift to Apricot Capital, a private investment firm linked to Super Group's Teo family.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks edge up, won weakens slightly
