summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.19% on Monday, closing at 3,435.66, with 797.5 million shares traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 185 to 134. Midas Holdings and KrisEnergy were among the top gainers, while DBS Group Holdings and Singtel fell 1.28% and 0.54% respectively. The Straits Times Index (STI) has been on a 5-day rally ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Cyber Monday showdown: Wal-Mart closes in on Amazon in online price war
summary: Wal-Mart is closing the gap with Amazon in the online price war, with its prices now only 0.3% more expensive than Amazon's on average. The company has invested over $1 billion to make its pricing more competitive, and its online sales have grown 50% year-over-year. Wal-Mart is now within striking distance of matching Amazon's online prices, a key milestone in its effort to regain the "low price leader" title. The company's consistent price cuts are expected to boost sales throughout the year, but analysts estimate it will need to invest around $6 billion over several years to maintain price parity with Amazon.

site_title: US oil dips on increased drilling, but Opec cuts support global markets
summary: US oil prices dropped 0.5% to $58.65 a barrel, easing from two-year highs, amid increased US output and expectations of an extended Opec-led supply cut. US crude production has risen 15% since 2016, with new drilling activity expected to drive further growth. Opec is set to meet on November 30 to discuss extending its production cuts, which currently expire in March 2018, but Russia's commitment to cuts is uncertain. This uncertainty and rising US production are preventing crude prices from rising further, with traders warning of potential volatility.

site_title: Sri Lanka to release 50 acres of capital land for investments
summary: Sri Lanka plans to release nearly 50 acres of state-owned land in Colombo's commercial area for investments, aiming to attract US$2.5 billion in foreign direct investments next year. The move aims to address land scarcity and restrictions for foreign investors. The government will offer 99-year leases for at least 1.92 billion rupees (S$16.6 million) per acre, targeting tourism, leisure, and mixed development projects. This is part of a broader effort to increase foreign investment in the country.

site_title: World's priciest home market defying doomsayers into '18
summary: Hong Kong's housing market continues to defy predictions of a bubble bursting, with prices rising 11% this year. Despite government efforts to curb the market, investors are pouring money into properties, and buyers are setting new records for luxury homes and undeveloped land. The frenzy has intensified, with blockbuster deals for commercial property in the city's central district. The market shows no signs of slowing down, with prices expected to continue to rise.

site_title: Early China indicators signal economy cooled in November
summary: China's economy showed mixed signals in November, with sales managers and steel producers losing confidence, while small businesses improved their sentiment. The country's leaders are pushing for sustainable growth, and economists expect a slowdown in the long term, with GDP growth projected to decelerate from 6.8% in 2017 to 6.4% in 2018. Private indicators suggest a slower rate of growth, with the construction sector and manufacturing indices showing a decline.

images.alt_text: Confidence among China's sales managers and steel producers waned in November, matching the mood among international investors, while sentiment among small businesses improved, according to the earliest available indicators.

site_title: Japan plans extra budget of US$24-26b for fiscal 2017: sources
summary: Japan plans to compile an extra budget of 2.7-2.9 trillion yen (S$32.3-35 billion) for fiscal 2018, primarily to fund spending on childcare support, productivity, and farm, fishery, and forestry industries. The government will issue 1 trillion yen in bonds and use cash reserves and unused debt servicing funds to cover the spending. No deficit-covering bond issuance is planned, following Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's cabinet's election win.

site_title: Hong Kong money market rates jump to near 9-year highs
summary: Hong Kong's three-month interbank rates surged to 1.06%, a near 9-year high, driven by strong demand for the Hong Kong dollar amid a hot stock market and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's efforts to stabilize the currency. The central bank's issuance of Exchange Fund Bills since August and recent IPOs have contributed to the increased demand. The rates are now at their highest level since 2009, reflecting the market's expectation of currency stability.

site_title: Monet's glasses sold for over US$50,000 in Hong Kong
summary: Claude Monet's personal belongings, including a pair of gold-coloured wire spectacles, sold for nearly US$11 million at an auction in Hong Kong, exceeding Christie's estimate of US$1,000 to US$1,500. The collection, which included paintings, sketches, and Japanese woodblock prints, was purchased by an Asian buyer. The top lots sold for well above their estimated prices, with an oil painting of a cliff face fetching US$4.6 million. The sale highlights the continued demand for Monet's artworks, which have broken world auction records, including a record US$81.4 million for "Meule" last year.

site_title: Two bodies, possibly North Korean, found on Japan coast
summary: Two decomposed bodies, possibly North Korean fishermen, were found on a beach in central Japan's Niigata prefecture. The discovery comes after a group of eight fishermen, claiming to be from North Korea, washed up on Japan's northern coast just days prior. Authorities found North Korean tobacco, boat parts, and life jackets near the bodies, and a wrecked wooden boat with squid-fishing equipment also contained Korean words. The link between the bodies and the boat is being investigated, with dozens of North Korean fishing vessels washing up on Japan's coast every year due to government mandates and equipment issues.

site_title: Xi wants China to spruce up toilets to boost tourism, quality of life
summary: China's President Xi Jinping emphasized the need to complete the "toilet revolution" by upgrading 64,000 toilets between 2018 and 2020 to boost domestic tourism and improve quality of life. The initiative, launched in 2015, aims to create a more civilised society by addressing the country's sanitation issues. Since 2012, Xi has visited rural areas to promote modernisation, including the use of sanitary toilets. China has already upgraded 68,000 toilets, completing about 19% of the task. The project is part of Xi's broader efforts to improve the country's tourism industry and satisfy people's desire for a "nice life".

site_title: Samsung Elec shares drop after M.Stanley cuts view, sees chip boom peaking
summary: Samsung Electronics shares fell 4.2% to a one-month low after Morgan Stanley downgraded its view of the company to "equal weight" from "overweight", citing concerns that a memory chip "super-cycle" may peak soon. The downgrade trimmed Samsung's price target by 3.4% to 2.8 million won. Analysts say Samsung is less affected by predicted trends in chip prices, with its strong position in NAND chips for data centre SSDs. The company expects a tight supply-demand position in the NAND and DRAM space in 2018.

site_title: Sailors replace soldiers at royal palaces to celebrate navy
summary: Sailors from Britain's Royal Navy performed the changing of the guard ceremony outside Buckingham Palace for the first time in 357 years, marking the start of "year of the navy" celebrations in 2017. The 48 sailors, dressed in traditional blue uniforms, replaced Foot Guards and will serve as guards at various royal palaces until the end of the month. The move is seen as a sign of the Royal Navy's return to its roots, with Admiral Sir Philip Jones praising the deployment as a demonstration of the navy's presence in national life.

images.alt_text: Sailors from Britain's Royal Navy performed the changing of the guard ceremony outside Buckingham Palace on Sunday for the first time in the famous drill's 357-year history.

site_title: SPH Buzz, Mastercard launch hybrid convenience store
summary: Mastercard and SPH Buzz have launched a hybrid convenience store featuring attended and unattended retail counters. The store, located at a gas station, offers a range of items, including beverages, meals, snacks, and medication, using Masterpass, a secure digital payment service. Customers can use their smart devices to order and pay for goods, reducing wait time and friction. The store will offer special deals until December 31, and Mastercard aims to improve the convenience experience for consumers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.13 points to 1,717.36. Volume reached 115.07 million lots worth RM38.78 million, with 124 gainers and 94 losers.

site_title: Airbus set to poach Rolls exec to head jetliner sales: sources
summary: Airbus is set to hire Rolls-Royce executive Eric Schulz to lead its commercial jetliner sales, replacing John Leahy who is expected to retire in January. Schulz, a 54-year-old French engineer, has been recommended for the role to bring in outside blood amid turmoil over UK and French corruption investigations. He will aim to restore staff morale and rebuild customer relationships following a wobbly Dubai Airshow and recent defeats against Boeing. Schulz's independent career path may give him a freer hand to shape the marketing machine, which has been in need of a fresh spark.

site_title: Mumbai Airport's flight record shows surge in India air travel
summary: Mumbai Airport set a world record for the most flights handled in 24 hours, with 969 flights on Friday. The airport, operating on a single runway, is fueling India's growing air travel market, driven by rising incomes and cheaper fares from budget carriers. India is expected to become the third-largest aviation market, with 337 million additional passengers forecasted over the next two decades. Only 3% of India's 1.3 billion population has flown, offering significant growth potential, according to low-cost airline SpiceJet.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks began the week with a decline, with the Hang Seng Index down 0.19% and the Shanghai Composite Index easing 0.21%. Investors await key manufacturing indicators later in the week. The Shenzhen Composite Index also fell 0.24%.

site_title: Hot stock: Lippo Malls down 8% to eight-month low of S$0.395
summary: Lippo Malls, an Indonesian retail mall owner, has fallen 8% to its lowest point since March, closing at S$0.395. The decline occurred without any announced news, with large blocks of shares changing hands before the break. The company had previously confirmed plans to consider a rights issue to fund acquisitions and reduce debt, but stated it did not expect any equity fundraising this year. Over 25 million shares were traded, boosting the Reit to among the top stocks by value traded on Monday.

site_title: South African self-defence trainer crowned Miss Universe
summary: Demi-Leigh Nel-Peters, a 22-year-old South African self-defence trainer, was crowned Miss Universe in Las Vegas. Nel-Peters, who recently earned a business management degree, was crowned after being hijacked and held at gunpoint in South Africa. She was crowned by current Miss Universe Iris Mittenaere, with Laura González from Colombia and Davina Bennett from Jamaica as the first and second runner-ups, respectively.

site_title: Singapore services business receipts grow 6.3% in Q3
summary: Singapore's services sector business receipts grew 6.3% in Q3 2017, with all industries reporting growth. The information and communications sector saw the largest improvement, increasing by 13.6%, followed by health & social services at 9.2%. On a quarterly basis, receipts rose 0.9% from Q2. The growth reflects an improved global outlook and a strengthening economy.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades a-iTrust to 'buy' on warehouse acquisitions
summary: DBS Equity Research upgraded Ascendas India Trust (a-iTrust) to a "buy" rating, citing the acquisition of warehouses as a transformative transaction that will drive growth. Analysts expect a three-year distribution CAGR of 9%, surpassing the average Singapore Reit. The acquisition, combined with redevelopments, and access to land-bank and sponsor pipeline, support long-term growth potential. A revised target price of S$1.25 was set, reflecting the upgraded call.

site_title: Asia: Markets kick week off with losses but euro holds gains
summary: Asian markets fell on Monday, with Shanghai slipping 0.7% and Hong Kong losing 0.5%, despite the euro holding gains due to healthy economic data in Germany and hopes for a government deal. The euro surged on Friday after a gauge of the German business climate hit an all-time high, and investors are now focusing on key data releases this week from China to the US. Oil prices retreated after Friday's gains, and markets are watching for the senate hearing for Jerome Powell, Donald Trump's pick as the next Fed boss.

site_title: China pork price slide seen forcing U.S. Smithfield to boost exports elsewhere
summary: China's pork prices are expected to drop sharply in 2018, reaching a bottom in the second quarter, due to a rapid expansion by large farms offsetting the closure of small family-run operations. This decline in prices is expected to curb demand for imports from the US, particularly from Smithfield, which has already boosted sales to Mexico, Japan, and South Korea. Despite this, WH Group, the parent company of Smithfield, expects Chinese imports to continue in the long term due to the country's huge demand and relatively high production costs.

site_title: Singapore workers fall short in global survey on taking responsibility for upgrading own skills: Randstad
summary: Singapore workers fall short of the global average in taking responsibility for upgrading their own skills, with 83% of employees ready to take the initiative despite numerous learning and development programs available. This ranks Singapore lower than Hong Kong (91%) and Malaysia (96%), according to the Randstad Workmonitor survey. While Singapore employees are more inclined to sign up for curriculum courses, they are less likely to search and pay for programs themselves compared to Malaysian workers, who prioritize personal responsibility for skill upgrades.

site_title: UnionPay QR code payments to be launched across all six AsiaMalls shopping centres in 2018
summary: UnionPay International and AsiaMalls Management have signed a memorandum of understanding to accept UnionPay QR code payments across six shopping centers in Singapore, starting 2018. This partnership will enable merchant discounts and payment transactions via a scan of a customer's QR code. It marks the first large-scale partnership in Singapore between a mall manager and a global payment brand to deploy QR code payments. The deal will be rolled out across all six AsiaMalls-managed shopping centers when they reopen in 2018.

site_title: China's Oct industrial profits surge on boost from higher commodities
summary: China's industrial profits surged 25.1% in October to 745.4 billion yuan, driven by strong commodities prices, particularly in mining and heavy industry. This growth rate was the second-highest for the year, despite a slight slowdown from September. Lower costs and higher operating margins contributed to the increase, with the mining industry seeing a 405.4% rise in profits. However, analysts warn that higher borrowing costs may put pressure on earnings and economic growth in the year ahead.

site_title: Shell and carmakers aim to go the distance with highway charging
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has partnered with top carmakers to deploy ultra-fast chargers on Europe's highways, aiming to remove a major obstacle for electric cars. The IONITY technology will initially bring high-powered docks to 80 highway sites in 2019, addressing the issue of journey distances. Shell expects the global electric vehicle fleet to grow from 1% to 10% by 2025, displacing 800,000 barrels of oil demand per day. The partnership aims to build a pan-European network of 400 charging stations by 2020, with an additional 20 stations expected in Germany.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks slump on tech sell-off, won edges down
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.85% to 2,522.60, its lowest in over a week, due to a heavy sell-off in tech stocks, particularly Samsung Electronics. The won edged down 0.15% to 1,087 per dollar, while US stocks ended the previous session with mild gains. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index was down 0.44%. The decline follows analyst reports suggesting the "memory chip super cycle" is nearing its end.

site_title: City of London says tax take backs case for Brexit banks deal
summary: The City of London reports a record £72.1 billion ($96.2 billion) in tax paid by the financial services industry in the past fiscal year, with tax revenues in the sector rising 1% and hitting a 10-year high. The City is calling for a transition deal by the end of the year to limit financial jobs moving to the EU after Brexit, citing potential impact on tax revenues. 10,000 financial services jobs are expected to move by Brexit Day, according to the Bank of England.

site_title: StarHub partners Nokia to develop commercial IoT services in Singapore
summary: StarHub has partnered with Nokia to develop commercial IoT services in Singapore. The companies signed a memorandum of understanding to co-develop IoT applications and services, focusing on connected living, vehicles, and buildings. Nokia will support StarHub in developing smart parking, environmental sensors, and video analytics, while promoting IoT technology through outreach programs and events. The partnership aims to address urban challenges and build viable business models for high-value services, with commercial services expected to launch in the first quarter of 2018.

site_title: Mount Agung eruption: At least 14 Singapore to Bali flights cancelled
summary: At least 14 flights from Singapore to Bali were cancelled due to the eruption of Mount Agung, with Bali's Ngurah Rai International Airport closed for the day. Airlines such as Scoot, Garuda Indonesia, and AirAsia cancelled multiple flights, leaving passengers stranded. Some passengers attempted to reschedule flights to unaffected areas of the island, while others were rebooked on alternative flights or received refunds. The Indonesian authorities raised the threat warning from the volcano to its highest level amid fears of potentially greater eruptions.

site_title: UOB to upskill 900 staff in professional conversional programme
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has launched a Professional Conversion Programme (PCP) to upskill 900 staff in digital skills, aiming to retain a strong Singaporean core amidst transformation plans. The 18-month programme, developed in collaboration with Workforce Singapore and others, covers areas like design thinking, customer journey design, and scenario analysis. The move is seen as a signal by the financial services sector to upgrade staff skills and stay ahead of technological changes, with Second Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo emphasizing the importance of such programmes.

site_title: Australia: Shares tick up with broad-based gains; NZ rises
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Monday, following a positive lead from Wall Street, with technology stocks leading the gains. Financial stocks reversed losses, while healthcare counters gained on news of China cutting import tariffs on medicines, food, and apparel. The Australian financial index rose 0.2%, with the 'Big Four' banks gaining between 0.1 and 0.3%. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also rose 0.4%.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Monday, driven by positive leads from Wall Street rallies. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.43% and the Topix index rose 0.38%, with the benchmark indices reaching 22,648.23 and 1,787.25, respectively. This follows the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq's edge to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Gold steady as dollar holds near 2-month lows
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Monday at $1287.67 an ounce, as the dollar hovered near a two-month low. US President Donald Trump will meet with Senate Republicans to discuss tax reform legislation. The Congressional hearing on Fed Chair nominee Jerome Powell on Tuesday is also expected to influence the market. Meanwhile, European Union leaders set a 10-day deadline for Theresa May to improve her Brexit offer, and German business confidence reached a record high.

images.alt_text: Gold prices were steady early on Monday, as the dollar held close to a two-month low hit in the previous session against a basket of major curriences.

site_title: Singapore investors making foray into Irish property
summary: Singapore investors are making a foray into Ireland's commercial real estate market, drawn by the country's chronic undersupply and rising rents post-Brexit. Investments include Fine Grain Property's €100 million (S$158.6 million) deal with Ireland Strategic Investment Fund, and Keppel DC Reit's acquisition of a data centre in Dublin. The trend is expected to grow, with rising prices and rentals making Ireland an attractive destination for international institutional capital. Banks' reluctance to lend outside Dublin is also driving demand for private investment in the sector.

site_title: After rally, still some value in emerging markets: Schroders
summary: Schroders' head of emerging market equities, Tom Wilson, notes that South Korea and Russia still offer value among emerging markets, despite the recent rally. He praises South Korea's cheap valuations and Russia's recovery from the oil price crash. Wilson also favors smaller emerging markets like Hungary and Poland, and sectors such as information technology and financials. However, he is cautious about valuations in South-east Asia, particularly Malaysia, and warns of potential risks, including US inflation and trade tensions.

site_title: Hot stock: Sabana Reit shares slide after talks with ESR-Reit fail
summary: Sabana Reit shares fell as much as 5.8% after talks with ESR-Reit, a Warburg Pincus-backed company, failed to materialize. The counter dropped to 40.5 Singapore cents before rebounding to 41.5 cents. Sabana confirmed in August that it was in discussions with ESR-Reit but announced the talks had ceased. The Reit will focus on tenant retention and improving occupancy for its assets, with plans to renew expiring master leases and replace its CEO.

site_title: Noble to sell US ethanol producer for US$12.5m plus adjustments
summary: Noble Group is selling its US-based ethanol producer, North America's South Bend Ethanol (NASBE), for US$12.5 million plus adjustments. The sale comes as Noble is selling off its global oil liquids business. Zeeland Farm Services is the buyer, and the deal is expected to be completed by October 1. If the sale falls through, Vitol will proceed with its own sale of NASBE after the Noble Americas Corp (NAC) takeover. The sale reduces the base consideration for NAC by one quarter of the proceeds from the NASBE sale.

site_title: Why Tencent wants to be more like Facebook in advertising
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd, China's largest company, is shifting its focus towards becoming a major advertising powerhouse like Facebook Inc. The company is working to synchronize data from its seven main business units to deliver precision and predictive ads to its billion-plus users. Tencent aims to capitalize on China's 350 billion yuan online advertising market, with its user data being a key factor in targeting commercials. The company is taking a gradual approach, showing just one ad per day on its WeChat platform, to avoid overwhelming users and driving them away.

images.alt_text: Tencent Holdings Ltd's rise into a US$500 billion company was fuelled by a culture of internal competition, where teams raced against each other to make ideas work. To become an advertising powerhouse like Facebook Inc, the internal barriers are starting to come down.

site_title: Trump again backs alleged harasser, Democrat gives up key post
summary: President Donald Trump backed embattled Senate candidate Roy Moore, ignoring sexual harassment allegations, in a tweet calling Democrat Doug Jones "weak on crime, the military and immigration." Many Republicans have withdrawn support for Moore due to allegations of molesting or harassing teenage girls. Meanwhile, Democrats are addressing their own party's harassment concerns. Trump's stance on Moore has been criticized, with many viewing it as a sign of Trump's continued support for Moore despite the allegations.

site_title: Euro at 2-month high on upbeat German sentiment data, political hopes
summary: The euro reached a two-month high against the dollar at US$1.1929, driven by strong German business confidence and reduced anxiety over European politics. The German business confidence index hit a record high, while German Chancellor Angela Merkel secured a political lifeline after coalition talks. The dollar remained stagnant, weighed down by persistently low inflation and upcoming Federal Reserve hearings. Market players await the Congressional hearing on Fed Chair nominee Jerome Powell and President Trump's tax reforms plan.

images.alt_text: The euro hit a two-month high versus the dollar and held firm against other major currencies on Monday thanks to strong German business confidence and reduced anxiety about political instability in Europe's biggest economy.

site_title: Bali raises volcano alert to highest level: officials
summary: Bali has raised the alert level for its volcano to the highest level due to constant tremors and large plumes of smoke. Officials fear a significant eruption could be imminent. The alert level increase comes as the volcano continues to belch smoke, raising concerns for nearby residents and tourists on the resort island.

site_title: Golden Agri to sell Tianjin oilseeds unit to Louis Dreyfus Company Asia
summary: Golden Agri-Resources is selling its wholly owned oilseeds business in Tianjin to Louis Dreyfus Company Asia. The unit, Sinarmas Natural Resources Foodstuff (Technology) Tianjin, has a registered capital of US$60 million and operates oilseed crushing and refining facilities. The sale is considered a strategic option to dispose of non-core assets. The final consideration will be based on the unit's initial enterprise value, working capital, and financial statements.

site_title: Oxley confirms talks to buy Chevron House; shares to resume trading
summary: Oxley Holdings has confirmed negotiations to buy Chevron House in Singapore's financial district, a 32-storey office and retail building. The company is conducting due diligence and has not reached a definitive agreement. The expected purchase price is around S$660 million. Trading in Oxley shares will resume on Monday after being halted following a Business Times article announcing the deal.

site_title: WH Group woos Chinese eaters with spicy pork, sticky rice sausages
summary: WH Group, the world's top pork producer, is launching new packaged foods to counter slowing Chinese pork demand. The company is introducing 100 new products, including spicy meat snacks and sausage with sticky rice, inspired by regional flavors. WH aims to boost sales volumes and reach the scale of its US business, Smithfield, which processes 30 million pigs annually. The company is also adapting to changing consumer tastes, with a focus on healthier options and convenience.

site_title: Drunk driver rams into revellers in German town, injuring 6
summary: A 29-year-old intoxicated driver deliberately crashed his car into a group of people outside a disco in Cuxhaven, Germany, injuring six, including all German nationals aged 19-29. The driver, believed to be from Syria, was held down by passers-by until police arrived. Initial investigation suggests a dispute outside the nightclub may be the motive, with no terrorist or political motives found. The incident has revived memories of last December's Berlin Christmas market attack, which killed 12 people.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sabana Reit, Oxley, Golden Agri, Noble
summary: Noble Group is selling its US$12.5 million ethanol business in the Americas. Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust has ended talks with ESR-Reit over a strategic review without a deal. Oxley Holdings is negotiating to buy the Chevron House building in Singapore's financial district. Golden Agri-Resources is selling its entire stake in Sinarmas Natural Resources Foodstuff to a subsidiary of Louise Dreyfus Company Asia for US$111 million.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Monday's open; STI down 1.67 points to 3,440.48
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 1.67 points to 3,440.48 at Monday's open, amidst fits of volatility in markets last week. Gainers outnumbered losers 73 to 42, with ThaiBev and Midas leading the gains. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also retreated, with DBS falling four Singapore cents to S$24.96. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Credit Suisse alumni start Asia credit fund to fill lending gap
summary: A group of former Credit Suisse staff, led by Australian investment banker John Wylie, has started Tanarra Credit Partners, an Asia-Pacific credit investment fund. The fund has raised over A$285 million and aims to invest in senior and mezzanine debt, targeting up to A$500 million. The fund will focus on sub-investment grade secured loan opportunities in Australia and New Zealand, and joins a growing list of firms raising credit funds to fill a lending gap due to banks tightening lending standards.

site_title: Zimbabwe's Mugabe "glowed" with relief after he quit: priest
summary: Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe "glowed" with relief after agreeing to step down, according to a priest who mediated his resignation. Mugabe, who ruled for 37 years, had faced pressure from the military, his party, and the people to quit. He finally accepted defeat after being sacked by his party and facing impeachment. His successor, Emmerson Mnangagwa, has vowed to tackle corruption and implement a smooth transition of power. Mugabe's wife, Grace, had been a rival to Mnangagwa for the presidency, and several of her associates have been detained and charged with corruption.

site_title: Meredith agrees to buy Time Inc with Koch Brothers backing
summary: Meredith Corp agreed to acquire Time Inc for $2.8 billion, including debt, in an all-cash offer of $18.50 per share. The deal, backed by the Koch brothers' $650 million equity investment, aims to help Meredith compete with Facebook and Google in advertising. Time Inc, publisher of Fortune and Sports Illustrated, has struggled to adapt to the digital age and print advertising decline. The acquisition gives Meredith a larger audience and a foothold in the struggling magazine industry, despite concerns about the potential for political influence.

site_title: US, Russia lend skill to non-stop Argentina sub hunt
summary: Argentina's missing San Juan submarine, which went silent 11 days after an explosion, has not been found in a 14-nation search. Aircraft from Argentina, Britain, and the US have been searching the South Atlantic for over a week. The search effort continues despite failing to locate the vessel at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean.

site_title: Hungary launches rail link tender as CEE-China summit starts
summary: Hungary has launched a tender for a modernized railway link with Serbia to ship Chinese goods into Western Europe. The estimated cost of the project is $2.82 billion, with 85% credit coverage from China's Exim Bank. The railway link is expected to become a key transport route for Chinese goods arriving by sea at the Greek port of Piraeus. Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban will sign 11 bilateral agreements with China at the upcoming summit, and other countries will sign dozens of deals. The project is part of China's efforts to strengthen its presence in the region.

site_title: Singapore getting snubbed as China rules Asia dollar bond market
summary: Singapore is facing a decline in its role as a key financial hub for marketing offshore dollar debt, with at least 37 Chinese companies skipping roadshows in Singapore this year, compared to 136 in Hong Kong. This shift reflects China's growing influence in the Asia dollar-bond market, as Chinese funds increasingly take a bigger share of the buyer base. Singapore-based investors are finding it harder to meet with debt issuers, but experts believe this trend may be short-lived as Chinese companies mature and seek wider distribution of their bonds.

site_title: German far-right relishes its power as Merkel struggles
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel faces a crisis in forming a new government in Germany, with the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) party entering parliament for the first time. The AfD's leader, Alexander Gauland, claims the party's success is proof of its growing power and Merkel's struggle to assemble a ruling majority. The AfD won nearly 13% of the vote and 100 seats, snatching millions of votes from mainstream parties. Merkel has been unable to cobble together a majority, and polls indicate that snap elections could trigger further gains for the AfD.

images.alt_text: Mr Gauland (above) has played down rivalries within the AfD, seen most spectacularly in the resignation of former co-leader Frauke Petry just days after the general election, saying the AfD would focus on its platform rather than personnel.

site_title: Bankers hard to replace with robots
summary: Nordea Bank, the Nordic region's largest bank, is planning to cut 6,000 jobs as part of its digital transformation. However, the bank's chief digital officer, Ewan MacLeod, says that customers will still be able to receive advice from humans for complex transactions such as wealth management and investment banking services. Automated tasks, such as replacing a credit card, will be handled by machines. MacLeod believes that machine learning and artificial intelligence will bring instant insight to investment bankers, reducing the need for human support work in the future.

site_title: 'Smoking kills,' US tobacco firms say in court-ordered ads
summary: US tobacco companies have begun publishing court-ordered ads stating that smoking kills an average of 1,200 Americans daily. The ads, which include messages on health topics such as lung cancer and heart disease, were ordered by District Judge Gladys Kessler in 2006 as part of a racketeering case against the companies. The ads are being published in major newspapers and on television as part of a settlement agreement reached in 2014, and are seen as a significant victory for public health, according to the American Cancer Society.

site_title: US Black Friday online sales climb to record high
summary: US Black Friday online sales reached a record high of US$7.9 billion, up 17.9% from last year, with Cyber Monday expected to drive US$6.6 billion in Internet sales, the largest US online shopping day in history. Despite muted activity in physical stores, shopper visits remained intact on Black Friday, bucking industry predictions. Retailers invested in improving their websites and delivery options, with mobile phone purchases accounting for 40% of Black Friday online sales.

site_title: Nationalists facing wipeout in Australian state election
summary: Australia's nationalist One Nation party, led by Pauline Hanson, faces a significant wipeout in the state election in Queensland, with the center-left Labor party leading in the vote count. Labor is expected to win 47 seats, allowing it to form a government without support from independents or minor parties. Despite polling around 14% of voters, One Nation is likely to win only one seat, according to analysts. The party's resurgence in national politics appears to have stalled in this state election.

site_title: Bake it like Beckham
summary: Former Manchester United and Real Madrid football star David Beckham made a special appearance at a pastry-making workshop at Marina Bay Sands in Singapore, interacting with 40 children. The event was a charity fundraiser for the integrated resort's designated charity, the Singapore International Film Festival. Beckham, a frequent visitor to Singapore, auctioned off a signed whisky box set at the gala dinner, supporting the charity. This was not his first charity event at MBS, having previously participated in a football clinic and observing a match for visually impaired athletes.

images.alt_text: Beckham with the young participants of a pastry-making workshop at The Bird Southern Table & Bar.

site_title: Yanlord founder eyes century-old legacy for firm
summary: Yanlord Land Group founder Zhong Sheng Jian aims to achieve a century-long legacy by strengthening corporate branding and long-term plans. The 60-year-old CEO made this statement after Yanlord acquired a stake in United Engineers Limited, marking a diversification milestone for the company. This move grants Yanlord access to Singapore's commercial real estate through UEL's portfolio. Zhong's goal is to replicate the success of century-old companies like United Engineers and WBL Corp, which have weathered wars, financial crises, and political transitions.

site_title: Your loss is your problem, China tells small investors as it tightens money rules
summary: China has introduced new guidelines to ban financial institutions from guaranteeing investors against losses, effectively ending implicit guarantees for wealth management products (WMPs). The move aims to standardize the country's financial markets and reduce risks. WMPs, which have warped prices and bred complacency, are expected to be replaced by transparent mutual fund products. Analysts predict a shift towards relatively safe bond funds or money market funds, potentially triggering a seismic shift in China's asset management industry. The new rules are part of Beijing's efforts to break "financial chaos" and promote professionalization in the industry.

site_title: London terror scare unexplained as suspects freed
summary: Armed officers locked down London's Oxford Street shopping district after reports of shots fired, injuring 16 people. However, no suspects were found, and no evidence of gunfire or casualties was discovered. Two men, aged 21 and 40, were interviewed but not arrested or charged. They were released without further action, and police have no further suspects in custody. The incident occurred on "Black Friday" at one of London's busiest areas, amid Britain's high alert following five terror attacks since March.

images.alt_text: Two men suspected of involvement in a fight that sparked a terror scare in London's Oxford Street shopping district have been questioned by police but released without charges, a spokesman said Sunday.

site_title: Malay/Muslim community has progressed since Berita Harian's first publication 60 years ago: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong praised Berita Harian, a Malay/Muslim newspaper, for maintaining journalistic integrity and reporting accurately over its 60-year history. This comes as many global newspapers struggle to retain readers and revenues. Lee's comments highlighted Berita Harian's commitment to responsible reporting and its national perspective.

site_title: Bitcoin now gunning for US$10,000 as cryptocurrency mania intensifiess
summary: Bitcoin's price has surged past $9,000, nearing $10,000, amid growing mainstream attention despite warnings of a bubble. The cryptocurrency has gained 40% over the past two weeks and 850% this year. Analysts at IG Group attribute the recent frenzy to the "fear of missing out" trade. However, others have raised concerns about downside risks from the introduction of bitcoin futures, highlighting the need for caution in the market.

site_title: Mugabe cried, lamented betrayal by lieutenants when he resigned
summary: Zimbabwe's former President Robert Mugabe resigned under pressure from the military and his party, citing "betrayal by his lieutenants". He stepped down after 37 years in power, paving the way for Emmerson Mnangagwa, a former Mugabe loyalist, to take office. Mnangagwa vowed to tackle corruption and uphold democracy, tolerance, and the rule of law. The new government is already taking action, bringing some of Mugabe's associates to justice, including former finance minister Ignatius Chombo, who faces corruption charges.

site_title: Nuclear power plant in Belarus stirs fears in Lithuania
summary: Belarus is constructing a nuclear reactor in Ostrovets, near the EU border, despite concerns in neighboring Lithuania. The two reactors, with a combined capacity of 2,400 MW, will be operational by 2019 and 2020. The project, funded by Russia's Rosatom, has revived fears of radiation from the 1986 Chernobyl disaster. Lithuania has denounced the project as a violation of international norms and is considering a law declaring the plant a national security threat, which would block its sale of electricity to the EU.

site_title: Merkel woos her opponents with vista of another grand coalition
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel proposed a grand coalition with the Social Democratic Party (SPD), her main opponents, in a speech to her Christian Democratic Union (CDU) members. Merkel stated that any coalition partner would need to support a balanced budget and pro-business policies. This move is seen as a clear attempt to woo her opponents and revive the "grand coalition" that governed Germany for the past four years. Merkel's proposal aims to create a stable government, but it remains to be seen if the SPD will accept the offer.

site_title: Sabana Reit's talks with suitor fall through
summary: Sabana Reit, a Singapore-based REIT, has ended talks with Warburg Pincus-backed ESR-Reit over a potential wholesale takeover. Instead, Sabana is focusing on three initiatives: selective asset sales, strengthening its current portfolio, and renewing senior leadership. The trust manager has also identified a new independent director to enhance the board. Sabana remains open to considering proposals from prospective strategic partners, but prioritizes internal decisions to improve performance and provide long-term value for stakeholders.

site_title: Needy families in limbo as Britain struggles with housing shortage
summary: In England, over 78,000 households are at risk of homelessness and require temporary accommodation, with the number of households in temporary housing increasing 60% since 2011. The situation worsens due to the high cost of housing and insufficient home building. The British government has pledged £44 billion over five years to address the issue, but critics argue that a lack of suitable homes leaves people stuck in dire conditions, affecting their mental health.

images.alt_text: Sandra Rumkiene, seen here with her daughter Jessica, is one of a growing number of poor families forced to live in temporary housing because of a lack of permanent social housing. The number of households living in temporary accommodation has jumped 60 per cent since 2011.

site_title: En bloc veteran Karamjit Singh launches Showsuite
summary: En bloc veteran Karamjit Singh has launched a new portal called Showsuite, designed to transform the way new homes are presented, marketed, and sold. The platform features 3D technology, virtual reality, and storey views, allowing potential buyers to remotely explore projects. Showsuite aims to save buyers time and provide a more accurate experience, as it can display units of all configurations. The portal is gaining traction with developers, including UOL, GuocoLand, and Bukit Sembawang, and is expected to feature all existing new launches.

site_title: Wealth effect fuelling US consumer spending
summary: US stocks are expected to rise to new records this week as retailers and investors anticipate a strong holiday season, with sales projected to increase 4% to $682 billion. The "wealth effect" is driving consumer confidence, with rising stock prices and home values leading to increased spending. Amazon's shares surged to an all-time high after the company reported strong Black Friday sales, and analysts predict the company will receive a significant portion of online holiday revenue. The S&P 500 is forecast to rise 14% in 2018, driven by above-trend economic growth and tax reform.

site_title: Healthy fun for 10,800 Big Walkers
summary: The National Steps Challenge The New Paper Big Walk 2017 took place on November 26, 2017, with 10,800 walkers participating in the event. The Big Walkers began at the Sports Hub and ended at Nicoll Highway, passing the Singapore Flyer. The event concluded with a carnival featuring fun and healthy activities. President Halimah Yacob flagged off the participants.

site_title: Adapting to a new era of uncertainty
summary: US President Donald Trump's one-year presidency has led to a shift in America's role in the global economy, with significant implications for businesses in Asia. The "America first" policy has diminished the US's geo-political influence, with other world powers taking advantage of the vacuum. This has led to uncertainty and pessimism about the US's economic policies, including the withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership and the Paris Climate Accord. Despite this, the US remains a powerhouse in the global economy, and its economy has held strong. The impact of Trump's policies on businesses in Asia will be significant, with potential changes to trade deals, investment decisions, and the supply chain.

site_title: Work permit holders 'must attend settling-in programme'
summary: The Singapore government has announced that all newly arrived non-Malaysian work permit holders will be required to attend a settling-in programme (SIP) starting from the second half of 2018. The one-day programme aims to educate foreign workers about employment regulations, Singapore laws, and social norms. Employers will cover the costs, and the initiative is part of the government's goal to provide a safe and fair environment for foreign workers. A pilot programme last year showed that 99% of participants improved their understanding of their rights and responsibilities.

images.alt_text: The enlarged SIP, which is already mandatory for first-time foreign domestic workers, will initially be rolled out to workers in the construction sector before being introduced for other sectors.

site_title: Markets entering jittery period of uncertainty
summary: Markets are entering a period of uncertainty, with the US stock market expected to be influenced by the Federal Reserve's upcoming leadership change and the ongoing tax reform discussions. Despite this, some markets, such as Singapore's, have seen steady gains, with the Straits Times Index ending the week on a respectable note. Investors are also keeping an eye on potential tax hikes in Singapore, which could impact the market.

site_title: Chinese fighters get home crowd roaring in UFC debut
summary: Chinese fighters dominated the UFC's Shanghai Fight Night, winning five out of eight bouts, including a record-breaking knockout. The event marked the UFC's first in mainland China, with a sell-out crowd of over 15,000 cheering on the local fighters. Despite initial doubts, the Chinese fighters proved their skills, with Li "The Leech" Jingliang predicting more top talent from China in the future. The UFC sees China as a key market for expansion, with plans for future events in the country.

site_title: Dozens of flights cancelled as Bali volcano continues to spew smoke
summary: A volcano on Bali's Mount Agung spewed smoke and ash, disrupting at least 28 flights and affecting over 2,000 passengers. The smoke reached 4,000 meters above the summit, prompting flight cancellations and travel warnings. Authorities have confirmed that Bali is still safe for tourists, except for a 7.5km zone around the volcano, and flights are continuing despite the disruption.

site_title: UBS seeks to expand workforce in artificial intelligence
summary: UBS is expanding its workforce in artificial intelligence, a growing area in banking where demand for talent is increasing. The bank is recruiting data scientists, architects, and business analysts to apply AI technology to areas such as fraud prevention, optimization, and risk management. This move follows a trend where nine out of 10 financial service companies are working with AI technologies, but are struggling to find the right talent. UBS aims to capitalize on this trend and stay competitive in the financial services industry.

site_title: Nepal goes to the polls for historic vote
summary: Nepal held historic elections for national and provincial parliaments on Sunday, marking a turning point for the impoverished Himalayan nation. The two-phase elections are the first under a new post-war constitution, which ended a 10-year Maoist insurgency in 2006. Millions of Nepalis cast their votes, hoping to end the country's instability and pave the way for a more democratic future. The elections are seen as a significant step towards Nepal's transition from monarchy to democracy.

site_title: Innovation, traditional strengths key to S'pore's role in Belt and Road
summary: Singapore's role in China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) is expected to be driven by its unique strengths in innovation, finance, and law. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat, who recently visited China, emphasized the importance of innovation and collaboration in capturing a slice of BRI. Singapore's traditional strengths in legal and finance will also be utilized to build infrastructure across the region. The country aims to be an international arbitration hub and is exploring ways to expand trade flows through trade and investment agreements and regulatory coordination.

site_title: Bubbles, bonds, banks and Bitcoin
summary: Schroders fund managers acknowledge the risk of inflation bursting a bond market bubble, but remain pragmatic, citing pockets of value in emerging market bonds and asset-backed securities. They note that timing the pop of the credit bubble is difficult and that alternative investments are scarce. Key fund managers, including Remi Olu-Pitan and Philippe Lespinard, advocate for a defensive approach, but also see opportunities in sectors like financials, telcos, and emerging markets.

images.alt_text: From left: Schroders fund managers Philippe Lespinard, co-head of fixed income, multi-asset fund manager Remi Olu-Pitan, and European equities fund manager James Sym at the Schroders International Media Conference 2017 in London.

site_title: Norway serious about curbing CEO pay
summary: Norway's $1 trillion sovereign wealth fund has increased its efforts to curb excessive CEO pay in the companies it invests in. Since releasing a position paper in April, the fund has voted against pay plans at companies like Alphabet, Noble Corp, and Liberty Global. The fund operates according to a set of ethical guidelines and has taken on a more activist role in voting on management proposals, aligning with its goal of responsible investment. This move is part of the fund's efforts to promote transparency and fairness in corporate governance.

site_title: Iraq plans US$2b eurobond sale to plug 2018 budget deficit
summary: Iraq plans to sell a $2 billion eurobond in 2018 to finance its budget deficit, which is expected to be below 10 trillion dinars. The country has made progress in stabilizing its finances, with Brent crude prices rebounding to over $60 a barrel and the war against Islamic State militants largely completed. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank have agreed to provide $850 million and $1 billion, respectively, to support Iraq's financial needs.

site_title: Foreign workers must undergo settling-in programme after mid-2018
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Manpower has announced that all newly arrived non-Malaysian work permit holders will undergo a settling-in programme starting in the second half of 2018. The one-day programme, already mandatory for first-time foreign domestic workers, aims to educate workers about employment regulations, laws, and social norms. Employers will cover the costs. The initiative follows a successful 2016 pilot programme, with participants showing significant improvement in understanding their rights and responsibilities.

site_title: Brexit fears see European banks slash UK assets by US$425 billion in a year
summary: European banks have reduced their UK assets by US$425 billion in the past year following the Brexit vote, with a 35% decline in derivatives exposures. This move indicates banks are preparing for the risk that the UK may not reach a future relationship agreement with the EU before its departure. The decrease in UK assets is a response to Brexit-related uncertainty, as banks aim to mitigate potential losses.

site_title: Momentum grows for another grand coalition in Germany
summary: Germany's Social Democrats (SPD) are likely to approve a renewed coalition with Chancellor Angela Merkel's conservatives, according to party member Niels Annen. A grand coalition is an option that cannot be excluded, given the country's global crises. The SPD had vowed to go into opposition after the September election, but is now under pressure to form a government. Party leaders, including Martin Schulz, agree to talks and will put any proposal to a vote. Issues such as citizens' insurance and renters' protection will be negotiated with conservatives.

site_title: Further upside expected in WTI oil
summary: WTI oil prices broke out of a 14-month range, moving above $55.00, driven by Saudi Arabia's anti-corruption purge and OPEC production cuts. The recent uptrend, marked by higher highs and higher lows since June 2017, has been supported by the 20 and 60-day moving averages. A bullish break above the $55.00 support area on November 3, followed by a bullish follow-through, has increased momentum, with further upside expected, targeting $60.00 and potentially $61.85.

site_title: EFG set to emerge from BSI scandal as 5th-largest Swiss bank
summary: Swiss-listed private bank EFG International is set to complete the union with defunct rival BSI by year-end, emerging as Switzerland's fifth-largest bank. The deal, announced in May 2017, was initially marred by regulatory sanctions in Singapore and Switzerland due to BSI's involvement in the 1MDB scandal. Despite these challenges, EFG International is expected to successfully integrate BSI and complete the acquisition.

site_title: Bali eruption: AirAsia, Jetstar, SilkAir flights among those affected on Sunday
summary: Mount Agung in Bali experienced powerful eruptions, disrupting flights to and from the area. AirAsia canceled 32 of 34 flights to and from Bali and Lombok, while SilkAir rescheduled two flights. Singapore Airlines maintained its flight schedule, and Jetstar delayed two flights. The eruptions led to an ash cloud banning flights over the area, with residents within 6-7.5km of the volcano advised to evacuate.

site_title: BMW joins race to secure cobalt for electric-vehicle batteries
summary: BMW is exploring ways to secure cobalt supplies for its electric vehicle battery production, amid concerns of a potential shortage and price hike. The company is in talks with cobalt suppliers, following similar efforts by Volkswagen. Cobalt is a key material used in EV batteries, with the Democratic Republic of Congo being the primary source. BMW has announced a 200 million-euro investment in a new battery prototype center in Munich, aiming to secure long-term access to the material. The company's board member Oliver Zipse emphasized the importance of sourcing cobalt and other materials for battery production.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's Adnoc seeks up to US$2b from unit IPO
summary: Abu Dhabi's Adnoc is planning to raise up to US$2 billion from an initial public offering (IPO) of its fuel-retailing unit, Abu Dhabi National Oil Co for Distribution PJSC. The IPO is valued at US$8 billion to US$10 billion and is expected to begin trading on Dec 13. The company plans to offer 1.25 billion to 2.5 billion shares, with the final offer size and pricing to be announced on Dec 8. This is part of a larger trend of Middle Eastern oil-rich governments selling assets to diversify their economies.

site_title: Brands pull YouTube ads over images of children
summary: Major brands, including Mondelez, Lidl, Mars, and Diageo, have pulled YouTube ads amid concerns over explicit child content. A Times investigation found the platform allowed ads to run alongside videos featuring scantily clad minors, with hundreds of pedophile comments posted. YouTube apologized and promised a review, but the backlash led to a loss of revenue for uploaders. Many brands, including P&G and Verizon, have since returned to YouTube, citing the platform's 1.5 billion users and the difficulty in finding alternative advertising space.

site_title: Gamers, shoppers power China's tech giants into elite league
summary: China's tech giants, Tencent and Alibaba, have catapulted to the elite league of the world's most valuable companies, powered by the country's vast market of 750 million Internet users. Tencent became the first Asian firm to break into the $500 billion league, briefly overtaking Facebook, while Alibaba is just a few billion shy of joining its Chinese competitor. The companies' success stems from their ability to tap into smartphone technology and restrict access to the Internet, which has enabled them to corner China's market.

site_title: Myopic gold CEOs get a tongue-lashing from Randgold Resources' Bristow
summary: Randgold Resources CEO Mark Bristow warned the gold industry that its focus on containing costs and minimizing risks will lead to a supply shortage by 2020, as half of the gold produced is not profitable to mine. He criticized the industry's reliance on all-in-sustaining costs and high-grading, which erodes asset quality. Bristow also blamed the industry's failure to reinvest in exploration and sustaining capital, and called for a reckoning within the industry. He suggested that large funds should be more active in appointing and removing board members to hold executives accountable.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week ending November 26, 2017, highlights a strong end to the week with weather delays in China and stronger iron ore prices boosting activity. Timecharter rates for mid-China to west Australian round voyages reached over $20,000 daily. Australian miners took several ships for loading within the 1-10 December time frame, with the West Australia/China rate reaching a high for the year at over $9.00. North Atlantic rates also firmed, with timecharter rates hitting the upper $20,000 daily for transatlantic rounds.

site_title: Europe: Shares snap two-week losing streak as DAX gains
summary: European shares ended nearly unchanged on Friday, snapping a two-week losing streak as the Stoxx 600 index rose 0.7% on the week. The German DAX index advanced 0.4%, boosted by a growing prospect of a grand coalition in Germany. Investor sentiment was lifted by the brightening economic picture in Europe, with business growth gathering pace and German business confidence reaching a record high. Shares in consumer staples businesses and banks also rose, driven by news of potential changes to European banking directives.

site_title: China online finance regulator tells unqualified micro-lenders to stop lending
summary: China's National Internet Finance Association has issued a risk warning letter to unqualified micro-lenders, ordering them to stop offering loans due to exorbitant interest rates and violent debt collection practices. The sector, worth 1 trillion yuan, has been accused of disrupting economic and social orders. Qualified lending institutions are urged to increase self-discipline, charge reasonable interest rates, and disclose information. The crackdown follows a top-level multi-ministry body's urgent notice to restrict new approvals for micro-loan firms, as shares of US-listed Chinese online finance firms fell this week.

images.alt_text: The 1 trillion yuan (S$204.03 billion) short-term, unsecured lending sector, known as "cash loan" in China, has been accused of charging exorbitant interest rates and violent debt collection practices.

site_title: S&P cuts South Africa local debt to junk; Moody's issues warning
summary: South Africa's local-currency debt was cut to BB+ by S&P Global Ratings, one step below investment grade, and its foreign-currency debt was also downgraded to BB. Moody's Investors Service put both ratings on review for possible downgrade, citing a deteriorating economic outlook and public finances. A downgrade could lead to a selloff in rand bonds, raising borrowing costs for the nation and potentially triggering outflows of $9.7 billion. The country's economic stagnation and erosion of external competitiveness have contributed to the downgrade.

site_title: M7 Multi-Let pursues private funding, scraps London IPO plan
summary: M7 Multi-Let REIT, a UK-based real estate investment trust, has scrapped plans to float in London, citing private funding from investors and market conditions. The company had agreed to buy 93 properties for £119.8 million and identified a pipeline of potential acquisitions valued at over £400 million. M7's decision marks another setback for the London Stock Exchange, which has seen several IPO cancellations recently. The move is seen as a boost to other companies, including Sabre, which is pursuing a London float.

site_title: Olympics: Russia deprived of two more Sochi golds for doping
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has annulled two gold medals won by Russia in the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics due to state-sponsored doping. Alexander Zubkov, a bobsleigh athlete, and Olga Fatkulina, a speed skater, were disqualified and their results struck off. This decision is part of a larger purge of Russian athletes, with nine medals, including four golds, being stripped from the 2014 Olympics. The IOC has also banned the athletes from future competitions and imposed life bans.

site_title: STI returns to above 3,400; Yoma CEO ups stake
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 2.5% over five trading sessions from Nov 17 to 23, reaching a dividend-inclusive return of 22.8% for 2017. Share buybacks worth S$10.1 million were conducted by 14 stocks, led by OCBC Bank and Silverlake Axis. Yoma Strategic Holdings CEO Melvyn Pun Chi Tung acquired 1 million shares at S$0.50 per share, increasing his stake to 0.97%. The STI's performance was compared to benchmarks of Japan, Hong Kong, and Australia, which averaged a 19.1% return for the year.

site_title: Formula 1: Liberty offer to cushion revenue blow for F1 teams
summary: Liberty Media, the commercial rights holder of Formula 1, has offered cash advances to teams to cushion the blow of reduced revenues caused by increased investment in the sport. The US-based company has made a "very generous offer" to teams, advancing monies to ensure the same revenue next year as this year on an interest-free basis. This move comes after a 14% drop in payments to teams compared to the same period in 2016, due to decreased race promotion and advertising revenue.

site_title: US shoppers browse stores, buy online as Black Friday deals beckon
summary: US shoppers browsed stores and bought online on Black Friday, with some reserving cash for internet purchases. Despite the lack of frenzied shopping, online sales rose, boosting shares of traditional retailers that have expanded beyond brick-and-mortar outlets. Stores managed inventory carefully to avoid post-holiday liquidation. The event saw fewer gimmicks and heavy discounts compared to previous years, with some retailers instead focusing on entertainment and free gifts. Overall, the outlook for traditional retailers was improved by the rise in online sales.

site_title: Shipping group CMA CGM powers ahead, founder retires
summary: French shipping company CMA CGM reported a third-quarter net profit of US$323 million, up from a US$268 million loss a year earlier, due to improving freight rates and participation in a global vessel alliance. Sales reached US$5.7 billion, a 28% increase from last year, driven by an 11.6% rise in volumes and 14.4% rise in average revenue per container. Founder Jacques Saade will step down as chairman and hand over the role to son Rodolphe Saade, who has led negotiations on the company's APL acquisition.

site_title: Gold rekindles appeal for asset managers as trading, ETFs rise
summary: Gold prices have surged, driven by a weakening US dollar, low inflation, and uncertainty over the US tax plan. Trading and exchange-traded fund (ETF) holdings are near their highest in a year, with aggregate open interest set to gain for the third consecutive quarter. This marks the longest streak since 2009, fueling hopes for the metal's biggest annual gain since 2010. The metal's appeal is rekindled as investors seek safe-haven assets amid global economic uncertainties.

site_title: Attack on mosque in Egypt's Sinai kills at least 235
summary: At least 235 people were killed and 109 wounded in a bomb and gun attack on a packed mosque in Egypt's North Sinai province, in the country's deadliest attack in recent memory. The attackers, wearing military uniforms, stormed the Rawda mosque, where Sufi worshippers were gathered for Friday prayers, before planting a bomb and opening fire on the crowd. The Egyptian military responded with airstrikes, destroying vehicles used in the attack and "terrorist" locations. The attack, attributed to Islamist extremist groups, has sparked widespread condemnation from leaders worldwide, with US President Donald Trump and Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi vowing to respond with force.

site_title: Police find 'no evidence' of shooting on London's Oxford Street
summary: Police on London's Oxford Street found no evidence of a shooting after armed officers responded to reports of shots being fired, despite a chaotic scene with panicked shoppers and a reported minor injury. The incident, lasting over an hour, was initially treated as a potential terrorism threat, but police later cleared the area and reopened nearby stations. CCTV images of two men were released, and they are believed to have information about the incident.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records on 'Black Friday' hopes
summary: US stocks closed at records on 'Black Friday' hopes, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq gaining 0.2% and 0.3% respectively. Amazon surged 2.6% ahead of Cyber Monday deals, while retail experts predict 4.2% holiday sales growth. Other retailers, such as Macy's and Gap, also saw solid gains, while Target and Nordstrom fell. The strong performance was attributed to low unemployment and lofty stock valuations, with many expecting a strong holiday shopping season.

site_title: Oil flirts with US$59 as Russia, Opec said to outline deal on cuts
summary: Oil prices surged to nearly US$59 a barrel, the highest level in two years, as Opec and Russia agreed on an outline for extending their oil production cuts. The deal, set to be announced at the Nov 30 meeting, aims to maintain the current cuts until the end of March. However, crucial details remain to be hammered out, with Russia hesitant to commit to a nine-month extension due to concerns over higher prices. The positive signs from Russia contributed to the oil market's strength.

site_title: Stock traders question Beijing's inaction after rout
summary: China's stock market experienced a 3% drop on Thursday, with the CSI 300 Index plummeting 52 points in the final 45 minutes of trading. Despite state funds not intervening to prop up prices, analysts believe the episode may help alleviate complacency in the market. Margin debt has increased for six straight months, and valuations among large-cap shares are considered too expensive for state-backed funds to intervene. The government's focus on leverage, particularly high margin debt, may be a key factor in the market's recent performance.

site_title: Sabana Reit calls off talks with Warburg Pincus-backed unit
summary: Sabana Shariah Compliant Industrial Reit (Sabana Reit) has ceased talks with Warburg Pincus-backed e-Shang Redwood (ESR) that were exploring options related to Sabana Reit's strategic review. The talks, which began in August, aimed to consolidate Singapore's US$3.5 billion mid-cap industrial trusts. Sabana's board of directors stated that discussions have ended, but the company remains open to considering proposals from strategic partners to further strengthen its position.

site_title: 'Tis the season to be healthy
summary: Samsung's Gear Fit 2 Pro fitness tracker offers a balance of features and simplicity, tracking workouts and health metrics without excessive smartphone integration. The device boasts a 1.5-inch OLED touchscreen display, wireless connectivity, and a water-resistant rating of 5ATM. Sensors track steps, calories burned, and heart rate, with a built-in GPS and ability to stream music via Bluetooth. The watch also displays notifications from the user's phone, but lacks canned responses for replies. Battery life is impressive, lasting up to four days with minimal usage. At S$268, the Gear Fit 2 Pro is a well-rounded and affordable option for basic fitness tracking needs.

site_title: Billionaire shareholder of Australia's Myer Holdings leads revolt against board
summary: Billionaire shareholder Solomon Lew led a revolt against Myer Holdings Ltd's board, with shareholders voting down executive pay proposals. Lew, who holds 10.8% of Myer, criticized the board's response to online competitors and stagnant sales growth, calling it "a very strong message" that the board's time is up. The rejection opens the door for a board spill next year, with Lew already commanding almost half of the required 25% vote to defeat the remuneration report in 2018.

site_title: On Home Ground
summary: Two Singaporean homeowners, Lim Choon Hong and Jefery Kurniadidjaja, share their unique living spaces. Lim, founder of Xtra, designed his four-storey home in Upper Bukit Timah, incorporating his favorite brands and eclectic style. The kitchen, designed by Italian architect Vico Magistretti, is a standout feature. In contrast, Kurniadidjaja, co-founder of Grafunkt, opted for a more minimalist approach, using his furniture company's pieces and making minor renovations to the 3,500 sq ft terrace house in Serangoon Gardens. Both homeowners emphasize the importance of personal taste and flexibility in home design.

site_title: Macbeth Reimagined
summary: Ninagawa Company's production of Macbeth, a reimagining of the Shakespeare classic set in feudal Japan, is set to premiere in Singapore on November 25. The production, directed by late Yukio Ninagawa, features exquisite period costumes and bloody katana-fights amidst cherry blossoms. This version rivals notable adaptations such as Akira Kurosawa's Throne Of Blood and Kenneth Branagh's live staging in 2013. The performance will be held at the Esplanade and tickets are available from Sistic.

site_title: Orchard Road to try out another 'scramble crossing'
summary: Singapore's Orchard Road will conduct a month-long trial of a pedestrian "scramble crossing" starting Dec 16, allowing shoppers to cross diagonally for 30 seconds. The trial aims to improve pedestrian connectivity and is part of the Orba initiative to enhance the precinct's street-level vibrancy. The trial will be held every weekend and on public holidays until Jan 28, and may be extended if successful.

images.alt_text: In the new trial, shoppers will be able to cross the Cairnhill Road-Orchard Road junction diagonally from H&M to The Heeren (above) for a period of 30 seconds.

site_title: GuocoLand's EcoWorld enters option to buy Sydney residences
summary: GuocoLand's Malaysia-listed unit, EcoWorld International, has entered into an option agreement to buy 25 out of 30 strata units in a Sydney site for A$33.8 million (S$34.7 million). The agreement gives EcoWorld consent from owners holding 84.2% of unit entitlements, allowing it to redevelop or sell the site. EcoWorld has until Sept 7, 2018, to exercise its option, with the option to acquire the remaining five units by negotiation or through the strata renewal process.

site_title: Bottoms Up
summary: Singapore's largest wine party, Uncorked Asia, is set to begin this weekend at Savourworld, featuring over 600 wine labels, masterclasses, live music, and food stations. Visitors can sample and buy wine at wholesale prices, with free entry available with a copy of the publication. The event runs at Science Park and more details can be found on www.uncorked.asia.

site_title: Developer urges Greece to show 'political will' on resort plan
summary: Greek developer Lamda has urged the government to demonstrate "political will" to clear hurdles for a luxury resort project on the site of a former Athens airport. The 8-billion-euro proposal, backed by Chinese and Gulf funds, aims to create 10,000 jobs. The project, which includes luxury residences, hotels, a yachting marina, and casinos, has been delayed. Lamda has submitted the proposal, despite initial concerns from local residents and environmental groups. The government's response is expected to shape the project's future.

site_title: Funny Man
summary: Vir Das, a rising stand-up star and actor, is set to perform in Singapore as part of his Boarding Das World Tour. The show, in support of Netflix's Abroad Understanding, marks Das's first Indian comedian special on the streaming service. His world tour has sold nearly a million tickets, and he also executive produces and stars in the Hulu original series In Theory. The performance takes place at Capitol Theatre on November 25 at 8:30 pm, with tickets available from S$48 to S$128.

site_title: OCBC Investment Research to come under Bank of Singapore
summary: OCBC Investment Research will merge with Bank of Singapore's research team in January, combining their expertise for greater synergies. The seven analysts from OCBC Investment Research will join the Bank of Singapore team, led by Marc Van de Walle, and will continue to report to him. The merger aims to enhance OCBC's wealth management platform, with Bank of Singapore clients benefiting from OCBC Investment Research's award-winning coverage of the Singapore stock market.

site_title: Maximum Protection
summary: Benjamins, an Italian label, offers stylish covers for the iPhone X, including hard cases with eye-catching motifs and embroidery designs. Mujjo, a Dutch designer, has released minimalist leather wallet cases with Japanese microfiber lining. The Nomad Clear Leather Folio showcases the iPhone's design while providing protection. Otterbox, the No.1 selling smartphone case in the US, has a new line-up for the iPhone X, offering various designs for different lifestyles.

site_title: SPH Golf November Medal & Laguna Golf Bintan Invitational
summary: The SPH Golf November Medal & Laguna Golf Bintan Invitational took place, marking a key moment a year ago when the non-estate golf privileges programme was launched with Sir Nick Faldo as honorary member. This event signifies the return to the club where the programme began.

site_title: Pack those clubs and head into a whole new world
summary: There is no article provided to summarize. The given text appears to be a collection of news article titles and publication dates, but no actual article content is included.

site_title: Marc Ong caps amateur year with final flourish
summary: Singaporean golfer Marc Ong caps his amateur year with a win at the Warren-MST Amateur Open, beating national team-mate Abdul Hadi in a play-off. Ong, 22, holed a difficult birdie putt to secure the victory, just minutes after missing a birdie attempt earlier in the round. This win marks a fitting climax to an impressive half-year for Ong, who will turn professional in January.

images.alt_text: Warren Golf and Country Club captain Yee Woon Yim (right) presenting the Warren-MST Amateur Open trophy to Marc Ong.
Ong will leave for Qualifying School in Thailand in January before he competes in the SMBC Singapore Open.

site_title: Kell Jay Lim
summary: Kell Jay Lim, former Accenture CRM/analytics consultant, took a pay cut to become the general manager of Grab (then GrabTaxi) in 2013. Under his leadership, Grab expanded rapidly, reaching 142 cities in seven South-east Asian countries and 4 million daily rides. App downloads tripled to 68 million, up from 45 million six years prior. Lim's decision to leave a stable job was worth it, as Grab's numbers have sizzled, with a five-fold increase in ride volume and a 50% increase in app downloads over the past five years.

site_title: Lexus is one step closer to making an uncrashable car
summary: Lexus is developing a lane-changing system that marks a step towards creating an uncrashable car. The goal is to eliminate car crashes by 2050, with human error being the main reason for most accidents. Lexus engineers believe that eliminating the need to drive would also eliminate crashes. The system uses sensors and cameras to detect and respond to lane changes, reducing the risk of accidents. While it's a small step, it represents a potential solution to the world's leading cause of traffic fatalities.

site_title: Hypebeast Hangout
summary: AW LAB, a multi-label boutique, has opened its first brick-and-mortar store in Asia Pacific at Suntec City in Singapore. The store will carry popular brands such as adidas Originals, Vans, Nike, New Balance, Jordan, and Under Armour, along with exclusive labels like Two of a Kind and Down UP. AW LAB offers a wide range of street-rooted apparel and limited-edition sneaker models. Located at Suntec City, West Wing, 3E Temasek Boulevard, #01-341/342, Singapore 038984.

site_title: These eco cars are about to get more expensive
summary: Eco cars in Singapore are set to become more expensive starting January due to a new vehicle tax scheme. The Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES) offers a rebate of up to S$20,000, compared to S$30,000 under the Carbon Emissions-based Vehicle Scheme (CEVS). Fewer cars will qualify for the cleanest A1 band under VES, resulting in increased costs for the very cleanest vehicles. This change is expected to affect buyers who want to save money and reduce their environmental impact.

site_title: Teamwork the key in SGA's push for excellence
summary: The Singapore Golf Association (SGA) recently defeated Malaysia 16-8 in the series at Keppel Club, marking a memorable year for golf in Singapore. This achievement can be attributed to the teamwork and collaboration among the SGA members, showcasing their commitment to excellence. The win is a testament to the growing popularity of golf in Singapore, with the SGA pushing the sport to new heights. The team's success is a reflection of their dedication and unity, setting a positive example for the golfing community in the country.
