site_title: Small-caps propel STI to 2-year high but mood cautious
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) reached a two-year high, closing at 3,442.15, driven by small-cap stocks. Gainers outnumbered losers 243 to 172, with nearly 2.57 billion shares changing hands worth S$911.9 million. The market was cautious, despite a quiet Black Friday shopping day.

site_title: AsiaPhos falls 15% on possible loss of licences for 3 mines
summary: AsiaPhos Limited shares fell 18.4% in early trading before closing down 14.6% to S$0.088 due to a request to vacate and rehabilitate two mining sites in China's Sichuan province. The company may have to bear 2.2 million yuan (S$448,316) in rehabilitation costs. AsiaPhos claims the request is not from the relevant authority and may be a prelude to formal negotiations on licence withdrawal. The company has sufficient inventories to cover operational needs until March 2018 and believes it can continue operating its downstream business effectively despite potential licence withdrawal.

site_title: Designer Touch
summary: Luxury fashion brands Tiffany & Co and Bottega Veneta are re-inventing themselves by bringing their high-end designs into the home with new collections. Tiffany & Co's "Tiffany Home & Accessories Collection" features handcrafted everyday objects in sterling silver, while Bottega Veneta has expanded its furniture and home accessories line with collaborations and its own atelier. FENDI also launched a new collection, "Welcome!", with a 17-piece ensemble designed by Chiara Andreatti, reflecting the brand's design DNA and incorporating natural materials.

site_title: Willing & Able
summary: Chef Willin Low, owner of Wild Rocket, has partnered with Christophe Lerouy and Gwen Lim of Patisserie G to open Lerouy, a new restaurant. Low, a lawyer-turned-chef, is taking a back seat in the kitchen, citing a desire to focus on business ventures. The trio met through Low's former restaurant, Dstllry, where Lerouy was head chef. The partnership marks a new chapter in Low's culinary career, following his previous ventures and resolutions to take it easier. Lerouy promises to bring bold, innovative cooking to the table.

site_title: MindChamps shares up 11% in mainboard debut
summary: MindChamps Preschool, the largest operator of premium-range preschool centers in Singapore, made its mainboard debut with shares rising 10.84% to close at 92 cents. CEO David Chiem plans to acquire "multiple schools" in China by 2018, rebranding them as MindChamps, and has already acquired and re-branded four preschool centers in Australia. The company expects to pay out 40% of its net profit as dividends in 2018. With a market cap of $222.3 million, MindChamps aims to expand into China and Australia with $34.5 million of IPO proceeds.

site_title: Productivity growth expected to hit 3% this year - highest rate since 2010
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to experience 3% productivity growth this year, the highest rate since 2010, driven by sectors such as manufacturing, finance, and professional services. Total employment is likely to remain flat or fall, but local employment growth is expected to outpace the decline. Productivity gains are critical to maintaining competitiveness and avoiding stagnant wages. The Ministry of Trade and Industry has upgraded its GDP growth forecast to 3-3.5%, with most growth coming from productivity improvements rather than employment changes.

site_title: Shop For Good
summary: K+ Artisans Weekend 2017 is returning to K+ and Scotts Square shopping mall on Nov 25-26, featuring 34 independent brands and makers, including Polkaros, WoonHung, and Mighty Jaxx. Workshops will also be held, and 10% of sales proceeds will be donated to HCA Hospice Care. The event aims to support local artisans while promoting community giving.

site_title: Porsche 911 GT3 4.0 review: Guilty pleasures
summary: The Porsche 911 GT3 4.0 is a high-performance sports car that prioritizes raw power over fuel efficiency. With a naturally-aspirated 4.0-liter engine, it produces exceptional acceleration, particularly for committed drivers. The shift towards turbo engines in the industry is attributed to stringent emissions standards. The 911 GT3 4.0's performance is undeniable, making it a guilty pleasure for those seeking a thrilling driving experience.

site_title: A Cook's Tour
summary: Auckland, New Zealand is renowned for its diverse and high-quality food scene, offering a taste of Maori hospitality and showcasing the country's produce. The city is home to top-rated restaurants such as Pasture, Giapo Haute Ice Cream, and The Sugar Club, each featuring local ingredients and unique culinary experiences. Visitors can also explore the region's wine country at Hawke's Bay, where the F.A.W.C! Food and Wine Classic takes place annually. For a more authentic Maori experience, the Napier Maori Tours offer a glimpse into the indigenous culture and its traditional cuisine.

site_title: High Court dismisses Ezion bondholder's originating summons
summary: The Singapore High Court has dismissed an originating summons taken out by bondholder Ravi Murarka, who sought a court declaration that Ezion Holdings' shares had ceased trading on the Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX). Murarka, who owns a significant share of the liftboat operator's bonds, had served Ezion a redemption notice citing the bond clause. The court's decision means Ezion's shares will continue to trade on the SGX.

site_title: You better watch out
summary: A range of articles were published on July 10-11, 2025, covering various topics. The US saw a drop in weekly jobless claims, while China urged Southeast Asian countries to support openness amidst US tariffs. Chinese property shares surged on reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Reliance Jio, owned by Ambani, delayed its India IPO beyond this year. China also unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: Everton sign deal to lease old dock as site for new stadium
summary: Everton Football Club has signed a 200-year lease agreement to use a site at Bramley Moore Dock in Liverpool for its new stadium. The lease is a "peppercorn rent" and is conditional upon securing funding and council consent. The stadium is expected to be a catalyst for a £5.5 billion regeneration of north Liverpool, including leisure and residential facilities. The move aims to improve Everton's match-day income, as its current stadium has a capacity of only 40,000, compared to Liverpool's 54,000-seat Anfield. The new stadium is expected to be completed in the new year.

site_title: Showtime
summary: Street opera, known as Wayang, was brought to Singapore by Chinese immigrants in the 19th century and gained popularity as a form of accessible entertainment. It incorporated singing, dancing, miming, acrobatics, and martial arts, with a unique blend of traditional music and instruments. Despite a decline in the 1970s due to industrialization, efforts by the government and community associations have helped preserve Wayang as part of Singapore's heritage, although its accessibility and affordability have changed over time.

site_title: CapitaLand and UnionPay to launch cashless payment in China
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based property developer, has partnered with China UnionPay to launch a cashless payment system in China through its CapitaStar rewards program. The alliance will integrate China UnionPay's debit and credit card facilities with the CapitaStar app, benefiting its 4 million members. The partnership aims to simplify transactions and enhance customer experiences, with plans to roll out facial recognition technology and innovation centers in China. The collaboration is part of Singapore's efforts to accelerate cross-border innovation with China.

images.alt_text: Capitaland has struck an alliance with China UnionPay to enable cashless payment in China through the former's cardless rewards programme, CapitaStar.

site_title: Cashless and ka-ching!
summary: The IMI Festival in Singapore adopted GrabPay, a cashless payment platform, to make the live music event more convenient for attendees. The festival-goers could pay for food, drinks, and merchandise using their mobile phones, eliminating the need for cash. GrabPay's ease of use and quick transactions were praised, with attendees appreciating the ability to top up their e-wallets and use the service for Grab rides and food purchases. This adoption of cashless payment technology is expected to boost spending and reduce queues and security costs for festival organisers.

site_title: Warning signs about another bitcoin exchange
summary: Bitfinex, a major unregulated Bitcoin exchange, has lost millions of dollars in customer money due to hacking incidents. The company, which operates in the British Virgin Islands, has been fined by US regulators and cut off by US banks. A recent hacking incident involving Tether, a virtual currency linked to the dollar, resulted in the loss of $30 million. Critics question the company's financial stability and the systemic risk it poses to the virtual currency industry. Regulators have tried to regulate the business, but unregulated exchanges like Bitfinex continue to operate, raising concerns about manipulation and money laundering.

site_title: Singapore bargain hunters throng stores for Black Friday shopping deals
summary: On Black Friday, shoppers in Singapore waited in long lines, with some staying overnight, to snag deals at stores like Robinsons Heeren. The Loh family, who started queuing at 11am on Thursday, were among the 150+ shoppers waiting by 6:20am on Friday. Some took time off work to secure the best deals, with one shopper, Art director Shing Cham, taking 1.5 days off to join the queue. Stores like Robinsons extended their hours, with Sephora opening at 9am, and offered free gifts with minimum spends.

site_title: BBQ Time
summary: Carnivore Brazilian Churrascaria at CHIJMES offers a party atmosphere with knife-wielding passadors serving freshly-grilled skewers of barbecue. The restaurant features a range of 15 cuts of meats, including Picanha, and over 16 types of hot and cold dishes. Readers can enjoy a 15% off buffet price on Saturdays and Sundays from Nov 24 to Dec 17, valid for dine-in only and excluding a-la-carte items. Prices are subject to 10% service charge and 7% GST.

site_title: Nike's bid to challenge old-school Adidas Cool gets winded
summary: Nike's attempt to revive the classic Cortez sneaker has fallen short, with weak sales and poor social media engagement. Despite a big campaign featuring supermodel Bella Hadid and rapper Kendrick Lamar, the shoe has failed to gain traction, outsold by Adidas' Stan Smith and Superstar models. Adidas' success is attributed to its ability to make retro models relevant and stoke demand among sneaker enthusiasts. Nike's sales continue to rise, but the company is shifting its focus to being more responsive to consumer needs, rather than relying on big marketing campaigns.

site_title: Factory output still running hot, but 'likely to cool off next year'
summary: Singapore's factory production grew 14.6% in October, driven by electronics and precision engineering, but economists foresee a slowdown in the fourth quarter and into 2018 due to less favorable base effects and slowing semiconductor demand. Excluding biomedical, manufacturing growth would have been 25.8%. The Ministry of Trade and Industry upgraded its forecast for Singapore's 2017 economic growth to 3-3.5%. Economists expect factory output to moderate towards the end of the year, with growth slowing to a single-digit pace in 2018.

images.alt_text: Electronics was the star performer. Within this cluster, semiconductors grew by a blazing 64.6 per cent.

site_title: Hope fades as search for Argentine submarine enters 9th day
summary: An Argentine submarine, the San Juan, has been missing for nine days, with hopes of finding the 44 crew members alive fading. Evidence suggests the submarine may have exploded, given a sound detected underwater consistent with an explosion. Relatives of the crew members have expressed despair and accused the navy of putting their loved ones at risk with an outdated vessel. The navy has denied these allegations, but the search operation continues.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Civmec has secured a role in Australia's A$4 billion offshore patrol vessel project, with production expected to begin in 2018. Cosco Shipping International has issued a formal offer to privatize Cogent Holdings, setting a Jan 5 deadline for minority shareholders. Top Glove Corp has entered exclusive negotiations to buy Adventa Capital's medical gloves business in a cash-and-shares deal. Jumbo Group reported a 6.7% drop in net profit due to higher expenses and a fall in other income.

site_title: Noble risks equity wipeout as shares retreat yet again
summary: NOBLE Group Ltd's shares plummeted 9.7% to 16.7 Singapore cents, the lowest level since 1999, amid a debt restructuring effort and asset sales. The company's market capitalization has collapsed from US$10 billion to US$166 million. Noble is transferring treasury shares to departing employees and has asked creditors to agree on a unified response to a restructuring proposal. Fitch Ratings Inc has cut the credit rating to junk territory, citing a probable default. The stock rout has wiped out the value of remaining equity holders, including founder Richard Elman and China's sovereign wealth fund.

site_title: Goldman says 'Fragile Five' are stronger than many think
summary: Goldman Sachs Asset Management, T Rowe Price Group, and BlackRock Inc have stated that the "Fragile Five" countries, previously downgraded by S&P Global Ratings, are stronger than initially thought. The countries, which include Brazil, India, Indonesia, Mexico, and South Africa, have shown resilience in the face of economic challenges. Investors are buying bonds from these nations, indicating confidence in their ability to respond to future shocks. This suggests that the global economic landscape has improved, allowing these countries to better withstand economic uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Even Pakistan, home to widening external deficits and shrinking foreign reserves, may be turning the corner. Corruption charges against Finance Minister Ishaq Dar and former prime minister Nawaz Sharif suggest national institutions are improving.

site_title: ChildAid 2017 raises over S$2m for beneficiaries
summary: ChildAid 2017 raised over S$2.1 million for socially-disadvantaged children, exceeding its goal. The event, now in its 13th year, featured a narrative musical about four children searching for their dreams in foreign lands. The musical, led by creative director Dick Lee, drew 1,325-strong audience and 192 child performers from Asia. Main sponsors Citi, HSBC, and UOB donated S$500,000 and above, with Suntory Beverage and Food Asia donating S$100,000. The event aims to inspire children to chase their dreams and has raised over S$16 million for arts training and school support funds.

site_title: For the stylish and the houseproud
summary: Cult Status columnist Michelle Quah shares unique gift suggestions for the festive season, focusing on fashion, accessories, and home décor items within a moderate price range. The article presents a curated list of stylish and thoughtful gifts, aiming to go beyond typical presents. Quah's suggestions cater to those seeking distinctive and affordable options for their friends and family.

site_title: Childish then, but Garcia is now a mature golfer
summary: Sergio Garcia, a golfer, competed in the Jumeirah Golf Estates course for the Race to Dubai crown. Despite having a 2-4% chance of winning, Garcia made a strong start with eight birdies but ultimately missed out on the title.

site_title: Beach Party
summary: Rosewood Hotels & Resorts has debuted its South-east Asian resort in Phuket, Thailand, with 71 beachfront-facing pool pavilions and villas. The property features in-house restaurants, including Thai and Italian options, and an integrative wellness concept called Asaya. The resort, which opened in early November, aims to differentiate itself in the luxury accommodation scene in Phuket with its unique offerings.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Wheelock Properties' Q3FY17 PATMI increased 72.1% year-on-year to S$48.8 million, beating expectations. The group's balance sheet strengthened with S$607 million in cash and equivalents. Thai Beverage Public Company's FY17 net profit surged 82% to 34.5 billion Thai baht, driven by one-off fair value gains. Both companies are recommended to "Buy" with fair value estimates of S$2.27 for Wheelock and S$1.07 for Thai Beverage.

site_title: Singing Standards
summary: Singer Frances Lee will perform a jazz standards concert at the Esplanade Recital Studio on December 1, 2017, featuring songs by Cole Porter, Barbra Streisand, Ella Fitzgerald, and Billie Holiday. This marks her first music performance, following her theatre and musical roles in productions such as Beauty World and Rent. The concert will be accompanied by Aaron Goh on piano, and tickets are available from Sistic.

site_title: Japan Inc takes further hit as another firm admits to faked data
summary: Mitsubishi Materials Corp admitted to falsifying data on products, including rubber seals and metal strips, affecting over 250 customers. The company's shares plummeted 11% as it reported the issue, following a similar scandal at Kobe Steel Ltd. The revelation is the latest in a series of scandals to dent Japan's manufacturing reputation, with other companies including Nissan and Subaru facing similar issues. Mitsubishi Materials' president stated that the company will investigate and take preventive measures, but the impact on earnings is unclear.

site_title: SPH Golf Travel Fair
summary: The first SPH Golf Travel Fair will open at Marina Square Shopping Mall in Singapore on April 6-8, offering golf enthusiasts deals on golf travel. The event aims to provide a platform for golfers to discover the latest travel packages and deals. No further details on the event's organizers or participating golf travel companies were mentioned.

site_title: Bank of China and Lianhe Zaobao launch co-branded credit card
summary: Bank of China and Lianhe Zaobao have launched a co-branded credit and debit card in Singapore, featuring UnionPay QuickPass for fast and secure contactless payments. This marks Singapore's first Diamond credit card.

site_title: Kimly posts S$5m profit in Q4
summary: Kimly Limited, a Singapore-based coffee shop operator, reported a net profit of S$4.98 million in the fourth quarter of 2017, up 76% from the same period last year. The full-year net profit was S$21.4 million, driven by revenue growth of 9.2% in Q4 and 12% in FY 2017. The company expects the F&B industry to remain challenging and is adopting technology to boost productivity and efficiency.

site_title: US online sales surge as shoppers throng stores on Thanksgiving night
summary: US online sales surged to over $1.52 billion on Thanksgiving evening, with 80% of online transactions tracked by Adobe Analytics. This marks a significant increase from last year, as shoppers turned to online shopping due to thinner crowds at stores. Average discounts ranged from 10-16%, with the best deals available online. The National Retail Federation projects a 3.6-4% increase in sales for November and December, driven by a strong labor market and rising home prices.

site_title: Black Friday deals lure few early US shoppers, many buy online
summary: US shoppers showed little enthusiasm for Black Friday deals, with crowds sparse at stores like Target and Macy's. Many opted to shop online instead, with over $1.52 billion spent online by Thanksgiving evening. Retailers are struggling to attract customers, as more people turn to online shopping. The traditional rush has been split by stores opening earlier, and deals are now available online for extended periods. This shift has forced brick-and-mortar retailers to adapt, with some filing for bankruptcy this year.

site_title: Final nights in Trump SoHo before the Trump name checks out
summary: The Trump Organization has reached a deal with the owner of the Trump SoHo hotel in Manhattan to remove the Trump name from the building by the end of next month due to faltering business. The hotel, which has lost revenue and shed guests due to controversy surrounding US President Donald Trump, has been offering reduced prices to attract travelers. Staff have quit, and some have even taken advantage of the situation to experience luxury at discounted rates, highlighting the hotel's opulent atmosphere despite its financial struggles.

site_title: Volkswagen Golf GTI review: Hot to trot
summary: Volkswagen's Golf GTI has been updated with a facelift, offering fast, fashionable fun with flexibility. The new model boasts a 10-horsepower increase and refined performance, making it one of the best bargains in motoring. The GTI can deliver hot and cold performances, thanks to its punchy power and persuasive performance. The updated model also features a new 9.2-inch touchscreen infotainment system and improved suspension, making it a great option for those seeking a versatile driving experience.

site_title: Centurion obtains nod for dual listing from Hong Kong stock exchange
summary: Centurion Corporation Limited has received an approval-in-principle from the Hong Kong stock exchange to list its shares on the exchange, allowing for a dual listing with the Singapore stock exchange. The company appointed a Hong Kong company secretary and share registrar in June and May, respectively. Centurion had previously stated it did not intend to delist from the Singapore stock exchange.

site_title: More Than Just Hollywood
summary: Los Angeles offers a diverse range of attractions beyond its iconic landmarks. The city boasts over 105 museums, including The Broad and The Getty Center, which feature prominent postwar and contemporary art collections. Visitors can also explore the city's beaches, such as Venice Beach, and enjoy outdoor activities like hiking and shopping. The city's food scene is diverse, with popular spots like the Grand Central Market and Eggslut serving a range of cuisines. Additionally, the city's Arts District offers a mix of art, food, and culture, with spots like Wurstkuche and Angel City Brewery.

site_title: The taxman cometh, and he means to have a hike
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that taxes, particularly the Goods and Services Tax (GST), will likely be raised in the upcoming national budget, sparking speculation and concern among citizens. The current 7% GST has not been changed since 2007, and a hike could disproportionately affect lower-income segments of the population. The government is exploring alternative revenue sources, including personal and corporate taxes, and potential new taxes like a sugar tax. Economists argue that higher taxes can be manageable if the funds are used effectively.

site_title: Mnangagwa sworn in as Zimbabwe president
summary: Emmerson Mnangagwa was sworn in as Zimbabwe's president on November 24, 2017, ending 37 years of Robert Mugabe's rule. Mnangagwa, 75, vowed to uphold the Constitution and protect citizens' rights, but some question his role in the 1983 Gukurahundi massacres. Despite Mnangagwa's promise of democracy, concerns remain about his treatment of Mugabe loyalists and his past involvement in the atrocities. Mnangagwa's swearing-in ceremony was attended by thousands of supporters, bringing a close to Mugabe's rule.

images.alt_text: Since his return to Zimbabwe, 75-year-old Mr Mnangagwa has been preaching democracy, tolerance and respect for the rule of law.

site_title: New initiative launched to connect Singapore and China tech firms
summary: Singapore's government launched the first overseas initiative under the Global Innovation Alliance (GIA), connecting Singapore and China tech firms. The GIA (Beijing) initiative will create launch pads for Singapore firms to connect with China's vibrant startup ecosystem, promoting innovation and entrepreneurship. The initiative aims to give Singaporeans opportunities to gain overseas experience and build networks, with funding and testing opportunities for selected startups. The move follows Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat's prioritization of innovation and strategic initiatives in China.

site_title: Jaguar's Cyber Monday sale sees prices kick off at S$99,000
summary: Jaguar is hosting a Cyber Monday auction in Singapore, offering three cars for sale online. The auction will feature a 2.0-litre petrol Jaguar XE, XF saloon, and F-Pace SUV, with starting prices of S$99,000, S$159,000, and S$199,000 respectively. The auction will last 24 hours, starting on Nov 27, and is expected to reach a tech-savvy audience. This marks the first online auction for new cars in Singapore, with Wearnes Automotive aiming to "get ahead" of a possible trend in car retail.

site_title: Midas falls to historic lows amid worries about its debt, earnings
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singapore-based company that manufactures train car bodies, plummeted to historic lows on Friday, closing at S$0.148 after a 25% drop in just a few days. The company's shares were trading near S$0.20 just a week ago. Concerns over its debt and earnings outlook, including worries about China's infrastructure spending, have contributed to the decline. Despite this, DBS analyst Paul Yong remains confident in the company, citing its strong credit quality and positive earnings momentum.

site_title: Sydney to spend A$2b to rebuild its two biggest stadiums
summary: The New South Wales state government plans to spend A$2 billion to rebuild Sydney's two largest stadiums, the ANZ Stadium and Allianz Stadium, replacing them with new 75,000-seat and 45,500-seat arenas. Critics argue the funds could be better spent on improving schools and hospitals, with Labor opposition leader Luke Foley calling the project a "white elephant." The redevelopment is expected to take several years to complete and will attract 3.5 million visitors annually, contributing over A$1 billion to the state's economy.

images.alt_text: The 83,500-capacity ANZ Stadium was completed in 1999 for Sydney's hosting of the 2000 Summer Olympics.

site_title: Full Circle
summary: Japanese architect Takano Todo and Singaporean visual artist Justin Lee have collaborated on an exhibition titled "The Circles of Life" at Japan Creative Centre in Singapore. The exhibition features ceramics, silkscreen fabrics, and prints inspired by the 2011 tsunami and the upcoming Tokyo 2020 Olympics. The collection aims to reflect on the nature of life and how it is influenced by events like the tsunami. The exhibition runs until December 9, with free admission from 10am to 6pm, Tuesday to Saturday.

site_title: US: S&P and Nasdaq hit records highs
summary: US stocks reached record highs on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite closing at 2,601.61 and 6,876.55, respectively. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 28.33 points to 23,554.51. The gains were attributed to rising oil prices and retail stocks ahead of the Black Friday shopping season. Despite recent tariff uncertainty, investors remained optimistic, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Militants kill 184 in attack on mosque in Egypt's north Sinai: state media
summary: Militants attacked a mosque in Egypt's north Sinai region, killing 184 people and wounding 125. The attack, which included a bomb detonation and shootings, targeted worshippers and ambulances. The Islamic State affiliate has been battling Egyptian security forces in the region since 2014. President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi declared three days of mourning and convened an emergency meeting with his defense and interior ministers. This attack is one of the deadliest in the region's Islamist insurgency.

site_title: Kimly posts S$5m Q4 profit on higher revenue
summary: Kimly Limited reported a net profit of S$4.98 million for the fourth quarter, a 76% increase from the previous year. This brings the full fiscal-year net profit to S$21.4 million, primarily driven by a restructuring exercise in shareholding structure when Kimly listed on the Catalist board in March. The surge is considered technical and not indicative of long-term growth.

site_title: Why most needs can be covered by term insurance
summary: A man named Mark spent 60% of his $1 million budget on a comprehensive fire-safety plan for his dream house, sacrificing interior design and materials to fully cover potential fire risks. This story illustrates how people often over-insure themselves, treating insurance as a financial goal rather than a contingency plan. The author argues that term insurance is a more practical and cost-effective solution for most people's insurance needs, especially for covering risks such as loss of income, disability, and medical expenses.

site_title: CapitaLand, UnionPay to launch cashless payment in China
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean real estate company, has partnered with China UnionPay to launch a cashless payment system in China through its CapitaStar cardless rewards program. This partnership aims to simplify transactions for CapitaStar's four million members in China and enhance their live, work, and play experiences. Additionally, CapitaLand has sealed technology collaborations with leading Chinese players, including launching a China-focused venture fund and introducing facial recognition technology at its offices and malls in China and Singapore.

site_title: United Food agrees to sell unit for 75m yuan
summary: United Food Holdings has agreed to sell its unit, Post-Ante Trading, to Financial Services Company for Innovative Industry in China Limited for 75 million yuan (S$15.28 million). Post-Ante Trading holds land use rights and machinery in Linyi City, Shandong province, with operations mainly in soybean processing and animal feed production. The sale comes after the company ceased operations in the pig rearing segment in 2014 and the soybean processing division in 2015 due to anti-pollution restrictions. The transaction is expected to be completed soon.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise, won hovers above 2-1/2-year high
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 7.18 points or 0.28% to 2,544.33, while the Korean won hovered above a 2-1/2-year high at 1,085.4 per US dollar. Bond yields rose, and the benchmark index gained 0.4% for the week. The Kospi has risen 25.2% this year and 2.52% in the past 30 days.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Friday, down 4.04 points to 1,717.23, with volume reaching 1.83 billion shares worth RM2.52 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 521 to 344.

site_title: Yuan eases, but set for best week since mid-October
summary: China's yuan weakened against the US dollar on Friday, with the official midpoint set at 6.5810 per dollar, its strongest in six weeks. The People's Bank of China's guidance rate breached the key 6.6 level, driven by strong corporate demand for the greenback. The yuan is on track for its best week in over a month, despite the central bank's efforts to support the currency.

site_title: Merkel to sit down with rival as German coalition edges closer
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel is set to meet with her opposition rival Martin Schulz next week to discuss forming a government after her coalition attempt with the Free Democrats and Greens collapsed. Merkel's Bavarian sister party will also attend. This meeting, hosted by President Frank-Walter Steinmeier, aims to find a way forward for Merkel's government after an inconclusive election two months ago. Merkel has been operating in a caretaker capacity since then, with the talks potentially resolving the country's political deadlock.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close up but Mitsubishi Materials plunges
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.12% to 22,550.85, rebounding from earlier losses, while Mitsubishi Materials plummeted 8.06% after a quality control scandal. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 0.69% for the week. Investors took advantage of late bargain-hunting, but external factors such as a strong yen and concerns over the Chinese market's stability also influenced the market. Sony and SoftBank rose, while Panasonic and Toyota fell.

site_title: Euro hits six-week high on growth outlook optimism
summary: The euro reached a six-week high against the US dollar, rising 0.6% since Monday, driven by optimism over the euro zone's recovery and weaker US dollar. The single currency is on track for a third straight week of gains, its best run since July. Strong economic data, including robust growth outlook and firm global commodity prices, contributed to the euro's strength, while US dollar weakness and US Federal Reserve policy concerns also played a role.

site_title: Two BMWs for two lucky buyers in Singapore
summary: Two special edition BMW i8 models, the Protonic Frozen Yellow Edition and Protonic Frozen Black Edition, have been introduced in Singapore. These limited-edition cars feature unique cosmetic and interior designs, including special paint, stitching, and trim materials. Mechanically, they are identical to standard i8s, with a 1.5-litre petrol engine and 96-kilowatt motor. Each car costs S$603,800, including Certificate Of Entitlement, making them exclusive and rare opportunities for drivers to combine eco-friendliness with high-performance driving capabilities.

site_title: JUMBO posts 6.7% drop in FY profit
summary: JUMBO Group Limited reported a 6.7% drop in net profit for FY 2017 to S$14.47 million, despite a 6.1% increase in revenue to S$145.1 million. Higher expenses and lower other income offset the revenue rise. The group plans to focus on lowering operating costs and improving productivity, and will explore opportunities to expand its F&B outlets. A tax-exempt final cash dividend and special dividend of 0.5 and 0.7 cents per share, respectively, were proposed for shareholders' approval.

site_title: Europe: Equities hold steady at open
summary: European stock markets steadied on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index flat at 7,417.74 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index up 0.1% to 13,023.52 points, and Paris' CAC 40 down 0.1% to 5,379.54 points. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks. Meanwhile, US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching new highs.

site_title: Productivity growth this year expected to be about 3%: Lim Swee Say
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow 3% this year, with productivity growth reaching 3% - the highest rate since 2010. Most of the growth is attributed to productivity gains, with total employment change likely to be flat or negative. Despite this, local employment is expected to grow faster than last year, driven by productivity improvements in sectors such as manufacturing, finance, and professional services. However, economists caution that the growth may not be sustainable beyond the current phase of the global economic recovery, and that productivity growth needs to translate into rising real median income for Singaporeans.

site_title: Singapore shares close up 0.55% on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at a fresh two-year high, rising 18.98 points, or 0.55%, to 3,442.15. The index gained 243 to 172 stocks, with notable movers including MindChamps PreSchool and Thai Beverage. Midas Holdings, however, faced a bourse query over heavy selling, which left the stock down 3.9%. The index has now reached its highest since May 2015.

site_title: Joining global festive online mega-sales gives local retailers' cash registers a merry peal
summary: Singaporean retailers are capitalizing on global online sales events, such as Singles' Day, to expand their reach beyond the local market. This year's Singles' Day saw a 240% increase in sales on Tmall Global for Singaporean retailers, with brands like Tiger Balm and Love, Bonito experiencing significant growth. Local companies are leveraging e-commerce platforms to tap into China's massive market, with 60,000 international brands participating in the event. Industry experts believe that Singapore's infrastructure and open economy make it an ideal location for cross-border e-commerce growth.

images.alt_text: That tourists from China head to Hong Kong, Thailand or Singapore to track down Tiger Balm products prompted Haw Par Corporation - the group behind the iconic ointment - to take part in the global online shopping extravaganza on Nov 11.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's factory production grew 14.6% in October, beating economist estimates. MindChamps Preschool shares jumped 11% in its Mainboard debut. DBS Group Holdings Ltd surpassed Singtel to become South-east Asia's most valuable company. Noble Group's shares retreated, risking an equity wipeout. Meanwhile, shoppers thronged stores for Black Friday deals, while the High Court dismissed a bondholder's originating summons. The STI closed up 0.55% on Friday, with Top Glove Corp entering exclusive talks to buy a medical gloves business.

site_title: Panic reigns as China railway play Midas falls to historic lows
summary: MIDAS Holdings, a Singapore-based company supplying aluminium parts to China's trains, has plummeted to historic lows amid debt and earnings concerns. Shares closed at S$0.148, down 3.9% from the previous day, with over 39 million shares changing hands. Despite CEO Patrick Chew's assurance that the company has no information on the sudden decline, DBS analyst Paul Yong remains confident, citing strong credit quality of Midas' customers and a recent extension of its US$30 million debt.

site_title: UBS seeks to expand workforce in artificial intelligence
summary: UBS is expanding its workforce in artificial intelligence, hiring data scientists, architects, and business analysts to leverage the technology in areas such as fraud prevention, optimization, and risk management. The move comes as big banks like UBS are using AI to stay competitive, with most financial service companies working with AI technologies. Despite the growing demand for AI experts, UBS is facing challenges in finding qualified candidates, and the bank's CEO has predicted a 30% reduction in the workforce over the next decade.

site_title: GuocoLand's EcoWorld enters option to buy Sydney residences for A$40m
summary: GuocoLand's Malaysian-listed unit, EcoWorld International, has entered an option agreement to buy 25 out of 30 strata units in a Sydney site for A$33.8 million. The owners of the remaining five units will be acquired through negotiation or the strata renewal process. If EcoWorld exercises the option by September 7, 2018, it could pay A$40 million for the project, assuming a rate of A$3,635 per square metre. The site is located in Macquarie Park, 12km north-west of Sydney's central business district.

site_title: Pure Yoga and Pure Fitness owner said to near sale to Chinese buyer
summary: A Chinese private equity firm, FountainVest Partners, is in advanced talks to buy control of Pure Group, the owner of Pure Yoga and Pure Fitness centres in Singapore, Hong Kong, and other locations. The deal would value the company at over $400 million, with billionaire-backed owners including buyout firm Leonard Green & Partners and businessman Bruce Rockowitz expected to divest significant portions of their holdings. Pure Group operates over 70,000 clients and employs 1,400 staff, with a new fitness club recently opened in Singapore and a new yoga studio slated for launch in Hong Kong.

site_title: Taiwan Q3 economic growth highest in over two years
summary: Taiwan's economy grew 3.1% in the July-September period, the highest in over two years, driven by robust overseas demand for consumer electronics products. This growth is attributed to a 17.49% increase in exports, primarily from electronic components. The Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics has raised its fourth-quarter forecast to 2.3% year-on-year and 2017 full-year growth to 2.58%, the highest since 2014. Despite major infrastructure projects planned for 2018, the economy is expected to grow 2.29% in 2018.

site_title: Aussie shares muted on bearish message from China; NZ up
summary: Australian shares fell 0.06% on Friday, weighed down by a slump in the Chinese stock market following a sell-off in Chinese bonds amid Beijing's deleveraging drive. China's CSI300 index tumbled nearly 3% and ended the day down 0.8%. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.35% as healthcare stocks led gains.

site_title: DBS overtakes Singtel as Southeast Asia's most valuable company
summary: DBS Group Holdings Ltd has surpassed Singapore Telecommunications Ltd as the most valuable company in Southeast Asia, with a market capitalization of S$62.97 billion. The bank's "digital to the core" strategy has contributed to its success, focusing on customers who generate a higher return on equity. DBS has seen a 42% gain this year, outperforming the Bloomberg Asia Pacific Banks Index, while Singtel added 1.4%. The telecommunications company faces increased competition from TPG Telecom Ltd.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks up after sell-off
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.53% on Friday, rebounding from previous day's losses, while Shanghai edged up 0.06%. The Hang Seng Index closed at 29,866.32, but the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.09%. The rally was despite traders remaining cautious over China's crackdown on speculative investing.

site_title: Singapore factory output in October powers ahead with 14.6% rise
summary: Singapore's factory production surged 14.6% in October, exceeding economist estimates, driven by strong electronics growth. Excluding biomedical output, factory output rose 25.8% and electronics growth was 45.1%. Precision engineering and chemicals also showed decent growth, while transport engineering declined 3.8%. The Ministry of Trade and Industry upgraded its 2017 economic growth forecast to 3-3.5% due to strong trade momentum and electronics demand.

site_title: PSA, NUS to jointly develop engineering, ICT programmes for next generation of port industry professionals
summary: PSA Corp and the National University of Singapore (NUS) have signed a memorandum of understanding to jointly develop engineering and ICT programmes for the next generation of port industry professionals. The collaboration aims to cultivate students' knowledge in data analytics, cybersecurity, and automation. PSA will provide problem statements and case studies to help NUS students apply these technologies to modern port operations. The partnership is expected to strengthen Singapore's position as a global maritime hub and create new career pathways for PSA employees.

images.alt_text: Professor Tan Eng Chye, NUS Deputy President (Academic Affairs) and Provost, and Mr Ong Kim Pong, Regional CEO Southeast Asia, PSA International after signing the MOU.

site_title: MindChamps shares jump 11% in Mainboard debut; CEO says will enter China by 2018
summary: MindChamps Preschool, Singapore's largest operator of premium preschool centers, made its mainboard debut with a 10.84% increase in shares, closing at S$0.92. The company aims to enter China by 2018 and plans to acquire and rebrand existing preschools. CEO David Chiem stated that the company will collect fees from these acquired schools, utilizing a unique, empirically-researched curriculum. MindChamps has a market cap of S$222 million and plans to distribute 40% of its net profit as dividends in 2018.

site_title: Mitsubishi Materials shares tumble after firm says units falsified product data
summary: Mitsubishi Materials shares plummeted 11% on Friday after the company revealed that its subsidiaries had falsified product data, affecting over 250 customers. Inspection data was manipulated for aircraft, automobiles, and industrial machinery parts, with no safety or legal issues found. The company has informed 54 of the 258 affected customers and stopped shipping affected materials. Japan's defence ministry is investigating the impact of the wrongdoing, but does not plan to stop using affected equipment.

images.alt_text: Mitsubishi Materials said that inspection data was falsified on parts used in aircraft, automobiles and industrial machinery, with more than 250 customers potentially affected.

site_title: Noble Group risks equity wipeout as shares retreat yet again
summary: Noble Group's shares have plummeted 9.2% to 16.8 Singapore cents, their lowest since 1999, as the company continues to restructure its debt burden and offload assets. The market capitalization has collapsed from $10 billion to $167 million. Noble Group is seeking to agree on a unified response to its restructuring proposal with creditors, amid concerns of a potential default. The company's shares have lost 18% since Friday's close, wiping out the value of remaining equity holders.

site_title: US dollar poised for weekly dip, pressured by Fed's inflation caution
summary: The US dollar is expected to decline this week due to the Federal Reserve's cautious stance on low US inflation, which remains below the 2% target. This follows minutes from the Fed's policy meeting showing policymakers concerned about weak inflation. The dollar has already declined after the release of the minutes, and further losses are predicted as the US markets resume trading after the Thanksgiving holiday.

site_title: Chinese airlines court Cathay pilots facing pay squeeze
summary: Chinese airlines are targeting disaffected Cathay Pacific pilots with high salaries to address a shortage of experienced captains, with over 100,000 new pilots needed by 2037. Chinese carriers, including China Southern Airlines and Hainan Airlines, are offering attractive salaries to fill the gap. The Civil Aviation Administration of China forecasts a shortage of captains with several thousand hours of flying experience, despite training around 4,700 new pilots annually.

site_title: Japan politician with baby ejected from chamber; sparks debate
summary: A Japanese politician, Yuka Ogata, was ejected from a municipal assembly meeting in Kumamoto city after bringing her 7-month-old baby to highlight workplace issues affecting women. The incident sparked debate over the chamber's rules, which only allow politicians, staff, and officials to attend. Ogata's action drew attention to the challenges women face in the workplace and the need for greater support.

site_title: Singapore shares resume flat on Friday afternoon; STI at 3,425.93
summary: Singapore shares resumed trading flat on Friday, with the Straits Times Index up 0.42% or 14.52 points to 3,437.71 as of 1pm. About 1.15 billion shares worth S$356 million changed hands. Allied Tech and QT Vascular were trading unchanged. This marks a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: 13 Myanmar passengers killed in Thai van crash: police
summary: Thirteen Myanmar passengers were killed in a van crash in central Thailand on Friday, when their vehicle collided with a 10-wheeler truck and burst into flames. The victims were on their way to Bangkok from the border town of Mae Sot, a common entry point for migrant workers. The Thai driver was also killed in the accident, which is part of Thailand's high rate of road fatalities, with over 24,000 deaths per year, according to the World Health Organisation.

site_title: Australia shares fall on weak China sentiment; NZ up
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% on Friday, weighed down by a slump in the Chinese stock market and concerns over the country's economy. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,970.100, its lowest since November 16. Financials dragged the index down, with the "Big Four" banks and industrials sectors also suffering losses. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.3% as healthcare stocks led gains.

site_title: AsiaPhos receives request for undertaking to vacate two mines in Sichuan; does not intend to sign
summary: AsiaPhos Limited, a phosphate-mining firm, received a request to vacate and rehabilitate two of its mining sites in China's Sichuan Province within the Jiudingshan Nature Reserve. The company stated it does not intend to sign the request, citing uncertainty about the request's authenticity. The mines, Mine 2 and the Feng Tai mine, were to be fully vacated by November 30 with the possibility of compensation. AsiaPhos plans to source rocks from other suppliers and believes its downstream business will mitigate the effects of the licence withdrawal.

site_title: Top Glove enters exclusive talks to buy medical gloves business from Adventa
summary: Top Glove Corp has entered exclusive negotiations to buy Adventa Capital's medical gloves business, Aspion, in a cash-and-shares deal. The final terms are yet to be decided, but the deal is expected to establish Top Glove as the largest surgical glove exporter in Malaysia and one of the largest worldwide. The acquisition is expected to provide access to new technologies, a higher gross profit margin, and a wider geographical reach. Adventa has agreed to negotiate only until January 15, 2018. The deal is expected to be finalized based on Aspion's after-tax profit and a multiple of 16-18 times the 2018 target after-tax profit.

site_title: Singapore consumers very open to buying financial products from big tech firms: Bain study
summary: A survey by Bain & Co found that 75% of Singaporeans are willing to try financial products from big tech firms like Amazon, Apple, and Alibaba, compared to 46% for start-ups. Established tech companies have earned high consumer trust, outperforming traditional retail banks. The study suggests that big tech firms' accessibility and existing payment services will enable them to expand into retail banking. To compete, traditional banks must speed up digital channel development to handle routine transactions.

site_title: Singapore shoppers throng stores for Black Friday deals; Queue starts at Robinsons 11am the day before
summary: Shoppers in Singapore flocked to stores on Black Friday, with some waiting for 20 hours to snag deals. At Robinsons, a queue of over 150 people formed by 6:20am, with some camped out overnight. Many took time off work to take advantage of discounts, with some aiming to get free gifts like iPhone Xs. The event marks the growing popularity of Black Friday in Singapore, with both online and brick-and-mortar stores offering extended hours and promotions.

site_title: Gold steadies as US dollar weakens further
summary: Gold prices steadied near flat on Thursday as the US dollar weakened further, extending its biggest drop in five months. The dollar's decline made gold cheaper for non-US investors, supporting prices. Spot gold settled 0.1% lower at $1,290.80 per ounce, while US gold futures were also 0.1% lower. Analysts see gold reaching its year-end target of $1,325 due to low inflation expectations, subdued yields, and rising geopolitical risks.

site_title: Virtual reality boom brings giant robots, cyberpunk castles to China
summary: China's first virtual reality theme park, the Oriental Science Fiction Valley, is set to open in Guiyang, Guizhou province, promising 35 virtual reality attractions, including giant robots and cyberpunk castles. The $1.5-billion park aims to boost China's virtual reality market, expected to grow tenfold to $8.5 billion by 2020. The park is part of China's efforts to develop new growth drivers in gaming, sports, and technology, and is expected to change the tourism structure of Guizhou province.

site_title: Civmec clinches role in Australian navy's A$4b patrol vessel project
summary: Singapore-listed Civmec has secured a role in Australia's A$4 billion project to build 12 offshore patrol vessels, with 10 to be constructed at the Henderson Maritime Precinct in Western Australia. Prime contractor Lürssen will utilize Civmec's capabilities and Austal's expertise. Production is expected to start in the fourth quarter of 2018. Civmec's share price was halted for the announcement, which was made on November 24, 2017.

site_title: Hot stock: Midas not aware of information that could explain stock's 7.8% drop
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singapore-listed aluminium alloy company, saw its stock drop 7.8% to S$0.142 on Friday due to unusual trading activity. The company stated it was unaware of any information that could explain the heavy selling. The stock had previously risen after Midas announced a 6.6% increase in net profit and a 11.5% increase in revenue for its third quarter. The unusual trading prompted a query from the Singapore Exchange, but Midas claimed it had no knowledge of the reason behind the stock's decline.

site_title: UK consumer confidence slumps to post-Brexit vote low: survey
summary: British households are their least confident since the Brexit vote, with a consumer confidence index dropping to 106.6 in November, down from 109.3 in October. The slump is attributed to interest rate hikes and a slowdown in the housing market. Factors contributing to the decline include the Bank of England's first interest rate hike in over a decade and a sharp cut to Britain's economic growth outlook by the Office for Budget Responsibility.

site_title: Ex-White House advisor Flynn moves to cooperate with probe: report
summary: Former White House national security advisor Michael Flynn is cooperating with a special prosecutor probing possible collusion between Donald Trump's campaign team and Russia during the 2016 election. Flynn's lawyers notified the president's legal team that they could no longer discuss the investigation, indicating Flynn is cooperating or negotiating a deal. This development comes as Mueller's investigation has led to the arrest of several Trump associates, including Paul Manafort and George Papadopoulos, who pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI. Flynn's frequent contacts with then-Russian ambassador Sergey Kislyak and alleged lobbying for Turkey are also under scrutiny.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.15 points to 1,719.12. Volume was 113.64 million lots worth RM63.79 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 147 to 118.

site_title: Australia's Myer says tough conditions to continue
summary: Australia's Myer Holdings Ltd, the country's largest department store chain, expects challenging conditions to continue into the second quarter. Billionaire investor Solomon Lew is set to challenge the appointment of Garry Hounsell as Myer chairman at the annual general meeting. Lew, chairman of Premier Investments Ltd, which controls a 10.8% stake in Myer, has demanded a greater say on the board. Myer's shares have fallen 40% since Premier Investments made the purchase in March. The outcome of the vote will determine the shape of Myer's new board.

site_title: Australian watchdog proposes to extend coordination between Jetstar's Asian brands
summary: Australia's competition watchdog has re-authorised coordination between Jetstar's Asian brands, including Jetstar Asia, Jetstar Pacific, and Jetstar Japan, for another five years. The coordination allows the brands to operate as a single organisation on matters such as flight scheduling and pricing. The decision is expected to result in public benefits, according to ACCC commissioner Roger Featherston. The Jetstar brands are also exploring partnerships with their shareholding airlines to expand passenger and cargo services in Asia.

images.alt_text: The coordination allows the brands - Jetstar Asia, Jetstar Pacific and Jetstar Japan - to operate as a single organisation on matters such as flight scheduling, marketing and pricing, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission added.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks resume gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks resumed their upward trajectory on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.50% to 29,856.88, following a one per cent drop. In contrast, Shanghai's Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.34% to 3,340.38, and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.38% to 1,917.12.

site_title: Hot stock: AsiaPhos falls 16% on possible loss of licences for 3 mines
summary: AsiaPhos Limited shares have fallen 18.4% after receiving a request to vacate and rehabilitate two of its mining sites in China's Sichuan Province. The company may have to bear 2.2 million yuan (S$449,680) in rehabilitation costs. The request may be a prelude to negotiations on withdrawing mining and exploration licences for two mines. AsiaPhos has sufficient inventories to cover operational needs until March 2018 and plans to source rocks from other suppliers.

site_title: New Zealand trade deficit narrows despite imports at record high
summary: New Zealand's trade deficit narrowed to NZ$871 million in October, despite record-high imports of US$5.4 billion, driven by a surge in dairy and lamb exports. Total exports rose to NZ$4.561 billion, with dairy and lamb shipments being the key drivers. The annual trade deficit widened only slightly to NZ$2.986 billion. The New Zealand dollar remained largely unchanged.

site_title: Bank of China, Lianhe Zaobao launch credit card for SPH readers
summary: The Bank of China and Lianhe Zaobao have launched a co-branded credit and debit card for Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) readers. The card offers various benefits, including 30.7% savings on petrol, 10% cash rebate on dining and shopping, and exclusive privileges at UnionPay partner merchants. It also allows cardholders to make fast and secure contactless payments with UnionPay QuickPass. The card is Singapore's first Diamond credit card equipped with this technology and will be compatible with the Bank of China Singapore e-wallet app.

images.alt_text: The Singapore branch of Bank of China and Lianhe Zaobao, the Chinese flagship newspaper of Singapore Press Holdings, have launched a co-branded credit and debit card.

site_title: China Hongxing: Wrote off some overdue debt from almost all customers
summary: China Hongxing Sports wrote off debt from 33 of 37 customers, accounting for 95% of its revenues in the first nine months of 2017, due to overdue payments over six months. The company has negotiated longer credit periods with suppliers and will continue to trade with the customers, but there is hope that payments will be made later. The company's shares are currently suspended from trading.

site_title: US online sales surge, shoppers throng stores on Thanksgiving evening
summary: US shoppers spent over $1.52 billion online by Thanksgiving evening, a 16.8% year-over-year increase, according to Adobe Analytics. Despite a trend of online shopping, stores saw a moderate crowd on Thanksgiving evening and Black Friday, with retailers opening early to attract customers. Strong labor markets, rising home prices, and stock markets have improved shopper appetite, reversing the trend of thin crowds seen in the past two years.

site_title: Europe: Markets flat as Wall Street stays shut for Thanksgiving
summary: Europe's major stock markets remained flat to firmer on Thursday, with the US markets closed for Thanksgiving. Despite a quiet trading session, European equities rose, driven by favourable economic indicators for France and the wider eurozone. The eurozone economy showed resilience against Brexit, with business rising sharply in November. In contrast, London's FTSE was affected by a domestic energy supplier's profits warning, while the dollar struggled following dovish Federal Reserve minutes.

site_title: Musk beats deadline for building world's biggest battery
summary: Elon Musk has completed a 100-day deadline to build the world's largest lithium-ion battery in South Australia, winning a $50 million bet. The battery, built by Tesla, will help prevent energy blackouts in the state. Testing is set to begin soon, with the goal of providing back-up power for thousands of homes. The project aims to reduce Australia's reliance on coal-fired power and lower greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo shares dropped 0.54% on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling to 22,401.37, amid investor adjustments ahead of the weekend and US players staying away from the global market.

site_title: Cosco Shipping sets Jan 5 deadline for Cogent privatisation bid
summary: Cosco Shipping International has issued formal offer documents for its S$1.02 per share bid to privatize Cogent Holdings, setting a Jan 5, 2018 deadline for minority shareholders. The acquisition, valued at S$488.07 million, aims to leverage Cosco Shipping's existing logistics business platform to develop new opportunities in South-east Asia. Cogent's four undertaking shareholders hold about 84.33% of the company's shares, and the independent financial adviser, CIMB, is expected to review the offer within two weeks.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks edge up, won takes a breather
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 3.10 points or 0.12% to 2,540.25 at 01:14 GMT on Friday. The Korean won held steady, while bond yields rose. The Kospi is up 25.2% so far this year and 2.52% in the previous 30 days. Foreigners were net sellers of 21,442 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Singapore shares slip at Friday's open; STI down 0.2% to 3,423.17
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.2% lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,423.17. Gainers outnumbered losers 44 to 39, with 30.7 million shares worth S$28.6 million traded. MindChamps PreSchool listed at S$0.85, 21.4 times subscribed to its initial public offer. The rally ahead of GDP data and no major economic news may have influenced the market.

site_title: MindChamps opens 1.2% above IPO price at 84 S cents on debut day
summary: MindChamps, an early education company, made its trading debut at 84 Singapore cents, 1.2% above its initial public offering (IPO) price. The IPO consisted of 30.45 million shares, with institutional investors subscribing for 5% or more of the invitation shares. Founded in 1998, MindChamps operates 54 preschools and reading-and-writing centers across four countries, with Singapore Press Holdings being a shareholder. The company's stock opened at 87.5 cents and traded 4.2% up on its opening price.

site_title: Uber told SoftBank about data breach before telling public on Nov 23
summary: Uber revealed that it informed potential investor SoftBank about a massive data breach before publicly disclosing the incident on November 23, 2017. The ride-hailing service said it discussed the breach with SoftBank as part of its duty to disclose to a potential investor, despite having incomplete information at the time. Uber's internal investigation took over two months to complete, and the company made the public disclosure once it had a more complete understanding of the facts.

site_title: Brokers' take: ThaiBev earns 'buy' rating from DBS, OCBC on FY17 results
summary: Thai Beverage (ThaiBev) has been given a "buy" rating by DBS Equity Research and OCBC Investment Research following its fourth quarter results. The company's FY17 headline net profit surged 82% year-on-year to 34.5 billion baht, driven by one-off fair value gains. Core net profit grew 4.6% year-on-year, and the company increased its full-year dividend payout. Analysts expect ThaiBev's performance to improve on a recovery in consumption, with DBS reiterating a "buy" recommendation and OCBC maintaining a "buy" rating.

site_title: Capital World acquires right to develop Johor township for RM63m
summary: Capital World acquires a joint development right to develop a 207.5-acre township in Johor, Malaysia, for RM63 million (S$20.6 million). The township, located near the Pengerang Integrated Petroleum Complex, is expected to drive demand for housing in the area. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to capture the rising housing demand in Pengerang, complementing Capital World's portfolio of mixed developments. The joint development right expires on Jan 18, 2114.

site_title: Hoe Leong unveils debt restructuring plan
summary: Hoe Leong Corporation has unveiled a debt restructuring plan to restructure S$77 million in debts owed to creditors. The plan involves converting S$20.7 million in debts into vessel loans and spare part loans, and extinguishing the remaining S$56.3 million through the issuance of new shares. The scheme is subject to various conditions, including creditor approval and shareholder consent. The company has also applied for a court-mandated moratorium on creditor actions until July 31 next year.

site_title: Rolling Stone's S'pore shareholder wants to buy the magazine
summary: Kuok Meng Ru, 29, is in talks to buy Rolling Stone's 51% stake, following Jann Wenner's decision to put the magazine up for sale. Kuok, founder of BandLab Technologies, aims to expand the brand globally, leveraging his existing music business. The sale comes as Rolling Stone struggles with declining sales and online advertising dominance. Wenner Media's 27-year-old son, Gus, will remain at the helm, but Jann Wenner will step down.

site_title: US oil hits 2-year high on pipeline outage, lower inventories
summary: US crude oil prices hit a two-year high due to a pipeline outage and lower fuel inventories, despite rising US production. West Texas Intermediate crude rose 54 cents to $58.56 per barrel, while Brent crude increased 23 cents to $63.55 per barrel. The Keystone pipeline shutdown is expected to reduce crude stocks in the US, and lower inventories are also supporting prices. US output has risen 15% since mid-2016, threatening OPEC's efforts to reduce global supplies.

site_title: Britain slashes property purchase tax for first-time buyers
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May has slashed property purchase taxes for first-time buyers, aiming to win over younger voters who shunned the ruling Conservatives due to unaffordable housing. The move, which abolishes stamp duty for homes up to £300,000 and reduces it on higher-priced properties, is expected to benefit one million people over five years. Finance Minister Philip Hammond announced the change in his annual budget statement, amid concerns that the policy could push house prices up.

site_title: Did you fall for Russian propaganda? Facebook will show you
summary: Facebook is launching a software tool to help users see if they engaged with Russian propaganda on the platform, particularly on Instagram and Facebook pages linked to the Internet Research Agency between 2015 and 2016. The tool aims to combat online misinformation and division, following Congressional pressure and other tech firms' efforts to combat disinformation. The move comes as Facebook faces criticism for allowing the spread of bogus news, including some directed by Russia, ahead of the 2016 US election. The tool will be released by the end of this year.

site_title: High Court dismisses Ezion bondholder's originating summons
summary: Singapore's High Court dismissed an originating summons filed by bondholder Ravi Murarka against EZION Holdings, a liftboat operator, citing a clause that allows him to demand repayment if the company's shares cease to be traded. The summons was filed after EZION suspended trading of its shares in August to discuss a debt reorganisation plan. EZION won bondholders' approval for a refinancing plan last week, which will help unlock a US$100 million working capital line. The company's shares remain suspended.

site_title: Penguin pledges S$10m to debt-laden Marco Polo Marine
summary: Penguin International, a Singapore-based offshore and marine company, has pledged S$10 million as an investor in debt-laden Marco Polo Marine, with a 10% stake in the company's enlarged share capital and a board seat. This move, despite Penguin's conservative cash management, is seen as a strategic investment, with the company expecting Marco Polo to turn around with new equity and resume its primary businesses. Penguin's executive chairman, Jeffrey Hing, believes the risks are manageable and the company will benefit from good bargains, with excess cash on hand to acquire vessels.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Cosco Shipping, Cogent Holdings, Ezion, MindChamps
summary: Cosco Shipping International issued formal offer documents for its S$1.02 per share bid to privatize Cogent Holdings, with acceptances due by Jan 5. Ezion Holdings' originating summons against a bond holder was dismissed by Singapore's High Court. MindChamps PreSchool made its debut on the Mainboard, with its IPO at 83 Singapore cents per share subscribed 21.4 times.

site_title: Zimbabwe's next leader prepares to take power
summary: Zimbabwe's Emmerson Mnangagwa is set to become the country's new president after the dramatic departure of Robert Mugabe, ending 37 years of authoritarian rule. Mnangagwa, who has close ties to the army and security establishment, returned home after being fired as vice-president and led a triumphant return, promising a new democratic era. He will be sworn in as president on Friday, amid warnings from the army about criminals impersonating soldiers and calls for Zimbabweans to obey the law. Critics warn that Mnangagwa could prove as authoritarian as Mugabe, and opposition figures are cautiously optimistic that he will establish a power-sharing government.

site_title: Trump Organization to exit NY SoHo hotel
summary: US President Donald Trump's family company, the Trump Organization, has sold its management and licensing agreement for the Trump SoHo Hotel in New York to CIM Group, a Los Angeles-based investment firm, ending the use of Trump's name at the hotel by the end of the year. The deal comes after the hotel struggled to attract guests and condo sales fell short of expectations. The termination fee is likely to be in the millions of dollars. This marks the second time this year the Trump name will be removed from a hotel-condominium tower, following a similar agreement in June for the Trump International Hotel & Tower in Toronto.

site_title: Oxley close to buying Chevron House
summary: Oxley Holdings is nearing a deal to buy Chevron House in Singapore for approximately S$660 million, working out to S$2,526 per square foot on the existing net lettable area. The 32-storey office and retail development, currently 98% leased, has 261,280 sq ft of NLA. Anchor tenant Chevron is expected to move to a new location, and Oxley may refurbish the property and sell its strata units or retain it as an investment property. This deal comes as the office investment sales market in Singapore sees significant activity, with S$8 billion in transactions sealed year-to-date.

site_title: Philanthropy - the 'leveraged giving' way
summary: Assisi Hospice chairman Anita Fam suggests leveraging government matching donations to attract new donors and cultivate long-term supporters. This "leveraged giving" model, where governments match private funds on a dollar-for-dollar basis, can maximize the impact of donations, producing two dollars for every dollar given. This approach is attractive to today's philanthropists looking to maximize their donations' impact.

site_title: A Japanese dinner that hits the spot
summary: Kyuu, a Japanese dinner restaurant in Singapore, offers an impressive omakase experience at S$129 for a 10-course meal. Chef Issey Araki's carefully curated menu features a mix of inexpensive and indulgent ingredients, presented in a civilized and comfortable setting. The open kitchen showcases Araki's skillful knife work, while the ala carte menu starts at 9pm. The meal includes a variety of dishes, from sashimi to grilled seafood and wagyu beef, all prepared to perfection. Overall, Kyuu provides a unique and satisfying dining experience without breaking the bank.

site_title: With a grim Brexit budget, Hammond hushes critics for now
summary: British Finance Minister Philip Hammond's Brexit budget has placated critics with a tax break on buying first properties, but faces intense pressure to address economic uncertainty and rising living costs. The budget slashed growth forecasts but maintained a cautious approach to Brexit and public finances. Hammond's efforts to win back voters, particularly young first-time home-buyers, have won over some Conservative lawmakers, but others remain skeptical. The Office for Budget Responsibility predicts a grim decade for productivity, with GDP growth forecast at 1.5% in 2017.

site_title: Correcting misconceptions about meaning of 'offshore'
summary: The Paradise Papers, a leak of financial information, has raised questions about the legitimacy of offshore entities and investments. However, experts argue that offshore structures are not inherently illicit, but rather provide a convenient way for individuals to manage assets and protect their privacy. Offshore trusts can be used for legitimate purposes such as legacy planning, protecting against forced heirship rules, and investing in zero-tax offshore funds. The problem lies not with offshore entities themselves, but with errant service providers who turn a blind eye to illicit activities. The rule of law should prevail, and existing defamation laws should be balanced with the right to privacy.

site_title: Pig farming in China's north-east going the whole hog
summary: China's largest pig farming companies are expanding to the north-eastern cornbelt, aiming to produce nearly 120 million pigs annually, upending traditional trade flows in meat and grain. The region, with its sparsely populated areas and cold winters, is ideal for large-scale farms. This expansion will modernize China's hog farming sector, create mega integrated farms, and boost demand for the region's main crops, revitalizing some of the country's poorest regions and fighting farm pollution. The move is expected to reshape grain trade, increasing corn needs by at least 4.6 million tonnes annually.

site_title: Bridging the gap in the needs of health care
summary: Gerardo Legaspi, director of the Philippine General Hospital, emphasizes the importance of private funding in sustaining government institutions. Charity patients receive free medical services, but inefficiencies hinder proper use of government funds. Private donations support initiatives like the Pediatric Neurosurgical and Craniofacial Unit, which has helped over 300 children. Legaspi aims to develop the private wing to equalize opportunities for patients and attract more private patients, generating revenue to fund subsidized services.

site_title: Emaar Development IPO takes a beating due to M-E geopolitical risk
summary: Emaar Development's stock fell 4.3% on its debut in Dubai, the worst performance among the 10 biggest IPOs in the Middle East and Africa since 2014. The IPO was fully subscribed, but geopolitical tensions in the region, including Saudi Arabia's crackdown on corruption and Lebanon's prime minister's resignation, led to a risk-off environment. Analysts attribute the decline to knee-jerk selling, but predict the stock will find support as sentiment improves. The share sale is the largest in Dubai since 2014, with Emaar Properties finishing up 2.6% despite a previous decline.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Swiber Holdings' shareholders have agreed to a rights cum warrants issue to settle a US$36.6 million debt. Vallianz's net owings to Swiber will be converted into shares, with each rights share having two free detachable warrants. Meanwhile, Ascendas Property Fund Trustee has agreed to acquire six warehouses from Arshiya Limited for S$112.5 million. Dukang Distillers Holdings has seen its production decrease by 60-70% due to severe air pollution in China, affecting its second and third quarters.

site_title: Brighter outlook, but restructuring must continue
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow 3-3.5% this year, driven by a brighter global outlook and strong trade momentum. The Ministry of Trade and Industry has upgraded its forecast, citing the economy's strongest quarterly growth in four years. However, companies should not let the improving outlook lead them to abandon restructuring efforts, as the economy still faces resource constraints, including manpower scarcity and rising business costs. A cyclical recovery may not last, and companies should continue to push for change to create a more efficient and sustainable basis for future growth.

site_title: Eight rescued after US Navy aircraft crashes off Japan
summary: A US Navy C2-A Greyhound aircraft crashed off Japan, resulting in the deaths of three personnel and the rescue of eight others. The incident occurred during a routine transport flight, and engine trouble is suspected to be the cause. The aircraft was on a mission to ferry cargo and passengers between Marine Corps Air Station Iwakuni and USS Ronald Reagan, which was participating in an exercise with Japanese forces.

site_title: A peek into designers' homes in BT Weekend
summary: Designers' homes featured in BT Weekend, showcasing their personal spaces, include Lim Choon Hong, Grafunkt's Jefery Kurniadjaja, and architect Philip Yong. The magazine also explores Singapore's retirement housing options, the inaugural IMI Festival, and the launch of the BMW i8 Protonic Frozen Yellow and Frozen Black Editions. Additionally, it features reviews of the Porsche 911 GT3 and Volkswagen Golf GTI, and lifestyle articles on mod-Indian cuisine and corporate purpose.

site_title: Onetime 'world's heaviest man' has second surgery in Mexico
summary: Juan Pedro Franco, 33, who was once the heaviest man in the world at 595kg, underwent a second stomach-reduction surgery in Mexico. The minimally invasive laparoscopy procedure aimed to help him shed over 200kg, with a goal weight of 120kg. After the successful operation, Franco is expected to be released in the next few days and hopes to stop taking diabetes and high blood pressure medication, and regain the ability to walk after seven years.

images.alt_text: Juan Pedro Franco, 33, who once weighed in at a stunning 595kg - about the same as a male polar bear - began a weight-loss programme a year ago, bringing his current weight to 366kg.

site_title: Raising private investments in S-EA infrastructure key, says World Bank
summary: The World Bank's Cledan Mandri-Perrott emphasized the need for increased private investments in South-east Asia's infrastructure development. Despite a rising trend, private participation remains low, with US$15 billion invested in infrastructure projects last year. Mandri-Perrott highlighted the importance of stable regulatory and political environments, as well as addressing uncertainties such as currency devaluations and capital repatriations. The region's countries must work together to create favorable conditions for private investors, according to the World Bank official.

site_title: Rollback of net neutrality protections has small US businesses worried
summary: The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) proposes to roll back net neutrality protections, which could significantly impact small US businesses. The rules, established in 2015, prevent internet service providers from slowing down or charging extra for certain websites. Without these regulations, small businesses fear they'll be at a disadvantage against larger companies that can afford to pay for faster internet speeds.
