summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has introduced two robots, Amy and Eve, to automate data entry tasks, reducing processing times by over half. The robots, using Robotics Process Automation software, assist with tasks such as processing Letters of Credit and reviewing credit card applications. Amy and Eve have been assigned to teams supporting UOB's wholesale and retail businesses, allowing human employees to focus on more challenging roles. The bank plans to onboard more robots in the coming months to manage other processes.

site_title: The Middle East's new balance of power
summary: Riyadh and Jerusalem are seeking US support to counterbalance Iran's growing influence in the Middle East. Israel and Egypt, who fought wars in 1967 and 1973, now maintain full diplomatic relations and may be coordinating their military strategy against Iran. This shift is a departure from the Cold War era, when the US and Soviet Union dominated the region. The move has raised concerns that the US may be drawn into a new regional conflict, challenging Washington's traditional role in the Middle East.

images.alt_text: Emerging as a central player in this changing regional environment has been the 32-year-old Saudi Arabian prince and heir apparent to the throne, Mohammed bin Salman.

site_title: Ford may exit some markets in South America, says JPMorgan
summary: Ford is considering exiting some markets in South America to turn around its money-losing business in the region. Analyst Ryan Brinkman said the company may work with rival carmakers and selectively exit certain markets. Despite economic and political crises, Ford continues to focus on making South America "operationally fit." The company has lost $587 million in South America in the first nine months of the year, but has boosted revenue on stronger sales and pricing. Ford has a factory in Venezuela and is committed to addressing the region's losses.

site_title: Kismis View launched for en bloc sale for S$102m
summary: Kismis View, a 90% consented collective sale site in Singapore, has been launched for sale by tender with a minimum price of S$102 million. The 90,863 sq ft site is zoned "Residential" and has a balance lease term of 64 years. JLL expects a low-rise apartment development of up to five storeys with a maximum of 168 units. The site's land cost reflects S$983 per sq ft per plot ratio, comparable to nearby land sales. The tender will close on January 17, 2018.

images.alt_text: Sole marketing agent JLL said the site may be redeveloped into a low-rise apartment development of up to five storeys, with a total gross floor area of about 139,929 sq ft including a 10 per cent bonus balcony area.

site_title: STI up 6.64 points in cautious market
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 6.64 points, or 0.19%, to 3,430.02 on Wednesday, its highest since May 2015, driven by gains from blue-chip stocks such as Singtel, Keppel Corporation, and DBS Group Holdings. Analysts attribute the rally to cautious optimism ahead of Singapore's GDP and inflation numbers, while markets globally, including the US and Asia, have been buoyed by strong economic indicators and a strong Dow Jones.

site_title: NODX on pace for fastest growth in at least 7 years; 2017 forecast raised to 6.5%-7.0%
summary: Singapore's trade agency, IE Singapore, raised its full-year forecast for non-oil domestic exports (NODX) to 6.5%-7.0% in 2017, up from a previous forecast of 5%-6%. The third-quarter growth rate of 7.6% is the fastest in at least seven years, driven by electronic products and machinery exports. Total merchandise trade is expected to grow 10.0%-10.5% for the full year, with oil trade rising 22.1% in the third quarter. The stronger export growth is attributed to a strengthened global economic and trade outlook.

images.alt_text: Singapore's trade agency is raising its full-year forecast for non-oil domestic exports (NODX) after the trade benchmark grew at a faster 7.6 per cent year-on-year pace in the third quarter of 2017.

site_title: 50 years on, Rolex and golf are still linked
summary: Rolex, the Swiss luxury watch brand, is celebrating its 50th anniversary with golf, solidifying its position as the sport's most passionate supporter. Founded in 1905, the company's enduring relationship with golf began in 1967 with golf legends Arnold Palmer, Jack Nicklaus, and Gary Player. Today, Rolex supports golf worldwide, partnering with major tournaments and organizations, and has a stable of influential golfers endorsing the brand, including Jason Day, Annika Sorenstam, and Jordan Spieth. Rolex aims to continue its support of golf long into the future.

site_title: Great Barrier Reef vs coal jobs in Queensland election
summary: The proposed Carmichael mine in Queensland, Australia, is a defining issue in the state election, with voters weighing the promise of new jobs against potential environmental threats to the Great Barrier Reef. The Labor government has vowed to reject A$900 million in federal funding for a new rail link, which could threaten the viability of the project. The outcome of the election may hinge on the fate of the mine, with opinion polls indicating a close result. The project's supporters argue it will create thousands of jobs, while opponents claim it could exacerbate coral bleaching and increase carbon pollution.

site_title: Cromwell Reit re-launches IPO after changes
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) has re-launched its initial public offering (IPO) after making changes to its portfolio. The trust, now comprising 74 properties, had initially excluded seven Polish retail assets due to investor concerns. The revised IPO offers 428.5 million units, raising 236 million euros, and is expected to start trading on November 30. The trust's yield of 7.8% is at a premium to the average 6% yield of Singapore Reits, with cornerstone investors including Cerberus Singapore and SingHaiyi Group.

site_title: GST hike is a reasonable price to pay for a stronger fiscal footing
summary: The Singapore government may consider raising the Goods and Services Tax (GST) to build a more sustainable fiscal base, given the country's growing national budget outflow and operating revenue growth. A GST hike would be a reasonable price to pay, as it has a wide reach, less impact on competitiveness, and can be mitigated through schemes like the GST Voucher for lower-income households. However, the government should help retailers in the short term to minimize the impact on consumer spending and the retail industry.

site_title: Strong trading in UK housing market: Countryside
summary: UK property developer Countryside reported robust trading in the housing market, with strong customer demand and favourable mortgage lending conditions. Completions rose 28% to 3,389 units for the year ended Sept 30, and the private forward order book jumped 8% to £242.4 million. This contrasts with peers who have flagged weakness in the sector, citing Brexit-related concerns and industry-wide skills challenges. Countryside attributes its success to low interest rates, the government's Help to Buy scheme, and "good political support."

site_title: Europe: Shares retreat on euro bounce; UK flat after budget
summary: European shares retreated on Wednesday, led by a bounce in the euro and a lack of progress in forming a new German government. The Stoxx 600 benchmark closed 0.3% lower, while the UK's FTSE index remained flat after the UK budget failed to impress. Despite the market's decline, analysts remain optimistic, citing a strong year-end rally in Europe, which has yielded positive returns 74% of the time. Energy and travel sectors saw gains, while consumer goods were the biggest decliners.

site_title: Kendall Jenner ousts Gisele Bundchen as world's top- earning model
summary: Kendall Jenner has surpassed Gisele Bundchen as the world's highest-paid model, earning an estimated $22 million in 2017. Jenner's social media influence and endorsement deals with brands like Adidas and Estee Lauder contributed to her success. Ashley Graham, a plus-size model, entered the Forbes list at 10th place with $5.5 million in earnings. The top 10 models collectively earned $109.5 million, driven by the growing power of social media influencers. This marks the first time Jenner has topped the list since 2002.

site_title: Trafigura's bonds show new financing route for commodity traders
summary: Trafigura, a major oil trader, has successfully sold US$470 million of bonds to six banks and plans to offer longer-dated notes to the capital market. The bonds, backed by a portfolio of crude oil and refined metal inventories, provide a new financing route for commodity traders, offering long-term committed funding, scalability, and access to a wider investor base. This new structure marks a milestone in the commodity financing space, potentially offering a solution to Noble Group's funding difficulties, and is expected to transform the industry.

site_title: RE&S Holdings closes 41% higher on first trading day
summary: RE&S Holdings Limited, a Japanese food and beverage group, made its debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board, closing 41% higher on its first trading day at 31 Singapore cents, exceeding its issue price of 22 cents. The stock received strong interest from investors, with 32 million invitation shares subscribed 37.8 times and 16 million cornerstone shares fully allocated to a sole cornerstone investor, Orchid 2 Investments Pte Ltd. Despite initial concerns over earnings, analysts have recommended subscribing to the IPO due to the company's diversified portfolio and strong management team.

site_title: US homes sales accelerate, supply still a constraint
summary: US home sales rose 2% in October to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.48 million units, exceeding expectations. The chronic shortage of houses continues to push prices upwards, sidelining first-time buyers who accounted for 32% of transactions. The median house price increased 5.5% from a year ago to $247,000, marking the 68th consecutive month of year-on-year price gains. Economists attribute the increase to easing hurricane-related disruptions and a rebound in sales in Houston and Jacksonville, but warn that the general lack of inventory remains a major obstacle.

site_title: Microsoft's Skype pulled from app stores in China
summary: Microsoft's Skype service has been removed from app stores in China, following a government announcement that foreign internet phone call apps violated local laws. Apple and other stores in China have pulled Skype, citing the government's decision. This is the latest setback for a foreign tech service in China, where the government has increasingly restricted foreign internet services. The move is seen as a further tightening of the country's strict internet regulations.

site_title: Driverless buses to be tested in 3 new towns from 2022
summary: The Singapore government plans to test driverless buses in three new towns, Punggol, Tengah, and the Jurong Innovation District, starting from 2022. These buses will operate during off-peak hours, providing a first- and last-mile commute solution for residents and workers. This marks the first time driverless buses will be available in Singapore, aiming to enhance public transportation efficiency and convenience.

images.alt_text: The Cetran Autonomous Vehicle Test Centre will facilitate the testing of autonomous vehicles in a simulated real-world environment, to prepare for their integration into public roads in the future.

site_title: Disney animation legend Lasseter takes leave over misconduct
summary: Disney animation legend John Lasseter is taking a six-month leave of absence after co-workers accused him of unwanted touching and hugs. Lasseter, 60, apologized for "missteps" that made people feel uncomfortable, citing instances of grabbing, kissing, and making comments about physical attributes. Disney committed to maintaining a respectful work environment and supported Lasseter's sabbatical. The move has raised concerns about leadership and the future of Pixar's creative direction, with some analysts questioning who will fill Lasseter's role as chief creative officer.

site_title: Nets to score home run with S$30m investment in cashless platform
summary: Nets, a payment services group, will invest over S$30 million to launch a unified e-payments platform in Singapore. The platform, which will be supported by DBS, OCBC, and UOB, aims to expand its interoperable QR code cashless payment system to over 100,000 acceptance points nationwide. The move represents a key milestone in Singapore's pursuit of a cashless society and is expected to be a success for Nets, leveraging the support and expertise of the three major banks.

site_title: Singapore's fiscal challenge
summary: Singapore is facing fiscal challenges, with various initiatives being implemented to address these concerns. The government has set up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific, while graduates are advised to remain calm despite early data showing better employment rates. Deputy Prime Minister Gan is scheduled to visit the US for trade talks, with a new grant of up to S$100,000 available for businesses affected by tariffs. Additionally, a study suggests Singapore has the potential to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging, and workforce development programs are being offered to help workers future-proof their careers.

site_title: MyRepublic tops up S$70m war chest; sets Q1 2018 for mobile launch
summary: MyRepublic, a Singaporean telecommunications company, has secured S$70 million in funding from Makara Capital to boost business growth. The investment is seen as a significant step towards the company's mobile launch, set for Q1 2018. MyRepublic's CEO believes the funding will "push the gas" on its growth plans, indicating a promising future for the company.

site_title: Hang Seng Index rises above 30,000 to decade-high
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index reached a decade-high of 30,003.49, up 0.6% due to gains in energy producers and Chinese developers, with Tencent Holdings Ltd surging 22% and Ping An Insurance Group Co jumping 23%. The index's rally is attributed to sustained inflows from mainland China and optimism about the global economy and US tax cuts. Analysts predict the index may reach 32,000 by the end of next year, with Goldman Sachs and Bocom International Holding Co forecasting continued growth in Chinese banks and technology shares.

site_title: Businesses need to leverage megatrends in Asia-Pacific
summary: The Asia-Pacific region is experiencing rapid growth, with a projected 440 million new middle-class citizens by 2023, driving megatrends of rapid urbanization, changing demographics, and hyper-globalization. These trends will create opportunities for businesses to innovate and grow, but also pose challenges such as cybersecurity threats and the need for sustainable and efficient infrastructure. To capitalize on these megatrends, businesses must undergo digital transformation, embracing new technologies and mindsets to stay competitive and deliver value to customers.

site_title: Airbus eyes single-pilot, autonomous airliner to help carriers cut costs
summary: Airbus is developing autonomous aircraft and single-pilot technology to reduce costs for carriers, with the goal of enabling a single pilot to operate commercial jetliners. The company's chief technology officer, Paul Eremenko, stated that autonomous technologies could also enable unpiloted operation. However, regulatory and public acceptance hurdles must be overcome, and the industry faces a shortage of pilots, with Boeing estimating 637,000 pilots will be needed globally in the next two decades. Airbus is exploring technologies for urban air mobility and has agreed to set up an innovation center in China to accelerate research and development.

site_title: Singapore issues travel advisory after small eruption at Bali volcano
summary: Singapore has issued a travel advisory to its citizens due to a small eruption at Indonesia's Mount Agung volcano in Bali, warning of potential ash clouds that could disrupt air travel. The alert status on Agung remains at one level below the highest, with no reports of flight cancellations. Singapore advises citizens to be ready to evacuate at short notice. Indonesia's National Disaster Mitigation agency says the eruption was a "phreatic eruption" with black smoke reaching 700 meters, and has downplayed the advisory as "excessive."

site_title: Clashes and little progress at Nafta talks
summary: US officials extended the Nafta renegotiation timeline and asked officials to skip the current round, but tensions remained high with Canada and Mexico. The US proposed raising the vehicle industry's manufacturing threshold to 85% and requiring half a car to be made in the US, sparking counterproposals and criticism. Progress was made on technical issues, but the parties continued to clash on contentious issues like trade disputes and government contracts. The US may withdraw from Nafta if negotiations fail, but economists warn it could harm the US economy, with a study predicting 187,000 jobs lost over a one- to three-year period.

images.alt_text: The negotiating parties continue to clash on the most contentious issues, including mechanisms to resolve trade disputes and award government contracts, as well as rules of origin.

site_title: Big tobacco companies face tax reckoning in Japan on next-gen products
summary: Japanese lawmakers are set to propose changes that could erode tax advantages for Big Tobacco's heat-not-burn products, potentially impacting Philip Morris International, British American Tobacco, and Japan Tobacco. The changes aim to raise revenue and curb health costs caused by smoking, with rival groups within Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's coalition debating levies based on weight, per unit, or nicotine content. A consensus is yet to be reached, with some lawmakers advocating for equalized tax rates and others seeking to maintain the tax advantage of heat-not-burn products.

site_title: Logistics industry well-placed to overcome challenges amid disruption
summary: The logistics industry is well-positioned to overcome challenges amid disruption, driven by e-commerce and online innovations. Business leaders discuss the need for cost competitiveness, productivity, and innovation to maintain excellence in service and quality. The industry is expected to become more digitalized and connected, with automation and robotics revolutionizing the sector. New opportunities for logistics players include emerging technologies such as AI, machine learning, and the Internet of Things. While disruption may lead to job losses, higher value-added jobs will be created in areas such as IT, data science, and business analytics. SMEs can survive and thrive by collaborating across industries and adopting technology.

site_title: China's steel industry - strict up north, easy down south
summary: China's steel industry is experiencing a divide between the north and south due to environmental restrictions. Mills in the colder northern regions, such as Beijing and Tianjin, are facing output restrictions, while southern mills are operating at full capacity with increased demand for their products. This has led to a shift in demand for iron ore, with southern mills benefiting from stronger demand and northern mills being affected. The restrictions are expected to cut steel production by around 30-50 million tonnes, but production hikes in other areas may offset the loss.

site_title: Demand for gold in China lifts profit at jeweller Chow Tai Fook
summary: Chow Tai Fook Jewellery Group Ltd reported a 46% increase in net income to HK$1.78 billion for the six months through September, driven by lifted demand for gold products in China. Revenue rose 15% to HK$24.8 billion, with retail sales increasing 16% in mainland China and 13% in Hong Kong and Macau. The company expects a turning point in the jewellery market recovery, with total rent costs expected to decline 15% in the current financial year.

site_title: US core capital goods orders post biggest drop in a year
summary: US core capital goods orders declined 0.5% in October, the largest drop in a year, following three months of gains. Shipments of core capital goods advanced 0.4% last month, driven by strong momentum in the economy as the year ends. The decline in orders is seen as a normal fluctuation, with business spending on equipment expected to continue supporting economic growth. The news comes after Republicans in Congress approved a broad package of tax cuts, including a 20% corporate tax rate, which is expected to boost manufacturing and economic growth.

site_title: Retail therapy at a click? You'll likely have to pay GST soon
summary: Singapore's government may soon impose Goods and Services Tax (GST) on e-commerce purchases, targeting big e-commerce players and consumers buying online. Senior Minister Indranee Rajah said e-commerce will be part of the tax regime in 20 years. The current exemption threshold of S$400 for online purchases may be reviewed. A "reverse-charge" mechanism could be used to tax digital services from foreign companies, or merchants could register for GST if they sell to Singapore consumers. Consultation with stakeholders is recommended to study the impact of new measures.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPHT) maintains FY17 distribution per unit guidance of 20-23 HK cents, translating to a 6.1-7.0% dividend yield. Management expects a mild decline in average selling price and low single-digit throughput growth in key terminals.

site_title: EuroSports upbeat with better numbers, new cars on the way
summary: EuroSports Global, a supercar dealer, reported a net loss of S$237,000 on a turnover of S$32.7 million for the six months ending Sept 30, a significant improvement from the previous year. The company attributes the improvement to better financial results. EuroSports is optimistic about strong sales from a new marquee model, which is expected to contribute positively to the company's financial performance. The company's improved financial results and prospects for future growth have boosted its investor confidence.

site_title: Trump spares his first Thanksgiving turkey
summary: US President Donald Trump spared his first Thanksgiving turkey, pardoning it for being born a turkey. Trump made the announcement in the Rose Garden, praising the bird's size and appearance before thanking American families and military personnel. The pardon, a long-standing White House tradition, was met with a sense of relief, as Trump seemed to momentarily set aside his ongoing Russia investigations and other pressing issues. The turkey, named Drumstick, will live instead of being eaten, a gesture Trump characterized as a "very special" act.

site_title: Whitman steps down as HP Enterprise CEO
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Co (HPE) CEO Meg Whitman announced her departure on Tuesday, effective immediately, after a six-year tenure. Shares fell over 6% following the announcement. Whitman oversaw the company's split into HPE and HP Inc in 2015 and aggressively shed assets to focus on server and networking businesses. Antonio Neri, a relatively unknown HP executive, will take over as CEO, and Whitman will remain on the board. The move comes as corporate customers shift operations to the cloud, leading to a decline in server sales.

site_title: US core capital goods orders post biggest drop in a year
summary: US core capital goods orders declined 0.5% in October, the largest drop in a year, after three months of gains. Shipments of core capital goods rose 0.4% last month, fueled by expectations of corporate tax cuts. Business spending on equipment has boosted economic growth for four quarters, and is expected to contribute to GDP in the October-December period.

site_title: Raising GST is the best way to expand revenue base
summary: Singapore's government may consider increasing the Goods and Services Tax (GST) to expand its revenue base. This could be achieved through a rate increase or a lowering of the exemption threshold. However, a rate increase would require rebates for lower-income groups, while a threshold reduction would increase the number of smaller businesses liable for GST. The government also faces challenges in maintaining competitiveness and achieving higher economic growth. According to Victor Mills, CEO of the Singapore International Chamber of Commerce, Singapore needs more taxpayers to support its economic growth.

site_title: Black Friday sales gain importance in UK amid Brexit jitters
summary: British retailers have extended Black Friday sales for two weeks to combat Brexit-related price increases and stagnant wage growth. The UK's midmarket stores saw their worst October sales in history, with a 5.2% decline. To tap into holiday shopping budgets, major chains such as Currys PC World and AO World began Black Friday promotions earlier this year. The extended sales period aims to boost sales before competition increases.

site_title: Japan fills its boots with bespoke shoes
summary: Japan has become a leader in bespoke leather shoemaking, with at least 40 workshops in Tokyo and potentially up to 100 nationwide. Master shoemaker Yohei Fukuda's workshop in Tokyo produces around 80 pairs per year, taking 120-140 hours of handwork to complete. The industry's success is attributed to Japan's emphasis on detail and uniqueness, with bespoke shoes costing upwards of $5,791. The Japanese have adopted Western skills and perfected them, with Western apprentices now traveling to Japan to learn the trade, bringing their own creative twists to the traditional craft.

site_title: EU lifts Britain out of special budget supervision
summary: The EU has ended its special budget supervision for Britain, lifting it out of the bloc's public spending rules after almost a decade. The European Commission says London has reduced its deficit from a peak of 10% of GDP in 2009-10 to 2.3% in 2016-17, meeting the EU's targets. This decision comes as a boost to UK Finance Minister Philip Hammond ahead of his annual budget announcement, amid looming Brexit and sluggish growth.

site_title: China clamps down on online micro lending
summary: China has cracked down on online micro-lending, urging provincial governments to suspend regulatory approval for new internet micro-lenders and restrict lending across regions. The move follows a spate of scandals and high-profile failures in the sector. Unsecured consumer lending via Chinese online platforms has more than tripled to almost $140 billion. Shares in Chinese online lender Qudian sank nearly 20% on Nasdaq, before recovering some ground. The crackdown aims to address rising household debt and risks in the internet finance sector.

site_title: Hackers stole data from 57 million Uber riders and drivers, says CEO
summary: Uber's CEO Dara Khosrowshahi revealed that hackers stole data from 57 million riders and drivers, including names, e-mail addresses, and cellphone numbers, in a breach that was concealed for a year. The company paid the hackers $100,000 to destroy the data, but did not notify users or regulators. Two members of the Uber information security team were let go, and the company is notifying drivers whose licence numbers were swiped and offering them credit and identity theft protections. Khosrowshahi acknowledged the company's mistakes and vowed to learn from them, as Uber faces ongoing scandals and regulatory scrutiny.

images.alt_text: Uber needs to clean up governance and other practices in order to meet its goal of a 2019 stock market debut that will open up the privately-held firm to greater scrutiny.

site_title: Ikea re-issues recall of wobbly dressers that have killed 8 kids
summary: Ikea is re-issuing a recall of its wobbly dressers that have killed 8 children, including a recent death of a 2-year-old. The company has refunded or secured about 1 million of the estimated 17 million dressers at risk, with customers able to receive a free wall-mounting kit or assistance. The recall, which began in 2016, includes Malm dressers and chests, and Ikea is offering refunds or wall-anchoring kits to customers. The company acknowledges its initial recall campaign was ineffective and is re-announcing the offer due to the latest death.

site_title: US: Tech stocks help Nasdaq eke out record high
summary: US stocks rose, with the Nasdaq hitting a record high, driven by technology stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also gained, although modestly. The Nasdaq Composite added 7.83 points, or 0.11%, to 6,870.31, marking its 10th record high of 2017.

site_title: US jobless claims fall as record run persists
summary: US jobless claims fell to 239,000 for the week ending November 18, matching analyst expectations, as the labor market continues its record streak of low levels. This marks the 142nd week below 300,000, the longest such streak since 1970. The decline suggests continued strong job creation and may influence the US central bank's decision to raise interest rates for the third time this year.

site_title: Digital currencies will not replace physical money soon: BOJ official
summary: A senior Bank of Japan official, Hiromi Yamaoka, stated that digital currencies will not replace physical money soon, citing that the technology is "under construction" and would drastically change the banking system. Despite Japan's recognition of bitcoin as legal tender and its fintech efforts, the BOJ and European Central Bank have deemed blockchain technology, which underpins bitcoin, as not mature enough for large-scale payments. The official also expressed concerns about the hype surrounding initial coin offerings.

site_title: SBH case: Mary Chia's costs add up to S$700,000
summary: Mary Chia Holdings Limited's wholly owned subsidiary, Mary Chia Beauty & Slimming Specialist Pte Ltd, will not appeal a court's decision dismissing its lawsuit against Slim Beauty House Co Ltd over a joint venture. The court had awarded Slim Beauty House Co Ltd S$700,000 in costs. The decision marks the end of the dispute between the two companies.

site_title: Malaysia, Indonesia say EU palm resolution will affect millions
summary: Malaysia and Indonesia, the world's largest palm oil producers, have warned that the European Parliament's resolution to curb palm oil use could affect millions of people running small-time plantations. The resolution aims to prevent deforestation by restricting market access for palm oil and promoting a single Certified Sustainable Palm Oil scheme. The two countries' leaders, Najib Razak and Joko Widodo, have expressed concerns that the measures will harm the livelihoods of millions of palm smallholders and work against the UN's goal of eradicating poverty.

site_title: Leadership appointments at Rowsley to beef up core design and engineering business
summary: Rowsley Ltd has announced leadership appointments to strengthen its core design and engineering business. Seah Chee Kien and Beh Swee Chiew will be managing directors of RSP Architects Planners & Engineers, while Teo Yann will lead Squire Mech. Tan Wee Tuck, CEO, stated that the new appointments will drive transformational change to innovate and excel in a competitive environment. The changes take effect from December 1.

site_title: 25 trade associations and chambers come under one roof to help companies grow
summary: Singapore's Trade Association Hub was officially opened by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, bringing together 25 trade associations to support companies in growth and overseas expansion. The hub offers shared facilities, including meeting and training areas, to reduce costs. Associations, such as the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry, are leveraging the hub to source new technological solutions, explore international markets, and collaborate with other industry players. The hub aims to foster a culture of mutual support and collaboration among trade associations, helping Singapore companies overcome industry limitations.

site_title: Sea's Q3 loss widens, but revenue up
summary: Sea, a gaming and e-commerce firm backed by Tencent, reported its first earnings report since its October public debut, meeting analysts' expectations. The company's net loss doubled to $132.7 million in Q3, but revenue grew 3.9% to $94.1 million. Cash revenue rose 73% to $151.7 million, driven by growth in its gaming platform and e-commerce portal Shopee. Shopee's GMV reached $1.06 billion, up 219% from last year, with 1.9 million monthly active sellers.

site_title: Mary Chia says unit will not appeal against dismissal order
summary: Mary Chia Beauty & Slimming Specialist Pte Ltd, a subsidiary of Mary Chia Holdings Limited, will not appeal a court's dismissal order in a lawsuit filed by Slim Beauty House Co Ltd. The court ruled in favor of SBH, ordering MCBSS to pay S$580,000 in damages and costs. MCBSS will also pay S$12,500 and reasonable disbursements to SBH. The company incurred S$100,000 in legal fees and S$700,000 in total costs, which will impact its financial year-end results.

site_title: Mugabe resigns as Zimbabwe president after impeachment threat; ends 37-year rule
summary: Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe resigned after a joint sitting of lawmakers voted to impeach him, ending his 37-year rule. Former Vice President Emmerson Mnangagwa, who was dismissed by Mugabe, will take over as interim leader and contest the 2018 presidential election. The move comes after the military placed Mugabe under house arrest and the ruling party fired him as leader. Mugabe's resignation sparks scenes of wild celebration in Harare, but his exit may not usher in a new era of democracy in Zimbabwe.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng unit to acquire two properties in South Perth via joint venture
summary: CHIP Eng Seng Corporation Ltd has agreed to acquire two adjoining properties in South Perth, Australia, through a joint venture. The properties, valued at A$10.9 million, will be redeveloped into a mixed-use development featuring residential apartments and retail/office suites. The joint venture, CES South Perth (WA) Pty Ltd, has entered into a shareholder loan agreement to fund the redevelopment, with each party providing an interest-free loan of A$14.5 million and A$6.2 million respectively. The redevelopment is expected to proceed, with the acquisition completed on November 22, 2017.

site_title: Buoyant risk appetite pushes euro up again
summary: The euro rose 0.25% to US$1.1769, its second consecutive day of gains, as investors sought the single currency due to expected strong economic growth. Risk appetite, with world stocks at a record high and market volatility near record lows, also supported the euro. The dollar's weakness due to softening US yields and uncertainty surrounding the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy contributed to the euro's gains.

site_title: Developers 'in two main camps over how much to bid for land'
summary: Developers in Singapore are divided on how much to bid for land, with a JLL study finding that 58% of winning bids suggest they expect selling prices to be around current levels or up to 10% higher. This contradicts comments from Redas that the market has seen "different risk appetites of developers" differing in views on supply and demand. The study's findings may indicate that some developers are adopting a more measured approach to bidding, while others remain aggressive in driving up land prices.

site_title: AA Reit raises gross S$55m from private placement at S$1.305 per new unit
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) raised S$55 million through a private placement of 42.145 million new units at S$1.305 per unit, exceeding its initial target of S$50 million. The issue price represents a 6.9% discount to AA Reit's volume weighted average price. The funds will be used to repay existing borrowings, provide debt headroom for future acquisitions, and support asset enhancement initiatives. AA Reit's CEO stated that the equity placement will strengthen the company's balance sheet and enhance its financial flexibility.

site_title: Acromec warns of further losses for FY2017
summary: Acromec Limited reported it will incur further losses in fiscal 2017 due to cost overruns on major projects. The company is finalizing its fiscal 2017 results, with unaudited financial results to be disclosed on or before November 29. This marks a continuation of the reported losses for the half year ended March 31.

site_title: COEs finish mixed in the second round of bidding in Nov 2017
summary: Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices in Singapore finished mixed in the second round of bidding in November 2017. Category A car premiums decreased from $47,112 to $46,791, while Category B car prices dropped slightly from $57,414 to $57,390. These changes reflect fluctuations in the market, with some categories experiencing slight decreases in COE prices.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Kismis View, a collective sale site in Singapore, has been launched for sale by tender with a price tag of S$102m. COE prices in Singapore finished mixed in the second round of bidding in November. Meanwhile, outside of Singapore, a Malaysian agency is set to seize about RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: The site may be redeveloped into a low-rise apartment development of up to five storeys, with a total gross floor area of about 139,929 sq ft including a 10 per cent bonus balcony area.

site_title: Petrobras eyes up to 22 billion reais valuation in distribution unit IPO
summary: Petrobras plans to offer a 25-33.75% stake in its fuel distribution unit BR Distribuidora SA through an IPO, valuing it at up to 22 billion reais (S$9.2 billion). The offering, priced on Dec 13, aims to raise 7.5 billion reais at the high end of a 15-19 reais per share price range. The IPO is part of Petrobras' plan to sell assets and reduce its debt load, following a revival in equity listings in Brazil's largest economy.

site_title: Are China-Japan ties starting to show some improvement?
summary: Japan and China are experiencing a thaw in their relations, with Chinese President Xi Jinping and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe meeting on the sidelines of the APEC gathering in Danang. The meetings mark a significant step forward, with Xi calling Abe an "old friend" and Abe proposing a resumption of regular summit meetings to normalise relations. However, China has been evasive, and a high-level visit from Abe to China remains in the realm of hope. Both leaders have strengthened their positions domestically, and Abe has also been moving to strengthen Japan's position internationally, including a dialogue with the US, Australia, and India.

site_title: LHN warns of lower profit for fiscal 2017
summary: LHN Limited has issued a profit warning, stating its profit before tax for fiscal 2017 is expected to be significantly lower compared to the previous year. The decline is attributed to non-recurring expenses, a fair value loss on investment properties, and the absence of a fair value gain from associates and joint ventures. The company will announce its unaudited financial results on November 29, providing further details on its financial performance.

site_title: Sterling treads water ahead of UK budget
summary: The British pound remained stable ahead of a budget statement by finance minister Philip Hammond, with traders cautious about taking large positions due to the likelihood of lower growth forecasts and limited room for bold budget moves. Analysts expect the statement to have little impact on sterling. Hammond is under pressure from Brexit supporters for his cautious approach to EU talks, but is also fighting for his political future. The UK's economy is preparing to leave the EU, and investors are watching the budget closely for any developments.

site_title: Japan's first solar auction pushes prices down by nearly a quarter
summary: Japan's first solar auction resulted in prices decreasing by nearly a quarter to 17,200 yen (S$208) per megawatt hour, with the lowest accepted bid being more than eight times the record-low price achieved in overseas markets. The government aims to reduce costs and cut the burden on electricity users, who have high guaranteed prices added to their bills. Japan plans to generate 24% of its power from renewables by 2030, up from 14.6% in 2015, as the country's solar power capacity has soared to over 40,000 gigawatt-hours.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei rises to near 2-week high before holiday as large-caps gain
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average rose to a near two-week high, closing at 22,523.15, driven by gains in large-cap stocks such as SoftBank and Fanuc. Financial companies also saw significant gains, while banks and insurers soared. The broader Topix index gained 0.3% to 1,777.08.

images.alt_text: Japan's Nikkei share average rose to a near two-week high on Wednesday, buoyed by gains in large-cap stocks such as SoftBank and Fanuc, and financial companies as global growth hopes lifted the mood across world markets.

site_title: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rises above 30,000 to decade-high
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index reached a decade-high of 30,199.69, surpassing 30,000 for the first time since 2007. The index rose 0.6% on the day, driven by Tencent Holdings' 22% surge and Ping An Insurance Group's 23% gain. Analysts predict sustained growth, with Goldman Sachs forecasting a rise to 32,000 by the end of next year. Despite some caution, the index remains relatively cheap compared to European and US benchmarks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Hang Seng index rises above 30,000 to decade-high
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng Index reached a decade-high of 30,003.49, gaining 0.6% on Wednesday. Energy producers and Chinese developers led the gains, with Tencent Holdings Ltd surging 22% to surpass $500 billion in market value. Goldman Sachs predicts the index will climb to 32,000 by the end of next year, driven by sustained inflows and rising technology shares. The index remains undervalued relative to European and US benchmark gauges, with investors showing caution despite some small declines.

site_title: China's banks are getting ready for bigger swings in the yuan
summary: China's banks have increased their foreign currency holdings to 5.39 trillion yuan, up 383 billion yuan from this year's start, amid anticipation of greater yuan fluctuations. This boost, similar to the 843 billion yuan increase in 2016, reflects banks' efforts to diversify their portfolios and prepare for potential swings in the exchange rate. Analysts believe the stockpile will enable lenders to profit from both advancing and depreciating yuan rates, as they can buy foreign currency at lower costs when the yuan rises and sell their holdings to capitalize on a weaker currency.

site_title: Iran pushes to retain Asia oil buyers as possible US sanctions loom
summary: Iran is offering discounted oil prices to Asian buyers to retain customers amid potential US sanctions, which could threaten the country's oil exports. The National Iranian Oil Company has lowered prices for its crude, making it more competitive with Saudi grades. The discounts aim to boost demand for Iranian oil, which has been under pressure from rising exports from Iraq and Qatar. Despite the threat of sanctions, Iran is expected to maintain its steady oil output and exports, and traders do not anticipate a repeat of the market share battle seen before the 2016 Opec supply cut deal.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.86 points to 1,723.54, closing higher on Wednesday. The index saw 2.23 billion shares traded for RM2.60 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 589 to 318. This marks a positive day for Malaysian stocks.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise; won strengthens to 2-1/2-yr high
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.39% to 2,540.51, with the won strengthening to a 2-1/2-year high of 1,089.1 per dollar. The currency's strong trend is expected to persist due to strong foreign demand for local equities. The KOSPI is up 24.9% so far this year, with foreigners net buying 40,038 million won worth of shares.

site_title: David Cassidy, 1970s heartthrob, dies at 67
summary: David Cassidy, a 1970s teen idol best known for his role in "The Partridge Family," has died at 67 due to liver failure. Cassidy, who had been diagnosed with dementia earlier this year, passed away in Florida surrounded by loved ones. He released hits such as "I Think I Love You" and sold over 30 million records worldwide, earning Grammy nominations. Cassidy is survived by his two children and had a career spanning over 40 years in music, television, and theater.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge higher, take a breather after global rally
summary: European shares opened slightly higher on Wednesday, regaining some momentum from overnight gains in Asia and the US. The STOXX 600 benchmark rose 0.1%, with most European bourses trading in positive territory. However, Norwegian media group Schibsted's decline of 8.2% after an offering of B-shares to finance mergers and acquisitions weighed on the index. The rally was driven by mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: UK predicts worse growth and earmarks cash for hard Brexit
summary: The UK government has set aside an extra £3 billion to prepare for all possible Brexit outcomes, as the Office for Budget Responsibility now predicts 2018 economic growth of 1.4%, down from 1.6% in March. Chancellor Philip Hammond acknowledged the UK economy faces a "future full of change and new opportunities," while Prime Minister Theresa May's government faces criticism over sluggish progress in Brexit negotiations and a potential hard Brexit. The budget deficit is expected to be £39.5 billion for 2018-19, with borrowing forecast to be less than previously predicted over the next five years.

site_title: Zimbabwe's Mnangagwa to return home after Mugabe resignation
summary: Zimbabwe's former vice president Emmerson Mnangagwa, who was sacked and forced into exile, will return home after President Robert Mugabe's resignation. Mnangagwa, 75, is expected to be sworn in as president and lead ZANU-PF into elections next year. Mugabe, 93, resigned after a week of military pressure, marking the end of his four-decade rule. Mnangagwa is expected to land in Zimbabwe on Wednesday and may be sworn in later that day or Thursday.

site_title: China iron ore rises with steel; coking coal hits two-month high
summary: Chinese steel futures rose for a third consecutive session, driven by leaner supply and expected recovery in consumption after winter production cuts. Iron ore and coking coal prices advanced, with coking coal hitting a two-month peak. Steel mills in northern China have been ordered to reduce output to combat smog. Global iron ore supply is expected to rise next year, putting pressure on prices, according to analysts.

site_title: MyRepublic snags S$70m investment to scale up products, expand regionally
summary: MyRepublic secures S$70 million in funding from Makara Capital, a key investment in its Series C funding round aiming for S$100 million. The funds will be used to expand the company's geographical footprint and scale up its product and service offerings. This investment is expected to support MyRepublic's growth and expansion in the telecommunications market.

site_title: Yellen says it's dangerous to allow inflation to drift lower
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen warned that allowing inflation to drift lower than the 2% target could lead to undesirable consequences, including downward drifting of inflation expectations. She cautioned that raising interest rates too quickly risks stranding inflation below the target, while leaving rates too low for too long poses risks. Yellen emphasized the need for a balanced approach to guide interest rates back to a neutral level, citing the median forecast of a 2.75% neutral rate.

site_title: Chinese oil giant denies Africa bribery scheme after US probe
summary: Chinese oil giant CEFC China Energy has denied involvement in a multi-million dollar bribery scheme in Africa, according to a US probe. US officials arrested Hong Kong's former home affairs secretary and Senegal's ex-foreign minister for allegedly sending bribes to secure business advantages for the company in Chad and Uganda. CEFC China Energy released a statement denying any commercial involvement with the fund and stating that any activities against the law are strictly prohibited. The company has denied any wrongdoing despite being identified in the complaint.

site_title: Australia shares rise as miners, energy firms shine; NZ up slightly
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.4% to 5,986.4, driven by gains in the energy and materials sectors. Mining heavyweights BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto advanced 1.4% and 0.9%, respectively. Oil prices rose due to ongoing Opec-led production cuts and falling US crude inventories. In New Zealand, the S&P/NZX 50 index increased 0.2% to 8,104.990, with gains in consumer staples offsetting losses in healthcare stocks.

site_title: BlackRock says Asian stocks can extend rally, boosted by China
summary: BlackRock's head of Asian and global emerging markets equities, Andrew Swan, predicts Asian stocks will extend their rally driven by global reflation, China's structural reforms, and India's economic growth. China's reforms and India's push for growth before the 2019 national election will underpin further increases in equities, Swan said. Asian stocks are near their 2007 peak, making it a favorable time to invest, according to Swan.

site_title: Gentrification breeds tension in New York's Harlem
summary: Gentrification is transforming Harlem, a historically African American neighborhood in New York City, into a hub of upscale living. Despite rising property values and new businesses, many long-time residents, mostly Hispanics and African Americans, are being priced out. The neighborhood's median income is $31,000 to $39,840, but the average rent for a one-bedroom apartment is $2,265 per month, making it difficult for low-income residents to afford. The influx of wealthier, often white, families has created tension, with some residents feeling harassed and threatened by newcomers, while others see gentrification as necessary for the neighborhood's evolution.

site_title: China's former internet czar faces graft probe
summary: China's former internet czar Lu Wei, 57, is under investigation for suspected "severe disciplinary violations" as part of the country's anti-corruption drive. Lu, who oversaw online censorship, had stepped down last year and was once named among the world's 100 most influential people by Time magazine. His investigation comes as China prepares to host its fourth World Internet Conference, amid criticism from rights groups. Lu's case is the latest top Communist Party figure to fall from grace since President Xi Jinping's second five-year term.

site_title: Singapore looking at wider e-commerce levies as one way to diversify tax base: Indranee
summary: Singapore is considering widening levies on e-commerce to broaden its tax base, said Senior Minister of State for Law and Finance Indranee Rajah. Currently, online shoppers in Singapore aren't taxed on orders under S$400, but the government is looking to change this. This move aims to diversify the tax base and prepare for future economic changes, following Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's warning of potential tax increases.

site_title: Rio Tinto may buy stake in lithium producer Sociedad Quimica y Minera
summary: Rio Tinto may acquire a stake in US$15 billion lithium producer Sociedad Quimica y Minera (SQM) as demand for lithium, cobalt, and copper grows due to increasing interest in electric cars. Following a period of cost-cutting and investing in commodities, Rio Tinto is considering a potential investment in SQM, which has limited exposure to the market. This move aims to capitalize on the rising demand for lithium, a commodity Rio Tinto has limited exposure to.

images.alt_text: Rio Tinto is getting distracted by a shiny new thing.

site_title: St Helena tourism cleared for takeoff as airport opens
summary: St Helena, a British territory in the Atlantic Ocean, has officially opened its airport, allowing for the first commercial flights to the island. The airport's opening, delayed by high winds, promises to boost the island's economy and attract tourists, with initial estimates of 30,000 visitors per year. However, the single weekly flight from Johannesburg will have a limited capacity of around 4,000 people, and the island's infrastructure is not yet equipped to handle large numbers of tourists, with only 121 guest beds available.

site_title: Coeure expects ECB rate guidance to gain prominence as QE ends
summary: European Central Bank policy maker Benoit Coeure expects the ECB to shift its focus from quantitative easing to interest rates as inflation appears to be on track. The ECB's current bond purchase program is scheduled to end in September 2018, and Coeure believes the link between bond purchases and inflation may be loosened before then. The ECB's interest-rate guidance is expected to gain prominence, with policy makers likely to make multiple small adjustments rather than a major change in language.

site_title: A vegan US: good for earth, problematic for people
summary: A new US Department of Agriculture study suggests a vegan America would reduce greenhouse-gas emissions by 2.6% but would face nutritional challenges due to deficiencies in calcium, vitamins A and B12, and fatty acids. The total food supply would increase by 23% as animal feed crops would be diverted to other uses. However, land used for feed crops would likely remain unsuitable for fruits and vegetables, adding to a glut in commodities. A complete shift to plant-based diets would require individuals to consume more calories and would need to be balanced to be healthy.

site_title: China clamps down on online micro lending; US-listed shares plunge
summary: China has issued an urgent notice to provincial governments urging them to suspend regulatory approval for new internet micro-lenders, part of a crackdown on the lightly regulated online micro-lending market. The move aims to rein in risks and rising household debt, which includes mortgages and consumer loans. Shares of US-listed Chinese financial firms, including Qudian, China Commercial Credit Inc, and PPDAI Group, plummeted after the announcement, with Qudian's shares sinking nearly 20%. The crackdown follows a spate of scandals and high-profile peer-to-peer (P2P) failures.

site_title: Fed debate over rate-hike pace in focus amid strong job market
summary: The Federal Reserve is considering a gradual pace of interest rate hikes amid a strong job market, with unemployment at a 16-year low of 4.1%. Minutes from the last meeting may indicate increasing concern about the labor market overheating, potentially leading to further rate hikes in December and 2018. Investors expect a higher than 90% chance of a rate increase next month, with the median expectation for one additional hike this year and three in 2018. The Fed views the labor market from a risk management perspective, with some officials warning of inflation reasserting itself.

site_title: UOB's 2 new robot employees cut data processing time by over half
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has introduced two software robots, Amy and Eve, to automate data processing tasks, cutting transaction processing time by over half. The robots, assigned to wholesale banking and retail businesses, excel in repetitive data entry tasks such as processing Letters of Credit and reviewing credit card applications. With Amy, data processing time was reduced from 240 seconds to 40 seconds, while Eve can handle up to 1,800 credit card applications per day, 3.5 times faster than humans. This marks the beginning of UOB's virtual workforce, with plans to onboard more robots in the coming months.

site_title: Malaysia says working on regulatory framework for cryptocurrencies
summary: Malaysia has started working on a regulatory framework for cryptocurrencies, aiming to prevent money laundering and terrorism financing. The country's central bank governor, Muhammad Ibrahim, announced that those converting cryptocurrencies into conventional currency will be designated as "reporting institutions" under the Anti-Money Laundering, Anti-Terrorism Financing and Proceeds of Unlawful Activities Act. This move comes after a significant increase in suspicious transaction reports related to terrorism financing, with 346 reports filed in the first six months of this year, compared to 93 in 2015.

site_title: Kismis View launched for en bloc sale for S$102m
summary: Kismis View, a 90% sold collective sale site in Singapore's Upper Bukit Timah area, has been launched for en bloc sale by tender for S$102 million. The 90,863 sq ft site, built in the early 1980s, is zoned "Residential" with a gross plot ratio of 1.4. The sale price reflects about S$983 per sq ft per plot ratio, compared favourably to nearby land sales. The site may be redeveloped into a low-rise apartment development of up to five storeys, with a total gross floor area of about 139,929 sq ft.

site_title: One country, two systems roils China's steel mills as curbs bite
summary: China's environmental cleanup efforts, implemented during the winter months, are affecting the country's steel industry, particularly in the north. The restrictions, targeting 2+26 cities, have led to a decline in steel production and a rise in demand for iron ore from southern mills. This has resulted in a shortage of raw materials, with inventories in the north reaching a record high. The impact is expected to be offset by production hikes from mills outside the restricted areas, but nationwide production has already started to slow.

site_title: British developer Countryside flags strong trading in property sector
summary: British developer Countryside Properties reported strong trading in the property sector, citing robust customer demand, favorable mortgage lending conditions, and government support. Completions increased 28% to 3,389 units for the year ended September 30, while the private forward order book jumped 8% to £242.4 million. This contrasts with peers who have flagged weakness in the sector due to Brexit concerns and rising interest rates. Countryside expressed confidence in delivering growth plans for 2018 and the medium term.

site_title: Samsung, LG investors unfazed by US trade action on washers
summary: US trade officials recommended imposing tariffs on foreign-made washing machines, but investors remained unfazed, with Samsung and LG shares rising 1.2% and 3% respectively. The proposed tariffs, which would range from 50% to 20%, would mainly affect South Korean brands sold in the US, despite excluding countries with free-trade deals. Analysts say the impact would be negligible for Samsung, which earns most of its revenue from memory semiconductors and smartphones. The move is seen as a test of President Trump's vow to crack down on countries not following international trade rules.

site_title: How Big Sugar killed a 1968 study that pointed to a heart disease link
summary: A 50-year-old research project on sugar's link to heart disease was terminated by the International Sugar Research Foundation (ISRF) in 1970 due to lack of funding, despite preliminary findings suggesting a possible connection. The study, known as "Project 259," was on the verge of linking sugar to coronary heart disease and bladder cancer. Internal emails obtained by researchers reveal that the ISRF's Vice President of Research cut off funding just months before the study could complete its findings. The sugar industry has long resisted efforts to declare a link between sugar consumption and heart disease, despite the potential implications of the study's findings.

site_title: Japan fills its boots with bespoke shoes
summary: Japan has become a leader in bespoke leather shoemaking, with at least 40 workshops in Tokyo and potentially 100 nationwide. The industry has boomed in recent years, driven by Japanese demand for luxury footwear. Artisans like Yohei Fukuda spend 120-140 hours crafting each pair of shoes by hand, with prices ranging from $5,801 for a basic pair. The Japanese approach to bespoke shoemaking is seen as an extension of the country's attention to detail and commitment to quality.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.73 points to 1,724.41 on Wednesday, with 277.8 million lots traded worth RM132.8 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 266 to 153.

site_title: Apple scientists disclose self-driving car research
summary: Apple researchers have published a paper on self-driving cars, proposing a new software approach called "VoxelNet" that helps computers detect three-dimensional objects. The approach uses LiDAR data to spot pedestrians and cyclists with "highly encouraging results." The experiments were computer simulations, and the researchers claim to have beaten other approaches for detecting three-dimensional objects using only LiDAR data. This is Apple's first publicly disclosed paper on autonomous vehicles, which has sparked interest in the tech industry.

site_title: Ikea furniture has killed 8 children; millions of recalled dressers may still be out there
summary: Ikea has refunded or secured about 1 million of the 17 million recalled dressers that can tip over, a year after the initial recall. The company still doesn't know how many customers have secured the dressers on their own or how many are still in use. Ikea again offered refunds or wall-anchoring kits to customers who purchased the recalled furniture. The company's efforts to address the issue come after eight children were killed by the dressers.

site_title: The 1990s Balkan wars in key dates
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

The 1990s Balkan wars in Yugoslavia were a series of conflicts that tore the country apart. Following Tito's death in 1980, nationalist sentiments surged, leading to the declaration of independence by Slovenia and Croatia in 1991. The Bosnian war broke out in 1992, pitting Muslims and Croats against Bosnian Serbs, resulting in a 44-month siege of Sarajevo and the Srebrenica massacre. NATO intervened in 1995, and the Dayton agreement was signed, ending the conflict. The Kosovo conflict followed in 1998, and the International Criminal Court has since prosecuted those responsible for war crimes.

images.alt_text: Ahead of the judgement Wednesday of Bosnian Serb army chief Ratko Mladic, here is a timeline of the 1990s Balkans conflicts that tore apart the former Yugoslavia.

site_title: Aussie, NZ dollars tested as yield cushions turn threadbare
summary: The Australian dollar and New Zealand dollar are under pressure as yields in the US have narrowed the gap between the two countries, marking the first time this has happened since 2000. The Australian dollar has fallen to a five-month low, while the New Zealand dollar has rebounded from a 30-year low. The Reserve Bank of Australia has downplayed the likelihood of interest rate hikes, citing soft data on wages and inflation, but the US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates next month.

site_title: Hedge funds are demanding China buyers pay more in M&A deals
summary: Hedge funds are challenging the valuations of Chinese companies' buyouts, seeking higher payouts for minority investors. Maso Capital, a Hong Kong-based hedge fund, has disputed the valuations of at least six transactions since 2015, citing asymmetries in information between fair value and company knowledge. The Cayman Islands court recently ruled in favor of Maso in a Shanda Games buyout, awarding the hedge fund 2.35 times the price paid. Other investors, including PAG Absolute Returns and Senrigan Capital Group, are joining the challenge, potentially reshaping the way buyouts are structured and leading to increased transparency and fairness in the process.

site_title: Hong Kong: Hang Seng Index rises above 30,000 to decade-high
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index reached a decade-high of 30,143.39, rising 1% to surpass the 30,000 mark. Tencent Holdings and Ping An Insurance Group drove the rally, with Tencent surging 25% this month and Ping An jumping 26%. The index has been boosted by sustained inflows from mainland China and gains in technology shares, fueling a wider regional rally in Asia.

site_title: Singapore shares higher at Wednesday break; STI gains 0.4% to 3,435.29
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.4% to 3,435.29 at mid-day on Wednesday, driven by gains in RE&S Holdings and other stocks. Gainers outnumbered losers 207 to 146, with 1.2 billion shares changing hands worth S$570.6 million. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Hot stock: Lifebrandz stock seesaws on heavy volume ahead of Q1 results
summary: LifeBrandz, a Singapore-listed lifestyle group, saw its stock price swing wildly on Tuesday with heavy trading volume ahead of its Q1 results announcement. The stock dropped 9.1% to 5 cents, but traded as high as 6 cents and as low as 4.7 cents. Despite a high volume of 31.2 million shares, LifeBrandz attributed the unusual trading to the pending quarterly results announcement and not to any undisclosed information. This is not the first time the company's stock has experienced unusual trading, following a similar incident in June.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday's open; STI up 1.09% to 3,423.38
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.09% on Wednesday, advancing to 3,423.38, driven by gains from RE & S Holdings and The Place Holdings, which made their listing debut. Gainers outnumbered losers 95 to 35. Active index stocks like DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank also rose, with DBS up 0.9% and OCBC up 1.2%. The rally comes ahead of the US Federal Reserve's overnight policy meeting minutes release.

site_title: Neo Group in exclusive talks to buy Teochew fish ball noodle business
summary: Neo Group has entered an exclusive negotiation agreement to acquire Jil & Yellowtail Pte Ltd and Li Xin (1968) @ ION Pte Ltd, a chain of Teochew fish ball noodles foodstalls and manufacturing business in Singapore, from individuals Lim Swee Meng and Rebecca Ng. The deal has a deadline of June 30, 2018, but the pricing has not been set. Li Xin sells fish ball noodles at various food courts and coffee shops, while Jil produces fish products supplied to Li Xin outlets.

site_title: Thai Oct exports up 13.1% y-o-y, beats forecast
summary: Thai customs-cleared exports rose 13.1% in October, beating a forecast of 11.8% growth, marking an eighth consecutive month of increases. This follows a 12.2% rise in September. The strong exports, driven by global demand, are a key driver of Thailand's growth.

site_title: Driverless buses to be tested in three new towns from 2022
summary: Singapore to test driverless buses in three new towns starting from 2022. The pilot program aims to enhance accessibility and connectivity for the elderly, families, and less mobile residents. The 2-hectare test centre, launched in 2016, will simulate various road conditions and test autonomous vehicles' navigation abilities. The Transport Minister expects the technology to transform urban mobility and alleviate the country's land transport constraints. Regulations and town planning will be key to safely integrating autonomous vehicles into the environment.

site_title: RE&S opens 60% above IPO price on debut day
summary: RE&S Holdings, a Japanese food and beverage group, made its debut on the Catalist board, with its shares opening 61% above its IPO price of 22 cents at 35.5 Singapore cents. The company received strong interest from investors, with 37.8 times subscription for its IPO. Institutional investors, including PhillipCapital, have subscribed for the placement shares. RE&S has a diversified portfolio with a strong track record and a team of experienced management, and is expected to trade at a historical price-earnings ratio of 13.7 times post-IPO.

site_title: TPP's resurrection: Will it be ratified at all?
summary: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) has been reborn as the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) after 11 Pacific Rim countries agreed to move forward despite the US withdrawal. The CPTPP retains key commitments, including tariff reductions and liberalization of trade in goods and services, but suspends certain provisions, including those on trade facilitation and intellectual property rights. The agreement is expected to benefit all 11 members, with the highest gains expected for Malaysia and Vietnam. Ratification is pending legislative action in each member country, with Canada facing a dilemma due to concerns about North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) negotiations.

site_title: Far East Orchard names Joanna Gok as chief financial officer
summary: Far East Orchard has appointed Joanna Gok as its chief financial officer, effective January 2, 2018. Gok, 38, will oversee business ventures, strategic partnerships, and financial matters for the company and its group of companies. She previously held roles as senior manager of finance and head of corporate development at Far East Orchard.

site_title: US sanctions 13 Chinese and North Korean organisations
summary: The US imposed sanctions on 13 Chinese and North Korean organisations, accusing them of evading nuclear restrictions and supporting Pyongyang through trade. The move follows President Donald Trump's decision to put North Korea back on the list of state sponsors of terrorism. The sanctions aim to hurt trade between China and North Korea, which the US sees as key to deterring Pyongyang's nuclear ambitions.

images.alt_text: "This designation will impose further sanctions and penalties on North Korea and related persons, and supports our maximum pressure campaign to isolate the murderous regime," said Treasury Secretary Steven T. Mnuchin.

site_title: Ford may exit some markets in South America: JPMorgan
summary: Ford Motor may exit some markets in South America to turn around its money-losing business in the region. Analyst Ryan Brinkman said the company may work with rival automakers or selectively exit certain markets. Despite economic and political crises in South America, Ford has struggled to earn money in the region, losing $587 million in the first nine months of the year. The company will continue to focus on making its South America operations "operationally fit." Ford has a factory in Valencia and is committed to addressing its losses in the region.

site_title: Asian stocks surpass 2007 peak in global rally
summary: Asian stocks surpassed the 2007 peak in a global rally, driven by US equities reaching all-time highs and optimism over tax reform and corporate earnings. Japan's Topix index rose 0.5%, Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index climbed 0.2%, and South Korea's Kospi index added 0.8%. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index broke through its 2007 peak, while the US dollar maintained losses as the Treasury yield curve flattened. Investors remain positive despite Thanksgiving holiday and tariff uncertainty, with the Australian dollar rising back toward 76 US cents.

site_title: Yellen gives passing grade to US balance sheet drawdown
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that efforts to unwind the central bank's multitrillion-dollar investment holdings are progressing well. The Fed's balance sheet, which stood at $4.5 trillion, is expected to taper down as the economy recovers. Markets have taken the balance-sheet unwinding in stride, with Wall Street continuing to rally despite expectations of a potential interest rate hike next month. Yellen also reiterated her support for Dodd-Frank Wall Street reforms, which have strengthened banks' capital and risk management.

site_title: Stocks to watch: AA Reit, Asian Micro Holdings, UOL, RE&S
Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on November 22, 2017, rising 0.88% to 22,614.17 on the Nikkei 225 index and 0.67% to 1,782.97 on the Topix index. The gains followed rallies on Wall Street. The market is expected to be cautious ahead of a national holiday.

site_title: Tesla blows through US$8,000 every minute amid Model 3 woes
summary: Tesla is burning through its cash at a rate of $8,000 per minute, with the company on track to exhaust its current cash pile on August 6. Despite this, investors remain confident, with Tesla shares rising 3% to $317.81. The company is ramping up production of its Model 3, which is expected to generate revenue. Elon Musk plans to raise funds by asking customers to pay upfront for vehicles that may not be delivered for years, but this has not deterred investors.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk said last week that Tesla Inc is designing a new sports car that could go from zero to 60 mph in 1.9 seconds.

site_title: Study sees link between pollution and sperm size, some sceptical
summary: A study of 6,400 Taiwanese men and boys found a link between exposure to fine particle air pollution (PM 2.5) and smaller, abnormally-shaped sperm. The analysis, from 2001-2014, suggests a "robust association" between PM 2.5 pollution and reduced "normal" sperm. The study warns that this may lead to a significant number of couples experiencing infertility.

site_title: US govt warns businesses about cyber bug in Intel chips
summary: The US government has warned businesses about a cyber bug in Intel chips, urging them to act on an alert about security flaws in Intel's Management Engine software. The vulnerabilities affect widely used business computers and servers with Intel processors released in the last two years. Experts say it's unclear how difficult it is to exploit the vulnerabilities, but they are troubling due to the widespread use of affected chips. Intel has provided software patches to major manufacturers, and computer makers are advised to review the warning and contact Intel for updates.

images.alt_text: Intel said that it knew of no cases where hackers had exploited the vulnerability in a cyber attack.

site_title: Meg Whitman to step down as HP Enterprise CEO
summary: Meg Whitman is stepping down as CEO of Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) on February 1, after six years leading the company. She will be succeeded by President Antonio Neri. Whitman, 61, oversaw significant changes during her tenure, including a $18 billion share repurchase and a 89% total shareholder return. Her departure comes as the company faces revenue and earnings challenges, with shares falling 5.3% in extended trading.

site_title: Hackers stole data from 57 million Uber riders, drivers: CEO
summary: Uber's CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, announced that hackers compromised personal data from 57 million riders and drivers in a breach that was hidden for a year. Two members of the Uber information security team were let go in response. Khosrowshahi stated that the breach "should not have happened" and expressed regret. The incident highlights concerns over data security at the company.

site_title: Asian Micro plans to acquire 4 Penang properties for RM1.6m
summary: Asian Micro Holdings plans to acquire four commercial units in Penang, Malaysia, for RM1.6 million (S$0.5 million). The company will issue 9.8 million new shares and RM16,075 in cash to Chew Choon Beng, who has the right to purchase three units and a fourth unit. This acquisition marks Asian Micro's diversification into real estate.

site_title: Uncertainties lie ahead: Outlook 2018 seminar
summary: Global economies are recovering, but uncertainties persist, according to a seminar on Outlook 2018. Experts warn of potential risks, including a shift in global monetary policy to a more hawkish stance, a slowing Chinese economy, and the increasing influence of China in the region. A trade war between China and the US could also have far-reaching consequences. The panel discussion also touched on the evolving retail scene, investment climate, and the need for businesses to adapt to changing market trends and geopolitical developments.

site_title: HP revenue beats estimates as PC maker bucks industry slump
summary: HP reported a 44 cents per share adjusted profit in its fiscal fourth quarter, beating analyst estimates. Revenue rose 11% to $13.9 billion, driven by a surge in personal-computer sales. The company's PC shipments grew 4.4% in the quarter, making it the top-selling PC brand for the second consecutive quarter. HP raised its forecast for the fiscal year, citing confidence in its business trajectory. The company's shares fell about 6% in extended trading after closing at a record $22.46.

images.alt_text: HP reported revenue that beat analysts' estimates, with an industry-defying surge in personal-computer (PC) sales driving a fifth consecutive quarterly increase.

site_title: JPMorgan said to weigh offering CME Bitcoin futures to clients
summary: JPMorgan Chase is considering offering CME Group's proposed bitcoin futures contracts to clients, weighing demand and potential risks. The move comes as bitcoin's eight-fold surge in value this year forces Wall Street banks to balance clients' interest in speculating on the cryptocurrency with executives' skepticism about its future. JPMorgan's CEO Jamie Dimon has been a prominent detractor of bitcoin, but his finance chief Marianne Lake has expressed openness to its potential uses, as long as they are properly regulated. The bank's deliberations are part of a broader competition between exchange operators CME Group and Cboe Global Markets.

site_title: Airbus exploring single-pilot, autonomous aircraft in tech race
summary: Airbus is exploring the development of autonomous aircraft and single-pilot technology, aiming to reduce crew needs and cut costs for carriers. The company's chief technology officer, Paul Eremenko, stated that pursuing single-pilot operation could also enable unpiloted operation. Airbus has established an innovation center in China's Shenzhen, where it will accelerate research on air travel technologies. The move is part of a broader trend in the aerospace industry, where companies like Boeing are racing to develop artificial intelligence for autonomous flight.

site_title: AkzoNobel, US rival Axalta halt merger talks
summary: Dutch chemical giant AkzoNobel has ended merger talks with US rival Axalta, citing inability to reach mutually agreeable terms. The deal, valued at around $30 billion, would have combined the two companies, with AkzoNobel focusing on its strategy of accelerating sustainable growth. The decision comes as AkzoNobel faces a bitter takeover bid by Pittsburgh-based PPG, which it has rejected multiple times, sparking a legal battle with activist investor Elliott Advisors.

site_title: Gold edges up on lower US dollar; market awaits Federal Reserve minutes
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,280.63 an ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar and safe-haven buying amid concerns over a German political crisis.
