This marks Cheung Woh's exit from the Chinese car market amid increasing competition, allowing the company to realize cash and unlock the value in its investment.

site_title: Drug firm Concordia overcharged Britain's health service with 6,000% price rise
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) alleges that Concordia, a sole supplier of liothyronine tablets, overcharged Britain's health service by a 6,000% price rise, from £4.46 to £258.19 per pack. The National Health Service spent £34 million on the drug last year, up from £600,000 a decade ago. The CMA may fine Concordia up to 10% of its annual turnover for breaking competition law. Concordia denies the allegations, stating that the pricing was transparent and that significant investment was made in the medicine.

site_title: Australia shares lifted by financial and material stocks; NZ down
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.3% on Tuesday, driven by financial stocks and resources shares, with the S&P/ASX 200 index reaching 5,963.50 points. The Reserve Bank of Australia's minutes showed policymakers warned of uncertainty about wages growth and inflation, keeping interest rates at record lows. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.02% due to losses in healthcare stocks, while consumer staples offset some of the losses with gains from dairy farm operator A2 Milk.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher as weak yen boosts exporters
summary: Tokyo stocks rose moderately on Tuesday, driven by a weaker yen that lifted exporters. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.70% to close at 22,416.48, while the Topix index rose 0.65% to 1,771.13. The gains followed a positive lead from Wall Street, where stocks rose despite US trade tensions. The weaker yen boosted exporters, contributing to the Tokyo market's moderate increase.

site_title: Global electric car sales jump 63% as China demand surges
summary: Global electric car sales surged 63% in the third quarter, driven by strong demand in China, where the market doubled amid government efforts to curb pollution. Sales of battery electric vehicles and plug-in hybrids exceeded 287,000 units, with China accounting for over half of global sales. This growth is attributed to China's efforts to reduce pollution and promote sustainable energy.

images.alt_text: Electric vehicles sales surged to a record in the third quarter, largely driven by strong demand in China.

site_title: Taylor Swift's 'Reputation' is 2017's biggest US album debut
summary: Taylor Swift's album "Reputation" sold 1.216 million copies in its first week, becoming the biggest US album debut of 2017 and the best-selling US album of the year. It surpassed the previous year's biggest debut, Kendrick Lamar's "Damn.," by 313,000 units. Swift's album marked another transformation in her image and follows her previous album "1989," which also debuted at the top of the US Billboard 200 chart. "Reputation" was her fourth album to sell over a million copies in a week, a feat she had achieved three times before.

site_title: China Environment company secretary resigns
summary: China Environment company secretary Ho Soo Hui has resigned, stepping down from his post in October 2016. His departure follows a series of developments, including a letter from Chen Fen Hua, the wife of former executive chairman Huang Min, seeking 47.1 million yuan in compensation. China Environment is assessing the claims and has reported Mr. Huang to Singapore's white-collar crime investigation unit. The company has also faced a civil suit loss in China, with FJDY liable for a loan of 36.7 million yuan. No reason was cited for Ho's resignation.

site_title: Foreign students, backpackers face 'endemic wage theft in Australia'
summary: International students and backpackers in Australia face "endemic wage theft", with 30% of temporary migrants paid half the minimum wage and 50% earning A$15/hour or less. The "Wage Theft in Australia" report, conducted by the University of New South Wales, found wage theft is widespread across industries, particularly in food services and fruit-and-vegetable picking. The study's co-author calls for the Australian government and businesses to act on the research, describing the level of non-compliance as "epidemic proportions".

site_title: Gold edges higher; All eyes on Fed minutes
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,279.67 per ounce ahead of the US Federal Reserve's minutes release, which may offer insights into interest rate hikes. The release is expected to provide clues on the pace of rate hikes, with analysts expecting a December hike. Gold prices fell 1.4% on Monday, their largest daily percentage drop since September 11. The Fed's Chair Janet Yellen is set to resign, and the release of the minutes will also be closely watched due to uncertainty surrounding the incoming Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's interest rate direction.

site_title: Prescient messages about Indian companies circulating in WhatsApp groups
summary: A series of prescient messages about Indian companies were circulated in private WhatsApp groups before official announcements, with at least 12 cases documented. The messages, which included specific metrics such as net profits and revenues, were shared hours or days before official company statements, including a message that predicted Dr. Reddy's Laboratories Ltd would report a loss of 587 million rupees. The Indian government has tightened insider trading rules in recent years, and circulating "unpublished price-sensitive information" can result in penalties of up to 250 million rupees and a jail term of up to 10 years.

site_title: Hot stock: F J Benjamin says no undisclosed information as share surge to 2-year high
summary: FJ Benjamin's share price surged 39.13% to 9.6 Singapore cents on Tuesday, its highest level in two years, amid an unusual trading activity. The fashion retailer stated it was unaware of any undisclosed information, but had announced a rights and warrants issue on Oct 23 to raise up to S$39 million. This move was seen as a possible explanation for the stock's price jump.

site_title: IE Singapore ties up with South Korea's Gyeonggi province in tech start-ups, wholesale trade, logistics
summary: IE Singapore has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with South Korea's Gyeonggi province to promote tech start-ups, wholesale trade, and logistics between Singapore and Korean firms. The agreement aims to facilitate business missions, business matching, and partnerships between Singapore and Gyeonggi-based companies, enabling Singapore technology startups to access Gyeonggi's ecosystem and ecosystem.

site_title: Halcyon Agri to acquire commodities trader RCMA's polymer division for up to US$33.8m
summary: Halcyon Agri has agreed to acquire RCMA's polymer division for up to US$33.8 million, creating a global distribution hub for latex and speciality tyre rubber. The acquisition, expected to complete in January 2018, will be funded by existing internal resources and enhance Halcyon Agri's market position. The polymer division offers services for the polymer industry, including natural rubber and synthetic rubber, and will be injected into two of Halcyon Agri's sales and distribution arms.

site_title: Singapore shares higher at Tues break; STI up 1% to 3,421.93
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.04% at mid-day break on Tuesday, reaching 3,421.93, with 180 gainers outnumbering 168 losers. Allied Tech fell 5.3%, while Hoe Leong and Chinese Global surged 35.3% and 36.4%, respectively. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day streak of gains.

site_title: China lifts up model who fell on Victoria's Secret catwalk
summary: China's internet rallied behind model Ming Xi after she tripped on the catwalk of the first-ever Victoria's Secret fashion show in Shanghai. Xi, who was born Xi Mengyao, apologized to the country for the mishap during the show, which featured a record seven Chinese-origin models. The event aimed to break into China's growing lingerie market, with the show broadcast in over 190 countries.

site_title: Nafta nations lock horns on US auto demands as fifth round ends
summary: US negotiators push for a 85% regional content threshold for autos in North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) talks with Mexico and Canada, but face resistance from the auto industry and are met with skepticism from Mexican and Canadian officials. The proposal is part of US President Donald Trump's America First strategy to bring back manufacturing jobs. Talks have been less confrontational than previous rounds, with the next round set to end by the end of March.

site_title: Temasek-linked DBS sold 900,000 StarHub shares for S$2.45m on Nov 13
summary: DBS Group Holdings sold 900,000 shares of StarHub for S$2.45 million, resulting in an average unit price of S$2.73, a 4% discount to the closing price. This sale reduced Temasek Holdings' deemed interest in StarHub to 55.97% from 56.02%. The sale occurred a few days before StarHub's CEO, Tan Tong Hai, announced his departure in May next year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks surge after Wall St lead
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 1.91% on Tuesday, reaching a 10-year high, following a positive lead from US markets. The Hang Seng Index closed at 29,818.07, with internet giant Tencent becoming one of the world's five largest firms by market capitalization. Other Asian markets also rose, with the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index advancing 0.53% and 0.79% respectively. The rally came despite ongoing US trade tensions.

site_title: Vietnamese brewer Sabeco to conduct stake sale roadshows in Singapore, London
summary: Vietnam's largest beer firm, Sabeco, will conduct stake sale roadshows in Singapore and London to sell the government's 89.6% stake in the company. The government aims to fully divest from Sabeco. The roadshows are scheduled for November 24 in Singapore and November 27 in London. This move follows the government's plan to sell its stake in the company, which has been in place since 1993.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start day with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.38% in the first minutes of trade, following Asia-wide gains after a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index reached 29,370.63, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices declined 0.30% and 0.16% respectively.

site_title: US-based AI firm DataRobot sets up S$15m Singapore research centre
summary: US-based AI firm DataRobot has established a S$15 million research and development centre in Singapore, expanding its workforce from 10 to 50 by 2019. The centre will be the company's second global R&D hub, following a Boston centre, and will focus on developing AI software for the Asia-Pacific region. DataRobot sees Singapore as a strategic location due to the region's growing importance in AI analysis and the "acute shortage" of data scientists. The company's expansion comes after the Singapore Government announced its AI growth area and an AI apprenticeship programme.

site_title: Broadcom eyes big changes for Qualcomm's patent practices
summary: Broadcom is considering significant changes to Qualcomm's patent licensing practices as part of its $103 billion bid to acquire the company. Qualcomm's patent licensing business generates $5.1 billion in pre-tax profits, but regulators and customers have criticized the practice of requiring mobile phone makers to pay licensing fees in addition to chip purchases. Broadcom plans to adjust pricing structures, renegotiate contracts with major customers, and potentially spin off or sell the licensing unit to address regulatory concerns and appease customers such as Apple. Changes could include shifting to a flat fee model or increasing chip prices using patents as leverage.

images.alt_text: As part of its US$103 billion bid to buy Qualcomm Inc, Broadcom Ltd has hinted that it would make big changes to Qualcomm's patent licensing business, a major cash-cow for the company but a source of bitter conflict with regulators and key customers including Apple Inc.

site_title: ACCA regional policy head Chiew Chun Wee gets board seat on global auditing standards body
summary: The International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB) appointed Chiew Chun Wee, ACCA's regional head of policy for Asia-Pacific, as a board member starting January 1, 2018. Chiew will serve for three years, bringing his knowledge and insights to the auditing standard organisation. His appointment aims to represent the views of small to medium-sized practitioners, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: CAAS awards S$7m contract to trial smart digital tower at Changi
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has awarded a S$7 million contract to UK-based NATS to trial a smart digital air traffic tower at Changi Airport over 22 months. The trial aims to enhance air traffic management and safety, and increase operational efficiencies. NATS will set up multiple cameras to provide live video to air traffic controllers, replacing the physical tower. CAAS will evaluate the trial's operational feasibility before determining the suitability of the smart digital tower for Changi Airport.

site_title: Singapore shares resume higher on Tuesday afternoon; STI at 3,425.93, up 1.2% on day
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.2% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,425.93 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 182 to 173, with a total of 1.17 billion shares worth S$610 million changing hands. Active index stocks included DBS Group and Singtel, which were down 1.12% and 0.27%, respectively. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally.

site_title: Sumo-Japan's national sport wrestles with latest act of violence
summary: A Mongolian sumo grand champion, Harumafuji, has apologized for assaulting a junior wrestler, Takanoiwa, after noticing him checking his phone while being scolded. The incident has raised concerns about the sport's culture of violence and the need for reforms, despite some wrestlers claiming that conditions have improved. A probe is underway, and the Japan Sumo Association is facing criticism for its handling of the situation, with some calling for greater oversight and accountability. The incident has sparked outrage among fans, who had been lured back to the sport after the promotion of a Japanese-born grand champion.

site_title: Sea investors look to first earnings since IPO for growth
summary: Sea Ltd, a Singapore-based company, will release its first earnings report Wednesday, with sales expected to reach US$94.5 million in the three months ended September, a 4.4% increase from last year. The company is counting on growth in its core games business to fund investment in e-commerce, which led to wider losses. Analysts are bullish on the stock, with five of six tracked by Bloomberg recommending buying Sea shares, despite a widening net loss of US$156.6 million. The company's share price has bounced around since its IPO, with a market valuation of US$4.9 billion.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally after Wall St lead, euro struggles
summary: Asian markets rallied on Tuesday, with Tokyo's Nikkei leading the way, driven by a weaker yen and optimism about the global economy. The rally followed a healthy run on Wall Street, despite concerns over US tax reform. The euro struggled due to German Chancellor Angela Merkel's struggle to form a government, with some market-watchers predicting a possible drop to US$1.1160. Other markets, including Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Sydney, also saw gains, while Seoul, Taipei, and Manila rose slightly.

site_title: Australian dollar slips to 5-month lows, NZ$ sours on milk oversupply fears
summary: The Australian dollar fell to a 5-month low of US$0.7532, while the New Zealand dollar dropped for a 9th straight session as investors worry about milk oversupply ahead of a global dairy auction. The Reserve Bank of Australia's minutes showed concerns about sluggish wages and cemented views that interest rates will remain low for months. The RBA cut forecasts for core inflation, suggesting interest rate hikes are unlikely in 2018 and 2019.

site_title: Luxury flat on Hong Kong's Peak sells for Asian record price of more than HK$1.16b
summary: A luxury flat in Hong Kong's Peak neighborhood sold for a record-breaking HK$1.16 billion, setting the highest price per square foot in Asia at HK$132,000. The 4,242 square foot property was sold to an unidentified buyer, equivalent to 2,745 years' worth of the median annual income of HK$204,000. This sale highlights the extreme wealth gap in Hong Kong, where the city's property market is experiencing a surge in prices, putting it at risk of a bubble.

site_title: Gold falls on pressure from stronger dollar, rate hikes in focus
summary: Gold fell 1.4% to $1,275.66 an ounce on Monday, amid pressure from a stronger US dollar and expectations of US interest rate hikes. The US dollar reached its highest level against a basket of major currencies in nearly a week, driven by concerns over German Chancellor Angela Merkel's failure to form a coalition government. The Federal Reserve's expected rate hikes in December and beyond are also seen as a headwind for gold.

site_title: Nestle is said to be among potential Hain Celestial suitors
summary: Nestle is reportedly exploring a potential purchase of Hain Celestial Group, a US-based maker of organic and vegetarian food, as the Swiss giant seeks to expand into healthier fare. Hain Celestial's shares rose 11% after temporary halt, valuing the company at over $4.2 billion. The move comes as the company faces declining annual profits and pressures from rapidly changing consumer tastes, with other companies, including US food makers and buyout firms, also expressing interest in a potential sale.

site_title: China pledges to be more open to providing information: China Daily
summary: China has pledged to be more open in providing information to the international community, citing a senior government official. Minister Jiang Jianguo stated that China should discuss its disadvantages and conflicts openly, and not avoid sensitive topics. Despite strict media controls, China aims to improve the accuracy, speed, and transparency of economic and environmental data. The country is also encouraging media to hold local officials accountable, a move seen as a step towards greater openness.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened unchanged on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 7.57 points to 3,394.16. About 41.9 million shares worth S$53.1 million changed hands. The market saw a 0.22% gain, with 68 gainers outnumbering 40 losers.

site_title: Hot stock: New Wave shares slide 6.7% in early trading
summary: New Wave Holdings shares dropped 6.7% to S$0.014 in early trading on Tuesday after the company announced no bids were received for its Jalan Besar Plaza en bloc tender. The property, owned by New Wave, received interest from an unnamed developer in November and is still in a position to enter into a private contract within 10 weeks. A previous voluntary conditional cash offer from Fragrance Group's CEO Koh Wee Meng, representing a 44.4% premium, is set to close on November 30.

site_title: Toyota to US workers: Made-in-Japan Camrys more profitable
summary: Toyota has informed US workers that building Camry sedans in Japan can be more profitable than in Kentucky, where the cars are currently assembled. The company's president, Wil James, revealed this in a video message, stating that cost-cutting efforts are necessary to maintain the factory's competitiveness. The move comes as President Donald Trump has pressured Toyota to increase local production, and the company is investing heavily in research and development. Toyota has pledged to continue investing in the Kentucky plant for the next 30 years, but workers are increasingly considering unionization in response to the cost-cutting drive.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Serrano, ISR Capital, OUE Lippo Healthcare
summary: Serrano Limited's request to delay its annual general meeting was rejected by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority. The company is appealing the decision. ISR Capital's former director, David Rigoll, sold a 13.61% stake for $1.2 million, breaching an undertaking not to sell shares. OUE Lippo Healthcare clarified reports of shelving plans to develop a piece of land in Kuala Lumpur, stating no decision has been made to sell or shelve development plans.

site_title: Ex-ISR director sells 14% stake for S$1.2m; no longer substantial shareholder
summary: Former ISR Capital director David Rigoll sold 14% stake for S$1.2m, reducing his substantial shareholder status. He sold 27.37m shares at 0.5 Singapore cent and 287.5m shares at 0.37 Singapore cent, following a pay dispute. ISR alleged the sales breached an undertaking not to sell shares. Rigoll had been selling shares since stepping down in March over a pay dispute, withdrawing the undertaking after the transactions.

site_title: Tencent beats Jack Ma's Alibaba to become first Asian company valued over US$500b
summary: Tencent, a Hong Kong-listed internet giant, has become the first Asian company valued over $500 billion, surpassing Jack Ma's Alibaba Group Holding. The company's market value surged to HK$3.99 trillion, with its shares rising 121.4% this year. Tencent's revenue growth, massive user base, and investments in new areas are credited to its meteoric rise. The company's founder and CEO, Ma Huateng, now has a personal wealth close to $47 billion, surpassing Alibaba's valuation.

site_title: Keppel unit's partner sues to block 2.9b yuan sale of China marina stake
summary: Keppel Corp's planned sale of its 80% stake in a China marina project, valued at 2.9 billion yuan, has been blocked by the minority shareholder Sunsea Yacht Club (Hong Kong) Co through legal proceedings in Singapore. The minority shareholder has served writs of summons to stop Keppel's wholly owned subsidiary Keppel Land China Ltd from selling its stake. A hearing is scheduled for Dec 4, 2017. Keppel plans to vigorously defend the attempts, which would result in a gain of about S$290 million if the deal is completed.

site_title: May prepares new Brexit offer after strategy talks with cabinet
summary: Prime Minister Theresa May has secured backing from her cabinet to offer the EU more money to break the Brexit deadlock, doubling Britain's exit payment offer to 40 billion pounds. The new offer includes allowing the European Court of Justice to guarantee EU citizens' rights in the UK. However, EU negotiators have expressed concerns that the size of the payment is less important than the principles underlying it, and that the UK must commit to meeting budget obligations. The EU is pushing for at least 60 billion euros in payments, and the UK's offer may not be enough to unblock talks on future trade relations.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Theresa May won the backing of ministers on both sides of her divided cabinet to offer the European Union more money to break the Brexit deadlock so talks can move on to discussing future trade relations, ITV News reported.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as exporters rise
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.90% and the Topix index increasing 0.69%. The gains were driven by a weaker yen lifting exporter stocks. This follows a positive trend on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: SoftBank funding may spur Uber to re-think tough Southeast Asian market
summary: SoftBank's $1-1.25 billion investment in Uber may lead to a potential consolidation with other ride-hailing assets, including Grab, in Southeast Asia. The Japanese group, which has invested in Uber's rivals across Asia, aims to achieve founder Masayoshi Son's vision of a future driven by artificial intelligence. Uber's CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, acknowledges the challenges in the Southeast Asian market, which is considered over-capitalized. Some investors believe that shutting down Uber's Southeast Asian operations could make for a more palatable IPO, while others predict that Uber will sell off its Southeast Asian operations to Grab or DiDi.

site_title: US files suit to block US$85b AT&T-Time Warner merger
summary: US antitrust enforcers have filed a lawsuit to block AT&T's $85 billion merger with Time Warner, citing concerns over the deal's impact on competition. The merger, announced over a year ago, would combine Time Warner's content, including HBO and CNN, with AT&T's internet and pay TV delivery networks. AT&T plans to challenge the lawsuit, arguing that the deal is a "vertical" merger without competitive overlap, and is confident that the court will reject the government's claims.

site_title: Collapse of German coalition talks deals Merkel a huge blow
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel faces a significant crisis after coalition talks collapsed, leaving her with few options to form a government. The talks between her conservatives, the Free Democrats, and the Greens ended with the Free Democrats pulling out, making a minority government or another "grand coalition" with the Social Democrats unlikely. With no viable path forward, Merkel is likely to call for new elections, which could lead to a fresh vote in spring 2018 and potentially favor the far-right Alternative for Democracy Party. The crisis has significant implications for European politics, including the UK's Brexit negotiations and French President Emmanuel Macron's EU reforms.

site_title: Trump declares North Korea state sponsor of terror
summary: US President Donald Trump declared North Korea a state sponsor of terrorism, adding its name to a terror blacklist previously led by Iran and Syria. Trump vowed a rapid ramp-up of US Treasury sanctions, citing the death of a US student in a North Korean jail and the assassination of Kim Jong Un's brother. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said Washington still hopes for diplomacy and that punitive measures are having a significant effect on Pyongyang's economy, but China's refusal to cut off oil supplies to its sole refinery remains a concern.

site_title: South Korea's Nov 1-20 exports jump 9.7% y-o-y: customs agency
summary: South Korea's exports from Nov 1-20 rose 9.7% year-over-year, driven by increases in exports to China (21.1%), the US (11.0%), and Vietnam (39.4%). Semiconductors and petrochemical products led the growth, rising 63.5% and 45% respectively.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 1.15 points to 1,719.51, with 50.96 million lots traded worth RM18.01 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 107 to 72.

site_title: US arrests two Chinese oil company reps in Africa bribery scheme
summary: US authorities have arrested Hong Kong's Patrick Chi Ping Ho and Senegal's Cheikh Gadio for leading a multimillion-dollar bribery scheme in Africa on behalf of Chinese energy company CEFC China Energy. The scheme involved bribing high-level officials in Chad and Uganda to secure business advantages. The two men allegedly offered $2 million in bribes and sent under the guise of donations, with possible jail sentences of up to 20 years. The charges are based on violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and money laundering.

site_title: Europe: Shares brush off German government worries; DAX reconquers key level
summary: European shares rose on Monday, driven by confidence in global economic activity and a retreating euro, despite Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel failing to form a three-way coalition government. The DAX index rose 0.5%, while the Stoxx 600 index added 0.7%. Key performers included Volkswagen, ProSiebenSat.1, and Roche, with the latter announcing trial wins for its immunotherapy Tecentriq. The euro's fall against the dollar also boosted European stocks, and investors expressed optimism about the German economy's growth prospects.

site_title: Noises detected in search for missing Argentine submarine
summary: Search vessels in the South Atlantic have detected noises on their sonar that could be coming from the crew of the missing Argentine submarine ARA San Juan, 44 crew members of whom have been missing for five days. The noises, which sound like tools being banged on the hull, were detected 360km offshore in relatively shallow water. A US Navy P-8A Poseidon plane was dispatched to the site, and analysis of the recordings will take a few hours. The search effort, involving countries including the US, Brazil, Britain, Chile, and Uruguay, has raised hopes for the crew's safety, but officials cautioned against creating false expectations.

site_title: Key European agencies move away from London in signs of Brexit's toll
summary: European agencies, overseeing Europe's banks and pharmaceutical sector, are relocating from London to Amsterdam and Paris, respectively, as part of Brexit's economic impact. The European Medicines Agency, a crucial pillar for the UK's pharmaceutical industry, will move to Amsterdam, while the European Banking Authority will relocate to Paris. This move diminishes the UK's economic clout and serves as a warning to London, currently the banking capital of Europe, of the consequences of Brexit. The relocation highlights the fierce competition from other capitals for financial business.

site_title: Oil eases as traders, investors grow edgy ahead of Opec
summary: Oil prices fell 0.8% on Monday, extending recent weakness ahead of the Opec meeting on November 30, where the group is expected to extend its output cut agreement. US crude production is a concern for Opec, with forecasts suggesting it could reach 10 million barrels per day within 3-6 months. A stronger dollar and high speculative interest in oil also contributed to the decline, with oil prices falling to $56.09 for US West Texas Intermediate crude and $62.22 for Brent crude.

site_title: Noble unit to invest £14m in two rare earth projects
summary: Noble Group is investing £14 million in two rare earth projects through its subsidiary Talaxis Limited. The investments will support the development of the Songwe Hill rare earths project in Malawi and the production of a new rare earth alloy powder, magnet, and other technologies for the electric vehicle market. The move aims to bolster Noble's position in the rare earths sector and strengthen its green technology and specialty metals supply chain.

site_title: Indian state oil firms betting on natural gas as next big thing
summary: Indian state-owned oil companies Indian Oil, Bharat Petroleum, and Hindustan Petroleum plan to increase natural gas contributions to 5-15% of their incomes over the next few years, up from nearly none now, to meet Prime Minister Narendra Modi's goal of making natural gas a bigger part of the country's energy mix.

site_title: Duterte offers his country's third telco role to China
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has offered China the opportunity to be the country's third telecoms operator, breaking a longstanding duopoly that has frustrated consumers. The move is part of Duterte's pursuit of closer ties with China, despite historical territorial disputes. The offer was made during a visit by Chinese Premier Li Keqiang, with the potential for improved telecommunications services and faster internet speeds. However, the process is complex due to constitutional limitations on foreign ownership of domestic telecoms companies, which limits foreign firms to 40% ownership.

site_title: Trafigura launches inventory-backed bonds from Singapore
summary: Trafigura, a leading independent oil trader, has launched inventory-backed bonds from Singapore, backed by a portfolio of commodities. The $470 million in notes were sold to six banks, including DBS Bank and OCBC, and will eventually be offered to the wider capital market after a credit rating is obtained. The bonds will allow Trafigura to diversify its funding sources and borrow more from banks through a separate entity, while also providing a safeguard against potential losses in case of bankruptcy.

site_title: US Midwest luring tech investors away from Valley
summary: US tech investors are increasingly looking to the Midwest for startup investments, with notable investors such as J.D. Vance and Steve Case's investment firm Revolution seeking to raise up to $100 million for a new seed fund. This shift is driven by the perceived undervaluation of the Midwest and its potential for innovation, with many startups succeeding in the region. Investors are drawn to the region's cost of living, tech talent, and access to industry knowledge, with the goal of marrying technology with industry expertise. The Midwest is seen as an antidote to Silicon Valley's dominance, with major cities like Columbus and Indianapolis now hosting clusters of startup accelerators and incubators.

site_title: PUB starts Phase 2 of DTSS; S$2.3b of work contracted out
summary: Singapore's national water agency PUB has begun Phase 2 of the Deep Tunnel Sewerage System (DTSS), with a total of five contracts worth S$2.3 billion already contracted out. The phase, to be completed by 2025, will extend the deep tunnel system to cover the western part of Singapore, including the downtown area and major developments. The tunnels will connect to existing tunnels from the first phase, creating an integrated system. The project aims to reduce land taken up by used-water infrastructure by 50% and produce NEWater, a sustainable water source.

site_title: SHC Capital to acquire MM Myanmar for S$69.7m
summary: SHC Capital Asia Ltd has announced the acquisition of MM Myanmar Pte Ltd for S$69.7 million, a reverse takeover of SHC Capital. The acquisition includes three businesses transferred from Yoma Strategic Holdings, including a hotel under construction and a parcel of land for commercial development. SHC Capital will issue new shares and change its name to Memories Group Ltd, with CEO Michel Novatin and COO Jean-Michel Romon leading the company.

site_title: HK retail stock buyers pile US$163b into IPOs
summary: Hong Kong retail investors have poured US$163 billion into initial public offerings (IPOs) this year, surpassing three-quarters of the territory's monetary base. This surge in interest is driven by small investors seeking growth in tech and other high-growth industries, with popular offerings including China Literature Ltd and FIT Hon Teng Ltd. The enthusiasm has boosted after-market performance, with some stocks doubling in value since their Hong Kong listings. Experts predict a strong year for IPOs in Hong Kong in 2018, with more tech, healthcare, and environmental-related companies expected to list.

images.alt_text: (From far left) Shang Xuesong, president of China Literature, and co-CEOs Liang Xiaodong and Wu Wenhui celebrating the listing of their company on Nov 8. It was this year's most popular IPO.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific takes 45% stake in A$74.1m purchase of Melbourne building
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings has acquired a 45% stake in a Melbourne office building for A$74.1 million (S$76 million). The freehold building has a 1,906 sq m site and 9,854 sq m of net lettable area. The joint venture partner, a private family office, holds the remaining 55%. The deal requires approval from the Australian Treasurer. This acquisition will give Roxy-Pacific its second Australian asset, following the sale of an office building in Sydney.

site_title: James Murdoch ready for career reset beyond Fox
summary: James Murdoch, CEO of 21st Century Fox, may consider a career reset as potential acquirers show interest in the company's international assets. Murdoch has built Fox's entertainment and sports businesses, but managing scandals at Fox News has been a challenge. If Fox sold entertainment businesses and kept the news channel, Murdoch would consider leaving. His father, Rupert Murdoch, is considering selling major parts of the company due to undervalued assets. Murdoch has also been approached by Disney and Comcast about joining a management role, and could potentially create his own venture.

site_title: Telecoms group Altice not selling shares to tackle debts
summary: Telecoms group Altice has no plans to sell shares to tackle its $58 billion debt, saying it will cut debts through asset sales. The company's shares rose 12.4% after a statement, reversing a 12% decline on Friday. Altice's billionaire founder Patrick Drahi has shifted focus from acquisitions to debt reduction and customer satisfaction. The company has identified non-core assets for sale, including telecoms towers, and has a strong liquidity position. Analysts say the update may reassure bondholders in the short-term, but Altice needs to improve its underlying performance in France.

site_title: In Kim Yuna's absence, Koreans holding out for Winter Games hero
summary: Korean figure skater Kim Yuna's impassioned speech to the International Olympic Committee in 2010 helped secure the 2018 Winter Games for South Korea. She was dubbed the "Face of Pyeongchang" and played a crucial role in selling the vision of a home Olympics, despite little prior interest in winter sports. Her efforts helped boost ticket sales, but her absence from the current Winter Games has left the host nation without a true winter sports hero, affecting ticket sales.

site_title: ACRA rejects Serrano's request to delay AGM
summary: ACRA has rejected Serrano Limited's request to delay its annual general meeting (AGM) from Nov 14, 2017 to Feb 28, 2018. The company had obtained SGX's approval for the extension, but ACRA denied the request. Serrano Limited is appealing the decision and will keep shareholders updated on the outcome. The company is undergoing schemes of arrangement with its creditors and has no accounts and finance staff following the departure of its group financial controller in July.

site_title: Brexit pushes EU bank regulator into arms of continental suitors
summary: The European Banking Authority (EBA) is relocating from London to the continent due to Brexit, with eight cities competing to host the regulator and its 180 employees. The EU's General Affairs Council will choose the new seats of the EBA and European Medicines Agency, with Frankfurt and Paris seen as potential beneficiaries. The EBA's move is unlikely to influence banks looking for a base in the EU after Brexit, according to experts. The selection process is expected to be announced in Brussels, with the goal of ensuring the agencies can operate by Brexit day.

site_title: US: Stocks begin holiday-shortened week on positive note
summary: US stocks started the holiday-shortened week on a positive note, rising 0.3% to 23,430.33 on the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 0.1% each. The rally comes after a run of good data, including a report on leading economic indicators, which suggests GDP growth could reach three percent in the third quarter. Investors are feeling upbeat despite concerns over tax cuts and high equity valuations.

site_title: Norway oil bosses insist end isn't nigh after US$35b shock
summary: Norway's US$1 trillion wealth fund has proposed selling its US$35 billion in oil and gas investments, sparking concerns for the country's offshore oil industry. Industry leaders say both moves are possible, but the proposal is seen as a nod to the industry's uncertain future. The government and Parliament must approve the plan, which would not affect the terms for oil companies operating offshore. Norway's powerful oil lobby believes the government will safeguard a consensus on stable terms, despite opposition from environmental groups and some opposition parties.

site_title: How Trump sold out world trade to China
summary: US President Donald Trump's 12-day trip to Asia was historic but not for reasons he stated. Instead of honoring America's sacrifice in Vietnam, Trump visited Da Nang to symbolically highlight the futility of US intervention. This followed a misreading of history, as US policymakers intervened in Vietnam to prevent Communist China's domination, not to stop its rise. Trump's trip marked a shift in US foreign policy, prioritizing China's interests over the US's. The move is seen as a sellout of world trade to China, with Trump's actions contradicting his earlier rhetoric on protecting American interests.

site_title: Alibaba bets US$2.9b on China's top hypermarket player
summary: Alibaba has agreed to invest $2.9 billion in Sun Art Retail Group Ltd, China's largest operator of hypermarkets, acquiring a 36% stake in the company. The deal aims to shake up the US$4 trillion brick-and-mortar retail market and expand Alibaba's presence in groceries. The investment is part of Alibaba's "new retail" strategy, which combines online and offline shopping to boost sales and customer data. The acquisition marks Alibaba's latest foray into physical commerce, following similar investments in Suning Commerce and Intime Retail Group Co.

site_title: Singapore could house Neste's next giant refinery
summary: Singapore is a potential location for Neste's next giant refinery, with the company's president and CEO, Matti Lievonen, stating that a final decision will be made by the end of 2026. The refinery, which will produce renewable diesel, is part of Neste's plans to expand its operations in the coming years. Lievonen did not rule out Singapore entirely, but also mentioned that the US is also being considered as a location for the investment.

site_title: Singapore's Q3 domestic wholesale trade growth eases to 11.3%
summary: Singapore's domestic wholesale trade grew 11.3% in the September quarter, down from 18.5% in the second quarter and 23.5% in the first quarter. Excluding petroleum, trade declined 3.7% quarter-over-quarter. After adjusting for price changes, overall trade rose 1.3% year-over-year, but fell 5.6% from the previous quarter. Year-on-year growth was reported in various industries, including general wholesale trade, electronics, and metals, but declines were seen in household equipment and food industries.

site_title: Robo-taxis hold promise, and perils, for carmakers
summary: Robo-taxis are revolutionizing the automotive industry, with major brands racing to create autonomous electric cars and trucks. By 2050, analysts predict fully electric cars will make up 90% of the global market, driven by concerns over smog and traffic jams. Carmakers are investing billions in batteries and autonomous driving technologies, but experts warn that those who fail to adapt risk not surviving. Industry giants like Volkswagen and PSA are betting on car-sharing and services, while the EU Commission urges collaboration to produce large-scale batteries domestically.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ST Aerospace wins a 15-year contract with Gulf Air for component support of Boeing 787 aircraft. New Wave Holdings' collective sale committee confirms no bids were received for Jalan Besar Plaza, but a developer expressed interest to purchase. PTC Logistics exercises its right to compulsorily acquire remaining shares of Poh Tiong Choon Logistics Limited. Wilmar International agrees to purchase Cargill's edible oil facilities in Kuantan, Malaysia. UOL Group's interest in United Industrial Corporation increases to 49.78% of issued share capital.

site_title: Friday's export numbers give stocks zing
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 4.21 points, or 0.12%, to 3,386.59 on Monday, driven by export figures last Friday and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's forecast of a 3% economic growth this year. However, losers outnumbered gainers, 279 to 150. Stocks like Singapore Airlines and Sats gained, while Oxley Holdings and Roxy-Pacific Holdings fell despite recent deals. The mixed performance was also influenced by global uncertainty, including the failed German Chancellor Angela Merkel's coalition talks and a decline in the Nikkei.

site_title: Homegrown venture Amerald sees value abroad
summary: Amerald Land, a Singapore-based property developer, has thrived in the cooling property market despite government cooling measures. The company focuses on areas with high growth potential, such as Malaysia and Indonesia, and prioritizes quality projects with environmentally friendly designs. Amerald's pragmatic approach to investing in undervalued properties and its parent company's expertise in construction services have contributed to its success. The company plans to expand overseas, but acknowledges the challenges of navigating unfamiliar markets and regulatory hurdles. With a focus on long-term customer satisfaction, Amerald Land aims to maintain its reputation as a developer of valuable and attractive projects.

site_title: Indonesia Parliament Speaker in detention
summary: Indonesia's Parliament Speaker, Setya Novanto, has been taken into custody by the anti-corruption agency for his alleged role in causing state losses of US$170 million linked to a national electronic identity card scheme. Novanto, who denied wrongdoing, was transferred from a hospital into a KPK detention facility after being arrested on Friday night. He will be held for 20 days for questioning and is one of the most senior politicians to be detained by the agency.

images.alt_text: Parliament Speaker Setya Novanto being escorted by officials from the Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK) in Jakarta on Sunday. He has denied wrongdoing but has repeatedly missed summonses for questioning by the agency in recent months, saying he was ill and needed heart surgery.

site_title: GST hike looms as Singapore's funding needs grow
summary: Singapore's Goods and Services Tax (GST) is likely to be increased within the next few years as the government's funding needs grow. Despite predictions that corporate tax rates and personal income tax rates may not be raised, experts suggest that a GST hike is the most likely option. The government has already stated that it expects a primary deficit of S$5.62 billion for the financial year 2017, and experts believe that higher tax revenues are unlikely to come from raising corporate tax rates or personal income tax rates. The government may consider taxing e-commerce spending as an alternative revenue source.

images.alt_text: The Goods and Services Tax (GST) is likely to go up within the next few years, with an announcement expected as soon as Budget 2018, economists and tax experts say.

site_title: GLP's privatisation - why every vote and voter counts
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) is set to undergo the largest privatisation of a listed company in Asia, with a proposed acquisition and privatisation valued at S$3.38 per share, representing premiums of 81% and 64% to the 12-month volume weighted average price and undisturbed share price. Minority shareholders are advised to exercise their right to vote on the GLP scheme, as every vote counts in ensuring the protection of their interests. The scheme must be approved by a majority of shareholders voting on the scheme and must also meet a share-count condition, where those who vote in favour must hold at least 75% of GLP shares voted.

site_title: London's iconic red buses to run on biofuel made from old coffee
summary: London's iconic red double-decker buses will run on a biofuel made from old coffee grounds, supplied by a demonstration project by Bio-bean and Royal Dutch Shell. The fuel, produced from 6,000 litres of waste coffee grounds annually, will be blended with ordinary diesel. This initiative aims to reduce carbon emissions and follows a trend of companies focusing on biofuels from waste materials, such as used cooking oil and inedible plants.

site_title: Airbus hits turbulence after Emirates halts US$16b deal for 36 A380s
summary: Airbus faced a significant setback after Emirates halted a $16 billion deal for 36 A380s, leaving uncertainty over the future of the world's largest jetliner. The deal's collapse came just moments before Emirates was set to sign a $30 billion order for Airbus and Boeing at the Dubai Airshow. The halt has raised concerns about the relationship between Airbus and Emirates, with the Gulf carrier demanding a guarantee that Airbus would continue producing the A380 for 10 years. The deal's collapse also raises questions about the future of the A380 program and the stability of Airbus's leadership.

site_title: Singapore's aviation ecosystem needs new strategic thinking
summary: Singapore's aviation ecosystem is facing challenges due to conflicting interests among players, including airlines, MRO providers, and airport operators. The country's airport, Changi, generates significant revenue but often at the expense of airlines and other players, leading to margin squeezes. In contrast, airports in the Middle East, such as Doha and Dubai, have common ownership structures that align interests. With the Singapore aviation sector facing increasing competition, cooperation among players is necessary to mitigate returns drag and maintain its competitiveness.

site_title: Re-imagining financial services
summary: A recent roundtable discussion in Singapore explored the impact of technology on financial services. Experts emphasized the need for incumbents to adopt a flexible and collaborative approach to business, driven by disruptions caused by technology. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) was highlighted as a leader in promoting the use of new technology. The panel also discussed various global economic and financial trends, including China's slowing GDP growth, Chinese banks' struggles with consumer lending, and Japan's MUFG's expansion into the US securitization market. A more collaborative approach is necessary for financial services to adapt to technological changes.

site_title: Nafta negotiations shift down a gear with eyes on US lobbyists
summary: US-Canada-Mexico Nafta talks have slowed down in Mexico City, with no significant breakthroughs in the fifth round of negotiations. The US is frustrated with Canada and Mexico for not presenting counter-proposals to its demands, particularly on regional content requirements and dispute settlement. US business groups, led by the US Chamber of Commerce, are lobbying the White House to back down from proposals seen as damaging to corporate interests. A deal remains far off, with negotiations set to continue into 2018.

images.alt_text: The US is said to be frustrated with what it perceives to be the reluctance of Canada and Mexico to present counter-proposals to US positions on key issues such as regional content requirements and dispute settlement.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS Group Holdings' digital implementation is gaining traction, with analysts from HB Research raising their target price to S$23.33. The bank is working on cloud architecture and has seen growth in India and Indonesia, which are expected to record 20% CAGR in income. Meanwhile, Keppel DC Reit is poised to benefit from the data centre industry's positive outlook, with its fair value estimate raised to S$1.50. Oxley Holdings landed a collective sale for S$311 million, and analysts from BS Group Research expect the new development to potentially house 387 units.

site_title: Feinmetall's fine art of service
summary: Feinmetall, a Singapore-based company, has achieved year-on-year double-digit growth since 2012 by focusing on innovation and customer needs. Under the leadership of General Manager Sam Chee Wah, the company has expanded its services from a regional repair center to a one-stop provider of probe card solutions, including manufacturing, maintenance, and training. Feinmetall has invested in a new digital manufacturing facility, further solidifying its position as a technology leader in the Asia-Pacific region and Europe. The company's strong balance sheet has enabled consecutive years of growth and reinvestments in capacity and capabilities.

site_title: Favourable short-term fundamentals on oil?
summary: Oil prices have surged in recent months due to strong demand, with Brent crude breaking the $60 per barrel ceiling since mid-2015. Despite fluctuations, bulls argue that a market rebalancing is underway, driven by a global economic recovery and constrained supply. However, risks include growing electric vehicle adoption, which may reduce oil demand in the medium term, and the potential for a supply response from shale producers, which may increase productivity if oil prices remain high. For now, fundamentals remain intact, with Opec production cuts and potential declines in production from key producers supporting prices.

images.alt_text: For now, with a resilient global economy and a relatively limited traction in electric vehicle adoption, the fundamentals for oil are still intact.

site_title: GIC takes majority stake in new innovation precinct in Melbourne
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has taken a majority stake in a new innovation precinct in Melbourne, Australia. Developed by Lendlease and partnering with the University of Melbourne, Urbanest, and other investors, the project will be majority pre-leased to the university for 42 years. GIC sees the innovation precinct as a resilient long-term investment opportunity, generating cash flows in line with global emerging trends of innovation hubs around universities.

site_title: Businesses can grow and thrive, even as countries look inwards
summary: China's "Made in China 2025" and participation in the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) demonstrate the country's efforts to balance domestic development and global engagement. Despite rising nationalism, China can be both pro-business and pro-worker by opening up to the global market and investing in its workforce. Singapore's approach, where the government and businesses work together to address challenges, serves as a model for a "win-win" situation, where both local and foreign workers benefit. This collaborative approach can help countries navigate the complexities of global politics and economic shifts.

site_title: Howard Marks on...
summary: Howard Marks, a renowned investor, expresses concerns about passive investing and the liquidity of exchange-traded funds (ETFs). He notes that investors may be disappointed if they rely on ETFs for quick liquidity, as market conditions can change rapidly. Marks also dismisses Bitcoin as a speculative mania, citing its lack of intrinsic value and the psychological factors driving its price increases. He emphasizes that liquidity is situational and directional, influenced by market sentiment and herd behavior.

site_title: Ezion wins vote to refinance S$575m of notes, perpetuals
summary: Ezion Holdings has successfully refinanced S$575 million of notes and perpetuals with a majority vote from holders, unlocking a US$100 million working capital line. The refinancing proposal included slashing coupon rates to 0.25% and offering flexibility to swap securities into shares. The move provides Ezion with extra runway to tide over the offshore and marine downturn, but the company still needs support from bank lenders and shareholders to secure a six-year refinancing proposal for over US$1 billion of loans.

site_title: Singapore can help to develop Asia's financial services
summary: Singapore's financial services sector can contribute to Asia's growth by developing the region's financial infrastructure, particularly in fintech. The Industry Transformation Map aims to create 1,000 jobs and boost productivity, with growth expected to reach 4.3% in the medium term. To achieve this, Singapore needs to support Asian finance, including expanding cross-border agreements, despite regulatory challenges. Technology can play a key role, with regulatory automation and AI-powered advice solutions emerging to address compliance and client demands. A financial services ecosystem in Asia, enabling smooth cross-border transactions and promoting competition, is the next step for Singapore to maintain its regional hub status.

site_title: It's smelling like S-chip trouble at ETC
summary: Singapore-listed property developer Emerging Towns & Cities Singapore (ETC) is facing a series of issues linked to its Chinese partner, Luo Shandong, who owns nearly 18% of the company. ETC's chairman, Christopher Chong, and audit committee chairman, Peter Tan, have been called to remove by Luo, who has nominated two new directors. This comes after ETC revealed that 118 million yuan (S$24.13 million) was siphoned off without authorization from its Chinese subsidiary. The incidents reflect challenges in implementing transparency and governance standards in Singapore companies operating in China.

site_title: Brexit deadline looms but exit deal breakthrough is nowhere in sight
summary: The UK and EU remain far from a Brexit deal, with a key deadline looming in mid-December. Despite recent negotiations, progress on the UK's financial exit bill and Irish border issues has been slow. UK Prime Minister Theresa May has acknowledged that there is still "a lot to be done" and has sought to seize back the initiative, but the EU has expressed skepticism about the UK's preparedness and vision. The EU's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, has described the UK's positions as a "fantasy," and the odds of a hard, disorderly Brexit are growing.

site_title: Uber steps up driverless-cars push with deal for 24,000 Volvos
summary: Uber has agreed to purchase 24,000 Volvo XC90s for $1.1 billion to create a fleet of driverless cars, with deliveries set to begin between 2019 and 2021. The vehicles will be equipped with Uber's sensors and software to enable pilot-less driving. The deal marks Uber's first commercial purchase of autonomous vehicles and is part of its efforts to replace human drivers, the company's largest cost. The partnership aims to speed up the development of mass-produced, self-driving vehicles and disrupt the automotive industry.

site_title: Qualcomm set to get nod from Japan, Europe for NXP bid
summary: US smartphone chipmaker Qualcomm is set to win "imminent" Japanese antitrust clearance for its $38 billion bid for NXP Semiconductors, with European approval expected by the end of the year after slight concessions. This would take Qualcomm a major step forward in closing the deal and counter Broadcom's $103 billion unsolicited takeover bid. Qualcomm agreed to not purchase NXP's standard essential patents and offered an interoperability pledge, addressing competition concerns. The company aims to become the leading supplier to the automotive chips market via the NXP purchase.

site_title: Malaysian central bank chief: Ringgit is not reflecting fair value
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor, Muhammad Ibrahim, stated that the ringgit is not reflecting its fair value, despite its recent recovery from a sharp selloff in 2016. The currency is now trading at its highest in over a year against the dollar. Ibrahim attributed the influence of external factors to waning, citing the need for domestic traders to play a bigger role in pricing the ringgit. The central bank announced new measures to boost liquidity in the onshore ringgit market, including the introduction of Bank Negara Interbank Bills.

site_title: Singapore ranks No 13 in world talent competitiveness
summary: Singapore ranks 13th in the IMD World Talent Ranking, up two spots from last year, driven by improvements in cost of living and remuneration. Despite this, Hong Kong fell to 12th place, down three spots. The rankings highlight the challenges of balancing domestic talent management with attracting foreign talent, with Denmark spending 7% of GDP on education and Singapore spending 2.9%. Experts warn that Singapore must find a balance to ensure demographic support for growth, as the economic centre of gravity shifts from the West to Asia.

images.alt_text: A slight improvement in factors such as the cost of living and remuneration helped make Singapore a more competitive place for talent this year, while the reverse caused Hong Kong to become less attractive, according to Swiss business school IMD.

site_title: Chinese buyers go cool on Australian homes
summary: Chinese buyers have cooled off on Australian homes due to tightened capital controls and stricter mortgage lending restrictions by local banks. According to Reserve Bank of Australia's head of financial stability, foreign buyers accounted for 10-15% of new construction and 5% of total housing sales. This decrease is attributed to Beijing's efforts to curb foreign investment in real estate. The easing of demand is expected to impact the Australian property market.

site_title: Euro hits 2-month low vs yen, then pares most losses
summary: The euro recovered from a two-month low against the yen after German Chancellor Angela Merkel's failure to form a three-way coalition government, sparking concerns of a new election. The euro initially fell 0.8% to 131.16 yen, but rebounded as much as one percent to trade flat at 132.18 yen. Investors cited uncertainty but deemed the impact on the euro's value minimal. The US dollar also sold off against the yen, but recovered in European trading.

site_title: China issues guidelines to boost private investment in manufacturing
summary: China has issued guidelines to boost private investment in manufacturing, focusing on greener development and moving up the value chain. The government will provide fiscal support and "innovative financing" options, such as corporate bonds and asset-backed securities, to private firms. The country aims to guide private capital towards high-end, intelligent, green, and services-oriented manufacturing, with a focus on areas like the "internet plus" model and global expansion. The guidelines also aim to support private firms in weak and vulnerable sectors, and encourage more private involvement in transforming traditional industries.

site_title: Emerald Media banks on startup
summary: KKR & Co-backed Emerald Media led a $65 million funding round for aCommerce, a Bangkok-based startup that helps brands sell products online across South-east Asia. The four-year-old firm plans to expand into new markets such as Vietnam. Existing backers Blue Sky, MDI Ventures, and DKSH also joined the series B round. The funding will support the company's growth and expansion in the region.

site_title: IPC shares lower after preliminary agreements with Chinese firm lapse
summary: IPC Corporation's shares fell 6.7% after preliminary agreements with Chinese firm Xinyuan (China) Real Estate Co Ltd lapsed. The agreements included a proposed acquisition of a robot maker and disposal of a hotel. Despite the lapse, IPC said it doesn't expect the deal's failure to impact its business operations. Shares closed at S$0.43, down 4.4% from its intra-day high. This marks a significant drop from the 71% surge in shares when the agreements were first announced in September.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse says about 20 banks join its clearing programme
summary: About 20 banks, including Bank of America Merrill Lynch, BBVA, and HSBC, have signed up to Deutsche Boerse's profit-sharing scheme on interest rate swaps, aiming to wrest trade from the London Stock Exchange amid Brexit uncertainty. The program offers significant revenue shares to the 10 most active participants and gives them a say in how Eurex Clearing is run. Deutsche Boerse's Eurex Clearing business has set a deadline of November 20 for banks to sign up with incentives.

site_title: Marks likes oil, but says markets are in 'last trimester'
summary: Renowned debt investor Howard Marks, co-chair of Oaktree Capital Management, warns that financial markets are in their "last trimester" and caution is warranted. He advises investors to focus on conservative, secure investments with less downside risk, such as bonds and real estate, rather than taking on riskier assets. Marks attributes his cautious stance to the current market conditions, including high stock valuations, low volatility, and excessive debt. He believes investors should prioritize preserving capital over seeking opportunities, and notes that the economy or markets may not turn down immediately, but the current situation is precarious.

site_title: Spanish hotels company Barcelo offers to buy NH Hotel Group
summary: Spanish hotel group NH Hotel Group has received a possible takeover offer from rival company Grupo Barcelo, proposing a 60% stake and majority board control. The unsolicited offer could create the largest hotel group in Spain, with a market value of 1.75 billion euros. NH has a current share price of 5 euros per share and is owned by Chinese conglomerate HNA. The company has recently approved an independent strategic plan, and trading in NH shares was suspended shortly after the announcement. The deal's details have yet to be confirmed.

site_title: China's home price growth picks up in October
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.3% month-on-month in October, with a 5.4% year-on-year increase, indicating broadening strength in the market. Despite falling sales and a tighter liquidity environment, prices remain resilient. The government has taken measures to curb speculation and a property bubble, with household loans for property purchases falling to 450.1 billion yuan in October. While prices are slowing, market watchers expect no significant price declines or crash, and weakness in the property sector is starting to drag on broader economic growth.

site_title: Earle Hyman, Bill Cosby's father on The Cosby Show, dies at 91
summary: Earle Hyman, the father of Bill Cosby on The Cosby Show, has died at 91 in Englewood, New Jersey. A renowned actor, Hyman broke racial stereotypes on Broadway and in Scandinavia in works by Shakespeare and Ibsen, and was known for his authoritative father figure role on the popular sitcom. He appeared in over 60 stage productions, including plays by Ibsen, Shakespeare, and O'Neill, and was inducted into the Theater Hall of Fame in 1997. Hyman was also a pioneer in developing black theatre in America, and lived and worked in England and Scandinavia for over 50 years.

images.alt_text: Hyman loved the stage. He played the traditionally white roles of Hamlet, Macbeth and Lear in New York and London, and the black roles of Othello, the Emperor Jones and the chauffeur in Driving Miss Daisy in Norway, Denmark and Sweden.

site_title: Toshiba targets 600b yen from shares sale to fend off delisting
summary: Toshiba plans to raise 600 billion yen by selling new shares and exploring the divestment of its Westinghouse-related assets to avoid delisting from the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The company aims to eliminate a negative 750 billion yen on its balance sheet by March 2018. If successful, the transactions will wipe out the negative equity and allow Toshiba to focus on rebuilding its remaining business units. The company has agreed to sell its memory-chip unit to raise funds, and private equity firms are considering offers for its Westinghouse unit.

site_title: Marvell Technology to buy Cavium for US$6b
summary: Marvell Technology Group announced the acquisition of Cavium for approximately US$6 billion. The deal combines the companies' offerings, expanding their product slate and boosting competitiveness in the data storage market. The acquisition values Cavium at US$80 per share and is expected to close in mid-2018. The combined company's total potential market is estimated to be over US$12 billion, with a more substantial research and development team to meet shifting industry needs.

site_title: US: Tech stocks lead Wall Street higher
summary: US stock indexes rose on Monday, led by technology stocks like Cisco and PayPal. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 17.09 points, or 0.07%, to 23,375.33, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite added 1.46 and 4.64 points, respectively. The gains pushed the S&P 500 and Nasdaq to fresh records despite ongoing US trade tensions.

site_title: Cash-flow issues 'threatening to stall SME growth'
summary: A survey by DP Info found that over 35% of Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are experiencing finance-related issues, with delayed payments from customers skyrocketing to 81% in 2017, surpassing higher interest rates for bank loans. This is threatening to stall SME growth, with cash flow constraints potentially holding back expansion plans. Despite this, SMEs remain focused on growth, with 60% using technology to drive revenue gains, and improving customer service being the most popular business strategy.

site_title: Tencent turns to WeChat, games and deals for global strategy
summary: Tencent Holdings, China's largest social network and gaming firm, is expanding its global strategy by launching WeChat in Malaysia, the first foreign country to do so. The company has secured an e-payment license and plans a launch early next year. WeChat has 980 million monthly active users and is expected to spearhead Tencent's expansion abroad. The move pits Tencent against rival Alibaba Group as they compete for new growth opportunities outside China. Tencent's strategy focuses on generating traffic for WeChat and exporting Chinese culture, rather than replicating its success in China.

site_title: UK queen and husband Philip celebrate 70 years of marriage, quietly
summary: Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip celebrated their 70-year marriage with a private party at Windsor Castle, marking the milestone in a quiet and low-key manner. The couple, who married in 1947, have had a long and devoted relationship, with Philip's support credited as key to Queen Elizabeth's successful reign. Unlike their previous silver, golden, and diamond wedding anniversaries, which were marked with public events, this occasion was kept private.

site_title: Apartment in HK's The Peak district sets record HK$132,000 psf price
summary: A luxury apartment in Hong Kong's The Peak district set a record with a sale price of HK$560 million (S$97.2 million) for a 4,242 sq ft unit, averaging HK$132,000 per square foot. The sale, part of the Mount Nicholson project, broke the previous record for Hong Kong's most expensive residence. The high price reflects the city's already expensive residential market, where home prices have jumped 400% since 2003, making it difficult for many to afford homes, with some residents forced to live in tiny "coffin homes".

site_title: Nets invests S$30m to launch unified e-payments platform
summary: Nets, a Singaporean payment services group, is investing S$30 million over three years to launch a unified digital payments platform, expanding to 100,000 acceptance points nationwide. The platform, supported by DBS Bank, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank, will enable seamless QR code payments across 37,000 merchants. The move aims to promote a cashless future in Singapore, with waiving setup costs and fees for hawkers. The unified QR code platform became effective for DBS, OCBC, and UOB customers, with HSBC, Maybank, Standard Chartered Bank, and Citibank expected to join in the first quarter of 2018.

site_title: TEE International JV to acquire waste management provider for S$18.5m
summary: Tee International Limited, Catalist-listed Advancer Global Limited, and a financial investor have agreed to acquire privately held waste management provider Chiang Kiong Environmental for S$18.5 million. The joint venture, led by TEE International, will hold a majority stake of 50.1% and acquire two subsidiaries, Chiang Kiong Resources (Paper) Pte Ltd and Envotek Engineering Pte Ltd. The proposed acquisition is expected to be completed by December 29, 2017, with the companies expressing excitement about the strategic collaboration and potential growth opportunities in the waste management industry.

site_title: Wilmar unit to buy Cargill's edible oil facilities in Kuantan, Malaysia
summary: Wilmar International Limited has agreed to purchase Cargill's edible oil facilities in Kuantan, Malaysia, for a transfer of ownership by the end of 2018. The facilities include a palm oil refinery and a storage facility. This move aims to expand Wilmar's presence in the edible oil market in Malaysia.

site_title: SHC Capital to acquire MM Myanmar for S$69.7m
summary: SHC Capital Asia Limited has proposed the acquisition of MM Myanmar Pte Ltd for S$69.7 million. The acquisition will be funded through a seven-to-one share consolidation, resulting in 264.997 million new shares. As part of the deal, SHC Capital also plans to change its name to Memories Group Limited and undertake a compliance placement of up to 93 million new shares. MM Myanmar's businesses include a hotel, a parcel of land, and a tourism-related business. Yoma Strategic Holdings has also entered into buyback undertakings for two of MM Myanmar's businesses.

site_title: Draghi says inflation rate still hasn't yet reached ECB target
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stated that the euro-area economy is experiencing its most broad-based expansion in two decades, but inflation remains below the ECB's target of 2%. Draghi emphasized that the economic recovery is solid but inflation dynamics have yet to show a self-sustained upward trend. The ECB's bond-buying program will be reduced to 30 billion euros next year, seen as a sign of growing confidence in the gradual convergence of inflation rates. The next ECB policy decision is due on December 14.

site_title: Profits rise but smaller UK manufacturers lukewarm on investment: survey
summary: UK manufacturers see profits rise, but remain cautious on investment. A survey found 40% expect to increase staff, down from 42% last quarter, and 43% plan to invest in machinery and buildings, down from 44%. Manufacturers prioritize productivity gains from existing workforce and equipment over new machinery and automation. The survey suggests a "sweet spot" for British manufacturers, benefiting from a weaker currency before potential Brexit downsides. The industry faces a challenge to improve productivity, a major limit to economic growth, ahead of the finance minister's budget.

site_title: Canada, Mexico to question US auto content demands at Nafta talks
summary: Canada and Mexico will present rebuttals to US demands for tougher Nafta automotive content rules, focusing on the potential damage to North American manufacturing. The US proposal requires 85% of North American-built autos to be produced in the US, sparking concerns of job losses and supply chain disruptions. Canadian and Mexican negotiators will raise technical questions and argue that the proposal is "unviable" and would harm the continental industry. The talks aim to update the 23-year-old North American Free Trade Agreement between the US, Canada, and Mexico.

site_title: Yanlord sells out phase 3 of Oasis New Island Gardens for 2.59b yuan
summary: Yanlord Land Group Limited sold all 636 apartments in the third phase of Oasis New Island Gardens in Nanjing for 2.59 billion yuan (S$529.6 million) on the first day of its launch, despite government price and sales curbs. The average selling price is 36,000 yuan per square meter, driven by strong demand for high-quality residential developments in first-tier and core second-tier cities. The sale showcases Yanlord's ability to manage prices to enhance profitability.

site_title: VW raises mid-term profit, sales outlook
summary: Volkswagen raised its mid-term profit and sales outlook, citing rebounding emerging markets and demand for new SUVs. The company now expects group revenue to exceed 2016 records by more than a quarter by 2020, and operating profit to rise by 25% or more by 2020. VW also published its first-ever free cash flow target, expecting net cash flow to grow to 10 billion euros or more by 2020. Analysts welcomed the revisions as signs of transparency and the carmaker's financial health.

site_title: For now, only one tiger can roar in Phnom Penh
summary: Cambodia's Supreme Court dissolved the main opposition party, the Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP), on charges of plotting a coup against the government. The move was seen as a blow to democracy, and the US and EU have threatened sanctions against Cambodia. The ruling CPP, led by Prime Minister Hun Sen, is now set to dominate politics with the CNRP's 118 senior officials banned from politics for five years. The country's general election, previously scheduled for 2018, will still proceed, with the CPP likely to benefit from the CNRP's loss of seats.

site_title: Greece to overshoot budget surplus targets in 2017, 2018: govt official
summary: Greece is expected to overshoot its budget surplus targets for a third consecutive year in 2018, with a primary surplus of 2.4-2.5% this year and more than 3.7% next year. The government hopes this will ease austerity measures and allow for targeted social and tax policy interventions. The Greek economy is expected to expand by 1.6% this year and 2.5% in 2018, with tourism revenues surging 10.3% in the first nine months of the year. The country's third financial bailout is expected to expire in August 2018, and Greece plans to finance itself in financial markets thereafter.

site_title: Gold dips on firmer US dollar but stays close to 1-month peak
summary: Gold prices eased 0.2% to $1,291.44 per ounce, near a one-month high, due to a stronger US dollar. Despite uncertainty over the US tax code overhaul, gold remains near its peak, with analysts predicting potential further gains. The US dollar index rose 0.2% as the euro faltered, while hedge funds increased their net long positions in gold and silver contracts.

site_title: Offeror for PTC Logistics to compulsorily acquire all shares
summary: Respond Logistics, backed by PTC Logistics' chairman Poh Choon Ann and Tower Capital Logistics, will compulsorily acquire all remaining shares of PTC Logistics after reaching a 90.17% stake. The offer values PTC Logistics at S$275.5 million. The company's public float will drop below 10%, triggering a trading suspension. The buyout offer was initially set to close on November 27 but has been extended. PTC Logistics will be privatized, and its listing status will not be preserved.

site_title: Singapore shares close up 0.12% on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 4.21 points, or 0.12%, to 3,386.59 on Monday, driven by export figures and a boost from Singapore Airlines' October operating results, which added 1.33% to S$10.68. However, the relief was uneven, with 279 losers outnumbering 150 gainers on the bourse.

site_title: No bids for Jalan Besar Plaza en bloc tender but it receives one expression of interest
summary: Jalan Besar Plaza, a mixed development in Singapore, received no bids at the close of its en bloc tender on Nov 10, but one developer expressed interest in purchasing the property. The collective sale committee will follow up with this developer and any others interested in the purchase. The committee has 10 weeks to enter into a private contract with a purchaser, despite no sale being concluded.

site_title: RHT Chestertons launches in Singapore with an eye on expanding Asian presence
summary: RHT Chestertons, a new property consultancy firm, has launched in Singapore, partnering with London-based real estate agency Chestertons. The collaboration aims to expand Chestertons' Asian presence and offer real estate advisory services, including agency sales, leasing, and investment advisory. The firm will serve clients in Singapore and Southeast Asia, capitalizing on growing property market demand in Indonesia and Vietnam.
