With its launch, RHT Chestertons seeks to create integrated wealth offerings for clients, leveraging its local knowledge and international network.

site_title: UOL's interest in UIC edges up to 49.78%
summary: UOL Group Limited has increased its interest in United Industrial Corporation (UIC) to 49.78% after purchasing 11.76 million shares at an average price of S$3.3072 per share. The acquisitions were made through UOL's wholly owned subsidiary and were aimed at consolidating its interest in UIC to achieve statutory control. The company stated that the acquisitions were in line with its objective to achieve control of UIC in the future.

site_title: Brokers' take: CIMB, UOB maintain 'buy' on continued promise of DBS's digital transformation
summary: Brokers UOB and CIMB have maintained a "buy" call on DBS due to its continued digital transformation and financial goals announced during its investor day. UOB raised its target price to S$26.10, while CIMB maintained its target price at S$25. DBS aims to achieve a return on equity of 13-14% in the next 3-5 years through digitalization efforts, with a focus on consumer and SME businesses. However, UOB warns that DBS may face competition from digital giants and a lack of physical distribution in growth markets.

site_title: EU ready for 'most ambitious' Brexit trade pact: Barnier
summary: EU Brexit chief Michel Barnier announced the EU is ready to offer Britain its "most ambitious" trade deal, but only if it meets the bloc's stringent Brexit conditions. The EU demands Britain make sufficient progress on key areas, including Northern Ireland and its Brexit bill, before moving on to talks on future relations. Barnier warned Britain that it must decide whether to stick to EU standards or align itself more closely with other countries, which would affect the ratification of any Brexit deal. The EU has set a deadline for Britain to make progress by December 14 for the trade talks phase to begin.

site_title: Oil holds above US$56 after surging on Saudi cut-extension plea
summary: Oil prices held above US$56 a barrel after surging 2.6% on Friday, driven by Saudi Arabia's energy minister's plea for Opec to extend supply cuts. The US drill-rig count remained steady, and inventories are unlikely to drain to average levels by the end of March. Analysts expect Opec to extend production cuts, with Saudi Arabia and Russia likely to be on board. Oil prices rose amid uncertainty over the timing of the decision, with Brent prices slipping 45 cents to $62.26 a barrel.

site_title: Thai Q3 GDP grows at best annual pace in years, despite soft domestic demand
summary: Thailand's third-quarter GDP growth reached 4.3% in the third quarter, its best annual pace in years, beating market expectations. Exports and tourism contributed to the growth, but domestic demand and infrastructure delays kept growth moderate. Economists say higher private investment and government spending are needed for sustainable growth. The National Economic and Social Development Board revised its 2017 growth forecast to 3.9% and forecast 2018's level at 3.6-4.6%.

site_title: James Murdoch said mulling future beyond Fox assets he built
summary: James Murdoch, CEO of 21st Century Fox, is considering a career reset after a surge in interest from potential acquirers. He may part ways with the company if Fox sells its entertainment businesses and keeps the news channel. Rupert Murdoch, James' father, is also contemplating selling major parts of the business to value its assets. The discussions come after scandals at Fox News, which has tarnished the company's reputation and impacted its takeover bid for Sky in the UK. Murdoch could consider joining Disney or Comcast in a management role or creating his own venture.

site_title: Lightning strikes MRT train; train captain receiving medical attention
summary: A Singapore MRT train on the East-West Line was struck by lightning, stalling near Bedok station. The train captain, in his 20s, received medical attention after suffering numbness and chest pains. The incident occurred during a thundery shower forecast by the National Environment Agency. The train is protected by a "Faraday Cage" that blocks electric fields and currents, minimizing the risk of injury to occupants. The train was withdrawn from service for investigation, with journey times delayed for at least 10 minutes.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Monday, down 3.3 points to 1,718.36, with a trading volume of 1.98 billion lots worth RM2.1 billion. Losers outpaced gainers 663 to 256.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's domestic wholesale trade grew 11.3% in Q3, slower than the previous two quarters. Nets plans to invest S$30m for a unified digital payments platform. Noble Group acquired a 49% stake in a rare earths project for £14m. Economists predict a possible GST hike in Budget 2018, while GIC invested in a Melbourne project. A survey found Singapore SMEs face cash-flow issues due to payment delays. Moody's expects steady earnings growth for Asian corporates in 2018.

site_title: German losses keep European shares flat as govt talks collapse
summary: Germany's main share index fell 0.2% on Monday after the collapse of government coalition talks, weighing on the broader European market. Despite this, pharma heavyweight Roche rose 3.7% after positive trial news, and utilities sector dealmaking kept the pan-European Stoxx 600 index flat. Other top gainers included RWE and Altice, while Elior and NEX Group fell. The Stoxx 600 benchmark is down 2.8% so far in November due to investors locking in profits, and Germany's political crisis may put more pressure on equities.

site_title: Honda to use Facebook to find owners with defective Takata airbags
summary: Honda plans to use Facebook's custom audiences tool to find car owners with defective Takata airbags. The tool will match encrypted email addresses associated with recalled vehicle identification numbers to Facebook users. This is in response to at least 18 deaths and 180 injuries linked to the airbag inflators, which can rupture and shoot metal fragments. The goal is to inform owners of the recall and facilitate repairs.

site_title: Budget in focus as sterling rises to 2-1/2 week highs
summary: Sterling rose to a 2-1/2 week high, reaching $1.3272, as investors viewed the weekend's Brexit news as mildly positive for the British pound. Britain will submit proposals on its divorce bill with the EU before an EU summit next month, with finance minister Philip Hammond promising to speed up house building and make some room for voters in the budget. This news provided a temporary boost to sterling, which scored gains against the euro and reduced short positions.

site_title: China's coal miners to keep contract prices for next year stable
summary: China's largest coal producers, China Energy Investment Group and China National Coal Group (ChinaCoal), will maintain 2018 coal contract prices at 535 yuan (S$109.38) per tonne, identical to 2017 levels. This decision was reached after discussions between policymakers, producers, and utilities, and will be announced at China's annual coal trade meeting on November 21. The move is seen as a disappointment to utilities, who had hoped for a price increase.

site_title: Holders of Ezion notes, perpetuals give approval for debt refinancing
summary: Holders of Ezion Holdings' notes and perpetuals have approved a debt refinancing proposal, with 93.5-98.82% of participants voting in favor. The proposal involves slashing coupon rates to 0.25% and offering two swap options to convert securities to shares or new notes. The move aims to raise over US$1 billion in loans, helping the company recover from a protracted offshore and marine downturn. The refinancing exercise is seen as crucial to Ezion's financial stability, with its success determining how far the company can ride out the downturn.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains to fourth day
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a fourth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.21% to 29,260.31. Shanghai and Shenzhen also saw gains, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.28% and the Shenzhen Composite Index up 0.90%. Investors appeared to brush off initial concerns about China's crackdown on risk-taking, with the rally attributed to a positive outlook and lack of major market-moving news.

site_title: Taiwan's strong Oct export orders set stage for record 2017
summary: Taiwan's export orders rose 9.2% in October, exceeding expectations and prompting the government to forecast a record-high export order value of $489.5 billion to $492.5 billion for 2017. Strong demand for tech gadgets, including Apple's new iPhones, drove the growth. This buoyant export performance is expected to support the government's upwardly revised 2.15% economic growth forecast, giving the central bank room to keep interest rates steady. November export orders are also expected to grow 7.7-10%.

site_title: Top palm oil growers go on defensive against EU curb threat
summary: Malaysian and Indonesian palm oil growers are defending their industry against a European Union (EU) resolution calling for tougher environmental standards. The EU's non-binding resolution, passed in April, aims to prevent deforestation due to palm oil production. Malaysia and Indonesia, the world's top palm oil producers, are concerned that stricter regulations could harm their exports and economies. Malaysian officials have met with European ambassadors and are preparing to retaliate if the resolution is implemented, while Indonesia's president has asked the EU to end discrimination against palm oil.

site_title: Financials drag down Australian shares; NZ up
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Monday, falling 0.19% or 11.554 points to 5,945.700, following a weak lead from Wall Street due to uncertainties over Republican tax reforms. The benchmark rose 0.2% on Friday, but its worst weekly performance since June. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.35% as healthcare and real estate stocks gained. Investors remain cautious ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's minutes, which are expected to reveal whether interest rates will be raised.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks reverse gains; won edges down
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index declined 0.25% on Tuesday, reversing earlier gains. The Korean won fell 0.62% against the US dollar, while bond yields decreased. Despite the decline, the KOSPI is up 25% so far this year, with a current price-to-earnings ratio of 12.10 and a dividend yield of 1.28%. Foreign demand remained subdued, and the US dollar has fallen 8.8% against the won this year.

site_title: GST hike announcement could be on the cards for Singapore Budget 2018: economists, tax specialists
summary: Singapore is likely to hike its Goods and Services Tax (GST) rate within the next few years, with economists and tax experts predicting an announcement in the 2018 budget. The government has already hinted at upcoming tax hikes in its February budget speech, citing growing expenditure needs, particularly in healthcare and infrastructure. A one percentage point hike in GST is expected to bring in S$1 billion per year in additional revenue, with analysts considering this a straightforward option given the tax's low rate of 7% compared to global averages.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte keeps open pit mining ban in policy clash
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has maintained a ban on open pit mining, despite recommendations from a government panel and the environment minister to lift the policy. The ban, implemented by former environment minister Regina Lopez, aims to prevent environmental degradation in mining areas. Duterte's spokesman, Harry Roque, stated that the President has not changed policy and will keep the ban in place, which could impact the development of major mining projects, including the US$5.9 billion Tampakan copper and gold mine.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has not lifted a ban on open pit mining, his spokesman said on Monday, going against the stance of a government panel and the environment minister who are seeking to reverse the policy.

site_title: Former Wimbledon champion Jana Novotna dies aged 49
summary: Former Wimbledon champion Jana Novotna has died at 49 after a long battle with cancer in the Czech Republic. She won the 1998 Wimbledon singles title and four doubles titles at the tournament. Novotna, who played in two other Wimbledon singles finals, was remembered by tennis stars Martina Navratilova, Pam Shriver, and Lucie Safarova as a kind, athletic, and competitive player. The WTA expressed condolences to her family, praising her as an inspiration both on and off the court.

site_title: Political crisis in Germany boosts safe-haven bonds
summary: Germany's 10-year bond yield fell to its lowest level in 1-1/2 weeks following talks to form a coalition government failing, raising the risk of fresh elections. The pro-business Free Democrats pulled out of negotiations with Chancellor Angela Merkel's conservative bloc, leaving Germany with two possible options: a minority government or a new election. The yield on Germany's benchmark 10-year bond dipped to 0.35%, while the euro fell to a two-month low against the yen and US dollar, weighing on risk sentiment in world markets. Merkel's weakened position raises potential leadership challenges.

site_title: Singapore's domestic wholesale trade growth eases again to 11.3% in Q3
summary: Singapore's domestic wholesale trade expanded by 11.3% in Q3, slowing from 18.5% in Q2 and 23.5% in Q1. Excluding petroleum, trade rose 2.7% year-over-year, but declined 0.9% quarter-over-quarter. Adjusting for price changes, overall trade rose 1.3% year-over-year but fell 5.6% quarter-over-quarter. Year-over-year growth was reported in various industries, but some, like household equipment and food, experienced declines.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower; Toshiba down on share issuance
summary: Tokyo stocks ended lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.60% due to a higher yen and Toshiba's share price dropping after the conglomerate announced plans to issue new shares. Toshiba's share price plunged, contributing to the decline in the benchmark index.

site_title: Bruno Mars wins American Music Awards on night of divas
summary: Bruno Mars won the top prize at the American Music Awards, taking home Artist of the Year for his album "24K Magic". The ceremony paid tribute to legendary divas Diana Ross and the late Whitney Houston, with Ross receiving a lifetime achievement award and Houston honored for her 25-year anniversary of "The Bodyguard". Performers included P!nk, who dangled off a 54-storey building, and Lady Gaga, who performed a choreographed routine with pyrotechnics. The awards highlighted the achievements of "earth-shattering women" and addressed the US's current tensions, with a call against violence and hate.

site_title: Trafigura creates US$470m structured financing product backed by commodity inventories
summary: Trafigura has created a US$470 million structured financing programme backed by commodity inventories. The programme will allow Trafigura to buy and sell crude oil and refined metal inventories across 12 jurisdictions, with the option to repurchase commodities early. This move enables Trafigura to become a systematic issuer of notes backed by commodity inventories, potentially seeking committed term financing in the asset-backed securities market. Six major banks, including DBS Bank, Natixis, and The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, are participating in the programme.

site_title: Singapore SMEs face cash-flow squeeze as more experience payment delays: survey
summary: Singapore SMEs face financial strain due to delayed customer payments, with 35% of businesses experiencing finance-related issues, up from 22% in 2016. Delays in payments from customers increased to 81% in 2017, along with higher interest rates for bank loans and suppliers tightening credit access. This can lead to cash flow and working capital problems. In contrast, concerns about manpower costs decreased to 70% and the proportion of SMEs having difficulties hiring staff decreased to 26%.

site_title: ST Aerospace wins 15-year contract from Gulf Air for B787 component support
summary: ST Aerospace has secured a 15-year contract with Gulf Air for component support of the airline's Boeing 787-9s. The agreement includes component maintenance-by-the-hour services, with deliveries starting in Q2 2018. The contract enables Gulf Air to maintain low operating costs while minimizing spare inventory. This is ST Aerospace's second contract with Gulf Air, following a similar agreement in 2013. The company provides component support for over 600 aircraft to 20 airlines across the Asia-Pacific, Europe, and Middle East.

site_title: Mom and Pop pile into Hong Kong IPOs in US$163b bonanza this year
summary: Hong Kong saw a surge in retail investor interest in initial public offerings (IPOs) this year, with $163 billion worth of equity placed in major deals, exceeding three-quarters of the territory's monetary base. This is the highest level since 2009. Small investors are jumping at the chance to buy into higher-growth industries like tech, with some deals seeing retail investors apply for 100 times the amount of stock initially offered. The improved sentiment is expected to boost next year's listings, with several companies, including Tencent, preparing to seek listings in Hong Kong.

site_title: Indonesia parliament speaker taken into custody by anti-graft agency
summary: Indonesia's parliament speaker, Setya Novanto, has been taken into custody by the country's anti-corruption agency, Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK), over his alleged role in causing state losses of $170 million linked to a national electronic identity card scheme. Novanto, who denied wrongdoing, had repeatedly missed summonses for questioning and claimed to be ill. He was transferred from a hospital to a KPK detention facility after a doctor's statement showed he no longer needed treatment for injuries sustained in a car crash.

site_title: Nets to invest over S$30m to launch unified digital payments platform
summary: Nets, a Singapore payment services group, plans to invest over S$30 million in the next three years to launch a unified digital payments platform. The platform will expand to over 100,000 acceptance points at 37,000 merchants nationwide, accessible to customers of seven major banks. Half of the investment will be used for infrastructure and setup costs, and the other half for marketing. The platform aims to simplify cashless payments by using a single QR code, waiving fees for hawkers for three years. The unified QR code platform was launched for DBS, OCBC, and UOB customers on Monday.

site_title: Singapore shares resume higher on Monday afternoon; STI at 3,384.53, up 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.1% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,384.53, driven by gains in DBS Group and Singtel. Losers outnumbered gainers 216 to 144, with about 1.24 billion shares changing hands. Key active stocks included Compact Metal Industries and Metal Component Engineering. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid a global stocks rally.

site_title: Drugmaker Roche announces trial successes in cancer, haemophilia
summary: Roche announced positive trial results for its immunotherapy Tecentriq, which showed a statistically significant and clinically meaningful reduction in the risk of disease worsening or death in the treatment of advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer. Additionally, data from the Hemlibra trial suggested the treatment could be used by more patients, indicating potential for expanded access. These trial successes come as Roche seeks to catch up with rivals in cancer immunotherapy, a significant market for the company.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific takes 45% stake in A$74.1m acquisition of Melbourne office building
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings has taken a 45% stake in a joint venture acquiring a Melbourne office building for A$74.1 million. The 1,906 square metre site in Southbank has a net lettable area of 9,854 sq m and is minutes from Melbourne's central business district. The deal, financed by internal funds and bank borrowings, requires approval from the Australian Treasurer. This acquisition marks Roxy-Pacific's second Australian asset, following the sale of an office building in Sydney.

site_title: Honda recalls 800,000 Odyssey Minivans linked to injuries
summary: Honda Motor Co is recalling approximately 800,000 Odyssey minivans in the US due to faulty passenger seats, which can tip forward during braking, potentially causing injury. The recall affects 2011-2017 models, and owners will receive free repairs starting in late December. This comes after Honda agreed to pay $484 million to settle Takata air-bag recall claims, with 20 million vehicles still awaiting repair.

site_title: Bitcoin soars past US$8,000 as technology shift concern vanishes
summary: Bitcoin surpassed US$8,000 for the first time, rising 4.8% to US$8,071.05, as investors overcame concerns about the technology behind the cryptocurrency. The surge marks a 700% increase in value this year, following a 29% tumble earlier this month. This is Bitcoin's third rally, following previous declines of more than 25%. The market shift suggests investor confidence in the cryptocurrency's long-term prospects.

site_title: Singapore shares lower at Monday break; STI falls 0.1% to 3,379.95
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.1% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index falling to 3,379.95. Approximately 1.21 billion shares worth S$469 million changed hands, with Compact Metal Industries being the most actively traded. The rally in stocks that began 5 days ago appears to be slowing, as losers outnumbered gainers 221 to 138.

site_title: IPC's plans to sell hotel, acquire robot maker fall through
summary: IPC Corp's plans to sell its Grand Nest Hotel in China and acquire a 51% stake in Beijing iJourney Technology Developement Co, a maker of butler robots, have fallen through after preliminary agreements lapsed. The deals, announced in September, were worth about 200 million yuan and US$5.1 million, respectively. The company did not provide reasons for the lapse, stating it would not have a material impact on its business operations and financial position. As a result, IPC shares were trading lower at S$0.42.

site_title: China: Shares slide on sweeping asset management rules
summary: China's stock market plummeted, with Shanghai's benchmark index tumbling over 1% and the CSI300 Index down roughly 1%, marking its worst day since mid-August. The drop was attributed to sweeping new guidelines issued by the central bank to regulate asset management products, which analysts said will dampen investors' appetite for riskier assets and curb money flows into the stock market. The new rules, set to take effect by June 30, 2019, aim to rein in the shadow banking sector and unify rules covering asset management products issued by all types of financial institutions.

site_title: Alibaba to pay US$2.9b in joint pact for hypermarket operator Sun Art stake
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd agreed to acquire a 36% stake in Sun Art Retail Group Ltd, China's largest operator of Walmart-style hypermarkets, for about $2.9 billion. As part of the deal, Auchan Retail SA will also increase its stake to 36%. The alliance reflects Alibaba's "New Retail" vision to combine online and offline experiences, with Alibaba investing in Sun Art to shore up its bottom line and boost revenue growth. The deal marks Alibaba's latest move to shake up China's $4 trillion retail market and deepen its lead over Amazon.com Inc.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank governor says ringgit not fairly valued
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor, Muhammad Ibrahim, stated that the ringgit currency is "far from reflecting its fair value." The ringgit has been trading at its highest in over a year against the US dollar, following a sharp selloff in 2016. Ibrahim announced new measures to boost liquidity in the onshore ringgit market, including expanding eligible collateral and introducing new bills. He emphasized that market forces should dictate the exchange rate and urged domestic traders to play a bigger role, but did not elaborate on what he meant by "illegal."

site_title: Carey Island port project to go on as planned, Malaysia minister says
summary: Malaysian Transport Minister Liow Tiong Lai confirmed that the Carey Island port project will proceed as planned, despite reports of it being put on hold. The mega port project aims to increase container throughput by 30 million 20-foot equivalent units (TEU) and will be a port city, with an estimated RM200 billion (S$65.3 billion) in infrastructure investments. Liow attributed the misinformation to "those who spread lies and fake news" with an ulterior motive.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.19% on Monday, building on last week's gains, to 29,255.25. The advance was limited by profit-taking and a negative lead from Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: PUB starts second phase of DTSS with S$2.3b of work contracted out
summary: Singapore's national water agency PUB has begun the second phase of the Deep Tunnel Sewerage System (DTSS) with S$2.3 billion in contracts. The phase, expected to be completed by 2025, will extend the system to cover the western part of Singapore, including downtown areas and major developments. The tunnels will connect to existing systems, creating an integrated network, and will convey used water to three centralized treatment plants before producing NEWater. The project aims to reduce land taken up by used water infrastructure by 50%.

site_title: Asian corporates set to see steady earnings growth in 2018: Moody's
summary: Moody's predicts steady earnings growth for Asian corporates in 2018, driven by healthy economic expansion and corporate earnings growth. The credit ratings agency expects stable outlooks for key sectors such as Chinese property, oil refining, steel, telecommunications, and power markets. However, Moody's notes downside risks including US trade policy, regional trade tensions, and China's decelerating growth. Upside risks include China's growth acceleration and better-than-expected growth in the US and European Union economies.

images.alt_text: Moody's has indicated stable outlooks for key sectors in the region - the Chinese property market, oil refining and marketing, steel, telecomunications, and the power market.

site_title: What's left for Noble Group creditors: The answer's in Jamaica
summary: Noble Group Ltd. is set to hold crisis talks with bondholders to restructure US$3.5 billion in debt. The company's remaining valuable asset, the Jamaican alumina plant Jamalco, is generating cash due to a 50% surge in alumina prices, making it an attractive asset for creditors. According to consultant Jean-Francois Lambert, Jamalco is likely to attract interest and is one of the few remaining assets, as the bulk of the company's good assets have been sold.

site_title: Subways may be the latest casualty of China's debt crackdown
summary: China's frenzied construction of subway systems may be easing amid reports of funding pulled for some projects as Beijing pushes to rein in debt levels. The National Development and Reform Commission is revising a 2003 policy on subway development, requiring cities to scrutinize population levels, economy, and fiscal conditions before approving projects. Fixed-asset investment in rail transportation has slowed to a standstill, with private rail transport investment slumping 58.6% from a year earlier, as China's leaders prioritize reining in financial risks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.66 points to 1,723.32 on Monday, with 127 gainers outpacing 61 losers. The country's shares opened higher as volume reached 136.54 million lots worth RM31.55 million.

site_title: Asia: Markets kick week off with losses as euro sinks
summary: Asian markets declined on Monday, with Tokyo down 0.6%, Hong Kong and Sydney each shedding 0.2%, and Shanghai plummeting over 1% due to a crackdown on the wealth management industry. The euro fell after German Chancellor Angela Merkel failed to form a government, sparking fears of a crisis that could lead to fresh elections. US lawmakers struggle to pass tax-cut plans, despite a House of Representatives approval and a Senate panel clearance.

site_title: Goldman Sachs sees Fed raising rates four times in 2018
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates four times in 2018 due to a tight US labor market and normal inflation. This exceeds Wall Street's expectations of three rate hikes. The economists attribute the strong growth momentum to reconstruction following US hurricanes and proposed tax cuts, raising their GDP growth forecast to 2.5% and unemployment rate forecast to 3.5% by 2019.

site_title: Beijing orders safety checks after apartment block fire kills 19
summary: A fire in a Beijing apartment block killed 19 people and injured eight, prompting authorities to order city-wide safety checks. A probe into the cause is underway, with preliminary findings suggesting a refrigeration facility in the basement likely started the blaze. Beijing's Communist Party boss Cai Qi ordered the checks, emphasizing the need to protect people's lives and safeguard the capital's safety and stability. The incident has raised pressure on policymakers, with China's GDP growth expected to slow.

site_title: Chinese buyers go cool on Australia homes
summary: Chinese demand for Australian residential property has eased due to tighter capital controls and mortgage lending restrictions in China and Australia, respectively. According to the Reserve Bank of Australia, foreign buyers, mainly from China, accounted for 10-15% of new construction and 5% of total housing sales. The easing of foreign demand may drive the expansion of new supply, but also raises concerns about the risk of a sharp correction in commercial property prices. Australian banks have tightened lending standards, leading to increased market share for Asian banks.

site_title: Australia shares fall, weighed by financials; NZ up
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% on Monday, weighed down by banking stocks, amid uncertainty over US tax reforms. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 14.354 points to 5,942.900. Financial stocks, particularly Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd and Commonwealth Bank of Australia, led the losses. In contrast, CSL Ltd rose 0.7% to its highest since November 13, and Santos Ltd rose 2.2%.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks steady; won edges up against US dollar
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 2.97 points or 0.12% to 2,536.96 at 0109 GMT on Monday. The Korean won edged up against the US dollar, quoted at 1,095.9 per dollar. Bond yields fell, and foreign investors bought 62.64 billion won worth of shares. The KOSPI is up 25.0% so far this year, with the market capitalization at 1,242.04 trillion won.

site_title: Brexit may shock UK companies into fixing productivity malaise
summary: Britain's productivity malaise may be alleviated by the country's exit from the European Union, according to UBS Wealth Management economist Dean Turner. With tougher immigration rules, companies may invest in technology and machinery to improve productivity, rather than relying on an unlimited supply of EU labor. However, this change would likely occur slowly and only offset the potential negative effects of Brexit, such as reduced trade and foreign investment. The UK's economy is already struggling to keep pace with international peers, and the need for a productivity solution is becoming more acute.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened unchanged on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.08 points to 3,382.46. Around 86 million shares worth S$91 million changed hands, with Compact Metal Industries being the most actively traded. Regional markets were pressured by Wall Street's retreat and German coalition talks, with Australian and Japanese shares down 0.2% and 0.1% respectively.

site_title: UK households feel the pinch as budget nears, Christmas sales seen down
summary: UK households face financial pressure as a survey by IHS Markit shows a decline in their finances, with the Household Finance Index falling to 43.4 in November. Credit card firm Visa predicts a 0.1% fall in spending during the Christmas holidays, the first annual decline since 2012. The UK's finance minister, Philip Hammond, is under pressure to address the issue in this week's budget. A report by university academics found that inflation due to the Brexit vote costs the average worker 448 pounds per year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble Group, Tee International and Advancer Global
summary: Noble Group announced its green tech subsidiary Talaxis is acquiring a 49% stake in Toronto-listed Mkango Resources' rare earths projects for £14 million. TEE International and Advancer Global Limited are acquiring privately held waste management provider Chiang Kiong Environmental for S$18.5 million, with TEE holding 50.1% and Advancer Global holding 20.1%. These deals are among the stocks to watch on Monday morning trading.

site_title: GIC takes majority stake in new innovation precinct next to University of Melbourne
summary: GIC, a Singapore sovereign wealth fund, has taken a majority stake in a new innovation precinct adjacent to the University of Melbourne in Australia. The precinct, developed by Lendlease, will be majority leased to the university for 42 years and features a unique blend of educational and commercial spaces. GIC believes the project will generate long-term, resilient cash flows, aligning with the global trend of innovation hubs near universities. The precinct is set to be completed by 2026, with access to Melbourne's central business district via tram and the proposed Melbourne Metro.

images.alt_text: Developed by Lendlease, the "innovation precinct" will be majority pre-leased to the University of Melbourne for 42 years.

site_title: Artists find their voice in Turkey's 'difficult' climate
summary: Turkish artists are finding innovative ways to address censorship and political turbulence in the country, despite government repression and purges. This year's Istanbul Biennial, the country's most important contemporary art event, featured works tackling topics such as the refugee crisis and conflicts in Syria, as well as the current situation in Turkey. Artists have been defying government restrictions and self-censoring, with some even leaving the country. Despite the challenges, many artists remain optimistic and are using their work to promote resilience and freedom of expression.

site_title: Toshiba seeks 600b yen in share sale to avoid delisting
summary: Toshiba plans to raise 600 billion yen ($7.27 billion) by selling new shares to avoid being delisted from the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The company aims to eliminate its negative shareholders' equity by the end of its fiscal year in March. Toshiba has agreed to sell its memory-chip unit to raise funds, but faces complications from legal action from Western Digital. The company expects the sale to close by December 5 and will use the capital to settle obligations to Westinghouse creditors.

site_title: Mugabe clings to office, dashes resignation hopes in TV speech
summary: Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe clung to power on Sunday, delivering a TV speech that suggested he would not resign despite a military takeover and mounting pressure for his 37-year rule to end. In the speech, Mugabe stated he would preside over the party congress and implied he would seek to stay in office until mid-December, sparking widespread anger and concern for a violent reaction. The ruling ZANU-PF party sacked Mugabe as its leader and warned of impeachment proceedings, but his defiant speech has left the country in deep uncertainty.

site_title: Japan's export growth signals economic recovery to continue in Q4
summary: Japan's export growth held steady in October, with a 14.0% year-on-year increase, driven by strong demand for cars and electronics. The growth signals an ongoing economic recovery, expected to continue into the fourth quarter. Analysts attribute the growth to brisk demand for electronics parts, infrastructure investment in China, and progress on tax cuts in the US. Japan's trade surplus with the US rose 11.3% in October, despite President Trump's demand for bilateral trade talks.

site_title: China's subways 'are next on crackdown list'
summary: China is scaling back its subway construction projects amid efforts to rein in debt levels and slow the frenzied construction boom. Funding for some projects has been pulled, and the National Development and Reform Commission is revising a 2003 policy to scrutinize population levels, economy, and fiscal conditions before approving local rail projects. This marks a reversal from the country's previous focus on infrastructure growth, which has led to a significant increase in debt levels and concerns over financial risks.

site_title: London's iconic red buses to run on biofuel made from old coffee
summary: London's iconic red double-decker buses will run on a biofuel made from 20% old coffee grounds, starting from a demonstration project by Bio-bean Ltd and Royal Dutch Shell plc. The fuel, produced from 6,000 litres annually, will be supplied by coffee shops across the UK and converted into biodiesel at a factory in Cambridgeshire. The UK produces 500,000 tonnes of used coffee grounds annually, and Bio-bean plans to expand throughout the UK and eventually to continental Europe and the US.

images.alt_text: London's iconic red double-decker buses will soon run on a biofuel partially made from old coffee grounds.

site_title: New Zealand service activity slows in October: BNZ
summary: New Zealand's services sector experienced a slowdown in October, with the Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ's seasonally adjusted performance of services index (PSI) dropping 0.3 points to 55.6. The drop was attributed to uncertainty surrounding the country's election results and coalition negotiations. This marked a reversal from the previous month, which saw a reading above 50 indicating expansion in activity.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as Toshiba drops on share issuance
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, following declines on Wall Street, with Toshiba plummeting after announcing a share issuance. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.45% to 22,296.00, while the Topix declined 0.40% to 1,756.77. This downward trend was likely influenced by global market fluctuations.

site_title: German coalition talks collapse as pro-business FDP quits
summary: German coalition talks collapsed as the pro-business FDP party walked out, ending Chancellor Angela Merkel's bid to form a new government. The FDP, led by Christian Lindner, cited a lack of trust and concerns over the government's performance. This collapse plunges Germany into a political crisis, potentially ending Merkel's career. The FDP's decision leaves the country without a government, raising questions about Merkel's future and the stability of the European economy.

site_title: TEE, Advancer Global and investor to acquire waste management provider for S$18.5m
summary: TEE International, Advancer Global, and a financial investor are acquiring privately held waste management provider Chiang Kiong Environmental for S$18.5 million. The joint venture will be led by TEE, holding 50.1% stake, Advancer Global holding 20.1%, and an independent investor holding 29.8%. The acquisition is expected to be completed by Dec 29, 2017, and will see the joint venture acquire Chiang Kiong's subsidiaries, expanding its business in the industrial and commercial environmental service space.

site_title: Noble unit to acquire 49% stake in rare earths project for £14m
summary: NOBLE Group's green tech subsidiary Talaxis acquired a 49% stake in Toronto-listed Mkango Resources' rare earths project in Malawi for £14m. Talaxis plans to invest £12m in Lancaster Exploration and £2m in a new company to develop new rare earth alloy powders and magnet technologies. The deal aims to strengthen Talaxis' supply chain in the tech metal products sector amid the global push to decarbonize the economy.

site_title: ETC majority shareholder calls for EGM to replace independent directors
summary: A majority shareholder of Emerging Towns & Cities Singapore (ETC) has called for a shareholders' meeting to replace two independent directors, Christopher Chong Meng Tak and Peter Tan, with his own nominees, Shasha (Liang) Du and Wang Guang. The move comes amid a dispute over unauthorized transfers of 118 million yuan from a Chinese subsidiary, with ETC owing the shareholder 164 million yuan. The company has suspended stock trading and is seeking advice on the requisition notice. The shareholders' meeting will decide on the replacement of the directors.

site_title: With little movement, Nafta talks said to run risk of stalemate
summary: US-Canada-Mexico talks to update the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) appear stalled, with little progress made amid complaints of US negotiators' inflexibility. The talks, which started in October, are set to conclude before Mexico's presidential elections in March 2018. Canada and Mexico object to US demands, including a five-year sunset clause and stricter automotive content rules. The US has shown some flexibility, but a deal remains uncertain, with the threat of the US scrapping Nafta hanging over the negotiations.

site_title: Gold leaf from Napoleon's crown fetches 625,000 euros
summary: A gold laurel leaf removed from Napoleon Bonaparte's coronation crown sold for 625,000 euros at an auction in Paris, exceeding the estimated price of 100,000-150,000 euros. The leaf, one of six cut from the crown, was given to a goldsmith's daughter and later passed down through the family. The sale price is triple that of a similar leaf worn during the coronation, which sold for 80,000 francs in the 1980s. The auction, held at Osenat auction house, also featured 400 works dedicated to Napoleon, including items made by goldsmith Martin Guillaume Biennais.

site_title: Saudi Aramco shuts Jeddah refinery indefinitely: sources
summary: Saudi Aramco has shut down its 90,000 barrel per day Jeddah refinery indefinitely due to age and environmental concerns. The refinery, which operated since 1967, supplied the western region of Saudi Arabia and its closure will increase demand at other facilities. The shutdown is expected to have minimal impact on oil product availability in Saudi Arabia, as Aramco will meet demand from other refineries. A new, 400,000 bpd refinery in Jizan province is expected to be completed by the end of this year.

site_title: Bumper profits, government pressure to drive Asia's dividend bonanza
summary: Asia's dividend payouts are expected to increase by 12% year-on-year in 2017, the largest increase in six years, driven by strong corporate profits and government pressure on companies to be more generous with shareholders. Technology companies and those in the consumer products sector are expected to lead the growth, with companies like Taiwan Semiconductor and Samsung Electronics announcing record profits and higher dividends. Analysts predict earnings growth will stay strong into 2018 and 2019, with Asian stock markets potentially rallying beyond current multi-year highs.

site_title: It's never wise to bet against a Saudi oil minister
summary: Opec and its allies are expected to extend their output restraint at their meeting on November 30, despite apparent dissent from some members. The decision will likely send oil prices higher, as speculative long positions in Brent crude have already been fully priced in. Saudi Oil Minister Khalid Al-Falih has expressed confidence in a clear decision, including an extension, and believes Russia will be on board. The extension is seen as a necessary move to prevent a repeat of the disappointment seen in May when Opec and friends failed to extend cuts.

site_title: Riding on good location to develop ports and more
summary: Oman's ports, particularly Salalah and Sohar, have developed into well-integrated logistics hubs with excellent locations on East-West trade routes. The Port of Salalah has expanded its capacity and is now the region's best-located port for serving the Middle East, Indian subcontinent, and East Africa markets. Sohar Port has also grown rapidly, with a 15% rise in port calls expected for the full year, and is leveraging its joint venture with the Port of Rotterdam to build itself up as an industrial port. Both ports offer seamless connections between sea and air logistics and are well-positioned for future growth.

site_title: US industry gears up to salvage Nafta talks
summary: US business leaders are urging the Trump administration to save the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) amid concerns that withdrawing from the treaty could devastate American agriculture and lead to significant job losses. Corporate groups, including the US Chamber of Commerce, have launched a campaign to convince lawmakers to preserve Nafta, citing its benefits to the US economy, including a $64 billion trade gap with Mexico and loss of jobs. Despite President Trump's denouncement of the agreement, many Americans believe Nafta has benefited the US, with a recent opinion poll showing 56% of Americans agree.

site_title: Oman calls for peaceful co-existence
summary: Oman emphasizes the importance of peaceful coexistence, adhering to internationally accepted principles and values. The country advocates for resolving disputes through peaceful means, supporting efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East, and reiterating the need for the UN to play a strong role in protecting humanity from conflicts. Oman also condemns all forms of terrorism and reaffirms its support for sustainable development and cooperation.

site_title: Russia's SWF eyes more tie-ups with Singapore investors
summary: Russia's sovereign wealth fund, the Russian Direct Investment Fund (RDIF), is seeking more partnerships with Singapore investors. With $40 billion under management, RDIF has over 20 major partnerships, including a deal with China Investment Corporation to invest $2 billion in Russia. RDIF CEO Kirill Dmitriev is on a mission to attract strategic partners to invest in Russia, focusing on sectors such as agriculture, technology, and infrastructure. He cited the successful partnership with Changi Airports International as an example, and is in talks with Olam International to finalize an agreement.

site_title: Merkel struggles to avert coalition talks collapse
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel is struggling to form a coalition government in Germany, with talks between her conservative CDU party and pro-business FDP, as well as left-wing Greens, failing to yield a breakthrough. The talks, which began after September's elections, are being hindered by disagreements over immigration policy, particularly the number of asylum seekers allowed to enter the country. If talks collapse, Germany risks returning to the polls in 2018, potentially ending Merkel's 12-year chancellorship.

site_title: Chaswood Resources says Malaysian unit in debt restructuring talks
summary: Chaswood Resources Holdings' Malaysian subsidiary, Chaswood Resources Sdn Bhd, has initiated debt restructuring talks with CIMB Bank, Malayan Banking, and AmBank over RM22 million in credit facilities. The talks are ongoing, and the unit will temporarily cease repayment on all borrowings. The restructuring aims to reschedule loan repayments, but the outcome is uncertain.

images.alt_text: Under the proposed debt restructuring, the unit, Chaswood Resources Sdn Bhd (CSRB), is holding discussions with its principal lenders - CIMB Bank Berhad, Malayan Banking Berhad and AmBank (M) Berhad, including the restructuring and rescheduling of loan repayments.

site_title: Restructuring - the time for traditional retail to reinvent and survive
summary: The retail industry is facing a bleak future due to the rise of Amazon and other e-commerce threats. However, a historical parallel with the airline industry suggests that restructuring can lead to survival and even record profits. Airlines underwent significant restructuring in the 2000s, merging, writing off debts, and renegotiating contracts, which allowed them to thrive. Retailers must follow a similar path, focusing on shareholder returns, reducing capacity, and adapting to changing consumer habits. The industry is expected to undergo significant changes, with some stores closing and others being refreshed, particularly in second- and third-tier communities.

site_title: Towards domestic development and closer bilateral ties
summary: Oman celebrated its 47th National Day on November 18, 2017, marking significant domestic development milestones in education, health, infrastructure, and more. Despite the slump in oil prices, Oman's financial position remains stable, and the government continues to implement developmental programs, including the "Tanfeedh" program, to diversify its economy. Oman and Singapore have strengthened bilateral ties, sharing similarities and values in trade, education, culture, tourism, and investment, with a focus on close cooperation and growth.

site_title: Europe turns on Facebook, Google and other US tech titans for digital tax revamp
summary: EU leaders are pushing for a digital tax overhaul, targeting US tech giants such as Google, Facebook, and Apple for their low tax payments. The current tax rules are seen as outdated for today's digital economy, where companies like these giants have a significant presence in Europe but pay minimal tax. EU leaders propose taxing these companies on sales generated in each European country, rather than on profits cycled through low-tax countries. The European Commission also plans to propose a reform of international tax rules, including the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base, to address the digital shortfall.

site_title: Singapore's fintech dive now delves for proof beyond concept
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is pushing for the adoption of blockchain technology in trade finance, aiming to create a global trade connectivity network (GTCN) with Hong Kong. The partnership, announced during the Singapore FinTech Festival, could set new global standards for the trillion-dollar industry. The initiative aims to digitize documents and bring about significant savings, but regulatory coordination and risks of fraud must be addressed. MAS plans to roll out the GTCN in early 2019, with other central banks, including China, ASEAN, and Japan, as target markets.

images.alt_text: MAS also plans to expand on an inter-bank payments pilot with the Bank of Canada to create a cross-border payments system between two countries that is powered by blockchain technology. The "killer app" is to go cross-border, according to MAS managing director Ravi Menon.

site_title: Mayfair Gardens sold en bloc for S$311 million
summary: Oxley Holdings' subsidiary, Citrine Property, sold Mayfair Gardens in Singapore en bloc for S$311 million, with an estimated land price of S$1,244 per square foot per plot ratio. The sale price translates to a gross sale price of around S$1.7 million to S$2.89 million per unit for 105 of the 124 units. The deal was funded by internal resources and bank borrowings, with Oxley Holdings' shares closing at S$0.67 on Friday.

site_title: Breaking boundaries in the WWE
summary: Asuka, a 36-year-old Japanese professional wrestler, has made history as the first female Japanese wrestler to be signed to WWE in over 20 years. She recently left NXT to join the main roster, having held the NXT Women's Championship title for 523 days. Asuka credits her skills and determination for her success, stating she was forced to adjust to matches with male wrestlers due to the lack of female competitors in Japan. She made her WWE main roster debut, defeating Emma, and is now set on winning the Raw Women's championship.

site_title: Australia's carsales.com to take control of S.Korean JV for US$184m
summary: Carsales.com Ltd has signed a deal to buy the remaining 50.1% stake in South Korean joint venture Encar.com for approximately A$244 million (S$250.1 million), following a 2014 purchase of 49.9%. The acquisition is expected to be completed in January, with an anticipated one-off non-cash gain of A$100 million. The deal is seen as a significant milestone in carsales' long-term strategy to become a global online auto classifieds leader. The company expects the deal to be neutral to adjusted earnings in fiscal 2018 and accretive in fiscal 2019 and beyond.

site_title: EU-Mercosur free trade pact supporters push for deal by year-end
summary: EU-Mercosur free trade pact supporters aim to finalize the deal by the end of 2017, despite stalled negotiations due to Brazil and Argentina's slow progress. The deal, worth four times as much as the EU's agreement with Japan, would be a significant victory for supporters of multilateral trade deals. EU officials, including Vice-President Jyrki Katainen, are optimistic about reaching a preliminary agreement, while Argentina's former foreign minister Susana Malcorra hopes the EU and Mercosur will seal a deal before the World Trade Organization's ministerial meeting in December.

site_title: Big bricks-and-mortar stores say it with earnings: we're not penny stocks
summary: US stocks fell slightly last week, but the retail sector showed resilience heading into the holiday shopping season. Major indexes may hit new record highs if the retail renaissance continues and Congress passes tax legislation. Wal-Mart Stores reported record growth, with shares of chains like JC Penney and Sears Holding recovering from "penny stock" status. Abercrombie & Fitch also reported a sales increase, and foot traffic at Wal-Mart's stores helped the company record its most pronounced growth in almost a decade.

site_title: GE shares lure buyers but worst may not be over
summary: GE shares stabilize after a 40% decline this year, but investors remain cautious due to reduced profit growth prospects and a halved dividend. Some investors see value in the company's assets, but a sufficient margin of safety is needed, with many expecting a short-term decline before potential long-term gains. The stock trades at a discount to rivals, but a return to comparable valuation levels may take time, with one portfolio manager calling GE a "tarnished blue-chip stock."

site_title: Women are breaching Big Oil's business model, especially in Asia
summary: Women are increasingly breaching the traditional male-dominated business model of the oil industry, particularly in Asia. Despite being underrepresented, women like Ryu Bok Young are pioneering in the industry, with companies like SK Innovation and Showa Shell Sekiyu focusing on hiring and retaining more female workers. The industry recognizes the benefits of diversity, with 61% of respondents in an Ernst & Young Global survey citing that gender diversity impacts financial performance. Companies are also adapting to the changing landscape, with some investing in daycare facilities and flexible work arrangements to attract and retain women, who make up only 22% of the global workforce in oil and gas.

site_title: Zimbabwe's ruling party expels Mugabe and wife
summary: Zimbabwe's ruling ZANU-PF party has expelled President Robert Mugabe and his wife Grace, forcing him to step down after a de facto military coup. Deputy Emmerson Mnangagwa has taken over as the new leader, and an interim unity government will focus on rebuilding ties with the outside world and stabilizing the economy. The move comes after months of growing pressure on Mugabe, who has ruled for 37 years. The expulsion is seen as a peaceful transition, with hundreds of thousands of people celebrating on the streets of Harare.

site_title: Serial System taps opportunities from digital to durians
summary: Serial System Ltd, a Singapore-based electronics components distributor, has achieved remarkable growth under CEO Derek Goh's leadership, with a compounded annual growth rate of 26% over the past 16 years. The company has expanded its operations, diversified its product range, and increased its customer base. Despite facing challenges, Serial has maintained a strong focus on discipline and has set ambitious targets, aiming to reach US$5-10 billion in revenues over the next decade. The company's diversification into new markets, such as hospitality and healthcare solutions, and its entry into the durian puree market, are expected to drive growth and increase income streams.

site_title: Singapore's largest cycling event continues to gain traction
summary: Singapore's OCBC Cycle 2017, its largest cycling festival, drew over 6,500 participants in its third year, with 2,600 riders taking part in the mass participation categories. The event featured competitive and non-competitive rides, including a superhero-themed ride and a corporate bike ride, which raised over $140,000 for beneficiaries such as the Today Enable Fund and SportCares. The event showcased the city-state's growing cycling culture and highlighted the importance of corporate social responsibility initiatives.

site_title: Driverless, electric future just round the corner for urban cars
summary: A driverless, electric car future is emerging in urban areas, with pollution clampdowns and technological advancements driving change. Hybrid cars, fully electric motors, and partially autonomous vehicles are already on the streets. Cities are shifting away from car-focused grid-plans, with car ownership no longer associated with prosperity. Electric vehicles are expected to dominate the market, with countries like Britain, France, and India planning to ban petrol and diesel cars. Driverless technology could ease gridlock and reduce traffic, with autonomous vehicles set to be on the roads by 2021.

site_title: k1 Ventures completes divestment of interests in Guggenheim Capital; to suspend trading of shares on SGX
summary: k1 Ventures completes divestment of its entire interests in Guggenheim Capital for approximately US$221 million. The company will suspend trading of shares on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) starting Nov 20 to avoid market speculation. After distributing excess cash to shareholders, k1 Ventures will take steps to commence voluntary liquidation.

site_title: Victoria's Secret to charm China with fashion gala
summary: Victoria's Secret is hosting its first lingerie show outside the US or Europe in Shanghai, China, marking a significant move into the growing Chinese market. The event aims to boost the company's sagging business performance, which has been affected by US competition and a product realignment. The show will feature six Chinese models, including top model Liu Wen, and will air globally on November 28. Despite the splashy debut, Victoria's Secret may face stiff competition from established domestic and foreign brands in the Chinese market, where growth rates are expected to slow to 4.4% by 2020.

site_title: Local bourse may enjoy 'Thanksgiving rally'
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index may experience a "Thanksgiving rally" as the local bourse seeks to rebound after a 1.1% loss the previous week. The rally could be influenced by US key stock indices, which declined last Friday, and the upcoming decision on Opec production cuts. Despite a slowing China and commodity-related uncertainty, global economic strength and a bullish trend in earnings season may provide optimism. A third-quarter GDP report and jobless data from the US will be closely watched, with some predicting a December rate hike from the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Improving public transport a priority: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the government's commitment to improving Singapore's public transport system, despite recent disruptions. He acknowledged the need for major investments, including upgrades to the North-South Line and the High Speed Rail, and stated that taxes will be raised as spending needs grow. Lee also stressed the importance of addressing technical issues, strengthening organizations, and maintaining morale. The government aims to maintain a "first-class transport system" with high reliability, comparable to other cities worldwide, and has pledged to complete ongoing projects, including the MRT lines and the megaport in Tuas.

site_title: Holyfield tries to find the next real deal
summary: Former four-time heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield is attempting to make a name for himself as a boxing promoter, utilizing the qualities that led to his success in the ring, including determination and self-reliance. Holyfield's promotional company, the Real Deal Boxing, held its fourth card at Resorts World Casino, featuring fighters such as Duke Micah and Edgar Berlanga, with about 2,000 attendees. While the company is still in its infancy, Holyfield aims to build a brand and attract a larger audience, offering financial counseling, medical staff, and victory bonuses to fighters.

site_title: S'pore's GDP growth may exceed 3% for 2017, productivity up: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to expand by more than 3% in 2017, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The official growth forecast is 2-3%, but private-sector economists have raised the figure. The country's productivity is also expected to improve, with a focus on becoming a global hub for advanced chip packaging.

site_title: Food delivery app war on the boil
summary: The food delivery app war in Singapore is intensifying with Deliveroo, Foodpanda, and UberEATS competing for market share. The three companies have received millions of dollars in funding but also recorded significant losses as they invest in promotions, technologies, and real estate. Despite the losses, the companies are focusing on customer acquisition and expanding their services, including 24/7 delivery and drone deliveries. Logistics remains a major challenge, with Deliveroo recruiting 3,000 additional riders and Foodpanda facing a finite supply of riders due to stringent work pass regulations.

images.alt_text: Deliveroo Singapore in 2016 recorded a net loss of S$16.86 million, according to BizFile data.

site_title: How sustainable are No Signboard's profits?
summary: No Signboard, a Singaporean restaurant chain, is set to go public with an initial public offering (IPO) amid declining customer visits and poor reviews. Despite fewer customers, the chain remains profitable. This IPO will compare No Signboard's performance to its listed competitor, Jumbo Group. The company's ability to maintain profitability despite declining sales raises questions about its sustainability and the future of the restaurant industry.

site_title: Wooing back share investors
summary: Singapore stock market aims to attract investors back with various strategies, including enhancing public awareness of the equity capital market, leveraging technology to reduce listing costs, and promoting growth in trading volumes. Experts suggest that the exchange needs to differentiate itself from competitors, increase liquidity, and provide investors with more options for investments and portfolio diversification. Reinstating the lunch break is seen as a positive signal, but a short-term solution, and more significant changes are needed to attract and retain investors. The exchange must focus on showcasing the capabilities of Singapore companies in current and developing technologies, improve human resources management, and boost tourism to attract more investors.

site_title: Rising investments from Singapore companies
summary: Singapore companies have invested significantly in Oman over the past two years, with partnerships and joint ventures in various sectors. ViewQwest launched broadband services in Oman, while CrimsonLogic assisted the Sultanate in its digital government transformation. SATS formed a joint venture with Oman Air for cargo handling, and Hyflux built a US$250 million desalination plant in Qurayyat. These investments aim to support Oman's National Broadband Strategy and Vision 2020.

site_title: CapitaLand matches its charity work with the kind of work it does best
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based property company, has matched its charity work with its business capabilities, focusing on education, healthcare, and shelter needs of underprivileged children in communities where it operates. The company's philanthropic efforts, such as the CapitaLand Hope Foundation and the CapitaLand Young Architect Programme, aim to leverage its expertise and resources to make a positive impact. By aligning its charitable work with its business goals, CapitaLand aims to create sustainable and multiplier effects, as evident in its annual sustainability report and volunteer programs, which have received support from senior management and employees.

site_title: Planting the Capella flag in Asia, one city at a time
summary: Capella Hotel Group, owned by Singapore's Kwee family, is expanding its Asia-Pacific presence with multiple new hotels set to open in the next 18-36 months. CEO Nicholas Clayton aims to establish the brand as a sought-after luxury hotel group, with a focus on cities like Beijing, Hangzhou, and Bangkok. The company is also considering markets in the Philippines, Laos, Cambodia, and Vietnam, with a goal of having 25 hotels under the Capella brand in the next decade. Clayton emphasizes the importance of a consistently high standard of service across all hotels.

images.alt_text: Aerial view of the five-star Capella Singapore resort on Sentosa Island. After more than eight years of having just that one Capella hotel in all of Asia, the group now wants to grow its regional footprint.
"There are so many opportunities for us to look at right now. Growth is what we're all about today. We're certainly not anywhere near a mature company," says Mr Clayton.

site_title: NY flats stay empty even as homelessness rate rises
summary: New York City's affordable housing crisis persists despite a stagnant homelessness rate, with over 62,000 people sleeping in shelters each night. A study found a 22% increase in families with children entering shelters between 2012 and 2016, with average stays increasing by 10 years. Mayor Bill de Blasio's housing initiative aims to build 300,000 affordable residences by 2022, but critics argue it doesn't provide enough for those with extremely low incomes. A Brooklyn building with 300 affordable units remains largely vacant due to a lack of qualified tenants in the lowest income brackets, highlighting the need for more affordable housing options.

images.alt_text: 535 Carlton Avenue in Brooklyn was developed to be affordable housing. However, there are gripes that it is still beyond the reach of some applicants due to its funding and subsidy structure.

site_title: Trump rollback of banking regulation well underway
summary: US President Donald Trump's rollback of banking regulation is underway, with key agency vacancies and new legislation in the works. Trump has decried the financial rules and regulations, particularly the Dodd-Frank Wall Street reform legislation, and plans to fill key positions at the Federal Reserve, Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, and Treasury's Office of the Comptroller of the Currency. Industry officials expect a "different tone" and an "industry-friendly approach" from the government, with some regulations being modified or scaled back, such as stress tests and capital requirements for major financial institutions.

site_title: Deliveroo may soon operate a dine-in restaurant
summary: Deliveroo may soon open dine-in restaurants in Singapore, with new remote kitchens set to launch across the island in 2024. One of these kitchens, currently operating as a delivery-only site, could evolve into a fast-casual eatery. The concept allows multiple restaurant brands to operate under one roof, reducing delivery times and increasing access for consumers. Deliveroo plans to explore dine-in options and offer pick-up services at new sites, which are expected to be located in heartlands.

site_title: Big Tobacco fumes over new EU salvo in cigarette smuggling war
summary: The European Union plans to track cigarette packages from factory to retail shelf using electronic codes, aiming to combat cigarette smuggling that deprives governments of over 10 billion euros in tax revenue annually. The proposed system has sparked resistance from tobacco manufacturers, citing technical hassles and potential costs, despite the commission's claim that the costs will be "moderate" and mainly borne by the sector. The EU's efforts to combat smuggling come as cigarette-related illnesses claim up to 695,000 lives in the EU each year.

site_title: 15 stocks buy back S$17m worth of shares
summary: In a five-session period from Nov 10 to 16, 15 Singapore stocks conducted share buybacks worth S$17.1 million, up from S$1 million in the previous period. This increase in buybacks coincided with a 2.4% decline in the Straits Times Index (STI), resulting in a dividend-inclusive return of 19.5% for 2017. The higher number of buybacks may be linked to the STI's pull-back during this period.

site_title: BlackGold Natural Resources' new Indonesia jetty will boost output capacity, reduce costs
summary: BlackGold Natural Resources has completed its new jetty in Indonesia, boosting output capacity and reducing transportation costs. The 3.6 million-tonne coal loading capacity and 45,000-55,000-tonne stockpiling capacity will provide better control over coal distribution networks. CEO Philip Cecil Rickard said the jetty will lower operating costs and deliver coal efficiently, enabling seamless coal distribution. The project is expected to significantly improve the company's operations.

site_title: Logistics has a key role in Oman's development
summary: Oman's logistics sector is poised for significant growth, driven by infrastructure investments and economic diversification efforts. The industry is expected to grow at a 7% CAGR between 2015 and 2020, contributing to increased inward investment, non-oil exports, and competitiveness. Oman's strategic location on the Indian Ocean and Arabian Gulf provides access to emerging markets, making it an attractive hub for trade and commerce.

site_title: EU budget deficit intractable problem for Brexit
summary: The EU is facing a deepening budget deficit due to the UK's impending departure in March 2019, with a requested 60 billion euros as a departure payment being deemed unreasonable. The EU's budget is increasing every year, with 16 member-nations benefiting from it, and the UK's estimated 10-15% contribution will be lost. EU negotiators have rejected the UK's initial offer of 20 billion euros, citing the need for extra money to address rising infrastructure and debt in poorer nations, as well as a growing refugee crisis.

site_title: Europe: Warnings, downgrades weigh as shares post another weekly fall
summary: European shares fell for the second consecutive week, down 0.3% on Friday, as disappointing earnings updates and broker downgrades weighed on the market. The Stoxx 600 index is still up 6% for the year. Analysts express caution over whether the current rally will continue, with some citing economic data slowdown and potential stock market correction. Meanwhile, Vivendi rose 4.4% after releasing earnings updates, and shares in Comcast and Verizon showed interest in acquiring assets from Twenty-First Century Fox.

site_title: The PAP must always stay close to Singaporeans, maintain their trust: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of maintaining trust between the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) and the public, warning that it must never be taken for granted or frittered away. He stressed the need for the PAP to work hard and implement policies that benefit the majority of Singaporeans, citing the need to avoid losing public trust like the US and UK have experienced. Lee also highlighted the significance of the upcoming general election, stating that the PAP must stay close to Singaporeans and maintain their trust and confidence.

site_title: Singapore growth could top 3% in 2017: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expects the country's economic growth to exceed 3% in 2017, surpassing initial expectations of 1.5-2% growth. The improved world economy, boosted by manufacturing and financial services, is contributing to the growth. However, Lee warned that government spending on healthcare and infrastructure will continue to rise, necessitating tax increases. He also expressed optimism about Singapore's relations with the US and China, noting that being friends with both countries is crucial for a small nation like Singapore.

site_title: Alliance Mineral Assets flags issue with placement to Burwill Commodity; will finalise CFO appointment by Nov 22
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets revealed an issue with the placement of A$5 million owed by Hong Kong-listed Burwill Commodity for the fourth tranche of subscription shares. Although 17.91 million shares were allotted and issued, the payment was not received until Nov 16. The company's board will review the matter and appoint an independent CFO by Nov 22, after initially identifying the position. The board has also established a governance review process and requires approval for any cash disbursement or material contract exceeding A$1 million.

site_title: Zimbabwe's ruling party expels Mugabe; Mnangagwa takes over
summary: Zimbabwe's ruling ZANU-PF party has expelled President Robert Mugabe, ending his 37-year rule, following a de facto military coup. Deputy Emmerson Mnangagwa, who was sacked by Mugabe this month, has taken over as the new leader. Mnangagwa is expected to head an interim post-Mugabe unity government, focusing on rebuilding ties with the outside world and stabilizing the economy. Hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets in Harare in support of Mugabe's overthrow, sending shockwaves across Africa.

site_title: China home prices snap three-month decline as market stabilises
summary: Chinese home prices rose in 50 of 70 tracked cities in October, snapping a three-month decline, indicating market stabilization. New-home prices climbed, with Shanghai seeing a 0.3% increase, while Beijing fell 0.2%. The data contradicts earlier reports of a 3.4% decline in home sales by value and 8.5% decline by area. The stabilization marks a shift from a government campaign to curb speculation and runaway price growth, suggesting a potential recovery in China's property market.

site_title: Trump halts decision to allow elephant trophy imports after uproar
summary: US President Donald Trump has halted the decision to allow imports of elephant trophies from Zimbabwe, citing a need to review all conservation facts. The move, which was met with outrage from animal activists, was set to resume hunting in the country after a review by career officials at the US Fish and Wildlife Service, which concluded that the killing of African elephants in Zimbabwe as trophies would enhance the survival of the species. Trump's decision comes amid a backlash to reports that the move would apply to two southern African countries, Zimbabwe and Zambia.

site_title: MRT incidents like Joo Koon collision should not have happened; we must put things right: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has emphasized the need to improve Singapore's public transport system, citing recent MRT incidents such as the Joo Koon collision. Despite statistics showing fewer delays and breakdowns, the public's confidence in the system has been shaken. Lee pledged to put things right, investing in major projects like resignalling and expanding the network, and raising taxes to fund these efforts. He also stressed the need to strengthen train operators and reinforce engineering and maintenance teams.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the tanker and dry bulk market for the week of November 12-18, 2017. Key developments include:

- Middle East Gulf VLCC rates fell two points to WS 69, while US Gulf rates were fixed at WS 26 and options cargo at WS 30.
- West Africa/China rates remained around WS 70.
- Suezmax rates initially eased 7.5 WS points but regained some lost ground, sitting around WS 75/76.
- Aframax rates gained six points to WS 100/102.5 region, with Black Sea rates fixed at WS 110 and WS 115.
- Panamax rates fell due to the decline in the Asia/Pacific market, with some charterers seizing opportunities in the spot market.
- Supramax rates remained weak, with a couple of grain fixtures reported in the Black Sea to the Mediterranean.
- Handy sector remained weak, with a turning point possibly for tonnage in the US Gulf and east coast South America.

site_title: Gold at one-month top on weak dollar, uncertainty over Trump tax bill
summary: Gold prices surged to a one-month high on Friday as the US dollar weakened amid uncertainty over the proposed tax overhaul. The US House of Representatives approved a tax cut package, while the Senate version faced resistance, fueling doubt among investors and boosting gold. Spot gold rose 1.2% to $1,293.53 an ounce, its largest one-day jump since August 28, and is poised for a 1.3% weekly gain, its strongest since mid-October.

site_title: Business jets risk US pilot shortage on competition from airlines
summary: Business jet operators in North America are facing a potential pilot shortage due to competition from US airlines offering higher salaries and benefits. The aviation industry is expected to need an additional 255,000 pilots by 2027, while business jets are offering double-digit raises to attract talent. Airlines are recruiting employees to fly new aircraft and replace retiring staff, making it a "buyers' market" for pilots. In contrast, European corporate jet operators have not experienced significant pilot losses due to airline competition, but may face challenges as new, high-end business jets enter the market.

site_title: Mayfair Gardens sold en bloc to Oxley Holdings subsidiary for S$311 million
summary: Oxley Holdings' subsidiary Citrine Property successfully bid S$311 million for the collective sale of Mayfair Gardens, a 124-unit private residential estate in Singapore. The sale price translates to approximately S$1,244 per square foot per plot ratio, with owners receiving a gross sale price of S$1.7 million to S$2.89 million. The purchase will be funded by internal resources and bank borrowings, with an estimated breakeven price for the new project at S$1,780 psf.

site_title: Cocky US pilot draws penis in sky, Navy not amused
summary: A US Navy pilot drew a large penis in the sky using the condensation trails from his F-18 jet, leaving residents of Okanogan, Washington stunned.
