summary: Asian markets ended the week on a positive note, boosted by news of US tax cuts moving forward. The Nasdaq reached a record close, while Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney also gained ground. However, Shanghai declined, and the dollar's rally was tempered by uncertainty about the reforms' future. Analysts warn that the Senate hurdle remains, and the bill's passage is far from guaranteed, potentially affecting global stocks and currencies.

site_title: Tesla unveils electric big-rig truck amid Model 3 factory 'hell'
summary: Tesla unveiled a prototype electric big-rig truck, dubbed the Tesla Semi, with CEO Elon Musk describing it as a key effort to move the economy away from fossil fuels. The truck has a range of 320-480 km and four motors, one for each rear wheel, with semi-autonomous driving capabilities. However, some analysts fear the truck may be an expensive distraction for Tesla, which is struggling to roll out the affordable Model 3 sedan and faces a crowded field for electric trucks.

site_title: China's average air quality worsens in October on the year
summary: China's average air quality worsened in October, with PM2.5 concentrations rising 5.6% to an average of 38 micrograms per cubic meter. The Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei region saw a 10.3% decrease in PM2.5 emissions in October, but the average over the first 10 months remains 8.5% higher than last year. Only 4 cities met the 15% target to cut PM2.5 concentrations, with 11 cities experiencing increased emissions. The environment ministry attributed the poor air quality to the province of Hebei's steel production and coal consumption.

site_title: Block porn or be blocked, Indonesia warns Google, Twitter
summary: Indonesia has threatened to block social media platforms such as Twitter and Google unless they comply with filtering content deemed obscene. The country's Communications Minister, Rudiantara, warned that failure to comply would result in severe consequences, including banning the platforms from operating in the country. The move comes amid concerns about the spread of terrorism and racial violence on social media, as well as the presence of pornography and child abuse. Google and Twitter have been summoned for meetings with government officials to discuss content monitoring, while Facebook has previously agreed to work with the government to filter content.

site_title: MPA to facilitate use of drones for ship surveys
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) is developing an acceptance criteria for the use of drones in ship surveys, targeting Singapore-registered ships. The criteria, expected to be rolled out in the first quarter of next year, follows successful trials by MPA. This move aims to increase efficiency and reduce costs in ship inspections, while also promoting the adoption of remote inspection techniques.

site_title: Genting Hong Kong continues to pare stake in Norwegian Cruise Lines
summary: Genting Hong Kong sold 5 million shares of Norwegian Cruise Lines Holdings, reducing its stake to 5.64%. This is part of a larger disposal plan, with a total of 10 million shares sold for $270.1 million. The company expects a $57.4 million gain from the sale. Genting Hong Kong plans to focus on North Asia and delist from the Singapore Exchange in April 2018 to save costs. The sale follows another stake disposal in August and aims to increase visibility among North Asian investors.

site_title: Images suggest North Korea 'aggressive' work on ballistic missile submarine: institute
summary: North Korea is reportedly pursuing an "aggressive schedule" to build its first operational ballistic missile submarine, according to satellite images taken on November 5 by the Washington-based 38 North institute. The images show activity at the Sinpo South Shipyard and suggest the construction of a new submarine, possibly the SINPO-C. This development comes as North Korea continues to work on developing a nuclear-tipped missile capable of reaching the United States, sparking international concern.

site_title: ETC says unauthorised withdrawals not material, group's risk contained
summary: Myanmar and China property developer ETC says unauthorised withdrawals of 106 million yuan (S$24 million) between July and October 2017 from its subsidiary Huizhou Daya Bay are not material and risk exposure is contained. The company owes its majority shareholder, Luo Shandong, about US$23.9 million. ETC has taken preventative actions, including serving legal letters against staff, to protect its assets, but may still owe Mr. Luo 164 million yuan.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on Friday open; STI up 0.89% to 3,371.12
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.89% to 3,371.12 on Friday, driven by the overnight gains in US and European markets. Trendlines and Cosco Shipping led the gains, with Trendlines up 1.3% and Cosco Shipping up 2.6%. The Straits Times Index beat losers 113 to 33, with 74.8 million shares changing hands. The rally extends a 5-day winning streak ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ETC, Hatten Land, Raffles Education, Spackman, Marco Polo, Nam Cheong
summary: Several Singapore stocks made announcements that could affect trading on Friday. ETC, a Myanmar and China property developer, said unauthorized withdrawals in China won't be material. Hatten Land acquired two parcels of land in Malacca for RM108.6 million, issuing 140.16 million shares at S$0.25 apiece. Raffles Education Corp withdrew a requisition notice, while Spackman Entertainment Group sunk 250 million won into a South Korean film production company. Marco Polo Marine secured majority approval for its restructuring plan, and Nam Cheong's subsidiaries were granted permission to restructure debts.

site_title: Few banks seen queuing for China's red carpet invite
summary: China has relaxed its rules on foreign banks, allowing them to take larger stakes in Chinese commercial banks and control of securities joint ventures. However, few expect global banks to rush to take advantage of the new rules due to the stringent ownership limits, opaque regulatory regime, and intense competition from domestic players. Foreign banks will need to navigate complex regulations, including "know-your-customer" requirements, and face pricing competition in key segments. The lack of management control and limited business lines also pose significant challenges, making it difficult for foreign entrants to gain market share.

site_title: US$7.5m Schumacher Ferrari sets record: Sotheby's
summary: Michael Schumacher's 2001 Ferrari F2001 sold for US$7.5 million at Sotheby's auction in New York, setting a record for a modern-era Formula One car. The seven-time world champion's car sparked furious bidding, exceeding its pre-sale estimate of US$4-5 million. The sale marked the first time a rare automobile was included in an art auction, with Sotheby's senior vice-president calling it "the very best racing car ever sold at an auction."

site_title: Barclays, Fragrance Group price separate Singapore-dollar bond deals
summary: Barclays priced two Singapore-dollar bond deals worth S$300 million, including a S$200 million Tier 2 subordinated callable note with a 3.75% coupon rate until 2025 and a S$100 million senior unsecured note with a 4.75% coupon rate until 2021. The bonds were priced by bookrunners Barclays, DBS Bank, OCBC Bank, Standard Chartered Bank, and UOB, with DBS serving as lead manager and bookrunner for Fragrance Group's S$100 million senior unsecured note.

site_title: LOT Polish Airlines to launch first direct Singapore to Warsaw flights in May
summary: LOT Polish Airlines will launch its first direct flights between Singapore and Warsaw on May 15, 2018, operating thrice weekly. The flights will increase to four times a week from July 2018. The airline will use a 252-seat B787-8 aircraft, offering economy, premium economy, and business cabins. This new link is part of Changi Airport's efforts to grow connectivity to Europe, providing greater convenience for passengers to reach Central and Eastern Europe.

site_title: Japan railway 'deeply sorry' after train leaves 20 seconds early
summary: A Japanese railway operator, Tsukuba Express, has apologized for a train departing 20 seconds early, surprising the nation known for its punctuality and politeness. The train left Minami Nagareyama Station at 9:44:20 instead of 9:44:40, but no customers missed the train. The company stated that lax management may cause safety problems in the future, highlighting the importance of following safety procedures. The incident has sparked comments on social media, with some questioning the severity of the apology.

images.alt_text: A Japanese railway operator has issued a deep apology for the "tremendous nuisance" caused by a train departing 20 seconds early, surprising even a nation renowned for both punctuality and politeness.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.67% on Friday, led by renewed hopes for US market-friendly tax cuts, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 29,214.36. In contrast, the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices declined 0.19% and 0.16%, respectively. The rally came despite US President Trump's recent threats, which traders seemed to brush off.

site_title: Singapore non-oil domestic exports beat expectations to rebound by 20.9% in October
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rebounded by 20.9% in October, surpassing economist estimates of a 10% expansion. This strong growth followed a 1.1% decline in September, mainly due to a drop in electronics shipments. Electronic exports increased by 4.5%, while non-electronic shipments expanded by 28.5%. Shipments to China, the European Union, and Malaysia led the growth, driven by a pick-up in global demand, particularly for electronics-related shipments.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher, boosted by cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on November 17, 2017, driven by a cheaper yen supporting Japanese exporters and rallies on Wall Street due to progress on a US tax cut plan. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 1.11% to 22,599.37, while the Topix index rose 0.92% to 1,777.90. This followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and fresh records on the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Moody's upgrades India's credit rating in boost for Modi
summary: Moody's upgraded India's credit rating to Baa2 from Baa3, citing progress in economic and institutional reforms. This marks the first time since 2004 and reflects the government's efforts to stabilise rising debt levels. The move comes despite India's growth slipping below 6% in the April-June quarter, prompting expectations of fiscal stimulus. The upgrade is seen as a boost for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government, but also reflects the country's changing economic landscape.

images.alt_text: The ratings firm upgraded India to Baa2 from Baa3 and said reforms being pushed through by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government will help stabilise rising levels of debt.

site_title: Apple diversity chief to leave months after taking the role
summary: Denise Young Smith, Apple's head of diversity and inclusion, is leaving the company after a few months in the role. Smith, who is black, apologized in October after making comments on diversity that sparked controversy. She will be succeeded by Christie Smith, a veteran of Deloitte. Young Smith is departing to join Cornell University's New York technology campus. The move comes after Smith faced backlash for suggesting that a group of "white blue-eyed blond men" could be considered diverse based on their life experiences.

site_title: US warns of Christmas terror threat in Europe
summary: The US State Department has updated its travel warning to advise citizens of an increased terrorist threat in Europe over the Christmas and New Year holiday season. The warning cites recent attacks in Britain, Finland, France, Russia, Spain, and Sweden as evidence of Al-Qaeda and the Islamic State group's continued activity. US citizens are advised to remain vigilant for potential attacks, particularly at festive events, with a notable example being last year's attacks in Berlin and Istanbul.

site_title: China's financial sector 'at risk of bubble; government considering property tax'
summary: China's financial sector is at risk of a bubble, according to Deputy Chairman Huang Qifan, with a property tax being considered to reduce speculation and debt. The sector's ratio to the overall economy is the highest in the world, with borrowing rates and credit expansion outpacing GDP growth. A property tax could be implemented in the next few years to temper speculation, with M2 growth slowing to a record low of 8.8% year-on-year. This comes as China seeks to reduce its years-long addiction to debt without shattering economic growth.

site_title: US regulator relaxes media ownership rules
summary: US regulators have relaxed media ownership rules, ending a decades-old ban on owning newspapers and television stations in the same market. The Federal Communications Commission adopted the changes in a 3-2 vote, allowing for single companies to own multiple broadcasters in the same market. Critics argue the revisions will lead to more media consolidation, layoffs, and a loss of local news outlets, while supporters see it as a modernization of outdated rules. The FCC claims the changes will improve service to local communities.

site_title: Baidu jumps into crowded smart speaker fray with Raven H
summary: Baidu has unveiled its smart speaker, Raven H, priced at 1,699 yuan (S$347), in China's crowded smart speaker market. The device relies on Baidu's DuerOS software and is designed to stake out a spot in the market dominated by US tech giants. The Raven H features a detachable top deck and adjustable design, and Baidu plans to use its vast user and search result data to supercharge AI services. The company aims to monetize its DuerOS software in three years, with plans to target overseas users within two years.

site_title: DBS sees double-digit growth from consumer and SME business in Singapore, Hong Kong
summary: DBS Group Holdings expects double-digit income growth from its consumer and SME business in Singapore and Hong Kong, with potential contributions of 50% of total income in five years. The bank attributes this growth to leveraging Asia's megatrends, such as intra-regional trade and growing affluence. The consumer and SME business in Singapore and Hong Kong currently generates S$5.1 billion, or 44% of the bank's 2017 income, with digital customers contributing significantly to income and profit.

site_title: Hatten Land acquiring two development sites in Malacca for RM108.6m
summary: Hatten Land acquires two parcels of land in Malacca for RM108.6 million (S$35.32 million) to develop integrated projects. The developer will acquire 85% stake in one parcel for RM46.75 million and 75% stake in another for RM61.88 million. The deal will increase Hatten's property portfolio and boost its net tangible assets per share. The company expects robust demand for mixed developments in the area, driven by new township developments and the Belt and Road Initiative.

site_title: Hot stock: Raffles Education falls after Oei Hong Leong withdraws ouster bid
summary: Raffles Education Corp's shares plummeted 7.8% to 29.5 Singapore cents after tycoon Oei Hong Leong withdrew his bid to remove the company's founder and CEO, Chew Hua Seng. Oei had served a notice for an EGM to address various issues, but the withdrawal means the meeting will not take place. Oei's stake in the company increased to 12.88% after recent share purchases, boosting interest in the stock.

site_title: US: Stocks jump as House passes tax cut, Nasdaq hits record
summary: US stocks surged on the House of Representatives' passage of the Republican tax cut plan, with the Nasdaq Composite Index hitting a fresh record. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also gained, driven by solid earnings from Wal-Mart and Cisco Systems. The tax cut plan was approved 227-205, but its passage in the Senate is uncertain, with some warning that it could be "dead" if it loses more Republican support.

site_title: US Congress sends US$700b defence bill for Trump's signature
summary: US Congress has authorised $700 billion in national defence spending for 2018, surpassing President Donald Trump's request by $26 billion. The National Defence Authorisation Act, passed unanimously in the Senate and 356-70 in the House, is about 15% higher than the 2016 defence budget. The bill will now be sent to the president for signature, representing a significant increase in defence spending.

site_title: US dollar steadies as risk aversion ebbs, yields rise
summary: The US dollar steadied against major currencies after a week of decline, as risk aversion in global markets receded and US yields rose. The dollar index was little changed at 93.822, while the euro inched up 0.1% to $1.1785. The US House of Representatives approved a tax cuts package, which is now moving to the Senate. Despite this, the dollar/yen may test the 114.00 handle but lacks momentum for a sustained surge. US Treasury yields rose 4 basis points, supporting the dollar.

site_title: Singapore suspends trade ties with North Korea
summary: Singapore has suspended trade relations with North Korea, becoming the latest major trade partner to cut ties under UN sanctions over its nuclear program. The suspension, effective November 8, prohibits all commercially traded goods from or to North Korea, with penalties of up to S$200,000 or four times the value of the goods. This move follows the US imposition of North Korea-related sanctions in September and comes as tensions on the Korean peninsula escalate. Singapore is North Korea's seventh-largest trading partner, with the Philippines being its fifth-largest.

site_title: How effective are schemes to help Singapore workers find new jobs?
summary: A parliamentary panel in Singapore has asked the government to review the effectiveness of job training and placement programs, citing concerns that some workers were unable to find employment through initiatives such as the Adapt and Grow program. The panel recommends designing better programs based on the review's findings, and the government has agreed to investigate the issue. The committee also expressed concerns over the lack of transparency and accountability in industry transformation programs and productivity schemes, calling for robust monitoring mechanisms and education and skills training.

site_title: Trump tax overhaul adopted by US House, debate shifts to Senate
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a landmark tax overhaul, with 227-205 votes, as President Donald Trump urged his party to advance the sweeping tax cuts. The bill aims to deliver historic tax cuts by the end of the year, with estimates suggesting a $1,182 savings for a typical family of four. However, the bill faces a tougher path in the Senate, where a narrower margin and opposition from some Republicans could lead to its failure. The Senate's version includes a repeal of the Obamacare individual mandate, which could increase health insurance costs by 10% and lead to 13 million fewer people with coverage over the next decade.

site_title: Vancouver condo rush sparks local and foreign flipping frenzy
summary: Vancouver's condominium market has seen a surge in speculation, with local and foreign buyers snapping up preconstruction units before completion. Prices have nearly doubled since 2015, and resale prices have risen 33% nationally. Flippers are selling units before completion to avoid the 15% foreign buyer tax, while the assignment market allows offshore investors to avoid the tax. The trend is seen as a sign of creeping speculation, which could lead to a crash if market conditions change. The government is reviewing its policy to crack down on speculation and reduce tax fraud.

site_title: Sterling extends gains but outlook clouded
summary: British pound extends gains against the dollar to 0.25% at $1.3208, driven by a mildly positive EU initiative on Brexit negotiations. However, the outlook remains clouded due to ongoing uncertainty and weak economic data, including lagging wages and a decline in the number of people in work in Britain. A mid-December summit in Brussels is seen as a crucial milestone, but progress is needed to clarify post-Brexit trade talks and boost investor confidence.

site_title: Raj Pink diamond fails to sell at auction
summary: A 37.3-carat cushion-shaped pink diamond, known as the "Raj Pink," failed to sell at Sotheby's auction in Geneva for a pre-sale estimate of US$20-30 million. The diamond, found in South Africa in 2015, was mounted on a ring and named by its owner, who wished to remain anonymous. The auction saw only 303 of 349 lots sell, with the sale netting 77.9 million francs. Other major lots, including a Harry Winston fancy light pink diamond ring, also failed to meet their secret reserve prices.

site_title: US' estimated tab for Middle East wars since 9/11 is US$4.4t - and rising fast
summary: US wars in Iraq, Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Syria since 9/11 have cost an estimated US$4.4 trillion, with projections to reach US$5.6 trillion. This estimate is nearly three times higher than the Pentagon's authorized US$1.52 trillion spending for the same period. The costs are a significant burden on US federal and state budgets and the economy.

site_title: Singapore will work with Asean neighbours on climate change issues: Masagos
summary: Singapore will work with ASEAN neighbours to mitigate climate change effects, focusing on reducing energy intensity and increasing renewable energy use. Environment Minister Masagos Zulkifli announced plans to advance the Asean Plan of Action for Energy Cooperation 2016-2025, aiming to reduce energy intensity by 20% and increase renewable energy to 23% by 2025. Singapore has pledged to reduce emissions intensity by 36% by 2030 and will implement a carbon tax from 2019, with plans to designate 2018 as the Year of Climate Action to raise awareness among citizens.

site_title: Good old back-to-basics superhero story
summary: The Justice League film marks a new direction for the DC Extended Universe, following the death of Superman in Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice. Directed by Zach Snyder, the movie brings together a team of superheroes, including Batman, Wonder Woman, Aquaman, Cyborg, and the Flash, to face the threat of Steppenwolf, a megalomaniacal alien. The film focuses on teamwork and camaraderie, allowing viewers to root for the good guys, and sets the stage for future installments. With its lighthearted tone and fun banter, Justice League is a fun superhero flick that signals a new dawn for the franchise.

site_title: Buoyed by disunity
summary: Theresa May's position as British Prime Minister appears precarious amidst Brexit negotiations. Despite facing opposition from within her own Conservative party and the rest of Europe, May remains in power due to her ability to mask her thoughts and maintain ambiguity. Her domestic rivals fear removing her could give Jeremy Corbyn an opening, while external pressures from the European Commission and European leaders keep her under scrutiny. May's relationship with Angela Merkel and her ability to navigate Brexit negotiations make her the most likely contender for a stable outcome, but her stubbornness and resistance to clear definitions on key issues hinder her progress.

site_title: MMP Resources issues convertible bonds and places shares to Maiora
summary: MMP Resources, a Singapore-based investment firm, has issued convertible bonds and placed shares to its controlling shareholder, Maiora Asset Management, for S$114,500. The funds will be used for investment in construction opportunities and operating expenses. Maiora, a Singapore fund manager, is subscribing for 7.99 million placement shares at a discount of 10% to the volume weighted average price. The convertible bonds will bear 12.5% interest annually and mature in 2021. MMP Resources will hold an extraordinary general meeting to obtain shareholders' approval for the bond subscription and share placement.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore-based companies reported earnings for the first half of 2018. Singapore Myanmar Investco (SMI) posted a 52.5% increase in gross profit to US$3.1 million, driven by higher gross profit margins. RHT Health Trust received a proposed takeover offer from Fortis Healthcare, valued at S$0.90 per share. Spackman Entertainment, a movie production company, is expected to launch two new movies in 2018 and may acquire more companies to diversify revenue.

site_title: Oil extends losing streak on US oversupply worries
summary: Oil prices ended lower on Thursday, extending a five-day losing streak, due to concerns about US oversupply and increasing inventories. Brent crude futures fell 51 cents to $61.36 per barrel, while US light crude declined 19 cents to $55.14 per barrel. Expectations of an OPEC supply-cut pact extension on November 30 have offset recent pressure, but analysts warn that the market's direction may remain unclear until after the meeting. US crude production has risen by 15% since its 2016 low, with the US expected to account for over 80% of global supply growth in the next decade.

site_title: Oct industrial output boosted by post-hurricane rebound
summary: US industrial output rose 0.9% in October, exceeding expectations, as industries affected by hurricanes resumed normal operations. The manufacturing sector increased 1.3% after an upwardly revised 0.4% rise in September. The effects of Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Nate, which previously held back industrial output, contributed 0.60 percentage points to the overall change. Import prices rose 0.2% in October, slowing after a 2.7% rise in September.

site_title: Subaru sees 20b yen in costs linked to inspection scandal
summary: Subaru Corp has recalled 395,000 vehicles in Japan due to improper final inspection procedures at domestic plants, resulting in estimated costs of 20 billion yen (S$240 million). This follows a similar oversight at Nissan Motor Co Ltd and tarnishes Japan's reputation for quality control. The automaker had previously cut its full-year operating profit forecast due to weak sales in the US, its biggest market. Subaru has not yet decided when to book the costs and will not revise its financial year forecasts.

images.alt_text: Subaru Corp said it was recalling 395,000 vehicles in Japan and that it expected to incur about 20 billion yen (S$240 million) in costs related to improper final inspection procedures at domestic plants.

site_title: Amazon's cashier-less store almost ready for prime time
summary: Amazon's cashier-less store, Amazon Go, is being fine-tuned in Seattle after a year of employee testing. The store uses mobile apps and sensing technology to track items and bill customers, eliminating the need for cashiers. While the system works for individual shoppers, it struggles with groups, such as families with children. Amazon is conducting further tests and focus groups to address these issues, with plans to roll out the technology at Whole Foods locations, although no timeline is set.

site_title: Sats taps foreign JVs, partnerships for growth
summary: SATS, a groundhandler, reported a 16.2% jump in net profit to S$72.2 million in its second quarter, driven by higher contributions from joint ventures and associates. The company has formed partnerships with Turkish Airlines and AirAsia, which are expected to boost growth. Sats has also inked a memorandum of agreement with Turkish Airlines to cater inflight meals at Istanbul's mega airport, set to open in 2018. Analysts have upgraded their target prices for Sats, citing the potential for more partnerships and growth in Asia and the Middle East.

site_title: Productivity, inequality key issues in Singapore's competitiveness
summary: Singapore faces long-term competitiveness challenges due to a rapid slowdown in labour productivity growth and rising inequality among businesses, mainly caused by the rise in new technologies. Equipping small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to adapt to these disruptions is crucial in addressing these twin issues. Economists emphasize the need for SMEs to be ready for new technologies to mitigate inequality and productivity concerns.

site_title: 20 banks likely to join frenemy trade pact between Hong Kong and Singapore
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong are set to launch a blockchain-based trade network, the first of its kind globally, targeting 2019. 20 global banks are expected to join the network, which aims to streamline the transfer of digital documents and data, covering trade flows between the two hubs. The partnership could set new global standards for the trillion-dollar industry, with Singapore targeting Asean and Hong Kong focusing on China. However, concerns over data privacy and regulations on distributed ledger technology remain, with regulators needing to address these issues to realize the network's full potential.

site_title: Beware the fallout from enforcing tighter packaging rules
summary: Plain packaging, removing branding and logos from food and beverage products, is being considered to combat obesity and other health issues. However, proponents of the policy argue that it will discourage innovation and increase the risk of counterfeiting, as brands will no longer be able to differentiate themselves through design. The introduction of plain packaging for sugared drinks could have negative downstream effects on the economy, including job losses in the packaging and advertising industries. The law may also limit intellectual property rights, making it easier for counterfeiters to produce fake products.

site_title: Europe: Recovery rally for stocks leaves oil sector behind
summary: European shares rebounded 0.8% on Thursday, snapping a losing streak since October 2016, as cyclical sectors such as financials, autos, and technology made a comeback. Energy firms lagged, with Europe's oil and gas index hitting a one-month low after a Norwegian sovereign wealth fund proposed to drop oil and gas companies from its benchmark index. Despite earnings updates, investors expressed caution, with some citing disappointing top-line revenue growth. European equity strategists saw the recovery as a buying opportunity, driven by a "robust" earnings outlook and rising long-term interest rates.

site_title: Singapore has big role to ensure Asean stays relevant and competitive
summary: Singapore is set to take the reins of the Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) in 2018, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong assuming the role. As chair, Singapore will host numerous meetings, summits, and celebrations, including the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) free-trade deal and the South China Sea territorial dispute. The country aims to tap into the digital economy, leveraging Asean's strong technology adoption and growing digital economy, expected to reach US$200 billion by 2025. Singapore's leadership is seen as crucial to ensuring Asean remains relevant and competitive in the next half-century.

site_title: Consortium bags HK residential plot at record HK$17.3b
summary: A consortium including Sino Land and Shimao Property Holdings has purchased a record HK$17.3 billion plot of residential land in Hong Kong's Cheung Sha Wan district. The plot is near an upcoming museum complex and rail terminus. This deal signals the property market remains hot, with the consortium members including Wheelock Properties, K Wah International Holdings, and SEA Holdings. The purchase price sets a new record for a residential land sale in Hong Kong.

site_title: 'A bunch of lunatics and a woman'
summary: The Impressionist art movement, initially dismissed by critics in 1874, revolutionized art with their free and loose brush strokes, unblended colors, and focus on everyday life. Led by artists such as Claude Monet, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, and Camille Pissarro, the movement gained recognition and popularity, particularly among the emerging middle class. Today, the National Gallery Singapore showcases 60 Impressionist artworks, including Monet's "La Pie" and Berthe Morisot's "Le Berceau," which depicts maternal duty with conflicting emotions. The exhibition highlights the impact of Impressionism on art history and its continued relevance in contemporary art.

site_title: SRX Property launches free service to match clients with agents
summary: SRX Property has launched a free service called myProperty Concierge, which matches clients with licensed estate agents in Singapore. The service, available on SRX.com.sg, myProperty Tracker, and the SRX Property mobile app, assigns a concierge to understand clients' needs and goals, then uses "advanced algorithms" to match them with the best-suited agent. The agents provide transparent, data-driven services, including market analysis, pricing, and financing, to deliver a quality experience and peace of mind for clients.

site_title: Philanthropy for the aged
summary: Southeast Asia's ageing population demands increased attention from philanthropists, particularly in Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia, where the population above 60 years old is projected to rise to 2.1 billion by 2050. A report by Credit Suisse highlights six themes in eldercare needs, including active ageing, financial security, and dementia. Governments struggle to prioritize attention and resources, leaving a gap for private philanthropy to drive innovation and accessibility in healthcare. Philanthropists can support government-funded programs, seed new initiatives, and commission research to maximize social impact.

site_title: Sodexo acquires local SME Kim Yew Electrical
summary: Sodexo has acquired Singapore facilities management provider Kim Yew Electrical & Sanitary for an undisclosed value. Kim Yew will operate as a wholly-owned subsidiary of Sodexo Singapore under its new name Sodexo Kim Yew. The acquisition aims to reinforce Sodexo's technical expertise in Singapore, complementing its existing soft FM services. Founder Jim Tan will continue to drive the day-to-day business, and there will be no short-term changes. The deal is expected to boost Sodexo's quality of life positioning and provide consumers with greater services and efficiencies.

site_title: Dior taps Fendi's fountain of youth in bid for future of luxury
summary: Christian Dior has appointed Pietro Beccari, CEO of Fendi, as its new CEO, effective early 2018. Beccari aims to modernize Dior's brand and online presence, following a five-year period of steady performance under previous CEO Sidney Toledano. Beccari's Fendi has successfully rebranded as a luxury experience, with a focus on immersive experiences and digital marketing, and is expected to bring a similar approach to Dior. The goal is to restore Dior's status as a trend-setter in the luxury industry.

images.alt_text: Fendi CEO Pietro Beccari at the Trevi Fountain - a Roman landmark renovated under the brand's sponsorship. He moves on to head Dior next year and is expected to rejuvenate the label with the same flair he exhibited in reviving Fendi and updating it for wired fashionistas.

site_title: Largest luxury liner based in Singapore sets off
summary: Singapore's Genting Dream, a 18-deck luxury liner with 3,352 passengers, set off on its maiden cruise from Singapore to Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, and Myanmar, marking the city-state's ambitions to become a cruise hub in Asia. The ship, part of Genting Hong Kong's fleet, is valued at S$1.4 billion and will offer two-night, three-night, and five-night cruise itineraries. The Singapore Tourism Board, Changi Airport Group, and Genting Cruise Lines have signed a tripartite partnership worth S$28 million, estimated to bring in 600,000 visitors and S$250 million in tourism receipts by 2020.

site_title: Is this 'male Mona Lisa' worth US$450m?
summary: The Leonardo da Vinci painting "Salvator Mundi" sold at Christie's auction for a record-breaking $450.3 million, the highest price ever paid for a work of art at auction. The painting, considered a lost work by Leonardo, was initially purchased for under $10,000 and was restored to its original form. While its technical analysis confirms it is a Leonardo, its beauty and artistic value are subjective. Critics argue that the painting's meekness and monotony cannot be redeemed by its details, making it a less distinguished religious picture from 16th-century Lombardy.

site_title: Singapore leads the way in innovation
summary: Singapore has emerged as a hub for innovative thinking, with recent events showcasing the country's commitment to digital solutions. Accenture's global digital hackathon, held in 11 cities, saw a team from Singapore win with a prototype for an early-warning system to detect dengue fever outbreaks. The system, named Dragonfly, uses Internet of Things technology to attract and identify mosquitoes, sending data to health authorities. This is part of Singapore's efforts to invest in innovation, with the government announcing plans to spend over S$150 million on artificial intelligence and hosting the second Singapore Fintech Festival, which drew over 25,000 participants from 100 countries.

site_title: GM challenges Tesla with promise of profitable electric cars
summary: General Motors (GM) plans to launch a new family of electric vehicles in 2021, aiming to make a profit for the US No. 1 carmaker. This represents a challenge to Tesla, which is struggling to get its more affordable Model 3 launched. GM aims to sell one million electric vehicles a year by 2026, with a new battery system that will be 30% cheaper than the current one, allowing for higher profit margins. The company plans to launch 20 new electric vehicles by 2023 and introduce three new models by 2020.

site_title: Prudential's new-business profit surges on Asia growth
summary: Prudential's new-business profit for the first nine months of 2017 rose 17% to £2.47 billion, driven by higher sales and favorable economics in Asia, the US, the UK, and Europe. In Asia, new-business profit rose 15% to £1.61 billion, with seven countries, including China and Hong Kong, experiencing double-digit growth. Prudential sees opportunities in the retirement needs of baby boomers in the US and life assurance and savings markets in the UK and Europe.

site_title: Technology a double-edged sword for financial inclusion
summary: Queen Maxima of the Netherlands emphasized the dual nature of fintech, highlighting both its potential to reduce inequality and its risks, including cyber-fraud, Big-Data discrimination, and lack of transparency. She noted that fintech can effectively lift people out of poverty, but warned that widening technology gaps between the rich and the poor could exacerbate inequality. Experts agree, citing statistics that financial inclusion can add $3.7 trillion annually to emerging markets' GDP by 2025 and attract 1.6 billion new people into the formal economy.

site_title: Honest Spanish tapas in homey café
summary: La Pepa, a Spanish tapas café in Singapore, offers honest and authentic dishes despite its limited menu. The restaurant's chefs, mostly local, have mastered traditional Spanish tapas with a Singaporean twist. Standout dishes include Mushroom Croquetas, Pan con Tomate, and Spanish Tortilla. However, the paella and churros were underwhelming. Despite some minor flaws, La Pepa's genuine and unpretentious approach to Spanish cuisine earns it a 6.5-star rating, making it a promising spot for those seeking authentic tapas.

site_title: Stunned Zimbabweans face uncertain future without Mugabe
summary: Zimbabweans are facing an uncertain future after the military took power and placed President Robert Mugabe under house arrest, marking the end of his 37-year rule. The army, led by General Constantino Chiwenga, took control on Tuesday after Mugabe fired his vice president Emmerson Mnangagwa, who had criticized Mugabe's leadership. The Southern African Development Community bloc is set to meet to discuss the situation, and analysts speculate that Mugabe and the military are negotiating a transition. Many Zimbabweans, including an unemployed man, are hopeful for a better future without Mugabe's rule, which has been marked by economic decline and human rights abuses.

images.alt_text: This file photo taken on April 18, 2017 shows Mr Mugabe with his wife Grace during the country's 37th Independence Day celebrations at the National Sports Stadium in Harare.

site_title: Trendlines, National Healthcare Group to develop solutions for unmet clinical needs
summary: Trendlines Group, a medtech incubator, has partnered with National Healthcare Group (NHG) in Singapore to co-develop healthcare solutions for unmet clinical needs. This is the incubator's first collaboration with a healthcare institution in Singapore. The partnership aims to build a pipeline of medtech startups and solutions for the global market. The Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) marks a significant step in addressing healthcare challenges and improving patient outcomes.

site_title: Snapchat's new test: grow the way Facebook does, without the baggage and loss of trust
summary: Snapchat's parent company, Snap, has announced a strategy shift to grow its user base and compete with Facebook. The company will redesign its app with a personalized feed using algorithms, and revamp its ad-buying process to be more like Facebook's. This move comes after a disappointing earnings report and a decline in its stock price. While Snapchat remains popular among American teenagers, the company's future is uncertain, and its shift towards Facebook-style growth may compromise its unique qualities and values. The move raises concerns about the impact on innovation and the tech landscape, as companies may feel pressured to conform to Facebook's model to survive.

site_title: STI falls a further 0.8% on poor sentiment
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 0.8% to 3,341.3 points, marking the fifth consecutive day of losses. Banking stocks led the decline, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC falling 1.1%, 0.7%, and 0.9% respectively. Noble Group was the only gainer, rising 5.5%. Traders continue to worry about the US tax reform plan and the pace of the Federal Reserve's rate hike. Most Asian markets held up well, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng rising 1.5% and 0.6% respectively.

site_title: Volkswagen eyes electric vehicles in China market
summary: Volkswagen is investing over 10 billion euros in China to produce and develop electric vehicles, with plans to introduce 40 locally produced models by 2025. The company's venture with Anhui Jianghuai Automobile Group will start production in the first half of 2018 and sales in the second half. Volkswagen aims to sell 400,000 new-energy vehicles annually by 2020, increasing to 1.5 million by 2025, as China requires carmakers to obtain a new-energy vehicle score. The company will also develop electric versions of all 300 models in its lineup, with a total investment of 50 billion euros by 2030.

site_title: Subaru recalls 400,000 vehicles in Japan as car industry reels
summary: Subaru recalls nearly 400,000 vehicles in Japan due to an inspection scandal, affecting nine models produced between 2014 and 2017. The recall, which was initially expected to cost around 5 billion yen, may cost more due to the re-inspection of all domestically produced vehicles from 2014. This is the latest blow to Japan's car industry, following a similar case at Nissan, which recalled 1.2 million cars in Japan last month. The recall does not affect vehicles sold overseas.

site_title: Indonesia's art scene and the rebirth of boardgames, in BT Weekend
summary: Indonesia's art scene is gaining international recognition with the Jakarta Biennale and new museums opening. The country's art market is expected to grow, with Indonesian art potentially becoming more sought after by collectors. Meanwhile, the boardgame industry is experiencing a revival, with tabletop gaming experiencing a massive resurgence. This trend is being highlighted in a Brunch feature in the magazine.

site_title: Profits triple at Malaysia's palm oil company Sime Darby
summary: Malaysia's palm oil company Sime Darby reported a 150% increase in first-quarter net profit to 1.32 billion ringgit, driven by increased production and asset sales. Revenue also rose to 8.14 billion ringgit. The company's plantation division saw profits jump by over four times, while its property division more than doubled on stake disposals. Sime Darby plans to spin off and list its plantations and property businesses by year-end.

images.alt_text: The company says plans are on track to spin off and list its property and plantations businesses by end-2017 after some restructuring.

site_title: From grape to table, Dutch community toasts urban vines
summary: In the Netherlands, a community project has taken off in The Hague, where amateur winemakers gather to grow and harvest grapes, producing around 600 litres of wine this year. The De Haagse Stadswijngaard, started four years ago, brings together local residents for workshops, debates, and wine tastings, fostering a sense of community and fellowship. With 650 plants and 40 enthusiasts tending to them, the project aims to promote wine-making and connect people from different backgrounds, despite the country's lack of traditional wine production.

site_title: Silver threads among the gold
summary: A report by Credit Suisse highlights the potential for philanthropy in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore, particularly in addressing ageing populations. Key findings include opportunities for venture philanthropy in Indonesia and Malaysia, government support in Singapore, and the need for long-term investment in care solutions. Philanthropists are encouraged to take a personal approach, understanding the issues and engaging directly. The report emphasizes the importance of scaling solutions to make a significant impact, particularly in addressing pressing issues like long-term care.

site_title: Thai coal miner Banpu invests in Pennsylvania shale gas field
summary: Thai coal miner Banpu has invested $500 million in US shale gas field Kalnin Ventures LLC, seeking a 20% return over five years. Banpu aims to diversify its business into gas, renewable energy, and power plants. The investment, made through Banpu's BKV Oil and Gas Capital Partners LP fund, is part of a strategy to include gas, renewable energy, and power plants. Banpu's CEO sees the Marcellus formation as a "compelling position" to expand further, driven by growing Asian demand for natural gas.

site_title: Top galleries' joint show
summary: The Art Galleries Association Singapore is hosting a joint exhibition titled "Fiction Of Precision" featuring works by 17 galleries, including established artists such as Phunk and Jeremy Sharma, as well as emerging artists. The show explores the concept of precision and perfection in art, with prices ranging from S$2,800 to S$10,000. Participating galleries include Fost, Gajah, STPI, and others, offering a diverse range of mediums and art styles.

site_title: Dollar rebounds vs yen as risk appetite recovers
summary: The US dollar rebounded against the yen, rising 0.2% to 113.09 yen, after a sharp decline on Wednesday. However, the dollar's performance against a basket of currencies remained flat, marking its lowest in almost four weeks. This follows a recent uptrend driven by hopes of a tax cut deal, which has since reversed.

site_title: More scope for charities, donors to help seniors live better: Health Minister
summary: Health Minister Gan Kim Yong emphasized the need for further partnerships between the government and philanthropic sectors to better serve seniors in Singapore. He identified three key areas where philanthropy can provide support: delivering care services, developing innovative products and services, and facilitating "last mile" delivery of care. The government has introduced initiatives such as the Community Silver Trust Fund and tax deductions for donations to IPCs to encourage charitable giving in healthcare. By 2030, one in four Singaporeans will be aged 65, highlighting the need for sustainable ageing solutions.

site_title: Plugging the gap in eldercare
summary: At 86, Tsao Ng Yu Shun founded the Tsao Foundation in Singapore in 1992 to improve elderly care and ageing issues. The foundation, chaired by her granddaughter, focuses on community-based elder-centric services and home care, believing that most people can live at home with support. Dr. Tsao notes that families can't always provide the necessary care, creating a gap that philanthropy can fill, allowing families to continue supporting their elderly relatives. The foundation aims to give the elderly greater control over their lives and provide them with a higher quality of life.

site_title: Marco Polo wins unanimous support as it fends off downturn
summary: Marco Polo Marine, a Singapore-listed offshore and marine company, has secured majority support from its noteholders and creditors to undertake a restructuring plan. The plan involves severe haircuts, with creditors agreeing to forgive 69% of debt and term out trade debts for three years. In exchange, the company will issue new shares at 3.5 Singapore cents per share. The restructuring is a step towards injecting S$60 million in new equity and has given hope to Singapore's battered O&M sector, which has seen solvencies for other companies like Ezra Holdings and Swiber Holdings.

site_title: Tech sector shines in Q3 earnings, banks could be weaker in Q4
summary: The technology sector reported stronger-than-expected growth in Q3 earnings, with 197 companies outperforming and 134 underperforming. The sector's aggregate earnings rose 22.7% year-over-year, driven by companies like Venture Corporation, which saw a 135% surge in net profit. In contrast, the banking sector may face a weaker performance in Q4, with some analysts citing concerns over excess provisions and non-performing assets. Meanwhile, the property sector had a mixed quarter, with developers experiencing significant earnings swings.

site_title: Baidu jumps into smart speaker fray with Raven
summary: Baidu has unveiled a smart speaker called "Raven H" to enter the Chinese market, priced at 1,699 yuan (S$348). The device uses Baidu's DuerOS software and features a unique design with a detachable top deck for a touch-sensitive remote. Unlike popular US smart speakers, the Raven H resembles a column of cards and has a limited range of features, making it a more basic offering in the market dominated by Google and Amazon. The device will go on sale in December.

site_title: Vista Park seeking minimum S$350m in collective sale tender
summary: Vista Park condominium in Singapore is seeking a minimum of S$350 million in its collective sale tender. Owners could receive a premium of over 60% if the project is sold en bloc, with estimated prices ranging from S$1.16 million to S$3.5 million per unit. The site offers a unique blend of natural surroundings and proximity to Pasir Panjang MRT station. The tender closes on December 13, with Spanish Village and other condominium projects also launching their own en bloc sales in the coming days.

site_title: Preparing for the silver tsunami
summary: Countries worldwide are preparing for an "aging tsunami" as populations rapidly age, leading to increased demand for long-term eldercare. Experts discuss key issues such as dementia, active aging, and end-of-life care. Zulkifli Bin Baharudin, a Singaporean expert, emphasizes the importance of elderly individuals aging in their homes, rather than community hospitals, where they can maintain dignity. The experts' views highlight the need for improved eldercare systems to address the growing challenge of an aging population.

site_title: Noble Group gives details of US$428m loss from exceptional items after SGX queries
summary: Noble Group reported a US$428 million loss from exceptional items in its third-quarter results, primarily due to non-cash losses on non-current assets. The group's shareholding in Yancoal Australia was significantly diluted after a capital-raising exercise, resulting in a US$257.8 million loss. Noble also reported impairment losses of US$149.9 million and US$415.3 million on supply chain assets. The company attributed the losses to changes in accounting methods and the recycling of accumulated foreign exchange losses.

images.alt_text: The group's US$428m loss from exceptional items primarily relates to non-cash losses on non-current assets.

site_title: China move prompts HK traders to seek link fixes
summary: Hong Kong traders are lobbying Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd (HKEX) to address several issues with the cross-border stock links with mainland China ahead of the country's shares joining key MSCI Inc benchmarks. Key concerns include daily trading limits, an investor identity system, and holiday trading closures. Traders want to see daily quotas removed or increased to reduce tracking error risk, and a more detailed investor identity system that can identify trades at the fund level. These issues must be resolved by the end of the year to ensure a smooth transition.

site_title: All ready to do their part for ChildAid
summary: The 13th edition of ChildAid, a charity event featuring 196 child performers, is set to take place next week. The musical, titled "An Amazing Awesome Asian Adventure," tells the story of four children who embark on a journey around Asia to retrieve their stolen dreams. The event, organized by The Business Times and The Straits Times, will feature performances from India, China, and other countries, raising money for two children's charities. Child performers, including 9-year-old Jyotsnaa Jayashanker and 13-year-old Justin Poon Junjie, are excited to participate in the event.

site_title: Train services between Joo Koon and Tuas West extension will be suspended for up to a month
summary: Train services on the Tuas West Extension line will be suspended until Nov 20 due to ongoing investigations into a collision at Joo Koon Station on Wednesday. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) will separate the Tuas West Extension from the East-West Line for up to a month, providing bus bridging services instead. The suspension is necessary to allow further assurance checks on the new signalling system, following a software problem that caused the collision.

site_title: US import prices rise less than expected in October
summary: US import prices rose 0.2% in October, less than expected, due to a decline in food prices offsetting gains in imported petroleum and capital goods. Import prices excluding petroleum increased 0.1% and rose 1.4% over the past 12 months. A weak dollar may keep import prices outside petroleum supported, while export prices remained unchanged in October.

site_title: Tencent rises in HK after results top analysts' estimates
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd, the owner of WeChat, reported a 61% rise in third-quarter sales to HK$65.2 billion, exceeding analyst estimates. The company's shares rose 2.7% in early trading, driven by strong mobile gaming revenue and advertising sales. WeChat's monthly active users reached 980 million, with daily message traffic at 38 billion. Net income surged 69% to 18 billion yuan, with games contributing 84% of revenue growth. Tencent's investments in artificial intelligence, cloud, and other areas are expected to drive future growth.

site_title: Singapore startup unveils Asia's first robot trader for retail investors
summary: A Singapore startup, AlgoMerchant, has developed Asia's first robot traders for retail investors, offering six robot creations with different trading philosophies for the Singapore, Hong Kong, and US stock markets. Each robot invests in its respective market, marking a significant development in the region's investment landscape. The startup, which started in 2015, aims to provide users with automated trading and investment strategies.

images.alt_text: Co-founders of AlgoMerchant: (standing from left) Justin Tjoa and Leonard Lu. (seated from left) Rein Chua, Marco Raditya and Aditya Santoso. Their offering is believed to be a first for retail investors in Asia.

site_title: Norway fund pulling out of coal-fired power plants
summary: Norway's Storebrand, the largest private pension fund provider, has announced it will divest from 10 companies developing new coal-fired power plants, exceeding a gigawatt limit. This move follows enhanced divestment criteria, which also assesses companies with high coal fuel mixes. The affected companies include Genting International and Tenaga Nasional, with Storebrand pulling out a total of 145.6 million Norwegian krone. The move aims to challenge the coal industry and meet climate targets, with Storebrand CEO Jan Erik Saugestad stating that "if you put new steel in the ground, we're not with you."

site_title: Tai Wah Building sold en bloc for $84.89 million
summary: A private equity investment firm, Lucrum Capital, has purchased the Tai Wah Building in Killiney Road for $84.89 million, approximately $2,209 per square foot per plot ratio. The building, completed in the mid-1980s, will be redeveloped into a serviced apartment with commercial space on the first floor, subject to authorities' approval. The site's existing gross floor area of 39,809 sq ft exceeds the permissible plot ratio of 2.8 under the 2014 Master Plan. Edmund Tie & Company acted as the sole marketing agent for the sale.

site_title: IMDA, MAS to push career development of fintech professionals
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) and Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have partnered with six local universities and five financial associations to develop fintech talent. The partnership aims to equip Singaporeans with skills in infocomm technology and financial technology. The initiative includes research collaborations, new courses, mentorships, and hackathons to help students and professionals understand emerging fintech trends. Over 42,000 additional ICT professionals will be needed in the next three years, with the goal of building a deep fintech talent pool in Singapore.

site_title: Funding for Asean fintechs surging, with Singapore getting lion's share of outfits
summary: Funding for fintechs in Asean has surged, with Singapore receiving the majority of investments. The region's young and underbanked population is driving the growth, with payments and mobile wallets attracting the highest level of funding. The global fintech industry attracted over $24 billion in investment in 2016, with Asean's share increasing to $338 million year-to-date in 2017. Singapore's developed financial infrastructure and supportive regulatory policies have positioned the country as a preferred fintech hub, attracting investors and start-ups. The region's low banking penetration and underserved population also make it attractive for fintech companies to develop solutions.

images.alt_text: Singapore is home to the lion's share of the 1,228 fintechs in Asean, at 39 per cent, said Tracxn, a start-up research platform.

site_title: Manchester United reports 17.3% rise in Q1 revenue
summary: Manchester United reported a 17.3% rise in Q1 revenue to £141 million, driven by strong growth in broadcasting and commercial businesses. Adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation rose to £36.6 million. The club's participation in this season's Champions League contributed to the revenue increase.

site_title: Oei Hong Leong withdraws requisition notice to Raffles Education Corp
summary: RAFFLES Education Corp announced that Oei Hong Leong and Oei Hong Leong Art Museum Limited have withdrawn their requisition notice to convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on November 29, effectively canceling the proposed resolutions. The EGM will be immediately brought to a close, and no voting will be conducted. Shareholders are advised to exercise caution when dealing in the company's shares.

site_title: China's 'hard bones' reform-drive seen leaving expansion intact
summary: China's reform drive is gaining momentum, with top officials signaling that tackling excesses won't derail growth. The country's debt pile is rising, but economists are optimistic that reforms can address challenges without slowing expansion. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley predict a slowdown next year, but still forecast a 6.5% growth rate in 2018. China aims to achieve "near-stabilization" of its debt-to-GDP ratio by 2019 and high-income status by 2025, with policymakers focusing on preventing systemic risks and supporting the real economy.

site_title: US industrial output boosted in October by hurricane-related rebound
summary: US industrial output rose 0.9% in October, exceeding expectations, as industries affected by hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Nate resumed normal operations. The manufacturing sector increased 1.3% and the percentage of industrial capacity in use rose to 77.0%. The effects of the hurricanes contributed 0.60 percentage point to the overall change in industrial production. The revised industrial production data for the third quarter showed a 0.3% annual decline, lower than the previous estimate of a 1.5% drop.

site_title: Fighting piracy by fighting poverty
summary: Asia has seen the lowest number of reported piracy incidents at sea since 2007, with 85 reported in 2016, a 58% decrease from 2015. However, the battle for improved ship safety and crew/passenger protection is ongoing. Masafumi Kuroki, executive director of ReCAAP, emphasizes the need for continued cooperation to combat piracy and armed robbery. Despite progress, the threat remains, and Asia must remain vigilant to ensure the safety of maritime trade and travel.

images.alt_text: Philippine troops with the bodies of Abu Sayyaf militants after an encounter in Sulu province in September. The group's members have been described as poor and desperate.
Despite fewer incidents, the threat to maritime safety has escalated, says Mr Kuroki, citing a rise in fatal incidents.

site_title: Tesla to unveil electric big-rig truck in midst of Model 3 factory 'hell'
summary: Tesla is set to unveil a prototype electric big-rig truck, the Tesla Semi, on Thursday, which may be capable of self-driving and could help the company transition away from fossil fuels. The truck, with a working range of 320-480 km, faces challenges in terms of power capacity, weight, and cost, but could be a lucrative market. CEO Elon Musk has described it as a key project, despite concerns from analysts that it may be an expensive distraction for the company, which is struggling to produce the affordable Model 3 sedan.

site_title: Climate change treaty can still deliver, despite US pullout
summary: The 2017 UN climate change summit in Bonn, Germany, concluded with a focus on implementing the Paris Agreement despite the US pullout. The summit emphasized the "bottom-up" approach of the Paris Agreement, which allows countries to develop their own plans to meet emissions targets. Key highlights include the presence of 45 countries with economy-wide targets to reduce emissions and 86 countries with specific renewable energy targets. Morocco, the host country, showcased its success in harnessing renewable energy, aiming for 50% of its energy to come from renewables by 2030. The summit concluded that decentralized policies, international partnerships, and innovative solutions can help countries meet their climate commitments.

images.alt_text: Protesters outside the White House in June. Implementing Paris will require diverse, often decentralised policies by different economies. This flexible arrangement is more likely to yield results even with the exit of big players like the US as a result of Mr Trump's pullout.

site_title: Mugabe refusal to quit is said to stall Zimbabwe transition
summary: Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe's refusal to resign has stalled plans for a transitional government after the military seized power on Wednesday. The military wants Mugabe to step aside to avoid a coup and tension with the Southern African Development Community. Talks between Mugabe and mediator Father Fidelis Mukonori are ongoing, with the military seeking a deal to establish a transitional government and hold elections. The new leaders aim to revive the economy, which has declined under Mugabe's 37-year rule, and repair relations with Western countries and international lenders.

site_title: Banking body head warns about impact of BOJ negative rate policy
summary: Japan's banking industry head, Nobuyuki Hirano, warns that the Bank of Japan's negative interest rate policy could cause financial system disruption if prolonged. Hirano, chairman of Japanese Bankers Association, cites the "reversal rate" risk, where low interest rates harm financial institutions' lending income and intermediation function. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has mentioned this risk, but assures it's being monitored. Hirano expresses concern that this risk could emerge in the near future, highlighting the need for careful policy management to prevent financial system instability.

site_title: Darco to raise S$900,000 from share placement to significant shareholder
summary: Darco Water Technologies is raising S$900,000 through a share placement with significant shareholder Robert Stone, who will acquire 1.5 million new shares at S$0.60. This deal will increase Stone's stake to 18.13% and is mainly used to invest in public-private partnership water infrastructure projects. Net proceeds will be S$882,000, with 70% going towards new projects and 30% towards working capital.

site_title: CapitaLand buys US$38.9m site for its 11th residential project in Vietnam
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean property developer, has purchased a 14,474 sq m site in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, for US$38.9 million to develop an 870-unit residential project. The site, in District 4, is expected to be worth US$177 million and will feature retail space with views of the Saigon river and city skyline.

site_title: Two Nam Cheong units granted application for scheme of arrangement
summary: Malaysian shipbuilder Nam Cheong's key subsidiaries, Nam Cheong Dockyard and Nam Cheong International, have been granted an application for a scheme of arrangement to restructure their debts under the High Court of Malaya. The group must convene a creditors' meeting within 90 days to consider and approve the proposed plan, which aims to compromise between the units and their respective creditors. This decision aims to address the companies' debt issues and facilitate a restructuring process.

site_title: TalkMed's China unit to provide management services for Singapore Cancer Centre brand in China
summary: TalkMed Group's China unit, TalkMed China, has entered into agreements with Beijing New Hope Management to provide management services for the Singapore Cancer Centre brand in China. The three-year agreements allow the group to expand its operations and capitalize on demand for quality medical oncology services in China. TalkMed China will be paid a 4% management fee and has an exclusive right to provide management services. The agreements are expected to have minimal impact on the group's financials.

site_title: Number of new homes in England nears pre-crisis high
summary: The number of new homes in England reached nearly 220,000 in 2016-17, close to the pre-financial crisis peak of 223,530 units. This figure still falls short of the estimated 250,000 homes needed annually to meet demand, particularly in London. Finance Minister Philip Hammond faces pressure to boost housebuilding in his upcoming budget. The government is exploring alternative solutions, such as helping housing associations, as traditional builders struggle to meet demand. A long-standing housing crisis continues to affect younger people, forcing them to live with parents or rent far from work.

site_title: Indonesia unveils plan to roll out 1,000 eco-mosques by 2020
summary: Indonesia has launched a plan to establish 1,000 eco-mosques by 2020, aiming to promote sustainable practices and environmental education in Muslim communities. The initiative, launched by Vice President Jusuf Kalla, will see mosques source renewable energy, manage resources sustainably, and reduce waste. The project is expected to boost environmental awareness and provide a model for other countries to follow, as Indonesia has a mixed environmental record due to deforestation and climate change.

site_title: Big Data fintech among winners of Global FinTech Hackcelerator
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced three winners of the Global FinTech Hackcelerator: Moxtra, a secure messaging service; Sqreem, a data analytics firm; and Trunomi, a fintech that enables customer data consent. The winners received a cash prize of S$50,000 each. The hackcelerator was part of the second Singapore FinTech Festival, which received 580 submissions from over 40 countries. MAS CEO Samuel Tsien urged fintech companies to consider their impact and responsibility, emphasizing the need to make technology a social leveller and not widen societal gaps.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Changjiang Fertilizer Holdings will hold an extraordinary general meeting on Dec 15 to vote on its transfer to the Catalist board. Spackman Entertainment Group has invested 250 million won in Korean film production company The Makers Studio. Malaysian shipbuilder Nam Cheong's subsidiaries have been granted a scheme of arrangement to restructure debts. TalkMed Group's subsidiary will offer management services for the Singapore Cancer Centre in China. Raffles Education Corporation has withdrawn a requisition notice to remove its founder and CEO.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

The article discusses various financial and business news. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall for H2, while London's Heathrow is considering increasing airport fees. In Indonesia, a Trafigura employee was detained in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS executive, is set to become OCBC's new CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are expanding their cooperation on green and transition finance. Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with CGSI downgrading Grab to a 'hold' due to expected slowing earnings growth.

site_title: China's Yixin posts strong HK debut amid tech IPO boom
summary: China's Yixin Group, backed by Tencent Holdings and JD.com, raised HK$6.77 billion in its trading debut, ending 6% higher. The IPO, which priced at the top of an indicative range, follows a string of successful tech floats in Hong Kong. This boosts the city's reputation for new listings, contributing to the tech IPO boom.

site_title: Ed Sheeran conquers sold-out crowd with Divide smash hits
summary: Ed Sheeran performed a sold-out two-night show at the Singapore Indoor Stadium, captivating a 10,000-strong crowd with his Divide smash hits. Despite fracturing his elbow and wrist just a month prior, Sheeran showed no signs of injury, delivering a high-energy 90-minute show with just his guitar and a loop pedal. The setlist featured 17 songs, mostly from his latest album ÷ (Divide), which boasts 10 UK Top 10 singles. The crowd, including reluctant boyfriends and husbands, was won over by Sheeran's charms and sing-along hits like Shape Of You, ending the show with the audience singing and dancing along.

site_title: Spackman Entertainment Group invests 250 million won in South Korean film production startup
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group has invested 250 million won (approximately SGD 309,171) in South Korean film production startup, The Makers Studio, owning 20% of the firm. The Makers Studio aims to produce and release four films between 2018 and 2020. The investment will strengthen Spackman's existing film production arm, leveraging its networks and resources to increase film visibility and distribution channels.

site_title: Scheme creditors give nod to Marco Polo's debt restructuring
summary: Marco Polo Marine has secured majority approval from its scheme creditors for its debt restructuring plan, with 75.5% of creditors voting in support. The plan calls for debt forgiveness towards S$258 million of liabilities to make way for S$60 million new equity. The company has also won a majority vote from its noteholders and has met the statutory requirement for its bank loans. The restructuring is a pre-condition for new equity injection into its business and will also term out trade debts for another three years.

site_title: New SUVs at Peugeot, Ford offset UK drag on Europe car sales
summary: European car sales rose 5.9% in October to 1.21 million vehicles, driven by new SUVs like Peugeot's 5008 and strong demand in France. This offset a seventh consecutive decline in UK sales. The euro-zone economy is expected to have its best annual performance in a decade, but UK concerns over Brexit are constraining western European sales. Full-year sales in western Europe are likely to be limited by UK sales, analysts predict.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rally after six-day retreat
summary: Tokyo stocks rallied on Thursday, rebounding from a six-day losing streak, with the Nikkei 225 index jumping 1.47% to 22,351.12 and the Topix index climbing 1.01% to 1,761.71. The rally was driven by bargain-buyers seeking to recover from the market's recent decline. This marked a positive trend in line with broader Asian advances.

site_title: Cyberthreat looms for UK banks as ring-fencing exposes data
summary: UK banks are vulnerable to cyber threats as the ring-fencing rules, aimed at protecting depositors, expose sensitive data. The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has warned banks of the risks, citing the potential for hackers to exploit changes to account data affecting about a million clients. The FCA's concerns come as banks prepare to implement the rules, which require lenders with over £25 billion in deposits to separate core services from riskier investment banking by 2019.

site_title: Housing shock conjures crisis ghost from 1990s to haunt Sweden
summary: Sweden's housing market is cooling, raising concerns of a potential repeat of the 1992 real estate crash that led to economic and banking crises. A boom in housing construction has slowed, with high-end developers selling off assets. Despite similarities, the current situation differs due to Sweden's strong economy, low unemployment, and higher bank capital buffers. The central bank has kept rates low to avoid deflation, and Governor Stefan Ingves remains vigilant on housing market risks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.88 points to 1,718.11. Volume reached 2.4 billion lots worth RM2.5 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 693 to 254.

site_title: Hong Kong defies bears as jobless rate drops to near 20-year low
summary: Hong Kong's jobless rate has dropped to its lowest level since 1998, defying economic skeptics. Employment data showed a tight labor market with further solid growth of the local economy. This follows positive data on GDP, retail sales, and real wages, which have all shown steady growth. Analysts had forecast "enormous stress" but the data indicates Hong Kong will continue to be a resilient economy, as predicted by Chuck Norris's character Josh Randall in the 1980s movie "Forced Vengeance".

site_title: Europe: Recovery rally for stocks as cyclicals make a comeback
summary: European shares rebounded, snapping their longest losing streak since October 2016, as cyclicals sectors made a comeback. The STOXX 600 index rose 0.4%, driven by financial services, basic resources, and technology sectors. French telecoms firm Bouygues led gains, while London-listed private equity firm 3i Group and Royal Mail also rose. However, facilities and catering firm Sodexo fell 4.9% after disappointing earnings results. The MSCI EMU index delivered 10.7% earnings growth in dollar terms for the third quarter.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.8% lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 27.4 points, or 0.8%, to close at 3,341.3 on Thursday, marking the fifth consecutive day of losses. Trading volume was 1.8 billion shares worth S$1.3 billion. Losers outpaced gainers 259-188, with the key index losing 0.8% in a day that saw investors remain cautious despite positive US market performance and a potential new funding round for eSIM platform Airalo.

site_title: Singapore gets lion share as fintech funding surges in Asean
summary: Fintech funding in ASEAN has surged, with Singapore receiving the lion's share, driven by the region's young and underbanked population. The sector has attracted $338 million in funding year-to-date 2017, a tenfold increase from 2012. Most funding comes from seed and angel investors, with payments and mobile wallets being the top focus area. The region's robust economic growth and young population are expected to drive investment, with digital platforms like e-commerce and Internet giants backing investments in the next unicorns of ASEAN.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Vista Park en bloc sale launched with an asking price of S$350m, offering unit owners a premium of over 60% compared to individual market sales. CapitaLand acquired a Ho Chi Minh City site for US$38.9m to develop a US$177m residences project. Singapore's Q3 GDP data is set to be released on November 23. IMDA and MAS signed a Memorandum of Intent to develop a talent pool in fintech. Trendlines partnered with National Healthcare Group to identify unmet clinical needs and develop technological solutions.

images.alt_text: Owners of Vista Park condominium project launched a collective sale tender on Thursday with an asking price of S$350 million, joining a spate of en bloc launches this week.

site_title: Twitter cracks down on verified accounts with new policy
summary: Twitter has updated its policies to remove verification of a user's identity without notice for behavior including promoting hate or inciting harassment. The company, citing criticism for verifying the account of Jason Kessler, who orchestrated the 2017 Charlottesville rally, is creating a new authentication program and reviewing current verified accounts to ensure users meet new guidelines. Twitter is no longer accepting public submissions for verification and is pulling the blue check mark at any time without notice.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise as Tencent hits a record on robust earnings
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.6% on Thursday, driven by Tencent's record high after posting a 69% jump in quarterly net profit. The Hang Seng index reached 29,018.76 points, with Tencent climbing over 2% and Ping An Insurance Group up 5.49%. The IT sector rose 1.9%, while the energy sub-index dipped 0.2%. The gains followed solid earnings reports from the Chinese internet giant.

site_title: Prudential's 9-month new-business profit rises
