summary: British life insurer Prudential reported a 17% increase in new-business profit to £2.47 billion for the first nine months of the year, driven by higher sales and favorable economics in its key markets of Asia, the US, and the UK and Europe. The company saw opportunities in the growing middle class in Asia, retirement needs of baby boomers in the US, and life assurance and savings markets in the UK and Europe. Gross annual premium equivalent sales rose to £5.17 billion, with Asia and the US driving the growth.

site_title: Sotheby's fails to sell 37-carat diamond as auction falters
summary: Sotheby's failed to sell the 37-carat Raj Pink diamond, a fancy intense pink diamond, at an estimated US$30 million, amid a volatile Geneva auction season. The auction, which also saw several other lots go unsold, contrasted with the strong performance of a Leonardo da Vinci painting sold for US$450 million at Christie's. The unsold lots included a US$18 million blue diamond ring and US$14 million yellow diamonds. The auction season's results have raised concerns about the diamond market.

site_title: IMDA, MAS to push career development of fintech professionals
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) and Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) signed a Memorandum of Intent to develop a talent pool skilled in infocomm technology with a focus on financial technology (fintech). The partnership aims to equip Singaporeans with the right skills for ICT jobs, including fintech research collaborations, new courses, mentorships, and hackathons. The move is expected to build a deep fintech talent pool in Singapore, driven by the strong demand for ICT professionals in the financial sector, which employed 24,300 ICT professionals in 2016.

site_title: Brexit deters some international staff from London tech firms - survey
summary: A survey by Tech London Advocates found that one in three London tech firms have struggled to secure international hires due to Brexit, with nearly two-thirds of entrepreneurs believing the vote has damaged the city's international reputation. Despite this, 60% of respondents still consider London the best place to start a tech company. The UK government has announced plans to increase the number of visas available to exceptional workers in areas like tech and science, aiming to keep the country competitive after Brexit.

site_title: Noble Group responds to SGX queries on US$428m loss in exceptional items
summary: Noble Group has responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange regarding a US$428 million loss in exceptional items in its third-quarter results. The loss primarily stems from non-cash losses on non-current assets, including a significant dilution of the group's shareholding in Yancoal Australia following a capital raising exercise. The company has provided a breakdown of the loss, which includes non-operational items such as impairment losses on supply chain assets from continuing operations.

site_title: Volkswagen, partners plan 10b euros China electric vehicles investment
summary: Volkswagen AG plans to invest over 10 billion euros with its partners to develop and manufacture electric vehicles in China, with the goal of introducing 40 locally produced vehicles by 2025. The investment will start production of electric vehicles in the first half of 2023 and sales will begin in the second half. This move follows Ford's investment in electric vehicle development in China, as the country's new-energy vehicle policy requires automakers to obtain a score linked to the production of zero- and low-emission vehicles.

site_title: AirAsia testing personalised baggage pricing, eyes more add-on revenues
summary: AirAsia is testing personalized baggage pricing and launching a travel money card to boost add-on revenues. The airline aims to increase revenue per passenger from add-ons by 22% by 2018, reaching RM60 per passenger. AirAsia Group CEO Tony Fernandes said the revenue target is ambitious but achievable with a US$100 million investment in digital initiatives, including a new duty-free website and reusable baggage tags. The airline uses data and machine-learning to tailor pricing to individuals, and a prepaid travel money card will be launched for South-east Asian travelers.

site_title: Renault, Toyota lead 5.9% European car sales gain
summary: European car sales rose 5.9% in October, driven by Renault and Toyota's strong performance. Renault posted a 17.6% increase, while Toyota's sales jumped 20.5%. PSA's combined sales of Opel, Vauxhall, Peugeot, Citroen, and DS brands rose 6.7% year-on-year. The UK saw a sharp decline in sales, contrasting with buoyant demand in France and southern Europe. The European market expansion this year now stands at 3.8%.

site_title: Vista Park en bloc sale launched with S$350m asking price; Spanish Village owners eyeing above S$810m
summary: Vista Park condominium owners launched a collective sale tender with an asking price of S$350 million, offering a premium of over 60% to individual unit sales. The site's unique surroundings, including its location at the edge of Kent Ridge Park and sea views, are expected to attract strong developer interest. Meanwhile, owners of Spanish Village condominium are also eyeing a collective sale, with a potential asking price of above S$810 million, and have appointed a marketing agent to start the en bloc process.

site_title: BHP Billiton eyes 2-year exit from shale; seeking buyer for nickel business
summary: BHP Billiton plans to exit its US shale business within two years, considering it non-strategic. The company also seeks a buyer for its nickel business in Australia, which CEO Andrew Mackenzie described as non-core. This move comes as oil and nickel prices experience a resurgence. The decision aims to focus on core businesses, allowing the company to optimize its operations and maximize returns.

site_title: China's outbound investment plunges as irrational deals curbed
summary: China's non-financial outbound investment declined 41% to $86.3 billion in January to October, the lowest level since 2010, due to curbed "irrational" deals. The Commerce Ministry reported no new real estate, sports, or entertainment deals during the period. The decline reverses a 44.1% surge in outbound investment last year, which was largely driven by capital controls and a crackdown on overseas mergers and acquisitions. Authorities aim to stabilize the yuan and maintain international influence through the Belt and Road program.

site_title: Emaar Properties to raise US$1.3b in development unit's IPO
summary: Emaar Development, a unit of Emaar Properties, priced its US$1.3 billion initial public offering (IPO) at 6.03 dirhams per share, below the mid-point of its indicative range. The IPO values the company at 24.1 billion dirhams and gives shareholders, including the UAE government, the opportunity to unlock the true value of the development business. The company aims to distribute US$1.7 billion in dividends over the next three financial years, with the first post-IPO dividend to be paid in 2018.

images.alt_text: Emaar Development, a unit of Dubai property firm Emaar Properties, priced its initial public offering below the mid-point of an indicative price range, valuing the deal at US$1.31 billion in Dubai's first major IPO in three years.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up but traders on edge after losses
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Thursday, with Tokyo up 0.8% and Hong Kong adding 0.4%, despite investor caution due to US tax reform struggles and concerns about high valuations. The optimism that pushed equities to multi-year highs last week has given way to caution. The US Senate's plan to repeal the Obamacare individual mandate has raised concerns that the tax reform bill could collapse, potentially hitting world equities. Oil prices crept up, but energy firms in Asia continued to struggle with the fallout of recent commodity losses.

site_title: Subaru recalls 400,000 cars in Japan
summary: Subaru recalls approximately 400,000 vehicles in Japan due to an inspection scandal involving uncertified staff at two factories. The recall affects nine models, including a sports car manufactured for Toyota, but vehicles sold overseas were not affected. This is the latest issue to hit Japan's beleaguered car industry, following similar scandals at other manufacturers. The recall is expected to have significant financial implications for Subaru.

site_title: Record HK$17.32b Hong Kong land sale shows market still hot
summary: A consortium led by Sino Land Co paid a record HK$17.32 billion for a residential land plot in Hong Kong, surpassing the previous record of HK$16.9 billion. The site, located in Cheung Sha Wan, has a maximum floor area of 91,770 square meters and is expected to be developed into a high-end residential project with ocean views. The record sale signals the property market remains hot, with commercial property also in demand, and is seen as a positive indicator for prices despite rising interest rates.

site_title: Yixin jumps on debut as tech fever grips Hong Kong market
summary: Yixin Group Ltd, an online car-loan provider backed by Tencent Holdings, made its Hong Kong stock market debut, jumping 32% on its first day of trading. The company's HK$6.8 billion IPO was sold at the top end of the marketed range, with massive interest from retail investors. Yixin's shares rose due to the company's strong fundamentals, not just the link to Tencent. The IPO has raised over US$4 billion this year, setting a new record for tech-related initial public offerings in Hong Kong.

site_title: Jitters send century-old Wharf's shares down after spinoff
summary: Wharf Holdings Ltd shares dropped 2% to HK$26.95 on the first day of trading excluding the spin-off of its US$29 billion commercial property unit. The shares had surged 28% in August after the spinoff plan was announced, but have since declined 10%. Analysts now question the valuation of the stock, citing concerns over the company's future focus and potential discount to its net asset value. The spinoff, Wharf Real Estate Investment Co, is set to start trading on November 23.

site_title: National Australia Bank sacks bankers over home-loan inaccuracies
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) fired 20 bankers and reprimanded dozens more for submitting home-loan applications with inaccurate or incomplete customer information. An extensive review found around 2,300 home loans since 2013 may not have been established in accordance with NAB's policies. The bank's chief customer officer described the incident as "unacceptable."

images.alt_text: National Australia Bank (NAB) said on Thursday it had fired 20 bankers and reprimanded dozens more for submitting home-loan applications that had inaccurate or incomplete customer information.

site_title: China, Philippines agree to avoid force in South China Sea dispute
summary: China and the Philippines have agreed to avoid force in resolving their differences over the South China Sea, a long-standing dispute. The agreement, made during a visit by Chinese Premier Li Keqiang to Manila, reaffirms the importance of peace and freedom of navigation in the region. The two countries will resolve the dispute through talks between relevant sovereign countries, rather than resorting to violence or threats. The agreement comes after improved relations between the two nations under Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte, and paves the way for the start of substantive negotiations on a Code of Conduct in the South China Sea.

site_title: Pfizer, Novartis agree UK price cuts for new breast cancer drugs
summary: Pfizer and Novartis have agreed to price cuts for their breast cancer drugs Ibrance and Kisqali to make them affordable for the UK's state-funded health service. The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (Nice) has recommended the use of the drugs despite uncertainty about their overall survival benefit. The price cuts bring the official list price down to £2,950, making the drugs more accessible to patients.

site_title: Singapore shares lower at Thursday break; STI down 0.4% to 3,354.73
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.4% to 3,354.73 at the mid-day break, with 917 million shares changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 175 to 162, led by ComfortDelGro and Wilmar International, which fell 2.87% and 2.17% respectively. Meanwhile, Cosco Shipping rose 3.51%. The Straits Times Index was down 13.97 points.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on solid foreign demand, won up
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.61% to 2,533.60 on Wednesday, driven by foreign investors' demand. The Korean won advanced to a 13-month high of 1,099.58 per US dollar, while bond yields fell. The Kospi has gained 24.3% this year and 6.06% in the past 30 days. Foreigners bought 209.16 million won worth of shares, while the US dollar has fallen 8.84% against the won this year.

site_title: Bombardier plans hiring spree for business jet programme: sources
summary: Bombardier plans to hire approximately 1,000 workers in Montreal over 18 months to support production of its new Global 7000 business jet. The hiring comes as the company ramps up production ahead of the jet's expected entry into service next year. This move is part of a larger effort by the Canadian plane and train maker to address a labor shortage in the aerospace industry, with Quebec facing a projected shortage of 32,000 aerospace positions over the next decade.

site_title: Fear and loathing in South Korea as university exam postponed by quake
summary: South Korea postponed its highly competitive university entrance exam for the first time due to safety concerns following a rare earthquake that damaged buildings, including some schools. The exam, seen as a "life assignment" for many high school seniors, is a crucial step in securing limited corporate jobs in the country. The one-week postponement has caused confusion and dejection among test-takers, who view a prestigious university on their resume as a minimum requirement for securing a job. The exam is set to resume on November 23.

site_title: Aussie shares take heart from Santos bid, NZ higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 5943.5, snapping a four-session losing streak, as Santos Ltd surged 13% after rejecting a $9.5 billion takeover bid. Financial stocks, including Big Four banks, also gained, while New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.4% led by consumer staples and utilities stocks. Australian employment data showed a 13th straight month of gains, with the jobless rate dipping to its lowest in over 4.5 years, while New Zealand's central bank ordered Westpac's New Zealand unit to boost capital levels.

site_title: Japan, US stage naval drill amid North Korea tension
summary: Japan and the US launched a 10-day joint naval drill in waters surrounding Okinawa, southern Japan, amid heightened tensions with North Korea. The exercise, joined by 14,000 US servicemen and several US warships, aims to increase defensive readiness and interoperability between Japanese and American forces. This comes after North Korea conducted its sixth nuclear test and test-fired advanced missiles, prompting US President Donald Trump to vow a global campaign of "maximum pressure" on the country. The drill is seen as a show of force to deter North Korea's nuclear ambitions.

site_title: Investment firm Kalnin Ventures not afraid of shale gas bear market
summary: Kalnin Ventures, backed by Thailand's Banpu Public Company Ltd, is investing heavily in the Marcellus shale gas formation in northern Pennsylvania, snapping up 55,000 acres over two years. Despite a bear market, the company is focusing on acquiring assets at discounted prices to generate cash. Its strategy aims to profit from the market's decline, rather than chasing growth, and seeks to return capital even as gas output dwindles and prices remain below their 10-year average.

site_title: Philanthropists can provide greater support to help seniors gain better quality of life: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Health Minister Gan Kim Yong emphasized the need for philanthropists to provide greater support to help seniors improve their quality of life. He identified three key areas: delivering care services, developing innovative products and services, and facilitating "last mile" delivery of care. With Singapore's population expected to age to one in four by 2030, the government aims to partner with philanthropists and community organizations to address the growing need for eldercare.

site_title: Hot stock: QT Vascular gains 5.88% after AngioScore settlement
summary: QT Vascular shares rose 5.88% after settling a long-standing dispute with AngioScore Inc., resolving patent infringement proceedings and uncertainties. The settlement aims to resolve all past, present, or future disputes. The company is also exploring potential asset sales, including the sale of its coronary assets to Medtronic. QT Vascular reported a narrower third-quarter net loss of US$3.73 million, with revenue increasing 58.7% to US$3.72 million. The settlement brings relief to the company, which was facing a potential US$20 million award to AngioScore.

site_title: Australia's Santos spurns US$7.2b takeover approach
summary: Australian gas producer Santos Ltd rejected a proposed takeover worth A$9.5 billion (S$9.8 billion) from Harbour Energy in August, citing the offer as "too cheap." Santos shares rose 13% following the news, sparking speculation of another bid. Harbour Energy, backed by private equity firm EIG Global Energy Partners, had also reportedly planned to increase its offer to A$5.30 a share. The rejection comes as gas demand is expected to surge in China, and a global LNG glut is expected to turn to a shortfall within five years.

site_title: China sets new rules for policy banks to curb risks
summary: China's banking regulator has set new rules for the country's three policy banks to curb risks, strengthening governance systems and capital restraint mechanisms. The rules, effective from 2018, aim to prevent systemic financial risks amid rising debt in the banking and corporate sectors. The three banks, with total assets of 25.12 trillion yuan, will establish capital adequacy ratios to manage risk. The move is part of Beijing's efforts to reduce financial risks and defuse housing bubbles, which could derail the economy if not handled well.

site_title: Trendlines ties up with National Healthcare Group to develop solutions for clinical needs
summary: Trendlines Group has partnered with National Healthcare Group (NHG) to develop technological solutions for unmet clinical needs. The partnership aims to identify key problem statements and develop innovative solutions, with potential startup companies to commercialize these solutions globally. Initial areas of collaboration include improving patient care, monitoring vital signs, and nutrition delivery. NHG will provide clinical infrastructure, while Trendlines will develop solutions, with the possibility of establishing companies in Singapore to bring these solutions to market.

site_title: Genting HK halts trading, pending announcement relating to disposal of Norwegian Cruise Line shares
summary: Genting Hong Kong halted trading of its shares on the Singapore bourse pending an announcement about the disposal of its shares in Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings. The company had previously announced it would delist its shares from the Singapore Exchange on April 17, 2018. Genting Hong Kong plans to focus on North Asia and increase its visibility among North Asian investors by listing on Hong Kong. The stock closed unchanged at US$0.23 on the day of the halt.

site_title: UK cyber security chief blames Russia for hacker attacks
summary: UK cyber security chief Ciaran Martin blames Russia for recent hacker attacks on the UK media, telecoms, and energy sectors. The attacks, part of Russia's alleged attempts to undermine the international system, include deploying fake stories and manipulated images. Martin's comments come amid reports of Russian interference in the Brexit referendum. The UK government is investigating Russian interference in UK politics, with parliament's committees requesting data from social media companies and interviewing executives.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tick higher at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.39% at the open on Thursday, following a two-day decline, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 28,963.77. Energy firms suffered losses due to falling oil prices. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.27% and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.16%.

site_title: MMP Resources to issue convertible bonds, place 8m shares with controlling shareholder
summary: MMP Resources, a Singapore-based investment firm, plans to issue convertible bonds and place 8 million shares with its controlling shareholder, Maiora Asset Management. The bonds will have a 12.5% annual interest rate and mature in 2021, while the shares will be priced at 0.53 Singapore cent each. The estimated net proceeds of S$114,500 will be used for investments in construction opportunities and operating expenses. MMP Resources will hold an extraordinary general meeting to obtain shareholders' approval for the deals.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as yen rises on US tax doubts
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.17% due to a rising yen against the US dollar amid concerns over a possible delay to US tax reform. The broader Topix index also declined 0.28%.

site_title: Philippines Q3 GDP grows 6.9% y-o, above forecast
summary: The Philippine economy grew 6.9% in the third quarter, beating forecast expectations of 6.5%. This is the fastest growth since 2018 and is attributed to strong industrial output and services. Economists had predicted a slight slowdown in the quarter, but the actual growth rate exceeded expectations. The country's GDP growth is expected to continue, with economists predicting annual growth of 6.5-7.0%.

images.alt_text: The Philippine economy grew by a faster-than-expected 6.9 per cent in the third quarter from a year earlier, supported by strong industrial output and services, the statistics agency said on Thursday.

site_title: SoftBank said to plan up to US$25b in Saudi investments
summary: SoftBank plans to invest up to $25 billion in Saudi Arabia over three to four years, with a focus on the Neom city project and state-controlled Saudi Electricity Co. The investments aim to diversify the economy away from oil and bolster Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's efforts to crack down on corruption. SoftBank's Vision Fund will deploy up to $15 billion in Neom and $10 billion in Saudi Electricity, with the potential to create a $300 billion asset management arm.

site_title: SRX Property launches free service to match clients with real estate agents
summary: SRX Property has launched a free service, myProperty Concierge, to match clients with real estate agents. The service uses "advanced algorithms" to connect clients with suitable agents based on their needs and goals. The goal is to provide a personalized match, but details about the algorithms remain unclear. This new service aims to simplify the process of finding a real estate agent in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore to release final Q3 GDP data on Nov 23
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Trade and Industry is set to release its third-quarter 2017 economic survey on November 23, providing the final growth figures for the July to September quarter. Advance estimates showed a 4.6% growth, the strongest pace since 2014, driven by manufacturing. The government's forecast for 2017's full-year GDP growth is expected to be revised upwards, potentially exceeding 3.4-3.7%, surpassing the official 2-3% range.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Thursday's open; STI down 0.12% to 3,364.78
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.12% to 3,364.78 at Thursday's open, following a decline in US and European stocks. Despite this, 72 gainers beat 61 losers, with 86 million shares changing hands. QT Vascular rose 11.8% after settling a patent infringement claim, while Wilmar lost 0.3% after announcing its results earlier in the week.

site_title: Here's how oil's spike will create winners and losers in Asia
summary: Oil prices are expected to create winners and losers in Asia as they pressure central banks to lift interest rates and fuel inflation. The region's economic growth, driven by an export boom, is already seeing inflation rise. Higher oil prices will increase food costs, affecting emerging Asia's inflation gauges, which average 38% and are higher in several markets. This could lead to policy changes, impacting the economy and markets in the region.

images.alt_text: The rally in oil prices is a potential game changer for inflation in Asia and will pressure central banks to lift interest rates after years of easy money.

site_title: Rajah & Tann partner Gregory Vijayendran re-elected Law Society president
summary: Gregory Vijayendran, a partner at Rajah & Tann, has been re-elected as Law Society president for 2018. Adrian Tan, a partner at Morgan Lewis Stamford, has been re-elected vice-president, while M Rajaram and Tito Shane Isaac have been elected vice-president and treasurer, respectively. Vijayendran's re-election marks the first time a non-senior counsel has led the society's governing team in over a decade.

site_title: Venezuela, in 'selective default', signs debt deal with Russia
summary: Venezuela signed a debt restructuring deal with Russia, restructururing $3.15 billion of debt taken out in 2011. The deal, which will pay back debts over 10 years, has been welcomed by Russia as "very favourable terms." However, S&P Global Ratings has placed Venezuela's state-owned oil company PDVSA in "selective default" due to missed interest payments, and Fitch has downgraded PDVSA and Venezuela. The country faces severe economic challenges, including food and medicine shortages, and a potential full default could have enormous consequences.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.17 points to 1,722.82. The market saw a higher volume of 84.52 million lots worth RM19.7 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 85 to 82.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS Group Research deems RHT offer price fair
summary: DBS Group Research deems Fortis Healthcare Limited's offer price for RHT's assets at 46.5 billion rupees (S$966 million) or S$0.90 a unit as fair, an 11% premium to the closing price. The price implies a 1.07 times price-net asset value ratio. Analysts believe the price is fair based on implied valuation, noting the first half 2018 distribution has not been declared.

site_title: Australia jobless rate hits near four-year low, wages still lag
summary: Australia's jobless rate dropped to 5.4% in October, the lowest since 2013, with 3,700 new jobs added. Full-time jobs rose 24,300, bringing annual gains to 298,000. However, wages still lag, with annual growth at 2% and a record low, and inflation remains below target. Economists say the labor market still has "plenty of slack," limiting wage pressure and making rate hikes unlikely until 2019.

site_title: World leaders plead for climate action at UN forum
summary: World leaders, including UN chief Antonio Guterres, French President Emmanuel Macron, and German Chancellor Angela Merkel, urged urgent climate action at the UN forum in Bonn, despite the US rejection of the Paris Agreement. A 12-year-old Pacific islander, Timoci Naulusala, shared his devastating experience with climate change, emphasizing the need for action. The leaders acknowledged the central challenge of climate change, labeling it "the defining threat of our time," and urged countries to implement the Paris Agreement to limit global warming to under 2°C.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble Group, Marco Polo Marine, CapitaLand, QT Vascular, Darco Water
summary: Noble Group is reorganizing under two subsidiaries, Kalon and Talaxis, to focus on rare earth and special ores markets. Marco Polo Marine won a majority vote to redeem S$50 million notes. CapitaLand acquired a site in Ho Chi Minh City for US$38.9 million to develop into US$177 million residences. QT Vascular reached a confidential settlement with AngioScore, while Darco Water Technologies raised S$900,000 through a placement of shares. These announcements may affect trading on Thursday.

site_title: Multilateral trade is in the interest of American companies
summary: US President Donald Trump's approach to multilateral trade has been a departure from his predecessor's stance, with the administration prioritizing bilateral trade deals over regional or multilateral agreements. Despite initial concerns, Trump's "America First" agenda has not led to a protectionist trade war with China, with several American companies announcing business deals in China during his visit. However, critics argue that Trump's approach undermines the multilateral strategy that has benefited American companies, as it fails to consider the complexities of global value chains and limits tariff concessions.

site_title: New Zealand consumer confidence falls in November: ANZ survey
summary: New Zealand's consumer confidence index fell to 123.7 in November, down from 126.3 in the previous month, as a slowing housing market and political uncertainty took a toll on optimism. The country's left-wing Labour government took office after a national election, adding to concerns about economic stability. Economists attribute the decline to "headwinds from the soft housing market, late cycle capacity pressures, and the uncertainty that political change can bring."

site_title: Broker's take: UOBKayHian sees Bumitama Agri outperforming palm oil peers
summary: UOBKayHian Research predicts Bumitama Agri will outperform its peers in the palm oil sector, driven by higher palm oil production in the fourth quarter, which will deliver the highest output growth among the four companies under its coverage. Bumitama maintained its 25% year-on-year growth guidance for fresh fruit bunches production, while First Resources and Golden Agri-Resources revised their production growth guidance downwards. UOBKayHian has a "buy" recommendation on Bumitama with a target price of S$1.03, citing the company's young tree age profile and strong production capabilities.

site_title: Australian diplomat dies after falling from New York balcony
summary: An Australian diplomat, Julian Simpson, 30, accidentally fell to his death from a 7th-floor balcony in New York City during a social gathering. He was playing a "trust game" with a house guest, but police say this detail has not been confirmed. Simpson, a junior diplomat with the Australian Mission to the UN, was pronounced dead at a hospital. The investigation is ongoing, and a toxicology report will determine if he was under the influence of alcohol at the time of his death.

site_title: Israel to tax Google, Facebook within a year
summary: Israel plans to tax internet giants Google and Facebook within a year, making it among the first countries to do so. The move aims to increase revenue for the country, with the goal of obtaining as much data as possible from these companies. This decision comes as the European Union struggles to form a unified policy on taxing tech giants, with France pushing for increased taxes and smaller EU member states opposing a broader international approach.

site_title: Gold drops slightly in choppy trade as dollar pares losses
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.2% to $1,277.51 after rising to a seven-week high, as the US dollar pared losses amid retail sales data showing a rise in underlying inflation. The US dollar's strength makes gold cheaper for holders of other currencies, while a weaker dollar also increases demand for gold. The outlook for US tax cuts was clouded after Senate Republicans linked repeal of Obamacare to tax reform plans, potentially delaying interest rate hikes and supporting gold prices.

site_title: Fed on collision course with bond markets in curve conundrum
summary: The Federal Reserve is facing a "curve conundrum" as it considers further interest rate hikes, with the Treasury market indicating a potential flattening yield curve that could derail the Fed's tightening path. A flattening yield curve could lead to short-term rates surpassing long-term rates, a scenario that could limit the Fed's ability to provide monetary stimulus. Experts warn that a drop in long-term market-based inflation expectations could signal a lack of confidence in the Fed's ability to hit its inflation target, potentially sparking an existential crisis for policymakers.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks rise, won steady
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 7.66 points or 0.30% to 2,525.91, while the won remained firm at 1,104.55 per US dollar. Bond yields fell, contributing to the market's stability. The KOSPI's steady performance was attributed to investors' positive sentiment despite uncertainty surrounding US trade policies.

site_title: Darco places 1.5m new shares at S$0.60 each to raise S$900,000 for pursuing projects
summary: Darco Water Technologies is raising S$900,000 through a placement of 1.5 million new shares at S$0.60 each. The placement price represents a 3.4% premium to the volume weighted average price. Following the placement, controlling shareholder Robert Stone's stake will increase to 18.13% from 15.99%.

site_title: Fear of glut grips commodities as Xi shifts China's economic focus
summary: China's economic focus is shifting towards quality over pace, raising concerns over a potential glut in commodities. The Bloomberg Commodity Index declined, with futures in China plummeting in overnight trading. The slowdown in China, the world's biggest consumer of commodities, is sparking fears of a raw materials surplus. This shift in focus may lead to weakening demand and a decrease in prices for commodities such as oil, aluminum, and gold. Beijing's efforts to calm price wars in the solar industry have also contributed to the market uncertainty.

site_title: Da Vinci sells for US$450m in auction record: Christie's
summary: Leonardo da Vinci's 500-year-old painting "Salvator Mundi" sold for a record-breaking US$450.3 million at Christie's auction in New York, surpassing the previous record held by Pablo Picasso's "The Women of Algiers (Version O)". The painting, believed to be one of fewer than 20 genuine Da Vinci works, was dated back to around 1500 and sold after just 18 minutes of frenzied bidding. The sale sets a new record for the most expensive piece of art sold at auction and has been at the center of a court battle between Russian billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev and Swiss art dealer Yves Bouvier over its authenticity and value.

images.alt_text: A 500-year-old work of art - believed to be by Leonardo da Vinci and depicting Jesus Christ - sold in New York on Wednesday for US$450.3 million, smashing a new art auction record, Christie's said.

site_title: Euro jumps to 3-week high as risk appetite returns
summary: The euro rose to a three-week high against the US dollar, reaching 0.4% at $1.1853, as investors regained risk appetite and grew skeptical about the prospects of the US tax plan. European economic growth, led by Germany, exceeded the US in the third quarter, bolstering the euro's gains. Dollar weakness and concerns about the US tax plan also contributed to the euro's rise.

site_title: US dollar on back foot as tax deal doubts weigh, Aussie looks to jobs data
summary: The US dollar weakened to a 4-week low, falling 0.6% to 93.851, amid doubts over tax reforms. A Senate Republican tax plan drew criticism from two lawmakers, potentially hindering its passage. Meanwhile, the Australian dollar hovered near four-month lows ahead of key jobs data.

site_title: Televisa, Globo paid Fifa bribes for 2026/2030 World Cup rights: trial witness
summary: A trial witness in a US corruption case testified that Mexico's Grupo Televisa and Brazil's Globo paid $15 million in bribes to secure media rights to the 2026 and 2030 World Cup tournaments. Alejandro Burzaco, former head of sports marketing company Torneos y Competencias, said Televisa, Globo, and Fox Sports were involved in the bribery. The companies have not been charged, and their lawyers denied taking bribes.

site_title: Serena Williams set to tie the knot in New Orleans: reports
summary: Tennis superstar Serena Williams is set to tie the knot with Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian in New Orleans. The intimate ceremony, attended by 250 A-list guests, is reportedly costing over $1 million. The event will feature a photo deal with Vogue, with guests instructed not to bring their cell phones. Williams, 36, and Ohanian, 34, welcomed their first child in September 2017 and announced their engagement in December 2015. The wedding planning has been shrouded in secrecy, with guests only learning details on Thursday morning. The ceremony will take place at the Contemporary Arts Centre.

site_title: Trump defends Asia trip, vows 'maximum pressure' on North Korea
summary: US President Donald Trump defended his recent Asia trip, vowing a "maximum pressure" campaign on North Korea. Trump said he successfully galvanized opposition to North Korean proliferation, with Chinese leader Xi Jinping agreeing to use Beijing's economic leverage to denuclearize the Korean peninsula. Despite criticism of the trip's lack of achievements, Trump claimed the trip showed America's return to global prominence, with warm hospitality and respect from foreign hosts. However, a Democratic senator criticized Trump's approach, saying he failed to make meaningful progress on critical issues.

site_title: Foxconn's Q3 profit tumbles 39% after iPhone X production hurdles
summary: Taiwan's Foxconn reported a 39% decline in quarterly profit due to production bottlenecks for the iPhone X, with margins squeezed by suppliers struggling with new features. Despite strong demand for the product, Foxconn's profit slide was attributed to labor idled due to a later-than-usual launch and a stronger yuan. Revenue remained flat, and shares fell 2.8% in trade, marking Foxconn's first quarterly decline in a year. Apple predicted strong holiday sales for the iPhone X, but most analysts expect a recovery in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Changjiang Fertilizer to hold EGM on Dec 15 to vote on transfer to Catalist
summary: Changjiang Fertilizer Holdings will hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on December 15 to vote on its transfer to the Catalist board. The meeting will also consider proposed acquisitions, a share consolidation plan, and the disposal of several subsidiaries. Shareholders will vote on resolutions including the acquisitions of WBH, CT8, and Kempas, as well as the disposal of JC Miluo, Changjiang Huafei, Huafei Hanshou, and Tangjia Electric at a minimum consideration of one yuan.

site_title: Indonesia amends contracts with 13 coal mining companies
summary: Indonesia has amended contracts with 13 coal mining companies, including US giant Freeport, to transition to new mining permit systems. The changes aim to simplify regulation and boost government revenues, with companies agreeing to pay 13.5% royalties on coal sales. The amendments will take effect immediately for some contracts and in 2018 for others, with the government expecting a US$68 million increase in state revenue.

site_title: Nafta negotiators open fifth round of talks - early
summary: Negotiators from Canada, Mexico, and the US began their fifth round of talks on the updated North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) on Wednesday, two days before the scheduled start. The talks aim to address issues such as a five-year sunset clause and auto content requirements. US President Donald Trump has demanded renegotiation of the 1994 trade pact, threatening to withdraw if unsatisfied. The negotiations come amid increased tension over US proposals and follow a previous round held in Washington in October.

site_title: Electronics surge expected to continue in 2018; global outlook rosy
summary: Singapore's electronics manufacturing sector is expected to continue its strong growth in 2018, driven by new product launches and strong global demand for electronics, particularly semiconductors. The sector's performance has prompted economists to upgrade their forecasts for Singapore's economic growth this year and next, with some expecting a 3.2% growth rate in 2017 and 3% in 2018. Despite challenges such as rising business costs and disruption from emerging technologies, manufacturers remain optimistic about the outlook, with some expecting revenue to increase by 3-5% in 2018.

site_title: Strong home demand in outer Australian cities prolongs building boom
summary: Strong demand for new homes in outer Australian cities is prolonging a building boom. Home prices have doubled in Sydney since 2008, driving buyers to the fringes for cheaper land. Construction approvals have reached an 18-month high, reversing a downward trend, and creating a labor shortage. Builders are using alternative products like aerated concrete panels to keep up with demand, and median residential land values have reached a record high. The construction surge is supporting the economy and stoking demand and jobs in the building industry.

site_title: Olam forecasts higher coffee prices, Q3 profit up 18%
summary: Olam International, a leading coffee trader, forecasts higher coffee prices due to a robusta market shortfall and a possible La Nina occurrence, which could lead to a shortage of four million bags per season. The company reported a 17.5% growth in Q3 net profit and a 41.7% increase in revenue to S$6.71 billion. Olam generated a free cash flow of S$1.11 billion in the first nine months of the year, driven by working capital optimisation measures.

site_title: US: Stocks drop as weak oil prices drag down oil shares
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.6% to 23,261.27, due to concerns over President Trump's tax cut proposal and weak oil prices. Analysts fear the proposal's complexity may delay or derail the measure, with the Senate considering repealing the Obamacare individual mandate. Petroleum producers declined, while General Electric and Bank of America gained 2.0% and 2.1% respectively.

site_title: Manulife's S$500m green bond is third to hit Singapore market
summary: Manulife sold a S$500 million 3% green bond, the first benchmark-sized Singapore dollar green bond issue, attracting S$700 million in orders. The bond is certified as climate bonds by the Climate Bonds Initiative, marking the first green bond issuance globally by a life insurance company. However, the slow pace of green bonds issuance in Singapore is attributed to an onerous certification process and a small investor base. Experts believe awareness and commercial demand need to increase for green bonds to gain traction in the market.

site_title: RHT shares soar on its move to sell assets for close to S$1 billion
summary: RHT Health Trust's shares surged 10.5% to S$0.895 after the trust announced exclusive talks with Fortis Healthcare to sell its India-based assets for approximately S$964 million. The deal, valued at 46.5 billion Indian rupees, is expected to be completed in six to nine months. The trust's trustee-manager plans to distribute "substantially" the net proceeds to unit holders, addressing investors' concerns over the trust's future growth potential.

site_title: Pan-European Reit takes Singapore IPO leap
summary: Pan-European Reit, Cromwell European Reit (Cereit), is set to launch its initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore, aiming for 865.7 million euros (S$1.39 billion) in gross proceeds. The IPO was delayed and some Polish properties were dropped from the portfolio due to investor concerns over the unfamiliar market. The Reit's portfolio will focus on western Europe, with 74 properties worth 1.35 billion euros, and a distribution yield of 7.8% for the coming year. Trading is expected to start on November 30.

site_title: Mattel declines on report that it rebuffed approach from Hasbro
summary: Mattel Inc declined in late trading after it reportedly rebuffed a takeover approach from rival Hasbro Inc, citing concerns over the deal's value and potential antitrust challenges. The shares dropped as much as 7.3% to $16.99 following the report, which comes after speculation about a potential merger began in October. The move follows Mattel's sharp sales decline last quarter, prompting the company to suspend its dividend and accelerate cost-cutting efforts.

images.alt_text: Mattel Inc slipped in late trading on a report that it rebuffed a takeover approach from rival Hasbro Inc, spurning a deal that could have created the largest US toymaker.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Envictus International Holdings' subsidiary Polygold Holdings has entered a conditional share sale agreement to acquire Motivage for RM24 million (S$7.8 million). The deal involves a cash payment of RM5 million and the issuance of 15.78 million shares at S$0.3913 per share, representing an 11.1% stake in Envictus. The acquisition aims to "fully and finally resolve all past, present or future disputes" between the parties.

site_title: Sergio Garcia eyes strong finish at Dubai season finale
summary: Spanish golfer Sergio Garcia is set to compete in the DP World Tour Championship in Dubai, where he will face a three-way battle with Fleetwood and Rose. Garcia is in contention to finish the season as European No 1 and clinch the Race to Dubai title. He is just three golfers away from winning the championship, and a win would also secure his first European No 1 finish.

site_title: Warning: Dodgy coin offerings could tar reputation of blockchain technology
summary: A forum at the Singapore FinTech Festival warned that the growing trend of initial coin offerings (ICOs) is threatening to tarnish the reputation of blockchain technology. Panellists cautioned that the market's frothiness and lack of regulation could lead to scams and damage the industry's credibility. They advised investors to be cautious and not to get caught up in the hype, comparing it to the infamous "Do not collect $200" line from the movie "The Great Escape."

site_title: Homeowners, developers willing to pay more for green buildings: survey
summary: A survey by the Building & Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore found that 70% of homeowners and 72% of developers are willing to pay more for green buildings, with homeowners willing to pay 3-4% more and developers willing to pay up to 5%. The survey also found that green buildings result in lower utility bills, reduced environmental impact, and better health benefits. The BCA plans to partner with the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory to develop zero energy buildings and export its expertise to the region.

site_title: MMP Resources - all 'snowed in'?
summary: MMP Resources, a Singapore-listed firm, has been struggling with consecutive years of losses, prompting the Singapore Exchange to place it on its watch list for non-compliance with minimum trading price rules. The company has undergone significant changes in its business and leadership, including a name change and multiple boardroom appointments. Its stock price has plummeted, and it faces a three-year deadline to improve its fundamentals or risk being delisted. The firm's controlling shareholder, Maiora Asset Management, has entered into advisory services agreements with MMP, raising concerns about potential conflicts of interest.

site_title: Novena Global buys 4 Singapore eyecare clinics, majority stake in Taiwan's Hexin Group
summary: Novena Global Lifecare Group has acquired four eyecare clinics in Singapore and a majority stake in Taiwan's Hexin Group, the third-largest healthcare screening provider in Taipei. The acquisition allows Novena Global to manage and oversee healthcare screening services in major hospitals, with a focus on growing the market in Taiwan. The deal is part of Novena Global's plans to expand beyond its medical aesthetics business, which owns over 100 clinics in Asia. The acquisition is valued at a multimillion-dollar deal, and will enable Novena Global to develop new "lifecare" products and solutions for consumers.

site_title: Vancouver imposes sharp curbs on Airbnb, homesharing sites
summary: Vancouver has implemented new rules banning the listing of unoccupied homes, entire condos, and secondary suites on short-term rental websites like Airbnb. Homeowners can rent out a room in their primary residence or temporarily rent their primary residence for a licensing fee. The rules aim to free up 1,000 units for long-term rentals and provide a framework for homeowners using websites like Airbnb. The move is part of Vancouver's efforts to address a housing shortage and soaring rents, with prices jumping 75% in five years.

site_title: Shortage of butter chills France's patisserie-loving soul
summary: France is experiencing a shortage of butter, sparking panic among bakers and threatening the country's patisserie industry. Supermarket shelves have been emptied, and prices are rising, potentially leading to a "croissant crisis." The shortage is attributed to various factors, including global demand and supply chain issues. The situation has left French patisseries in a state of crisis, with the French way of life potentially at risk.

site_title: New Barbie is modelled after hijab-wearing US Olympian
summary: The Mattel company has introduced a new Barbie doll modeled after US Olympian Ibtihaj Muhammad, who wears a hijab. The doll, part of the "Shero" line, features dark skin, athletic build, and a hijab, reflecting Muhammad's own experiences as a Muslim woman athlete. The doll's introduction has sparked a range of reactions, including both praise and criticism, with some expressing concern over the potential backlash. Mattel's goal is to promote diversity and inclusivity in the Barbie line, which has long been criticized for its lack of representation.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit 8-week lows as commodity weakness weighs
summary: European shares hit an 8-week low, falling 0.4% to their lowest level since September 20, as commodity stocks declined due to weaker metal prices and lower crude oil prices. The Stoxx 600 index closed at its seventh straight session of losses, with autos and mining stocks among the biggest losers. However, Airbus rose 2.4% after winning a record plane deal worth $49.5 billion. Despite the losses, the Stoxx 600 is still up nearly 6% this year, with Deutsche Bank strategists expecting a pull-back in the coming months.

site_title: China corruption could lead to Soviet-style collapse, says graft buster
summary: China's second most senior graft buster, Yang Xiaodu, warns that the country's battle against corruption is crucial to prevent a Soviet-style collapse. In an editorial, Yang said that if corruption is not addressed, the party's leadership will weaken, and the country's ideology will become apathetic. The editorial comes as President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption efforts intensify, with plans for a national supervision law and a new commission next year. Yang emphasized that the fight against corruption must continue, with no retreat or pause, to safeguard the country's future.

site_title: CapitaLand buys Ho Chi Minh City site for US$38.9m to develop US$177m residences
summary: CapitaLand buys a 14,474 sq m site in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam for US$38.9 million to develop a US$177 million residences project, consisting of 870 units and retail space. The project will be its 11th residential development in Vietnam, expanding the company's portfolio to 11 developments, 21 serviced residences, and one international office development. The acquisition is part of CapitaLand's strategy to diversify its portfolio and strengthen its foothold in Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of the 870-unit residential development. Capitaland has bought a 14,474 square metre site in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, for US$38.9 million, to develop into residences.

site_title: Airbus seals record US$50 billion jet deal to outdo Boeing in Dubai
summary: Airbus announced a record-breaking $50 billion deal for 430 A320neo planes with US investor Indigo Partners, outdoing Boeing's $20 billion mega-deal. The pact marks a turnaround for Airbus and more than doubles its previous order book for the year. The deal features 273 A320neo jets and 157 A321neo variants, and is worth $49.5 billion before customary discounts. The transaction boosts Airbus's backlog above 7,000 jets and reverses expectations that orders will trail deliveries in 2017, pushing the European planemaker ahead of Boeing in the order tally this year.

site_title: AT&T engages its Washington firepower with mega-deal for Time Warner on the line
summary: AT&T's $85.4 billion bid for Time Warner faces uncertainty as the Justice Department questions the combined company's potential for too much power. AT&T is fighting an increasingly public battle with Justice Department officials, and the company is increasing its lobbying efforts in Congress. The merger has drawn President Donald Trump's ire, particularly over the CNN unit. AT&T's CEO has vowed not to sell the CNN unit, and the company is seeking a settlement or a court victory. The outcome is uncertain, with some experts warning of a protracted battle.

site_title: Businesses see GDP growth racing past official forecasts
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow at a rate of 3.4-3.7% in 2017, surpassing the government's forecast of 2-3%, according to a BT-SUSS Business Climate Q3 survey of 164 firms. Despite this, businesses remain cautious about the next six months, with a net balance of -9% indicating expansion. The manufacturing sector continues to perform well, and firms are optimistic about business prospects in Singapore, with 9% expecting growth. However, overseas business activities have weakened, and domestic activities have strengthened, with Singapore's expansion rate outpacing other developed countries.

site_title: Great Eastern's Khoo Kah Siang joins Manulife as Singapore head
summary: Khoo Kah Siang, former head of business development and regional bancassurance at Great Eastern Holdings, has joined Manulife Singapore as its new head, pending regulatory approval. This move comes as part of a senior management shake-up at Great Eastern, which has seen seven senior executives leave in the past 18 months. Khoo's departure will impact Great Eastern's operations in Singapore, while Manulife gains a well-regarded actuary with experience driving the life business in Singapore.

site_title: In brief
summary: Singapore and Poland's Monetary Authority and Financial Supervision Authority have signed a FinTech Co-operation Agreement, outlining a framework for cooperation and referrals between the two regulators. The agreement aims to support fintech companies in understanding regulatory regimes in each jurisdiction. Additionally, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced a new S$27 million grant to promote the adoption and integration of artificial intelligence (AI) and data analytics in the finance sector, with a focus on workforce development and research projects.

site_title: Becoming a global technology hub
summary: Singapore aims to become a global technology hub, leveraging government funding, infrastructure support, and talent. The country has already gained recognition for its startup talent, surpassing Silicon Valley. Recent collaborations with tech giants like Alibaba and Nasdaq have strengthened its position. To achieve this goal, Singapore needs robust funding platforms, a seamless pathway for private and public fundraising, and education and collaboration between finance and technology. With its size and connectivity, Singapore is well-positioned to become a leading technology hub, potentially shifting the centre of gravity for tech from the US to Asia.

site_title: Tencent delivers a blowout quarter as Honour of Kings shines
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd reported its strongest growth in over seven years, with a 61% rise in revenue to 65.2 billion yuan (S$13.3 billion) in the September quarter. The company's mobile gaming revenue increased 84% thanks to the success of games like Honour of Kings. Net income surged 69% to 18 billion yuan, beating projections. Tencent's advertising and finance business on WeChat expanded rapidly, with online advertising sales growing 48% in the quarter. The company is investing in artificial intelligence research and expanding into new areas such as cloud, financial services, and movies and music.

site_title: Zurich Insurance expects rising prices to boost delivery on targets
summary: Zurich Insurance confirmed its 2017-2019 financial targets, citing improved insurance pricing due to recent natural catastrophes. CEO Mario Greco stated that rising prices would boost the company's ability to deliver on its goals. Zurich aims to achieve $700 million in expense savings, improve underwriting performance, and increase return on equity to over 12%. The company is focused on delivering an attractive and growing dividend, with cost-cutting goals previously upped to $1.5 billion by 2019.

site_title: Tax aftershock creates widening two-speed economy in India
summary: India's largest tax overhaul, the Goods and Services Tax (GST), has created a two-speed economy, where bigger companies have adapted to the new levies and gained market share, while small businesses are struggling. Since its introduction on July 1, 2017, companies like Titan Co Ltd and Maruti Suzuki India Ltd have used the disruptions to gain market share, while a vast swathe of small businesses, representing almost half the economy, are struggling to adapt.

images.alt_text: A supporter of India's ruling BJP with a placard during a rally to support implementation of the GST in Mumbai on June 30. The tax's disruptive roll-out and concerns about a widening gap between better-run companies and the laggards poses a challenge to the PM.

site_title: Noble starts talks on capital structure; reorganises rare earths, special ores activities
summary: Noble Group has initiated talks with stakeholders to address its capital structure and liquidity position, amid market speculation of debt restructuring. The discussions aim to optimise cash usage and treat stakeholders fairly. The company is also reorganising its rare earths and special ores activities under two subsidiaries, Kalon Resources and Talaxis, to capture growth opportunities. Noble reported a net loss of $1.2 billion for the quarter and has $256 million in cash and short-term deposits, but Moody's expects the firm to struggle with sustaining positive cash flow due to weak underlying profitability.

images.alt_text: Noble says the principles in its talks with stakeholders are in line with the group's objectives of managing the maturity of its borrowings to optimise the use of available cash for the foreseeable future, and treating all stakeholders fairly.

site_title: Japan chalks up best winning streak since 2001 on export boost
summary: Japan's economy expanded for a seventh consecutive quarter, its longest expansion since 2001, with a 1.4% annualized growth rate in the third quarter. Exports and business investment boosted growth, while consumer spending declined 0.5%. The economy continues to expand above its potential growth rate, driven by fiscal stimulus and monetary easing. Despite low inflation, economists expect higher wage gains and consumer price increases as the labor market tightens. The Bank of Japan is unlikely to alter its policy settings, and Prime Minister Abe's planned economic package may gain momentum.

site_title: En bloc fever rages as Pearlbank aims for S$728m
summary: Pearlbank Apartments, a 37-storey iconic development in Outram, Singapore, is up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$728 million. This is the fourth attempt at an en bloc sale. Other developments, including Parkway Mansion, Derby Court, and Riviera Point, are also being sold. Owners are expected to receive minimum gross prices of between S$1.8 million and S$4.9 million, with potential proceeds of up to S$6.9 million. The sale is seen as part of the en bloc fever, with 16 private residential estates already being put up for sale in the past seven months.

images.alt_text: The owners of Parkway Mansion (left) could receive between S$4.2m and S$4.4m while owners of Pearlbank (right) stand to receive minimum gross prices of between S$1.8m and S$4.9m.

site_title: Vietnam govt aims to complete Sabeco stake sale in Dec
summary: Vietnam's government plans to complete the sale of its majority stake in Sabeco, the country's largest brewer, in December. The sale, worth trillions of dong, will be conducted as a public auction and follows a formal divestment plan approved on November 9. Sabeco's high demand and limited float have complicated the sale, with the stock price rising nearly 150% since its December listing price. The sale is part of Vietnam's broader privatisation effort, which aims to tap into the country's attractive beer market.

site_title: Businesses need to consider different ways of handling IP
summary: Businesses must adapt to the rapidly changing landscape of innovation, where intellectual property (IP) is no longer a one-way street. As technology advances at an exponential rate, companies must consider alternative ways of handling IP, such as partnerships, shares, and equitable distribution of winnings. This approach fosters a culture of collaboration, open-handedness, and giving, leading to better employee retention, customer satisfaction, and higher profits. A giving culture, modeled by leaders, is essential for driving innovation and success in today's competitive market.

site_title: Consumer prices edge up; retail sales increase unexpectedly
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.1% in October, edging up from the 0.5% increase in September, due to a decline in gasoline prices. Despite this, underlying inflation pressures remain steady, with rising rents and healthcare costs. Retail sales unexpectedly increased 0.2% last month, driven by heavy price discounting by automobile manufacturers. This data suggests the Federal Reserve will likely raise interest rates next month, as low inflation helps underpin consumer spending. The year-on-year core CPI rose to 1.8%, in line with economists' expectations.

site_title: Buffett-backed BYD to open electric-truck plant in Canada
summary: BYD Co, a Chinese electric-vehicle maker backed by Warren Buffett, plans to open its first assembly plant in Canada, anticipating a surge in demand for electric trucks from municipalities and businesses. The plant, set to open next year in Ontario, will hire about 40 people and start with short-range vehicles such as garbage and delivery trucks. BYD's move comes as countries shift to electric vehicles to combat climate change, with Canada offering thousands of dollars in rebates to electric-vehicle buyers.

site_title: High Court approves Pan-United Corp's proposed capital reduction
summary: Singapore's High Court has approved Pan-United Corp's proposed capital reduction and distribution, allowing the company to reduce its capital and distribute the funds to shareholders. The move follows the planned spin-off of its ports business Xinghua to be listed in Hong Kong and a rights issue to pay off port-related debt. Upon completion, PanU will undergo a capital reduction exercise, returning funds to shareholders through the distribution of its Xinghua shares.

site_title: Airbnb said to double net revenue to US$1b in Q3 as it plans IPO
summary: Airbnb doubled its net revenue to $1 billion in the third quarter, marking the company's 17th consecutive profitable quarter. The San Francisco-based home-rental company remains on track to file for an initial public offering (IPO) next year. Despite concerns about growth from Morgan Stanley, Airbnb's global expansion, including a 60% increase in bookings in Latin America and Asia, suggests the company is meeting its growth targets. The company is also expanding into new product categories, such as luxury accommodations and guided tours, to compete with larger travel companies.

site_title: Nations need to forge their way in a new world order
summary: Harvard economist Dani Rodrik argues that it's impossible for nations to have full sovereignty, democracy, and globalization simultaneously. He claims that too much globalization erodes democratic nation-states' sovereignty, potentially allowing authoritarian regimes to thrive. Rodrik's concept, the "political trilemma of the world economy," highlights the tension between these three ideals, suggesting that finding a balance is crucial in the evolving global landscape.

site_title: 28 hurt after 2 MRT trains collide at Joon Koon
summary: Two MRT trains collided at Joo Koon station in Singapore due to a software glitch in the signalling system of the East-West Line. The incident resulted in 28 injuries, with 26 commuters and 1 SMRT staffer on the first train, and 1 SMRT staffer on the second train. The glitch mistakenly profiled the stalled train as a three-car train, causing the second train to misjudge the distance and collide. The incident is under investigation, with Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan calling for a thorough check of the system before resuming operations.

site_title: Clients benefit when the insurance industry goes digital
summary: The insurance industry is shifting towards digitalization, enabling customers to manage their insurance needs more easily and directly. Traditional agents are losing influence, and customers are turning to online platforms to compare and purchase insurance products. Regulatory bodies, such as the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), have implemented guidelines to protect consumers from potential mis-selling and "churning" of policies. Direct Purchase Insurance (DPI) and online life insurance platforms have been introduced to cater to the needs of tech-savvy and self-directed customers, offering simpler and more affordable insurance options.

site_title: Canada home sales edge up in October, but prices fall
summary: Canada's housing market stabilized in October with resales rising 0.9% from September, but home prices fell 1% from the previous month, according to the Canadian Real Estate Association. This decline follows tighter mortgage rules and a foreign buyers' tax in Toronto. Despite a 4.3% drop in actual sales from October 2016, home prices rose 9.7% from a year earlier. Experts warn of a potential housing bubble correction, with some regions experiencing price declines, while others continue to rise. Mortgage tightening and interest rate hikes are expected to slow the market further.

site_title: Chinese AI startup SenseTime seals investment deal with Qualcomm
summary: Chinese AI startup SenseTime has sealed an investment deal with chipmaker Qualcomm as part of a funding round valued at around $2 billion. The deal, announced last month, aims to collaborate on AI and deploy SenseTime's proprietary algorithms in smart devices. The startup, which employs AI for facial recognition, has raised over $820 million in funding and counts 40 local Chinese governments as clients. SenseTime plans to expand overseas, including a possible Asean headquarters in Singapore, and is seeking to deploy its technology in smart devices.

site_title: War games helping firms spot cybersecurity talent
summary: Cybersecurity experts competed in the annual UK Cyber Security Challenge competition, where they faced a realistic scenario created by companies such as BT, Airbus, and Cisco Systems. The competition aimed to attract talented individuals to fill the 1 million unfilled cybersecurity jobs globally, with about 70% of finalists being hired into cybersecurity jobs within 12 months. The competition featured a live "red team" of professional network penetration testers, making the war-gaming more realistic and difficult, and included presentations to a mock board of directors, demonstrating the need for business knowledge and presentation skills in cybersecurity.

site_title: Google pays to put search back on Firefox browser in the US
summary: Mozilla Corp rolled out a major Firefox update, making Google the default search engine in the US, Canada, Hong Kong, and Taiwan. The deal reverses a 2014 agreement with Yahoo Inc, which paid over $300 million per year for five years. Google is likely paying less than Apple, which pays Yahoo $1 billion per year to keep its search bar on iPhones. The agreement could boost Google's search market share and increase its Traffic Acquisition Costs, which rose to $5.5 billion in the third quarter.

site_title: Property developer ETC uncovers unauthorised withdrawals in China
summary: Singapore-based property developer ETC has uncovered unauthorized withdrawals of 118 million yuan (S$24 million) from its subsidiary Huizhou Daya Bay Mei Tai Cheng Property Development Co to two companies controlled by majority shareholder Luo Shandong. The withdrawals, made between July and October 2017, were despite repeated warnings from ETC's chairman Christopher Chong. ETC is launching a shareholder derivative suit in China's PRC courts. The company's net profit for the third quarter ended September 30, 2017, more than doubled to S$1.4 million, driven by sales of residential units in its Golden City project.

site_title: Russia's Sberbank posts record profit in Q3, strengthening case for dividend boost
summary: Sberbank, Russia's largest bank, has posted a record profit in the third quarter, with net income rising 62% to 222 billion roubles ($5 billion). The bank is considering a plan to raise dividends to 40% of this year's profit, citing its strong capital position and expanding consumer loan book. Analysts say the bank can afford to pay higher dividends, and its CEO has set a target of a "comfortable" 12.5% capital adequacy level. The bank's supervisory board will review a new strategy, including changes to dividend policy, on December 12.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Bumitama Agri, a palm oil producer, reported a core net profit of 68-70% of forecast in its nine-month FY2017 results. The company expects Q4 earnings to be stronger, driven by higher FFB output and lower unit costs. RHB Research maintains a Buy recommendation with a target price of S$0.95. In contrast, Deutsche Bank Research downgrades Bumitama Agri to Hold, citing concerns over its strategic review and competitive landscape. Yanlord Land Group, a real estate developer, reported a strong nine-month delivery and maintains a Buy recommendation with a target price of S$2.25.

site_title: Hapag-Lloyd sticks to 2017 outlook
summary: German shipping group Hapag-Lloyd maintained its 2017 outlook after a nine-month operating profit surged over 10-fold to 267.9 million euros, narrowing the gap with Maersk. Hapag-Lloyd's shares rose 15% following the earnings announcement, while the company expects Ebit and Ebitda growth in the full year. The company attributed the improvement to an improving global economy and reduced competition following mergers, and sees opportunities to grow faster in Latin America.

site_title: US FDA warns Indian drugmaker Lupin on repeated quality violations
summary: The US FDA has warned Indian drugmaker Lupin Ltd for repeatedly ignoring quality control tests at two of its facilities, resulting in 134 failed tests in 2015 and 2016. Lupin disputed the results, calling them "laboratory error", despite evidence suggesting otherwise. The FDA's warning is a significant regulatory action against the company, which manufactures generic antibiotics, antidepressants, and heart medications in the US.

images.alt_text: In 2015 and 2016, the FDA found 134 instances when drugs or active ingredients failed initial testing but the firm chose to override the results. Lupin called the failed tests at the plant "laboratory error".

site_title: RE&S Holdings launches IPO, aims to raise more than S$10m
summary: RE&S Holdings Limited, a Japanese food and beverage group, has launched its initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board, aiming to raise more than S$10 million. The IPO will see 38 million shares offered at S$0.22 a share, with Orchid 2 Investments Pte Ltd emerging as the sole cornerstone investor. The funds raised will be used to expand businesses in Singapore and Malaysia, and the company expects its market capitalization to be about S$77.9 million post-IPO.

site_title: Property optimism unfazed by govt caution: analysts
summary: Analysts remain optimistic about Singapore's property market, despite government efforts to cool it down. In October, developers saw strong sales, with buyers mainly purchasing units in already launched projects. Speculative purchases remain few, indicating the market is not being significantly impacted by government caution. This suggests that the current cooling regime is having limited effect on demand, at least in the short term.

site_title: Thai developer Sansiri expands into services
summary: Thai real estate developer Sansiri is expanding into services, including hospitality, lifestyle, and property management, to complement its growing property services arm. The firm has invested $80 million in various ventures, such as co-working space provider JustCo, Airbnb home rental management service provider Hostmaker, and global affairs magazine Monocle. Sansiri aims to be a lifestyle provider and global player, with plans to launch a mixed-use residential concept with Monocle in Bangkok next year and partner with JustCo to launch four new offices in Bangkok.

site_title: Shanghai Pharma buys Cardinal Health's China business for US$557m
summary: Shanghai Pharma has agreed to buy Cardinal Health's China drug distribution business for $557 million, expanding its presence nationwide and becoming a leading importer of foreign medicine in China's second-largest drug market. The deal gives Cardinal's business in mainland China and Hong Kong an enterprise value of $1.2 billion. The acquisition will help Shanghai Pharma become a leading importer of foreign medicine into the world's second-largest drug market. The deal was won in a highly competitive auction amid China's upcoming drug distribution reform.

site_title: Crucial for banks to secure the social licence to operate
summary: Asia's rapid growth and prosperity come with environmental and resource costs. To ensure sustainable development, companies must adopt sustainable practices. Banks can play a key role by influencing capital allocation and promoting sustainable finance. Rather than exiting industries that cause harm, banks should support sustainable practices that promote business, employment, and growth. This approach can help balance growth with social responsibility and minimize negative impacts on the environment and community.

site_title: QT Vascular reaches settlement agreement with AngioScore
summary: QT Vascular has reached a confidential settlement agreement with AngioScore, Inc, resolving all past, present, or future disputes between the two companies. The settlement aims to finalize patent infringement proceedings initiated by AngioScore in 2012 against QT Vascular's subsidiaries and CEO Eitan Konstantino. Details of the agreement remain undisclosed.

site_title: Noteholders give landmark nod to Marco Polo's debt restructuring
summary: Marco Polo Marine's noteholders overwhelmingly supported the restructuring of S$50 million notes, paving the way for a new S$60 million equity injection. The restructuring was approved by 78.5% of the notes principal, with noteholders holding S$39.25 million. This decision will allow Marco Polo Marine to access new funding and strengthen its position as an offshore support vessel-focused listed group.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip celebrate 70 years of marriage
summary: Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip celebrated their 70th wedding anniversary on November 20, 2017, with a small family party at Windsor Castle. The couple, who met in 1934, married in 1947 and have been together for 70 years, making it the longest marriage of a British monarch. Despite having their ups and downs, like any married couple, they have avoided the travails of three of their four children and have been a rock to each other throughout Queen Elizabeth's 65-year reign.

site_title: NTUC amends constitution to cover more jobs and positions
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) in Singapore has amended its constitution to cover more jobs and positions, aiming to represent "all working people" with various services and groupings. This move aims to provide help to a broader range of workers, including managers and freelancers, in addition to its current focus on blue-collar workers. The updated constitution formalizes NTUC's commitment to serving the diverse needs of Singapore's workforce.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on oil price slide
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 109.77 points, or 0.47%, to 23,299.7, as a slide in oil prices hit global markets and concerns about US tax cuts weighed on the mood. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 losing 13.02 points, or 0.50%, to 2,565.85, and the Nasdaq dropping 39.19 points, or 0.58%, to 6,698.68.

site_title: Blockchain-based digital trade platform for SMEs to debut in 2018
summary: Singapore's first blockchain-based digital-trade platform, Fasttrack Trade (FTT), will debut in the first quarter of 2018, enabling SMEs to seek business partners, buy and sell goods, and buy insurance on a single platform. Developed by fintech startup Cites Gestion with funding from Prudential, FTT will utilize distributed-ledger technology, providing a common audit trail and making transactions safer and cheaper. The platform aims to support the growth of SMEs in Singapore and beyond, addressing a significant trade financing gap in South-east Asia.

site_title: Train service between Joo Koon, Tuas Link stations to be suspended on Thursday
summary: Train service between Joo Koon and Tuas Link stations will be suspended on Thursday to allow for investigations into a collision that injured 28 passengers. The incident occurred when a glitch in the train control system caused a safety software feature to malfunction. Trains on the North-South and East-West lines will run at slower intervals as an interim safety precaution. Thales, the company providing the signalling system, has said it has never had a collision before and may review its safety measures. The Land Transport Authority will conduct a thorough check before resuming the service.

site_title: Saudi Arabia is set to be a commodities player
summary: Saudi Arabia is poised to become a significant player in the global commodity market, driven by its economic and political developments. The country's reliance on petroleum is expected to increase as it invests in infrastructure, technology, and renewable energy projects, such as the $500 billion Neom metropolis. The government aims to reduce its reliance on oil by diversifying its economy, with plans to invest in sectors like manufacturing, tourism, and renewable energy. This shift is expected to bolster commodity trade flows, as Saudi Arabia seeks to increase its exports of goods like metals, fertilizers, and paper.
