site_title: Envictus Int'l proposes acquisition of Malaysian firm for RM24m
summary: Envictus International Holdings' subsidiary Polygold Holdings has agreed to acquire Malaysian firm Motivage for RM24 million. The acquisition includes a cash payment of RM5 million and the issuance of 15.78 million shares at a discounted price of S$0.3913. The deal is considered an interested party transaction due to the involvement of Envictus' deputy group CEO and his sister, who are directors and shareholders of Motivage. The acquisition aims to expand Envictus' presence in the food processing and trading industry.

site_title: Australia's Cromwell revives pan-European Reit listing after dropping Polish assets from IPO portfolio
summary: Cromwell Property Group, an Australian real estate investment trust, is reviving its pan-European Reit listing after initially dropping Polish assets from its IPO portfolio. The revised IPO, Cromwell European Reit (Cereit), will list on Nov 30 with an expected market capitalization of 865.7 million euros (S$1.39 billion). The portfolio will comprise 74 properties across five European countries, with a focus on western Europe, and will be valued at 1.35 billion euros. This marks a significant change from the original IPO, which included Polish retail properties.

site_title: Deutsche Post invests 335m euros to expand DHL Hong Kong hub
summary: Deutsche Post is investing 335 million euros to expand its DHL Hong Kong hub, increasing throughput by 50% when operating at full capacity. The expanded hub, expected to begin operation in 2022, aims to bolster regional trade amid rising international e-commerce and intra-Asian trade. The investment will strengthen DHL's global network and services, with the goal of supporting Hong Kong airport's three runway system completion in 2024.

site_title: SoftBank planning up to US$25b in Saudi investments
summary: SoftBank plans to invest up to $25 billion in Saudi Arabia over the next three to four years, with a focus on the new city of Neom and state-controlled Saudi Electricity Co. The investments aim to diversify the economy away from oil and bolster Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's efforts to crack down on corruption. SoftBank's Vision Fund will also have portfolio companies open offices in Neom, providing a significant influx of foreign direct investment into the country, which totaled $7.45 billion last year.

site_title: Airbus seals record US$50b deal to outshine Boeing in Dubai
summary: Airbus has secured a record-breaking deal worth $50 billion for 430 A320neo planes from US investor Indigo Partners, surpassing Boeing's orders at the Dubai Air Show. The deal, valued at $49.5 billion before discounts, more than doubles Airbus's previous order book for the year and pushes its backlog above 7,000 jets. The pact gives Airbus the upper hand in the global commercial plane market and helps CEO Tom Enders overcome an investigation into bribery allegations. The A320 is Airbus's best-selling product, and the deal is seen as a significant boost to the company's sales and reputation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 10.62 points to 1,722.99. Losers outnumbered gainers 638 to 254, and volume reached 2.34 billion lots worth RM2.283 billion.

site_title: Mugabe under house arrest as military takes control
summary: Zimbabwe's military took control of the country on November 15, 2017, with President Robert Mugabe under house arrest. Generals denied staging a coup, stating they were targeting "criminals around" Mugabe, but their actions posed a major challenge to his 93-year-old rule. Mugabe's wife, Grace, was in prime position to succeed him, sparking opposition from the military. The US embassy warned citizens to "shelter in place" due to ongoing uncertainty, while South Africa urged Zimbabwe to resist "unconstitutional changes" of government.

site_title: Noble Group restructures green tech and speciality metals supply chains under 2 subsidiaries
summary: NOBLE Group is restructuring its green tech and specialty metals supply chains under two wholly owned subsidiaries, Kalon Resources and Talaxis. Kalon will focus on special ores and metals, while Talaxis will concentrate on cobalt, lithium, and rare earths resources. The move aims to capture growth opportunities in these markets and enhance the range of growth options for the company. The two entities will have independent management teams and access to Noble Group's operational capabilities, supporting the creation of new industrial supply streams and alternative sourcing solutions for market participants.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Developers Pearlbank Apartments and Parkway Mansion launched tenders for collective sale on November 16, targeting S$728m and S$138m respectively. In October, 969 homes were sold, a 7% increase from September. Private condo rents fell 0.7% in October, while HDB rents rose 0.3%. Manulife Singapore appointed a new chief after the Canadian insurer announced leadership changes. Meanwhile, Noble Group discussed capital structure and liquidity options, and Hong Kong's Xin Hua Securities joined the SGX's derivatives market.

site_title: Pink dollar' boost to Australia economy after gay marriage vote
summary: Australia's historic move towards legalizing same-sex marriage is expected to bring a massive boost to the economy, dubbed the "pink dollar." The country's wedding industry is poised for a boom, with estimates suggesting over $650 million in revenue in the first year. Tourism is also expected to benefit, with same-sex couples and Australian expats returning to get married. Long-term benefits include increased home ownership and economic growth, as same-sex couples can make better commitments to each other. The legislation is expected to pass parliament by the end of the year, following a national poll in favor of same-sex marriage.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.9% lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed 0.9% lower at 3,368.70 on Wednesday, with 323 counters declining and 134 counters rising. Turnover reached 2 billion shares worth S$1.3 billion, compared to Tuesday's 2.6 billion shares worth S$1.7 billion.

site_title: Australia has more 'growth engines' than it realises-RBA
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia's Assistant Governor Luci Ellis stated that Australia has multiple "growth engines" driving the economy, including booming infrastructure spending, expanding resource exports, and a strong tourism and services sector. Ellis also cited rapid population growth and rising workforce participation, particularly among women. These factors are expected to contribute to 1.2 percentage points of GDP growth over the next two years. The optimism has led financial markets to rule out another interest rate cut, instead pricing in continued economic growth.

site_title: Great Eastern regional bancassurance head leaves for Manulife
summary: Khoo Kah Siang, head of Great Eastern's bancassurance, is set to join Manulife Singapore as its new chief, pending regulator's approval. He will join the Asia Executive Committee and report to Anil Wadhwani, replacing outgoing chief Naveed Irshad. Khoo, a seasoned actuary, led Great Eastern's life business in Singapore, increasing its market share and giving Manulife a run for its money. This move marks the latest exit of a senior executive from Great Eastern, following others who left in the past 18 months.

site_title: No formal notification as yet on outcome of Jalan Besar Plaza en bloc exercise: New Wave
summary: New Wave Holdings has yet to receive a formal notification on the outcome of the Jalan Besar Plaza en bloc exercise, which was launched on October 10 and closed on November 10. The guide price for the freehold complex is S$390 million, or S$2,170 per square foot per plot ratio. The company will continue to monitor the situation closely and disclose updates to shareholders.

site_title: Noteholders grant nod to Marco Polo's restructuring
summary: Marco Polo Marine has secured a majority vote from note holders in support of a restructuring plan, allowing the company to partially redeem S$50 million notes maturing in January 2018. The proposal, which includes a cash payment of S$35,868 and the issuance of 1.02 million shares, has been approved by 89.81% of the votes cast. The move paves the way for S$60 million in new equity to be injected into the company's offshore support vessel-focused business, pending the successful restructuring of S$202 million bank loans.

site_title: MAS would consider trialling ICOs in regulatory sandbox, says chief fintech officer
summary: Singapore's financial regulator, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), considers trialling initial coin offerings (ICOs) in a regulatory sandbox if they focus on improving capital markets efficiency. The MAS's chief fintech officer, Sopnendu Mohanty, stated that ICOs backed by technology enhancing capital markets, such as smart contracts, could be suitable for a sandbox. However, ICOs that promise unrealistic returns or unproven technology will not be considered. The MAS joins other jurisdictions in grappling with how to regulate ICOs, which have raised over $3.5 billion globally.

site_title: Europe: Weaker commodities drag European shares to 8-week low
summary: European shares fell to an 8-week low due to weaker commodity stocks, with the STOXX 600 index down 0.6% and the FTSE 100 and DAX indices down 0.3% and 0.7%, respectively. A decline in crude oil prices and metal prices weighed on mining and energy stocks, while banks were also affected. However, Airbus rose 3.4% after winning a big jet order worth $49.5 billion.

site_title: Citigroup, UBS among banks most exposed to Riyadh's rich: sources
summary: Citigroup, UBS, and JPMorgan Chase & Co are among international banks managing large assets for Saudi Arabia's ultra-rich, some of whom are under investigation for alleged corruption. Prince Alwaleed bin Talal and Khalid al-Tuwaijri, former chief of the Royal Court, are clients of Citigroup's private bank and among those detained in the probe. The investigation has raised concerns about the role of wealth managers in advising the kingdom's wealthy elite.

images.alt_text: Citigroup's private bank counts Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, the world's 58th-richest person, as one of its clients.

site_title: Tencent Q3 profit surges on smartphone games, payment services
summary: Chinese internet giant Tencent Holdings Ltd reported a 69% jump in quarterly net profit to 18 billion yuan, driven by strong growth in smartphone games and payment-related services. Revenue rose 61% to 65 billion yuan, beating estimates. The company's market capitalization has more than doubled this year, reaching $472 billion. Monthly active users of WeChat increased to 980 million, and daily messages sent rose 25% year-over-year. Revenue from smartphone games grew 84% to 18.2 billion yuan, led by popular titles like Honour of Kings.

site_title: China: Stocks extend losses, resources firms hit by growth worries
summary: China's major stock indexes extended losses on Wednesday, with the CSI300 index falling 0.6% and the Shanghai Composite Index dropping 0.8%, amid concerns over a slowdown in industrial production and moderating growth. Resources shares were particularly affected, with commodities prices tumbling in Shanghai. The data release on Tuesday showed China's economy cooled further, with industrial output and fixed asset investment missing expectations. The Shanghai stock index is still up 10.5% this year, but the losses mark a reversal of the previous week's gains.

site_title: Zurich Insurance expects rising prices to boost delivery on targets
summary: Zurich Insurance confirmed its 2017-2019 financial targets, citing an expected improvement in insurance pricing following recent natural catastrophes. The company expects rising prices to boost its ability to deliver on its goals, which include cost-cutting of $1.5 billion by 2019 and a return on equity of over 12%. Zurich also aims to maintain a dividend of at least 17 Swiss francs per share and grow towards paying out 75% of net profit. The company's improved business performance and strong balance sheet give it confidence to increase its return of capital to shareholders over time.

site_title: Novena Global buys 4 Singapore eyecare clinics, majority stake in Taiwan's Hexin Group
summary: Novena Global Lifecare Group has acquired four eyecare clinics in Singapore and a majority stake in Taiwan's Hexin Group, the third largest healthcare screening provider in Taipei. The deal aims to expand Novena's healthcare services beyond medical aesthetics. The acquisition will allow Novena to manage healthcare screening services in major hospitals in Taipei and capitalize on Taiwan's mandated healthcare screening for employees. Novena plans to expand into anti-aging treatments, stem cell treatments, and other healthcare services in North Asia.

site_title: Olam sees higher coffee prices, reports 18% rise in Q3 net profit
summary: Olam International, a major coffee trader, expects higher coffee prices due to a robusta market shortage and possible La Nina occurrence. The company reported a 17.5% growth in Q3 net profit, driven by higher sales volume and operational improvements. Olam anticipates a 4 million bag shortage in each season, leading to higher fair value for robusta coffee and potentially spiking prices.

site_title: Singapore shares begin afternoon trading in negative territory; STI at 3,374.13
summary: Singapore shares began afternoon trading on November 15, 2017, in negative territory, with the Straits Times Index at 3,374.13, down 0.7% or 24.96 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 251 to 130, and 953.3 million shares worth S$573.8 million were traded. Notable movers included RHT Health Trust and QT Vascular, while DBS Group Holdings and SingTel were among the active index stocks.

site_title: Australia: Shares decline for 4th straight session
summary: Australian shares declined for the fourth consecutive session, losing 0.6% or 34.546 points to 5,934.2, as sliding oil and metal prices weighed on commodity stocks. The decline was driven by losses in material and financial stocks, with major miners BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto also falling. Westpac Banking Corp was the second biggest drag on the benchmark, falling 0.8% to its lowest in a month. The losses were also attributed to weak industrial data from China and the New Zealand central bank's decision to boost capital levels for Westpac's New Zealand listed shares.

site_title: South Africa craft beers brew up a challenge to old order
summary: South Africa's craft beer industry is gaining momentum, with over 200 breweries operating in the country. Despite being dominated by mass-market lagers, craft ales are gaining popularity, with market analysts estimating the global craft ale market could be worth $500 billion by 2025. Local brewers are targeting the growing black middle class and seeking to attract tourists with unique brewery concepts. Major brewers, including Heineken and SAB, are also entering the craft market, but start-up opportunists are warned to be cautious and differentiate themselves from others to survive.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end down, resources and industrial firms weigh
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1.0% to 28,851.69 points, dragged down by resources and industrial firms amid worries over China's economic growth. Data showed China's economy cooled further last month, with industrial output and retail sales missing expectations. Byd Co Ltd and New China Life Insurance Co Ltd were the biggest decliners, down 4.63% and 4.4% respectively.

site_title: Singapore homeowners, developers willing to pay more for green buildings
summary: In Singapore, a survey by the Building & Construction Authority (BCA) found that 70% of homeowners believe green buildings have better resale value and are willing to pay 3-4% more for a certified Green Mark building. Developers are also willing to pay up to 5% more for green buildings, with 72% preferring to invest in or purchase a green building. The survey results support the business case for green buildings, with 90% of respondents citing lower utility bills, reduced environmental impact, and better health benefits.

site_title: SMRT collision is second incident in MRT's 30 year history
summary: A collision on the SMRT train in Singapore has injured 25 passengers, marking the second such incident in the MRT's 30-year history. The incident occurred when a train stopped at Clementi MRT station due to a technical fault and was then hit by another train when the automatic train protection system failed. The cause is attributed to a technical fault and inadequate response to an oil spill from a locomotive. An investigation led to the replacement of all hoses and oil seals on locomotives and the purchase of new locomotives with a different engine.

site_title: US housing costs drive modest gain in Oct inflation
summary: US consumer inflation rose 0.1% in October, driven by rising housing and medical care costs, according to the Labor Department. The core CPI, excluding volatile food and fuel costs, increased 0.2% for the first time since January, meeting analyst expectations. Consumer spending, excluding volatile auto sales, rose 0.1%, supporting GDP growth in the final quarter of 2017. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates next month despite low inflation, which has remained below the central bank's target of 2% despite falling unemployment and steady job growth.

site_title: Deloitte recruits new hires to strengthen data analytics capabilities in Asia Pacific
summary: Deloitte has partnered with Cameron Price and Gerard Skybey to strengthen its data analytics capabilities in the Asia Pacific region. The accounting firm will also hire 39 employees from CBIG Consulting, bolstering its Analytics and Information Management teams in Sydney, Melbourne, and Singapore. The move comes as the demand for data analytics is robust in the region, with the big data and business analytics market in Asia Pacific expected to reach US$13.6 billion by 2017, growing at a 14.4% compound annual rate through to 2020.

site_title: People Magazine names Blake Shelton 'sexiest man alive'
summary: Blake Shelton, 41, has been named 'Sexiest Man Alive' by People Magazine. Shelton, the country crooner and boyfriend of Gwen Stefani, expressed his gratitude and humor about the title, saying he's "ugly" but has finally found his sexy side. He shared that the title will be used in various conversations and joked about taking the title as a way to prove his worth. Shelton's co-star Adam Levine, also a recipient of the title, is a close friend.

images.alt_text: Country crooner Blake Shelton - also known for his role as a judge on TV's The Voice - is this year's "sexiest man alive," People Magazine announced on Tuesday.

site_title: Butter shortage chills France's patisserie-loving soul
summary: France is experiencing a severe butter shortage, with supermarket shelves empty and bakers worried about the "croissant crisis." The shortage is attributed to rising demand in Asia, particularly China, and the EU's dwindling butter reserves. French people, who consume three times more butter per capita than Americans, are panicking, with some turning to YouTube tutorials on how to make butter. Wholesale prices have more than tripled over the past year, and many bakeries are struggling to find reliable suppliers, with some putting aside stocks for potential holiday shortages.

site_title: Forget robots. The real threat to jobs, even lower-skilled ones, comes from digital tools, says study
summary: A study by the Brookings Institution found that digital tools are increasingly displacing jobs, even lower-skilled ones, in the US economy. Since 2002, 517 of 545 occupations have seen a significant increase in digital tool use, with many lower-skilled jobs now requiring digital skills. The study suggests that workers need to gain digital skills to remain employable, and jobs with greater digital content tend to pay more. Digital scores for occupations rose from 29 in 2002 to 46 in 2016, with some jobs like warehouse workers and roofers seeing significant increases.

site_title: Canadians a bit less happy, but satisfied with their jobs
summary: Canadians report being less satisfied with their work-life balance, with 68% satisfied or very satisfied, down 10 percentage points from 2016. Despite this, 84% are satisfied with their jobs. Women are slightly less likely to be satisfied with their work-life balance than men. The main reasons for dissatisfaction include a bad work environment and low pay. Canadians generally view new technologies as positive, with most viewing virtual connection as a positive aspect of life.

site_title: Hong Kong's Xin Hua Securities joins SGX's derivatives market as trading member
summary: Hong Kong-based Xin Hua Securities has joined as a trading member of Singapore Exchange's (SGX) derivatives market, bringing the total number of SGX's trading members to 58. Xin Hua Securities also has 23 clearing members in the derivatives market and 11 for OTC-traded financial derivatives. The addition is expected to increase liquidity in SGX's growing suite of derivative products. SGX head of derivatives Michael Syn stated that the active participation of Xin Hua Securities and their network will enhance SGX's position in the derivatives markets globally and especially in Asia.

site_title: Experimental peanut allergy patch shows promise
summary: Researchers have found an experimental peanut allergy patch showing promise in reducing allergic reactions in children and adults. The patch delivers a high dose of peanut protein and was tested on 221 participants, with the highest dose of 250 micrograms being most effective in helping half of the patients. A larger study is needed to confirm the results, but the patch has the potential to reduce the risk of peanut allergy in infants by 81%. Further trials are planned to test the patch's effectiveness in children aged 4-11.

site_title: Taiwan's foodie cred given Michelin boost
summary: Taiwan is set to become the latest Asian city to have its own Michelin guide in the first quarter of 2018, with the Taiwanese capital, Taipei, expected to receive its first edition. The city's street food scene, known for its vibrant night markets and fresh local ingredients, is being recognized by Michelin alongside higher-end restaurants. Taiwanese chefs are speculating that some of their humble eateries could receive Michelin stars, but others are concerned about the pressure that comes with the prestigious award.

site_title: Star Wars meets fruit farms as lasers deter berry-stealing birds
summary: A Netherlands-based firm, Bird Control Group, has developed a laser technology that imitates predators to scare off birds from farms, reducing damage to crops by 70-99%. The Agrilaser Autonomic emits a 3-inch diameter greenish laser beam that mimics a physical danger, causing birds to instinctively take flight. About 100 US farms have adopted the technology, with the company expecting the number to triple by next year. The laser is also being used in vineyards, poultry farms, and to keep geese off agricultural land.

site_title: En bloc sales: Derby Court near Novena aims for S$62m with public tender
summary: The owners of the Derby Court condominium near Novena have launched a public tender for collective sale, with a reserve price of S$62 million. The site, comprising 20 units, can be developed into a 70-apartment project, subject to approval. The strategic location on the corner of Derbyshire Road may offer developers flexibility in designing the new apartments to maximize unblocked views. Tan Hong Boon from JLL notes that the site is a good investment choice for developers looking for smaller sites in District 11 with proximity to good schools.

site_title: China to tackle coal price gouging, ensure supplies in winter
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission will strengthen coal price monitoring and regulation to ensure stable prices during the winter season. The move comes after coal prices soared 60% this year, affecting utilities in northeastern provinces. Inspections and investigations will be conducted to prosecute cases of price gouging and price monopoly. The commission aims to increase coal supplies by releasing high-quality coal capacity and improving transportation capacity in major ports and utilities.

site_title: Japanese restaurateur RE&S launches IPO at 22 cents a share, starts trading Nov 22
summary: Japanese restaurant group RE&S Holdings has launched an initial public offering (IPO) of 38 million shares at 22 Singapore cents a share, with the offer price representing 11.6 times its 2017 earnings per share. The IPO is expected to raise S$11.9 million, with proceeds earmarked for expansion, refurbishment, and working capital. Trading of its shares will begin on November 22.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open down, in line with Asia sell-off
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.64% to 28,964.11, mirroring an Asia-wide retreat and losses on Wall Street. The decline follows a recent rally, with investors cashing out. The Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.39% and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.29%. The sell-off is part of a broader market trend, with other Asian markets also experiencing declines.

site_title: Developers keep up pace in Oct with sale of 969 homes, up 7% from Sept
summary: Developers in Singapore sold 969 new private residential homes and executive condominiums in October, a 7% increase from September. This marks a 15.4% increase in private residential units sold excluding ECs. The surge in sales comes despite recent government efforts to dampen market optimism, and market watchers expect a strong finish to the year.

site_title: Chinese commodities futures tumble on concerns of slowing economy
summary: Chinese commodities futures tumbled across the board due to concerns about a slowing economy. Steel and metals posted losses amid falling property investment and sales. The government's extension of a crackdown on debt risks and factory pollution also contributed to the decline. Analysts, such as Zhao Chaoyue, attributed the sharp fall to the slowing Chinese economic growth.

site_title: Singapore shares lower at Wed break; STI down 0.85% to 3,370.23
summary: Singapore shares fell at the mid-day break, with the Straits Times Index down 0.85% to 3,370.23. Losers outnumbered gainers 249 to 123, driven by declines in DBS Group Holdings and SingTel. RHT Health Trust was a notable exception, gaining 11.1% after a controlling shareholder proposed to acquire its asset portfolio. The market remains ahead of GDP data, which is due on Friday.

site_title: Food fight breaks out over fresh fruit-and-vegetable packaging
summary: A US trade agency is investigating allegations that four companies, including B&G Foods Inc and Landec Corp, used patented breathable packaging for fresh produce without paying for the patent. The packaging, known as microperforated packaging, is used to extend shelf life of produce. Windham Packaging LLC, the inventor of the technology, filed a complaint claiming the companies infringed on its 2006 patent. The trade commission may block imports of affected products, which could impact the US market for fresh produce.

site_title: Asia: Stocks down as plunging oil prices hammer energy firms
summary: Asian energy firms experienced a sell-off, dragging regional equity markets down, as oil prices plummeted due to warnings of slowing demand and rising stockpiles. The International Energy Agency cut its forecast for crude consumption, citing recovering prices and a mild winter. Oil prices fell over 1% as investors reacted to the news, affecting energy firms and broader markets.

site_title: US says North Korean malware lurking in computer networks
summary: US authorities have warned that North Korean malware, known as "Hidden Cobra" or "Lazarus", is still present in many computer networks, giving hackers backdoor access to various organizations. The malware, linked to the Pyongyang government, has been active since 2009 and has been used in cyberattacks, including the WannaCry ransomware outbreak. The Department of Homeland Security has issued an alert warning of potential further exploitation of these networks, with the aim of advancing the North Korean government's military and strategic objectives.

site_title: Australia dollar hits 4-mth low on weak wages, NZ$ on defensive
summary: The Australian dollar fell to a four-month low of US$0.7580 due to weak wages data, which threatened to keep inflation and interest rates lower for longer. Wages rose only 0.5% in the third quarter, below forecasts of 0.7%, posing a challenge to the Reserve Bank of Australia's view that wages would pick up as the labor market tightens. The sell-off led to a decrease in interest rates and a decline in the premium offered over US debt, with markets trimming the probability of a rate rise next year until early 2019.

site_title: En bloc sales: Pearlbank aims for S$728m, Parkway Mansion targets S$138m
summary: Two Singapore condominium projects, Pearlbank Apartments and Parkway Mansion, are launching tenders for collective sale. Pearlbank has a reserve price of S$728 million and Parkway has an indicative price of S$138 million. The tenders, set to close on Dec 19 and Dec 13, respectively, are expected to attract interest from local and foreign developers amid strong demand for development sites. Apartment owners stand to receive significant proceeds, with minimum gross prices ranging from S$1.8 million to S$6.9 million. The sales are seen as a positive sign for the Singapore residential market, which has been recovering after a four-year down cycle.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, falling 0.57% and 0.61% on the Nikkei 225 and Topix indexes, respectively. This follows a seventh consecutive quarter of economic growth in Japan, with traders cashing in on recent gains. The decline was attributed to traders' cautious stance amid uncertainty.

site_title: Asean must raise green investment by 400% to guard against environmental risks, says new study
summary: A new study by DBS and the UN Environment Inquiry into the Design of a Sustainable Financial System recommends that the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) increase green investment by 400% annually to protect its economies from climate change and environmental risks. The region needs $3 trillion in green investment between 2016 and 2030, with Indonesia requiring the largest volume. Current flows of $40 billion need to scale up to meet demand, with private finance playing a crucial role in filling the gap.

site_title: SMRT train hits stationary train at Joo Koon MRT station; 28 injured
summary: A SMRT train collided with a stationary train at Joo Koon MRT station in Singapore, injuring 28 people, including two with "major emergencies". The incident occurred during peak hour and led to major delays on the East-West Line. The collision was attributed to a malfunction of the new signalling system. 23 passengers and 2 staff sustained light to moderate injuries, with 9 treated and discharged, 2 still in hospital, and 2 others currently being treated. The incident caused significant disruptions, with services suspended for about two hours between Boon Lay and Tuas Link.

site_title: China throws lifeline to builders facing record wall of debt
summary: China has eased access to offshore financing for struggling developers, allowing them to tap into international markets to refinance record debt. The move comes as the country's housing market slows, with new home sales falling 3.4% in October and developers facing restrictions on local borrowing. Regulators have also approved larger quotas for offshore bond deals, with at least eight builders receiving approval or indications of imminent approval. However, experts warn that the measures will slow down sales and cash receipts, and may not be enough to prevent smaller developers from exiting the industry.

site_title: Competition commission seeks feedback on supply of HDB lift parts
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore is seeking public feedback on proposals to address the availability of proprietary lift parts for third-party maintenance contractors in HDB estates. Allegations of refusals to supply parts have raised concerns of anti-competitive situations. BNF Engineering and C&W Services have proposed voluntary commitments to sell spare parts on a fair, reasonable, and non-discriminatory basis. The consultation will close on November 28, aiming to address concerns and ensure fair access to lift maintenance services.

site_title: Manulife prices first green bond; S$500m of 12-year notes offer 3% coupon
summary: Manulife Financial Corp priced S$500 million of 3% green bonds with a 12-year maturity, marking the first green bond of benchmark size issued by a life insurance company. The bonds will be used for sustainable investments and have a fixed coupon for the first seven years, increasing to 0.832% over the prevailing five-year Singapore dollar swap rate. The offering is expected to close on November 21, 2017, and has received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading Limited.

site_title: Australian stocks benchmark set to end lower for 4th straight session, NZ down
summary: Australian stocks fell 0.5% on Wednesday, marking the fourth consecutive session of decline, as commodity-related stocks plummeted due to lower oil prices and a decline in nickel. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped to 5,946.6, while New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.2%. Global miners BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto led the decline, and Woodside Petroleum's shares dropped as low as A$30.34 after Royal Dutch Shell sold its stake for $2.7 billion.

site_title: Home demand in outer Australian cities prolong building boom
summary: Home demand in outer Australian cities has driven a building boom, with construction approvals reaching an 18-month high of 9,929 in September. The surge in demand has led to a labor shortage, with builders substituting brick with larger aerated concrete panels. This has supported the economy by stimulating demand and jobs in the building industry, but has also tempered price growth. As a result, land values have reached record highs, with Sydney's median residential lot land values reaching A$470,000 in October, and borrowing to buy finished new homes hitting a 38-year peak.

images.alt_text: On the edges of Sydney, where Australia's biggest city is sprawling across paddocks and market gardens, demand for new homes is running harder than tradesmen can lay bricks.

site_title: Airbnb said to double revenue to US$1b last quarter
summary: Airbnb reported a 100% increase in net revenue to US$1 billion in the third quarter, ending September, with the company maintaining a steady profit streak for at least 17 months. This growth is expected to position Airbnb for an initial public offering next year.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks fall, won down
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.35% on Wednesday, weakening to 2,517.66 points. The won dropped 0.06% to 1,115.2 per US dollar, while bond yields rose. Foreigners were net sellers of 29,949 million won worth of shares. The US dollar has fallen 7.58% against the won this year, with the won's high for the year at 1,107.3 per dollar on March 27, 2017.

site_title: Macau to bolster casino oversight ahead of licence renewals
summary: Macau regulators are strengthening oversight of the US$30 billion casino industry ahead of licence renewals. The local government will review and regulate junket operators, promote responsible gaming, and boost competitiveness. This move comes as business in the world's biggest gaming hub is booming, with VIP gamblers driving a three-year high in casino revenue in October. The government aims to increase revenue not tied to gambling, following China's anti-corruption crackdown in 2014. Analysts forecast 2018 gaming revenue to climb to 291 billion patacas, driven by high rollers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: RHT Health Trust, Ellipsiz, Olam, HMC, China Jinjiang, SingPost
summary: Stocks to watch: RHT Health Trust, Ellipsiz, Olam, HMC, China Jinjiang, SingPost. Key announcements include RHT Health Trust's proposed acquisition of its asset portfolio for $965.95 million, Olam International's 17.5% net profit growth, and SingPost's 9.5% lower net profit despite revenue growth.

site_title: Singapore to launch first digital trade platform for SMEs using blockchain technology
summary: Singapore is set to launch its first digital trade platform for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) using blockchain technology, called Fasttrack Trade (FTT), in the first quarter of 2018. Developed by fintech startup Cites Gestion, the platform is a partnership between Prudential Singapore and Starhub, offering insurance services to mitigate business risks. The platform aims to simplify trade processes and improve efficiency for SMEs.

site_title: Noble enters talks with stakeholders to address capital structure, liquidity position
summary: Noble Group initiates discussions with stakeholders to address capital structure and liquidity concerns. The discussions aim to optimize borrowing maturity and utilize available cash. The company will prioritize near-term liquidity and continue operating normally. Noble shares have declined 88% this year, closing 10% lower on Tuesday at S$0.198. The company will inform the market of material developments as they occur.

site_title: Airbus is said near over US$40b jet deal with US's Indigo
summary: Airbus is nearing a deal to sell 430 aircraft valued at over $40 billion to US airline investor Indigo Partners. The transaction would give Airbus a significant lead in orders at the Dubai Air Show, surpassing Boeing. The deal would also mark a major achievement for Airbus sales chief John Leahy, who is retiring after building the order book into thousands of aircraft. The purchase would provide upgraded single-aisle jetliners to ultra-low-cost carriers in Indigo's portfolio, including Frontier Airlines and Wizz Air Holdings Plc.

site_title: Private condo rents down 0.7% in Oct, HDB rents up 0.3%: SRX
summary: Private condo rents fell 0.7% in October, a steeper decline than the 0.1% drop in September, according to SRX Property. In contrast, HDB rents rose 0.3% in October. The decline in private condo rents was mainly driven by the Core Central Region, while HDB rents were boosted by increases in 4-room and executive flats. Rental volumes for both private and HDB flats improved, with a 5.8% increase in private condo transactions and a 6.3% increase in HDB flat rentals.

site_title: Australians vote in favour of gay marriage
summary: Australians voted in favour of gay marriage, with 62% of 12.7 million participants supporting the measure. The non-binding postal survey result will now be turned into law by the parliament, potentially allowing same-sex couples to marry by Christmas. The outcome sends a positive message to the LGBTQ+ community and sets a precedent for the country's social and cultural evolution.

site_title: ETC posts Q3 profit of S$1.4m alongside acquisitions, discloses S$24m in unauthorised withdrawals
summary: Emerging Towns & Cities Singapore (ETC) reported a Q3 profit of S$1.4 million, more than doubling from the previous year, alongside acquisitions and unauthorised withdrawals. The company also disclosed S$24 million in unauthorised withdrawals from its subsidiary, Huizhou Daya Bay Mei Tai Cheng Property Development Co. ETC plans to file a shareholder's derivative suit in China and is exploring offsetting the withdrawals against amounts owed to its controlling shareholder, Luo Shandong.

site_title: AusNet Services H1 profit rises 14.1% to A$203.7m due to colder weather
summary: AusNet Services reported a 14.1% increase in H1 profit to A$203.7 million, driven by colder weather and increased customer contributions. Revenue rose 4.7% to A$1.07 billion, while earnings before interest, tax, depreciation & amortisation (Ebitda) increased 8.8% to A$647.4 million. The company attributed the growth to the colder weather, which led to increased energy demand and customer contributions.

site_title: Fortis proposes to buy RHT Health Trust's entire asset portfolio for S$966m
summary: Fortis Healthcare Limited, the controlling shareholder of RHT Health Trust, has proposed acquiring the trust's entire asset portfolio for S$965.95 million. This would result in the sale of RHT's Indian subsidiaries and its entire asset portfolio, including 12 clinical establishments, four greenfield clinical establishments, and two operating hospitals in India. The proposal is part of a term sheet to negotiate exclusively for 60 days, with consideration to be adjusted based on changes in net current assets.

site_title: Hon Hai's profit falls most since 2008 as iPhone delays hurt
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry, the Taiwanese company that assembles iPhones for Apple, reported a 39% decline in net income to NT$21 billion in the third quarter, its largest earnings drop since 2008. The decline was attributed to technical issues with the production of Apple's 10th-anniversary iPhone X, which delayed its release. Hon Hai's operating expenses rose 16% and net margins fell to under 2%. The company's growth is threatened by competition from Chinese smartphone vendors and a shortage of suppliers for OLED displays.

site_title: Bharti Airtel sells 33.25b rupee stake in mobile tower business to cut debt
summary: Bharti Airtel sold 33.25 billion rupees worth of shares in its mobile tower business to reduce debt, amid a price war sparked by Reliance Jio. The sale was made to global investors and fund managers, and the proceeds will primarily be used to pay off the company's debt, which stood at 914.8 billion rupees. This comes after a 77% slump in quarterly profits and as competitors like Idea Cellular and Vodafone India also seek funds to fend off Jio's deep pockets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 0.53 points to 1,734.14. The market saw 88 gainers for every 78 losers, with a total trading volume of 92.53 million lots worth RM27.6 million.

site_title: Firefox opts for Google as default search in US, surprising Yahoo
summary: Firefox has ended its 3-year partnership with Yahoo, making Google its default search engine in the US and other regions. The decision, announced by Mozilla, was reportedly made due to Google's growing spending on app and device searches. The deal was valued at $375 million and was set to run through 2019. Mozilla's chief business and legal officer stated that the company sought to prioritize its brand and user experience. Google will now be the default search provider on Firefox desktop and mobile in the affected regions.

site_title: US wholesale inflation hits 5-year record in October
summary: US wholesale inflation rose to a 5-year record in October, driven by rising costs for services such as medications, meats, and industrial chemicals. The Producer Price Index (PPI) increased 0.4% from the prior month and 2.8% year-over-year, surpassing the Federal Reserve's 2% inflation target. A rising PPI suggests robust price pressures ahead, potentially leading to interest rate hikes at the Fed's final meeting of the year.

site_title: Euro steadies after rallying on strong German data
summary: The euro remained near a 2-1/2 week high in early Asian trading on Wednesday, driven by strong German economic data. Germany's seasonally adjusted GDP rose 0.8% on the quarter, beating expectations. The euro's ascent pushed down the dollar index, which tracks the US currency against a basket of six major rivals. Investors await US consumer inflation data, which may impact the probability of a Fed rate hike in December.

images.alt_text: The euro remained close to 2-1/2 week highs in early Asian trading on Wednesday, getting a boost from upbeat German economic data as investors awaited US consumer inflation data later in the global session.

site_title: China throws lifeline to developers hitting record wall of debt
summary: China's regulators have eased access to offshore financing to help developers facing a record wall of debt repayments. Home sales have slowed, with a 3.4% decline in October, and developers are relying on shadow loans and offshore bonds to stay afloat. Despite a sizable cash buffer, smaller developers may struggle to access funding, with some potentially exiting the industry. The government's cooling measures are likely to slow down sales and cash receipts, and restrictions on borrowing remain in place.

site_title: Japan'S GDP grows for 7 straight quarters, outlook remains solid
summary: Japan's economy has experienced its seventh consecutive quarter of growth, the longest period since 1999-2001, with a 1.4% annualized expansion in the third quarter driven by strong exports. Consumer spending declined 0.5% from the previous quarter, but the economy remains solid due to near-full employment and rising capital expenditure. The government plans to announce economic measures by year-end, and the Bank of Japan is likely to maintain its monetary easing framework amid expected inflationary pressure. This growth outlook is expected to ease concerns about sluggish inflation.

site_title: Olam's Q3 net profit grows 18% to S$24.1m on higher sales volume
summary: Olam International reported a 17.5% increase in net profit to S$24.1 million in its third quarter, driven by 41.7% revenue growth to S$6.71 billion and a 99% increase in traded volume to 5.8 million tonnes. Earnings per share dipped to 0.3 Singapore cents. The company's co-founder and CEO, Sunny Verghese, attributed the performance to the successful execution of its strategy, which has generated strong free cash flow. Despite caution about market uncertainties, the company remains confident in its ability to generate long-term value.

site_title: US exchanges seek delay of massive new regulatory audit system
summary: US stock exchanges, including the New York Stock Exchange, Nasdaq, and CBOE, have requested a one-year delay in the implementation of the Consolidated Audit Trail (CAT), a massive database aimed at policing markets. The delay is due to security concerns, including the lack of production-level security testing and difficulties in approving a chief information security officer. The CAT, which was ordered by the SEC after the 2010 "flash crash," would be a central database for all stock and options message traffic, holding sensitive personal identifying information.

site_title: US household debt continues steady rise: NY Federal Reserve Bank
summary: US household debt continued its steady rise in the third quarter, reaching a record high of nearly $13 trillion, with total debt increasing by $116 billion or 1% from the previous quarter. Delinquency rates for auto loans rose to 4% and for credit cards to 7.5%, while mortgage foreclosure rates hit a new low. Officials are watching for signs of consumer or financial institution overextension, citing differences in underwriting standards between bank loans and auto finance company loans, which may indicate a trend similar to the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: Football: global media paid bribes, Fifa trial hears
summary: A former Fifa executive, Alejandro Burzaco, testified in a US federal court that media companies including Fox Sports paid bribes to secure television rights to soccer matches. Burzaco, who pleaded guilty to racketeering and money laundering, said companies such as Fox Sports, TV Globo, and Full Play paid bribes to CONMEBOL executives. He described the "presidential treatment" received by former Fifa officials Julio Grondona and Ricardo Teixeira. The trial, which began on Monday, involves three South American defendants charged with racketeering and money laundering conspiracies.

site_title: Europe: Shares mope at 7-week low as disappointing earnings weigh
summary: European shares fell 0.6% to a seven-week low, erasing earlier gains, as disappointing earnings weighed on the market. The Stoxx 600 benchmark declined despite a strong tech sector. Analysts say a pause in the market is warranted but not a major turning point. The decline was driven by a fall in commodities-related sectors and telecoms firm Altice, outweighing the tech sector's gains.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Wednesday, down 10.3 points or 0.3% at 3,388.73. The Straits Times Index saw 107.3 million shares traded worth S$83.9 million, with losers outpacing gainers 83 to 69. Key stocks like SingTel, DBS, and OCBC fell in early morning trades.

site_title: RHT Health Trust surges 15% on offer by controlling shareholder
summary: RHT Health Trust's units surged 14.8% to 93 Singapore cents after its controlling shareholder, Fortis Healthcare Limited, offered to buy its entire asset portfolio for 46.5 billion Indian rupees (S$965.95 million). This deal includes 12 clinical establishments, four greenfield clinical establishments, and two operating hospitals in India. The offer is for 60 days, and the net proceeds will be substantially distributed to unitholders.

site_title: Largest diamond ever auctioned sold for record US$34m in Geneva
summary: The largest diamond ever offered at auction, a 163.41-carat flawless D colour diamond, sold for a record US$34 million in Geneva. The diamond, suspended from an emerald and diamond necklace called The Art of Grisogono, fetched 33.5 million Swiss francs after taxes and commissions. This marks a new world-record price for a D colour diamond at auction, with a telephone bidder purchasing the necklace for well above the asking price of 25 million francs.

site_title: Gold edges up from one-week low after US dollar dips
summary: Gold prices rose 0.34% to $1,281.94 per ounce after the US dollar fell against major currencies, making the dollar-denominated commodity less expensive to holders of other currencies. The weakening dollar and sluggish stock market contributed to the increase, as traders sought safe-haven assets. Uncertainty over a US tax cut also prompted buying of gold. Gold prices are expected to target $1,350 in the short term, according to market strategist Dan Hussey.

site_title: Strong global rebound is on firm footing
summary: The global economy has turned a corner, with GDP growth averaging 3.9% for the past three quarters. Trade has expanded by 4.7% year-over-year, and purchasing manager indices are at multi-year highs. The synchronous recovery, driven by improved risk attitudes, China's debt reduction, and macro stability in emerging markets, is expected to sustain for longer. Global growth is forecast to remain above trend in 2018, with a potential acceleration to 3.7% next year, driven mainly by emerging markets excluding China.

site_title: Bombardier 'near US$1.1b deal with EgyptAir'
summary: Bombardier is in talks with EgyptAir for a potential $1.1 billion order for 12 CS300 jets, with options to buy another dozen. The deal would come after a recent partnership with Airbus and follows EgyptAir's expansion push after a fatal crash and slumping tourist visits. The CS300, which has a list price of $89.5 million, could help accelerate sales of the C Series program, which has faced delays and cost overruns.

site_title: Half-hearted support for shipping's global regulator
summary: A campaign by the International Chamber of Shipping and the Comité Maritime International aims to encourage governments to ratify international maritime conventions, citing a disappointing record of most countries failing to do so. The campaign focuses on key IMO instruments, including the Hong Kong Convention on ship recycling and the 2003 Protocol to the 1992 Civil Liability and Fund Conventions concerning oil spill compensation. Despite some progress, the slow pace of ratification remains a concern, with the potential for chaos and regional regulations if more countries do not follow suit.

site_title: Blockchain source codes publicly released to spur payment innovations
summary: A financial industry consortium in Singapore has publicly released the source codes for three different blockchain models for inter-bank payments. The move aims to encourage innovation in cross-border payments, increasing speed and improving privacy. The prototypes, developed by 16 institutions, will be made available to central banks, financial institutions, and research institutions to facilitate experiments and innovation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore hopes to "encourage institutions and individuals to contribute and improve" the prototypes, with the goal of developing cheaper, safer, and more efficient cross-border payments.

site_title: Majority of BTO flats being launched to use new pre-fabricated method
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has announced that 80% of the 4,829 Build-to-Order (BTO) flats launched in the latest exercise will be built using the pre-fabricated pre-finished volumetric construction (PPVC) method, a new construction technology that reduces the number of workers needed at construction sites, minimizing safety hazards and inconvenience to the public.

site_title: Lawrence Wong cautions home buyers, developers amid property rebound
summary: Singapore's Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong has cautioned homebuyers and developers amid the strong recovery in property transactions, citing an elevated vacancy rate of 8.4% and a large supply of private residential units. Wong warned developers not to compromise on construction quality if profit margins are under pressure, and hinted at regulatory measures, including stricter accountability and licensing requirements, for those who fail to meet standards. The government aims to strike a balance between monitoring the market and maintaining a stable and sustainable property market.

site_title: Oil falls on rising US output, global demand concern
summary: Oil prices fell for a third consecutive day, with Brent futures dropping 1.5% to $62.21 a barrel and US WTI crude losing 1.9% to $55.70, amid forecasts of rising US crude output and a gloomier outlook for global demand growth. The International Energy Agency (IEA) cut its oil demand growth forecast, citing warmer temperatures and rising output from producer countries. Despite supply restrictions led by Opec and Russia, analysts expect oil prices to remain under pressure, with some speculators selling out of their positions.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell for a third day in a row on Tuesday on forecasts for rising US crude output and a gloomier outlook for global demand growth in a report from the International Energy Agency (IEA).

site_title: US: Stocks fall on tax cut doubts; oil shares hit
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday due to doubts over tax reform and concerns about an oil glut. Analysts said differences between the House and Senate tax bills could delay the proposal, hindering investor confidence. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.1%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.2%. Oil shares, including Apache and Schlumberger, plummeted 3% or more due to an International Energy Agency warning of oversupplied crude markets.

site_title: JD.com posts surprise 1.01b yuan profit in Q3
summary: JD.com, China's second-largest online mall, reported a surprise quarterly profit of 1.01 billion yuan, exceeding analyst expectations. Sales rose 39% to 83.7 billion yuan, driven by investments in logistics and new areas such as fashion. The company owns a fleet of vehicles and warehouses, enhancing customer satisfaction. JD expects revenue in the December quarter to be between 107-110 billion yuan. The company's American depositary receipts jumped 7% to US$42.77, following the strong earnings report.

images.alt_text: The result is a boon for JD.com, which is rapidly broadening its portfolio beyond its traditional strength in consumer electronics as it pursues an asset-heavy vision for online retail.

site_title: Singtel pitches hotel angle for Hill Street site
summary: Singtel has put its Hill Street property up for sale, citing its redevelopment potential as a hotel site. The property, comprising two adjoining land plots, has secured approval for a hotel development with a 3.5 plot ratio. Market watchers expect an indicative price of around S$100m, or nearly S$1,700 per square foot per plot ratio. The sale will close on Dec 13, with CBRE as the exclusive adviser.

site_title: Asean is key to region, says PM Lee as S'pore takes chair
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of ASEAN as a "lifeboat" for regional cooperation, highlighting its role in managing issues and promoting a rules-based regional order. As the new chair, Singapore will prioritize promoting economic integration, enhancing connectivity, and leveraging digital technologies to drive growth. The country also aims to strengthen relations with external partners, including the US and China, and build on recent agreements, such as the Code of Conduct for the South China Sea.

site_title: Resale prices of city-fringe condos hit record high in October: SRX
summary: Resale prices for city-fringe condos in Singapore reached a record high in October, with SRX Property's resale price index for non-landed private homes in the Rest of Central Region (RCR) hitting 184.6, exceeding the previous peak in August 2013. The index rose 1.5% month-on-month in October, with RCR outperforming the other two regions. The overall resale price index for private apartments and condo units rose 1.3% in October, driven by a 46% increase in resale volume for the first 10 months of the year, compared to 2016.

site_title: Britain targets tech talent by doubling visa numbers
summary: Britain is doubling visa numbers for exceptional workers in digital technology and science to 2,000 in an effort to retain an edge after Brexit. The move aims to attract the best talent, as companies like Facebook and Google have announced plans to expand in London. The digital sector has expressed concerns about the impact of Brexit on its status as a leading European destination for tech start-ups and investment. This move is seen as a key step to help Britain maintain its competitive edge in the tech industry.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Theresa May said the digital sector had the full backing of the British government after she met digital entrepreneurs and innovators on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia's US$30b pension to allot more money for foreign deals
summary: Malaysia's Retirement Fund Inc plans to increase its foreign investments to 15% of its US$30 billion portfolio, aiming to boost performance as domestic returns slow. The move comes after a 3 percentage point increase, which would shift US$900 million into foreign deals. The fund is reviewing its asset allocation strategy and is considering investments in Uber, Alibaba Group, and other disruptive technologies. Domestic investment returns are lower than global investments, despite the ringgit being weaker than three years ago.

site_title: Omega hits a US$1m first at auction
summary: An Omega wristwatch prototype with a tourbillon sold for US$1.4 million in Geneva, setting a record price for the brand. The sale, held by Phillips auction house, surpassed Christie's total of 23.9 million Swiss francs, while Sotheby's trailed behind with 5.2 million francs. The vintage-watch market has seen a boom, with Phillips' previous sale of a Rolex valued at US$17.8 million. The sale highlights Phillips' growing presence in the market, challenging larger rivals Christie's and Sotheby's.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Wilmar International reported Q3 earnings within expectations, with revenue rising 0.4% to US$11.1 billion and net profit falling 5.7% to US$370 million. The company's shares have historically been correlated with oil prices, which are rising again. Analysts maintain a neutral to hold stance on the stock, with some lifting their target prices. Wilmar's associates contributed to the earnings growth, but the company's tropical oils and sugar businesses underperformed.

site_title: US$81.3m Van Gogh kicks off NY art auction season
summary: Christie's kicked off the NY art auction season with a US$81.3 million sale of Vincent Van Gogh's "Laboureur dans un champ". The painting set a new record price, surpassing its pre-sale estimate of US$50 million. Fernand Leger's 1913 abstract "Contraste de formes" sold for US$70 million, a new world record, while Rene Magritte's "L'empire des lumieres" set a world auction record for the Belgian surrealist at US$20.56 million. The auction house's flagship sale netted a total of US$479 million, with the highest price paid for a Van Gogh at US$81.3 million.

site_title: China wants to cut renewable energy wastage
summary: China aims to reduce renewable energy waste by 2020, with targets to cut curtailment rates in various regions. The National Energy Administration (NEA) sets targets of 90% for hydro power, 30% for wind power in north-western provinces, and below 20% for solar power in Gansu and Xinjiang. China also plans to boost renewable energy consumption and reduce coal dependence, capping coal-fired power capacity at 1,100 gigawatts by 2020.

site_title: Noble keeps credit ratings but agencies warn of downgrades if liquidity worsens
summary: Credit rating agencies, Moody's and Fitch, have maintained Noble Group's credit ratings despite the company's significant net loss and deteriorating cash position. Noble reported a net loss of $1.2 billion in the third quarter and a cash deficit of $256 million at end-September 2017. The agencies warned that if liquidity worsens, Noble's ratings could be downgraded to "CC" signaling probable default. The company is attempting to raise cash through asset sales, including the sale of its US oil liquids unit, North America Corp.

site_title: Singapore workers to see 2.7% real pay increase next year: survey
summary: Singapore workers can expect a 2.7% real pay increase in 2018, according to the Salary Trends survey by ECA International. This nominal salary rise of 4% factors in an inflation rate of 1.3%. The survey ranks Singapore a joint 9th globally, with other APAC countries like India and Vietnam also experiencing above-inflation salary increases.

site_title: US researchers using nanotech, gene editing to turn off cholesterol gene in mice
summary: US researchers used nanotechnology and CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing to turn off a key cholesterol-related gene in mouse liver cells, achieving a 35% drop in total cholesterol. The system, which protects CRISPR components from degradation, was effective in eliminating the gene in over 80% of liver cells. The breakthrough holds promise for treating high cholesterol and other liver diseases, and the team plans to refine the approach for use in humans.

site_title: Cosco Shipping gains 7.3%; shares highest in over two years
summary: Cosco Shipping International (Singapore) Co shares rose 7.3% to a 2.5-year high, closing at 58.5 Singapore cents, after the company announced a S$488 million cash buyout of logistics firm Cogent Holdings. The stock's price has nearly doubled since the start of November, driven by the acquisition. Analysts attribute the rally to the cash buyout, which represents a 5.2% upside for Cogent's shareholders. The company's divestiture of its shipyard business and plans to buy Indonesian shipping logistics company PT Ocean Global also contributed to the gains.

site_title: SMEs should use the grants that come, but be nimble too
summary: The Singapore government has launched "Industry Digital Plans" to support small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the logistics and retail sectors, providing bundled grants, guides, and funding for digital solutions. Despite this, a recent report by the Economist Intelligence Unit ranked Singapore 14th in business confidence in the digital environment, with businesses citing government aid as a major source of support. The report suggests that government assistance may be hindering innovation, as businesses in top-ranked cities rely less on government support and instead seek funding from private sources.

site_title: Goldman lays groundwork for control in China onshore business
summary: Goldman Sachs is close to gaining control of its Chinese onshore business after its partner, Fang Fenglei, is open to selling a majority stake in their local joint venture. The US firm already has a 33% stake and has been negotiating with Fang's associates to acquire the remaining shares. China's decision to lift a 49% ownership cap on foreign banks' joint ventures has created a favorable environment for Goldman Sachs' expansion in China. The company plans to increase headcount and capital deployment in China once it achieves equity control, with potential implications for its competitors, including UBS and Morgan Stanley.

site_title: Paradise Papers reveal lack of reform
summary: The Paradise Papers reveal widespread tax evasion and money laundering in offshore financial centers, with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development estimating 4-10% of global tax revenue lost annually. The leak of confidential documents from law firm Appleby has sparked controversy over aggressive tax planning by multinationals. The OECD is leading efforts to combat tax evasion and improve transparency, with over 90 countries signing a common reporting standard. The revelations suggest a need for reform, following the Panama Papers scandal, and highlight the need for greater transparency in offshore financial centers.

site_title: New Indonesian halal law seen disrupting business, hurting SMEs
summary: Indonesia's new halal law, set to take effect in 2019, is expected to disrupt business and harm small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), with estimated compliance costs reaching $4.4 billion. The law, which requires certification of food, drink, textiles, and pharmaceuticals, will affect hundreds of billions of dollars in consumer products. Industry groups worry about the impact on SMEs, which may struggle to afford the costs of reprinting labels and disposing of finished goods. The administration of President Joko Widodo faces a delicate political environment, with Islamic conservatives holding more clout, and businesses hope that the president may use his mandate to amend the legislation to make standards voluntary again.

site_title: Solar companies grapple with shortage of key material
summary: Solar manufacturers face a shortage of key material, polysilicon, due to China's environmental crackdown and annual lull in production. The price of polysilicon has spiked 35% in the past four months, affecting companies such as Canadian Solar and Hanwha Q Cells. The shortage is expected to drag down earnings for Chinese manufacturers, with Canadian Solar reporting a decline in profit. Analysts predict that prices will eventually come down, but margins will be affected until then, with some companies, like JA Solar, yet to release their quarterly results.

site_title: Amazon tries to catch up in move to monitor chemicals in products
summary: Amazon is developing a plan to regulate chemicals in its products, but still lags behind retailers like Walmart, Target, and Apple in reducing toxic chemicals and disclosing their presence. Amazon received a D grade in Mind the Store's ranking, ranking 14th out of 30 retailers. The company is in the process of developing a chemicals policy, but has not yet implemented a public safer-chemicals policy. Other retailers, such as Walmart and Target, have introduced and expanded programs to reduce chemicals in their products.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare, Healthway Medical to explore smart healthcare solutions
summary: Singapore-listed companies OUE Lippo Healthcare and Healthway Medical have partnered with South Korean firms SK Telecom and Seoul National University Bundang Hospital to explore innovative healthcare solutions. The partnership aims to leverage cutting-edge ICT in healthcare applications, including hospital information systems, tele-medicine, and smart primary health centers. The collaboration may lead to the formation of joint ventures to market and implement hospital information systems. The move is expected to enhance market competitiveness and provide better care and convenience to patients.

site_title: Provisions offer clue to oil & gas sector turning the corner
summary: DBS Group Holdings made a significant move to clean up its exposure to troubled oil-and-gas borrowers, nearly doubling its provisions for bad debts to S$815 million. This move is seen as a positive step forward for the offshore and marine sector, which has been battered by the downturn. Industry observers believe that successful restructuring, including lender involvement, is crucial for recovery. Despite this, uncertainty remains, with some companies still under acute stress and a long road to full recovery ahead.

site_title: Euro scores biggest daily rise in a month
summary: The euro surged 0.5% against the dollar, its largest daily rise in a month, driven by growing expectations of strong economic growth in the euro zone. The euro zone economy expanded by 2.5% in the September quarter, surpassing the US, and investors resumed buying risky assets. The euro's rise was also supported by the European Central Bank's "forward guidance" on future policy moves, which has steered market expectations. The dollar slipped, more than reversing its previous gains, as investors took profits.

site_title: HSBC to pay 300m euros to avoid French tax fraud trial
summary: HSBC's Swiss unit has agreed to pay 300 million euros to avoid a French tax fraud trial. The deal, under a new procedure, allows companies to negotiate a fine instead of going to trial. HSBC was accused of helping French clients hide at least 1.67 billion euros from tax authorities through offshore tax havens. The case against HSBC Holdings has been dropped, with prosecutors dropping charges and French authorities dropping the case against the bank. The probe also targeted former HSBC executives, including Peter Braunwalder and Judah Elmaleh.

site_title: PM Abe presses on with his dream of a peaceful alliance
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Security Diamond" alliance, comprising the US, India, Japan, and Australia, has been revived after officials from the four countries met in Manila. The quadrilateral alliance aims to balance China's aggressive military expansion in the region through closer military and strategic linkages. The partnership also seeks to counter China's financial hegemony by promoting alternative economic development models. The move is seen as a response to China's growing assertiveness under President Xi Jinping, and the initial dialogue is expected to gradually turn into ministerial-level talks and eventually a summit of government heads.

site_title: Singapore in top 10 in terms of average wealth per adult
summary: Singapore ranks 9th globally in terms of average wealth per adult, with US$173,400 per adult, following Switzerland's US$537,600 and Australia's US$402,600 as of mid-2017.

site_title: URA and Redas team up to seek public involvement for urban innovations
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and the Real Estate Developers Association of Singapore (Redas) have launched the URA-REDAS SPARK Challenge, a joint initiative to seek public involvement in urban innovations. The challenge aims to enhance the quality of the built environment, with the first theme focusing on health and wellness. Participants can submit project proposals online, with the top three proposals selected to develop two prototypes, which will be showcased in six selected malls. The public can vote for their favorites, and the winning prototype will receive S$10,000.

site_title: Golden Agri's Q3 net profit down 80% on forex loss, tax
summary: Golden Agri-Resources, the world's second-largest palm oil producer, reported an 80.1% drop in Q3 net profit to US$43.7 million due to foreign exchange losses and tax expenses. However, the company expects 10-15% year-on-year growth in fresh fruit bunches (FFB) production, driven by a favorable La Nina weather phenomenon, which may bring higher rainfall in Southeast Asia. La Nina is also expected to impact soybean production in the Western hemisphere.

site_title: Tat Hong still in the red for Q2 but halves losses
summary: Tat Hong Holdings, a Singapore-based crane supplier, reported a net loss of S$2.79 million for the second quarter, down 48% from the previous year. Revenue rose 13% to S$124.27 million, driven by improved business in Australia, where the general equipment rental business posted a 34% increase. The company also reported higher equipment and parts sales in Australia and revenue from the tower crane rental segment in China. Despite the positive results, Tat Hong cautioned about "challenging market conditions" in certain parts of the Asean region and will continue with fleet rationalisation activities.

site_title: Straco's Q3 profit down 6% at S$21.4m
summary: Straco Corporation, a Singapore-based tourist attraction operator, reported a 6% decline in net profit to S$21.4 million for the third quarter of 2017. Revenue fell 3.2% to S$46.1 million, mainly due to lower revenue from Underwater World Xiamen. However, other attractions like Shanghai Ocean Aquarium and Singapore Flyer contributed to the positive growth. Visitors to all attractions dropped 5.1% to 1.91 million, mainly due to fewer visitors to UWX. The company's executive chairman expressed satisfaction with the overall performance, citing positive growth at other attractions.

site_title: MAS to debut blockchain-based trade network with HK in 2019
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to launch a blockchain-based trade network with Hong Kong in early 2019, aiming to improve the efficiency and safety of trade finance. This network, called the Global Trade Connectivity Network (GTCN), will enable the seamless transfer of digital documents and data across borders. MAS is also exploring similar partnerships with China and is collaborating with the Bank of Canada to test the use of distributed-ledger technology for cross-border payments. The move is part of Singapore's efforts to maintain its position as a top financial center and to harness fintech innovation.

site_title: China activity slows as pollution measures bite
summary: China's economic activity slowed in October, with industrial output rising 6.2% year-on-year, down from 6.6% in September. The slowdown was attributed to a cooling property sector and softer foreign demand, as well as disruptions from an anti-pollution crackdown. Retail sales grew 10% last month, while fixed-asset investment growth slowed to 7.3% in the January-October period. Analysts expect the economy to continue slowing, with a potential knock of 0.2 percentage points off headline GDP growth in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Top central bankers vow to talk investors out of easy money
summary: Top central bankers from the Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, Bank of England, and Bank of Japan pledged to guide investors on future policy moves as they withdraw monetary stimulus. The central bankers emphasized the importance of clear communication to avoid market upsets. ECB President Mario Draghi noted that forward guidance has been effective, while Fed Chair Janet Yellen stressed that guidance should be conditional and related to the economy's actual development. The bankers also acknowledged the challenges of steering markets, citing past examples of market reactions to policy hints.

site_title: Lufthansa offers 250m euros to take on most of Alitalia's fleet, half of staff -source
summary: Lufthansa has offered €250 million to take on most of Alitalia's fleet and half of its staff, a source revealed. This comes after Alitalia's staff rejected a plan to cut jobs and salaries. The German airline is one of seven companies that submitted binding offers for Alitalia by October 16. This move follows Alitalia's special administration earlier this year, which was put in place after the airline made a profit only a few times in its 70-year history.

site_title: How to foil cyberspies on your business trip
summary: Business travelers are vulnerable to cyber espionage when using public Wi-Fi, sending unencrypted data, and using weak passwords. Experts warn that hackers and state-sponsored spies can steal sensitive information such as technical product specifications, investment plans, and marketing strategies. To protect against this, devices should send encrypted data, strong passwords should be used, and two-factor authentication should be enabled. Travelers should also be cautious of physical security, such as leaving laptops in hotel rooms or using public Wi-Fi. Companies can take steps to improve cybersecurity for business travelers by issuing devices with built-in security features and providing training on secure practices.

site_title: Value of land deals 'set to hit record in 2017'
summary: Land transactions in Singapore reached a six-year high of S$12.6 billion in 2017, with the total value expected to reach a historical record of S$16 billion if all pipeline deals materialize. The surge is attributed to land prices doubling in the last decade, with developers anticipating an upturn.

site_title: Silicon Valley blasts move to tax startup options
summary: The US Senate has proposed taxing stock options as they vest for startup employees, resulting in potential annual tax bills in the tens of thousands of dollars. This provision, aimed at offsetting tax breaks in the bill, would require employees to pay regular income tax on the value gain of their stock options before they can be exercised. The move has sparked panic in Silicon Valley, with startup founders and investors warning that it could be "crippling" to the industry and force them to sell their companies or take on massive debt.

site_title: Millions more just got high blood pressure
summary: The American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association have expanded the definition of hypertension, classifying 30 million more Americans as having high blood pressure, bringing the total to 103 million adults. The new guidelines now consider a systolic reading of 130 mmHg or higher as stage 1 hypertension, and those under 45 will see a tripling of men and doubling of women diagnosed. Experts recommend lifestyle changes such as a healthier diet and exercise, with medication only for those with additional risk factors.

site_title: Hong Kong versus Singapore: A tale of two tax systems
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong have long been competing for businesses to set up in their territories, with both cities offering low corporate tax rates and a holistic tax-friendly environment. However, a recent announcement by Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam of a two-tier profit tax system may reduce Singapore's advantage for less profitable companies. Singapore's effective tax rate can be as low as 4.25%, while Hong Kong's is 16.5%.
