Singapore also offers a group relief system, allowing tax losses to be transferred between entities, while Hong Kong has no group relief. Ultimately, businesses should consider both tax and non-tax factors when deciding between the two cities.

site_title: Goldman can hit US$13b in new consumer loans in three years: CFO
summary: Goldman Sachs' Marcus online lending business is expected to reach $13 billion in new consumer loans in three years, according to CFO Marty Chavez. The platform has already lent out $2 billion and aims to achieve a return on equity of mid- to high teens. Goldman launched Marcus in 2016 to target credit card borrowers with debt consolidation loans. The company believes Marcus can contribute $1 billion in annual revenue by 2020, despite concerns about weakening consumer credit conditions.

site_title: China home sales down the most in 3 years as curbs bite
summary: China's new home sales declined 3.4% in November, the largest drop in nearly three years, amid curbs on price increases. Sales by value dropped to 909 billion yuan, following a 9.2% increase in September. Investment in real estate development slowed, growing 5.6% last month, and a Bloomberg index of Chinese real-estate owners and developers slipped 0.3%. The data suggests the government's efforts to control home prices are having an impact, but also indicates a moderating economy.

site_title: Safeguard your identity in the data breach era
summary: To safeguard identity in the data breach era, experts recommend creating long, nonsensical passwords or using a password manager, and enabling two-factor authentication for sensitive accounts. Additionally, using biometric authentication such as fingerprint or facial recognition can provide an extra layer of security. It's also advised to avoid reusing passwords and to select security questions that are difficult to guess. By implementing these measures, individuals can significantly reduce the risk of falling victim to cyberattacks.

images.alt_text: Almost everyone has a digital identity nowadays - nearly 60% of residents across Asean were Internet users in 2016, so attackers have a vast playing field. Learning to outsmart the bad guys can go a long way in helping to secure our digital identities.

site_title: Cloud: Foundation for the future
summary: IBM has unified its cloud technology into one architecture to help enterprises simplify their data management and migration to the public cloud. The IBM Cloud approach is differentiated by three core elements: a data-first approach to fuel innovation, a hybrid cloud model that combines public and private cloud environments, and access to higher-value services such as AI, analytics, and blockchain. This approach is being adopted by various clients, including airlines, financial services firms, and startups, to unlock transformative insights from their data and gain a competitive edge.

site_title: Art project transforms historic Indian fishing dock
summary: Thirty artists from around the world transformed Mumbai's 142-year-old Sassoon Dock into an exhibition space as part of the St+art Urban Art Festival. The dock, home to Mumbai's traditional Koli fishing community, now features colourful artworks, including large portraits and murals representing the community. The exhibition, which opened on November 11, aims to make art accessible to everyone and runs until December 30. The project is part of the seventh edition of the St+art Urban Art Festival, which also features a giant mural on the nearby Churchgate railway station.

site_title: China's OTC equity market touches 3-year low
summary: China's OTC equity market, also known as the New Third Board, reached a 3-year low of 1,000.437 points on Tuesday, amid growing investor concerns over tightening regulations. The market, which was seen as a key financing channel for small private firms, is struggling with low liquidity due to stricter supervision. Regulators have tightened scrutiny on initial public offerings, making it harder for companies to go public, and investors are losing interest, further exacerbating the market's decline.

site_title: Forecasts of cheap batteries zap India's 25-year coal power deals
summary: India's power distributors are shifting away from traditional 25-year coal power deals to shorter-term agreements of 10 years or less due to falling battery costs and increasing renewable energy. The move aims to stabilize the domestic electricity grid and benefit from softer prices in the future. Coal-fired power plants are struggling to find customers, and the poor financial condition of state-owned power distribution companies is limiting their ability to buy and supply more electricity.

site_title: En bloc sales may run into new road-block
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has mandated a traffic impact study for en bloc sales, which may cap the number of units built, potentially tempering bidding fervour. Developers must consult LTA and submit a study assessing traffic impact and proposing car-lite initiatives before submitting outline planning applications. This new rule may reduce profit margins for developers and lead to lower prices for collective sales, but analysts expect a small cooling effect on the market.

site_title: New hub in CBD for fintech innovation to spur startup scene
summary: A new fintech innovation hub, 80RR Fintech Hub SG, is being set up in Singapore's Central Business District. The 100,000 sq ft space will provide physical spaces for experimentation and collaboration, supporting the growth of the local fintech scene. The hub will offer rental spaces for startups and fintech companies, with the aim of fostering innovation and entrepreneurship in the sector. The launch follows a series of fintech innovation labs and research centers established by global multinationals and startups in Singapore over the past few years.

site_title: New Ericsson chief invests in R&D to safeguard company's future
summary: Ericsson's new CEO, Borje Ekholm, is investing in research and development to safeguard the company's future despite pressure to cut costs. He foresees another wave of new rivals emerging due to the shift to software-based networks, and believes investing in R&D is crucial to protecting Ericsson's market position. Ekholm has given himself breathing room on mid-term profit targets and is focusing on competing over the long run, particularly in fifth-generation mobile technology and services.

site_title: Singapore in top 10 in terms of average wealth per adult
summary: Singapore's average wealth per adult remains high at US$268,800, ranking 9th globally, according to the 2017 Global Wealth Report by Credit Suisse Research Institute. Household wealth in Singapore grew 3.4% to US$1.2 trillion, with 22% of the population having less than US$10,000 in wealth. The number of millionaires in Singapore is expected to grow to 170,000 by 2022, while ultra-high net worth individuals are projected to reach over 1,000.

site_title: Bombardier near US$1.1b C Series deal with EgyptAir
summary: Bombardier is in advanced discussions with EgyptAir for a potential US$1.1 billion order for 12-15 C Series CS300 jets, valued at around US$1.1 billion, according to sources. This deal would be the program's second major order in less than a month, following a partnership with Airbus. The agreement, which could be announced at the Dubai Air Show, would give Bombardier another customer for its new jet, which has been plagued by delays and cost overruns.

site_title: Miclyn Express Offshore working with Sias to engage bondholders
summary: Miclyn Express Offshore is working with the Securities Investors Association (Sias) to engage holders of its US$150 million 8.75% bonds due on Nov 25, 2018. The company is not in default, but the offshore and marine sector is experiencing a downturn. Sias will facilitate meetings between Miclyn and its bondholders, who can register their interest to join the steering committee. The move aims to restructure the debt and mitigate the impact of the downturn on the company.

site_title: White House still all at sea over China
summary: US President Donald Trump's 12-day Asia tour was met with criticism from pundits and journalists, who claimed he failed to achieve significant diplomatic achievements. Despite the trip's symbolic nature, Trump's "America First" agenda was seen as a protectionist and isolationist stance, potentially worsening US ties with China. In contrast, former President Barack Obama's 2009 trip to China was also criticized for achieving little, but his "Pivot to Asia" strategy aimed to counterbalance China's rise. Trump's emphasis on bilateral trade deals and Realpolitik considerations may not be enough to succeed where Obama's efforts failed, highlighting the need for a new grand strategy in US foreign policy.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower over tax plan doubts
summary: US stocks fell for the fifth consecutive day, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 65.35 points, or 0.28%, to 23,374.35, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. Investors are concerned about Republican tax plans and the potential for more interest rate hikes, weighing on the market. The declines follow a mixed session on Monday, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: China Jinjiang Environment's Q3 bottom line down 28%
summary: China Jinjiang Environment Holding Company reported a 28% drop in net profit to 100.82 million yuan (S$20.7 million) in Q3 2017 due to lower gross profit and revenue. The company's earnings per share fell to 8.28 fen, down from 12.29 fen a year earlier. Additionally, the company's subsidiaries are selling a 42% stake in Inner Mongolia Pulate Transportation Energy Co for 67.2 million yuan, an interested party transaction. The disposal is expected to be completed in early 2018.

site_title: Moderation in Chinese data drags STI
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.59% to 3,399.09, dragged down by concerns over delayed US tax cuts and moderation in Chinese data. China's industrial production growth declined to 6.2% year-on-year, mainly due to air-pollution curbs. The STI's performance closely followed the Dow futures, which remained unchanged. Market movers, including Wilmar International and OCBC, contributed to the losses. Despite this, New Zealand equities rose, and US tax cuts uncertainty weighed on the market.

site_title: Ellipsiz says controlling shareholder approached by third party for potential transaction
summary: A controlling shareholder of Ellipsiz, Bevrian, has been approached by a third party to explore a potential transaction, which may lead to an offer to acquire shares. The discussions are at a preliminary stage, and no definitive agreement has been reached. The company advises shareholders to exercise caution and exercise vigilance in dealing with its shares until further notice.

site_title: Sydney's pick of funny name for ferry an insult, says union
summary: The New South Wales state government has named one of its Sydney ferries "Ferry McFerryface" after a public vote, with Transport Minister Andrew Constance describing it as "one for the kids." However, the Maritime Union, which staffs the ferry fleet, has expressed frustration with the decision, citing that ferries have traditionally been named after Sydney's beaches and successful Olympians. The union claims the name is an insult, and the decision treats public transport as a joke.

site_title: Rotary Engineering's Q3 profit expands by 29%
summary: Rotary Engineering's Q3 profit expanded by 29% year-over-year to S$1.58 million, driven by a 43% surge in revenue to S$75.24 million. Despite global economic uncertainty, the company's order book stood at S$474.8 million. The controlling family is set to take the company private with a cash offer of S$0.46 per share, launched through Orochem Pte Ltd.

site_title: Qatar 'thousand times better off' without Gulf allies: Emir
summary: Qatar's Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani stated his country is "a thousand times better off" without its Gulf allies, Saudi Arabia and the UAE, amid a dispute over alleged support of Islamist extremism. Despite the boycott, Qatar plans to introduce food security projects and has received assistance from Iran, Turkey, and Spain. The emir also announced plans to hold elections for the Shura Council, which will be the first step towards reforming the country's governance. Qatar remains committed to its sovereignty and economic strength, despite the economic impact of the boycott.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to work with partners in Hong Kong and Canada to develop the use of blockchain technology and e-payments, aiming to create a fintech hub. Resale condo and private apartment prices in Singapore's city fringe reached a new high in October, according to SRX Property. Noble Group agreed to include Noble Petro in its sale to Vitol US Holding Co, while a financial industry consortium released blockchain models' source codes to spur innovation in inter-bank payments.

site_title: Healthway Medical Corp in the red in Q3
summary: Healthway Medical Corp reported a Q3 2017 loss of S$2.82 million, down from a profit of S$69,000 the previous year, due to higher staff costs and operating expenses. Revenue rose 6.6% to S$27.16 million, driven by its specialist and wellness healthcare segment. The company aims to improve patient care with its new management team and recently opened a gastroenterology clinic. Despite the challenges, Healthway Medical is working to expand its clinic network.

site_title: For Noble, banks' pullout marks deepening crisis
summary: Noble Group, a distressed commodity trader, faces a deepening financial crisis as banks pull out of its revolving credit facility and other financing. DBS Group sold off its US$60 million stake in the facility for 44 cents on the dollar, while ANZ sold a US$45 million block for the same price. The move indicates growing doubt in the market about Noble's ability to meet its debts, with credit default swaps showing an 82% probability of default for its bonds due in March next year. Noble's remaining bankers are re-examining their exposure, and a deepening lack of confidence may lead to the winding up of the firm unless an equity injection is secured, with Chinese sovereign wealth fund CIC remaining quiet as a potential investor.

site_title: CWT Q3 net profit down 9%
summary: CWT reported a 9% year-on-year decline in net profit for the third quarter, reaching S$20.64 million, despite a 34% jump in revenue to S$3.14 billion due to higher commodity prices. Profit after tax fell 7% to S$21.52 million, primarily due to lower gross profit from base metals concentrates trading and start-up costs from a new logistics hub. Earnings per share decreased from 3.77 cents to 3.44 cents.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia posts bigger loss in Q3
summary: Hong Leong Asia reported a wider third-quarter loss of S$17.58 million, down from S$13.92 million a year ago, due to losses from its consumer products unit. Revenue rose 16% to S$963.19 million, driven by growth from its Yuchai diesel engines unit. Loss per share increased to 4.7 cents. The group expects weak performance for the remainder of 2017 and plans to explore strategic options, including restructuring its consumer products unit, while maintaining cost control.

site_title: Wheelock Properties Q3 bottom line strengthened by write-back
summary: Wheelock Properties reported a 72% year-on-year jump in profit to S$48.77 million for Q3, driven by a S$10.83 million write-back of diminution in value of The Panorama development in Singapore. Revenue rose 20% to S$182.65 million, with earnings per share increasing to 4.08 Singapore cents. The group expects recurring income from rental income, investment, and associate profits to continue. As of Sept 30, 78 of 84 units at Ardmore Three and 299 of 338 units at Scotts Square have been sold, with all units at The Panorama sold.

site_title: China Environment receives 41.7m yuan demand from ex-chairman's wife
summary: China Environment received a letter of demand from Chen Fen Hua, wife of former executive chairman Huang Min, seeking 47.1 million yuan. The company is assessing the claim and will take action. China Environment has reported Mr. Huang to the Commercial Affairs Department in Singapore regarding certain receivables and allegations of fraud.

site_title: Jubilee Industries pulls itself out of the red in H1 2018
summary: Jubilee Industries Holdings reported a net profit of S$808,000 for the six months ended Sept 30, 2017, reversing a loss of S$2.68 million in the same period a year ago. Revenue grew 84% year-over-year to S$87.48 million, driven by its electronic components distribution segment. Non-executive chairman Terence Tea aims to increase business volume and focus on higher-margin products, with plans for organic growth and mergers and acquisitions in both electronic and mechanical segments.

site_title: Govt estimates doubling of new private housing units in the next 1-2 years: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's government expects a doubling of new private housing units over the next 1-2 years, with over 30,000 vacant units. Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong urged buyers to do their homework, citing an 8.4% vacancy rate, the highest in nearly two decades. The government may take measures against developers who compromise on quality, including stricter regulations and penalties. Developers will also face higher land prices and the risk of paying penalties for not completing projects within five years.

site_title: Property developer Land Securities says Brexit negotiations too slow
summary: Land Securities, Britain's largest listed property developer, expressed concerns over the slow pace of Brexit negotiations, citing increased caution in the market. Despite a 5.2% rise in revenue profit to £203 million, the company reported a £33 million pre-tax loss for the six months ending Sept 30. The decrease in value of its combined portfolio narrowed to £19 million, and adjusted diluted net asset value per share rose 1.1%. The company's Chief Executive attributed the uncertainty to the slow pace of negotiations, stating that its balance sheet remains healthy.

site_title: Qatar real estate slump deepened in October
summary: Qatar's real estate market continued to decline in October, with housing and utility prices falling 5.4% from the previous year, their largest drop in several years. The decline was attributed to economic sanctions imposed by other Arab states, hurting investor sentiment and stifling demand. Consumer prices rose 0.2% from a year ago, driven by a 4.9% increase in food and beverage prices. The sanctions have disrupted imports, leading to higher food prices and tightening liquidity in the banking system.

site_title: URA and Redas roll out initiative to seek public input on urban solutions
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and the Real Estate Developers Association of Singapore (Redas) have launched the URA-REDAS SPARK Challenge, a public initiative to gather innovative ideas for enhancing health and wellness in the built environment. The public can submit project proposals online until February 7, 2018, with three selected proposals receiving $5,000 each to develop two prototypes. The winning prototype will be chosen based on judging criteria and public voting, with a total of six prototypes to be placed in six Redas-member malls.

site_title: Top central bankers vow to talk investors out of easy money
summary: Top central bankers from the Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, Bank of England, and Bank of Japan have emphasized the importance of clear communication to investors as they gradually withdraw monetary stimulus. The central bankers agreed that forward guidance, or communicating policy intentions, is a crucial tool to manage investor expectations. However, they also acknowledged that past instances of poor communication have led to market volatility. The bankers stressed the need for simplicity and clarity in their messaging to avoid misunderstandings and maintain investor confidence.

site_title: Volvo owner buys flying-car maker planning first model for 2019
summary: Volvo owner Zhejiang Geely Holding Group Co has acquired US flying-car maker Terrafugia Inc, with plans to launch its first model in 2019. Terrafugia aims to deliver the first vertical take-off and landing car by 2023. The deal, approved by regulators, sees Terrafugia stay headquartered in the US and Chris Jaran, a former Bell Helicopter China executive, become CEO. The acquisition is part of a growing interest in flying cars, with Geely Founder Li Shufu competing against billionaires like Larry Page.

site_title: Services boost US producer prices; underlying inflation firming
summary: US producer prices rose 0.4% in October, driven by a surge in services costs, leading to the largest annual increase in wholesale inflation in over 5-1/2 years. The 12-month PPI jumped 2.8%, the largest increase since February 2012, supporting expectations of a gradual inflation increase and keeping the Federal Reserve on track to raise interest rates in December.

site_title: SingPost Q2 earnings dip by 9.5% in the absence of previous one-off gain
summary: SingPost's Q2 earnings dropped 9.5% to S$28.47 million, despite a 10.2% increase in revenue to S$354.7 million. The company's logistics segment contributed the largest growth, driven by 7.6% increase in revenue. Postal revenue rose 16.9% due to cross-border e-commerce deliveries. However, e-commerce revenue slipped 0.8% and earnings per share decreased to 1.09 Singapore cents. An interim dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent was declared, half the size of the previous year's dividend.

site_title: Ikea counts cost of Brexit as furniture import prices soar
summary: Ikea UK has reported a 13.7% increase in costs due to Brexit, primarily driven by the drop in sterling. To maintain affordability, Ikea absorbed most costs and increased prices by 3.6%. Despite rising costs, Ikea's UK sales rose 5.8% and overall retail sales grew 3.6% to €34.1 billion, driven by growth in China, Germany, Canada, and Poland.

site_title: Singapore shares resume lower after Tuesday's break; STI at 3,398.9
summary: Singapore shares fell 20.23 points, or 0.6%, to 3,398.9 on Tuesday, with about 1.52 billion shares changing hands. The decline came after the mid-day break, with losers outnumbering gainers 309 to 93. Despite the drop, the Straits Times Index remains above its 50-day moving average.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Tuesday, down 3.88 points to 1,733.61. The index saw 3 billion lots worth RM2.6 billion traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 588 to 300.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: MoneyMax Financial Services' subsidiary Cash Online Sdn Bhd has agreed to purchase 13 pawn brokers in Malaysia for RM56.6 million (S$18.3 million) in cash. Ellipsiz's controlling shareholder Bevrian has been approached to explore a possible transaction that may lead to an offer to acquire shares in the company. Wheelock Properties posted a 72% year-on-year profit jump to S$48.77 million, driven by a S$10.83 million write-back on The Panorama development. Hong Leong Asia's third-quarter loss widened to S$17.58 million, while Jubilee Industries swung into the black with a net profit of S$808,000.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall; won up
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell 3.71 points, or 0.15%, to 2,526.64 at 0632 GMT. The won rose 0.13% to 1,117.49 per US dollar, while bond yields rose. Foreigners sold 300.32 billion won worth of shares, and the US dollar has risen 7.36% against the won this year. Despite the decline, the KOSPI is up around 24.9% so far this year.

site_title: German economy powers on as trade, investments drive Q3 growth
summary: Germany's economy grew 0.8% in Q3, exceeding consensus forecasts, driven by strong exports and investments. This marks the second consecutive quarter of growth, solidifying Germany's role as the euro zone's growth engine. Companies are stepping up investments, contributing to the expansion, according to economist Ulrike Kastens.

site_title: Singapore shares lose 20 points as Asian markets remain weak
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 20.04 points or 0.59% to 3,399.09 on Tuesday, as Asian markets remained weak due to concerns over delayed US tax cuts and sluggish Chinese data. The benchmark index closed lower, with turnover reaching S$1.7 billion. This marks the second consecutive day of losses for the STI.

site_title: Straco Corporation's Q3 earnings down on lower revenue
summary: Straco Corporation recorded a 6% fall in earnings for Q3 2017, with net profit at S$21.4 million and earnings per share at 2.48 Singapore cents. Revenue declined 3.2% to S$46.11 million, mainly due to lower revenue from Underwater World Xiamen, but was partially offset by higher revenue from other attractions. Visitor numbers to all attractions decreased 5.1% to 1.91 million, primarily impacted by UWX's 30% drop in visitor numbers due to local restrictions.

site_title: China coal output falls to eight-month low on party congress
summary: China's coal production in October plummeted to its lowest in eight months, falling 8% from September to 9.15 million tons per day. This decline was largely due to mining operations being halted to ensure safety during the 19th Communist Party Congress. Despite a 4.8% rebound in total output for the first 10 months of the year, analysts expect domestic coal output to return to September levels in November as mines resume operations after the party congress.

site_title: Singtel puts Hill St site up for sale
summary: Singtel has put its Hill Street property in Singapore up for sale through a public tender conducted by CBRE, with a provisional permission to redevelop the site into a hotel project. The property, comprising two land plots, has a combined land area of 39,738 sq ft and a maximum allowable GFA of 139,084 sq ft. The sale is expected to close on Dec 13, with indicative pricing estimated at around S$100 million per plot, equivalent to nearly S$1,700 per square foot.

site_title: UK regulator clears Tesco's £3.7b Booker takeover
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has provisionally cleared Tesco's £3.7 billion takeover of wholesaler Booker, citing that the two companies do not compete head-to-head in most of their activities. The CMA found that Tesco primarily competes with other retailers, while Booker supplies to caterers, independent, and symbol group retailers. The takeover is expected to complete in early 2018, with Tesco stating it will create the UK's leading food business and bring benefits to independent retailers, caterers, and suppliers.

site_title: MoneyMax to buy stakes in 13 pawn brokers in Malaysia for RM56.6m
summary: MoneyMax Financial Services has agreed to purchase stakes in 13 pawn brokers in Malaysia for RM56.6 million, with the plan to expand its geographical network of pawn broking operations. The acquisition is conditional on approval from relevant authorities and valuation of the target companies. The deal is expected to have minimal impact on MoneyMax's earnings per share. The transactions are separate from a joint venture established in 2014 between MoneyMax and Chong Mei Sang to carry on the business of pawn broking in Malaysia.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge down to extend losing streak
summary: Tokyo stocks declined on Tuesday, extending a losing streak, as investors sought fresh trading pegs after the corporate earnings season. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.98 points to close at 22,380.01, while the Topix index declined 0.26% to 1,778.87. This marks the fifth straight session of losses for the Nikkei 225 index.

site_title: US imposes anti-dumping duties on Chinese hardwood plywood
summary: The US has imposed anti-dumping duties on imports of hardwood plywood products from China, totaling $1.12 billion last year. The Commerce Department found that Chinese exporters sold the products at 183.36% less than fair value, and that the Chinese government provided subsidies ranging from 22.3% to 195%. This move is part of the US's efforts to address its trade deficit with China, which stood at $350 billion last year. The duties will be imposed starting January 20, 2018.

site_title: Crane supplier Tat Hong's Q2 net loss narrows to 48% from improved performance Down Under
summary: Tat Hong Holdings, a mainboard-listed crane supplier, reported a net loss of S$2.79 million in Q2, a 48% drop from the same period last year. The company attributed the improvement to better performance in its Australian operations, with revenue rising 13% to S$124.265 million. However, the crane rental division was the only segment to see a decline in revenue. Despite the losses, Tat Hong's results showed a significant improvement from the same period in the previous year.

site_title: Brokers' take: Phillip Capital downgrades Asian Pay Television Trust to 'accumulate'
summary: Phillip Capital downgraded Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT) to "accumulate" due to the company's share price appreciation without a change in fundamentals. The trust's dividend yield and operating cash flows are considered attractive, but its average revenue per user (ARPU) remains sluggish. Capital expenditure is expected to decline in FY2018. The broker shaved its FY2017 earnings estimates due to higher FX losses and taxes, but expects cash flows to improve in FY2018 as capex for premium digital services ends. The outlook remains stable.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall after sluggish China economic data
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.1% on Tuesday, following China's economic data showing industrial output, fixed asset investment, and retail sales missed expectations. The Hang Seng index dropped to 29,152.12 points, while the China Enterprises Index lost 0.7% to 11,601.69 points. The slump was attributed to the government's crackdown on debt risks and factory pollution. Top gainers included Air China, Anhui Conch Cement, and Zhuzhou CRRC Times Electric, while the three biggest decliners were PICC Property and Casualty, People's Insurance Group, and Postal Savings Bank of China.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Tuesday, rising 3.3 points to 3,422.46, driven by gains from Wall Street overnight. US stocks, including the Dow Jones and S&P 500, edged higher, with gains led by high-dividend-paying sectors. The Straits Times Index has now reached a 5-day rally, with investors maintaining a positive stance despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Oil markets cautious as rising US output undermines Opec supply cuts
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures down 22 cents to $62.94 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude down 14 cents to $56.62 per barrel. The decline came as traders became cautious on further price rises, citing rising US oil output and ongoing Opec-led production cuts. Opec raised its oil demand forecast, expecting 33.42 million barrels per day in 2018, while the International Energy Agency predicted oil prices would rise towards $83 a barrel by the mid-2020s.

site_title: Tesla's a hotbed for racist behaviour, worker claims in suit
summary: A Tesla employee filed a lawsuit alleging the company's Fremont factory is a "hotbed for racist behavior" with over 100 African-American workers affected. The employee claims he was terminated after complaining about racial harassment, which included the use of the "N word." The lawsuit seeks unspecified damages and policies to prevent and correct harassment. Tesla CEO Elon Musk has acknowledged that the company fired about 700 workers for low performance, but has not released diversity statistics. An attorney says Tesla is not doing enough to address the issue, citing a need for a diverse workforce to feel welcome.

site_title: Amazon plays catch-up in push to police chemicals in products
summary: Amazon is developing a plan to regulate chemicals in its products, but lags behind retailers like Wal-Mart and Target in reducing toxic chemicals. The company received a D grade from the Safer Chemicals, Healthy Families coalition, ranking 14th out of 30 retailers. Despite this, Amazon is shunning certain "chemicals of concern" in some private-brand products. Other retailers, such as Apple and Wal-Mart, have introduced and expanded programs to reduce chemicals in their products, with some receiving A- or B-plus grades from the coalition.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise off 7-week low as telecoms earnings impress
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Tuesday, rebounding from a seven-week low, driven by encouraging earnings from telecoms companies. The STOXX 600 index also benefited from gains in British retailer Tesco after the UK regulator approved its US$4.9 billion takeover of wholesaler Booker. Telecom and tech sector strength contributed to gains in German and French benchmarks, while euro zone blue-chips rose 0.3%.

site_title: Consortium shares blockchain models' source codes to spur innovation in inter-bank payments
summary: A consortium led by the Monetary Authority of Singapore has released the source codes of three blockchain models for inter-bank payments, dubbed Project Ubin. The models, developed on Corda, Hyperledger Fabric, and Quorum platforms, aim to increase speed and privacy in cross-border payments. The move encourages innovation in inter-bank payments, with the source codes available for central banks, financial institutions, and technology companies to experiment and research. The goal is to develop cheaper, safer, and more efficient cross-border payments, with potential future integration of DLT-based systems for improved connectivity.

site_title: En-bloc redevelopments to require traffic impact study before approval: URA
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has announced that en-bloc redevelopment proposals will require a traffic impact study before approval. This new rule aims to assess the maximum number of dwelling units that can be built without straining the existing road network and causing congestion. The study will evaluate traffic demand and propose car-lite initiatives, and applicants must engage a traffic consultant to assess the transport impact. The URA will only support the proposed number of dwelling units after LTA approval.

site_title: FS-ISAC and MAS launch regional office in Singapore to step up fight against cybercrime
summary: FS-ISAC and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have launched a regional office in Singapore to combat cybercrime. The FS-ISAC Asia Pacific regional analysis centre will provide 24/7 threat information sharing, actionable intelligence, and tools to support 49 financial institutions across nine Asia-Pacific countries. The centre aims to strengthen local intelligence capabilities and cyber resilience, helping countries deal with cross-border cybercrimes. The partnership will also grow talent in cybersecurity through internships with Temasek Polytechnic.

site_title: Asia: Most markets down as fears grow for US tax reform
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday, mirroring a tepid US market, amid fears of stalled US tax reform. Despite initial optimism, investors are growing concerned that the reform push could collapse, similar to the Obamacare repeal. Key markets fell, including Hong Kong (-0.1%), Shanghai (-0.4%), and Sydney (-0.9%), while Tokyo's Nikkei rose 0.3% after Monday's 1.3% drop. The US is set to release key inflation and retail sales figures, providing further market insight.

site_title: Noble keeps credit ratings but agencies warn of downgrades if liquidity worsens
summary: Noble Group reported a massive net loss of US$1.2 billion for the third quarter, with its cash and short-term deposits falling to US$256 million. Credit rating agencies Moody's and Fitch have maintained their Caa3 and CCC ratings, respectively, but warned of potential downgrades if the company's liquidity worsens. The agencies cited Noble's weak underlying profitability, large bank debt, and bonds due in the next 12 months. The company is selling its US oil liquids unit, North America Corp, to raise funds and has announced the resignation of co-CEO Jeffrey Frase.

site_title: FDA approves a digital pill that can track when you swallowed it
summary: The US FDA has approved a digital pill, Abilify MyCite, that tracks when patients swallow their medication, developed by Otsuka Pharmaceutical and Proteus Digital Health. The pill contains a sensor that sends a signal to a patch worn on the patient's torso, transmitting data to a smartphone app. The approval aims to improve medication adherence, particularly for patients with mental illness, and gather anonymized data for research. However, concerns about patient privacy remain, with some experts warning that the technology could create a "looking-over-your-shoulder effect."

site_title: Australia: Shares lower, weighed by energy; New Zealand marginally up
summary: Australian shares fell nearly 1% on Tuesday, weighed down by energy stocks following Royal Dutch Shell's divestment of its stake in Woodside Petroleum Ltd. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5953.5, with Woodside Petroleum falling 3.2% and other major energy stocks trading in the red. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index gained 0.02% despite the downturn.

site_title: Increased likelihood of La Nina to benefit palm oil production: Golden Agri
summary: Golden Agri-Resources expects a 60% chance of La Nina occurring, which could positively impact palm oil production due to higher rainfall in South-east Asia. The company expects 10-15% year-on-year growth in fresh fruit bunches production this year and up to 10% in 2018. However, extreme rainfall could lead to lower production if it results in flooding. The firm's net profit fell 80.1% to US$43.7 million in the third quarter due to foreign exchange losses and tax credits.

site_title: Australia shares end weaker for third session; NZ higher
summary: Australian shares ended down 0.9% for the third consecutive session, weighed by weak oil prices and a Woodside Petroleum stake sale. Oil prices fell as US output prospects undermined OPEC production cuts. Woodside Petroleum shares dropped 3.2%, while other oil and gas heavyweights, such as Origin Energy and Santos, also declined. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.4%, driven by gains in healthcare and telecom stocks, including an all-time high for Fisher & Paykel Healthcare Corp.

site_title: Singapore shares lower at Tuesday's break; STI down 0.5% at 3,400.81
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.5% at the noon break on Tuesday, closing at 3,400.81, as trading volume reached 1.49 billion shares worth S$714 million. The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 18.32 points. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: China's economy cools as government curbs hit factories, property and retailers
summary: China's economy cooled further in October, with industrial output, fixed asset investment, and retail sales missing expectations due to government crackdowns on debt and factory pollution. Industrial output rose 6.2% year-on-year, while fixed asset investment slowed to 7.3% and retail sales gained 10%. The slowdown is attributed to Beijing's efforts to curb financial risks and pollution, with property sales and new construction starts also falling. Despite this, China's economy is expected to still meet its 6.5% growth target for 2017, with policymakers walking a tight rope between growth and debt reduction.

images.alt_text: China's economy cooled further last month, with industrial output, fixed asset investment and retail sales missing expectations as the government extended a crackdown on debt risks and factory pollution.

site_title: China property investment growth cools in Oct, sales decline accelerates
summary: China's property investment growth cooled in October, with a 5.6% increase in real estate investment from the same period last year, the slowest since July. Property sales by floor area fell 6.0% in October, while new construction starts measured by floor area declined 4.3%. The decline in sales and new construction starts is the biggest since 2015, reinforcing expectations of a gradual slowdown in China's economy. Authorities have intensified efforts to curb illegal financing and contain risks from a rapid build-up in debt.

site_title: Brokers' take: Vard's illiquid shares may incentivise shareholders to accept parent company's exit offer
summary: Fincantieri Oil & Gas SpA has proposed a voluntary delisting via an exit offer for Vard Holdings at 25 Singapore cents in cash per share. The offer's fairness is questioned, but DBS Group Research notes that the pricing is similar to its target price and the shares' illiquidity might incentivize shareholders to accept the offer. A delisting will proceed if less than 10% of total shareholders vote against it, and Fincantieri can compulsorily acquire remaining shares if it reaches 90% ownership.

site_title: And the winner of Europe's earnings season is: the energy sector
summary: Europe's earnings season concludes with energy companies leading the way, posting strong results despite lower oil prices. Energy firms such as BP and Statoil beat profit estimates, driven by cost cuts and growing confidence in the industry's recovery. The energy sector has gained 2.8% since October, outperforming other sectors, including real-estate and automobiles. This positive performance has helped offset disappointing results from the banking industry. Energy companies' profitability shows they have managed to cut costs, allowing them to remain profitable in a lower oil price environment.

images.alt_text: Companies from BP to Statoil beat third-quarter profit estimates, driven by a combination of higher crude prices and deep cost cuts and signaling growing confidence that the oil-industry downturn is coming to an end.

site_title: Trump's efforts to promote coal at climate summit draw protests
summary: Protesters interrupted a panel discussion at the UN climate change talks in Bonn, criticizing the Trump administration's efforts to promote coal and its decision to exit the Paris Agreement. Over 100 activists walked out, singing an anti-coal song, as White House climate adviser George David Banks touted coal-fired power as a means of ensuring "universal access" to electricity. Some panelists, including a coal executive and a former Obama envoy, expressed support for the US remaining in the Paris Agreement, while others defended the administration's decision, citing the need for cleaner fossil fuels and technologies like carbon capture.

site_title: US federal court approves part of Trump's latest travel ban
summary: A US appeals court approved part of President Donald Trump's latest travel ban, allowing the ban on citizens of six Muslim-majority countries who don't have a "bona fide" relationship with a US person or entity. The ruling creates an exemption for foreigners with American ties, including those with relatives, jobs, business ties, or connections to educational institutions. The decision was made despite a federal judge's previous block of the ban and an upcoming hearing on December 6 to determine whether the stay should be kept or permanently overturned.

site_title: City-fringe resale condo, private apartment prices touch new high in October: SRX
summary: SRX Property reported that resale prices for non-landed private homes in the city fringe reached a new high in October 2017, with an index of 184.6, surpassing the August 2013 peak. The index for the suburbs and prime areas also increased, with 1.7% and 0.3% gains, respectively. The overall resale price index for private apartments and condo units rose 1.3% in October 2017, with a 6.3% year-on-year gain. Resale volume also increased, with 1,461 units resold in October 2017, up 122% from the previous year.

site_title: For first time, majority of latest batch of HDB BTO flats to be built using new pre-fab method
summary: The Housing Board (HDB) has announced that 80% of the latest batch of Build-to-Order (BTO) flats will be built using a new pre-fabricated pre-finished volumetric construction (PPVC) method, reducing the number of workers needed at construction sites and minimizing safety hazards. This is part of the government's push to raise productivity in the construction sector. 22% of BTO flats launched this year will use PPVC, with the goal of 35% by 2019.

site_title: US dollar underpinned by US yields, sterling steadies
summary: The US dollar strengthened against its rivals, including the Japanese yen, as higher US Treasury yields provided support. The US dollar index remained steady at 94.499, while the 10-year Treasury yield rose to 2.405%. Sterling steadied after facing pressure from British political turmoil, while the euro held steady at US$1.1670. The US Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates in December, potentially driving the dollar higher.

site_title: Hot stock: Cosco Shipping rises 7.3% to 2.5-year high of S$0.585
summary: Cosco Shipping International's shares surged 7.3% to a 2.5-year high of S$0.585, reaching a 54% gain over the past week and 95% over the past two weeks. The stock's rally followed Chinese shipbuilder Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's better-than-expected third-quarter earnings and Cosco's recent announcements, including a S$488 million cash buyout of Cogent Holdings and divestment of its shipyard business. The company also appointed Wang Kang Tian as its new CFO and chief risk officer.

site_title: Minerva sees Asia beef demand at 50% of world market in 3-4 years
summary: Minerva SA predicts Asia will account for up to 50% of the world's beef demand in 3-4 years, driven by rising demand in China. This growth is expected to boost shipments from South American producers like Brazil, which has seen a surge in protein supplies. Minerva has expanded its presence in South America, taking market share from competitors like JBS SA, the world's largest meat packer. The company's Chief Commercial Officer attributes the rise in demand to changing consumer tastes.

site_title: Australia dollar gets helping hand from domestic data, NZ$ slips
summary: The Australian dollar rose to US$0.7630, its highest level in four months, after a strong business survey showed improved conditions with sales and profits surging in October. The Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate outlook remains steady, despite disappointing Chinese data on retail sales and industrial production. New Zealand's commodity-linked currency slipped 0.4% to US$0.6875, influenced by Chinese demand signals. The Aussie's rebound was seen as a relief to the RBA, while the kiwi's decline was attributed to Beijing's tightening of debt and pollution controls.

site_title: US$81.3m Van Gogh kicks off NY art auction season
summary: Christie's kicked off the US fall art auction season with a strong show, selling a Vincent Van Gogh painting for $81.3 million, exceeding its pre-sale estimate of $50 million. The painting, "Laboureur dans un champ," was completed in 1889 while the artist was in a French asylum. The sale was followed by Fernand Leger's abstract "Contraste de formes" selling for $70 million, setting a new world auction record, and Rene Magritte's "L'empire des lumieres" selling for $20.56 million, also a world auction record. The total sales for the evening were $479 million.

site_title: Trump Jr bares messages with WikiLeaks during campaign
summary: Donald Trump Jr. released a series of Twitter direct messages with WikiLeaks, revealing about a dozen messages between September 2016 and July this year. WikiLeaks sought to feed information to the Trump campaign and enhance the impact of its Hillary Clinton releases. The messages included requests for tax returns, emails regarding a meeting with a Russian lawyer, and promotion of the group's publications. Trump Jr. replied to only three messages, thanking WikiLeaks for information and making a slighting comment about Clinton. WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange said the messages were part of promotional efforts.

site_title: SoftBank says considering investment in Uber but no final agreement reached
summary: SoftBank Group Corp is considering investing in Uber Technologies Inc, but no final agreement has been reached. The investment could be worth up to US$10 billion. SoftBank stated that it may not make the investment if conditions on share price and number of shares are not satisfactory. Uber had previously stated that a deal with SoftBank and Dragoneer Investment Group was moving forward.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, extending a four-day losing streak. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.20%, or 45.72 points, to 22,335.27, while the Topix index slipped 0.17%, or 3.11 points, to 1,780.38. Investors searched for fresh trading pegs after the corporate earnings season.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 6.61 points to 1,744.10. The index saw 116 gains and 55 losses, with total volume reaching 42.49 million lots worth RM23.24 million.

site_title: MAS plans cross-border tie-ups on blockchains, e-payments; to develop 80 Robinson as fintech hub
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to collaborate with Hong Kong and Canada to develop blockchain technology for trade finance and cross-border payments. The MAS will set up a cross-border platform with the Hong Kong Monetary Authority to boost trade finance and collaborate with the Bank of Canada to test the use of distributed ledger technology for cross-border payments. Additionally, the MAS will launch a S$27 million Artificial Intelligence & Data Analytics Grant to support the adoption of AI and data analytics in financial institutions, and establish a fintech innovation hub named 80RR in Singapore.

site_title: Noble to include Noble Petro in sale of US oil liquids unit; keeps Moody's Caa3 rating
summary: NOBLE Group has agreed to include its equity interest in Noble Petro in its proposed sale of US oil liquids unit Noble Americas Corp to Vitol US Holding Co. This adjustment increases the base consideration in the sale by US$15 million to US$217 million, resulting in approximately US$597 million in cash proceeds after deducting debt of US$836 million. Moody's Investors Service has maintained Noble's Caa3 corporate family rating, citing the company's weak financial results but acknowledging the significant probability of default within the next 12 months.

site_title: South Korea: Financial markets to open later on Thursday
summary: South Korea's financial markets will open an hour later at 0100 GMT on Thursday due to a nationwide college entrance exam. This is not related to the article content provided, which discusses various market news from other regions and companies.

site_title: M1, VMware unveil cloud offering for Singapore digital startups
summary: M1 Limited and VMware Inc have announced a new cloud offering in Singapore to empower digital startups. The cloud service allows small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to innovate software-based products without upfront infrastructure costs. Powered by VMware's Cloud Provider program, the offering includes container support and toolkits for faster deployment of containerized workloads across private and public clouds. The initiative aims to provide enterprise-grade tools to SMEs, supporting their growth ambitions in Singapore.

site_title: Australia business conditions jump to all-time high in Oct: survey
summary: Australia's business conditions reached an all-time high in October, according to a survey by National Australia Bank, with its index of business conditions jumping 7 points to +21, quadrupling its long-run average. This surge is attributed to strength in sales and profits across various industries, including retail, which saw modest improvement. The survey's business confidence measure held steady at +8, and the construction sector reported booming conditions due to public investment and housing. This positive trend is expected to have positive spill-overs into the labor market and investment.

site_title: Facebook tells FEC it supports campaign advertising transparency
summary: Facebook has filed comments with the Federal Election Commission (FEC) stating its support for campaign advertising transparency. The company had previously fought for blanket exemptions from the FEC's disclosure rule, but now seeks clarity on how to comply with transparency laws. Facebook argues that digital companies should be allowed to be creative in displaying paid sponsors of election ads. The FEC has reopened its comment period for rulemaking on disclosure for online ads, with a bipartisan group of senators introducing a plan to impose new disclosure requirements for political ads on Facebook, Twitter, and other online services.

site_title: Oil steady near two-year highs, US supply increase caps rise
summary: Oil prices held steady near two-year highs, with Brent crude futures at $63.16 a barrel and US WTI crude futures at $56.76 a barrel. Middle East tensions, including Saudi Arabia's leadership purge and ongoing conflicts in Yemen, supported prices despite concerns about rising US production. OPEC forecast higher demand for its oil in 2018 and said its production cuts were reducing excess supply. Hedge funds increased bullish wagers on US crude futures, with net long positions equivalent to nearly 544 million barrels of oil.

site_title: Google faces Missouri probe as antitrust concerns grow
summary: Missouri's Attorney General Josh Hawley has launched an investigation into Google over allegations that the company manipulated search results to benefit its own products, scraped information from competitors without permission, and misappropriated data from users. Hawley issued a subpoena requiring Google to cooperate with the probe, which comes amid growing antitrust concerns in the US. The investigation follows similar probes in Europe, where Google was fined $3.8 billion for giving its own shopping products more prominent placement in search results. Hawley's probe is part of a broader push to hold tech giants accountable for their business practices.

images.alt_text: The simmering debate over whether big internet companies are breaking antitrust rules to extend their dominance has a new front - Missouri.

site_title: SunMoon Food posts narrower loss of S$417,000 for Q2
summary: SunMoon Food Company reported a narrower net loss of S$417,000 for Q2, improving from S$1.6 million a year ago. Revenue rose 24.2% to S$9.9 million, driven by sales to Shanghai YiGuo E-Commence Co, which accounted for 58% of total revenue. The company's loss per share decreased to 0.1541 Singapore cent, and no dividend was declared. For the half-year period, SunMoon posted a net loss of S$914,000 on the back of a 31% improvement in revenue to S$16.1 million.

site_title: Largest US pension fund Calpers considers more than doubling bond allocation to 44%
summary: The California Public Employees' Retirement System (Calpers) is considering doubling its bond allocation to 44% to reduce risk and volatility, as the stock bull market approaches nine years. This move would cut equities to 34% from 50%. The change aims to lower the fund's discount rate from 7% to 6.5%. However, this shift could require larger contributions from taxpayers and public agencies, a move opposed by some board members.

images.alt_text: Calpers is looking at a menu of options for its fixed-income target ranging from the current 19 per cent to as much as 44 per cent, according to a presentation for a board workshop.

site_title: Global oil demand to withstand rise of electric vehicles: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts that global oil demand will only fall modestly alongside the rise of electric vehicles over the next two decades, with consumption in petrochemicals and transportation still growing. The agency estimates that 50 million electric vehicles will be on the road by 2025 and 300 million by 2040, cutting only 2% off global oil demand. Oil prices are expected to rise towards $83 a barrel by the mid-2020s, with the market finding a longer-term equilibrium in a range of $50-70 a barrel.

site_title: Gold recovers lost ground as US dollar steadies, stocks retreat
summary: Gold prices recovered 0.2% on Monday as the US dollar steadied, despite uncertainty over a US tax reform plan and concerns about rising US interest rates. Spot gold rose to $1,279 an ounce, while US gold futures settled up 0.4% at $1,278.90 per ounce. The metal has remained within a narrow range, awaiting more clues on the path of US interest rates and a potential rate hike by the Federal Reserve in December.

site_title: Coming soon to Washington: A new anti-Trump hotel for Liberals
summary: A new hotel, Eaton Workshop, is set to open in Washington in late spring 2018, catering to liberal guests with a custom-commissioned video art installation and a liberal philosophy woven into every aspect of the guest experience. The hotel's founder, Katherine Lo, aims to create a haven for Democrats, with a focus on social activism and community engagement. Eaton Workshop will feature a TED talk series, local art commissions, a co-working space, and wellness programs, with partners and staff who share the hotel's progressive values.

site_title: New York state regulator fines Credit Suisse US$135m over forex practices
summary: Credit Suisse has agreed to pay a US$135 million fine to settle allegations of deceptive forex practices, improper information sharing, and manipulation of currency prices from 2008 to 2015. The New York State Department of Financial Services found "unlawful, unsafe and unsound conduct" in the Swiss bank's forex business. As part of the settlement, Credit Suisse must improve controls and compliance and hire a consultant to review remedial efforts for at least a year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Tuesday, extending the previous day's gains ahead of Chinese economic data. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.42% to 29,303.52, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index were marginally down. The gains come ahead of China's economic data release, which could impact global markets.

site_title: Golden Agri Q3 profit drops 80.1% to US$43.7m on FX losses, lack of tax credit
summary: Golden Agri-Resources' third-quarter net profit fell 80.1% to US$43.7 million due to foreign exchange losses and the absence of tax credits. Revenue grew 10.1% to US$5.6 billion, driven by higher average crude palm oil prices and improved production. The company incurred a foreign exchange loss of US$3.7 million, down from a US$50.5 million gain in the previous year. Golden Agri also announced an interim dividend of 0.693 Singapore cents per share, payable on November 29.

site_title: Sterling falls on worries over PM May's staying power
summary: Sterling falls against the dollar and euro as investors worry about Theresa May's ability to stay as British prime minister and secure a good EU exit deal. The pound hit a one-week low of US$1.3063, down 0.7% on the day, amid concerns about domestic political uncertainty and a potential "hard" Brexit. The Bank of England's rate hike earlier this month has also eroded support for the currency. A letter from pro-Brexit cabinet members has further fueled concerns about May's leadership, with 40 lawmakers from her party agreeing to sign a letter of no-confidence in her.

site_title: Record-holding cats missing, feared dead after fire
summary: A fire destroyed the home of Will and Lauren Powers in a Detroit suburb, feared to have killed the world's tallest cat, Cygnus, and his companion cat, Arcturus, both Guinness World Records holders. The pair, a 44.5cm-tall Maine Coon and a 53.6cm-long Savannah cat, went missing on Sunday morning. Their owners, who run a cat shelter, are holding out hope they escaped but fear the worst, as a fundraising page has raised over $2,500.

site_title: Europe: Poor earnings updates keep shares at 7-week low
summary: European shares fell 0.7% to their lowest level since September, driven by heavy losses in utility company EDF after a profit warning, and disappointing updates from other companies including Sonova and Swiss hearing aid maker. EDF dropped 10% after lowering its 2018 earnings forecasts due to lower power consumption and nuclear reactor availability. Despite this, some sectors, such as mining and healthcare, supported shares, while US-EU trade talks were in focus.

site_title: ISEC Healthcare Q3 profit up 30% on increased patient visits, clinics contributions
summary: ISEC Healthcare Limited reported a 29.7% increase in net profit to S$2.2 million for its third quarter, driven by increased patient visits and revenue contributions from its JL Medical clinics. Revenue climbed 31.3% to S$9.7 million, while cost of sales rose 36% to S$5.1 million. Earnings per share rose to 0.42 Singapore cent, and the company's net asset value per share remained flat at S$0.12. The company's shares closed unchanged at S$0.315.

site_title: Sarine falls to net loss of US$530,000 in Q3 on surplus of diamonds in market
summary: Sarine Technologies, an Israeli diamond specialist technology firm, reported a net loss of US$530,000 in Q3 due to a 35% decrease in revenue to US$11.3 million. The decline was attributed to a buildup of higher-than-normal inventories of polished diamonds and ongoing illicit operations affecting sales. Loss per share decreased to 0.15 US cents, down from 1.14 US cents a year ago. No dividend has been recommended for the current financial period.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MoneyMax, Noble, Delfi, ISEC Healthcare, Golden Agri-Resources
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Stocks to watch on Tuesday include MoneyMax, Noble, Delfi, ISEC Healthcare, and Golden Agri-Resources. MoneyMax plans to acquire 13 pawn broking entities in Malaysia for RM56.6 million. Noble Group has amended its sale of its Americas-focused oil liquids business to Vitol US Holding for US$217 million. Delfi posted a 44.1% drop in net profit to US$3.3 million, while ISEC Healthcare saw a 30% increase in net profit to S$2.2 million. Golden Agri-Resources reported an 80.1% drop in net profit to US$43.7 million due to foreign exchange losses and tax credits.

site_title: US House GOP has votes to pass tax cut bill, Brady says
summary: The US House GOP has the votes to pass its tax cut bill, with House Ways and Means Chairman Kevin Brady stating that minor revisions are possible. The bill would preserve property tax deductions up to $10,000, but would repeal state and local tax deductions. President Donald Trump is set to speak to House Republicans on Thursday, urging support for the bill. The Senate plan, which would fully repeal state and local tax deductions, is estimated to increase the federal deficit by $1.5 trillion over a decade. Despite some lawmakers expressing concerns, the House is expected to vote on the bill as early as Thursday.

site_title: Blockbuster land deals signal Singapore property set to sizzle in 2018
summary: A series of blockbuster land deals in Singapore signals the city-state's property market is set to break out of its slump in 2018. Record bids were made for a residential plot and an office development site, with office rents rising for the first time in 2.5 years. More than S$3.3 billion of land deals are expected to be completed by the end of the year, pushing the annual total to S$14 billion, the highest since 2011. Analysts predict home prices could rise 10% next year and office rents 7-9% due to improved market sentiment and economic growth.

site_title: Bumitama Q3 profit up 29% on improved palm production, palm oil prices
summary: Bumitama Agri Limited's third-quarter profit rose 29% to 266.25 billion rupiah, driven by improved palm production and higher crude palm oil prices. Revenue increased 37.2% to 2.05 trillion rupiah, while costs of sales rose 34.7%. Earnings per share and net asset value per share also increased. The company's shares closed 2.5% higher at S$0.825, following the positive quarterly results.

site_title: Saudi coalition refuses to re-open key Yemen port
summary: The Saudi-led coalition in Yemen will ease the blockade on key ports in 24 hours, but will not reopen the rebel-held port of Hodeida unless tighter inspections are put in place. Ports in government-controlled areas will be reopened, but the coalition demands stricter controls on Hodeida to prevent the supply of weapons. The UN warns that lifting the blockade is crucial to prevent a massive famine, with 7 million people at risk of starvation. The UN has listed Yemen as the world's number one humanitarian crisis, with 17 million people in need of food.

site_title: Football: Italy miss out on World Cup; Buffon ends international career
summary: Italy failed to qualify for the World Cup for the first time since 1958, losing to Sweden 1-0 on aggregate after a 0-0 draw at the San Siro. Despite dominating possession, Italy struggled to create clear-cut chances, while Sweden secured their first World Cup appearance since 2006 with Jakob Johansson's first-leg strike. The draw marked the end of Gianluigi Buffon's international career, as the four-time champion failed to reach the World Cup for the first time in 59 years.

site_title: CIMB reports loss of tapes with customer data; steps up security
summary: CIMB Group reported a loss of magnetic tapes containing customer data, including information from its Singapore branch. Despite no evidence of compromised information, the bank is stepping up security measures and advising customers to be vigilant. CIMB has temporarily suspended some services and is reviewing its security and internal processes to prevent a similar incident. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is monitoring the situation and advising customers to exercise vigilance and closely monitor alerts.

site_title: United resumes Newark-Delhi flights after halt due to poor air quality
summary: United Airlines has resumed flights from Newark, New Jersey to New Delhi, India after suspending them due to poor air quality. The airline had cancelled UA Flight 82 on Friday and Saturday, but it has resumed operations. United will continue to monitor air quality conditions and may adjust its policies. The decision comes as New Delhi remains under a public health emergency due to toxic smog, with a US embassy measure of PM 2.5 showing a reading of 481 on Monday morning.

site_title: High blood pressure is redefined as 130, not 140: US guidelines
summary: The American Heart Association redefined high blood pressure as readings of 130/80 or higher, lowering the previous limit of 140/90. This update, the first in 14 years, aims to treat the condition sooner to prevent complications. The revised guidelines recognize that high blood pressure can cause issues at lower numbers, prompting earlier intervention.

site_title: Amazon to launch 'Lord of the Rings' TV show
summary: Amazon has acquired the global television rights to "The Lord of the Rings" series, based on JRR Tolkien's novels, with a multi-season commitment. The adaptation will explore new storylines preceding "The Fellowship of the Ring" and may include a potential spin-off series. The production budget is estimated to be $100-$150 million per season, with the series set to be available on Prime Video in over 200 countries and territories. Amazon Chairman Jeff Bezos aims to create a prestigious fantasy series to rival "Game of Thrones."

images.alt_text: Amazon said on Monday it had acquired the global television rights to The Lord of the Rings, based on the celebrated fantasy novels by JRR Tolkien, with a multi-season commitment.

site_title: US: Wall Street treads water on continued tax jitters
summary: US stocks narrowly closed above the flat line on Monday, rebounding from two consecutive trading sessions in the red, as investors continued to worry about delayed corporate tax cuts. Despite President Trump's tweets calling for a cut in the top individual tax rate, investors remain skeptical about tax reform, with Maris Ogg of Tower Bridge Advisors stating "I don't think we're going to get tax reform." The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose less than a tenth of a point, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq gained 0.1% to close at 2,584.84 and 6,757.60, respectively.

site_title: Uber's South Asia policy chief quits in latest senior departure: sources
summary: Uber's chief policy officer for India and South Asia, Shweta Rajpal Kohli, has quit the company, according to sources. Kohli, a former Indian journalist, is set to join Salesforce.com Inc next month. Uber declined to comment on the matter. This is the latest high-level departure at the online taxi company, following other senior exits.

site_title: SembMarine settles contractual spat with Marco Polo
summary: SembCorp Marine has settled its contractual dispute with Marco Polo Marine without admitting fault or liability. The settlement agreement allows Marco Polo to move forward with its restructuring program. The dispute began in 2015 over a US$214.3 million contract for a jack-up rig, with Marco Polo alleging SembMarine failed to comply with contractual obligations. The settlement has no material impact on SembMarine's net tangible assets or earnings per share.

site_title: Dealmaking in Singapore expected to rise by 26% in 2017, peaking in 2019
summary: Dealmaking in Singapore is expected to rise by 26% in 2017, peaking in 2019, with a total value of US$23.1 billion in 2017 and US$27.4 billion in 2019, according to a report by Baker McKenzie. This growth is attributed to mega deals, with the three largest deals in 2017 collectively worth US$6.2 billion. The report also predicts a strong pickup in IPO activity, with a 30% increase in 2018 and US$2.7 billion in cross-border transactions.

site_title: Weed-killer prompts angry divide among US farmers
summary: US farmers are divided over the use of dicamba, a weed-killer that has been used to combat Palmer amaranth, a resistant weed. The herbicide's ease of vaporization and wind dispersal has led to complaints and an urgent ban on its sale in Arkansas. The state plans to ban its use between April and October, with some farmers, like Perry Galloway, favoring a compromise, while others, like Shawn Peebles, prefer alternative methods. The issue has personal and financial implications, with some farmers losing profits and one family experiencing a fatal altercation related to the herbicide.

site_title: Qualcomm shuns Broadcom bid, setting up US$105b proxy fight
summary: Qualcomm Inc rejected Broadcom Ltd's $105 billion acquisition offer, calling it an opportunistic move undervaluing the company. The deal, which would make Broadcom the third largest semiconductor maker, faces regulatory scrutiny and Qualcomm's own push to close a $40 billion NXP Semiconductors purchase. Qualcomm's board believes the offer significantly undervalues the company and recommends shareholders reject the deal, setting up a potential proxy fight between the two companies.

site_title: Alibaba's rise creates 10 billionaires, Jack Ma not included
summary: Alibaba founder Jack Ma has created a network of people with combined fortunes totaling over $52 billion, excluding his own $47.6 billion fortune. This network includes at least 10 billionaires from various industries supporting Alibaba's e-commerce platforms, such as payment systems, delivery companies, and complementary retailers. The collective wealth is equivalent to the economies of 136 countries, with some of the billionaires emerging from fintech and parcel delivery companies. Ma's vision for a long-term, open system connecting different parties in the supply chain has driven the creation of this vast network.

site_title: Asean must stay credible, united on issues of concern: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged Asean to remain united and credible on regional and international issues, including North Korea and the South China Sea. He emphasized the need to continue calling on North Korea to abide by its international obligations and commitments. This comes as the bloc faces various challenges, including the ongoing Myanmar election, the UK economy's shrinkage, and the US trade talks.

site_title: How Singapore factories can get smart and stay ahead
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector has experienced 13 consecutive months of growth, driven by high-value manufacturing clusters such as electronics and precision engineering. To stay ahead, manufacturers must adopt Industry 4.0 technologies like RFID, Real-time Locationing Systems, and wearable technologies. The 2017 Asia-Pacific Manufacturing Vision Study estimates that 46% of manufacturers in the region will support fully connected factories by 2022, significantly ahead of the worldwide average. Manufacturers must prioritize technologies like RTLS, RFID, and mobile solutions to improve productivity, quality, and visibility, and remain competitive in the region.

site_title: Court dismisses Perennial's appeal in Capitol case
summary: The Court of Appeal in Singapore dismissed Perennial Real Estate Holdings' appeal against the High Court's decision to deny its application to wind up three joint entities related to the Capitol integrated development project. The entities jointly own the hotel, shops, residential units, and theatre. The decision upholds the High Court's earlier ruling, allowing the joint entities to continue operating without winding up. The outcome ensures the Capitol project's continuation, with Perennial and Pontiac Land affiliate Chesham Properties maintaining control over the development.

site_title: Vietnam and China agree to back off on conflicts in South China Sea
summary: Vietnam and China agreed to ease tensions in the South China Sea, a vital shipping route, during a state visit to Hanoi by Chinese President Xi Jinping. The communist neighbors will manage disputes and maintain peace, avoiding actions that could complicate or expand conflicts. This comes after tensions flared in 2014 over an oil rig dispute and earlier this year when Vietnam suspended an oil exploration project in an area claimed by China. US President Donald Trump offered to mediate the dispute, but China appeared to dismiss his offer.

site_title: Delfi's profit falls 44% for Q3
summary: Delfi, a mainboard-listed chocolate confectionery company, reported a 44.1% drop in net profit for the third quarter to US$3.3 million, down from US$5.9 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 1.5% to US$87.9 million, driven by growth in Own Brands sales in Indonesia, its primary market. For the nine-month period, net profit fell 19% to US$18.2 million, also due to revenue decline.

site_title: Metro Holdings in the red in Q2 on one-off expense
summary: Metro Holdings, a Singaporean property and retail group, reported a net loss of S$13.59 million in the second quarter due to a one-off expense of S$17 million from the expiry of conditional remission of additional buyer's stamp duty for a joint venture project. This loss was partially offset by a reversal of a S$9.5 million write down due from another joint venture. The group's share of results from joint ventures was a significant contributor to the loss.

site_title: Banks should thank economy for their quarterly showing
summary: Three local banks posted reasonable results for their core businesses in the third quarter, driven by rising economic activity and consumer sentiment. The economy's recovery is gathering pace, with growth rates accelerating due to sustained global electronics demand and a trade upswing in Asia. This has led to increased manufacturing activity, rising incomes, and stronger domestic spending.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a summary of the article in 100 words or less:

Several Singaporean companies have released earnings updates. ComfortDelGro's Q3 net profit was above estimates at S$80.1 million, but CIMB Research maintains a Hold call pending final Uber tie-up details. Courts Asia downgraded to Hold due to weak Q2 earnings, while ISOTeam was upgraded to Buy with a target price of S$0.46. UOL Group's net attributable profits rose 8% year-on-year, and OCBC Research upgraded its valuation model to a fair value of S$9.70. The analysts also provided target prices for the companies, ranging from S$0.36 to S$9.70.

site_title: With big data, 'nowcasts' may replace economic forecasts
summary: Singapore's economy is on the cusp of a big data revolution, with technology offering instant, constantly updated insights into a nation's economic health. Traditional economic forecasting methods, which rely on government statistics with a lag of one to two months, are being replaced by "nowcasting" using real-time data. Companies like Orbital Insight and SpaceKnow are using satellite imagery to track factory output, traffic volumes, and other metrics, providing policymakers and forecasters with more accurate and timely information. While some economists see this shift as promising, others note that traditional data sources will still be used to supplement real-time data.

site_title: Greek PM announces welfare handouts of 1.4b euros
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras announced a 1.4 billion euro welfare handout package, targeting households earning less than 18,000 euros annually and pensioners. The package includes 720 million euros for one-off payments, 315 million euros for compensating health insurance costs, and 360 million euros for cheaper tariffs for poor electricity consumers. The move reflects the government's priorities, following a similar measure worth 617 million euros announced last year.

site_title: Building quality with innovation
summary: Seiko Architectural Wall Systems, a local building façade specialist, is expanding overseas while maintaining quality control despite a saturated local market. Under the leadership of Rodney Cheong, who joined the family business in 1994, Seiko has adapted to changes in the business environment, shifting its business model to stay competitive. Cheong succeeded Yan Chi Kong as managing director in 2001 and has led the company's growth into a successful international business.

site_title: Razer sees gain of as much as 41% on IPO debut
summary: Razer's shares surged 41% on their first trading day in Hong Kong, reaching HK$5.49, after a successful initial public offering (IPO) that raised HK$3.9 billion. Investor confidence in Asian tech IPOs and Razer's diversification into smartphones and e-payments contributed to the boost. The company's market capitalization rose to HK$41.8 billion, with heavyweight investors such as GIC and Li Ka-Shing backing the IPO. Analysts attribute Razer's strong performance to favorable sentiment towards IPOs and the company's growth potential in the gaming market.

site_title: Thor sequel remains box office smash hit
