summary: Thor: Ragnarok continues to dominate the box office, earning US$56.6 million in its second weekend, bringing its total to US$211.5 million in North American cinemas and US$650 million globally. The film's success can be attributed to its self-mocking humor, with Chris Hemsworth's portrayal of Thor and Cate Blanchett's performance as Hela. The movie's box office performance solidifies its position as a smashing hit.

site_title: Noble loses support from DBS, co-CEO resigns
summary: DBS Group has cut its support to NOBLE Group, a commodity trader, by selling a US$60 million stake in a US$1.1 billion revolving credit facility. The move follows Noble's announcement of a US$1.17 billion third-quarter loss and its struggles with liquidity constraints. Co-CEO Jeffrey Frase has resigned to pursue other opportunities, and the company will now be headed by co-CEO William Randall. Market observers say the loss of DBS' support signals a loss of confidence in Noble's prospects, and the company's survival prospects appear bleak.

site_title: Thai Airways swings to Q3 operating profit, but sees rising competition
summary: Thai Airways swung to a quarterly operating profit of 739 million baht, reversing a 836 million baht loss from the same period last year. Revenue rose 6.3% to 46.9 billion baht, but average fares declined 7.5%. The airline faces increasing competition from low-cost rivals Thai Vietjet, NokScoot, and Thai AirAsia X, who plan to add flights to Asia destinations. Thai Airways expects a challenging operating environment due to intense price competition, capacity additions, and shortages of trained staff.

site_title: Index payouts from CPF to inflation
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) system received an overall B rating from the Melbourne Mercer Global Pension Index, ranking as the best performer in Asia. To attain an A grade, Singapore can improve the system by indexing CPF payouts to inflation, preventing the erosion of purchasing power. This approach automatically adjusts payouts to match inflation rates, ensuring retirees can enjoy their retirement without initial decreases. The recent addition of the CPF Life plan offers flexibility, but indexing to inflation is a more desirable option.

site_title: UEL posts lower Q3 net profit on discontinued operations
summary: United Engineers Ltd (UEL) reported a 92% drop in Q3 net profit to S$10.6 million, mainly due to discontinued operations from its US subsidiary and environmental engineering businesses. Excluding these, net profit increased 9% to S$11.7 million. Revenue rose 41% to S$143 million, driven by project completion in Malaysia and property sales in Singapore. The company's 9-month net profit was 56% lower than the year-ago period.

site_title: Temasek-backed Heliconia acquires 2% stake in HMI through S$11m placement
summary: Temasek-backed Heliconia Capital Management acquired a 2% stake in Health Management International (HMI) through an S$11 million placement. HMI will issue 16.9 million new shares at S$0.65 per share, with plans to use the funds for business expansion and growth. The deal reflects Heliconia's interest in HMI's regional healthcare business and its growing middle-class and ageing population. This move follows HMI's strong Q1 financial performance, with net profit more than doubling to RM13.79 million and revenue increasing 6.9% year-on-year.

site_title: Fincantieri ups Vard bid by one cent
summary: Fincantieri, an Italian shipbuilding group, has increased its bid to privatize its Singapore-listed subsidiary, Vard Holdings, by one cent to 25 Singapore cents per share. This offer values the remaining shares at over S$60.94 million. The move comes despite favorable third-quarter results for Vard, which has 28 vessels scheduled for delivery in 2018. Fincantieri aims to delist Vard to implement synergies in engineering and production, and the exit offer is comparable to the net tangible asset value of Vard's shares.

site_title: ST Engg's barge order another sign LNG bunker newbuilds are picking up
summary: ST Engineering's US shipyard has won a contract to build a liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering barge, as the maritime industry prepares for the implementation of a global sulphur cap in 2020. The barge, expected to be delivered in Q1 2020, will carry 4,000 cubic meters of LNG. This is another sign of the industry's shift towards LNG bunkering, with Shell already chartering an LNG bunker barge from Q-LNG to operate on the US east coast. The delivery coincides with the global sulphur cap, which limits sulphur content in ship fuels to 0.5%.

site_title: The unhurried lunch returns for brokers
summary: Singapore's stock exchange, SGX, has reinstated the mid-day break from 12pm to 1pm after six years, bringing back lunchtime trading for brokers. The move was seen as a strategic move to align with Hong Kong's trading hours and to give brokers time to build rapport with clients. The resumption of the break is aimed at encouraging a vibrant securities market ecosystem, but some traders have expressed skepticism about its impact on trading volumes.

site_title: TPP 2.0 will create pressures for more countries to join
summary: The Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) has been revived, with 11 countries agreeing on a revised version of the original agreement. The new agreement suspends 20 provisions, mainly related to intellectual property protection and labor rights, but maintains the high standards set by the original agreement. The CPTPP is expected to come into force in 2019 and will create pressures for other countries to join, particularly those with significant trade relationships with CPTPP members. The agreement's accession mechanism will allow new members to join, but companies from the US may face competitive disadvantages in CPTPP member countries.

site_title: PayNow to rope in businesses; S'pore plans for payment links abroad
summary: Singapore aims to boost its cashless efforts with the rollout of initiatives to enable cross-border payment linkages with neighboring countries, including India. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will work with NETS and the National Payment Corporation of India (NPCI) to allow Singaporean NETS cardholders to make online purchases in India. Additionally, the PayNow system will be extended to businesses around the middle of next year, allowing them to pay each other and receive payments through their Unique Entity Numbers. The MAS also plans to expedite the application assessment for its fintech regulatory sandbox and set nationwide common QR specifications for e-payments.

site_title: Jardine C&C purchases 5.53% stake in Vinamilk
summary: Jardine C&C, a Singaporean conglomerate, acquired a 5.53% stake in Vietnam's leading dairy producer, Vinamilk, in a US$616.6 million deal. The investment comes around a year and a half after the government lifted foreign ownership limits on Vinamilk. This move aligns with Jardine C&C's strategy of investing in market-leading South-east Asian firms. The acquisition adds to Jardine C&C's exposure to the Vietnamese economy, with potential for further investments.

site_title: Wilmar Q3 earnings down 5.7%
summary: Wilmar International reported a 5.7% decline in Q3 net profit to US$370 million, mainly due to weaker results in tropical oils and sugar businesses. However, the oilseeds and grains segment showed a 2.2% growth in pretax profit, driven by higher crush volume and good crush margins. The company expects the good performance in this segment to continue into the fourth quarter. Despite this, net asset value per share rose to 243.3 US cents, and chairman Kuok Khoon Hong remains optimistic about the future of Asia and Wilmar's expansion plans.

site_title: Dubai wants production guarantee before it orders more A380s
summary: Dubai's Emirates, the largest Middle East carrier, wants Airbus to guarantee A380 production for at least 10 years before placing a new order. Emirates' president, Tim Clark, stated that the airline will likely stick with Boeing 787 jets for its mid-sized fleet needs. Despite unveiling a surprise order for 40 Boeing 787-10 jets, Emirates' concerns about the A380's future remain, with the airline seeking assurances from Airbus about the production line's continuation.

site_title: HKEX starts trading iron ore futures
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd (HKEX) has started trading iron ore futures, challenging Singapore Exchange Ltd's leading position in the market. The new dollar-denominated contract was launched on Monday, offering waived trading fees for six months. This move is seen as part of the "iron ore wars" between the two Asian financial heavyweights, which has been marked by extraordinary volatility and a popular way to bet on China.

site_title: Peugeot launches joint venture to build cars in Algeria
summary: Peugeot has launched a joint venture with Algerian partners to build cars in the North African country. The French carmaker will invest 100 million euros (S$158 million) and hold 49% of the joint venture's capital. The plant will be set up in Oran, Algeria, and is expected to start production next year, with full operation by 2019. The move aims to boost investment in the region, following France's loss of ground to countries such as China, Turkey, and Italy, and is seen as part of France's efforts to strengthen economic ties with its former colony.

site_title: Bank layoffs: players split over how bad it will be
summary: Bank executives predict a significant reduction in banking jobs over the next decade, with some suggesting up to 90% of current roles may become outdated in the digital age. However, not all executives share this view, with SEB AB's CEO Johan Torgeby stating that new roles and retraining may replace redundant positions, potentially leading to an increase in staff. Following Nordea's job cuts, Sweden's biggest banks have reduced their branch network by 30%. The industry's shift towards digitalization is expected to impact employee numbers, with some predicting a need for a significant productivity increase to sustain growth.

site_title: Oil drilling in Arctic: Norway dragged to court
summary: Norway is facing a court challenge over its decision to award 10 Barents Sea exploration licenses, which Greenpeace and a Norwegian group claim breaches the country's constitution. The plaintiffs argue that drilling in the Arctic poses a threat to the environment and contradicts Norway's commitment to fight climate change under the 2015 Paris Agreement. The case, the first of its kind in Norway, aims to force the government to reconsider its fossil fuel policies and promote green initiatives.

site_title: Bitcoin tumble erases US$38b in value as rival cryptocurrency gains
summary: Bitcoin's value plummeted by $38 billion, erasing 9.5% of its value, after a technology upgrade was cancelled, prompting some users to switch to rival cryptocurrency Bitcoin Cash. Bitcoin Cash surged 40% since Friday, benefiting from its larger block size, which makes transactions cheaper and faster. Despite the volatility, Bitcoin still boasts a market value of $101 billion, and experts advise investors to "hold on to both coins" until the situation stabilizes.

site_title: CapitaLand opens its largest mall in Suzhou
summary: CapitaLand has opened its largest mall in Suzhou, China, Suzhou Center Mall, spanning over 300,000 sq m, featuring over 600 retail brands. The mall is part of an integrated development with four office towers, two residential towers, and a hotel, and is the centrepiece of the Suzhou Industrial Park. The mall's opening caps a record year for CapitaLand, with over 1 million sq m of retail space offering. The mall boasts a unique architectural design, green spaces, and a wide range of anchor tenants, including CGV cinemas and an Olympic-size ice rink.

site_title: BT-supported kids' arts centre opens
summary: The Little Arts Academy (LAA), supported by The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, has opened its first two campuses in Northpoint City, Singapore, expanding its free arts training for kids from socially disadvantaged homes. LAA can now train up to 800 students yearly, up from 500 previously. The academy aims to inspire and connect communities through arts, aligning with the National Arts Council's vision for Singapore to be a hub for diverse and distinctive arts.

site_title: Iceland's home prices up 56% since 2009 crash
summary: Iceland's housing market has seen a 56% surge since its 2009 crash, driven by a lack of supply and continued demand. Experts expect further price increases, with investors adding to their exposure. Lower interest rates and a growing demand for housing are expected to support the market. The central bank's recent rate cut and exit from capital controls have contributed to the island's economic recovery, with tourism and construction driving growth. A housing shortage is expected to persist for several years, supporting higher prices.

site_title: STI ends flat, dragged by heavyweights
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) ended flat at 3,419.13, despite a strong earnings season, due to heavyweights like DBS, Singtel, and Hongkong Land. DBS alone lost 26 cents, indicating a correction. The market struggled to climb new highs, with shares of these heavyweights dragging down the overall index.

site_title: Uber board strikes agreement to pave way for SoftBank investment
summary: Uber's board of directors has agreed to a deal with SoftBank Group Corp, paving the way for a potential $10 billion investment by the Japanese conglomerate. The agreement resolves a legal battle between former CEO Travis Kalanick and prominent shareholder Benchmark, allowing SoftBank to proceed with an offer to buy Uber stock. The deal also includes a secondary transaction where SoftBank and Dragoneer Investment Group will buy up to 17% of existing shares from investors and employees. The investment is expected to be at Uber's current valuation of $68 billion.

site_title: Modi's cash crackdown, new laws hurt India's real estate sector
summary: India's real estate sector is struggling due to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's crackdown on cash, which removed 86% of cash from transactions and led to a 60% decline in project launches across top seven cities. The sector was already experiencing a slowdown, and the government's new laws, including a nationwide sales tax, have further constrained the industry. While the new consumer law has protected home buyers, the high number of unsold units indicates a recovery is still far away, with inventory in key cities like Delhi and Mumbai taking years to be absorbed.

site_title: Euro slides, consolidating below last week's high
summary: The euro slid lower on Monday, consolidating below a one-week high, as investors awaited a central bank conference on Tuesday. The conference, featuring ECB chief Mario Draghi and other prominent central bankers, may influence market sentiment. FX strategist Christin Tuxen expects a cautious stance from policymakers, potentially indicating a shift in market complacency.

site_title: How to tool up for the future: EDB offers help, free workshops
summary: The Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) has launched the Singapore Smart Industry Readiness Index, a diagnostic tool to help manufacturers build smart factories and take advantage of Industry 4.0. The index provides an assessment matrix across 16 dimensions and a step-by-step improvement guide. It aims to enhance the competitiveness of Singapore's manufacturing sector and has been piloted with SMEs and multinational corporations. The index helps companies prioritize their Industry 4.0 efforts, making it more accessible and realistic for smaller companies to adopt. Free workshops will be conducted to help companies understand and use the index.

site_title: Europe's recovery is spilling over to rest of world
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded its forecast for Europe's growth to 2.4% this year, citing the region's robust recovery from years of monetary stimulus. The IMF notes that the recovery is driven by low unemployment, bolstered private consumption, and a strengthening momentum in trade. However, the sustainability of the rebound remains uncertain due to adverse demographic trends and subdued productivity. The European Central Bank is expected to maintain accommodative monetary policy to support the economy, with some economists predicting a "golden period" of low-inflationary expansion.

images.alt_text: The eurozone's turnaround is striking for a region that plunged from the global financial crisis into its own sovereign debt turmoil, record unemployment and near-deflation that threatened the very survival of the currency union.

site_title: An elixir for the future
summary: Elixir Technology, a Singapore-based startup, has been recognized as an Enterprise 50 (E50) Award winner and aims to provide world-class solutions in the "Smart Nation" field, focusing on urban mobility, healthcare, and regulatory technology. Founded by Lau Shih Hor, the company has ambitious plans to become a major player in the industry.

site_title: Rebound in Russia economy forecast to slow down
summary: Russia's economy is forecast to slow down after experiencing a rebound following its worst recession this century. The country's economy added 2% in the third quarter, down from 2.5% in the previous quarter, due to a decline in oil prices. Despite a bull market rally in oil, the growth is expected to slow down.

site_title: JPMorgan sees China deals heating up after party congress
summary: JPMorgan predicts China will see an increase in deals following the recent Communist Party Congress, with a focus on tourism, airline, and infrastructure sectors. The country's openness to reforms and President Xi Jinping's promise of a more transparent business environment are driving the growth. China has already announced $149 billion in foreign deals this year, and JPMorgan expects this trend to continue, driven by the country's expanding middle class and infrastructure push.

site_title: Four in 10 London home sellers cutting their prices: report
summary: London home sellers are cutting their prices, with 4 in 10 revising lower, resulting in a 6.7% average price cut. This reflects a tougher market, with buyer demand cooling and sellers needing to tempt buyers with lower prices. Nationally, 37% of sellers have cut their asking price, while new properties to the market have seen a 0.8% decline. The UK's annual house price growth slowed to 0.8% last month, with transactions slumping 5% in the first nine months of the year.

site_title: Precision engineering roadmap drives 10 future-ready projects
summary: Singapore's precision engineering sector is being transformed with a roadmap that has kicked off 10 projects since its launch in October 2016. The Industry Transformation Map aims to increase sector output to S$42 billion by 2020 and raise productivity by 30%. Multinational firms, large local enterprises, and small and medium-sized enterprises are participating in the projects, which include smart factory technologies and digital capabilities. The sector's output is expected to increase significantly, with 50 SMEs set to become core suppliers to multinational companies by 2020.

site_title: Trump still has time to turn around his presidency
summary: US President Donald Trump returns to Washington after a 12-day Asia tour, amidst record low poll ratings and speculation surrounding congressional and FBI investigations into his team's alleged ties with Russia. Trump has failed to achieve significant success since his election, and his presidency is now at a highly uncertain point. To turn his presidency around, Trump needs to demonstrate governing competence, exploit his presidential prestige and leadership reputation, and build coalitions to support his legislative agenda. A successful governing agenda will depend on his ability to address the country's divisions and polarisation.

site_title: Nickel rally fragile as looming supply cools battery dreams
summary: Nickel prices have retreated after rising to a two-year high due to predictions of increased demand from electric vehicles. However, analysts now believe that demand growth will be slow in the short term, with batteries representing only 3% of demand this year. New supply from Indonesia and the Philippines is expected to rise, potentially outweighing the boost from electric vehicles. The market is also influenced by a softening Chinese stainless steel market and rising supplies of nickel pig iron. As a result, nickel prices are expected to remain stable in the short term, with growth expected to occur in the longer term.

site_title: Trump meets Japan, Australia leaders over trade, N. Korea threat
summary: US President Donald Trump met with Japan's Shinzo Abe and Australia's Malcolm Turnbull on the sidelines of a summit in Manila, discussing North Korea's missile tests and trade. Trump stated "a lot" of progress had been made in trade negotiations, while Abe emphasized regional peace and stability. The three leaders reaffirmed their commitment to maximum pressure on North Korea and discussed expanded security cooperation. They also focused on "free and open" trade in the Indo-Pacific region.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Everbright Water Limited posted a 35% increase in Q3 earnings to HK$123 million, with earnings per share rising to 0.047 Hong Kong cents. The company's revenue increased 35% to HK$746 million.

site_title: Italy's white truffles fetch hot prices at Alba auction
summary: Italy's white truffle auction in Alba saw a record price of 75,000 euros (S$119,023) for a 850g truffle, due to dry weather and changing climate patterns that have undermined production. Truffle hunters report a 30% decrease in production over the past 25 years, with limited supply driving prices to an all-time high of 6,000 euros per kilo. The drought has also affected other Italian farmland, costing the agriculture sector 2 billion euros.

site_title: Tabloid gossip diva Liz Smith dies, aged 94
summary: Liz Smith, the 94-year-old "amiable queen of tattle-tale columns," died on Sunday at her Manhattan home. She was the highest-paid columnist in the newsroom, known for coaxing juicy stories from Hollywood's biggest stars. Smith's columns ran for 33 years, syndicated in 60-70 newspapers, and she became as prominent as legendary predecessors like Walter Winchell and Hedda Hopper. Despite criticism of conflicts of interest and lack of objectivity, Smith was praised for her kinder, gentler approach to gossip, which provided an insider's view of celebrities' lives.

site_title: Big Brother's watching: Chinese facial recognition firms woo investors
summary: Chinese facial recognition firms are attracting investors, fueled by China's plans for a ubiquitous CCTV surveillance network. Firms like SenseTime Group and Face++ are developing software that can quickly identify individuals using artificial intelligence. The market for facial recognition technology is expected to grow at 12.4% annually, with China's market valued at $6.4 billion in 2016. Despite concerns over government surveillance, investors, including US venture capital firms, are pouring money into these firms, which also offer security and payment solutions.

images.alt_text: A facial recognition screen in Shanghai. Face++, whose technology is behind Chinese company Alipay's "scan-your-face-to-pay" function, has already helped the police catch more than 3,000 fugitives.

site_title: US:Wall St opens lower on tax reform uncertainty
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday amid uncertainty over a tax reform deal. The Dow Jones fell 60.63 points, the S&P 500 lost 6.5 points, and the Nasdaq dropped 19.96 points. Despite recent record highs, the US market is weighed down by ongoing tariff discussions.

site_title: Genting HK to be delisted from SGX on 17 April
summary: Genting Hong Kong (Genting HK) will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on April 17, 2018, with the last day of trading set for April 10. The company plans to retain its primary listing in Hong Kong to increase visibility among North Asian investors and reduce costs. Genting HK has not raised funds in Singapore in the last six years and aims to focus on North Asia.

site_title: Nexon surges to all-time high as annual profit outlook doubles
summary: Nexon, Japan's largest gaming company, has surged to an all-time high after doubling its annual profit forecast to at least 91 billion yen, driven by its largest acquisition since 2012 of Pixelberry Studios, a US-based mobile game developer. The acquisition is expected to fuel expansion outside of Asia, with Nexon's CEO, Owen Mahoney, citing the "vast blue ocean" of the market for games targeting women. The deal is seen as a strategic move to add new growth drivers to Nexon's portfolio of profitable but ageing games, with the company's shares rising as much as 10% and gains for the year exceeding 100%.

site_title: SBI Offshore: Corporate governance over the edge?
summary: SBI Offshore's corporate governance is under scrutiny after the departure of three independent directors, allegations of breach of directors' duties, and a lack of clarity from the board. The company's CEO was ousted under contentious circumstances, and the board has been reconstituted with new directors, including Tan Woo Thian, who has direct and deemed interests of almost 14%. UniLegal LLC's report found potential breaches of directors' duties by Tan and Hui, but the board has decided not to take action, citing a lack of financial loss. Regulators should consider whether the listing rules and regulations are complied with and whether investors are misled.

site_title: Iceland home prices soar 56%
summary: Iceland's housing market has surged 56% since its 2009 crash, driven by a lack of supply and growing demand. Despite concerns of a potential bubble, investors like Gisli Hauksson see the market as supported by low interest rates and a shortage of housing. The central bank expects a continued housing shortage and price increases, with no signs of a drop in prices in the near future. Hauksson's investment firm has recently bought a developer to build 4,000 houses, further fueling the market.

site_title: Weakness in tropical oils, sugar businesses weigh down Q3 earnings at Wilmar
summary: Wilmar International's third-quarter earnings fell 5.7% to US$370 million due to weakness in tropical oils and sugar businesses. The oilseeds and grains segment performed well, with revenue increasing 0.4% and net profit rising 92.4% for the nine-month period. Despite this, earnings per share were lower than expected. Chairman Kuok Khoon Hong expects continued strong performance in the oilseeds and grains segment, with expansion plans for consumer products in Asia.

site_title: Pontiac-Perennial joint entities that developed Capitol will not be wound up: Court
summary: A Singaporean court has dismissed Perennial Real Estate Holdings' appeal to wind up joint entities developed with Pontiac Land's affiliate Chesham Properties, including Capitol's hotel, retail shops, and residential units. The Court of Appeal upheld the High Court's decision, citing an available exit mechanism allowing one party to sell shares to the other at fair value. Perennial will consider its options, with shares closing half a Singapore cent lower at S$0.88 on Monday.

site_title: Trump's trip to China: Beneath the smiles, a harsh reality
summary: US President Donald Trump's three-day visit to China ended with a "state visit plus" treatment, despite his dissatisfaction with China on trade and North Korean issues. Trump praised Chinese President Xi Jinping in public, but made implicit threats against China, citing the need for action on trade deficits and North Korea's nuclear program. The US leader warned that China's failure to act will lead to tougher measures, including the military option. The visit ended with a shift in tone, as Trump and Xi moved on to an APEC meeting in Vietnam, where underlying tensions remain.

site_title: First Resources reports lower Q3 net profit
summary: First Resources, a palm oil producer, reported an 11% year-on-year decline in Q3 net profit to US$31.91 million, impacted by lower average selling prices and sales volumes. Revenue fell 9.3% to US$137.45 million. Earnings per share dropped to 2.01 US cents from 2.26 US cents. The company expects favourable industry fundamentals, driven by consumption growth, biofuel demand, and slower supply growth, despite current weaker-than-expected output growth.

site_title: Venezuela meets creditors in bid to dodge default
summary: Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro holds talks with creditors to renegotiate a $60 billion debt, aiming to avoid default that would plunge the economy into crisis. Despite concerns over US sanctions and security in Caracas, investors are sending representatives to the meeting. Maduro's government has made close to $2 billion in payments in the past two weeks, but many say his promise to restructure debt rings hollow. A default could free up $1.6 billion in hard currency, but could also lead to aggressive lawsuits and impact foreign trade.

site_title: Temasek unit acquires 2 per cent stake in HMI for S$11 million
summary: Heliconia Capital Management, a unit of Temasek, is acquiring a 2% stake in Health Management International (HMI) through an S$11 million placement. HMI will issue 16.9 million new shares at S$0.65 each, representing a discount to its closing price. The funds will be used to finance business expansion and growth. HMI owns two tertiary hospitals in Malaysia and a healthcare training centre in Singapore.

site_title: The rail way to track growth in Asean
summary: Asean is set to boost growth with a massive railway network project, dubbed the South-east Asian railway network, under China's Belt and Road Initiative. The 7,000 km rail line will connect China's Yunnan province to Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand, and is expected to double Sino-Asean trade by 2025. Several countries have already announced or started construction on the project, including Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Singapore, with estimated investments of up to $85 billion. The project aims to increase regional trade efficiency, productivity, and connectivity, while also generating opportunities for corporates and investors globally.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of Bandar Malaysia station on the Kuala Lumpur to Singapore high-speed railway. The project is targeted to be completed in 2026 and cut travel between the cities to just 90 minutes.

site_title: GM's electric car sales will meet quotas by 2019, says China chief
summary: General Motors' China joint ventures, led by GM China chief Matt Tsien, aim to meet new energy vehicle (NEV) sales volume quotas by 2019 without purchasing credits. The quotas, set by China, require automakers to produce 10% of annual sales as NEVs by 2019, increasing to 12% in 2020. GM has already launched an electric car, the Baojun E100, which has sold 1,724 units in October, exceeding expectations. Both joint ventures plan to meet the quotas by producing and selling enough NEVs.

site_title: Businesses to join PayNow next year; fintech sandbox applications to be expedited
summary: Singapore's PayNow system will allow businesses to make payments starting mid-2018, with Unique Entity Numbers (UENs) linking to bank accounts. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will expedite fintech sandbox applications to foster innovation. MAS will also set a nationwide QR specification for e-payments and establish cross-border payment linkages with India. These moves aim to promote digital payments and financial inclusion in the country.

site_title: Qualcomm rejects Broadcom's US$103b takeover bid
summary: Qualcomm Inc rejected Broadcom Ltd's US$103-billion takeover bid, stating it "dramatically" undervalued the US company and came with significant regulatory uncertainty. The Board, in consultation with financial and legal advisors, made the decision after a comprehensive review. Qualcomm's shares rose 1% to US$65.25, while Broadcom's shares fell 0.7% to US$263. The rejection comes after Broadcom's proposal was met with skepticism, citing regulatory hurdles and a perceived undervaluation of Qualcomm.

site_title: Singapore shares end the day flat
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended Monday's session flat, closing at 3,419.13, after a slow start. Turnover was 2.2 billion units worth S$1.2 billion, with 251 gainers and 217 losers. Analysts note that earnings from companies like UOL group, Sats, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding surpassed market expectations, with 14 STI components beating market consensus.

site_title: HPL Q3 bottom line up 32%
summary: Hotel Properties Limited (HPL) posted a 32% year-over-year jump in net profit to S$42.22 million for Q3, driven by increased revenue from condominium unit sales and hotel contributions, particularly in Bali and the Maldives. Revenue rose 18% to S$165.09 million. Earnings per share increased from 5.73 Singapore cents to 7.78 Singapore cents.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 4.79 points lower at 1,737.49 on Monday, with 2.9 billion lots traded worth RM2.2 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 594 to 319, marking a lower session.

site_title: Yanlord Q3 profit up 11%
summary: Yanlord Land Group reported a 11% year-over-year increase in third-quarter net profit to 627.52 million yuan (S$128.7 million), driven by lower costs and higher joint venture profits. Revenue fell 32% to 3.76 billion yuan due to decreased gross floor area deliveries. Earnings per share rose from 28.97 fen to 32.41 fen.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end day on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.21% and closing at 29,182.18. The gains were attributed to China's announcement last week that it would lift foreign ownership limits in the financial sector. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with the latter gaining 0.29%. The positive trend was seen as a relief to investors, who had been affected by recent US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Sinarmas Land posts flat Q3 profit
summary: Sinarmas Land's Q3 net profit remained flat at S$17.57 million, up 0.7% year-over-year, driven by a 36.8% increase in revenue to S$199.58 million. However, costs and joint venture expenses rose, contributing to a loss of S$6.15 million, compared to a gain of S$2.55 million in the same period last year.

site_title: Noble Group's co-CEO resigns to pursue other opportunities
summary: Noble Group's co-CEO Jeffrey Frase has resigned, effective November 13, to pursue other opportunities. He was instrumental in building up the oil liquids business and led its global expansion. Frase's resignation comes after the recent sale of the business to Vitol, and William Randall will take over as CEO. The board expressed gratitude for Frase's leadership, citing his success in guiding the business towards a new opportunity.

site_title: Metro posts net loss in Q2 FY18, dragged down by one-off expense
summary: Metro Holdings reported a net loss of S$13.59 million in Q2 FY18, primarily due to a one-off expense from the expiry of conditional remission of additional buyer's stamp duty. Share of results of joint ventures recorded a loss of S$17 million, with profit after tax stripping out one-off items being S$4.6 million. Revenue expanded 6.8% to S$30.25 million, with Metro's retail top line improving 7.2% to S$28.6 million, but profitability was affected by pressures on margins and higher operating costs.

site_title: Opec, allies unlikely to delay decision on oil cut extension
summary: Opec and its allies are likely to decide on extending a global oil supply cut agreement at their Nov 30 meeting, moving beyond the previously indicated timeframe. The current deal, which began in 2017, aims to curb oil supply by 1.8 million barrels per day until March 2018. Ministers from the UAE and Oman expressed confidence in reaching a decision this month, with the possibility of extending the agreement until the end of 2018. However, some producers may not agree to deepen the supply cuts.

site_title: Europe: Equities stable at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets stabilized in opening deals on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.4% to 7,463.12 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 index and Paris' CAC 40 index were 0.2% and flat, respectively. The markets were influenced by mining and healthcare sectors, while US-EU trade talks were also in focus.

site_title: SembMarine unit enters into settlement agreement with Marco Polo on legal spat
summary: SembMarine's unit PPL Shipyard has entered into a settlement agreement with Marco Polo Marine on a without admission of fault or liability basis. Marco Polo Marine had terminated a US$214.3 million contract in 2015, alleging non-compliance with contractual obligations. PPL Shipyard initially rejected the termination and claimed Marco Polo failed to pay a progress payment. The settlement agreement allows PPL Shipyard to withdraw its claim and interest in the arbitration proceedings, with Marco Polo Marine and its subsidiary withdrawing their own claims. The matter is not expected to impact SembMarine's net tangible assets or earnings.

site_title: China's Tingyi Q3 profit jumps, but margin pressure remains
summary: Tingyi, a Chinese partner of Starbucks and PepsiCo, reported a 30% jump in Q3 profit to 1.24 billion yuan, driven by revenue growth of 8.5%. However, the company warned of margin pressure due to rising raw material costs, citing China's changing economic development mode and changing consumer demand. Gross profit margin dropped 0.94 percentage points to 32.5%. Despite this, shares rose 1.9% after the results.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's second Fintech Festival began with over 25,000 participants from 100 countries. The festival comes as mergers and acquisitions (M&A) activity in Singapore increased by 26% in 2017, driven by three megadeals worth $2 billion. Meanwhile, CapitaLand opened its largest mall in Suzhou, China, and Alibaba's Lazada achieved record sales of $123 million in South-east Asia on Singles Day. However, Singapore ranks low in consumers' trust in digital services, coming in ninth out of 10 Asia-Pacific economies, according to a survey.

site_title: CIMB flags loss of back-up data, heightens security measures
summary: CIMB Group reported that several magnetic tapes containing customer information, including those of CIMB Bank and its subsidiaries, were lost in transit. The bank stated that there is no evidence that any information has been compromised, as the tapes do not contain authentication data like PINs or credit card CVV numbers. CIMB has heightened security measures, including temporarily suspending services, and is working with authorities to protect its customers. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has advised customers to exercise vigilance and monitor alerts from their financial services providers.

site_title: IMF says Europe's recovery is spilling over to rest of world
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has revised its global outlook, citing Europe's robust growth as a key factor in the improved outlook. Forecasting 2.4% expansion in Europe this year, up from 1.7% in 2016, the IMF attributes the bulk of the upward revision to Europe's growth. The region's recovery is solidifying, but the IMF notes that the sustainability of the rebound remains uncertain due to adverse demographic trends and subdued productivity. Europe's improved demand is boosting world trade and inflation pressure, with the IMF cautioning that monetary policy should remain accommodative for an extended period.

site_title: UEL posts S$10.6m profit in Q3 from continuing operations
summary: UEL posted a net profit of S$10.6 million in Q3 from continuing operations, a 92% drop from the same period last year. Excluding discontinued operations, the group's net profit from continuing operations marked a 9% drop. Revenue increased 41% year-over-year to S$143 million, driven by revenue recognition from a project in Malaysia and higher sales of property units in Singapore. Despite regional geopolitical uncertainties, the Singapore property market has stabilized, and UEL expects sustainable growth in the longer term.

site_title: Taiwan tells US it does not want to cause trouble in Taiwan Strait
summary: Taiwan's envoy to the Asia-Pacific summit, James Soong, assured the US that Taiwan does not intend to cause trouble in the Taiwan Strait, amid strained relations with China. Soong stated that Taiwan hopes to use peaceful means to solve problems and maintain stability with China. The comments come after China suspended a dialogue mechanism with Taiwan and increased diplomatic pressure. Relations between Beijing and Taipei have worsened since President Tsai Ing-wen took office, with China viewing her as a threat to its "one country, two systems" policy.

site_title: Alibaba's Lazada drums up record sales of US$123m in South-east Asia on Singles Day
summary: Lazada, a subsidiary of Alibaba, achieved record sales of US$123 million in South-east Asia on Singles Day, surpassing last year's sales by 191%. This marked a significant increase, with 6.5 million items ordered, mostly from mobile devices. The growth is attributed to rapid smartphone adoption and a growing middle-class in the region. Lazada's CEO aims to provide access to a wide range of products with deals and discounts, previously unavailable in local markets.

site_title: Microsoft founder Gates commits US$100m for fund, startups to fight Alzheimer's
summary: Bill Gates is investing $50 million in the Dementia Discovery Fund and an additional $50 million in startups working on Alzheimer's research, a disease affecting 50 million people worldwide. Despite decades of research, there is no treatment to slow progression, and Gates believes it may take 10 years to find effective treatments. He aims to focus on "less mainstream" approaches and is working with the UK government, pharmaceutical companies, and researchers to develop new theories and treatments for Alzheimer's.

site_title: New India Assurance falls on trading debut after US$1.5b IPO
summary: New India Assurance Co Ltd, India's top non-life insurer, fell 10% on its trading debut after a $1.5 billion IPO, with subscriptions reaching only 1.2 times the shares on offer. The IPO raised $1.99 billion, but high valuations have translated into weak post-listing share price gains for insurers. The company's valuation was 76 times its earnings per share, compared to ICICI Lombard's 48 times. India is enjoying a record year for IPOs, but high valuations pose a challenge for insurers.

site_title: China Everbright Water's Q3 profit rises more than one-third
summary: China Everbright Water Limited reported a 35% increase in its third-quarter earnings, driven by a 33% year-on-year rise in gross profit from construction services. Net profit reached HK$123 million, while earnings per share increased to 0.047 Hong Kong cents. Revenue rose 35% to HK$746 million, mainly attributed to construction revenue from projects in Zhenjiang City and Nanjing City. The company closed at S$0.46, up 1.1%, after securing six new projects worth over 1.8 billion yuan.

site_title: Hedge funds pile on bullish oil bets as Middle East tension heats up
summary: Hedge funds have significantly increased their bullish bets on oil prices, with bets on rising Brent crude hitting a record high amid rising tensions in the Middle East. Disruptions in Libya, Nigeria, and Venezuela previously failed to trigger strong rallies, but Saudi Arabia and Iran's escalating tensions have driven oil prices to their highest in over two years, surpassing $80 per barrel.

site_title: Aussie publisher delays book alleging China influence in Australia
summary: Australia's largest independent publisher, Allen & Unwin, has delayed the publication of a book alleging Chinese government influence in Australian institutions due to legal concerns. The book, "Silent Invasion," was set to be published but its author, Clive Hamilton, was unwilling to delay publication. The publisher cited concerns over possible legal action from Beijing, prompting Hamilton to request the return of the book's rights. The book's publication has been put on hold pending further discussion.

site_title: Abu Dhabi fund seeks energy stakes after spending US$5b
summary: Abu Dhabi's state fund, Mubadala Investment Co, has spent US$5 billion in the past few months on energy investments, primarily in the US, driven by low costs and high demand. CEO Musabbeh Al Kaabi cited attractive feedstock and expansion opportunities in the US petrochemicals sector. Recent investments include a US$1.7 billion chemicals joint venture and US$2.1 billion chemicals in Louisiana, with further expansion planned in Vietnam.

site_title: Sembcorp unit wins second wind power auction in India
summary: Sembcorp Green Infra, a unit of Sembcorp, has won the second nationwide wind power tender in India with a 250 MW project. The project, expected to be fully commissioned by mid-2019, will be developed in phases and sold to Solar Energy Corporation of India under a 25-year power purchase agreement. This is Sembcorp's second win in the tender, following a similar 250 MW project announced in April. The company already operates over 4,000 MW of power capacity in India, and this win reinforces its commitment to sustainable energy in the country.

site_title: United Air resumes Delhi Service after pollution improves
summary: United Airlines has resumed its Newark-New Delhi flight after temporarily suspending the service due to poor air quality in Delhi. The airline cited improving pollution levels as the reason for resuming the flight. The US Embassy monitor reported PM 2.5 levels of 495 at 9am on Monday, below the hazardous threshold of 300. Customers are advised to check the United Airlines website or mobile app for updates. The resumption comes after Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal described Delhi as a "gas chamber" due to thick toxic smog.

site_title: South Korean workers seek assurances over Opel shift to Europe
summary: South Korean workers are seeking assurances about the impact of Opel's planned shift of car production from South Korea to Europe on General Motors' (GM) South Korean unit. Opel boss Michael Lohscheller stated that by 2020, GM's European arm will import nearly 200,000 vehicles less per year, citing the move as a way to increase production in Europe. This shift has raised concerns about the potential decline in output at GM's South Korean unit, which is already experiencing slumping sales.

site_title: Emirates puts pressure on Airbus to commit to ailing A380
summary: Emirates President Tim Clark urged Airbus to commit to its struggling A380 program, stating that a new order would require contractual assurances of continued production for 10-15 years. Clark expressed his airline's willingness to take more A380s beyond its current 142 on order, but emphasized the need for Airbus to demonstrate its support. Airbus is currently negotiating a follow-on accord for 36 A380 units, but has already pushed back on new engines, a key demand for Emirates. The airline's relationship with Airbus shows its bargaining power, but the program's future remains uncertain.

site_title: Norway to defend itself in court over Arctic oil exploration
summary: Norway is defending itself in court over its Arctic oil exploration, with a group of activists claiming the country's decision to award exploration licenses breaches its constitution. Greenpeace and a Norwegian group, Nature and Youth, argue that drilling in the Barents Sea poses a threat to the environment and contradicts Norway's commitment to fight climate change under the 2015 Paris Agreement. The lawsuit marks a growing global trend of legal challenges against governments and companies for falling short on climate change, and could pave the way for more legal fights.

site_title: Follow the Yellow Brick Road
summary: Singapore's OCBC Bank has announced its new CEO, Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran. Helen Wong will retire as CEO, making Tan Teck Long her successor. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to enhance cooperation in green and transition finance. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup has set a target of 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. Chinese banks are struggling with the impact of Beijing's consumer lending push.

site_title: Delhi smog shortening lives, say doctors as hospitals fill up
summary: Delhi's severe smog, with PM2.5 levels exceeding 500, is shortening lives, according to doctors. Patient numbers at hospitals have tripled since pollution spiked, with symptoms including chronic bronchitis and respiratory problems. The World Health Organization's guidelines state that exposure to 25 PM2.5 over 24 hours is safe, but current levels are hazardous. Experts warn that while the effects may not be immediate, pollution can lead to a slow decline in life expectancy, with potential lethal effects noticed years later. Authorities have taken measures to reduce pollution, but doctors advise against living in the city due to health concerns.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall; won down on weaker demand for risk
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell 0.50% on Monday, with the won weakening to a two-week low against the US dollar. The currency finished at 1,120.6 per dollar, down 0.08% from the previous day. Bond yields rose, and foreigners were net sellers of 63.62 billion won worth of shares. The KOSPI is up 25.5% so far this year, but faces weaker demand for risk.

site_title: Thai court takes up case against owner of Leicester City
summary: A Thai court has accepted a 14 billion baht (S$587.8 million) lawsuit against King Power International, the owner of Leicester City football club, for allegedly failing to pay the Thai government 14 billion baht from its airport franchise operation in 2006. The lawsuit, filed by anti-graft official Charnchai Issarasenanark, also targets executives from state-owned airport operator Airports of Thailand. The case will be heard on February 12 next year, with billionaire Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha's family owning King Power.

site_title: Australia shares fall as banks weigh; NZ crawls higher
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% on Monday, led by financial stocks, including Westpac and ANZ trading ex-dividend. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,021.8. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose marginally, ending a six-session losing streak. Gains in material stocks, such as Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton, were offset by losses in technology stocks.

site_title: UK companies a decade behind Denmark in technology, CBI says
summary: The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) reports that UK companies are nearly a decade behind Denmark in adopting new technologies such as cloud, e-purchasing, and cyber security. This lag is hurting productivity and pay, with the UK's output per worker ranking at the bottom of the Group of Seven. The CBI estimates that by adopting proven technologies, businesses could add £100 billion to the economy and reduce income inequality by 5%. The group is calling on the government to support businesses in adopting these technologies and fund local support when needed.

site_title: Longtime New York gossip columnist Liz Smith dead at 94
summary: New York gossip columnist Liz Smith, 94, died at her Manhattan home. Born Mary Elizabeth Smith in Fort Worth, Texas, she chronicled the lives of Hollywood and Broadway stars, moguls, models, and the wealthy, starting in the 1950s. Smith famously broke news of Donald Trump's separation from his first wife, Ivana, and earned over $1 million a year at her peak. Her column, known for its insider look into the lives of the rich and famous, offered a more nuanced approach to gossip, focusing on glamour and celebrity rather than scandal.

site_title: Once Asia's top market, home-price gains fade on India cash ban
summary: India's property sector, once Asia's top market, has seen home-price gains fade due to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's crackdown on cash. The government's measures, including a nationwide sales tax and new home-buyer protections, have constrained the industry. Project launches declined 60% and sales dropped 32% in the quarter ended Sept 30. While the new protections have given home buyers a level playing field, the industry is still recovering, with unsold inventory in major cities taking 62-52 months to be absorbed.

site_title: Super Majors lose edge with birth of another LNG giant
summary: Total SA has signed a $1 billion deal to acquire liquefied natural gas assets from Engie SA, solidifying the company's position as a major player in the industry. The acquisition is part of Total's strategy to grow in a low-price market, and it is expected to double the company's output and control 10% of the global market by 2020. The deal comes as the global liquefied natural gas market is poised to double to $90 billion by 2040, driven by increasing demand from emerging markets for power generation.

site_title: Tennis: Tour Finals fair for all, says Federer amid clay talk
summary: Roger Federer dismissed Rafael Nadal's claim that the ATP Tour Finals should be played on clay courts, stating that the current indoor hard-court surface is a good choice given the tournament's schedule. Federer, who will compete for a seventh title, acknowledged that Nadal's preferred surface has an advantage but believes the indoor surface is fair and suitable. The world number one also expressed no regrets about not finishing the year as world number one, citing Nadal's success and his own limitations.

site_title: Japan to delay multi-billion dollar fighter jet development
summary: Japan plans to delay a decision on developing a new advanced fighter jet, known as the F-3, amid pressure to improve defenses against North Korea and China. The estimated $40 billion project has raised concerns over its future. The delay may impact the lucrative contract and raises questions about Japan's military capabilities. Officials are instead focusing on acquiring new US equipment, such as ballistic missile interceptors and F-35 stealth planes, to bolster its defenses. The decision is seen as a strategic shift in Japan's military priorities.

site_title: Fewer foreign students are coming to US, survey shows
summary: The number of newly arriving international students in the US declined an average 7% in fall 2017, with 45% of campuses reporting drops in new international enrollment, according to a survey by the Institute of International Education. Experts cite an uncertain social and political climate in the US as a major reason for the decline, which also saw a 3% drop in first-time international students. The decline may have significant financial implications for small universities relying on foreign students, who provide a $39 billion annual infusion into the US economy.

site_title: China push for facial recognition technology bolsters start-ups
summary: China's plans to build a comprehensive CCTV surveillance network are fueling investments in facial recognition technology start-ups. Companies like SenseTime Group, Face++, and DeepGlint are receiving funding for their software that uses AI to quickly identify individuals by analyzing facial features. The technology has potential applications in public security, commercial settings, and payments systems. With a multi-billion-dollar global market at stake, these start-ups are poised to benefit from China's push for ubiquitous surveillance.

site_title: Iron wars break out as Hong Kong picks fight with Singapore
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd (HKEX) has launched futures contracts for iron ore, challenging Singapore Exchange Ltd's (SGX) leading position. The new US dollar-denominated contract was introduced with waived trading fees for six months, targeting the volatile commodity. Iron ore has seen extraordinary price fluctuations in recent years, with trading volumes jumping 59% at SGX last year. HKEX aims to create value with its new contract, but analysts question its ability to gain traction against SGX's established offshore contract.

site_title: Gold steady amid firmer dollar; US rate hike view weighs
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Monday, holding near the previous session's low, amid a firmer US dollar and expectations of interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve. Spot gold was nearly unchanged at US$1,275.63 per ounce, while US gold futures gained 0.1%. Analysts attribute the price stability to the market digesting news of potential interest rate hikes, with Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker predicting a rate hike next month and three more in 2018.

site_title: Australia shares pulled down by financials; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares declined 0.2% on Monday, dragged down by financials, including Westpac and ANZ, which fell 3.4% and 3.2%, respectively. This followed a similar decline in US markets, which fell for the first time in nine weeks. Investors are cautious about US tax reform plans and potential delays. Meanwhile, materials stocks rose on metal price increases, and New Zealand's benchmark index remained flat.

site_title: Noble Group said to lose key bank support as DBS cuts lending
summary: Noble Group, a struggling commodity trader, lost key bank support as DBS Group Holdings cut lending, including a $60 million stake in its revolving credit facility. The move is the latest blow to Noble, which is moving towards debt restructuring after suffering losses of over $3 billion this year. DBS had been a key supporter of Noble, but the bank's decision is a significant blow to the company's efforts to secure financing.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher in first session since return of mid-day break
summary: Singapore shares closed 0.1% higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index up 3.2 points to 3,423.3. About 985 million shares worth S$537 million changed hands, with Jiutian Chemical being the most actively traded stock. Gainers outnumbered losers 198 to 174, marking the first session since the return of the mid-day break.

site_title: Airbus suffers early Dubai blow as Boeing wins surprise 787 deal
summary: Airbus suffered a major setback at the Dubai Air Show when Emirates, its largest customer, committed to buying $15.1 billion worth of Boeing's 787-10 Dreamliners, surpassing the order value Airbus had planned for its A380 super jumbos. The surprise deal marked a twin blow for Airbus, which is heavily reliant on Emirates, and came despite initial delays and confusion at the air show. Boeing's deal added to Emirates' existing order of 70 A350 jets, which they cancelled in 2014. Airbus is now facing a significant challenge to secure a large order for its A380.

site_title: Brookfield is said to make over US$14b buyout bid for GGP
summary: Brookfield Asset Management has made a $14 billion buyout bid for mall owner GGP, valuing the company at $23 per share. The bid represents a 21% premium to GGP's closing price on November 6. Brookfield's real estate unit acquired 34% of GGP in the third quarter, up from 29% after exercising warrants for $462 million. The company had previously agreed not to increase its stake beyond 45% for four years. The bid comes as shares of mall companies have been hit hard by the rise of e-commerce.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on US tax reform jitters
summary: Tokyo stocks declined on Monday due to concerns over a potential delay in US corporate tax cuts and profit-taking. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.32% to 22,380.99, while the Topix index dropped 0.94% to 1,783.49. The decline followed recent gains, with investors locking in profits ahead of US presidential election uncertainty.

site_title: Brokers' take: Phillip Capital issues 'add' to F&N on continued growth of Vinamilk
summary: Phillip Capital upgraded Fraser and Neave (F&N) to "add" due to the continued growth of Vinamilk, with a target price of S$2.83. Vinamilk contributed 47% of F&N's FY17 earnings before interest and taxes, with an exceptional gain of US$1.1776 billion from the reclassification of Vinamilk as an associate company. However, F&N's earnings were dampened by higher finance costs and losses in certain business segments, leading to a net debt position.

site_title: Amazon says Australia launch imminent ahead of spending season
summary: Amazon is "really close" to launching in Australia, with its country manager Rocco Braeuniger stating the company will ship goods from its first Australian warehouse in time for the holiday season. The move is expected to shake up Australia's retail sector, which is already struggling with weak trading conditions. Amazon plans to bring more services to Australia, including its retail unit, and has signed up "many thousands" of sellers. The company will not enter the Australian grocery market initially, citing the complexity of delivering fresh food.

site_title: Six months on, Macron unpopular but in control
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron has chalked up several major reforms in his first six months in power, including a law to clean up politics and labor code reforms. However, his approval rating has plummeted to 32% due to his use of executive decrees and perceived elitism. Despite this, Macron remains in control and has a long-term outlook, according to insiders. He faces a balancing act between lowering taxes and slashing the deficit, while pushing for ambitious EU reforms. Macron's popularity may improve as the economy grows and time gives him more room to prove his leadership.

site_title: Fed's Harker stands by call for rate hike next month
summary: Federal Reserve President Patrick Harker has reaffirmed his expectation of a December interest rate hike, citing the need to position the central bank for future economic shocks. Harker has "lightly penciled in" a rate hike, but has less conviction than last month due to weak inflation and concerns about its measurement. He projects three rate hikes in 2018 if inflation remains on track, aiming to normalize policy and reduce the Fed's balance sheet. The US economy is seen as ripe for further gains in consumer prices, with unemployment expected to drop below 4% late in 2018.

site_title: Yuuzoo's Q3 profit up 24%
summary: Yuuzoo Corp reported a 24% increase in Q3 net profit to S$7.86 million, driven by a 13% rise in revenue to S$15.6 million, primarily due to improved franchise and celebrity branded network sales. The company attributed this growth to discontinuing payment services to high-risk clients, resulting in non-cash revenue of S$15.1 million.

site_title: Razer surges on debut after raising HK$4.1b in HK IPO
summary: Razer Inc, a maker of computer accessories for gamers, surged on its Hong Kong debut, with its stock rising 41% to HK$5.49. The company raised HK$4.1 billion (S$721 million) in its initial public offering. Razer, backed by Singapore's sovereign wealth fund and Li Ka Shing, produces gaming products and is expanding into smartphones. Its debut follows China Literature Ltd.'s 86% jump in Hong Kong debut, marking a wave of technology listings in the city.

site_title: Asia shares down on uncertainty over US tax reform plans, sterling falls
summary: Asian shares declined on Monday due to uncertainty over US tax reform plans, with Tokyo's Nikkei falling 0.7% and the MSCI Asia-Pacific Index down 0.4%. The British pound also fell 0.5% amid growing doubts over Prime Minister Theresa May's leadership. Investors remain cautious ahead of a potential compromise between the US Senate and House of Representatives on tax bills. Meanwhile, oil prices held firm due to concerns over Saudi Arabian instability and a potential Venezuelan debt default.

site_title: IMF chief sees confidence in China's plan to open financial system
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde praised China's plan to ease foreign-ownership limits on financial firms, describing it as a "very positive development" that indicates openness and confidence in their financial system. China's removal of foreign-ownership restrictions follows a pledge to fight protectionism and embrace globalisation. Lagarde expressed optimism about the global economy, predicting 3.6% growth this year and 3.7% in 2018, with Asia expected to generate 5.5% growth.

site_title: China's yuan eases on weaker fix and seasonal corporate US dollar-buying
summary: China's yuan weakened against the US dollar on Monday, falling to 6.6347 per dollar, the weakest level in nearly two weeks, due to corporate demand for the greenback and a weaker official fixing. The People's Bank of China lowered its midpoint rate 0.1% weaker than the previous fix. The US dollar gained against major peers, including the pound, as US yields spiked. This move is seen as a response to the weakening yuan, which has been under pressure due to the ongoing trade tensions between China and the US.

site_title: Oil markets firm on Middle East tensions, but US drilling caps gains
summary: Oil markets opened cautiously on Monday amid Middle East tensions, with Brent crude futures up 12 cents to $63.64 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude up 13 cents to $56.87 per barrel. Rising US drilling caps suggested producers are preparing to increase output. However, the gains were limited by ongoing tensions in the Middle East.

site_title: Citizenship fiasco threatens economic confidence in Australia
summary: Australia's government is facing a citizenship crisis that threatens economic confidence, as Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull leads a minority government. The crisis, sparked by lawmakers discovering they hold dual citizenship, has led to the resignation of two lawmakers and a special election. The turmoil is distracting the government from passing legislation, including company tax cuts, and has turned voters off the government, with Labor increasing its lead over the coalition. The crisis risks undermining economic confidence, particularly with the Australian economy struggling with record household debt and record-low wage growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tick higher at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.25% to 29,194.93, driven by anticipation of Chinese economic data release later in the week. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up, increasing 0.07% and 0.05% respectively.

site_title: 3 megadeals push Singapore M&A activity up 26% in 2017: Baker McKenzie
summary: Singapore's mergers and acquisitions (M&A) activity surged 26% in 2017, reaching US$23.1 billion, driven by three megadeals worth US$2 billion. The country is expected to maintain this level in 2018 and peak at US$27.4 billion in 2019. Singapore's GDP growth is seen as cyclical peak, while a stronger Singapore dollar will impact US dollar deal values. Domestic M&As are expected to rise from US$5.7 billion to US$12.7 billion in 2018, with IPO transactions projected to increase to US$5.98 billion and US$2.7 billion respectively.

site_title: Singapore ranks low for consumers' trust in digital services, survey finds
summary: A survey by Experian and IDC found Singapore ranks 9th out of 10 Asia-Pacific economies for consumers' trust in digital services, with a score of 2.3 out of 10. Despite having advanced fraud management systems, Singapore consumers are less trusting of companies' ability to manage post-fraud experiences. However, Singapore consumers are most trusting of the government, particularly in personal data protection. The survey also found that 18.5% of Singaporeans were directly impacted by fraud in the past year, and 32.7% had fraud experience.

images.alt_text: Singapore consumers are most trusting of the government with over 75 per cent of those polled saying they trust government agencies, way above the APAC average of 51.7 per cent.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Monday, with a 0.41-point gain to 1743.14. The index saw 116.64 million lots traded worth RM63.71 million, with 127 gainers and 67 losers.

site_title: Singapore Fintech Fest launches with more than 25,000 participants from over 100 countries
summary: The Singapore Fintech Festival, organized by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, launched with over 25,000 participants from 100 countries. The week-long festival features talks from global experts, an innovation lab crawl, and networking events. A new feature is the Investor Summit, providing opportunities for Singapore-based fintech startups to access funding. The festival also includes the three-day FinTech Conference, with over 160 speakers, and the Global FinTech Hackcelerator, showcasing 20 market-ready fintech solutions.

site_title: "You are the light" - Philippines' Duterte croons at Trump's request
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte sang a Filipino love song "Ikaw" at a dinner for Asian leaders, including US President Donald Trump, at Trump's request. The song's lyrics express devotion, with one verse saying "You are the light in my world." Duterte claimed he sang uninvited, but later said he did so on Trump's orders. The meeting between the two leaders comes amid strained US-Philippines relations, with Duterte's government facing criticism over human rights abuses and executions in the country's war on drugs.

site_title: Formula One: Vettel wins Brazilian GP, Hamilton fourth from pits
summary: Sebastian Vettel won the Brazilian Grand Prix for Ferrari, 2.8 seconds ahead of Valtteri Bottas, after taking the lead at the start. Vettel controlled the incident-packed race, with Kimi Raikkonen holding on to third. Lewis Hamilton, the newly-crowned four-time champion, was fourth after a late challenge. The win marked Vettel's first victory since his world championship disappointment.

site_title: Some 230 units of Parc Botannia sold at launch
summary: Parc Botannia, a 735-unit 99-year leasehold condominium in Sengkang, Singapore, sold 230 units at its launch, exceeding initial expectations. The average selling price was $1,270 psf, with buyers mostly locals. The project, developed by a 70:30 joint venture between Sing Holdings and Wee Hur, offers one to five-bedroom apartments. The most popular units were one-bedroom, two-bedroom, and four-bedroom units, with over half of the one-bedders sold and about half of the four-bedders sold. The project is targeted for completion by end-2021.

site_title: Pound slips as trouble mounts for May, US dollar edges up
summary: The pound slipped 0.55% against the US dollar as British Prime Minister May faces mounting troubles, including a potential leadership challenge from 40 Conservative MPs. Brexit talks are also facing a crucial deadline, with the UK refusing to offer a figure for its EU debt. Meanwhile, the US dollar edged up 0.2% against a basket of six major currencies due to rising US Treasury yields.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars pressured as yield buffers erode
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are under pressure as their yield buffers erode, with the Australian dollar stuck near major chart support. The Aussie dollar's yield premium has shrunk to 15 basis points, its thinnest since 2001, while the New Zealand dollar has edged down to US$0.692. Analysts predict the AUD will weaken to US$0.70 by end 2018 and US$0.68 by mid 2019, and the NZD will lift above US$0.70 in a relatively short period.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on concern over US tax plan
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday due to concerns over a potential delay in US corporate tax cuts, snapping an eight-week winning streak on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.35%, and the Topix index declined 0.16%. The move followed US President Trump's latest threats to extend the current stock rally, which has been driven by optimism over the tax cuts.

site_title: Weiye Q3 profit swings to 12.8m yuan loss on fall in revenue
summary: Weiye Holdings, a Chinese property developer, reported a net loss of 12.8 million yuan in the third quarter, down from a net profit of 10.0 million yuan in the same period last year. Revenue dropped 39.6% to 118.6 million yuan, mainly due to weaker sales and lower total net saleable floor area handed over to customers. The company's loss per share was 6.53 fen, and its net asset value per share dipped to 5.97 yuan.

site_title: HRnetGroup Q3 profit grows 20.2% to S$10.7m as minority interests shrink
summary: HRnetGroup reported a 20.2% increase in Q3 net profit to S$10.7 million, driven by a S$1.4 million reduction in non-controlling interests. Revenue rose 7% to S$97.5 million, primarily due to growth in the flexible staffing business. The company expects to announce new projects and focus on merger and acquisition opportunities.

site_title: Guidelines for smart factories launched as manufacturers gear up for Industry 4.0
summary: The Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) has launched the Singapore Smart Industry Readiness Index, a diagnostic tool to help manufacturers build smart factories and take advantage of Industry 4.0. The index evaluates the state of facilities and provides a transformation roadmap. Industry 4.0 refers to automation and data exchange in manufacturing technologies, creating a "smart factory" with human and robot collaboration. The index was validated by an advisory panel and will be used to enhance Singapore's manufacturing competitiveness. A series of workshops will be conducted to help companies understand and use the index.

site_title: Roadmap for precision engineering sector spurs 10 digital transformation projects
summary: Singapore's precision engineering sector is undergoing digital transformation through the Industry Transformation Map (ITM), which aims to propel the sector's output to S$42 billion by 2020. Since its launch, 10 projects have been kickstarted, including three by multinational firms, three by large local enterprises, and four by small and medium-sized enterprises. The projects are expected to raise productivity by 30% on average, with 27 companies already qualified as core suppliers to multinational companies in high-growth manufacturing segments. The sector's output is expected to increase by 30% over the next five years.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday on Wall Street's soft lead
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 5.33 points lower at 3,414.77 on Monday, amid a soft lead from Wall Street, where US stocks closed down last Friday due to concerns over a delay in US corporate tax cuts. Investors also await the release of economic data and major central bank speeches, while a divergence in tax reform plans may pose downside risks to sentiment.

site_title: Alibaba's rise creates 10 billionaires not named Jack Ma
summary: Alibaba's co-founder Jack Ma has created a network of 10 billionaires, with combined fortunes exceeding $100 billion, through his investments in supporting industries such as e-payments, insurance, delivery companies, and complementary retailers. Ma's wealth is valued at $47.6 billion, while his network's collective net worth is larger than the economies of 136 countries. The network includes billionaires from companies like ZhongAn Online P&C Insurance Co., Qudian Inc, SF Express, and YTO Express, with some emerging this year through initial public offerings. Alibaba's ecosystem has driven the growth of the e-commerce market in China, with Singles' Day sales exceeding $25 billion this year.

site_title: NSA veterans catch eye of Silicon Valley investors
summary: NSA veterans, including Ellison Anne Williams, are leaving the agency to start their own cybersecurity companies. Williams co-founded Enveil, which has raised $5 million from investors, and is one of several former NSA employees to transition to the private sector. The trend is driven by the growing demand for cybersecurity services, with the global market valued at $100 billion. Investors, including Silicon Valley venture capital firms, are taking notice and providing funding to Washington-area cybersecurity startups. This trend aims to tap into the expertise and knowledge of former intelligence agency employees, who are often skilled in "offensive" cybersecurity.

site_title: Australia's central bank sees no shock that could force a rate rise
summary: Australia's Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) deputy governor Guy Debelle stated that there is no shock on the horizon that could force a sharp interest rate rise, despite households' high debt loads. A material increase in rates would pressure households, but the RBA is unlikely to raise rates, which have been at a record low of 1.5% for over a year. The central bank shows no signs of leaving rates unchanged soon.

site_title: Procurri returns to profitability in Q3 with S$14,000 net earnings
summary: Procurri Corp returned to profitability in Q3 2017 with net earnings of S$14,000, marking a significant improvement from a year-ago loss of S$178,000. Revenue rose 60.9% to S$51.3 million, driven by higher sales volumes in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa, as well as the Americas. Despite a 9-month net loss of S$1.5 million, the company's third-quarter results demonstrate a positive trend.

site_title: LinkedIn faces setback in China over verifying of identities
summary: LinkedIn, a foreign internet company, faces a setback in China after blocking individuals from advertising jobs on its site due to new government regulations requiring identity verification. The company can still post job listings, but it's unclear when it will allow individuals to do so again. The move comes after a rash of online hiring scams, including a recent incident where a young college graduate killed himself after being deceived by a pyramid scheme. The government has increased scrutiny on internet job postings, and LinkedIn must adhere to local rules, including censoring content and limiting group creation.

site_title: Four in 10 London homesellers are cutting prices in tough market
summary: London home sellers are cutting prices, with over four in 10 revising their asking price downward. The average price cut is 6.7%, reflecting "initial over-optimism" in the market. New vendors are reducing their expectations modestly, with a 0.2% decline, and the overall market is experiencing a cooling trend, with buyer demand dropping and transactions slumping 5% year-over-year.

site_title: Jardine C&C acquires 5.5% of Vietnam dairy producer Vinamilk for US$616m
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (JC&C) has agreed to acquire a 5.53% stake in Vietnam Dairy Products Joint Stock Company (Vinamilk) for US$616 million. The acquisition, funded through internal resources and external borrowings, aligns with JC&C's strategy of investing in market-leading companies in South-east Asia. Vinamilk, a 58% market share leader in Vietnam's dairy market, will see JC&C's earnings per share increase from 178 US cents to 180 US cents, following the acquisition.

site_title: Shawn Mendes wins best artist at MTV Europe Music Awards
