summary: Shawn Mendes won best artist and best song at the MTV Europe Music Awards, beating heavyweights like Taylor Swift and Ed Sheeran. Mendes, 19, also took home the "biggest fans" award. Other winners included Eminem, Camila Cabello, Coldplay, and Kendrick Lamar. The awards ceremony, hosted by Rita Ora, marked the first time the EMAs were held in London in 20 years and featured performances by U2 and David Guetta.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS upgrades UMS to 'buy' on positive outlook for its main client Applied Materials
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded UMS Holdings to a "buy" rating, citing growth in front-end semiconductor equipment manufacturing and a positive outlook for main client Applied Materials. The broker raised its target price to S$1.21 from S$0.90 and increased earnings projections by 23-31% for 2017-19.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Jardine C&C, Vard Holdings, Procurri, APTT
summary: Key stocks to watch include Jardine C&C, which agreed to acquire a 5.53% stake in Vietnam Dairy Products Joint Stock Company for $616 million. Vard Holdings' majority shareholder is offering to buy out non-controlling shares at 25 cents per share, while Procurri Corp reported a return to profitability in its third quarter earnings. Asian Pay Television Trust's distribution per unit remained unchanged at 1.625 cents, with revenue increasing 6.5% year-over-year.

site_title: Resigned Lebanon PM says free in Saudi and will return home 'soon'
summary: Lebanese Prime Minister Saad Hariri has stated he is "free" in Saudi Arabia, where he resigned last week, and plans to return to Lebanon "very soon." In an interview, Hariri denied rumors of being under house arrest, saying he can travel freely if he wishes. His comments come as Lebanon faces a political crisis and uncertainty about his future.

site_title: UK shoppers cut spending by most in more than 4 years: Visa
summary: UK shoppers cut spending by 2% in October, the largest decline in over four years, according to Visa's credit and debit card data. This marks the fifth fall in the last six months. Clothing and footwear suffered the biggest decline, down 9% from last year, due to warm weather. The Bank of England's recent interest rate rise is seen as a factor, with economists warning that high inflation and weak wage growth are squeezing household budgets. November's Black Friday and Cyber Monday sales will provide further insight into the Christmas season.

site_title: Tokyo pushes back on 'bizarre' death tax that deters expats
summary: Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike is urging the Japanese government to review a "bizarre" death tax that deters expats, which subjects long-term foreign residents to inheritance tax of up to 55% on their worldwide assets. The tax, introduced in 2013, has been amended to restrict it to those who have lived in Japan for over 10 years, but critics argue it still creates a disincentive for talented individuals to move to Japan. Koike's efforts aim to attract asset managers and financial firms to the city, but the tax remains a major challenge, with experts warning it could force financial industry veterans to leave the country.

site_title: Xi gets head start on Trump in contest for South-east Asian money
summary: China's President Xi Jinping is gaining an upper hand in the competition for influence in South-east Asia, with his country pushing ahead with free trade agreements and massive infrastructure projects. In contrast, US President Donald Trump's Asian tour has been met with skepticism, with 38% of people in the region expecting relations with the US to worsen during his presidency. China has significantly widened its lead in trade and investment with South-east Asia, with a growing number of Chinese tourists visiting the region.

site_title: Strong earthquake hits Iraq and Iran, killing at least 210
summary: A magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck Iraq and Iran, killing at least 210 people and injuring over 1,700. The hardest-hit province was Kermanshah in Iran, where at least 207 people were killed, with many more injured and trapped under rubble. The quake caused widespread damage, including damaged hospitals and homes made of mud bricks, and prompted fears of aftershocks. Emergency services and international aid are being deployed to assist in the response efforts.

site_title: New kids on the block: tech giants turning Sydney's CBD into 'Silicon Place'
summary: Global tech giants, including Amazon, LinkedIn, and Expedia, are moving into Sydney's central business district, transforming it into "Silicon Place." This influx has tightened the office rental market, driving down the city's vacancy rate to a near-decade low. The market is expected to remain tight for the next two years, with new supply not anticipated until 2020. The tech invasion is also contributing to growth and employment in the construction industry, and is seen as a gateway to Asia.

site_title: Collaborating to drive growth
summary: Singapore-based businesses can drive growth and operational efficiencies by taking a holistic approach to Asean operations, fostering skills and talent development, and leveraging the region's infrastructure and tech ecosystem. The business community can support the Asean Economic Community's development by promoting trade facilitation, streamlining regional trade rules, and pushing initiatives that lower barriers to entry. With Singapore's position as the regional gateway and digital innovation hub, the country can continue to drive deeper regional integration, foster trust and regional partnerships, and provide access to growth opportunities for the region's 600 million people.

site_title: Making the elevator pitch
summary: Singaporean fintech companies showcased their innovative solutions at the Abu Dhabi Global Market's fintech event, with Silent Eight and FRS Labs emerging as winners in the Innovation Challenge. Silent Eight utilizes AI to accelerate the anti-money laundering process, while Mesitis provides data standardization and analytics. Pivot brings intelligent investments using AI and machine learning, and Sqreem uses AI to analyze vast amounts of data and predict complex patterns. These companies aim to reduce regulatory burdens and improve compliance costs, while enhancing the efficiency of financial institutions.

site_title: Singapore Fintech Festival
summary: There is no relevant information about the Singapore Fintech Festival in the provided article.

site_title: CapitaLand opens its biggest-ever mall in Suzhou, over 3 times the size of ION Orchard
summary: CapitaLand has opened its largest mall yet, the Suzhou Center Mall, in China, spanning over 300,000 square metres and housing over 600 retail brands. The mall is more than three times the size of ION Orchard in Singapore, marking a record year for CapitaLand with one million square metres of retail space.

site_title: Derivatives' decline - a danger sign?
summary: Global derivatives trading has hit a 10-year low, reaching $13 trillion in the first half of 2017, down from $15 trillion in 2016. This decline is seen as a sign of low market volatility, potentially indicating a correction. Economists and fund managers warn that the low volatility could be a warning sign of an impending market downturn, as the bull market in equities and fixed income securities is eight years old and price-earnings ratios are high.

site_title: Laggards? Not in insurance, says Aon's global analytics chief
summary: Aon's global analytics chief, Paul Mang, disagrees that the insurance industry is lagging behind in innovation and technology, stating that it has been using Big Data for 400 years. He believes the industry is actually ahead of others in using data to predict the future and pool risk. However, Mang acknowledges that the industry needs to improve customer experience and work together in an "open architecture" to tackle big risks like cyber and pandemics. Collaboration between insurers, startups, and universities is necessary to develop new risk assessment models.

site_title: APTT's DPU for Q3 unchanged at 1.625 S cents
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT) reported unchanged distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.625 Singapore cents for Q3, with revenue 6.5% higher at S$84.5 million. In constant Taiwan dollars terms, revenue increased 1.1% from the previous quarter.

site_title: Fincantieri makes another bid to delist Vard; offers S$0.25 per share
summary: Fincantieri, a majority shareholder of Vard Holdings, has made another bid to privatize the shipbuilder by offering S$0.25 per share, a 1 cent increase from its previous offer. The offer, part of a proposed voluntary delisting, aims to fully integrate Vard with Fincantieri's other subsidiaries. Despite a 0.9% discount to the one-month volume-weighted average price, the offer represents a 0.5% premium to the net tangible asset per share. Vard's shareholders will convene to vote on the proposal.

site_title: Making the grade
summary: Singapore is stepping up its efforts to become a top fintech hub by boosting talent in the field through education and training institutions. Memoranda of understanding have been signed with polytechnics and the Monetary Authority of Singapore to develop fintech curricula and internships. Fintech companies such as Fidor have invested in building fintech programs with polytechnics, while universities like NUS and SMU have introduced new specializations and courses in financial technology. The move aims to equip students with the skills needed to succeed in the fintech industry and prepare them for emerging trends in the financial sector.

site_title: Teambuild secures first-mover status in pre-fab building
summary: Teambuild Construction, a Singaporean construction firm, has secured first-mover status in the use of prefabricated pre-finished volumetric construction (PPVC) technology in the country. The company, which started its PPVC journey in 2013, has successfully completed several projects, including the West Terra housing development and Singapore's first concrete PPVC private residential project, The Brownstone executive condominium. Despite initial challenges, including disruptions from visitors and higher costs, Teambuild has persevered and now has a pipeline of four new projects requiring PPVC. The company's efforts have earned it a higher contract sum and government funding support, with the government co-funding up to 70% of the cost difference between conventional and PPVC construction methods.

site_title: Uber board strikes agreement to pave way for SoftBank investment
summary: Uber Technologies Inc's board has reached a deal with former CEO Travis Kalanick and Benchmark, an early investor, to allow a SoftBank investment worth up to $10 billion to proceed. The agreement resolves a legal battle between Benchmark and Kalanick, who had been fighting over the terms of the investment. The Uber board had previously agreed to bring in SoftBank as an investor and board member, paving the way for the multibillion-dollar deal.

site_title: FDI income between US, S'pore down in 2016
summary: Singaporean firms in the US saw their investment incomes fall to US$282 million in 2016, down from US$866 million in 2015, with a rate of return of 1.2%. US MNCs in Singapore also experienced a decline, with investment returns dropping from US$25.05 billion to US$23.15 billion. However, US investments in Singapore remained the highest in the Asia-Pacific region, with a 8.9% rate of return, still outperforming the global average.

site_title: Imagining a cashless Singapore in 2027
summary: In 2027, Singapore has become a cashless society, where digital payments are seamless and convenient. The government's efforts to promote e-payments, facilitated by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, have led to the development of a unified payments platform. Industry players have adapted to the new system, with smart point-of-sale terminals and e-invoices, reducing the reliance on cash and cheques. The country has successfully leapfrogged the challenges faced by emerging markets, becoming a model for cash-light societies in Asia.

site_title: Singapore embraces fintech to stay ahead
summary: Singapore is embracing fintech to stay ahead in the financial services industry. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has seen the potential of technology and innovation in creating jobs and value, and is promoting fintech startups and collaborations between fintechs and financial institutions. The country now boasts 400 fintechs, including unicorn firm TransferWise, and is hosting the world's largest fintech festival. MAS aims to harness technology to improve financial services, including electronic payments, retail payments, and cross-border transactions, while balancing regulation and risk management. The goal is to make Singapore a leading international financial center and to encourage fintech unicorns to emerge from the country.

site_title: Cathay Pacific dropped from Hong Kong's benchmark index
summary: Cathay Pacific, Hong Kong's flag carrier, was removed from the city's Hang Seng Index, effective December 4. The airline, which has been on the index since 1986, faces intense competition from mainland Chinese carriers and budget airlines. Cathay posted its first annual loss since the financial crisis in March, citing reduced demand from business travelers. Its market capitalization has declined by almost half in the past seven years. State-owned Qatar Airways acquired a 9.6% stake in Cathay, calling it "one of the strongest airlines in the world" with "massive potential".

site_title: Fintech investors striking a match
summary: Fintech investors are finding opportunities in the growing market, with funds like GTR Ventures and tryb Capital investing in startups that cater to the global trade ecosystem. GTR Ventures, a Singapore-based venture capital firm, is looking to close deals worth at least US$20 million by year-end, focusing on trade-related fintech that boosts efficiencies and mitigates fraud. tryb Capital, another investor, is targeting established mid-market companies in Asean with cloud-based solutions for digital financial contracts. Meanwhile, InnoVen, a joint venture between UOB and Temasek Holdings, is offering venture debt financing to fintech startups in China, India, and South-east Asia.

site_title: Tackling the question of diversity
summary: Singapore's GovTech CEO Jacqueline Poh emphasized the need to tackle misconceptions about elderly people's ability to adopt new technology, citing examples of seniors using iPads to play mahjong and cloud technology. The country aims to increase digital inclusiveness for seniors. Meanwhile, a trend of men dominating the IT sector is observed in Singapore and Silicon Valley, with Accenture and CA Technologies advocating for a 50-50 gender balance in the workforce. The industry faces challenges of job displacement due to automation, with experts emphasizing the importance of human-centered design and embracing diversity.

site_title: Not a dull moment in week ahead for markets
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.1% for the week, despite concerns over the US tax reform, driven by strong earnings from local companies such as Genting Singapore and Singapore Airlines. Analysts expect the market to be cautious on Monday following Wall Street's eight-week winning streak, but remain optimistic about the upside due to positive earnings and relatively cheap valuation. The week ahead will feature local earnings, data from China and the US, and the US President's Asia tour, which may impact market sentiment.

site_title: In the wake of Weinstein, Bollywood bares its underbelly
summary: India's film industry, the world's largest, has been reluctant to name and shame perpetrators of sexual assault and harassment, despite a wave of similar complaints following the Harvey Weinstein scandal. Three women shared their experiences of being propositioned or harassed by industry professionals, but the industry's patriarchal nature and fear of false allegations have hindered efforts to address the issue. Laws requiring internal committees to investigate workplace harassment are not effectively enforced, and many cases go unreported.

site_title: Buddy up
summary: Singapore's fintech venture capital activity surged in the first half of 2017, with $79.24 million invested in 10 deals, exceeding the total of $68.61 million invested in 2016 over 30 deals. This marks a significant shift from 2015, where large mega deals skewed the numbers. KPMG's head of financial services advisory, Chia Tek Yew, attributes the increase to banks' growing interest in collaboration and fintech companies' desire to enter the market without regulatory hurdles. The Monetary Authority of Singapore encourages this trend, supporting innovation in technologies like cloud computing, blockchain, and AI to drive industry dynamism.

site_title: Forging new ties in fintech partnerships
summary: Singapore has signed more fintech cooperation agreements than any other country, with over 10 partnerships established in the past year, according to Deloitte. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has partnered with countries including the UK, India, and the Middle East, and has established a regulatory sandbox to facilitate fintech innovation. The move aims to create a niche for fintech and innovative technologies in Singapore's financial ecosystem, with a focus on attracting specialist talent and entrepreneurs. This trend is expected to drive the growth of fintech globally.

site_title: Analysts not yet ready to short tech's circuit
summary: Singapore's tech manufacturing sector remains bullish, with contract manufacturers reporting growing order books and strong earnings growth. The sector's diversification beyond mobile phones and personal computers, driven by the Internet of Things (IoT) and automotive innovation, is seen as a key factor. Analysts point to companies like Venture Corp, Hi-P International, and Valuetronics Holdings as top picks, citing their exposure to emerging industries and strong revenue growth. Despite some concerns over a potential slowdown in the semiconductor industry, analysts remain optimistic, citing the sector's broad base and the increasing use of chips in various aspects of daily life.

site_title: EU Brexit chief preparing for 'possible' failure of divorce talks
summary: EU Brexit chief Michel Barnier is preparing for the "possible" failure of divorce talks with Britain, which have been given two weeks to reach a preliminary agreement. Barnier said it's not his preferred option but a possibility that everyone needs to plan for. The EU is making contingency plans, including technical preparations, in case of a failure.

site_title: Insurtech shakes up insurance industry
summary: Traditional insurance companies in Singapore are facing disruption from emerging insurtech startups, which are leveraging technology to improve convenience and efficiency. Insurtech companies are developing apps and programs to simplify the insurance-buying process, allowing customers to manage their policies and make payments through digital platforms. Many insurance firms are investing in new technologies, such as data analytics and artificial intelligence, to boost customer experience and stay relevant in the industry. As a result, insurance companies are open to collaborating with fintech partners and embracing digital innovation to remain competitive.

site_title: UK's May under pressure as 40 MPs signal no confidence in her: report
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May faces a fresh challenge as 40 Conservative MPs agree to sign a letter of no confidence in her, falling short of the 48 needed for a leadership challenge. The move comes amid ongoing issues, including the resignation of two Cabinet ministers and mounting calls for Foreign Minister Boris Johnson's removal. May is under pressure from Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn, who says she should "govern or go," as the UK struggles with Brexit negotiations and economic woes.

site_title: Paris fashion rental offers top labels for as little as 10 euros a day
summary: A new service in Paris allows women to rent luxury handbags and clothes from top brands like Dior, Gucci, and Saint Laurent for as little as 10 euros per day. The Instant Luxe website, founded by Yann Le Floc'h, offers a range of options, including 20 classic handbags styles for a minimum of four nights. The trend is seen as a shift in consumption habits, with many women opting to rent luxury items rather than owning them. Experts describe this as the "Cinderella syndrome," where women can enjoy luxury without the long-term commitment of ownership.

site_title: Singapore as test case for robo-advisory
summary: Singapore is being considered as a test case for implementing robo-advisory services, a form of wealth management that uses automation. The global market for digital advice is expected to reach $500 billion by 2020, with assets under management projected to reach $2.2 trillion. In Singapore, 80% of millennials are interested in robo-advisory, and 60% of Singaporeans are comfortable using a robo-advisor. However, human financial advisors are still widely consulted, and the government has proposed regulatory concessions for digital advisors targeting retail investors.

site_title: DBS lifts data centre onto cloud to cut cost
summary: DBS Bank has partnered with Equinix to move one of its data centers in Singapore to the cloud, reducing its energy consumption and carbon footprint by 75%. The move aims to cut costs and increase energy efficiency. This is part of DBS' ongoing migration to cloud technology, with plans to shift half of its computing workload to the public cloud by next year. The bank's 23,000 employees are also using cloud-based productivity tools.

site_title: Road to fintech
summary: Singapore has established itself as a top fintech hub, with over 400 fintechs setting up shop and at least 20 global financial institutions launching innovation labs. The country's progressive regulations and openness to innovation have driven this growth. The Singapore FinTech Festival, the world's largest fintech event, attracts tens of thousands of delegates worldwide, showcasing top trends like blockchain, payments, and cybersecurity. This growth is part of Singapore's strategy to maintain its position as a leading financial hub in Asia, allowing banks and insurers to partner with startups and drive innovation.

site_title: Responding to anonymous whistleblowers
summary: The identity of whistleblowers should not be the primary reason for deciding whether to investigate a complaint. Whistleblowing is a common channel for exposing corporate irregularities, and many jurisdictions have enacted dedicated whistleblower protection laws. A significant number of whistleblowing reports are anonymous, with over 65% of cases remaining anonymous. To investigate or not, two tests should be applied: whether the allegations are substantive and can be substantiated with the details provided by the whistleblower. If both tests are passed, a further investigation should follow. The company's value in knowing the identity of the complainant is weighed against the need to protect whistleblowers, who often prefer to remain anonymous.

site_title: Trump complains about US trade deficit with Vietnam
summary: US President Donald Trump visited Hanoi, Vietnam, where he signed several energy and aviation deals worth billions of dollars. Trump complained about the US trade deficit with Vietnam, worth $32 billion in 2016, and emphasized the need to boost American exports and protect domestic companies. The deals signed include agreements with Vietnam Airlines, VietJet, and American energy firms, aiming to strengthen economic and trade ties between the two countries.

site_title: Diving deep into S'pore's fintech ecosystem
summary: The second Global FinTech Hackcelerator is underway at the Singapore FinTech Festival, engaging 20 mature fintech teams from around the world. The program, organized by KPMG, aims to help the top three winning startups commercialize their solutions with industry champions and business sponsors. This year, 580 startups applied, with Singapore-based companies making up 28% of the total applications. Last year's winners, Aida Technologies and insurtech firm FitSense, have seen significant success, with Aida raising $1 million and FitSense securing a strategic investor. The program focuses on customer-facing, financial inclusion, and regtech solutions, with a 12-week program and themed sessions to guide the finalists.

site_title: Trump lands in the Philippines, offers to mediate on South China Sea
summary: US President Donald Trump arrived in the Philippines for a summit of South-east and East Asian nations, hours after offering to mediate on competing claims to the South China Sea. Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte, however, said the issue should be left untouched to avoid conflict. Trump's visit aims to shore up relations strained by Mr Duterte's anti-US sentiment and enthusiasm for ties with Russia and China. The summit will focus on procedural steps to cool tensions in the South China Sea, rather than resolving the dispute.

site_title: MAS, R3 test blockchain in payments
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has successfully tested a blockchain-based payment system, Project Ubin, in collaboration with R3 and 11 major financial institutions. The system uses distributed ledger technology (DLT) to facilitate inter-bank transactions, eliminating the need for intermediaries. The test, which ran from November 2016 to December 2016, assessed the feasibility of DLT for central bank currency and digital currencies. The results showed that the system can disintermediate traditional payment processes, reduce transaction times, and minimize costs. The MAS plans to build on the success of Project Ubin, exploring further applications of DLT in the future.

site_title: Visa wants to lead S'pore to go cashless
summary: Visa Singapore aims to lead the country towards a cashless society, with 30% of transactions still done in cash, particularly at hawker centers and among small merchants. The country's head of Visa, Ooi Huey Tyng, notes that Singapore's efficiency and safety don't motivate people to adopt cashless payments. To overcome this, Visa proposes charging for cheques, which take days to clear, and increasing interoperability among digital payment options. Visa also aims to simplify the on-boarding process for merchants and promote a seamless consumer experience, with a focus on low-cost models and incremental fees for smaller merchants.

site_title: STI edges above 3,400; Wee Cho Yaw increases his stake in UIC
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1.3% over five trading sessions, reaching levels last seen in May 2015, and reached 3,400 for the first time in over two years. The dividend-inclusive return for 2017 was 22.5%, surpassing the benchmarks of Japan, Hong Kong, and Australia. Notable changes in director interests and substantial shareholder holdings include Wee Cho Yaw increasing his stake in United Industrial Corporation (UIC) to 49.76% after acquiring 110,000 shares. Other notable changes include Liaw Hin Hao increasing his stake in Jadason Enterprises to 5.24% and Aberdeen Asset Management Asia Limited increasing its holdings in Raffles Medical Group to 6.01%.

site_title: Mastercard aims to boost digital trust
summary: Mastercard aims to boost digital trust in Singapore, a key area of concern as the country lags behind in e-payments due to security concerns. The company is rolling out its biometrics-based authentication service, Mastercard Identity Check Mobile, to enhance security and convenience. Mastercard is also partnering with the Land Transport Authority to implement a cashless ticketing system and expanding its Masterpass digital payment solution. The company's goal is to build a holistic digital payments ecosystem, foster public-private partnerships, and drive Singapore towards becoming a cashless society.

site_title: Alibaba Singles' Day posts record 168b yuan in sales
summary: Alibaba's Singles' Day generated a record 168.2 billion yuan (S$34.5 billion) in sales, exceeding Citigroup estimates and defying economic slowdown concerns. The annual event saw a 39% increase in sales, with 82 brands reaching 100 million yuan in sales, including Nike and Xiaomi. The event helped Alibaba connect traditional retailers with the internet, with 90% of transactions done via mobile. The company aims to make Singles' Day a more global event, with plans to host a gala overseas soon.

site_title: MUFG ups the ante on blockchain
summary: Japan's largest bank, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG), is investing in blockchain technology to improve customer service and reduce costs. The bank aims to tap into the estimated 50 trillion yen market in blockchain-enabled services in Japan, with a focus on practical applications such as cross-border payments and settlements. MUFG has raised the bar in developing a digital coin and is partnering with other banks and startups, including Ripple and Ethereum, to develop blockchain-based solutions. The bank expects its digital innovation efforts to reduce costs, with a goal of cutting 120 billion yen by 2023.

images.alt_text: "At MUFG, we recognise the potential of technologies like blockchain, AI and robotics, and are fully focused on harnessing them for our strategic business efforts." - Hirofumi Aihara, general manager of MUFG's digital transformation division.

site_title: Bond traders brace for inflation data that could rattle Fed
summary: Bond traders are bracing for the release of October inflation data, which could influence the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates. The Labor Department's report is expected to show steady price growth, with the core measure likely holding at 1.7% since April. Officials may raise interest rates again, with a December hike considered a foregone conclusion. A weak inflation print could re-steepen US yield curves, but a strong print may not deter a rate hike.

images.alt_text: The core measure that strips out energy and food prices has remained stubbornly below 2 per cent since April and October data has "game-changing potential".

site_title: Asean signs free trade, investment pacts with HK
summary: Asean and Hong Kong signed two free trade and investment pacts, aimed at enhancing trade and investment flows between the two regions. The agreements, signed in 2017, will give better access to each other's markets, create new business opportunities, and bring about more job opportunities for the region's people and businesses. Negotiations began in 2013, and the pacts are likely to be ratified in two years. The agreements are seen as a signal of commitment to free trade, particularly in the face of protectionist sentiments worldwide.

site_title: Correction highly likely as Topix nears 1,823 resistance level
summary: The Japanese equity market is nearing the 1,823 resistance level of the Topix index, a critical area that has historically been a stumbling block for bulls. The index has surged to a new 52-week high, with the Nikkei 225 leading the way, and is now in an overbought condition according to the Relative Strength Index (RSI). A correction is highly likely, with a possible drawdown of up to -20%, similar to the 2007-2008 Global Financial Crisis (GFC) where the Topix fell -61% from its peak.

site_title: Prudential taps AI for claims assessment
summary: Prudential Singapore is launching a trial to assess claims using machine learning, aiming to process 14,000 paper bills and receipts in just seconds. The system, which has been trained on claims data from the last two years, uses text-mining engines and machine-learning engines to identify payable and non-payable items, and recommend outcomes and payment amounts. Initial claims assessors will review the machine's recommendations, with the goal of shortening processing time from seven days to mere seconds by mid-2018.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for November 12, 2017, reveals steady rates for tankers and dry bulk cargo, with some fluctuations. Middle East Gulf rates for VLCCs remained steady in the low $70s, while US Gulf rates for 280,000-tonne cargo were fixed at $28.5 per cape/cape basis. Suezmax rates eased six points to $83.25 for 130,000 tonnes to Europe, while Aframax rates for 80,000 tonnes dropped 40 points to $90. Panamax rates held steady at $115 for 55,000 tonnes from ARA to US Gulf.

site_title: Singapore as Prudential's global launchpad for insurtech tie-ups
summary: Prudential Singapore has launched its first global fintech partnership programme, PRU Fintegrate, to partner with global fintech startups and co-develop digital solutions for customers. The programme, part of the Singapore FinTech Festival 2017, aims to bridge the protection gap and simplify insurance purchase and claims processes. Six finalists have been selected, and Prudential will collaborate with startups that offer commercially viable solutions, providing guidance and integrating them into the business through its API platform. The programme is seen as a key pillar of Prudential's digital roadmap to deliver better customer experiences.

site_title: South Korea leader to visit China for summit in December
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in plans to visit China in December for a summit, focusing on North Korea's nuclear program. The visit comes amid improved relations between Seoul and Beijing, following a resolution on the deployment of a US missile shield on South Korean soil. Japan's Prime Minister Abe proposed a meeting with Chinese President Xi but received no invitation, highlighting tensions between Tokyo and Beijing over their wartime history and territorial disputes. The summit will likely top the agenda with both leaders urging caution and dialogue on North Korea's nuclear ambitions.

site_title: Aon's analytics centre in Singapore to expand staff by 40% in next five years
summary: Aon's analytics centre in Singapore plans to expand staff by 40% over the next five years, with most new hires coming from Singapore. The centre, which has grown from five to 110 staff, aims to deepen expertise in blockchain, machine learning, and other areas. The expansion is part of Aon's US$400 million annual investment in data analytics, which contributed US$285 million to the company's revenue in 2017. The centre is working with universities to train talent and enable companies to adopt new business models with more confidence.

site_title: UnionPay expands beyond China
summary: UnionPay International, the world's largest bank card group, plans to launch an open-platform wallet function in global markets to help partners outside of China build their wallet applications. The one-stop mobile wallet aims to facilitate easy payments for daily services like shopping, utilities, and transport. This move follows UnionPay's global expansion, with Chinese clients venturing into overseas markets. The new wallet function is expected to support UnionPay's push into global markets, expanding its services beyond China.

site_title: A developer's tale of two cities
summary: Far East Consortium International executive director Dennis Chiu has over 30 years of experience in the Singapore and Hong Kong property markets. Chiu, a naturalized Singaporean, notes that the Singapore government's involvement in the property market and strict anti-speculation measures make it difficult for developers to achieve scale and survive downturns. Unlike Hong Kong, where the government has less intervention, Singapore's dominant Housing & Development Board and stringent cooling measures, such as Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty, deter foreign investors and limit private developers' growth.

images.alt_text: Mr Chiu says Singapore's property cooling measures make the operating environment "very challenging" for developers in terms of riding the ups and downs of the property cycle.

site_title: Controversial Da Vinci is New York auction season star
summary: Leonardo da Vinci's "Salvator Mundi" painting, worth $127.5 million, is set to be auctioned off at Christie's in New York, with a valuation of $100 million. The painting, dated circa 1500, is one of fewer than 20 known works by Da Vinci's hand. Russian billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev, who bought the painting for $127.5 million, is suing Swiss art dealer Yves Bouvier over the alleged swindle. The sale is expected to generate over $1 billion in combined art sales, with other notable lots including Fernand Leger's "Contraste de formes" and Van Gogh's "Laboureur dans un champ."

site_title: The man versus the machine
summary: Four Nobel laureates, Roger Myerson, Michael Spence, Robert Merton, and Peter Diamond, discuss the impact of technology on the workforce. They believe that humans will adapt to technological changes, and machines will be designed to work with humans, leading to increased productivity. The experts acknowledge that some jobs may become obsolete, but they argue that social safety nets and public education programs can mitigate the effects. They also emphasize the need to redesign pension systems to accommodate changing demographics. While debating universal basic income, they agree that experimentation and a data-driven approach are key to finding effective solutions.

site_title: Ghana's maritime boundary victory to spark oil bounty
summary: Ghana has secured a key court victory over Ivory Coast at the International Tribunal on the Law of the Sea, paving the way for billions of dollars in extra revenue from offshore oil exploration and extraction. The ruling, the result of a long and arduous journey, will fuel Ghana's efforts to boost its oil industry. As a result, the country can now tap into the vast oil reserves located in its exclusive economic zone, expected to generate significant revenue.

images.alt_text: Mr Akufo-Addo: The tribunal ruling opens up "possibilities of development, progress and prosperity".

site_title: Alibaba Singles' Day sales hit US$8.6b in first hour
summary: Alibaba's Singles' Day shopping event saw record-breaking sales of $8.6 billion in the first hour, with over 256,000 transactions per second. The event, which took place in 192 countries and regions, was attended by 93% mobile transactions. Analysts predict a 31% rise in transactions, dwarfing other events like Black Friday and Cyber Monday. Alibaba is using the event to test its plans to revamp China's traditional retail sector with technology, and to expand its cloud computing, delivery, and payments units.

site_title: Crisis-stricken GE braces itself for more belt-tightening
summary: General Electric (GE) is preparing to sell major business segments and lay off thousands of employees amid a financial crisis. The company's market capitalization has dropped over $100 billion since January, and it has only $7 billion in cash flow. CEO John Flannery has vowed to cut costs and restructure, citing a "crisis of investor confidence." The belt-tightening measures include significant layoffs, closing research and development centers, and selling off businesses such as transportation and medical IT segments, with the goal of shedding $20 billion in assets over the next two years.

site_title: Debt collection is thriving - thanks to professionals
summary: Debt collection in Singapore is thriving, with credit and debt-collecting firm Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau (SCCB) recording a six-year high in debt collection in 2016. Companies are outsourcing debt collection to professionals, who use data and profiling to pressure debtors into paying. Blacklisting is a particularly effective tool, as it can damage a company's reputation and deter future business. Payment performance has declined over the past five years, with companies outsourcing debt collection early to avoid costly and time-consuming in-house collections.

site_title: Abe meets Taiwan politician hours after Xi's warning
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe met with Taiwanese politician James Soong on Sunday, hours after Chinese President Xi Jinping warned him not to break with past consensus on Taiwan. The meeting, held on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit, risked criticism from China. Abe emphasized Taiwan's importance as a partner with shared values and close economic ties, while maintaining the unofficial nature of the relationship. The meeting follows recent diplomatic efforts, including a cultural exchange meeting in Taiwan and a name change for Japan's mission in Taipei.

site_title: Colossal SoftBank fund could shake up tech world
summary: Japan-based SoftBank is launching a $100 billion venture capital fund, the Vision Fund, which is expected to significantly impact the tech industry. The fund's massive investment of nearly $10 billion in ride-sharing giant Uber could accelerate the trend of fast-growing startups remaining private, potentially overinflating the market. SoftBank's CEO Masayoshi Son has a strategic approach, focusing on late-stage investments and mergers to bring together startups with the potential to benefit each other, with the goal of driving innovation and efficiency.

site_title: Creating a marquee platform for global fintech community
summary: Singapore FinTech Festival 2017, the world's largest fintech event, took place in November 2017, featuring over 300 exhibitors and 10 theme-based zones. The festival, organized by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and SingEx, aimed to foster collaboration and innovation in the fintech industry. With a focus on personalization and engagement, the event offered a unique delegate experience, including a hybrid of commerce, creativity, education, and entertainment content. The festival also featured a FinTech Awards ceremony and a week-long celebration of Singapore's fintech community.

site_title: Boeing finds solace in Trump tweets amid Saudi corruption purge
summary: Boeing has expressed confidence in its ability to win business in Saudi Arabia despite a government-orchestrated corruption purge. The company is benefiting from improved US-Saudi relations, with President Donald Trump's support, particularly his tweets on the arrests. Boeing is preparing to capitalize on Saudi Arabia's "Vision 2030" plan to modernize its economy, which aims to increase pilgrim travel to 30 million. The company is pitching its 737 Max jets to Saudi's biggest carrier and has received requests for 30 narrow-body aircraft from a new Saudia offshoot.

site_title: Japan's green incentives chop down palm trees in search for fuel
summary: Japan's government incentives for renewable energy have led to a surge in biomass projects, including those that burn palm oil, a cheap and reliable fuel source. Despite environmental concerns over deforestation and peatland destruction, palm oil is being used due to its low construction costs and land requirements. However, the environmental impact of palm oil production is complex, with some studies suggesting emissions are twice as high as coal when accounting for land-use changes. The government aims for biomass to provide 4.6% of Japan's power by 2030, with palm oil projects expected to play a significant role.

site_title: A stronger lift for financial inclusion
summary: The Asian Development Bank reports that digital finance can accelerate access to financial services in South-east Asia, citing it as a game-changing enabler. This comes as the second Singapore FinTech Festival highlights the potential of fintech to tackle the unbanked issue in the region. Regulators, policymakers, and industry participants must address structural issues to facilitate growth in financial services for the unbanked.

images.alt_text: From left: Onelyst co-founder Hizam Ismail, chief technology officer Prakash Raja, and co-founder Mohamed Abbas. Onelyst has created Rely, which offers short-term loans to blue-collar workers who need to buy gadgets.

site_title: Q&M third-quarter profit up 28% to S$3.6m
summary: Q&M Dental Group reported a 28% increase in third-quarter net profit to S$3.6 million, driven by a 5% decline in revenue from dental and medical clinics due to the deconsolidation of its China dental business Aoxin. Excluding Aoxin, revenue was up 8% year-on-year. The company's shares last traded at S$0.65.

site_title: UOB offers alternative funds for fintechs
summary: UOB has introduced alternative funds for fintech startups, providing them with access to funding options such as equity crowdfunding and venture debt. This move aims to support the growth of these startups, which often face challenges in raising money through conventional methods. The bank offers startups professional advice and strategic collaborations to help them scale up their businesses. UOB's initiatives include partnerships with OurCrowd and Temasek's InnoVen, which provide equity crowdfunding and venture debt financing to startups in Asia.

site_title: Experimenting in innovation labs
summary: More than 20 banks and insurers in Singapore have set up innovation labs to test ideas and collaborate with partners and staff, aiming to reinvent the financial industry with technology. The labs, such as Standard Chartered's SCB eXellerator and MUFG's innovation centre, are driving fintech projects globally, including blockchain technology and digital payments. Collaboration with fintech organizations and startups is also underway, with companies like PayPal and Mastercard establishing innovation labs in Singapore. The goal is to simplify and digitize financial processes with a "human touch," while driving innovation and talent development in the fintech space.

site_title: Keeping digital security under lock and V-Key
summary: Fintech has transformed global payments with digital wallets and e-payments, making transactions faster and more convenient. Banks and fintech companies collaborate to innovate and provide better customer experiences. However, cybercrime threats surge, highlighting the need for robust security solutions. V-Key, a fintech company, has developed a virtual secure element to provide secure cryptographic storage and processing of user credentials and transactions, making it easier and safer for customers to bank on their mobile devices. Banks must partner with companies like V-Key to make the most of the fintech revolution and trust the systems that provide them.

site_title: China faces historic corruption battle, ruling party's new graft buster says
summary: China's new anti-corruption leader, Zhao Leji, warns that failure to eradicate corruption will lead to the ruling Communist Party's downfall and erasure from history. In an editorial, Zhao emphasizes the party's responsibility to maintain control and strict governance. He stresses that China's historic task of building a prosperous nation cannot be fulfilled if corruption prevails. Zhao's statement underscores the ruling party's focus on eliminating corrupt behavior, highlighting the significance of winning the battle against corruption to ensure the party's survival.

site_title: Bull market likely to get back on track this week
summary: The US stock market is likely to rebound this week, as long as the Republican tax cut plan and retail earnings meet expectations. Despite recent setbacks, including state elections and a sexual-abuse scandal involving Republican candidate Roy Moore, the "Trump bump" in the stock market has largely held up. The S&P 500 Index has gained 21% in the past year, and economists expect tax cuts to boost economic growth, with GDP growth rebounding to around 3%. However, some analysts warn that slowing job growth and consumer confidence may impact the market in the coming year.

site_title: TPP trade deal advances without United States
summary: Countries in the Trans Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal have agreed on core elements to move forward without the United States, overcoming last-minute resistance from Canada. The agreement, now called the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), will be finalized and take effect after ratification by six of the 11 member nations. The deal aims to eliminate tariffs on industrial and farm products across the 11-nation bloc, with Japan lobbying to bring back the US. Canada's participation has been complicated by its simultaneous renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

site_title: Saudi Arabia boosts oil security as Iran denies pipeline attack
summary: Saudi Arabia is increasing security measures at its oil facilities following a fire at a pipeline connecting Saudi Arabia and Bahrain, blamed on Iran by Bahrain's Interior Ministry. Iran denied involvement. The security boost was reported by Saudi's energy ministry, citing Al-Arabiya television. The incident is part of recent reports of terrorist activities in Bahrain directed by Iran, which has been a longstanding regional rival to Saudi Arabia.

site_title: 230 units of Sengkang's Parc Botannia sold during weekend launch
summary: 230 units of Sengkang's Parc Botannia condominium project were sold over the weekend, with an average selling price of S$1,270 per square foot. The buyers were mostly locals, and popular units included one-bedroom, two-bedroom, and four-bedroom units. The project, developed by a 70:30 joint venture between Sing Holdings and Wee Hur, is expected to be completed by end-2021.

site_title: Mencast sinks deeper into red with S$7.1m loss in Q3
summary: Mencast Holdings, a marine and oil and gas industry services provider, reported a net loss of S$7.1 million in the third quarter ended September 30, 2017, down from a loss of S$2.8 million in the same period last year. Revenue declined 17% to S$12.7 million, attributed to a challenging business environment in the oil and gas industry. The company cited continued weakness in the outlook and business conditions as the cause of the decline.

site_title: Finally, you can have Breakfast at Tiffany's
summary: Tiffany & Co. has opened the Blue Box Café at its flagship store, 56 years after the iconic scene from "Breakfast at Tiffany's" was filmed. The café, located on the fourth floor, offers a seasonal menu with options such as a croissant and coffee, buttermilk waffle, and smoked salmon, priced between $29 and $49. The café aims to provide a luxurious experience, with a nod to the brand's classic robin-egg blue motif and a view of Central Park. This move follows Tiffany's recent focus on cultivating experiences for shoppers, as traditional retailers face challenges from online competitors.

images.alt_text: Cultivating experiences for shoppers, the Fifth Avenue cafe is accentuated by heavy usage of the company's classic robin-egg blue motif on everything from the walls to the plates.

site_title: Apec ministers publish joint statement after wrangling over language
summary: APEC ministers released a joint statement three days late due to disagreements over language, with the US pushing for changes to emphasize "fair trade" and "America First" policy. The statement still refers to free and open trade and adherence to WTO rules, but with added emphasis on fair trade. US President Donald Trump has been vocal about his "America First" stance, which differs from predecessors' approaches to trade. The delay is similar to previous G-20 meetings where the Trump administration demanded changes to traditional language.

site_title: Getting Prudential ready for the future
summary: Prudential Singapore is undergoing significant transformations under new Chief Wilfred Blackburn to meet customer needs in the future. The company is investing in technology, including robotic process automation and a chatbot, to improve efficiency and productivity. A new online community portal, PRU For You, allows customers to provide feedback and ideas. The insurer is also shifting its mindset and culture by rewarding employees for leadership and innovation, and introducing flexible work arrangements and sponsored education. The goal is to create a collaborative environment where employees can work together to drive creative solutions.

site_title: Lee Metal inks MOU on potential offer; shares hit 3-year high before announcement
summary: Lee Metal Group, a steelmaker, has entered into a binding MOU with an unrelated third party. The company's shares reached a 3-year high before the announcement, closing at S$0.385, up 5.5% from the previous day. Certain shareholders had received an unsolicited approach on a potential transaction, which "may or may not lead to an acquisition of the company's issued share capital." The MOU has no obligation to consummate the proposed transaction.

site_title: PayNow extends to businesses from 2018
summary: Singapore's PayNow peer-to-peer fund-transfer service is expected to be extended to businesses in 2018, aiming to increase efficiency in the city-state's cashless services. Since July 2017, seven major retail banks have offered the service, allowing customers to send and receive Sing-dollar funds using mobile numbers. Businesses will be able to link their unique entity numbers to their bank accounts to receive payments via PayNow, further promoting cashless transactions in Singapore.

site_title: Australian MP resigns over dual nationality in new blow for government
summary: Australian MP John Alexander has resigned due to concerns over his dual nationality, leaving Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's government clinging to power. The government faces a no-confidence motion, but Turnbull claims to have the support of two independents. A by-election on December 16 is expected to return Barnaby Joyce to parliament, bolstering the government. Alexander's resignation is the latest blow to the government, following a High Court ruling that five MPs were ineligible to be lawmakers due to dual nationality. The government must rely on independents to block opposition legislation.

site_title: Britain's Prince Charles steps up as Queen steps back
summary: Prince Charles will step up as Queen Elizabeth II gradually scales back her duties, a rare public symbol of the 91-year-old monarch's transition. On Remembrance Sunday, Charles will lay the queen's wreath, a milestone in the slow-motion process. Experts say the queen will never consider abdication or regency, but Charles will take on more duties outside core constitutional obligations. The ceremony marks the start of the queen's gradual reduction in public roles, with her husband Prince Philip also stepping back from public duties.

site_title: OCBC's tech team evolves into division dealing with banking's future
summary: OCBC Bank's technology division, which started as a side project five years ago, has evolved into a key growth driver for the lender. The division now deals with big questions about the future of banking, including what a bank of the future looks like. As the division continues to grow, it is poised to play a significant role in shaping the future of banking in Singapore.

site_title: Bitcoin Jesus praises new coin as US$7m wager falls through
summary: Bitcoin Jesus, Roger Ver, remains bullish on Bitcoin after a $7 million wager with other cryptocurrency evangelists fell through due to the cancellation of a hard fork upgrade. Bitcoin Cash, a rival coin, has more than doubled in value since the upgrade was called off, thanks to its larger block size. Ver now plans to use the 1,000 Bitcoins he wagered to buy more Bitcoin Cash, citing its potential to speed up transactions and reduce fees. Ver believes "the real bitcoin" is Bitcoin Cash, which he sees as a more scalable alternative to Bitcoin.

site_title: Boeing 747s and bottled flatulence: 5 Chinese e-bargains on Singles Day
summary: On China's Singles Day, online shoppers snapped up unusual items, including a Boeing 747 cargo plane for 123 million yuan, and products like a glass bottle of supposedly human gas, cabinda bark extract, and eyebrow stamps. Other bizarre items included latex masks of world leaders and a powder for shaping eyebrows. These unique bargains were available on Taobao.com, the main platform of Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba, with some items selling for as low as 20 yuan.

site_title: EU states to sign joint defence pact
summary: More than 20 EU states are set to sign a landmark joint defence pact, known as the permanent structured cooperation on defence (Pesco), on Monday. The agreement aims to deepen defence cooperation and improve coordination in the development of new military technology. The pact includes commitments to increase defence budgets, devote 20% of spending to procurement and 2% to research and technology. This is part of efforts to reboot the EU's defence capabilities following Brexit and as Russia flexes its muscles to the east. The agreement will be officially launched in December.

site_title: US toymaker Hasbro makes new approach to buy Mattel
summary: Hasbro Inc has made an approach to acquire rival Mattel Inc, a move that could create a toy powerhouse uniting the two companies' brands. A deal would give Hasbro more pricing power to negotiate with entertainment studios and unite popular brands like Barbie and Nerf. Mattel's stance on the offer is unclear, and a deal remains uncertain. The news sent Mattel's shares soaring 24% in after-hours trading, while Hasbro's shares rose 3.3%.

site_title: Fox's Rupert Murdoch said to have called AT&T's CEO about CNN
summary: Rupert Murdoch, executive chairman of 21st Century Fox, made two calls to AT&T's CEO Randall Stephenson to discuss CNN, according to people familiar with the situation. Fox had no interest in buying CNN, and Stephenson reiterated that he wasn't interested in selling the network. The talks come amid criticism of CNN by President Donald Trump, who is reviewing the acquisition of Time Warner. AT&T met with the Justice Department's antitrust chief and discussed the potential sale of CNN, but Stephenson said such a move would be counter to his plans.

site_title: Tennis: Federer, Nadal urge caution over rule changes
summary: Tennis stars Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal expressed caution over rule changes in the sport. Federer warned against making too many changes, citing the benefits of the current format, while Nadal, who is bidding to win the ATP Finals, said he is open to innovation but doesn't want drastic changes. The rule changes being trialled include shorter sets and a 25-second shot clock, aimed at creating a high-tempo, TV-friendly product to attract new fans. Both players emphasized the importance of preserving tradition in tennis.

site_title: Investment veterans launch real estate and hospitality buyout vehicle
summary: Investment veterans Noam Gottesman and Mike Fascitelli are behind Landscape Acquisition Holdings Limited, a US$500 million special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) focused on real estate and hospitality deals in North America and Europe. Gottesman, former chairman of fund manager Man GLG, and Fascitelli, former president of Vornado Realty Trust, have raised US$40 million for the IPO, which will list on the London Stock Exchange on November 15. The SPAC has two years to make an investment, with an option for a one-year extension, and will return money to investors if no deal is made.

site_title: Gold falls on bond yields, US tax doubts limit losses
summary: Gold prices fell 0.7% on Friday due to rising US Treasury bond yields, but losses were limited by weaker stock markets and a declining US dollar. The US dollar fell as investors became uncertain about the timing of US tax reform, which could impact gold prices. Despite this, gold was still on track for a 0.5% weekly rise.

site_title: Taylor Swift's 'Reputation' debuts to strong sales, mixed reviews
summary: Taylor Swift's album "Reputation" debuted at number one on the iTunes charts with strong sales, but received mixed reviews from critics. The 15-track album marks a tougher image for Swift, with songs hinting at her ex-boyfriends Calvin Harris and Tom Hiddleston, as well as her current boyfriend Joe Alwyn. The album's mix of hip-hop and pop projects a more vindictive tone, with some critics praising its "sneakily potent" sound, while others call it "oddly bifurcated."

site_title: Thousands protest austerity measures in Brazil
summary: Thousands of Brazilians demonstrated nationwide against government austerity measures, including a labor law and pension reform project, on November 10, 2017. The protests, which also targeted privatisation, were part of a day of national mobilisation. Demonstrators, including teachers and workers, expressed concerns over the measures' impact on social gains and democracy. The measures aim to address a huge budget deficit and revive the recession-hit economy.

site_title: Oil prices slide after US drillers add rigs
summary: US oil drillers added 9 rigs this week, bringing the total to 738, despite expectations of Opec extending production cuts. Crude prices slid 43 cents to $56.74 per barrel, with Brent futures falling 41 cents to $63.52. Analysts expect Opec to extend cuts, but warn of rising US shale production. Tensions in the Middle East, including Saudi Arabia's relations with Lebanon, also support prices. Strong demand in South-east Asia and rising tensions in the region are contributing to price volatility.

site_title: 'Fair amount' of structural reform needed to achieve inclusive growth: SBF
summary: Business leaders from Singapore and the Pacific Rim met with Apec leaders to discuss inclusive growth and structural reform. The Singapore Business Federation presented a 66-page report recommending structural reform to achieve regional economic integration and prosperity. The report emphasized the importance of effective reform to counter domestic discontent and economic challenges, urging Apec leaders to press ahead towards a shared vision of inclusive growth. Effective structural reform is seen as key to achieving regional economic integration.

site_title: IMF urges Argentina to step up pace of economic reforms
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged Argentina to accelerate its economic reforms, citing significant gains made by President Mauricio Macri's government in transforming the economy. The IMF forecasts Argentina's growth to recover to 2.75% this year and 2.5% in 2018, despite remaining risks, including stubbornly high inflation and increased foreign borrowing. The IMF recommends accelerating reforms to reduce vulnerabilities and create quality jobs, with a focus on trade, investment, and financial inclusion.

site_title: EU, South American bloc reported close to free trade accord
summary: The European Union and the South American economic bloc Mercosur are close to concluding a free trade accord after nearly two decades of talks. EU Vice-President Jyrki Katainen said the two sides are "that close" to having a new agreement, while Brazilian President Michel Temer emphasized the importance of building bridges in contrast to President Trump's wall. Key issues to be settled include Mercosur exports of beef and ethanol, government procurement, and intellectual property rights. A ministerial-level meeting of the World Trade Organization in Buenos Aires is set to announce the agreement next month.

site_title: European shares suffer worst week since August as earnings growth slows
summary: European shares suffered their worst week in three months, falling 1.9% on Friday, as a slowdown in earnings growth and jitters in bond markets led to profit-taking. The Stoxx 600 index remains up 7.5% for the year, but Leonardo's 21.6% decline after cutting its guidance and Elekta's 10.1% drop after announcing a delay of a key product were the biggest losers. Analysts attribute the correction to a strong economic backdrop and the potential for higher bond market volatility.

site_title: Double Duty
summary: A recent article from November 10, 2017, discusses incorporating workwear staples into weekend ensembles, suggesting alternatives to traditional weekday attire such as a casual silk shirt and corporate blazer. No other key information is presented in the provided article.

site_title: Music matters
summary: The Esplanade's Mosaic Series is returning with a year-end edition, dubbed The Art of Song, featuring Norwegian composer-singer Bernhoft on Nov 11, Danish jazz diva Sinne Eeg on Nov 12, Japanese experimental pop darling Shugo Tokumaru on Nov 13, and four-time Grammy-nominee Feist on Nov 14. The event runs until Nov 14.

site_title: UN chief says US$100b climate fund far from guaranteed
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres stated that a $100 billion annual fund to support developing countries in tackling climate change is crucial for achieving the Paris climate deal goals. However, he emphasized that this amount is not entirely guaranteed, and more action is needed to mobilize the funds.

site_title: Sembmarine to land US$490m contract with Statoil
summary: Sembmarine, a Singapore-based shipyard, has secured a US$490 million contract with Statoil for the engineering, procurement, and construction of a newbuild FPSO hull and living quarters for the Johan Castberg field development off Norway. The contract is the company's largest announced win this year, and the project is expected to be completed by Christmas. This win follows recent positive financial results, with Sembmarine posting a net gain of S$2.72 million, reversing a loss from the previous year.

site_title: STI slips 0.1% on Friday, but ends week more than 1% higher
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week 0.1% lower, closing at 3,420.1, after a five-session gain of 1.3% from Nov 3-9. The index reached a 10-year high of 3,429.21 on Nov 9, surpassing its May 2015 level. Year-to-date, the STI is up nearly 19%. Despite a Wall Street correction on Thursday, the STI remained in positive territory, with a week-on-week gain of nearly 38 points or 1.1%.

site_title: On her own time
summary: Singer-songwriter Anggun, a mother and United Nations Goodwill Ambassador, shares her time management strategies, prioritizing spending time with her daughter and embracing the preciousness of time. The World Music Award winner and Asia's Got Talent judge is now working on her upcoming album, themed around her life experiences, which she hopes will be meaningful and not just fill a sonic space. Anggun is also a fan of luxury watch brand Audemars Piguet, owning a Millenary watch and appreciating its craftsmanship and beauty.

site_title: Fine dining blues
summary: Fine dining in Singapore has become increasingly expensive, with the city ranking second only to Hong Kong in terms of cost. A tasting menu at two-starred restaurants in Hong Kong costs around S$300, while similar options in Singapore range from S$195 to S$340. This has led restaurateurs to raise prices, citing high labor costs, ingredient prices, and rental expenses. Despite this, some chefs argue that fine dining is not going away due to rising affluence, and that there will always be a demand for high-end restaurants. However, experts warn that the high costs may deter talented chefs from entering the industry and may lead to a decline in the quality of fine dining in Singapore.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance's Q3 net leaps 84% on lower interest expense
summary: Hong Leong Finance's Q3 net profit surged 84% to S$23.6 million due to lower interest expense. Annualized earnings per share rose to 21.19 cents from 11.52 cents. Net interest income/hiring charges gained 48%, while provisions for bad debt surged to S$2.8 million. Staff costs rose 2% and other operating expenses fell 8.8%. The company plans to closely manage liquidity management and deposit-taking activity amid higher interest rates.

site_title: Baking star
summary: Heather Soto, a pastry specialist-turned-Michelin inspector, will conduct two baking masterclasses in town on Nov 18. The 4-hour session, priced at $230, includes a tutorial on selecting ingredients, dessert styling, and a mystery box challenge. Participants will receive $150 worth of free desserts and ingredients, and their creations will be critiqued by Soto. The masterclass is a tie-up with local baking start-up Homebakee.

site_title: Cars put the brakes on retail sales
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 0.5% year-on-year in September, the first drop in six months, due to poor motor vehicle sales. However, excluding cars, retail sales grew 3.3% year-on-year. Motor vehicle sales fell 15.3% year-on-year, the largest decline among categories. The decline was expected, given a drop in COE prices and vehicle registrations.

site_title: Bond investors suffering hangover from high-grade debt binge
summary: Bond investors are facing a "hangover" from high-grade debt binge, with over $24 billion of bonds priced this week. Companies, including tech giants like Apple and Oracle, are issuing debt to take advantage of cheap financing before potential changes in tax laws. The market has pushed spreads to a one-month high, making it difficult for investors to absorb new supply. Analysts say the drivers of demand haven't changed, but the tax-driven boost in supply is weighing on the market, with some predicting a temporary supply glut.

site_title: Marc Ong ready to go pro
summary: Singaporean amateur golfer Marc Ong plans to turn professional early next year, after competing in several events. The 22-year-old golfer is aware of the risks involved, having heard stories of others who took the pro route too early. Ong aims to gain experience and build his skills before making the transition, a common approach for top amateurs.

site_title: US: Doubts about Trump tax cuts weigh on Wall Street
summary: US stocks ended the week lower for the first time in nine weeks, with losses in Intel and Apple, amid concerns over the future of promised corporate tax cuts. Republican lawmakers unveiled dueling tax plans, differing on key fronts, including delaying corporate tax cuts for a year. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average fell, weighing on Wall Street.

site_title: MindChamps eyes mainboard listing to fund growth
summary: MindChamps, Singapore's largest premium pre-school operator, has lodged a preliminary prospectus for a mainboard listing to fund its expansion drive. The company is seeking a valuation of S$200 million and has secured commitments from three cornerstone investors, including Target Asset Management and Singapore Press Holdings, which will collectively hold an 11.97% stake post-IPO. MindChamps plans to use the net proceeds to repay loans and fund expansion and acquisition plans in Singapore and overseas.

site_title: BMW 330e review: Run this BMW for S$36 a month
summary: The BMW 330e, a plug-in hybrid electric vehicle, can be run for S$36 a month due to its fuel-efficient design. The car's electric motor and 2.0-litre turbo engine work together to achieve a combined power output of 252 horsepower. While it has a limited electric range of around 30km, the vehicle's fuel efficiency can be significantly reduced with regular charging. The car's fuel consumption rate is 5.2L/100km, making it suitable for drivers who use their car for short distances or have access to charging facilities.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Q4 profit up 12.1% at S$248m
summary: Frasers Centrepoint, a property and hospitality group, reported a 12.1% increase in Q4 net profit to S$248 million, driven by a 15.4% year-on-year rise in full-year net profit. Revenue slipped 20% to S$950.6 million. The group's PBIT rose 16.1% to S$1.09 billion, with improvements from its Australia and international businesses. The group's net-debt-to-equity ratio rose to 70.6% and net asset value per share increased to S$2.46. Frasers Centrepoint has proposed a final dividend of 6.2 Singapore cents.

site_title: Investors can either buy 'bubbles' or be left far behind
summary: A hypothetical portfolio of over-inflated assets, dubbed "Bubblicious," would have returned over 120% in 2017, outperforming the S&P 500 Index. The portfolio includes Chinese real estate, internet names, US tech behemoths, cryptocurrency, bonds with decades-long maturity, and short volatility bets. Despite being considered highly volatile, the portfolio posted a positive total return every month in 2017, highlighting the challenge of value investing in a market driven by momentum mania.

site_title: Two NY skyscraper projects run into US$76m union spat
summary: Two major New York construction projects, Manhattan West and One Vanderbilt, are embroiled in a $76 million labor dispute. Navillus Tile Inc, a contractor, was ordered to contribute to union funds, leading to bankruptcy and termination of its contract. The dispute dates back to a 2014 lawsuit alleging Navillus evaded pension and welfare obligations. Aecom-Tishman, the project's manager, has backed Navillus with insurance, and negotiations are underway for a $135 million financing to allow the contractor to continue working on the sites.

site_title: Through the looking glass
summary: Research suggests that addictive smartphone technologies are damaging mental health, causing anxiety and depression, by keeping users enthralled by a different reality. The persuasive design of smartphones and social media platforms can lead to excessive use, negatively impacting attention spans and cognitive capacities. Experts advise "getting off the phone" to mitigate these effects, echoing a long-standing warning from the past.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Haw Par Corporation reported a 4.4% decline in third-year net profit to S$40.5 million, with revenue growing 7.4% to S$53.4 million. Earnings per share dropped to S$0.184.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: UOL Group reported no surprises in its Q3 2017 operating performance, with a one-off gain from consolidating UIC and marking hotels to market. The company is seen as a beneficiary of Singapore's property market rebound, with its target price raised to S$9.85, maintaining a "buy" recommendation.

site_title: Poor ore grades continue to weigh down CNMC's Q3 profit
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings Limited reported a 45.8% drop in its third-quarter earnings to US$957,300 due to poor ore grades. The company is exploring alternative industrial metals like iron ore and plans to increase gold, silver, lead, and zinc resources and reserves. Despite a challenging quarter, CNMC CEO Chris Lim believes gold will "stay" as a store of value, contrasting with the emergence of cryptocurrencies like bitcoin. The company has also started initial trial production at its newly constructed carbon-in-leach plant at the Sokor mine.

site_title: European portfolio, China funds to drive GLP's growth
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 33.6% increase in net profit to US$231.3m in its second quarter, driven by a 31.9% rise in revenue to US$281.7m. The company's European portfolio and potential new China acquisition are expected to drive growth, with GLP also announcing plans to complete its 85% syndication and set up new China funds. The company's co-founder and CEO, Ming Mei, stated that negotiations for the European acquisition are ongoing and the new China funds are in the final stages of initiation.

site_title: Love of bikes
summary: Singapore's first art gallery, Soek Seng 1954 Bike Art Gallery, has opened in Upper Thomson, showcasing Poon Kng Joo's 100+ classic racing bicycles. The gallery, run by cycling enthusiast Poon, also features cycling jerseys, photographs by cycling photographers, and artworks created from bicycle parts. Poon plans to hold workshops and lease out the space for events, and is open to selling his bicycles to enthusiasts. The gallery aims to attract both cycling fans and art enthusiasts, with visitors from Singapore and overseas already expressing interest.

images.alt_text: (1) Hanging display of classic racing bicycles.
"Others may see unwanted bicycle parts as junk but I see them as art." - Poon Kng Joo

site_title: Audi SQ5 review: Hurry up and Q
summary: The Audi SQ5 is a high-performance SUV that competes in a crowded segment, offering a spacious and well-appointed interior. Its turbocharged 3.0-liter V6 engine produces 354 horsepower and 500 Newton-metres of torque, making it impressively responsive and fun to drive. The SQ5 also features a comfortable ride, advanced tech, and a range of capabilities, including active cruise control. Despite fierce competition from rivals like the Mercedes-AMG GLC 43 and Porsche Macan S, the SQ5's user-friendliness and capabilities make it a compelling choice for buyers.

site_title: Over 100 businesses could roll out MyInfo next year
summary: Singapore is moving closer to becoming a digital nation with over 100 businesses expected to roll out MyInfo, a service allowing customers to quickly complete transactions online, by 2018. The MyInfo Developer & Partner Portal, launched by GovTech, enables businesses to integrate their digital services with MyInfo. The service, which automatically populates online forms with verified personal data, has already seen an 80% reduction in application time for customers in the banking sector. Four financial institutions aim to roll out MyInfo by Q1 2018, setting Singapore apart as one of the first governments to let businesses access consent-driven citizen data.

site_title: The essence of success
summary: Waft, a Singapore-based startup, allows customers to create their own custom perfume online, with delivery in under a week. Founded by Valerie Boffy, a French-born entrepreneur, the company partners with International Flavours and Fragrances to ensure quality. Customers can choose from 40 ingredients, select a fragrance style, and even name their creation, with a refund policy in place. Although the author was initially underwhelmed with their own custom perfume, they praised the concept and personalized experience offered by Waft, which is reimagining the $40 billion perfume industry.

site_title: Kitchen Takeover
summary: Award-winning nomadic culinary collective Paris Popup is taking over the Open Farm Community (OFC) for three weeks with its 35th pop-up, Kampong French. The all-day dining menu features 12 small and sharing plates with a contemporary French flair, using 70-80% locally sourced ingredients from farms in and around Singapore. Kampong French runs from Nov 13 to Dec 3 at OFC (130E Minden Road).

site_title: US dollar weakened by worries over delay to hoped-for cut in US company taxes
summary: The US dollar weakened against a basket of currencies due to investor disappointment over a potential delay in implementing part of the US tax overhaul until 2019. The US dollar index fell 0.08% to 94.37, marking its biggest weekly drop in a month. This move was attributed to concerns over the tax overhaul's impact on the economy.

site_title: DBS makes it into the Asian bond market big time
summary: DBS Bank has entered the top 10 Asia ex-Japan G3 league table, ranking alongside Bank of China, the world's fourth-largest bank. Chinese issuers dominate the market, accounting for 70% of Asia's bond market. DBS's inclusion marks a significant milestone for the Singaporean bank, highlighting its growing presence in the Asian bond market.

site_title: UK house price growth peters out; London prices weakest since 2009
summary: The UK's housing market has seen a slowdown, with London house prices falling at their fastest pace since 2009, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors.
