The benchmark house price index fell to +1 in October, indicating flat price growth. Political uncertainty and the recent interest rate hike by the Bank of England are cited as major factors contributing to the market's decline. Economists predict a further decline in sales over the next 12 months, with first-time buyers focusing on new-build homes supported by government incentives.

site_title: Kikuo Ibe
summary: Kikuo Ibe, the "Godfather of G-Shock," has celebrated a milestone with Casio, as the company shipped its 100 millionth G-Shock watch in September. Ibe invented the iconic timepiece in 1983, inspired by his father's gift, which he accidentally damaged, and his vision to create a watch that can withstand shocks. Over four decades, Ibe has worked with Casio, developing the MR-G series, which combines durability with advanced technology. He hopes to one day invent a watch that can function in outer space and emphasizes the importance of using time wisely to create quality.

site_title: ComfortDelGro earnings down 8.2% in Q3
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp reported an 8.2% drop in net earnings to S$80.1 million for the third quarter, primarily due to a decline in its core taxi business affected by private-hire competition. Revenue slipped 2.4% to S$991.4 million.

site_title: Third-quarter profit surge puts Yangzijiang on a roll
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, a China-based shipbuilding group, reported a 208% year-on-year jump in third-quarter net profit to 866 million yuan, exceeding its annual order target of US$1.5 billion. The company's share price hit a six-year high, and it raised its new-order target to US$2 billion for this year and next. Executive chairman Ren Yuanlin stated that YZJ aims to deliver 46 to 50 vessels this year and next, and is exploring merger and acquisition possibilities to diversify its order book and build capacity.

site_title: Weddings unhinged
summary: Comedian Sharul Channa's new show "Sharul Weds Sharul" tackles Indian weddings, targeting customs and practices from various castes and social stratas. Her sharp tongue will critique everything from over-the-top buffets to lovey-dovey hashtags. The show will be held at the Esplanade Recital Studio on Nov 18 at 5pm and 8pm, with tickets available for S$30.

site_title: Skills and career paths drawn up for 119 infocomm tech roles
summary: Singapore has launched a skills framework for infocomm technology (ICT) roles, covering 119 job roles and over 80 skills. The framework, developed by the Infocomm Media Development Authority, SkillsFuture Singapore, and Workforce Singapore, provides training programs for skills upgrading and mastery. Organisations can seek consultancy advice with 70% subsidy, while the TechSkills Accelerator has enabled 16,000 ICT professionals to up-skill. The sector contributes 8% to Singapore's GDP and is expected to hire 42,000 ICT professionals between this year and 2019.

site_title: Got S$132,000 to spare? Ducati has a new bike for you
summary: Ducati has launched the 1299 Superleggera, a limited-edition motorcycle priced at S$132,000, in Singapore. The bike was one of the first sold by Ducati Singapore when Wearnes Automotive took over the franchise in July. Only 500 units of the Superleggera will be built, and one was purchased by a local buyer. The Superleggera is part of Ducati's high-end motorcycle market, which is driven by pure desire, according to the general manager of Ducati Singapore. This move comes after BMW's successful launch of the HP4 Race, a limited-edition superbike.

site_title: The Louvre to open - in Abu Dhabi
summary: The Louvre Abu Dhabi officially opened in Abu Dhabi, UAE, after a decade-long construction process, with over 235 works of art on display, focusing on world history and religions. French President Emmanuel Macron hailed the museum as a "decisive turning point" in France's ties with the UAE, while Crown Prince Mohammed bin Zayed Al-Nahyan described it as a "global cultural monument." The museum's unique design, by Jean Nouvel, features a silver-toned dome with perforated arabesque patterns, and includes a monumental piece by Chinese artist Ai Weiwei.

site_title: A disruptive break-up
summary: A Singaporean mobile user breaks up with their telco, Circles.Life, a fourth telco, after discovering an extra monthly fee despite having a contract that had ended months prior. Circles.Life stands out from the "big three" telcos with its customer-centric approach, offering contract-free plans and generous data allowances. The telco rewards loyalty with bonus data and allows customers to customize plans online. Its digital-first approach to customer service is also a key differentiator, providing efficient and convenient support. The article concludes that Circles.Life's approach can be a model for businesses to adapt to changing consumer preferences and shift away from traditional, customer-unfriendly practices.

site_title: Tat Hong confirms StanChart arm's offer price of S$0.50 a share
summary: Standard Chartered's private equity arm has made a non-binding proposal to acquire a 29% stake in crane supplier Tat Hong Holdings Ltd for S$0.50 a share, valuing the investment between S$109 million and S$154 million. The offer price is S$0.04 higher than Tat Hong's last closing price. The proposal is subject to conditions and does not constitute a firm intention by Standard Chartered Private Equity to make an offer.

site_title: 79 set for Warren Amateur Open
summary: The Warren Amateur Open golf tournament is set to take place from November 21 to 23 at the Warren Golf & Country Club. A total of 79 golfers, including 57 men and 22 women from 12 countries, have entered the event. The tournament is R&A-endorsed and offers points for the world ranking table, drawing global attention. National golfer Ong is the favourite for the men's event, while Callista Chen heads the women's field. The club has introduced a junior division and MST Golf returns as the title sponsor, aiming to provide exposure and lessons for amateur golfers.

site_title: Vard cuts Q3 losses to 8m kroner
summary: Vard Holdings reported a net loss of 8 million Norwegian kroner (S$1.34 million) for the third quarter, a 90% improvement from the same period last year. Revenue jumped 33% to 2.01 billion kroner, driven by increased activity at its yards in Romania and Vietnam. The company's net loss for the nine months to Sept 30 widened to 102 million kroner, while revenue inched up 3% to 5.91 billion kroner. Vard's order book stood at 41 vessels with a total value of 12 billion kroner as of Sept 30.

site_title: Homebuilder D R Horton beats profit estimate, ups 2018 forecast
summary: Homebuilder D R Horton Inc reported a better-than-expected quarterly profit, with shares rising 2.5% and reaching a record-high of $46.55. The company raised its fiscal 2018 revenue and cash flow forecasts, indicating a strong US job market is driving demand for houses. This is the latest evidence of the demand for housing being fueled by a strong US economy.

site_title: Sole Survivor
summary: Singapore's premier sneaker and streetwear convention, Sole Superior, returns for its fifth edition on November 25, featuring curated vendors, exclusive merchandise, and a charity component. The event, conceptualized by sneakerhead friends Jonathan Fong and Dexter Tan, aims to celebrate sneaker culture and its lifestyle. This year's edition includes a new after-party and collaboration merchandise, as well as limited-edition items from brands like New Era, XLARGE, and Novesta. The event also supports local designers and charities, with a focus on giving back to the community.

site_title: What's driving returns in Asia ex-Japan - place or sector?
summary: Asia ex-Japan equities have posted a 31% year-to-date return in US dollar terms, driven mainly by China, Hong Kong, and Korea, which contribute 72% of the total return. Sector dispersion is also rising, with IT, financials, real estate, and consumer discretionary contributing 81% of the total return. As monetary policy normalizes, return dispersion is expected to rise, creating more "alpha" opportunities for active managers. Active investors should focus on sector allocation, particularly in "micro-driven" sectors like IT, health care, and consumer discretionary, where firm-specific risks drive higher dispersion of returns.

site_title: EU and Iran defend nuclear deal, under fire from Trump
summary: The European Union and Iran have defended the 2015 nuclear deal, which limits Iran's nuclear program, amid pressure from US President Donald Trump. EU foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini stated the EU will ensure the deal's full implementation, while Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif said Iran's compliance with the deal proves its commitment to non-proliferation and nuclear disarmament. The US Congress has until mid-December to decide whether to reimpose sanctions lifted by the deal.

site_title: Have you been invited to the BMW Pavilion?
summary: BMW launched the BMW Pavilion in Singapore, a pop-up store offering exclusive experiences for 1,000 visitors over a fortnight. The event features six models, including the 6 Series Gran Turismo, with prices starting at S$311,800. The venue is hosting closed-door sessions for select guests from other luxury brands, aiming to build connections rather than make sales. This approach is seen as fitting for the high-end market, where luxury is about exclusivity and attitude, rather than accessibility.

site_title: Willas-Array Electronics Holdings reports surge in H1 FY18 net profit
summary: Willas-Array Electronics Holdings reported a significant surge in H1 FY18 net profit, jumping to HK$60.15 million (S$10.48) from HK$14.57 million previously. Revenue rose 14% year-over-year to HK$2.35 billion, driven by growth in automotive and premium home appliance segments. The company remains cautious, managing costs and maintaining a healthy liquidity position to support long-term growth.

site_title: River Run
summary: Singapore River's history dates back to the 18th century when it was believed to be the location of a 'strange beast' spotted by Sang Nila Utama. The river became a hub of shipping activity from the 1820s to 1840s, with ships docking at its mouth and along Boat Quay to handle trade in silk, porcelain, tea, and spice. As the river became crowded, new wharfs were built in the 1860s to ease passage, transforming the river into the lifeblood of the island's economy.

site_title: House Proud
summary: FLAUNT, an online store created by the Singapore Furniture Industries Council, has launched to promote locally designed furniture and home accessories. The platform features 13 Singapore brands, including Commune, Jottergoods, and Onlewo, which are now available for consumers to purchase on Lazada. The goal is to support local companies and provide a platform for designers to gain exposure. Other brands featured include Scandinavian design brand Stelton, and Tala, a lighting brand that aims to support a carbon-neutral economy.

site_title: Garden party
summary: Vineyard, a French-Italian restaurant with a garden-to-table concept, is offering a dining deal curated by BTWeekend. The promotion, valid from Nov 11 to Dec 15, 2017, provides 15% off total bill for dine-in only, lunch and dinner, and a la carte food and drinks. Reservations are required and can be made by calling 6479-7977 or online at vineyardhortpark.com.sg/online-reservation. This offer is exclusive to the magazine and cannot be combined with other promotions.

site_title: High-yield funds go bananas as junk-bond rout worsens
summary: High-yield funds experienced a surge in trading, with the iShares iBoxx High Yield Corporate Bond ETF seeing volume spike over five times higher than its average level. The largest junk-bond fund, Blackrock Inc's $18.7 billion fund, saw over 23.8 million shares traded, surpassing its one-day average for the past year. This surge in trading comes as the US markets face a sharp selloff, with the S&P 500 heading for its worst slump since August due to the delay in the Republican tax plan.

site_title: Business, personal finance radio station goes on air in January
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) is launching its first business and personal finance radio station, Money FM 89.3, on January 29, targeting professionals and financial-market participants. The station will draw content from The Straits Times, The Business Times, and ShareInvestor. Industry veterans will host the station, while SPH also announced upcoming changes to its print and digital products, including a redesigned Friday edition of The Straits Times and a new digital offering called Stirr.

images.alt_text: SPH Radio general manager Sim Hong Huat (extreme left) introducing the radio DJs from Money FM 89.3FM, and for 96.3 Hao FM, a new Chinese-language station, at the event on Friday.

site_title: Out of Asia and into the Indo-Pacific
summary: US President Donald Trump's Asia tour has shifted the focus to the "Indo-Pacific" region, marking a significant change in the administration's messaging and strategy. The term, which includes India, reflects a desire to counterbalance China's growing influence and promote a network of alliances, including the US, Japan, Australia, and India. This move is seen as a departure from the "Asia-Pacific" approach, which prioritized China's concerns. China has strongly opposed the term, but leaders like Trump and Japan's Prime Minister Abe have welcomed the shift, signaling a more assertive US stance in the region.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump's choice of terminology is a first step towards ensuring that China's leaders do not have it all their way.

site_title: Beijing to remove foreign ownership limits on banks
summary: China announced plans to remove foreign ownership limits on banks, allowing overseas firms to take majority stakes in local securities ventures, fund managers, and insurers. The move aims to increase global financial companies' access to the world's second-largest economy. The new rules, unveiled on November 10, 2017, are seen as a major step towards China's financial system opening up. The decision is expected to provide unprecedented access to the Chinese market for global financial companies.

site_title: mDR Q3 net profit up on other income
summary: mDR, a mobile device distributor, reported a 84% year-on-year increase in Q3 net profit to S$1.4 million, driven by higher sales from its distribution management solutions business and other income of S$1.13 million. Revenue rose 4% to S$66.06 million. The company expects positive results for the rest of the year due to an improving domestic economy and anticipated festive season sales.

site_title: Hotel Royal Q3 bottom line up 29%
summary: Hotel Royal's net profit for the third quarter ended September 30 rose 29% year-over-year to S$2.88 million, driven by higher revenue and lower tax expenses. Revenue was 4% higher at S$15.7 million, primarily due to increased room revenue and food and beverage sales at Hotel Royal Bangkok@Chinatown. Earnings per share increased to 3.44 Singapore cents from 2.66 Singapore cents a year ago.

site_title: Trudeau's no-show at meeting throws spanner in TPP talks
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's no-show at a meeting of world leaders in Da Nang, Vietnam, has derailed talks on the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade pact. The meeting was intended to discuss the future of the pact, following the US withdrawal in January. Trudeau's absence has raised concerns and caused confusion among the attendees, who were left scrambling to find an alternative solution to proceed with the talks. The meeting was subsequently scrapped, marking a significant setback in the negotiations.

site_title: CIMB's Nazir Razak plans Asean fund of up to US$1b
summary: Prominent banker Nazir Razak, brother of Malaysia's prime minister, plans to set up an "indigenous Asean" private equity fund with a capital of between US$700 million and US$1 billion, based in Singapore. The fund, which could be launched by the third quarter of next year, will be based on a capital of between US$700 million and US$1 billion. Nazir will keep his role at CIMB Group while acting as one of the fund's five partners.

site_title: LTA awards S$205m contract for Circle Line 6 to China State Construction
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) awarded a S$205 million contract to China State Construction for the Circle Line 6 (CCL6) project in Singapore. The final civil contract includes the construction of Cantonment station, with works expected to commence by end 2017 and be completed by 2025. The CCL6 will connect HarbourFront Station to Marina Bay Station, bringing the total number of stations on the circle line to 33. The project will improve commute routes between areas in the west and Central Business District, providing quicker access to retailers and offices in the HarbourFront area.

site_title: Industry shines in otherwise hazy vista for UK economy
summary: The UK economy showed its strongest month in September, with a 0.7% growth in industrial and manufacturing output, exceeding forecasts. However, consumer spending remains a concern, with a 1.6% monthly drop in construction and British shops suffering their worst October for sales in a decade. Economists predict the economy will slow next year due to Brexit uncertainty, with the Bank of England expected to engineer a budget that addresses this challenge.

site_title: Allianz lowers 2017 profit outlook after natural disasters
summary: Allianz has lowered its 2017 profit outlook due to increased claims from natural disasters in North America, including hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria, as well as earthquakes in Mexico and fires in California. The insurer's finance chief cited a "smidgen" decrease in its forecast, with operating profit now expected to be in the "upper half" of its target range of 10.3-11.3 billion euros. The catastrophes cost Allianz over 500 million euros in the third quarter, with total insured losses from the three hurricanes estimated to be around $100 billion.

site_title: IBM ups pressure on rivals with quantum computer prototype
summary: IBM has created a 50 qubit quantum computer prototype, a significant milestone in quantum computing, and is making it available to paying customers through its cloud computing platform by the end of 2017. This move puts IBM in a neck-and-neck race with Google, which plans to demonstrate a similarly-sized machine by the end of the year. The prototype's 90-microsecond coherence time is among the best recorded for superconducting materials, demonstrating advancements in quantum computing technology.

site_title: EU aims for December Brexit deal as talks yield no breakthrough
summary: European Union chief negotiator Michel Barnier stated that no breakthrough was made in Brexit talks, but progress was made on citizens' rights. The UK's resistance to a better financial settlement is hindering progress on the future trading relationship and transition deal. Both sides aim for a deal in December, with the Irish border issue potentially delaying a deal until March.

site_title: Uber's London problems stack up with employment appeal loss
summary: Uber Technologies lost an appeal in a UK court over whether it should pay overtime and give vacation time to its drivers, with a judge ruling the original decision was "neither inconsistent nor perverse." Uber plans to appeal to higher courts, which could have implications for the broader gig economy. The ruling may impact thousands of workers in the UK and other countries, and could also affect Deliveroo, a rival food-delivery company being sued by dozens of riders over similar workers' rights issues.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on worries over delay in tax cuts
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday due to concerns over a delay in corporate tax cuts, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 16.1 points to 23,445.84. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 losing 4.57 points to 2,580.05 and the Nasdaq dropping 12.97 points to 6,737.08. Despite this, Walt Disney's shares rose, limiting losses in the Dow.

site_title: Chinese company offers lifetime of booze for 11,111 yuan
summary: A Chinese white liquor maker, Jiangxiaobai Liquor Company, is offering a lifetime supply of booze for 11,111 yuan (US$1,700) on Singles Day, China's biggest shopping festival. The offer, limited to 99 customers, includes 12 boxes of grain-based baijiu with a 45-degree proof, and can be inherited by a family member if the customer dies within five years. The offer is significantly lower than the original price of 99,999 yuan and comes with a certificate pledging a full refund if the company fails to deliver the alcohol in the next 30 years.

site_title: When the bull won't be taken by the horns
summary: The global stock market has reached new highs, with Asia, the US, and Europe experiencing mixed but overall upward performance. Despite geopolitical turmoil and concerns over stock valuations, experts attribute the rally to strong economic growth, robust corporate earnings, and the accelerating growth in major economies. The International Monetary Fund has raised its 2017 forecast for global growth to 3.6%, and corporate earnings are estimated to have grown 8% year-over-year. However, some warn that the prolonged bull market may be unsustainable and that investors should consider dollar-cost averaging, while others advise against timing the market.

images.alt_text: Markets in Asia, US and Europe too have charted new highs on the back of a global rally that has gone on for the better part of a decade.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The US stock market opened lower due to Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Companies reported mixed earnings, with Creative Technology warning of below-target revenue and an operating loss similar to H1. Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. In other news, Indonesia detained an employee in a graft case, and Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the People's Bank of China announced deeper cooperation in green and transition finance. Grab's earnings growth is expected to slow in H2, according to CGS-IIB.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Q4 net profit up 12.1% to S$248m
summary: Frasers Centrepoint (FCL) reported a 12.1% increase in group net profit for the fourth quarter ended Sept 30 to S$248 million, driven by a fair value gain on investment properties and increased contributions from its Australia and international businesses. Revenue slipped 20% to S$950.6 million. The group's net-debt-to-equity ratio rose to 70.6% as at Sept 30, 2017, and net asset value per share increased to S$2.46. A final dividend of 6.2 Singapore cents was proposed, unchanged from the previous corresponding period.

site_title: Xi, Trump offer duelling visions of globalisation at Apec summit
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Donald Trump presented contrasting visions for Asia's future at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Vietnam. Xi emphasized China's role in promoting global free trade and stability, while Trump criticized the World Trade Organization and offered trade agreements on America's terms. The speeches reflect divergent pitches for leadership in a region suspicious of China's intentions and unsure about America's staying power. Xi's remarks signal a push for China to open its economy, but doubts remain about the country's commitment to reform.

site_title: Opec and hedge funds could be setting oil prices up for a fall
summary: Opec and its allies are expected to prolong supply cuts, potentially setting oil prices for a fall. Hedge funds have bet heavily on rising oil prices, but if Opec extends the agreement, the market may be unable to sustain it. This could lead to a deeper sell-off, similar to the 4.6% drop in oil prices after the last meeting. Analysts warn that the market has "already priced in" the expected extension, and a shorter deal or delay could result in a significant sell-off.

site_title: Mueller probing alleged Flynn plan to deliver cleric to Turkey: WSJ
summary: Special counsel Robert Mueller is investigating whether former Trump national security adviser Michael Flynn was involved in a plan to deliver Muslim cleric Fethullah Gulen to Turkey in exchange for millions of dollars. The alleged plan, involving Flynn and his son, would have forcibly removed Gulen from his US home and delivered him to Turkey. Flynn is a central figure in Mueller's investigation due to his conversations with Russian Ambassador Sergei Kislyak and his failure to register as a foreign agent. The investigation also includes discussions of a December meeting where Flynn and Turkish representatives discussed removing Gulen.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.53 points to 1,742.28. The decline was attributed to a lower market volume of 3.1 billion lots worth RM2.1 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 479 to 371.

site_title: Trump says Asia held hostage by N Korea's 'twisted fantasies'
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that the Asia-Pacific region is being held hostage by North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's "twisted fantasies" of violent conquest and nuclear blackmail. Trump emphasized the need for regional unity in curbing North Korea's nuclear program, warning that time is running out. During his speech at the APEC forum in Vietnam, Trump urged countries to stand united against Pyongyang, calling for a collective response to the crisis.

site_title: SPH to launch two new radio stations; previews upcoming changes to its newspapers
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) is launching two new radio stations, 96.3 Hao FM and Money FM 89.3, in January 2018. Money FM 89.3 will be Singapore's first business and personal finance radio station, while 96.3 Hao FM will be a Chinese infotainment station targeting those aged 45 and above. The launch follows a successful tender in March 2017 and brings the total number of radio stations managed by SPH to five. Upcoming changes to SPH's newspapers, including The Straits Times and The Business Times, include creating more premium content and shifting technology news to the Life section.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore retail sales fell 0.5% in September, the first decline in six months, due to poor motor vehicle sales. However, excluding car sales, retail sales grew 3.3%. The Singapore Exchange is expected to see a small increase in trading volumes due to its reinstatement of a lunch break. SembCorp Marine won a $490m contract from Statoil, while the Land Transport Authority awarded a $205m contract for Circle Line 6 to China State Construction.

site_title: MindChamps lodges preliminary prospectus for IPO
summary: MindChamps PreSchool, the largest operator of premium pre-school centres in Singapore, has lodged a preliminary prospectus for a mainboard listing on the Singapore Exchange. The company is seeking a valuation of about S$200 million and has secured commitments from cornerstone investors China First Capital Group, Hillhouse Capital, and Target Asset Management, which will hold an 11.97% stake in the company. This marks the company's entry into the public market.

site_title: Haw Par profits down by 4.4% to S$40.5 million as higher expenses weigh down earnings
summary: Haw Par Corporation Ltd reported a 4.4% decline in net profit to S$40.5 million in the third quarter, despite a 7.4% increase in revenue to S$53.4 million. The decline was attributed to higher expenses. The company's earnings growth was impacted by rising costs, which weighed down its overall performance.

site_title: Australia, home of coal, signals shift away from future plants
summary: Australia, a major coal producer, is shifting away from building new coal-fired power plants due to the decreasing costs of renewable energy sources like solar and wind. Energy Security Board Chairman Kerry Schott stated that advances in these technologies make them an attractive option, with low-emissions coal plants being expensive. The country plans to rely on solar, wind, batteries, and demand response to meet its energy needs, rather than relying on new coal-fired plants. This shift is aimed at addressing Australia's power grid reliability and lowering emissions.

site_title: CBS' buyout of Australia's Ten Network nears final hurdle
summary: CBS Corp's buyout of Australia's Ten Network Holdings has won approval from an Australian court, with only clearance from the nation's securities regulator remaining. The bankrupt broadcaster's creditors voted in September to accept the CBS offer, and a court dismissed opposition from three small shareholders. The deal, which requires final clearance from the Australian Securities and Investment Commission, is expected to be completed by November 14, with all stock transferred to CBS control. The buyout was approved by the Foreign Investment Review Board last month.

site_title: Malaysia's giving working mums a better maternity deal than US
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has unveiled a budget aimed at increasing female participation in the workforce, offering tax exemptions, extended maternity leave, and mandatory childcare facilities. The plan seeks to boost productivity and address Malaysia's middle-income trap, with a target to become a high-income country within three years. The move is seen as a significant step to address the country's low female labor force participation rate, which is among the lowest in Southeast Asia. The government hopes to attract more women back to the workforce, citing studies that show increased female participation can boost GDP by up to 34%.

site_title: Globalisation an 'irreversible historical trend': Xi
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping declared globalisation an "irreversible historical trend" at the APEC summit in Vietnam, contrasting with US President Donald Trump's "America First" doctrine. Xi defended multinational trade deals, saying they benefit poorer nations, while Trump vowed to rewrite global commerce rules, prioritising bilateral pacts. Xi's comments came after the US withdrawal from the Trans Pacific Partnership, which China is now pushing to fill.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets sit tight at open
summary: European stock markets opened relatively steady on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.1% to 7,493.81 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index gaining 0.2% to 13,206.35 points. Paris' CAC 40 index remained flat at 5,405.55 points. The markets appear to be unaffected by recent US threats, instead focusing on ongoing trade talks between the US and EU.

site_title: Over 100 businesses could roll out MyInfo next year to speed up online transactions
summary: More than 100 businesses in Singapore are expected to offer MyInfo, a service allowing customers to complete online transactions more quickly, by 2018. The MyInfo Developer & Partner Portal was launched by GovTech to support local businesses integrating their digital services with MyInfo. The service, which was first introduced in 2016, allows SingPass users to skip filling in personal data for every online transaction, saving time and the need for verification documents. Several banks, including Citibank and HSBC, are targeting to have MyInfo onboard by Q1 2018.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte says he once stabbed a person to death
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte claimed in a speech that he stabbed a person to death as a teenager, stating he was 16 years old at the time. The incident allegedly occurred over a look, and he said it was "just over a rumble." Duterte's comments come ahead of a summit of world leaders, including US President Donald Trump, where he has been criticized for his deadly drug war, which has resulted in thousands of deaths. Critics accuse him of orchestrating a campaign of extrajudicial mass murder.

site_title: Trump defiant on trade, vows to put 'America First'
summary: US President Donald Trump delivered a speech at the APEC Summit, emphasizing his "America First" doctrine and vowing to address unfair trade practices, intellectual property theft, and closed markets. He criticized the World Trade Organization for failing to enforce free trade and accused Asia-Pacific nations of undercutting the US economy. Trump's speech was seen as a challenge to China's growing influence in global trade, as China announced plans to further open its financial markets to foreign firms. The speech marked a shift towards "economic nationalism" in the US, raising concerns about the impact on decades of US-led economic diplomacy and free trade agreements.

site_title: Australia, Peru sign sweet free trade deal for sugar industry
summary: Australia and Peru have signed a free trade pact eliminating nearly all tariffs for Australian exporters in Peru, boosting the sugar industry and other sectors. The deal will give Australian sugar growers access to about a third of Peru's import market, with initial exports expected to reach 30,000 tonnes, doubling to 60,000 tonnes within five years. The agreement also opens up trade in beef, dairy, and mining services, with Australia's dairy industry set to have an export quota of 7,000 tonnes.

site_title: Noble Group tumbles as trader's cash dwindles to decade-low
summary: Noble Group's shares plummeted 9.3% after the commodity trader reported a third-quarter net loss of $1.17 billion, taking its year-to-date losses to $3 billion. Cash holdings fell to a decade-low of $262 million, and liquidity headroom decreased by 43% over the quarter. Analysts predict an all-but-inevitable debt restructuring, with bonds due in March and a bank loan in May. The company is offloading non-core operations and considering asset sales to raise $800 million to $1 billion.

images.alt_text: Noble Group's shares tumbled as the embattled commodity trader's cash holdings fell to the lowest in more than a decade, adding to pressure on what analysts say is an all but inevitable debt restructuring. The bonds due in March also dropped.

site_title: Kobe Steel blames data scandal on focus on profit, lack of controls
summary: Kobe Steel Ltd, Japan's third-largest steelmaker, has admitted to widespread data tampering that compromised the safety and performance of products for car and plane makers worldwide. The company blames a focus on profits and lack of quality controls for the scandal. Kobe Steel has promised to automate operations and reorganize quality control systems to recover from the scandal, which has led to losses and a decline in its shares. The company has identified multiple workers and managers involved in the data tampering, and is in talks with customers to recover costs of safety inspections.

images.alt_text: Kobe Steel Ltd said on Friday a lack of quality controls and a focus on profits was behind the widespread data tampering that has shaken up the supply chains of car and plane makers around the world.

site_title: Peugeot chief says Brexit adds pressure on Vauxhall's plants
summary: PSA Group's CEO Carlos Tavares says Brexit poses pressure on Vauxhall's UK factories, which face higher production costs and potential trade barriers. To offset these risks, PSA aims to make the plants more competitive with European facilities, possibly by reversing Opel branding and focusing on local markets. Analysts predict Vauxhall's future may be uncertain, with some calling for the brand to be "dumped." Tavares argues that Vauxhall's heritage and British roots make it a valuable asset, and that the company will find a way to keep it.

images.alt_text: PSA Group is pushing the UK factories acquired in its deal for General Motors's European operations to make a leap in competitiveness to offset the potential risks posed by Brexit.

site_title: GSH Corp reports stronger bottom line in Q3
summary: GSH Corp reported a significant increase in its third-quarter net profit, rising to S$2.05 million from S$103,000 in the same period last year, largely due to a share of profit from an associate. Revenue declined 26% year-over-year to S$20.97 million, primarily due to the absence of revenue from its property business. The company highlighted positive sales for its Eaton Residences project in Kuala Lumpur, with recognition of sales starting from Q4 2017.

site_title: South Korea to join three US aircraft carriers in drills
summary: South Korea will participate in joint drills with three US aircraft carriers, USS Ronald Reagan, USS Nimitz, and USS Theodore Roosevelt, in international waters between Saturday and Tuesday. This is the first triple-carrier drill in the region since 2007, with US Pacific Fleet commander Scott Swift noting the unusual deployment. The drills aim to demonstrate a show of force against North Korea, following recent tensions in the region.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.1% lower on weak lead from Wall Street
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.1% lower on Friday, capping the week's trading at 3,420.1, with 2.2 billion shares worth S$1.3 billion changing hands. Weak lead from Wall Street, where US stocks fell due to delayed tax reform plans, contributed to the decline. The STI saw 236 counters fall and 206 rise, with the key index losing 3.81 points.

site_title: China's deliverymen face robot revolution as parcel demand soars
summary: China's delivery industry is undergoing a robot revolution as parcel demand soars, driven by 50% annual growth. Companies like JD.com, S F Express, and ZTO Express are testing robots and automated sorting lines to keep pace with the industry's staff shortages and declining margins. China is leapfrogging the US in adopting automation technologies, with some firms already seeing significant cost savings and improved efficiency. The government's "Made in China 2025" initiative is also spurring growth in robotics, but the industry faces challenges from regulatory hurdles, particularly with drone-based last-mile deliveries.

site_title: Tillerson calls wave of arrests in Saudi Arabia 'well intended'
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson described the recent wave of arrests in Saudi Arabia, detaining at least 11 princes and a billionaire investor, as "well intended". He expressed concern about the treatment of those detained, calling for clarity on the situation. Tillerson made the comments in an interview while flying from Beijing to Vietnam, following a sweep of anti-graft crackdowns on November 4.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said a wave of arrests in Saudi Arabia that snared at least 11 princes, a billionaire investor and former government officials was "well intended", but he remained concerned about how those detained would be treated.

site_title: Indonesia loses WTO appeal in food fight with New Zealand, US
summary: Indonesia lost a WTO appeal against US and New Zealand over food import restrictions, which cover products like beef, poultry, apples, and grapes. The Indonesian government will study the ruling before easing any restrictions, citing health concerns and halal food standards. The dispute began in 2016, with Indonesia appealing a panel's finding that its rules were not based on health concerns. The Indonesian trade ministry will conduct internal coordination and consider implications for current regulations.

site_title: Asia: Markets turn lower as US tax-cut fears brew
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday as traders worried about US tax-cut plans, despite a recent rally. The uncertainty stems from differing ideas among Republican lawmakers, which may delay or alter the overhaul. This has led to a sell-off in global markets, with the Nikkei down 1.4% and other markets, including Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Seoul, also falling. Oil prices eased, but analysts expect them to rise due to growing tensions in the Middle East.

site_title: China to expand corporate tax cuts for hi-tech services firms nationwide
summary: China is expanding corporate tax cuts for high-tech services firms nationwide, reducing the tax rate to 15% effective January 1, 2017. This move aims to attract foreign capital into the high-tech, high-value-added services industry, which accounts for over half of China's economy. Firms must generate at least half of their annual revenue from high-tech services to qualify for the tax incentives. The expansion is part of China's efforts to rebalance its growth model and boost the services sector.

site_title: Hot stock: Cosco Shipping rallies 13% alongside Yangzijiang's gains
summary: Cosco Shipping International shares surged 13% on Friday, driven by fellow Chinese shipbuilder Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's better-than-expected third-quarter earnings. Yangzijiang's shares rose 4.5% after reporting a 208% increase in earnings. Analysts attribute Cosco's gain to its takeover bid for logistics firm Cogent and expected logistics business focus. The move is seen as a potential "catch-up play" after Yangzijiang's outperformance this year.

site_title: Singapore deepens collaboration with the International Energy Agency
summary: Singapore strengthened its collaboration with the International Energy Agency (IEA) at the biennial IEA Ministerial Meeting in Paris, with Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran attending and outlining strategies to enhance energy security and promote a transparent regional gas market. Singapore will work with the IEA on capacity building programs and a workshop on digitalisation and energy for Asean in 2018, as it assumes the chairmanship of the 36th Asean Ministers on Energy Meeting. The collaboration aims to foster a resilient and sustainable energy community in Asean.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week with loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week with a 0.05% drop to close at 29,120.92, despite China's announcement to further open its financial sector to foreign firms, which boosted the Shanghai Composite Index 0.14% and the Shenzhen Composite Index 0.52%.

site_title: Tat Hong: StanChart PE makes non-binding offer at S$0.50/share
summary: Tat Hong Holdings, a crane supplier, received a non-binding offer from Standard Chartered Private Equity Singapore (SCPE) to acquire shares at S$0.50 per share. The proposal, if successful, could see SCPE invest between S$109 million and S$154 million in Tat Hong. The deal is subject to various conditions, including regulatory approvals and definitive partnership terms. The company had previously indicated interest in potential transactions, and this offer does not constitute a firm intention to make an offer.

site_title: SGX's volumes will shift around but won't grow much with lunch break: Nomura
summary: SGX's reinstatement of a one-hour lunch break will have minimal impact on trading volumes, with approximately 5.5% of daily trading volumes currently occurring between noon and 1pm. The trades will be redistributed throughout the day, resulting in a small bulge in volumes rather than a significant increase.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange's (SGX) reinstatement of the lunch break on Monday will be more street cart than full-service banquet when it comes to impact on trading volumes, analysts at Nomura's Instinet Pacific said in a report.

site_title: YZJ raises new-order target to S$2b from S$1.5b; shares hit 6-year high
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's executive chairman Ren Yuanlin raised the company's new-order target to S$2 billion for 2017 and 2018, exceeding the previous target of S$1.5 billion. The company secured new orders of 59 vessels worth S$1.6 billion this year, posting a net profit of 866 million yuan (S$177 million) for the third quarter. Shares rose 4.5% to a six-year high, with analysts predicting market conditions for the shipbuilding industry will continue to improve, but warning of potential earnings deterioration in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge lower on materials; NZ down
summary: Australian shares edged lower on Friday, falling 0.3% due to weakness in commodity prices, particularly in materials and energy stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached a 10-year high earlier in the week but retreated after BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto fell 2.9% and 2.8%, respectively. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also declined 0.3%, driven by technology and consumer cyclicals stocks.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars slip for the day, but poised for weekly gains
summary: The Australian dollar slipped to US$0.7680 after the Reserve Bank of Australia downgraded forecasts for inflation and growth, signaling steady interest rates. The New Zealand dollar eased from a two-week high, poised for its second straight weekly gain. Analysts expect the Aussie to break above US$0.77 to gain upside momentum, while the kiwi's gains may be sustained by positive policy statements from the Reserve Bank of New Zealand.

site_title: Xi's economic aide poised for key role in China debt cleanup
summary: Liu He, a key adviser to Chinese President Xi Jinping, is poised to take on a more prominent role in addressing China's debt issues. A new committee formed to coordinate financial regulators is led by Vice-Premier Ma Kai, but analysts expect Liu He to become Xi's key lieutenant. Liu's experience guiding economic policy and his Harvard education make him a strong candidate to lead the debt cleanup efforts, which are seen as crucial to preventing a financial meltdown in China.

images.alt_text: Liu He, a key adviser to Chinese President Xi Jinping known for guiding economic policy behind the scenes, appears destined to occupy more of the spotlight.

site_title: CIMB's Nazir Razak said to plan US$1b Southeast Asia fund, based in Singapore
summary: CIMB's Nazir Razak plans to launch a US$1 billion Southeast Asia private equity fund based in Singapore, targeting investments in consumer, technology, logistics, and financial services industries. The fund will be one of five partners, including Kenny Kim and David Heng, and is expected to raise US$700 million to US$1 billion from investors. This move comes as private equity deals in Southeast Asia have more than doubled to US$37.4 billion this year, driven by lower labor costs, growing demand, and infrastructure improvements in the region.

site_title: Hot stock: Yangzijiang climbs nearly 5% on surge in Q3 earnings
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (Holdings) reported a 208% surge in its third-quarter earnings, with net profit reaching 866 million yuan (S$177.5 million). Revenue rose 13% to 4.38 billion yuan. Analysts expect market conditions to continue improving, but some predict a decline in shipbuilding revenue in the fourth quarter. The stock rose 4.5% to S$1.635, with some analysts maintaining a "hold" rating but others advising to sell before earnings deterioration becomes more obvious.

site_title: Singapore retail sales slip 0.5% in Sept; first slide in 6 months as vehicle sales sputter
summary: Singapore retail sales declined 0.5% in September, the first drop in six months, driven by a sharp 15.3% decline in motor vehicle sales. Excluding car sales, retail sales grew 3.3% year-on-year. This reversal from August's 3.7% growth rate, the strongest since March 2016, was attributed to poor COE supply and government policies affecting car sales. Other categories, such as supermarket sales, rose 9.8% and petrol service station sales rose 9.2%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks track Wall St down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading on Friday, following a broad Asian sell-off, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.17% to 29,087.04. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with declines of 0.13% and 0.10%, respectively. The sell-off follows losses on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing US-China trade uncertainty.

site_title: China lets foreign firms own 51% of securities joint venture
summary: China has relaxed foreign ownership limits in the securities industry, allowing overseas firms to own up to 51% of local securities ventures. This move is part of the country's efforts to liberalize its financial industry and ease entry barriers for foreign banks, asset managers, and insurers. The decision, made amid Sino-US dealmaking, aims to encourage foreign investment and competition in the sector, which has been restricted by a 49% cap.

site_title: Singapore launches skills framework for ICT roles, to subsidise consultancy fees
summary: Singapore has launched a skills framework for ICT roles, covering 119 job roles and 80 skills, to support the development of a skilled ICT workforce. The framework, developed by IMDA, SkillsFuture Singapore, and Workforce Singapore, provides career pathways and training programs. The government will subsidise 70% of consultancy fees for organisations adopting the framework, aiming to help companies and workers deepen digital capabilities and stay relevant in the digital transformation era. This initiative supports the TechSkills Accelerator, which has enabled over 16,000 ICT professionals to up-skill and re-skill themselves since 2017.

site_title: Call out for proposals on redesigning government regulations to help industries facing disruption
summary: Singapore's Pro-Enterprise Panel (PEP) has called for proposals to redesign government regulations to help industries facing disruptions, particularly those related to technological and business model changes. The panel aims to create a nimble and responsive regulatory framework to support the growth of new industries and businesses. The move is part of three new initiatives by the PEP to promote a pro-business environment. The panel will review regulations based on specific themes, work closely with government agencies, and share success stories to encourage businesses to provide suggestions.

site_title: China deal seen as no guarantee for Alaska LNG export project
summary: China has agreed to develop a massive liquefied natural gas export project in Alaska, boosting the US$43 billion project's profile, but analysts say it's not a guarantee for its success. The deal includes a pipeline and export terminal, with China's Sinopec and a sovereign wealth fund on board. However, binding offtake agreements and financing details are lacking, and analysts warn that securing major deals is crucial for project viability. The project, backed by Alaska's state-owned energy company, aims to deliver 20 million tonnes of LNG per year to Chinese buyers.

site_title: SembMarine set to win US$490m contract from Statoil
summary: SembCorp Marine is expected to win a US$490 million contract from Statoil for engineering, procurement, and construction services on a newbuild floating production storage and offloading (FPSO) hull and living quarters for the Johan Castberg field development. The contract is part of a tender process, and a letter of intent has been signed. The award has yet to be finalized, with no expected impact on net tangible assets and earnings per share.

site_title: Pacific Radiance cuts Q3 net loss to US$13.2 million by slashing costs
summary: Pacific Radiance, an offshore and marine group, reported a 27% reduction in its third-quarter net loss to US$13.16 million, from a year-ago loss of US$17.97 million. Revenue declined 9% to US$17.21 million, mainly due to lower vessel utilization and charter rates. The company attributed the improvement to cost-cutting efforts, including right-sizing its fleet and reducing operating costs. Despite this, operating conditions are expected to remain challenging in the next 12 months due to lingering supply overhang in the offshore market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, closing at 1,746.56 points, down 0.25 points. Trading volume reached 110.24 million lots worth RM34.2 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 94 to 78.

site_title: Joel Robuchon appoints two new head chefs in Singapore
summary: French chef Joel Robuchon has appointed two new head chefs in Singapore, Kim Joinié-Maurin and Vianney Massot, for his restaurants Joël Robuchon Restaurant and L'Atelier de Joël Robuchon, respectively. Both chefs have international training under Mr. Robuchon and have joined the team in 2006 and 2009, respectively. Mr. Robuchon expressed confidence in their abilities to take the restaurants to new heights, citing their exceptional culinary talents.

site_title: Japan to build four radar stations for the Philippines to counter piracy surge
summary: Japan plans to build four coast guard radar stations in the Sulu Celebes Seas to help the Philippines counter a surge in piracy by Islamic insurgents. The stations will be funded through Japan's Overseas Development Aid budget and will include training for local coast guard personnel. The move aims to deepen economic and security ties with the Philippines, a key ally in preventing China's growing influence in the region. A funding agreement and training plan may be signed by Japanese Prime Minister and Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte next week.

site_title: FCL full-year profit up 15% on higher revenue, fair value gain
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) reported a 15.4% increase in net profit to S$689.1 million for its 2017 financial year, driven by higher revenue and a S$215.3 million fair value gain on investment properties, nearly double the previous year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 1.26% to 22,580.70 and the Topix index down 1.10% to 1,793.23. The decline followed a negative lead from Wall Street.

site_title: Gold rises on weak dollar; palladium dips from 16-year high
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to a three-week high at $1,286.27 per ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar. Spot gold reached its highest level since October 20. Meanwhile, palladium dipped but remained close to its 16-year peak. The price movements were influenced by the Trump administration's fresh tariffs on Canada and potential tariff threats to other countries.

site_title: More Americans think wealthy, not middle class, will benefit from tax reform: poll
summary: A Reuters/Ipsos opinion poll found that 32% of Americans believe the wealthy will benefit most from the tax reform currently being pushed by US Congress, despite Republicans' insistence that the goal is to help the middle class. Only 8% of Americans think the middle class will benefit the most, with 79% prioritizing cutting taxes for the middle class over corporations. The poll also showed significant opposition to eliminating deductions for mortgage interest and medical expenses.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yangzijiang, Ho Bee Land, Hyflux, Banyan Tree, KOP, Vard, SembMarine
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 208% increase in net profit to 866 million yuan (S$177.5 million) in its third quarter, driven by higher turnover and vessel deliveries. Ho Bee Land saw a 103.5% jump in net profit to S$54.4 million, while Banyan Tree swung into profit with a S$20.07 million profit. In contrast, Hyflux reported a net loss of S$26.1 million due to a weak Singapore power market. Vard Holdings improved its loss to 8 million Norwegian kroner (S$1.34 million), while Sembcorp Marine expects to win a US$490 million engineering contract.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday; STI slips 0.45% to 3,408.52
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index slipped 15.39 points, or 0.45%, to 3,408.52 at 9:03am on Friday, following a negative lead from US and Europe markets. Yangzijiang Holdings rose 3 cents, or nearly 2%, after reporting a 208% surge in net profit. Other active stocks included DBS Group Holdings and CapitaLand, which announced their results earlier in the week.

site_title: Europe: Shares suffer worst day since June as earnings underwhelm
summary: European shares fell 1.1% on Thursday, the worst day since June, as underwhelming earnings updates from companies like Siemens and Vestas led investors to take profits. The Stoxx 600 benchmark index is up 7.9% this year, but analysts say earnings growth has slowed to 7.6% in the third quarter. Despite this, some investors remain upbeat about the region's equities, citing strong economic data and easing political fears.

site_title: US: Stocks sink amid fears of GOP tax cut delay
summary: US stocks plummeted 0.4-0.6% on Thursday, driven by concerns over delayed corporate tax cuts promised by the Trump administration. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq dropped 0.6% and 0.6% respectively. Tech stocks were among the biggest losers, with Alphabet, Microsoft, and Apple experiencing losses. Investors were also spooked by the prospect of delayed tax cuts, leading to profit-taking and selling pressure.

site_title: Boeing wins US$37b China orders for 300 aircraft
summary: Boeing wins a US$37 billion order from China Aviation Supplies Holding Co for 300 aircraft, including 260 narrowbody planes and 40 widebody aircraft. The order comes as Chinese airlines ramp up capacity to meet rising demand, with the country projected to overtake the US as the largest air-travel market in as little as five years.

site_title: Ezion still in the red, more impairment losses expected
summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore and marine group, reported a net loss of $13.7 million for the third quarter, marking the third consecutive quarter in the red. Revenue declined 20.2% to $63.71 million due to reduced charter rates and lower fleet utilization. The company expects further impairment losses and is seeking support from creditors to restructure its $1.5 billion liabilities. Ezion is also considering disposing of undeployed assets and canceling contracts to stem cash burn.

site_title: Disney announces new Star Wars trilogy
summary: Disney announces a new Star Wars trilogy, with plans to launch in a direct-to-consumer pay service offering thousands of hours of film and TV content. The new trilogy, developed by Rian Johnson, follows the success of the last two released films and includes a film based on the Han Solo character. The 2019 release of Episode 9 is also planned, with production recently wrapping. Disney CEO Robert Iger expressed confidence in the upcoming release of The Last Jedi and the franchise's continued growth, citing its "big ambitions" and "exceeding expectations" since Disney acquired LucasFilm five years ago.

site_title: Oil prices rise on supply cuts and political tensions in Saudi Arabia
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Thursday due to supply cuts by major exporters and concerns about Saudi Arabian politics. Brent crude settled at $63.93 a barrel, while US light crude rose to $57.27 a barrel. These increases followed a two-year high set earlier in the week.

site_title: US slams World Bank lending to rich countries
summary: The US Treasury has criticized the World Bank for lending to rich countries, citing China as an example. Under Secretary for International Affairs David Malpass stated that such lending hurts poor countries in need of assistance. The Trump administration will push the World Bank to move countries towards graduation as their economies grow, allowing them to access private financing. Currently, 25 countries meet the graduation threshold, but some, like South Korea, have continued to borrow despite their high incomes.

site_title: Regulator, AT&T at odds over CNN in Time Warner deal
summary: US antitrust regulators and AT&T Inc are at odds over the proposed $85.4 billion deal to buy Time Warner Inc, with the Justice Department demanding significant asset sales, including CNN or DirecTV, to approve the merger. AT&T has denied offering to sell CNN and claims it will not do so. The dispute raises concerns about the deal's impact on competition and the role of politics in the review process, with US President Donald Trump having previously vowed to block the deal. Negotiations continue, with the Justice Department seeking a 10-year condition on AT&T's post-merger behavior.

site_title: Parked A380 plane seeks new operator or it'll be scrapped
summary: Airbus's first A380 to exit service, a 10-year-old superjumbo, will be stored in France with its engines removed, awaiting a new operator. The plane's owner, leasing firm Dr Peters, is in talks with potential buyers, but time is running out, and scrapping may be an option. The move is a setback for Airbus, which is trying to save the A380 program by selling new planes to Emirates. The aircraft will be stored at Tarbes airport, and Rolls-Royce will return the engines for rental to other operators.

site_title: Gold miner CNMC's Q3 profit falls 46% to US$0.96 million on poorer ore grades
summary: Malaysian gold miner CNMC Goldmine Holdings reported a 46% decline in Q3 profit to US$957,300 due to lower ore grades affecting production and sales. Revenue nearly halved to US$4.7 million, with average realised gold price declining to US$1,275 per ounce. The company's all-in production costs rose to US$1,546 per ounce, mainly due to lower gold output and higher capital expenditure for a new carbon-in-leach plant. CNMC expects the plant to improve efficiency and reduce costs.

site_title: New Silkroutes expects revenue of at least US$500m for FY2018
summary: New Silkroutes Group, a Mainboard-listed company, expects revenue of at least US$500 million for FY2018, a 15% growth from FY2017. The forecast is driven by increased oil trades and revenue from new acquisitions in healthcare and real estate. Despite revenue doubling in the first fiscal quarter, the company reported a net loss of US$551,000, attributed to lower profit margins and consolidation costs. This would be the third straight loss-making year for the company if its market capitalization falls below S$40 million.

site_title: UOL Q3 profit up 600% on UIC deal
summary: UOL Group's third-quarter profit surged 609% to S$618.1 million, driven by a S$542.1 million gain from acquiring United Industrial Corporation (UIC) as a subsidiary. The acquisition increased UOL's stake in UIC to 48.96%. The company reported a 37% increase in group revenue to S$537.9 million, driven by consolidation and joint ventures. Net asset value per share rose to S$10.95, and the counter ended three Singapore cents higher at S$8.80.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says 201 people held in anti-graft swoop
summary: Saudi Arabia has arrested 201 people, including princes, ministers, and a billionaire business tycoon, in a corruption crackdown estimated to be worth $100 billion. Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, consolidating power, has frozen bank accounts and warned of asset seizures. The purge comes amid heightened regional tensions, including a missile attack from Yemen and a crisis in Lebanon. The government claims to have uncovered "very large" corrupt practices and is centralizing power, which analysts describe as a bold but risky move.

site_title: GLP net profit up 34% in Q2 on higher revenue and forex gain
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 33.6% increase in net profit to S$231.3 million in Q2, driven by higher revenue and foreign exchange gains. Revenue rose 31.9% to S$281.7 million, mainly due to revenue from financial services in China and development projects. The group also announced several executive appointments to support its long-term global growth strategy, including new CFO and CEO of GLP Financial Services, and global treasurer for GLP and CFO of GLP Japan.

site_title: Greening the office environment
summary: Ricoh Asia Pacific commits to sustainability, aligning its business with environmental protection and climate change mitigation. As the regional headquarters of Japanese imaging and electronics group, the company promotes eco-friendly office equipment and solutions through its subsidiaries and distributors. By implementing measures to improve resource productivity, Ricoh Asia Pacific aims to reduce its environmental footprint and contribute to a greener office environment.

site_title: Is CEA a relevant body for Reits' activities?
summary: Singapore's real estate investment trusts (Reits) are facing an identity crisis due to the dual regulatory bodies they are subject to. The Council for Estate Agencies (CEA) has informed Reit managers that they must be licensed and registered under the Estate Agents Act, despite being exempt from this requirement for buying and selling properties for the Reit. However, Reit managers are still required to be licensed for leasing properties to third parties. Industry players question the CEA's relevance in governing Reit activities, citing the need for a one-size-fits-all approach and the potential for an uneven playing field.

site_title: Apec ministerial meeting ends a day late due to differing views on trade and protectionism
summary: A Pacific Rim trade and foreign ministers' meeting at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) in Da Nang, Vietnam, ended a day late due to differing views on trade and protectionism. The US stalled talks on Wednesday, insisting on changes to language in a communique for Apec leaders, while other nations, including Malaysia and Singapore, expressed concerns on protectionism and the balance of trade. Despite the disagreements, Vietnam's Deputy Prime Minister described the meeting as a "big success" and a "very good outcome" that reflects the interests of all Apec economies.

site_title: Banks up digital offerings for healthcare
summary: Singapore banks OCBC and UOB are expanding their digital health services, offering new ways for customers to buy health insurance through digital channels. This move follows the fintech fervour in the country, aiming to meet customers' needs in the health space. The banks' digital initiatives are part of a broader effort to provide customers with more convenient and accessible healthcare options.

site_title: The machines have risen, but there's no need to panic
summary: Artificial intelligence has become a reality, with machines already displacing some jobs and augmenting human capabilities. The development of deep learning systems, such as those used by Google's DeepMind, has enabled computers to mimic human thought processes and learn from data. While some experts warn of an existential risk, most agree that AI will offer humans the opportunity to enhance their capabilities, rather than relinquish them. The potential applications of AI are vast, including improved hearing aids, speech recognition, and autonomous vehicles. As the machines rise, humans will adapt, and transformative technology will make those who have had parts of their jobs automated more valuable and productive.

site_title: CDL's Q3 profit sinks 8.3% to S$156m on sales slide
summary: City Developments (CDL) reported a 8.3% decline in Q3 profit to S$156.1 million due to smaller one-off gains and lower property sales revenue. Revenue fell 6.5% to S$863.1 million. CDL's Q3 and year-to-date results were boosted by a gain from the divestment of a non-core office building. Executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng urged the government to review the qualifying certificate policy to balance supply and demand in the property market.

site_title: Taylor Swift sticks to a safe space - Tumblr
summary: Taylor Swift has been relatively quiet since the release of her album Reputation, with no interviews in 18 months and only one public performance this year. However, it's not a complete silence, as she has released four songs and two music videos. Swift's strategic rollout strategy is reminiscent of Beyoncé's approach, letting the music speak for itself. The article suggests that Swift is choosing to keep a low profile, possibly to maintain her image and focus on her music.

site_title: Singapore shares inch up on China data
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 2.66 points or 0.08% to 3,423.91 on Thursday, driven by China's strong producer prices and consumer inflation data. The index was weighed down by Jardine group losses, but gains from three banking stocks - DBS, OCBC, and UOB - pushed it higher. Analysts expect a robust Chinese economy despite price pressure, with UOB Kay Hian placing a "buy" call on Singtel's stock.

site_title: Electric cars don't need subsidies anymore
summary: The US House Republicans' proposed tax reform bill would scrap the $7,500 federal tax credit for electric vehicle purchases, sparking concerns about the impact on electric car adoption. Despite initial predictions that the credit would help sell 1 million plug-in vehicles by 2015, cumulative sales in the US fell short, with only 400,000 vehicles sold. The tax credit's effectiveness was further hindered by low petrol prices favoring trucks and SUVs. The proposal's impact on electric vehicle adoption and the environment remains uncertain.

site_title: Apec's cooperative spirit a plus against challenges to trade
summary: APEC leaders, including US President Donald Trump, will convene in Da Nang, Vietnam, to discuss trade and economic cooperation among the 21 APEC economies, which account for half of global trade and 60% of the world's GDP. The meeting aims to address challenges to trade, such as tariffs, administrative red tape, and mismatching standards, while promoting growth and job creation. Despite progress in lifting over a billion people out of poverty, the meeting also faces scrutiny over the fairness of trade and the impact of globalization, with populist movements and technological change posing significant challenges.

site_title: Philippine call centres brace for job losses from AI translators
summary: The Philippine call centre industry is concerned about job losses due to the rise of artificial intelligence (AI) translators, which could dilute the country's advantage in English and replace up to 50,000 jobs in the next 5 years. The industry, worth $23 billion, is worried that AI-powered translators will take over process-driven jobs, affecting the sector's competitiveness. The Philippines has the most call centres in the world, surpassing India. The industry is urging caution and seeking measures to mitigate the impact of AI on its workforce and economy.

site_title: Rooftop farms now allowed under landscape replacement policy: URA
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) in Singapore has expanded its landscape replacement policy to allow rooftop urban farms and vertical greens to replace lost greenery due to development. Up to 10% of the site area can be used for rooftop farms, and vertical greenery and inaccessible green roofs also qualify. The move aims to boost Singapore's food security and support commercial farming, with existing commercial rooftop farms set to benefit from the policy.

site_title: Vietnam Airlines in share sales talks
summary: Vietnam Airlines is discussing the sale of a 4.1% stake to foreign investors, including another airline, as it prepares for a listing on the Ho Chi Minh City Stock Exchange in 2018. The airline sold an 8.8% stake to ANA Holdings last year for $108 million. Vietnam Airlines aims to expand its fleet and improve service quality, with plans to list on the benchmark stock exchange and reduce its government stake to 51% by 2019-2020. The airline expects to see 12% growth in international air passengers and 12% growth in domestic air travel.

site_title: Boosting the triple bottom line
summary: The Singapore Apex Corporate Sustainability Awards promote sustainability efforts in the region, recognizing companies that achieve the triple bottom line of social, environmental, and financial benchmarks. The awards align with the principles of the United Nations Global Compact and aim to raise awareness and adoption of corporate sustainability among businesses. The Singapore Exchange introduced sustainability reporting on a "comply or explain" basis, and the awards serve as a reference point for companies to begin or deepen their sustainability journey. The Global Compact Network Singapore (GCNS) will continue to promote corporate sustainability, forming strategic partnerships and collaborations to achieve its goals.

site_title: Are Democrats getting their mojo back?
summary: Democrats appear to be regaining momentum after the Republican losses in Virginia and New Jersey gubernatorial elections. The losses, combined with the GOP's struggles to connect with key electoral groups, suggest that Democrats are solidifying their hold on urban professionals, educated women, and other demographic groups. This shift could be a turning point for Virginia, potentially transforming it into a full-fledged Blue/Democratic state. The Republican Party's "Trumpisation" may also increase the chances of Democratic candidates winning congressional elections in the 2018 mid-term elections.

site_title: Saudi billionaires said to be moving assets out
summary: Saudi billionaires are moving assets out of the kingdom amid a crackdown on corruption, which intensified with weekend arrests of princes and ministers. The move comes as the country struggles with a slump in oil prices and King Salman's efforts to clear obstacles for his son, Prince Mohammed, to ascend to the throne. The crackdown has prompted investors to sell, pushing benchmark stock indexes lower, with stocks in the GCC region losing US$17.6 billion in value.

site_title: Gain from NetLink Trust IPO masks fall in Singtel's Q2 underlying profit
summary: Singtel's Q2 underlying profit slipped 4.1% to S$929m, despite a record net profit boosted by a S$2.3 billion gain from the sale of its majority stake in NetLink Trust. Earnings nearly tripled to S$2.889 billion, with a special dividend of S$0.03 per share to be paid out. The decline was attributed to Airtel's poor performance in the Indian market, but the telco remains optimistic about regional markets and its associates' growth.

images.alt_text: Shareholders can look forward to a special dividend of S$0.03 cents a share - arising from the sale of NetLink Trust - on top of an interim dividend of S$0.068 cents.

site_title: Riyadh's Ritz-Carlton now a '5-star prison'
summary: The Riyadh Ritz-Carlton hotel in Saudi Arabia has been shut down and its rooms unbookable until February 1, after the Saudi government took over the luxury facility allegedly to house arrested princes, ministers, and former officials. The hotel, which had hosted high-profile guests and businessmen just weeks prior, has been closed and its phone line is unresponsive. The move has been seen as a luxury prison, with some speculating that the detained individuals may be added to the hotel's guest list, sparking amusement among locals.

site_title: The story of a relationship that caused an uproar
summary: Queen Victoria, a 70-year-old monarch, forms an unlikely relationship with Abdul Karim, a young clerk from Agra, in the 1880s. Despite her royal duties, Victoria is lonely and bored, leading to a chance encounter with Abdul that sparks a deep connection. She appoints him as her munshi, causing a stir in the royal household, and the two engage in cultural debates and share simple moments together. The film "Victoria & Abdul" is a revisionist take on real events, exploring themes of loneliness, culture, and the complexities of royal life.

site_title: Kiwi dollar up as RBNZ advances rate-hike forecast
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank (RBNZ) revised up inflation forecasts, now expecting inflation to reach the midpoint of its 1-3% target in the second quarter of 2019, nine months sooner than previously forecast. The RBNZ kept the official cash rate at 1.75% and signaled interest rates may need to rise slightly earlier than expected. The kiwi dollar rose, jumping more than a third of a US cent on the governor's statement. The central bank attributed the revised forecast to capacity pressures and a weaker currency, which will increase tradables inflation and promote balanced growth.

site_title: The allergies of the few are affecting the diets of the many
summary: US restaurants are increasingly catering to food allergies, with nearly 26% of menus now featuring "gluten-free" options. The rise in ingredient intolerance has led to the creation of separate fryers and cooking surfaces for dishes containing common allergens like gluten, nuts, and seafood. Companies like Next Door and The Little Beet have adopted this approach, with some even considering gluten-free essential to "real food." However, experts worry that this trend may lead to a decline in nutrition for the general population, as healthy staples like wheat and soybeans are shunned.

site_title: China October factory prices jump as pollution crackdown squeezes supply
summary: China's factory prices jumped to a nine-month high in October, with the producer price index (PPI) rising 6.9% due to a crackdown on pollution and subsequent commodity price increases. Retail inflation also rose to 1.9%, well within the government's target of 3% for the year. Despite a slowing property sector and financial deleveraging, the economy remains on a healthy stance, with strong domestic demand and services sector growth. Analysts expect GDP growth to soften to 6.7% in the fourth quarter, but PPI expansion is expected to drop later next year.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore stock market analysts UOB Kay Hian have set a 2018 target of 3,530 for the FSSTI index, which could reach 3,730 if corporate earnings exceed expectations. Key stock picks include OCBC, Keppel Corp, and Singtel, while mid-cap gems are Cityneon, GL, and Banyan Tree. Conversely, UOB Kay Hian recommends selling Singapore Press Holdings and top-slicing CapitaLand Mall Trust.

site_title: Clean and green solutions
summary: Local SMEs Neutrinos Engineering and New Resources Technology were recognized for their trailblazing clean technology solutions. Neutrinos Engineering's patented NEUTO Intelligent Hydrogen System reduces vehicle emissions by up to 70-90% and restores engine power by up to 10-15%. The system uses pure dry hydrogen gas and has no chemical waste. New Resources Technology developed advanced battery cell technologies for energy storage solutions, overcoming common challenges such as low energy density and high cost. Both companies are expected to benefit from growing demand for electric vehicles driven by governments' commitments to reduce carbon emissions.

site_title: Siemens flags continued slump in energy markets
summary: Siemens reported a 10% decline in fourth-quarter profit to 2.2 billion euros due to weaker orders for energy-generating equipment. The company expects a slump in demand for turbines and plans significant job cuts at its power and gas division. Siemens also announced plans to merge its rail business with Alstom SA and prepare for an initial public offering of its healthcare division, Healthineers. The company forecasts an industrial business profit margin of 11-12% and modest revenue growth for the coming fiscal year.

site_title: HK housing faces prime threat as banks get squeezed on rates
summary: Hong Kong's housing market faces a potential threat as banks get squeezed on interest rates. The prime rate, set individually by banks, is crucial for mortgage payments.
