summary: Singaporean remisier Joey Choy's trading career was nearly derailed by a S$740,000 loss after a client declared bankruptcy following the 2013 penny stock crash. Choy, who was a new father at the time, took drastic measures, including mortgaging his parents' condominium, to repay the debt. Through relentless hard work, online branding, and video content, Choy rebuilt his career, repaying the debt in 2.5 years and achieving a monthly trading volume of S$1 million to S$2 million. He now runs a training business, inspiring others in the industry.

site_title: Twitter to double tweet limit to 280 characters
summary: Twitter has doubled its tweet limit from 140 to 280 characters, allowing users to express themselves more freely. The change, which was first tested in early September, aims to boost engagement and make the platform easier to use. Despite initial concerns that it may alienate long-time users, Twitter found that most people still used 140 characters or fewer, and the brevity of the platform remained intact. The change is being rolled out in all languages except Japanese, Korean, and Chinese.

site_title: Snap fails again to beat expectations of Wall Street
summary: Snap's latest financial snapshot disappointed Wall Street, with revenue missing expectations and a larger-than-expected loss. The company reported $207.9 million in revenue, up 62% from last year, but below estimates of $235.5 million. Snap's net loss was $443.2 million, nearly four times the size of the loss a year ago. Despite adding 5 million users to its messaging service, the growth was below estimates. CEO Evan Spiegel attributed revenue growth to the automation of ad-buying processes and promised to focus on user growth, content, and augmented reality in 2018.

site_title: Europe: Financials weigh on stocks as "Trumpflation" hopes fade
summary: European financial shares declined on Wednesday amid doubts over US tax reform plans and concerns over European lenders' earnings and non-performing loans in Italy. The "Trumpflation" trade, which bet on rising rates, inflation, and stock prices, has lost momentum. Deutsche Bank analysts stated that the US fiscal policy has been lacking, contradicting the initial expectations after Donald Trump's election. The European markets were weighed down by these factors, resulting in a decline in financial shares.

site_title: Best World revenue notches first dip in four years
summary: Best World International, a Singapore-based direct selling company, reported its first year-on-year decline in quarterly sales since Q3 2013. Revenue for the third quarter ended September 30, 2017, fell 10% to S$46.8 million due to a 46% plunge in Taiwan revenues. However, China market revenues rose 33% to S$26.2 million, and net profit rose 36% to S$12.2 million. The company attributes the decline to increased market competition and online discounting, but remains cautiously optimistic about its profitability for the next reporting period.

site_title: Fair value, divestment gains lift CapitaLand's Q3
summary: CapitaLand's Q3 earnings rose 28.1% to S$317 million, driven by fair value gains from redevelopment projects and portfolio gains from divestments. Excluding one-off items, operating profit fell 18.8% due to lower home sales in China. The group's earnings per share increased to 7.5 Singapore cents, with analysts maintaining a positive outlook for the developer's results, citing improved property market sentiment and asset recycling activities.

images.alt_text: In Q3, revenue was driven by higher-value residential sales, mostly from units at The Interlace (above) and Victoria Park Villas.

site_title: Singapore on right track in using AI for hospitality sector
summary: Singapore is leveraging advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) and robotics to transform its hospitality sector, addressing the country's labor shortage and improving efficiency. Service robots, such as humanoid receptionist Nadine, are being deployed to handle tasks like guest check-in and room service. The use of big data analytics and AI can also help personalize guest experiences, identify trends, and optimize operations, including yield management. The Singapore Tourism Board and National Research Foundation are investing in initiatives to support the development of AI capabilities and solutions, positioning the country as a global leader in the use of technology in the hospitality industry.

site_title: ST Engineering Q3 earnings surge 67.5% in absence of one-off charge
summary: ST Engineering's Q3 net profit surged 67.5% to S$128.4 million, driven by the absence of a one-time S$61.1 million charge for its specialty vehicle business in China. Revenue remained little changed at S$1.62 billion. The company announced S$1.1 billion in new contracts, bringing its order book to S$13.3 billion. ST Engineering maintains its outlook for comparable revenue and profit, with its robotics business expected to contribute significantly in the next few years.

site_title: Singtel Q2 profit jumps 197% to S$2.9b on NetLink Trust divestment, to pay special dividend
summary: Singtel's Q2 profit surged 197% to S$2.9 billion, driven by a S$2.05 billion gain from the divestment of its 75.2% stake in NetLink Trust. Operating revenue rose 6.9% to S$4.37 billion, and underlying net profit fell 4% due to Airtel's performance in India. A special dividend of three Singapore cents per share will be paid out, totaling S$500 million. The company's digital and ICT services now account for 25% of revenue, reflecting positive momentum in its digital transformation.

images.alt_text: Singtel announced a 197.1 per cent jump in second quarter earnings to S$2.9 billion, boosted by gains from the divestment of 75.2 per cent of its stake in NetLink Trust in July this year.

site_title: Brookfield has held early talks about GGP takeover: source
summary: Brookfield Asset Management Inc has held preliminary discussions with GGP Inc about acquiring the stake in the mall owner it doesn't already own, taking the company private. The proposed deal would value GGP at over $20 billion, with a premium of 10-15% above its current share price. Shares rose 16% on the news, with the company's 34% stake in GGP now valued at $20 billion. Talks are at an early stage, and no guarantee a deal will happen, with pricing and ownership stake subject to change.

site_title: Economic diversification a necessity for Saudis
summary: Saudi Arabia's economic recession is a sign of potential upheaval and the need for reform, driven by decreasing oil demand, competition from US shale producers, and rising unemployment. The country's ambitious economic reform program, Vision 2030, aims to diversify the economy through initiatives such as the Future Investment Initiative conference and a $500 billion investment zone called Neom, which will be powered by renewable energy. Crown Prince Mohammed Salman's plans for reform are uncertain, as the initial public offering of Saudi Aramco's state-owned oil giant has been delayed, and the kingdom is courting private investors and the international banking community.

site_title: SIA's transformation programme starting to bear fruit
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has seen a significant turnaround in its financial performance, with net profit soaring to S$189.9 million in the second quarter, up from S$64.9 million a year ago. Revenue rose 5.3% to S$3.85 billion, driven by increased passenger and cargo traffic. The airline's transformation programme, launched in 2016, has enabled it to target different segments more specifically and manage its overall mix of passengers better. Despite competition from rivals, SIA's efforts to transform the group are crucial to keep it relevant and profitable.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand Limited reported a 28.1% year-on-year increase in Q3-17 profit after tax and minority interest to S$317 million, but operating profit fell 18.8% to S$204.5 million due to one-time items.

site_title: ABN Amro ready for impact of new global rules
summary: ABN Amro, the Netherlands' largest domestic lender, expects new Basel IV banking regulations to impact its capital ratios, potentially reducing them by 6 percentage points. Despite this, the bank is confident it can weather the hit, having strengthened its capital ratios to 17.6% of risk-adjusted assets. Its third-quarter net profit rose 11% to €673m, driven by a growing loan book and falling expenses. The bank plans to implement the new rules in December or January, but expects no effect on its dividend policy.

site_title: Oil prices dip on lower Chinese crude imports
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday as Chinese crude imports dropped to their lowest level in a year, but the overall market remains well supported due to Opec-led supply cuts. Brent futures decreased 26 US cents to $63.43 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 30 US cents to $56.90 per barrel. The decline follows a recent rise to an over two-year high. Opec's supply cuts and escalating tensions in the Middle East, particularly between Saudi Arabia and Iran, are expected to support oil prices.

site_title: EU-Arab summit comes at tumultuous time
summary: The 2017 EU-Arab Summit in Athens will focus on economic and political cooperation amidst a tumultuous time, marked by the Arab Spring and European instability since the 2008 financial crisis. The region has experienced significant unrest, including revolutionary changes of power in Egypt and Libya, and demonstrations in countries such as Algeria, Bahrain, and Morocco. The use of social media has played a key role in mobilizing protests, and high youth unemployment rates, particularly in the Middle East, have fueled discontent. The summit aims to address these issues and promote interdependence between the EU and Arab regions.

site_title: Nine mostly non-O&M investors to take S$60m punt on Marco Polo
summary: Nine prominent investors, including Super Group and Soilbuild founders, have pooled S$60 million in rescue financing for Marco Polo Marine, a listed offshore and marine group. The investors will dilute the CEO's family's controlling stake from 62% to 6% in exchange for new shares. The company faces significant debt and liabilities, with S$258 million in debts and S$150.8 million in negative equity. Marco Polo Marine plans to restructure its debt and liabilities through debt forgiveness and settlement schemes, with the goal of turning the company around.

site_title: Chinese insurer in talks to buy newly built HK tower: sources
summary: A unit of China Taiping Insurance Group is in talks to acquire a newly built office tower in Hong Kong, valued at HK$10 billion, from Henderson Land Development Co. The talks come as evidence of buoyant Chinese demand for commercial property in the city, which is the priciest market in the world. This deal follows a recent record HK$40.2 billion acquisition by China Energy Reserve and Chemicals Group of a 346-metre skyscraper, signaling a potential easing of government scrutiny on outbound property deals.

site_title: MMA fighter Angela Lee hurt in car crash, pulls out of Nov 24 title defence
summary: Angela Lee, a 21-year-old MMA fighter, was injured in a car crash in Hawaii, forcing her to withdraw from a title defence on November 24. Lee, who holds an 8-0 record, suffered a concussion, minor burns, and a banged-up body after her car flipped over several times while she was driving to the gym. Despite the severity of the accident, Lee is expected to make a full recovery and will not compete on the scheduled date. ONE Championship founder Chatri Sityodtong expressed gratitude for support from fans and called for "love, prayers, and positive energy" for Lee and her family.

site_title: China's commodities buying slows ahead of winter cuts
summary: China's commodities imports slowed in October, with all major commodity imports falling, ahead of government efforts to curb smog over winter. The slowdown was driven by environmental constraints in various industries, including steel mills and aluminium smelters, which reduced production and worked off inventory. Coal imports fell due to efforts to replace coal with cleaner fuels, while crude oil imports reached their lowest level since October last year. The data suggests that China's factories are clearing inventory ahead of the government's unprecedented measures to curb smog.

site_title: Life insurance industry sees 18% rise in new sales for year to September
summary: The life insurance industry in Singapore saw a 18% rise in new sales for the year to September, with total weighted new business premiums reaching S$2.75 billion. This growth was recorded across all product types, including single-premium and annual-premium products. The industry also saw a 24% increase in policies designed to provide regular payouts during retirement years, with 2.94 million Singaporeans holding Integrated Shield Plans. The LIA president attributed the growth to more Singaporeans recognizing the value of financial planning and insurance for their future.

images.alt_text: Said LIA Singapore president Patrick Teow: "More Singaporeans are recognising the value of financial planning and insurance for their future, and this is reflected in yet another quarter of strong growth for the life insurance industry.

site_title: Turbocharging your company's innovation engine
summary: A company's innovation efforts can be hindered by a lack of comprehensive programs, with many executives investing in dedicated innovation groups that yield modest returns. To develop a world-class innovation program, companies should examine their current features and identify areas for improvement, focusing on the eight essentials of innovation: vision and strategy, intellectual basis, resource allocation, governance, collaboration, creativity, scaling, and organisational capabilities and culture. Companies can learn from examples like Ping An and SoftBank, which have successfully implemented these essentials to drive innovation and growth.

site_title: Craft beer boom drives revival in barley demand
summary: A 100-year-old batch of barley has been revived in demand due to the booming craft beer industry. GrainCorp Ltd, an Australian crop handler, has found a new market for the malted barley, which is used in craft beers. Demand for craft beer has grown by 6.2% in the US, driven by millennials seeking customization and sustainability. The company's single-paddock malt is in high demand for single malt whiskies, with exports from Scotland increasing 3.4% in value.

images.alt_text: GrainCorp, which has a facility in Newcastle, Australia (above), revived demand for ancient barley varieties now used in craft beers.

site_title: It's just lunch, weary remisiers say
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is reinstating a lunch break from November 13, from noon to 1pm, after a six-year absence. However, many brokers, including those at UOB Kay Hian and Phillip Securities, remain indifferent to the return of the break, citing poor business and blaming the SGX for taking it away in the first place. The break was initially scrapped in 2011 to address gap risk and facilitate continuous all-day trading. Despite some positive reactions, the reinstatement is seen as a "nice-to-have" for brokers' welfare, rather than a game-changer.

site_title: Charles Schwab entry in S'pore heralds new era for investors
summary: Charles Schwab has opened an office in Singapore, marking a new era for investors in the city-state. The US-based brokerage aims to provide access to the US market through its proprietary tools and research, offering a simple fixed-fee structure with competitive pricing. With a minimum opening balance of US$25,000, Schwab seeks to attract investors who are restricted by high fees and unfamiliarity with the US market. The launch follows a successful system integration and accounts migration in October, and is expected to revolutionize the investment landscape in Singapore.

site_title: EU and other nations grappling with how to counter offshore tax avoidance
summary: The Paradise Papers leak has sparked a global debate on how to combat offshore tax avoidance and the publication of confidential banking and legal information. The leak, which includes 13.4 million records, reveals alleged ties between wealthy individuals, politicians, and major companies, including the Queen of England and US Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross. The leak highlights the need for governments to address the issue of tax havens and leakage, with the European Union finance ministers calling for a blacklist of tax havens to be drawn up. However, the implementation of such measures is proving difficult, with some EU countries, such as Luxembourg, being criticized for acting as tax havens.

site_title: China SOEs continue to snap up commercial prime HK property
summary: China's state-owned enterprises (SOEs) are aggressively acquiring prime Hong Kong commercial properties, with the latest record-breaking sale of The Center skyscraper valued at over $5 billion. Analysts attribute the move to Beijing's strategy to tighten its grip on the territory, as the city's property market continues to boom. The Chinese government's restrictions on overseas investment have driven mainland cash into the market, with companies using Hong Kong as a base for expansion and to build their international brand. This influx of cash poses challenges for the Chinese Communist Party's internal governance and capital control, as Hong Kong remains a significant loophole in China's capital controls.

site_title: Hollywood wracked by chaos in aftermath of sex scandals
summary: Hollywood is experiencing chaos following a series of sex scandals, including those involving Harvey Weinstein, Kevin Spacey, and Brett Ratner. Since The New Yorker and The New York Times published allegations of Weinstein's serial predatory behavior, over 100 women have come forward with allegations of misconduct ranging from harassment to rape. The scandal has led to project cancellations, film releases being halted, and studios being threatened, ultimately rattling the Oscars. The emboldened victims have now voiced allegations against other powerful men in the industry, causing widespread disruption.

site_title: Increased car sales boost Jardine's Q3 profit
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage's Q3 net profit rose 13% to US$211.1 million, driven by a strong showing from its Indonesian subsidiary Astra International. Revenue increased 13% to US$4.4 billion. Astra's underlying profit for the nine months ended Sept 30 rose 25% to US$499 million. The group expects a positive outlook for the rest of the year, despite concerns over increased competition in the car market and provisioning in certain financing activities.

site_title: Businesses should take the lead in sustainability: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of businesses leading the way in sustainability, citing studies that show it lowers costs and improves operational performance. He highlighted the need for businesses to take up initiatives like the Changi Airport Group's Living Lab program to test innovative solutions. The government also committed to contributing to sustainability efforts, such as aggregating demand for clean energy and setting policy conditions.

site_title: Online travel sites are getting squeezed by Airbnb, hotel chains
summary: Online travel booking sites Priceline Group and TripAdvisor faced significant declines in shares, with TripAdvisor falling 23% and Priceline declining 13.5%, as their industry-disrupting model is under pressure from competitors such as Expedia Inc. The pressure comes after Expedia reported weaker-than-expected third-quarter results, highlighting the growing competition in the online travel market.

site_title: US$ slips on fears over tax reform trouble
summary: The US dollar dropped to a one-week low against the yen due to concerns over potential delays in US President Trump's tax reform plans, which may lead to lower Treasury yields. Senate Republican leaders are considering a one-year delay in the implementation of a major corporate tax cut to comply with Senate rules. This news, combined with Trump's waning popularity, contributed to the decline in the dollar.

site_title: China warning ignored by bond buyers
summary: China's local government financing vehicles (LGFVs) have continued to perform well despite a warning from Beijing to untangle themselves from the sector. LGFVs have sold billions of yuan in bonds, with investors still counting on local government guarantees. The yield premium on LGFV bonds has dropped, but they have kept pace with the corporate-debt market, outperforming government securities. Experts say investors have grown accustomed to negative headlines on LGFV bonds, and there has yet to be a systematic crisis in the sector, leading to continued issuance and reliance on local government backing.

site_title: Ford, Zotye to invest 5b yuan in China electric cars
summary: Ford Motor Co and Anhui Zotye Automobile Co will invest 5 billion yuan (S$1.03 billion) to produce and sell small electric cars in China. The joint venture, equally owned by the two companies, plans to build a new manufacturing facility in Zhejiang province and sell vehicles under a new Chinese brand. The investment is part of carmakers' efforts to meet stricter emission and fuel-economy rules in major markets, including China's upcoming cap-and-trade framework.

site_title: COEs shoot up on zero-growth fears
summary: Singapore's vehicle population is set to freeze from February due to a government plan to cut growth rate from 0.25% to zero. This has led to a surge in COE prices, with cars up to 1,600cc closing at a six-month high of S$47,112, and commercial vehicles at a 15-month high of S$58,036. Motor traders attribute the increase to fears of higher premiums in 2018. The Land Transport Authority has downplayed the expected impact on COE prices.

site_title: F&N FY17 profit soars on fair value adjustment, exceptional gain
summary: F&N FY17 net profit surged to S$1.3 billion, driven by a fair value adjustment and exceptional gain of S$1.2 billion from the realisation of Vinamilk shares. However, net profit before fair value adjustment and exceptional items was down 8.3% to S$100 million. Revenue fell 4.1% to S$1.9 billion, with beverages and publishing and printing businesses impacted by lower sales and rising input costs. A final one-tier tax-exempt dividend of 3 Singapore cents has been recommended.

site_title: China's Tencent takes 12% stake in Snapchat parent
summary: China's Tencent acquires a 12% stake in Snapchat parent Snap Inc, signaling confidence in the social network despite disappointing results. Tencent purchased 146 million shares worth $220 million, or 12% of Snap's equity. This comes after Snap reported a 17% increase in daily users, but a 16% decline in its share price following quarterly losses that tripled to $443 million. The investment could provide a lift for Snap's struggling stock.

site_title: Uber chief lays out new workplace culture, urges workers to 'do the right thing'
summary: Uber's new CEO Dara Khosrowshahi has outlined a new moral creed for the company, urging employees to "do the right thing" and evolve away from a culture of growth at all costs. Khosrowshahi, who took over in August, aims to steer the ride-sharing service away from controversies, including sexism and harassment allegations. He has introduced new workplace norms, including celebrating diverse backgrounds and trimming expensive programs, as Uber prepares for a stock market debut by 2019.

site_title: Chinese insurer in talks for HK$10b building
summary: A unit of China Taiping Insurance Group is in talks to acquire a Hong Kong office tower valued at HK$10 billion (S$1.75 billion) from Henderson Land Development Co. The acquisition adds to evidence of buoyant Chinese demand for commercial property in Hong Kong, the world's priciest market. This deal follows a recent record HK$40.2 billion acquisition of a skyscraper by China Energy Reserve and Chemicals Group, which has sparked optimism that China's government is easing up on outbound property deals.

site_title: Christian Dior chief Toledano to step down
summary: Christian Dior's CEO Sidney Toledano is stepping down after nearly two decades, to be replaced by Pietro Beccari, managing director of Fendi, early next year. Toledano oversaw the brand's expansion, particularly in men's fashion, and was instrumental in firing John Galliano in 2011. LVMH CEO Bernard Arnault credits Beccari with harnessing the creativity of Karl Lagerfeld and Silvia Venturini Fendi, signaling a new era for Christian Dior. The leadership change comes as the brand has doubled its sales over the past five years.

site_title: Malaysia's PNB to issue 2b ringgit green sukuk for office tower project
summary: Malaysia's PNB plans to issue 2 billion ringgit green sukuk for its 83-storey office tower project, targeting completion in 2020. The 15-year tenure sukuk complies with Sustainable Responsible Investment (SRI) requirements and Asean Green Bond Standards. This is the third and largest green sukuk issued in Malaysia, following Edra Power Holdings and Quantum Solar Park Malaysia. The financing facility will be arranged by MIDF Amanah Investment Bank Bhd.

site_title: Fate of TPP, without the US, remains up in the air
summary: The future of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) remains uncertain as 11 remaining nations, excluding the US, meet in Vietnam to discuss the mega free trade deal. Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Kono hopes for an in-principle agreement this week, while Malaysian Trade Minister Mustapa Mohamed opposes re-negotiation, citing a long timeframe. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau emphasizes Canada's engagement in discussions, while Vietnam, the poorest TPP member, seeks to press on with the deal to balance its interests. An agreement could boost the region, but negotiations face challenges.

site_title: Roman temple restored deep under City of London
summary: A Roman temple, the London Mithraeum, has been restored to its original site seven meters below the City of London. The 3rd-century temple, dedicated to the god Mithras, was discovered in 1954 and was previously dismantled and reassembled 100 meters away. The site has been excavated and restored, featuring sound, lights, and a misty haze, and is now open to the public. The temple's reconstruction brings back the original layout, revealing artifacts and insights into Roman London, including a 2,000-year-old wooden tablet.

site_title: US:Wall St slips at open
summary: Wall Street opened slightly lower on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 12.77 points, or 0.05%, to 23,544.46. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 losing 2.71 points, or 0.10%, to 2,587.93. Investors focused on the tax bill debate among lawmakers, with no significant news reported.

site_title: Donald Duck is king in Germany
summary: Donald Duck is a beloved comic character in Germany, with over 50 years of popularity and 5 million copies sold annually. The comic, "Lustiges Taschenbuch" (Funny Paperback), features Donald and his family, and has been translated into German with unique characteristics such as German names and dialects. Hardcore fans, known as "Donaldists," gather to dissect the latest comic and discuss its details, with some even assuming that Duckburg, the fictional city, is real. The comic's enduring popularity cannot be attributed solely to marketing, with experts attributing it to a particular German mentality that resonates with the character's lovable loser persona.

site_title: SMRT chief urges staff to learn from flooding incident, which left firm 'awash in colle]ctive shame'
summary: SMRT group chief executive Desmond Kuek urged staff to learn from the recent tunnel flooding incident, which left the firm "awash in collective shame." The incident, which occurred on October 7, involved a team of six who falsified maintenance records, causing a 20-hour disruption to train services. Kuek emphasized the importance of integrity, ownership, and responsibility in maintaining safe and reliable public transport services. He called on staff to resolve to do better in their work habits, attitudes, and behavior, and to report any wrongdoing.

site_title: Brand Singapore moves into a new era
summary: Brand Singapore has entered a new era with the launch of its best country brand concept, "Passion made possible," in August. The concept, developed by the Singapore Tourism Board and Economic Development Board, has resonated with outsiders, with many foreign visitors finding it "perfectly apt" and referencing opportunities for personal advancement. The initial skepticism from some Singaporeans has given way to widespread acceptance, marking a significant shift in the country's branding strategy.

site_title: FSL Trust sinks into the red in Q3 on impairment losses
summary: Shipping trust First Ship Lease (FSL) Trust reported a net loss of US$21.7 million in Q3, driven by impairment charges of US$22.2 million on chemical tankers and product tankers. Revenue fell 18.5% to US$18.7 million, mainly due to softening rates across all shipping markets. Despite this, the trust generated US$9.1 million in net cash from operations and held US$19.6 million in cash and cash equivalents. The board is committed to refinancing opportunities to ensure the trust's stability and future.

site_title: Marks and Spencer slows food expansion plans
summary: Marks and Spencer, a British clothing-to-food retailer, reported a 2.6% increase in revenue to £5.1 billion in its half-year to September 30, driven by higher sales. The company's net profit after tax rose to £84.7 million, a five-fold increase from the previous year. However, Marks and Spencer plans to slow its expansion of standalone food stores, citing a desire to focus on its core business.

site_title: Canada housing starts, building permits rise unexpectedly
summary: Canada's housing market showed unexpected gains in October, with housing starts rising to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 222,771, exceeding expectations. The condo market, particularly in Toronto and Vancouver, remained strong despite a broader slowdown in sales. Building permits also increased in September, driven by a 12.5% rise in multiple urban starts, and a 3.8% rise in the non-residential sector. Analysts attribute the gains to mild weather and demographic support, but note that elevated activity levels may limit future growth.

site_title: Brazil's tech junkies seek healing at digital detox clinic
summary: Brazil's Delete Institute, a digital detox clinic, treats patients struggling with "nomophobia," a condition characterized by excessive digital dependency. The clinic, founded by psychologist Anna Lucia King in 2013, has already helped 800 people, including students, adults, and adolescents. Patients undergo evaluation, treatment sessions, and exercises to learn healthier digital habits, with the goal of transitioning from abusive users to conscientious ones. The clinic aims to address the physical and emotional consequences of excessive technology use, including neck injuries and social phobias.

site_title: US, Chinese firms sign US$9b in deals during Trump visit
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping signed 19 deals worth $9 billion during a ceremony in Beijing, marking the start of Trump's state visit. The agreements include natural gas and soybean exports, with a focus on addressing the US-China trade surplus, which fell to $26.6 billion in October. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross stated that fair and reciprocal treatment for companies is a shared objective, while Chinese Vice Premier Wang Yang saw economic deals as a key contributor to the bilateral relationship's stability.

site_title: With oil off its hands, DBS needs to fire bigger digital gun
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, has recognized significant allowances in the oil-and-gas (O&G) segment, aiming to refocus on its operating performance and digitalization agenda. The bank's share price has recovered from a slower recognition of O&G sector troubles, fueled by strong buying interest in property and expected rate hikes. DBS has set aside S$1.66 billion for O&G-related losses, with a 25% collateral markdown. The bank's loan growth is guided at 7-8% for the full year, but its digital engine needs new momentum, with a recent API platform launch aimed at increasing digital sales.

site_title: Human-centric innovation a must in age of disruption
summary: New technological breakthroughs are disrupting industries, sparking buzz around AI, IoT, autonomous vehicles, and other advanced technologies. However, innovation remains human-centric, with humans driving the future, not machines. Unlike previous technological advancements, which were initially met with widespread adoption, future innovations will require significant changes in human behavior and work practices. The article emphasizes the need for humans to adapt and maximize the benefits of each innovation, rather than simply relying on technological advancements.

site_title: China sets max loan ratio for new energy car loans at 85%
summary: China's central bank and banking regulator set the maximum loan ratio for new energy car loans at 85% for self-use and 75% for commercial use. The rules, effective January 1, 2018, aim to shift towards new-energy vehicles and phase out subsidies. The loan ratio for used car purchases was raised to 70% from 50%. The move aims to encourage the growth of new energy vehicle sales despite concerns about consumer demand.

site_title: F&N's full-year profit jumps to S$1.3 billion
summary: F&N's full-year net profit surged to S$1.3 billion due to a fair value adjustment and exceptional gain of S$1.2 billion from the sale of Vinamilk shares. This was despite lower earnings before fair value adjustment and exceptional items, attributed to higher finance costs, weaker beverage sales, and higher marketing expenses. Revenue fell 4.1% to S$1.9 billion, mainly due to declines in beverage and publishing and printing businesses.

site_title: COEs shoot up on zero growth fears
summary: Certificates of entitlement (COE) in Singapore surged sharply due to panic buying triggered by the government's decision to freeze the country's vehicle population. COE prices for cars, motorcycles, and commercial vehicles reached 15-month highs, with prices increasing by up to 12.8% for some categories. The Land Transport Authority's plan to cut the growth rate from 0.25% to zero from next February is expected to have a significant impact on COE prices, with traders fearing higher premiums next year.

site_title: Businesses should take the lead in pursuing sustainable practices: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat urged businesses to lead in pursuing sustainable practices, citing climate change as a threat to small island states like Singapore. He noted that sustainable practices lower a company's cost of capital and result in better operational performance, with investor demands and customer expectations increasingly favoring sustainable businesses. The Singapore Apex Corporate Sustainability Awards recognized 10 organizations for their performance and innovation in corporate sustainability, with companies such as Neutrinos Engineering, Armor Asia Imaging Supplies, and Frasers Centrepoint taking home awards.

site_title: Nine white knights pool together S$60m in rescue financing for Marco Polo Marine
summary: Nine prominent business owners, including Super Group and Soilbuild, have pooled together S$60 million in rescue financing for Marco Polo Marine, listing offshore and marine group. The founders will dilute their shareholding to 6% in favor of the new investors, who will also receive board seats. The group aims to deleverage its balance sheet and reduce total liabilities to S$12 million. Marco Polo has over S$258 million in total debts, with UOB being the largest senior lender. The deal is conditional on the group's restructuring plan being approved by shareholders.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas asked to exit Myanmar in protest of Rohingya crisis
summary: Malaysia's state-owned energy firm Petronas has been urged to exit its operations in Myanmar amid the ongoing Rohingya crisis. Over 40 Malaysian MPs signed a petition calling for Petronas to relinquish its participation in Myanmar unless the government recognizes the Rohingya as legitimate citizens and stops persecution. The move comes as Malaysia has expressed strong criticism of the violence against the Rohingya minority. Petronas did not immediately respond to the request for comment, following similar calls from a non-profit group to exit Myanmar.

site_title: Ford, China's Zotye Auto invest US$756m in electric vehicle
summary: Ford Motor and China's Zotye Auto have agreed to invest $756 million in a 50-50 joint venture to build electric passenger vehicles in China. The new venture, Zotye Ford Automobile Co Ltd, plans to produce all-electric vehicles under a new Chinese brand. The joint venture aims to tap into China's booming electric vehicle market, with the goal of introducing innovative vehicle connectivity and mobility solutions for young Chinese customers. The deal was signed during US President Donald Trump's visit to China, with the two countries agreeing on commercial deals worth $9 billion.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit IPO over-subscribed
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit's initial public offering (IPO) received overwhelming interest from both institutional and retail investors, with the placement tranche exceeding its target. The Reit raised approximately US$553.1 million from over 628.5 million units issued, with the public offer drawing 6.7 times subscribed. The strong demand reflects confidence in the Reit's high-quality portfolio and growth opportunities.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks retreat after previous day's rally
summary: Hong Kong shares retreated on Wednesday, following a day of strong gains, as investors took profits. The Hang Seng Index eased 0.30% to 28,907.60, despite upbeat Chinese trade data. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw minor gains. The retreat was attributed to profit-taking, with no major new developments or economic data released that would have otherwise influenced the market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on strong yen
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on November 8, 2017, after reaching a 25-year high the previous day, due to the yen firming against the dollar. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.10% to 22,913.82 and the Topix index dropped 0.24% to 1,817.60.

site_title: Jardine C&C Q3 net profit up 13% on automotive sales, higher commodity prices
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage reported a 13% increase in Q3 net profit to US$211.1 million, driven by strong sales from its automotive business and higher commodity prices. Revenue rose 13% to US$4.4 billion. Earnings per share increased to 53 US cents, and the company's net asset value per share reached US$5.77. Astra International, the group's main profit contributor, reported a 26% increase in net profit under Indonesian accounting standards. Despite concerns over increased competition and provisioning in financing activities, the outlook for the rest of the year is expected to remain positive.

site_title: CSE Q3 net profit down 25% amid struggling oil and gas sector
summary: CSE Global, a mainboard-listed engineering company, reported a 25% decline in net profit to S$3 million for its third quarter ended September 30, due to lower gross margins from the oil and gas sector. Revenue grew 6% to S$85.6 million, driven by a 38.6% increase in the Americas region. Earnings per share slipped to 0.58 Singapore cent. The company expects weaker operating performance for the next quarter and is reviewing accounts receivables and financial reviews. A loss for FY2017 is expected, but the company will remain in a net cash position.

site_title: Swiss Life confirms 2017 targets as fee income, premiums rise
summary: Swiss Life confirmed its 2017 financial targets, driven by a 3% increase in premiums to 13.81 billion Swiss francs and a 6% rise in fee and commission income to 1.04 billion francs. The company cited strong performance in its insurance business and asset management, with CEO Patrick Frost expressing confidence in meeting 2017 targets. This marks a positive outcome for the company despite the challenging global economic environment.

site_title: Best World International sales take a dip, but lower expenses drive profit up 36%
summary: Best World International reported a 10% drop in revenue to S$46.8 million in its third quarter ended Sept 30, 2017, but a 36% increase in net profit to S$12.2 million due to lower distribution and administrative costs. The company remains optimistic about its profitability for the next period and 2017, citing growth in its export segment.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The life insurance industry saw double-digit growth for the first nine months of the year. Charles Schwab launched its Singapore office to expand access to the US market. A commodity trader, Trafigura, introduced an apprenticeship scheme for A-level and diploma holders. Singapore was ranked the fourth most-visited city in the world, projected to surpass London by 2025. Alliance Mineral completed a placement with Burwill Commodity, while Singapore stocks closed higher with the STI up 8.15 points.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Wednesday, with the FTSE 100 index up 0.1% to 7,521.55 points. The DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also gained, with SSE shares jumping 3.5% after announcing a tie-up with Npower to serve 11.5 million customers. The rally was driven by mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Charles Schwab opens Singapore office
summary: Charles Schwab has launched its Singapore office, aiming to provide greater access to the US market for Singapore and Asian investors. The brokerage will utilize its proprietary tools and research, quality service, and competitive pricing to achieve this goal. This move follows a successful system integration and accounts migration in Singapore from optionsXpress, a derivatives trading platform acquired by Charles Schwab in 2011.

site_title: ABN Amro beats estimates with rise in Q3 net profit
summary: ABN Amro reported a 11% rise in Q3 net profit to 673 million euros, beating analyst estimates. The bank's loan book grew while expenses fell 12%, driven by cost-saving programs. The Dutch economy's strong growth also kept loan defaults low. ABN Amro expects to set aside a 50-100 million euro restructuring provision in the fourth quarter, with plans to continue job losses in its retail, private, and commercial banking divisions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 6.74 points lower on Wednesday at 1,744.20, with a trading volume of 2.6 billion lots worth RM 2.1 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 481 to 367.

site_title: Virgin Australia considers going private as profits return
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd is considering going private after swinging to profitability in the first quarter, with underlying profit before tax improving by about A$18 million from a loss a year ago. The airline's domestic business saw unit revenue rise by over 8% and expects continued improvement in the second and third quarters. Privatization could allow minority shareholders to cash out and reduce public scrutiny of its financial performance, which has been weaker than rival Qantas Airways. The board has discussed privatisation, but no outcome has been reported.

site_title: China Literature soars in HK debut after Tencent spinoff
summary: China Literature Ltd., the mainland's biggest e-book publisher, soared 100% in its Hong Kong debut after raising HK$8.3 billion with a majority stake retained by Tencent Holdings Ltd. The IPO price was HK$55, with shares reaching HK$110 before trading at HK$104. The company plans to invest in data analysis, WeChat and QQ integration, and convert popular titles into anime, movies, or games. It had a profit of 213.5 million yuan in the first half of 2017, with 9.6 million works and 6.4 million writers.

site_title: China Oct exports rise 6.9% y-o-y, miss forecast; imports up 17.2%
summary: China's October exports rose 6.9% year-over-year, missing forecasts, while imports grew 17.2%, beating expectations. The resulting trade surplus was $38.17 billion. This rebound in trade performance is attributed to strong domestic and foreign demand. However, global investors are more focused on China's demand for industrial commodities, boosting resource prices worldwide, potentially influencing China's economic growth.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks rise; won down
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 6.96 points or 0.27% to 2,552.40, while the won fell 0.16% to 1,114.27 per US dollar. Bond yields rose, and foreigners were net sellers of 2,880 million won worth of shares. The KOSPI is up 25.6% so far this year, and its price-to-earnings ratio is 12.10. The market capitalization is 1,242.04 trillion won.

site_title: Tencent's online bookstore unit whips up more IPO fever in Hong Kong
summary: Hong Kong's IPO fever intensifies as 417,000 people apply for shares in China Literature's online bookstore unit, exceeding one-in-20 of the city's population. The IPO was 625 times oversubscribed, locking up HK$520 billion, a third of the city's monetary base. This surge in demand is attributed to tech stocks, with China Literature's shares surging 100% on debut. The city's interbank rates have also been affected, with overnight Hibor fixing jumping 2.1 percentage points. This trend is similar to 2006-2007 and 2000, with the Hang Seng Index rallying 32% this year to a decade-high.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher with STI up 8.15 points
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 8.15 points, closing higher, after a morning decline. Investors took profits from the previous day's gains, but Chinese data, showing a 6.9% increase in exports and 17.2% growth in imports, supported the market. Despite ongoing US tariff uncertainty, the STI edged up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Taiwan grounds Mirage jets after plane goes missing
summary: Taiwan's air force grounded all Mirage jets after a pilot, Captain Ho Tzu-yu, went missing during a training mission off the northeast coast. The single-seat Mirage-2000 disappeared 34 minutes after takeoff, with authorities launching a search involving 17 military planes and 10 naval vessels. Authorities say there's no sign of problems or irregularities, and the pilot is described as an "excellent pilot." An investigation into the cause of the incident is ongoing, with no comment on reports of Capt Ho's health.

site_title: Bangalore beats San Francisco in confidence to go digital
summary: Bangalore has been ranked as the top city for digital transformation globally, surpassing San Francisco, according to a report by the Economist Intelligence Unit. The city excelled in areas such as people and skills, financial environment, innovation, and technology infrastructure. The survey of 2,620 executives across 45 cities found that 48% of companies are willing to relocate to Bangalore, with a higher percentage of Asian firms expressing interest compared to the US, Australia, and Europe. This ranking highlights Bangalore's strong digital environment, with a high demand for skills in digital security and Big Data analytics.

site_title: MMA fighter Angela Lee hurt in car crash, pulls out of title defence
summary: Angela Lee, a 21-year-old MMA fighter, was injured in a car crash in Hawaii on Tuesday while driving to the gym. She suffered a concussion, minor burns, and a banged-up body but miraculously survived. Lee was set to defend her atomweight world title on November 24 but will withdraw from the event due to her injuries. ONE Championship founder Chatri Sityodtong expressed gratitude for the support and prayers from fans, stating Lee will make a full recovery.

site_title: Australia shares close slightly higher as materials offset financials gains
summary: Australian shares finished slightly higher on Wednesday, closing at 6016.3 points, just above the 10-year peak. Financial stocks, particularly Commonwealth Bank of Australia, drove the gains, with CBA's first-quarter cash profit jumping 10% and topping analyst expectations. However, materials and energy stocks, weighed by softer oil and commodities prices, offset gains. Mining majors BHP and South32 fell 1% and 1.6% respectively, while New Zealand's benchmark index lost 0.1%.

site_title: Singapore was world's fourth most-visited city, will overtake London by 2025: Euromonitor
summary: Singapore was the world's fourth most-visited city in 2017, with 16.6 million visitors, and is expected to surpass London by 2025, according to Euromonitor. Hong Kong and Bangkok took the top two spots, with 26.6 million and 21.2 million visitors, respectively. The Asia-Pacific region is driving growth in travel, with Chinese outbound tourism playing a key role. European cities, particularly those in the Middle East and North Africa, have profited from unrest in the region, while the US is uncertain due to global unease and potential trade disruptions.

site_title: Bond buyers loving local debt units ignoring Beijing's warning
summary: Bond buyers in China are ignoring warnings from Beijing to distance themselves from local government financing vehicles (LGFVs), which have a high risk of default. Despite a warning from Beijing in April that LGFVs should be untangled from local governments, their yields have dropped to 163 basis points, keeping pace with the corporate-debt market. LGFVs have continued to issue bonds, totaling 634 billion yuan in the third quarter, and investors remain optimistic about their ability to repay debts. Beijing is trying to balance reducing financial risks with avoiding a collapse of the LGFV sector, which could impact the country's economy.

site_title: Nissan slashes profit forecast after announcing Japan recalls
summary: Nissan Motor Co cut its annual profit forecast to 645 billion yen (S$7.7 billion) due to a recall of vehicles in Japan that went through a faulty inspection process. The recall halted production at domestic plants, resulting in a 50% decline in deliveries in October. Shares fell 2.3% in Tokyo trading. Nissan's CEO Hiroto Saikawa faces his first major crisis, amid a broader crisis for Japan Inc, which is reeling from a Kobe Steel scandal.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index increasing 0.44 points to 3,413.54. About 100.4 million shares changed hands, with QT Vascular being the most actively traded counter. The Dow Jones Industrial Average edged into positive territory, while the S&P 500 was flat, and Tokyo stocks opened lower.

site_title: Ex-Secret Service agent in Silk Road probe gets more prison time for bitcoin theft
summary: A former US Secret Service agent, Shaun Bridges, was sentenced to an additional two years in prison for stealing bitcoins worth $11.3 million during a probe into the online drug marketplace Silk Road. Bridges, who had previously been sentenced to 71 months for diverting $800,000 worth of bitcoins, pleaded guilty to money laundering in a second case. The sentencing brings the total prison time for Bridges to nearly six years.

site_title: Move over Mickey, Donald Duck reigns in Germany
summary: In Germany, Donald Duck surpasses Mickey Mouse as the country's favorite cartoon character, with over 50 years of sales success. The comic, "Lustiges Taschenbuch," has become a cultural phenomenon, with dedicated fans known as "Donaldists" who analyze and discuss the series. The character's enduring popularity is attributed to the unique blend of humor, adventure, and relatable flaws, which resonates with German readers. Despite the decline of traditional magazine sales, "Lustiges Taschenbuch" remains a staple on newsstands, with five million copies sold annually.

site_title: Lamborghini tapping MIT to design self-healing electric supercar
summary: Lamborghini is partnering with MIT to develop a self-healing electric supercar, dubbed the Terzo Millennio, which could feature supercapacitors that store energy physically and don't generate heat. The car would be able to continuously monitor its structure and detect wear and damage, automatically repairing small cracks. The concept also includes in-wheel electric motors and a body made from carbon fiber panels that can be used to form the battery. A production model is expected years away, with no price guidance provided.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 4.56 points to 1,746.38. Volume was 61.7 million lots worth RM26.42 million, with 103 gainers and 83 losers.

site_title: Life insurance industry sees 18% rise in new sales for year to September
summary: The life insurance industry in Singapore experienced a 18% rise in new sales for the year to September, with total weighted new business premiums reaching S$2.75 billion. The sum assured for new business increased by 14% to S$92.5 billion. This growth was driven by strong uptake across all product types, including single and annual premium products, as well as retirement products. The industry's growth is attributed to increasing recognition of the value of financial planning and insurance for the future.

site_title: Online travel sites getting squeezed by Airbnb, hotel chains
summary: Online travel booking sites Priceline, TripAdvisor, and Expedia are facing increased competition from Airbnb and hotel chains, leading to declining investor confidence. TripAdvisor's shares fell 23%, Priceline's shares declined 13.5%, and Expedia's shares dropped 2.74% after reporting weaker-than-expected results. Hotel chains are offering incentives to draw customers away from third-party sites, and are recapturing lost market share. To compete, online travel sites are increasing advertising spending. Airbnb continues to dominate the market, with a valuation of $31 billion.

site_title: Gold dips after Monday rally as dollar strengthens
summary: Gold prices fell 0.5% on Tuesday, retreating from its 1% rally on Monday, as a stronger US dollar reduced demand for safe-haven investments. The dollar's 0.3% rise against the euro, driven by expectations of diverging monetary policies, also contributed to the decline. Oil prices dropped after Monday's rally, following an anti-corruption purge in Saudi Arabia. The gold/silver ratio reached its lowest since mid-September, with silver down 1.6% at $16.96 an ounce.

site_title: Craft beer boom driving revival in barley demand
summary: Craft beer's growing demand is driving a revival in barley demand, with Oregon's forgotten barley batch selling for a high price. GrainCorp Ltd, an Australian crop handler, is reviving ancient barley varieties to meet the demand for specialty brews. The company's US$655 million acquisition of United Malt Holdings in 2009 marked a major move into malt, and it has since expanded its operations. Demand for craft beer is expected to continue growing, with North America leading the revival, and is also spreading to India and China.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks rise, won down
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 1.82 points or 0.07% to 2,547.26 at 01.13 GMT on November 8, 2017. The won fell 0.14% to 1,114.5 per US dollar, while bond yields rose. The Kospi has risen 25.6% this year and 5.26% in the past 30 days. Foreigners were net buyers of 23,935 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Commodity trader Trafigura to start apprenticeship scheme for A-level, diploma holders
summary: Global commodity trader Trafigura has launched a one-year apprenticeship program for A-level and diploma holders, starting January 2018. The program, supported by IE Singapore, aims to provide a pathway to the world of commodity trading. Participants will be assigned to business operations units and could earn a place on Trafigura's two-year graduate program. The program builds on existing ties with higher learning institutions to boost the talent pipeline in international trade, according to Senior Parliamentary Secretary for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling.

site_title: Uber chief urges workers to 'do the right thing'
summary: Uber's newly-installed chief, Dara Khosrowshahi, urged employees to "do the right thing" in a message, as the company moves away from its "growth at all costs" era. Khosrowshahi stated that Uber's culture needs to evolve to prioritize responsible growth. This comes amid controversy surrounding the company, with no specific changes or actions mentioned in the message. The tone suggests a shift towards a more responsible approach, but details remain unclear.

site_title: New York mayor de Blasio wins re-election in widely expected result
summary: New York City mayor Bill de Blasio won a decisive re-election victory, securing nearly 65% of the vote and a margin of 35 percentage points over Republican opponent Nicole Malliotakis. De Blasio, a progressive liberal, campaigned on his efforts to increase affordable housing and maintain the city's historically low crime rates. He positioned himself as a vocal critic of President Donald Trump, who received strong disapproval ratings from voters in the city. De Blasio's victory was widely expected, with opinion polls showing him holding a comfortable lead before Election Day.

images.alt_text: Democratic New York City mayor Bill de Blasio scored a decisive victory on Tuesday in his bid to secure a second four-year term in charge of the United States' biggest city.

site_title: Asia: Traders cautious, rally checked by profit-taking
summary: Asian traders are moving cautiously on Wednesday, as a rally in world equities is being checked by profit-taking and lingering Middle East tension. US President Donald Trump's regional tour continues, with a meeting with Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping in Beijing. Despite optimism about the global economy and positive earnings, traders are watching for discussions on trade, a thorny issue between the two countries since Trump's election. The rally in Singapore stocks has been extended, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday, but investors remain cautious due to tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Texas church shooter once escaped mental hospital, made threats
summary: A 26-year-old gunman, Devin Patrick Kelley, killed 26 people, including an unborn child, at a Texas church in 2017. Kelley had previously escaped from a mental hospital and made death threats against his military superiors while serving in the US Air Force. He was court-martialed for assaulting his wife and stepchild, and received a bad conduct discharge. Kelley's phone has been recovered by the FBI, but they have been unable to access it due to increased encryption and password protection. The motive behind the attack is believed to be related to a "domestic situation."

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as yen rises
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on November 8, 2017, as the yen strengthened against the dollar, causing the Nikkei 225 index to fall 0.53% and the Topix index to drop 0.30%. This follows a 25-year high the previous day. The decline was attributed to a loss of momentum in the US stock market, which had seen a rally in recent days.

site_title: Trump aborts surprise visit to Korean DMZ
summary: US President Donald Trump was forced to abandon a surprise visit to the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) in North Korea due to bad weather. The visit was meant to be a historic moment, marking the first time US and South Korean presidents had visited together. Trump had previously stated he would not make the trip, but changed his mind at the last minute. The visit was meant to focus on North Korea's nuclear program, but the weather conditions made it impossible for Trump to proceed, leaving him "pretty frustrated".

site_title: Waymo cars taking to the road without drivers
summary: Waymo, a subsidiary of Alphabet, has begun testing self-driving cars in fully autonomous mode without a driver on public roads in the Phoenix area. After eight years of development, the company plans to launch an automated ride service, potentially eliminating car ownership. Waymo employees will initially test the service, with public invitations to follow in the coming months. The company has logged over 3.5 million miles of autonomous driving and is ahead in the competitive ride-sharing market, with established automakers and ride-sharing groups also developing autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Australia: Shares pressured by materials, CBA shines after results; NZ lower
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% on Wednesday, weighed down by basic materials and energy firms, but Commonwealth Bank of Australia's strong quarterly earnings lifted its stock, limiting losses. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 10.24 points to 6,004.1. Basic material stocks, including BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, declined due to sharp drops in metal prices. Energy stocks also fell, while financials stocks provided some support, with Commonwealth Bank gaining 2%. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.8%.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, CapitaLand, OKP, SIA, Perennial
summary: ST Engineering's third-quarter net profit surged 67.5% to S$128.4 million, driven by the absence of a one-time charge for its Chinese business. CapitaLand's earnings rose 28% to S$316.95 million, boosted by fair value and portfolio gains. OKP Holdings' net profit plummeted 62.4% to S$742,000 due to an accident at one of its worksites. Singapore Airlines' Q2 net profit nearly tripled to S$189.9 million, while Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a substantial jump in its net profit to S$16.9 million.

site_title: US Senate panel targets Chinese banks with North Korea sanctions
summary: The US Senate Banking Committee has unanimously backed new sanctions targeting Chinese banks that do business with North Korea, as President Donald Trump visits Beijing. The "Otto Warmbier Banking Restrictions Involving North Korea (BRINK) Act" will strengthen existing sanctions and target foreign financial institutions in China and elsewhere that provide services to those subject to North Korea-related sanctions. The bill aims to increase pressure on Pyongyang and is seen as a step towards President Trump's goal of pressuring China to tighten its stance on North Korea.

site_title: New Zealand's six-toed 'First Cat' Paddles dies
summary: New Zealand's Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern's cat, Paddles, a ginger cat known for having six toes, has died after being hit by a car on November 7, 2017. Paddles' owner, Ardern, announced the news on November 8, 2017, prompting an outpouring of grief on social media. The cat's rise to fame mirrored Ardern's rapid rise to the prime ministership, which began in August 2017. Paddles' social media following and adorable appearance made her a beloved figure in New Zealand, and her passing was met with widespread sadness.

site_title: Alliance Mineral completes placement to Burwill Commodity
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets Limited has completed a placement with Burwill Commodity Limited, issuing 17.9 million shares to the Hong Kong-listed firm for A$19.575 million. The placement, which represents 15.56% of Alliance Mineral's existing share capital, will primarily fund operational and capital expenditure for its Bald Hill project. The number of issued and paid-up ordinary shares has increased to 555.6 million. The shares were issued in four tranches at discounts of up to 10% of the stock's volume-weighted average price of 29.72 Singapore cents.

site_title: US charges five in Rolls-Royce bribery probe
summary: The US has charged five individuals in a bribery probe involving Rolls-Royce, accusing them of conspiring to pay bribes to win energy-related contracts in Kazakhstan. The charges, part of a larger $800 million settlement, follow guilty pleas from four others. The defendants, including Petros Contoguris of Greece and former Rolls-Royce executive James Finley, are accused of violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The case marks another step towards holding individuals accountable for corporate crimes, according to US Justice Department officials.

site_title: Snap shares dive as loss widens
summary: Snapchat's parent company Snap shares plummeted 16% to $12.58 after reporting a widened loss of $443 million in the third quarter, tripling from the same period last year. Revenue rose to $207.9 million, but daily user numbers fell short of market expectations at 178 million, a 17% increase from the same quarter last year. The company needs to show strong growth to keep pace in the rapidly evolving social media sector dominated by Facebook.

site_title: Troubled fashion label Lanvin to get a makeover
summary: French fashion house Lanvin, founded in 1889, is set to undergo a relaunch by the end of the year. The brand, which has been in turmoil since the departure of designer Alber Elbaz two years ago, will expand into accessories and luxury goods under new designer Olivier Lapidus. Owner Shaw-Lan Wang is funding the turnaround with a fresh cash injection, and the company has no debt. Lapidus aims to revive the label's evening and wedding dresses, while also introducing luxury lifestyle products and decoration.

images.alt_text: Troubled French fashion house Lanvin is to be relaunched before the end of the year, with plans to expand into accessories and other luxury goods, the label told AFP on Tuesday.

site_title: Top US court rejects Samsung appeal of patent loss to Apple
summary: The US Supreme Court has declined to hear Samsung's appeal of a lower court ruling that reinstated a jury award of $120 million in favor of Apple over patent infringement. The 2016 ruling by the US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit upheld a verdict that found Samsung Electronics infringed on Apple's patents for iPhone features. The decision leaves the lower court ruling in place, affirming Apple's victory in the long-standing patent dispute between the two companies.

site_title: Twitter to roll out 280-character tweets worldwide
summary: Twitter is rolling out 280-character tweets worldwide after a successful test in September, where users spent less time editing and were less likely to abandon their tweets. Users posting in languages not prone to "cramming" will remain at 140 characters. The company did not announce a specific launch date for the new feature.

site_title: In a democracy, there can be no bystanders
summary: A senator announced plans to leave office, sparking a nationwide outpouring of letters and calls expressing deep concern over the country's leadership. Many wrote to express gratitude for the senator's willingness to speak out against the current president, who they see as divisive and careless with the nation's institutions and liberty. The senator received thousands of letters, each with a sense of urgency and distress, with many urging them to continue speaking out. The outpouring reflects a nation deeply worried about its leadership and the direction of the country.

site_title: ST Engineering Q3 profit up 68% on absence of one-time charge
summary: ST Engineering's Q3 net profit surged 67.5% to S$128.4 million, driven by the absence of a one-time charge for its Chinese speciality vehicle business. Revenue remained largely unchanged at S$1.62 billion. The company's order book remains strong, with S$13.3 billion worth of contracts, and it maintains its outlook for comparable revenue and profit before tax for the year.

site_title: US: Dow ekes out record close for fourth straight day
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at a record high for the fourth consecutive day, finishing at 23,557.23, despite financial stocks sagging. The broader S&P 500 and tech-heavy Nasdaq also saw gains, with the Nasdaq rising 0.3% to 6,767.78. Investors appeared to brush off new US threats, focusing on recent record closes and ongoing trade talks.

site_title: Apple supplier Hi-P 'not a one-man show', says executive chairman
summary: Hi-P International's executive chairman, Yao Hsiao Tung, has emphasized that the company is not a one-man show, citing his own limitations at 77 years old. Tung introduced a new chief operating officer to delegate tasks and build a foundation for future growth. This move comes as Tung prepares to test potential successors, with the possibility of a "pipeline" of candidates.

site_title: Perennial's Q3 profit boosted by UEL stake
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a Q3 net profit of S$16.9 million, a significant boost from S$425,000 the previous year, due to the effective share of results from associate company Yanlord Perennial Investment's acquisition of United Engineers (UEL) shares. Revenue slumped 42% year-on-year to S$20.4 million, but was partially offset by higher management business income from the UEL transaction. Perennial plans to continue investing and exploring opportunities for new investments, with its healthcare assets in China expected to remain resilient.

site_title: CapitaLand posts 28% rise in Q3 profit on fair value, portfolio gains
summary: CapitaLand, a real estate giant, reported a 28% rise in Q3 profit to S$316.95 million, driven by fair value gains and portfolio gains from Singapore and China properties. The company's earnings per share increased to 7.5 Singapore cents. Revenue rose 9.7% to S$1.51 billion, boosted by development projects in Singapore and rental revenue from new shopping malls. The group's operating profit after tax decreased 18.8% due to lower residential project handovers in China.

site_title: New York could seek Weinstein indictment next week: reports
summary: Manhattan's District Attorney Cyrus Vance is preparing a criminal case against Harvey Weinstein, which could be presented to a grand jury as early as next week. The case stems from a credible rape allegation by actress Paz de la Huerta, who claims Weinstein raped her twice in 2010. This is at least the third investigation into Weinstein's alleged misconduct in New York, with over 100 women accusing him of harassment or rape since a New York Times expose in October. Weinstein denies any non-consensual relations.

site_title: Nissan resumes most of its scandal-hit car production
summary: Nissan resumed most domestic car production after Japan's transport ministry approved changes to inspection procedures following a scandal over uncertified technicians signing off on final inspections. A third-party investigation found new evidence of improper training and sharing of test questions with examinees. Nissan is retraining and retesting inspectors and correcting inconsistencies in documents. The company's plants in Fukuoka, Kanagawa, and Tochigi restarted production on Tuesday, with a plant in Kyoto awaiting ministry approval. Nissan's shares were flat in afternoon trade.

site_title: China's Meituan-Dianping mulls US IPO of US$3b in 2018
summary: Meituan-Dianping, a Chinese online platform for ordering food and booking movies and restaurants, is considering a US$3 billion initial public offering (IPO) in the US as early as 2018. The company, valued at US$30 billion, has raised US$4 billion in fresh funding and is looking to capitalize on the current market bull run. An IPO would be the largest listing of a Chinese company in the US since Alibaba's US$25 billion float in 2014, and would give Meituan-Dianping access to additional funding for investments in offline retail and artificial intelligence technology.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: DBS Group appointed Lim Tse Ghow Olivier as a new independent director, effective Tuesday. Olivier, 53, previously served as deputy CEO at CapitaLand Limited. The Hour Glass reported a 7% increase in first-half net profit to S$18 million, driven by higher revenue and improved consumer sentiment. The company attributed the gains to the growth of luxury brands in selective markets.

site_title: Emerging-market funds turn away new clients
summary: Emerging-market macro hedge funds are experiencing their ninth consecutive annual advance, with demand remaining strong despite concerns over the withdrawal of quantitative easing. Some funds, such as Pharo Management and Antoine Estier's Amia Capital, are turning away new clients due to high demand. Investors are optimistic about the economic recovery in emerging markets, with forecasts predicting 5% growth by 2019. Macro hedge funds have outperformed broader money pools, with the average emerging-market macro hedge fund making 5% this year, narrowly beating the 4% gain for funds investing across the market.

site_title: Amazon debuts private-label sportswear
summary: Amazon has launched two new private-label sportswear product lines, Rebel Canyon and Peak Velocity, on its website. The lines feature affordable and high-end apparel, including sweatpants, hooded fleeces, and technical jogger pants. The move is part of Amazon's effort to fill gaps in its apparel line-up and generate fresh competition for major sports brands like Nike and Lululemon. The private-label brands are being produced with Taiwanese suppliers, and customer reviews have already started appearing on the site.

site_title: GIC took correct view of developed market equities
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) took a conservative view of developed market equities, reducing its allocation and missing out on a surge in DM equities over the past five years. Second Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong attributed this to high valuations in DM equities, which he believes will lead to lower future returns. GIC's 20-year annualized real rate of return is 3.7% above global inflation, slightly down from the previous year. The government views GIC's performance as creditable, but will review its strategies if there is underperformance in the future.

site_title: RCEP negotiations at critical juncture: Koh Poh Koon
summary: Singapore's Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry, Koh Poh Koon, stated that RCEP negotiations have reached a critical juncture. The proposed free trade agreement involves 10 Asean members and six trading partners, aiming to deepen economic integration within the region. Since its launch in 2012, 20 formal negotiating rounds have taken place, with two chapters concluded. Negotiators are working on market access, investments, and reducing non-tariff barriers, but finding a landing zone acceptable to all parties remains a complex process.

site_title: Oil eases from 2-1/2 year highs, focus on Saudi tensions
summary: Oil prices eased on Tuesday after rising to 2-1/2 year highs, with Brent crude settling down 58 cents to $63.69 a barrel. Tensions between Saudi Arabia and Iran escalated, with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman tightening his grip on power and the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) meeting to discuss production cuts. The US Energy Information Administration forecast increased domestic crude oil production in 2018, and US crude stocks fell last week. Opec members agreed to restrain crude output by 1.8 million barrels per day until March 2018, but Brazil rejected an informal effort to join the deal.

site_title: Staffing company Adecco's Q3 earnings take a hit from culling of brands
summary: Adecco, the world's largest staffing company, reported worse-than-expected Q3 earnings due to a 129 million euro writedown from cutting its brand portfolio from 70 to less than 10. Net profit fell 29% to 123 million euros, missing estimates. Sales rose 2% to 5.9 billion euros, but revenue growth was lower than expected. Analysts were unimpressed, sending shares down 1.9%. The company aims to consolidate brands to capitalize on digital opportunities and give them a clearer identity.

site_title: Building a Smart Nation starts with trust
summary: Singapore's Smart Nation vision aims to build a digital future through trust, but cybercrime poses a significant threat. To uphold digital trust, three imperatives are necessary: strengthening the cybersecurity ecosystem, educating consumers about online risks, and leveraging data science to analyze and make sense of high-volume, high-velocity data. A multi-pronged approach, involving government support, corporate participation, and individual effort, is needed to achieve progress and make the Smart Nation master plan a reality.

site_title: Keeping the focus on human beings, and jobs, in today's AI-driven world
summary: Artificial intelligence is transforming various industries, including finance and banking. 94% of North American trading firms plan to automate foreign-exchange trading operations within three years. In Singapore, a chatbot named Emma has closed over $70 million in home loans since its launch. Companies are leveraging AI and machine learning to combat financial crime. Meanwhile, AI talent wars are intensifying, with China competing with the US and other countries for skilled professionals.

site_title: Europe: Shares pull away from 2-year high, earnings updates disappoint
summary: European shares declined 0.5% on Tuesday, reversing earlier gains, as defensive sectors dropped and some earnings reports disappointed. Despite this, oil stocks were a bright spot. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index reached a two-year high earlier in the session but ultimately ended at its lowest level since August 2015.

site_title: Dollar gains as risk appetite flourishes
summary: The euro fell against the dollar as investors anticipated diverging monetary policies between the US and euro zone. Risk appetite remained high, with the dollar gaining against the Japanese yen and Swiss franc, while emerging markets currencies showed some respite. Despite strong economic data, the euro remained within recent trading ranges.

site_title: Getting students involved in creating spaces
summary: The CapitaLand Young Architect Programme, funded by CapitaLand Hope Foundation, mentored 70 secondary school students from low-income families in Singapore to co-develop sustainable solutions for public and common areas. The programme aimed to engage the public in designing spaces that promote well-being and sustainability. Students from five Community Development Councils (CDCs) participated, with the winning project featuring a void deck with an imagination corner, communal kitchen, and herb garden. The programme's success has inspired CapitaLand to engage the public in shaping real estate and promote sustainable living.

site_title: Hoteliers ambushed by politics in Saudi Arabia, China, US
summary: High-profile hotel owners have been targeted in Saudi Arabia and China, with billionaire Prince Alwaleed bin Talal and Anbang Insurance Group Co chairman Wu Xiaohui arrested on unrelated charges. The arrests have raised concerns about the future of luxury hotels and management companies, including Four Seasons and Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc.
