The platform aims to provide a seamless, affordable, and efficient solution for same-day, on-demand delivery services in Singapore. With a network of hundreds of drivers, Rapido offers automated and streamlined delivery processes, including e-tracking, e-invoicing, and payment. The company's goal is to achieve 2,000 deliveries a day within the first year of operation and become one of the top courier service providers in Asean and beyond.

site_title: Airbus stalwart Leahy to stay on till next month when successor is found
summary: Airbus sales chief John Leahy plans to stay on until a successor is found, with a decision expected within the next week. Leahy's deputy, Kiran Rao, confirmed he would not be running for the post, prompting Airbus to begin a fresh search. Leahy's departure marks a significant change in the company's leadership.

site_title: Smartkarma raises US$13 million for overseas expansion
summary: Smartkarma, a Singapore-based investment research platform, has raised US$13 million in funding for overseas expansion, bringing its total funding to US$21 million. The Series B round aims to boost sales and distribution globally, as the company seeks to capitalize on the growing demand for subscription-based investment research.

site_title: About MORS Group
summary: MORS Group is a 2012-founded organisation aiming to promote leadership and sustainability excellence in Asia. It spearheads various programmes to foster industry peers' esprit de corps and boost business prominence. The group's differentiated value lies in its research and development efforts, integrating with reputable industry players. MORS Group's mission is to create a resilient and united Asia through progressive learning and engagement with stakeholders and employees.

site_title: Da Nang gears up for high-level Apec meeting
summary: Da Nang, Vietnam is set to host the largest gathering of world leaders in its history as the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit meetings begin. US President Donald Trump, Chinese President Xi Jinping, Russian President Vladimir Putin, and Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will attend, along with other leaders from 20 countries. The summit will focus on boosting innovative growth and regional trade, with discussions also taking place on off-agenda issues such as the Trans-Pacific Partnership. The event comes at a complex time, with regional tensions over North Korea and the South China Sea.

site_title: Visitor arrivals, spend up in 1H; uptrend likely to continue
summary: Singapore's tourism industry experienced a boost in the first half of 2017, with visitor arrivals growing 4% to 8.5 million and tourism receipts expanding 10% to S$12.7 billion. Chinese travelers accounted for the largest spenders and source market, with a 10% increase in tourism receipts. The growth momentum is expected to be sustained due to the supportive macro-economic backdrop and the festive season. Economic growth is forecasted to reach 2.8% this year, driven by the services cluster.

site_title: Welcome to the Powell Fed
summary: Jerome "Jay" Powell, a lawyer and former Treasury Department official, is set to become the 16th chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, the world's most important economic policymaker, in early 2018. Powell, a Republican, has spent most of his life in financial markets and has consistently backed outgoing Fed Chair Janet Yellen. His nomination is seen as a continuity of her policies, with the Fed aiming to sustain the economic recovery without fueling inflation. However, some economists warn that interest-rate increases could backfire, particularly if the Republican tax cut overstimulates the economy.

site_title: Hi-P International's Q3 profit up 24.9%
summary: Hi-P International Limited, a Singaporean company, reported a 24.9% increase in its third-quarter net profit to S$38.4 million. Revenue rose 6.2% to S$411.3 million, driven by improved product mix and operational efficiency. Gross profit increased 24.7% to S$68.1 million, with a gross profit margin expansion to 16.5%. The company expects higher sales for Q4 2017 and has appointed a new chief operating officer.

site_title: Westpac posts weaker-than-forecast profit
summary: Westpac, Australia's second-largest lender, posted a weaker-than-expected 3% rise in annual cash profit, with a drop in profitability attributed to finicky consumers and a sluggish economy. The bank's record cash profit of A$8.06 billion ($6.17 billion) narrowly missed analyst estimates. Westpac's net interest margin, a key profitability measure, fell 4 basis points to 2.06%, eroded by increased competition. The bank's shares were down 2.4% following the release of its financial results, with analysts expressing concerns about the outlook due to stagnant household incomes and rising energy costs.

site_title: Singapore banks may be past worst of O&G battering
summary: Singapore banks may have weathered the worst of the oil and gas (O&G) sector's impact, but analysts expect the industry's fundamentals to remain uninspiring. DBS, the only local bank to underperform in Q3, reported a 25% decline in net profit and a significant increase in provisions. The bank's CEO expects consolidation in the industry, while Fitch Ratings analyst Ng Wee Siang believes the majority of large troubled accounts will be classified by year-end. The banks' shares traded lower, but analysts note that their downside risks are becoming more limited as they make additional provisions.

site_title: Cogent minorities unhappy with Cosco's offer
summary: A group of 10 minority shareholders of Cogent Holdings have expressed dissatisfaction with Cosco Shipping International's S$1.02 apiece buyout offer, deeming it "unfair" and "too low". The minority shareholders, who collectively own around 16% of the company, fear that this precedent could be set for other companies to follow. Despite four major shareholders backing the S$488 million cash takeover bid, the minority shareholders have sent a protest letter to Singapore's shareholder watchdog group.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust Q2 DPS up 2.9%
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-HTrust) reported a 2.9% increase in its distribution per stapled security (DPS) for the second quarter, driven by lower net finance costs. The trust's distributable income rose 3.7% year-on-year to S$16.1 million, despite higher retention of income. Gross revenue increased 5.2% to S$58.4 million, while net property income grew 0.8% to S$24.5 million. A-HTrust's shares closed at S$0.885, up 0.5 cent or 0.6%. The trust's H1 2018 DPS was 2.73 Singapore cents, up from 2.67 Singapore cents the previous year.

site_title: Brazil eats into US soybean market share in China
summary: Brazil is expected to win a larger share of China's soybean imports, potentially cutting US exporters' market share, due to a record harvest. Brazil plans to sell around 5 million tonnes of soybeans to China in the fourth quarter, double the amount shipped last year. US soybean exporters rely on the October-December period for 53% of their annual shipments, and a bumper crop in Brazil could leave little time for US farmers to boost sales.

site_title: Kobe Steel execs will decide whether to resign after external probe: sources
summary: Kobe Steel executives, including President Hiroya Kawasaki, will decide whether to resign in response to a cheating scandal involving falsifying product specifications. An external probe is due by the end of the year, and the company plans to release an internal report on Friday. The scandal has led to a global review of product safety and performance, with no identified safety issues. Kobe Steel's shares have fallen by nearly a quarter since the revelation, and the company has pulled its forecast for its first annual profit in three years.

site_title: Genting Singapore's Q3 profit gets a boost from VIP business
summary: Genting Singapore's Q3 profit rose 35% year-over-year to S$143.79 million, driven by a 8% increase in revenue from stronger VIP and premium mass business volumes. Gaming revenue contributed 11% more year-on-year, with operating profit increasing 24% to S$226.08 million. The company's attractions business saw higher average visitor spend, while its hotel business maintained a 93% average occupancy rate. Genting's shares closed at S$1.235, up one cent.

site_title: Exhibiting great leadership
summary: Cityneon Holdings, a 60-year-old events and exhibitions company, is undergoing a transformation under the leadership of executive chairman and group CEO Ron Tan. The company has introduced a new business leveraging intellectual property rights from major studios, such as Marvel and Disney, to organize exhibitions. This shift has contributed to a 15-fold increase in market capitalization, now over $300 million. Tan balances the needs of various stakeholders, including shareholders, management, employees, and clients, by staying disciplined and focused on the company's fundamentals and long-term vision.

site_title: New UK property rental website cuts out role of letting agents, fees
summary: A new UK property rental website, HomeRenter, launched on Monday, offering a fee-free alternative to traditional letting agents. The platform allows tenants to rent properties directly from landlords, cutting out agent fees that have risen sharply due to the affordable housing shortage. HomeRenter charges landlords an annual membership fee of £99.99 to showcase properties, targeting the estimated two million landlords who own fewer than three properties. The site aims to create a happier tenancy experience for both landlords and tenants, potentially challenging traditional estate agents.

site_title: Businesses with a heart
summary: RT&Co, a Filipino professional services firm, was established in 2010 and has grown exponentially in the past seven years. The firm's business model, 'Firm Principles. Wise Solution', emphasizes 'People First', driving sustainable growth for its client base. RT&Co is recognized in the industry for its expertise in due diligence, tax, IT consulting, and advisory services. The firm's value-added solutions have enabled its exponential growth, solidifying its position as a leading authority in the industry.

site_title: BreadTalk's Q3 profit rises 22.2% on lower expenses
summary: BreadTalk Group reported a 22.2% increase in Q3 earnings to S$4 million due to lower expenses. Revenue dipped 2% to S$154.3 million, while net profit surged 139.5% to S$16.8 million. The company closed franchise agreements with underperforming franchisees in China and plans to expand in profitable segments and markets. An interim dividend of one Singapore cent per share was recommended, and new outlets in Shanghai and the UK are expected to generate new revenue streams in 2018.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: KSH Holdings' share price surpassed the target price of S$0.87 by 2.2% due to Singapore's heating-up property market. However, construction remains weak, and the company has no projects ready for launch. Venture Corp's 9M FY17 revenue grew 44.5% year-on-year, driven by a diversified revenue base, and its profit after tax and minority interests jumped 81.5% year-on-year. Manulife US Reit's distribution per unit figures have been adjusted, and its dividend discount model-derived target price is S$0.98.

site_title: Subaru disappoints with Q2 profit, cuts annual forecast
summary: Subaru Corp reported a disappointing operating profit for the second quarter, cutting its annual forecast due to expected lower US car sales. The company sold around 159,000 vehicles in the US, down 7.3% from last year, and now expects to sell around 668,000 vehicles in the year to March, lower than a prior forecast. Operating profit for the full year is expected at 380 billion yen, lower than last year's 410.8 billion yen. Subaru also faces a negative impact of 10 billion yen due to improper final inspection procedures.

site_title: Venture Corp up almost 14% after Q3 results leave analysts scrambling
summary: Venture Corp's Q3 earnings exceeded expectations, with shares rising 13.94% and becoming the market's biggest gainer. Analysts increased their price targets, and investors responded with a buying frenzy. This significant move has left analysts scrambling to reassess their forecasts.

site_title: Indonesian economy still sluggish despite interest rate cuts
summary: Indonesia's economy grew 5.06% in the third quarter, slightly below expectations, as private consumption remained sluggish. The country's growth has stagnated at around 5% since 2014, with consumption growing 4.93% in the third quarter. Despite the recent interest rate cuts, the economy has not seen an impact, with bank lending expanding 7.86% from a year earlier. The government has set a growth target of 5.2%, but President Joko Widodo's pledge of 7% in 2019 seems unreachable.

site_title: NetEase to spend US$11 billion on goods for Kaola e-commerce unit
summary: NetEase, China's second-largest video game publisher, plans to spend $11 billion on inventory from the US, Europe, and Japan for its Kaola e-commerce unit over the next three years. The company aims to capture 24% of the cross-border e-commerce market in China, worth 500 billion yuan by 2021. Kaola will source products from US companies like GNC, Japan, and Europe, with additional funds to be spent on Australia and South Korea. This move is part of Netease's strategy to bolster growth by tapping into local demand for international brands.

site_title: Saudi energy services firm Arkad forms joint venture with ABB
summary: Saudi energy services firm Arkad has formed a joint venture with ABB Ltd to expand its business outside Saudi Arabia, targeting markets in North Africa and the Gulf region. The deal, valued but undisclosed, will give Arkad a foothold in Algeria, Kuwait, and the UAE, as the company seeks to diversify its operations amid lower crude prices. The joint venture, Arkad-ABB SpA, aims to capitalize on Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030 plan to diversify the economy.

site_title: Olayan family puts Saudi IPO plans on hold; decision predates anti-corruption purge
summary: The Olayan family, a major Saudi conglomerate, has put plans to sell shares in local assets on hold due to slow economic growth in the kingdom. The decision predates the anti-corruption purge and may be revived in the future. The proposed initial public offering (IPO) of a holding company with around 20 local units, potentially worth $5 billion, has been put on hold.

site_title: The Lion King roars into 20th year as Elton John hits the high note
summary: The Lion King celebrated its 20th anniversary on Broadway with a special performance featuring Elton John, who made a surprise appearance at the Minskoff Theatre. John performed the song "Circle of Life" accompanied by cast members and played the piano. The musical, which has grossed over $7.9 billion, will continue its run with a free show on November 15 and head to Asia in 2018 with stops in the Philippines, Korea, Taiwan, and Singapore.

site_title: Fuel-guzzling yacht industry takes the plunge into hybrid technology
summary: The luxury yacht industry is shifting towards hybrid technology as consumers increasingly demand environmentally friendly options. Dutch yacht company Heesen showcased its 50-metre hybrid yacht, Home, at the Fort Lauderdale International Boat Show, which can travel at nine knots in virtual silence for approximately 14,484 km using less than 7.5 litres of fuel per hour. Industry experts, such as Thomas Conboy, emphasize the importance of adopting hybrid technology to stay relevant and meet growing societal demands.

site_title: Japan's smaller banks turn to deal-making as loans business dips
summary: Japan's smaller regional banks are turning to mergers and acquisitions as their loans business dips due to a shrinking rural population. Traditional banking culture discourages advising clients to sell businesses, but many owners are now seeking acquisition as successors are scarce. To boost profit margins, regional banks are commissioning deals and aiming to double revenue from mergers and acquisitions to $12 million by 2020. This trend may lead to consolidation in the regional banking sector, with limited resources forcing banks to form alliances and reorganize.

site_title: Qatar Air buys 9.6% Cathay Pacific stake for HK$5.2b
summary: Qatar Airways agreed to acquire a 9.6% stake in Cathay Pacific Airways for HK$5.16 billion, making it the third-largest shareholder in the Hong Kong-based carrier. The deal, valued at S$902.5 million, provides Qatar Airways with access to mainland China, a growing aviation market. Shares of Cathay fell 4.9% after the announcement, but Cathay CEO Rupert Hogg expressed optimism about the partnership. The investment is part of Qatar Airways' strategy to expand its presence in the East Asian market.

site_title: How Michelangelo finally got his due
summary: The Metropolitan Museum of Art's curator, Carmen Bambach, has attributed a 1530 black chalk drawing to Michelangelo, challenging earlier skepticism. The drawing, which was previously attributed to Giorgio Giulio Clovio, features a reclining nude and handwriting that Bambach believes is consistent with the style of Sebastiano del Piombo, a contemporary of Michelangelo. She points to the drawing's incised contours, forceful use of chalk, and similarities to other known Michelangelo works as evidence of the artist's hand. The attribution is part of a larger exhibition of Michelangelo's drawings, which showcases over 130 works from around the world.

site_title: Millions of leaked files shine light on where the elite hide their money
summary: The Paradise Papers, a leaked document set containing over 13.4 million files, has shed light on trillions of dollars in offshore tax havens. The leak focuses on the Bermudan law firm Appleby, which caters to blue chip corporations and wealthy individuals, helping them reduce taxes, obscure ownership, and set up offshore trusts. The documents reveal how Appleby's clients, including celebrities and business leaders, hide their wealth in low-tax jurisdictions. The leak has sparked concerns about global tax evasion and the lack of transparency in the financial system.

site_title: A road worth travelling for Singapore businesses
summary: Singapore businesses are poised to capitalize on China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), a massive infrastructure project that spans over 60 countries and 4.4 billion people. The government has encouraged enterprises to engage in the BRI, but many are hesitant due to concerns over risk-return trade-offs and lack of details. To succeed, businesses must form partnerships, differentiate themselves competitively, and leverage Singapore's financial system, which provides access to financing solutions and a gateway into the RMB market. With the right approach, Singapore companies can unlock significant opportunities and become key players in the BRI development.

site_title: Improving education one school at a time
summary: China Overseas Holdings Limited, a Hong Kong-based property company, has donated over HK$156 million to support the construction of China Overseas Hope Schools in poverty-stricken areas of mainland China. Established in 2008, the company's CSR Committee oversees the donation process and focuses on education development, environmental protection, and poverty relief. Recognized for its charitable efforts, the group has received several awards, including China's Outstanding Charity Contribution Award and the 5 Year Plus Caring Company logo by the Hong Kong Council of Social Service.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson's Stelara shows promise against lupus in study
summary: Johnson & Johnson's Stelara, a biotech drug, showed promise against lupus in a mid-stage clinical trial, with 60% of patients experiencing improvement in disease activity after 24 weeks of treatment. The results, released on November 6, 2017, were strong enough to advance Stelara into larger Phase III testing, and the company's known safety profile provided added comfort. This is the first new treatment for lupus in over 50 years, with the existing treatment, Benlysta, approved by GSK in 2009.

site_title: Transforming lives and communities
summary: Universal Harvester, Inc. (UHI), founded by Milagros How in 2003, prioritizes corporate social responsibility, focusing on education, training, and farmer-business opportunity initiatives. The company has benefited over eight million Filipino farmers through its CSR programs, which also include study tours and exchange programs to promote agriculture technology. UHI has partnered with the Junior Chamber International-Philippines to recognize outstanding farmers through the "Outstanding Farmers of the Philippines" awards. The company has also undertaken projects to preserve historic landmarks, such as the Banaue Rice Terraces, and has sponsored study tours to promote sustainable farming practices.

site_title: The problem with 'the will of the people'
summary: Separatist movements in Catalonia and Kurdistan have exposed flaws in democratic governance, highlighting the need for elected officials to fulfill their duties and for governments to explain their policies. The swift intervention by central governments in both regions has raised questions about the stage at which the "will of the people" should be constrained. The failures of democratic systems, including the 2003 invasion of Iraq and the botched Arab Spring, have led to resentment and disillusionment among citizens. Experts warn that democracy must be balanced with pragmatism to avoid further turmoil and instability.

site_title: Australian realtor McGrath issues profit warning as new rules curb Chinese interest
summary: Australian realtor McGrath issues a profit warning, citing higher taxes and restrictions on Chinese buyers as a major contributor to the slowdown. The company expects full-year pre-tax earnings to be 25% below forecast, with shares plummeting 26% in early trade. The move is seen as a clear indication of impending pain for developers, who have been building units to cater to foreign buyers. New rules in Australia, such as higher taxes and lending restrictions, have led to a sharp pullback in Chinese interest, with deal numbers dropping by 90% according to a Chinese property advisor.

site_title: China offers perks to boost lending to small firms
summary: China has introduced policies to boost lending to small firms, exempting banks' interest income from loans to small firms and rural households from value-added tax from Dec 1, 2017, to the end of 2019. Loans of one million yuan or less will also be free of stamp taxes from 2018 to 2020. The move aims to address China's long-standing issue of lack of financing to small firms, which account for most employment and productivity in the country. The policies are part of a series of measures to support China's credit-starved small companies.

site_title: Citi harnesses tech that helps people do the right thing
summary: Citi launches the Citi Tech for Integrity Challenge (T4I), a global open innovation competition using technology to combat corruption and bad business practices. The program, initiated in 2016, brings together fintechs and corporate clients to develop solutions for integrity challenges. The Singapore Demo Day showcased solutions such as online authentication and financial crime prevention, with award recipients including iProov and identitii. Citi aims to ensure an open architecture and has partnered with large corporations like Mastercard and Microsoft to explore engagement with finalists, with plans to continue scanning the world for innovative solutions.

site_title: Jervois Green up for sale by tender for S$48m
summary: The freehold apartment block Jervois Green is up for sale by tender in Singapore for S$48 million, matching the price of nearby Jervois Gardens. The 8-apartment block, completed in the late 1980s, sits on a 27,356 sq ft plot and is zoned for residential use. Marketing agent Colliers International estimates the land could be turned into a 43-unit development, with each new home around 850 sq ft. The tender closes on Dec 5, with developers potentially attracted by the comparable price and shorter turnaround time under single ownership.

site_title: Women who mean business
summary: Women in leadership positions are highlighted in the article, showcasing their achievements and contributions to their respective industries. Farshila Binti Emran, Managing Director of Pharmaniaga Berhad, led the company to receive the EU Good Manufacturing Practice certificate. Anne Patricia Sutanto, Vice President Director & CEO of PT Pan Brothers, has held her position since 2010 and graduated from the University of Southern California. Yenn Wong, CEO of JIA Group, is a young leader in the hotel business, expanding her restaurant to London and receiving a Michelin star. Dr. Jikyeong Kang, President and Dean of the Asian Institute of Management, has served on prestigious business school accreditation bodies.

images.alt_text: Farshila Binti Emran, Managing director and executive director
Anne Patricia Sutanto, Vice president director & CEO
Dr Jikyeong Kang, President and Dean

site_title: Citigroup faces Saudi setback with arrest of billionaire backer
summary: Citigroup faces a setback in its Saudi Arabia business after billionaire backer Prince Alwaleed bin Talal's arrest in an anti-corruption drive. The prince, who has held Citigroup shares since 1991, was detained without disclosure of the allegations. The arrest is likely to make it more difficult for Citigroup to operate in the kingdom due to concerns over association with companies and individuals involved in the crackdown. Despite this, Citigroup aims to rebuild its presence in the country, with a new licence in place since April and plans to appoint a new head to oversee its business.

site_title: Recent en bloc sales do not mean higher prices: Lawrence Wong
summary: National Development Minister Lawrence Wong said recent en-bloc sales in Singapore will not necessarily lead to higher prices due to demand and supply forces in the market, including the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD). Developers are subject to selling new units within five years or incurring 15% additional duties, which helps keep prices reasonable. The recent en-bloc sales of 2,700 units will increase supply in the market, potentially moderating prices in the next one to two years.

site_title: Panel of ACES judges
summary: The ACES Awards, recognizing Asia's finest conscientious trailblazers in good governance, sustainability, and novelty, has highlighted exemplary companies that are driving change through integration of economic, environmental, and social impacts. The panel of judges emphasized the need for public-private partnerships and the importance of leaders who mobilize their people and unleash their competence. The 41 winners demonstrated strong leadership, engaging in conversation for learning and possibility, and seeking new ways to solve problems, ultimately creating a culture of action-orientated entrepreneurship.

site_title: Soilbuild, Super families to help refloat Marco Polo
summary: Singapore-based companies Soilbuild and Super Group are investing $60 million in Marco Polo Marine, a troubled listed group, as part of a restructuring plan. The investment will be used to reduce debt and improve working capital. The Lim and Teo families, who own Soilbuild and Super Group respectively, will emerge as significant shareholders in Marco Polo. The company has qualified for a debt restructuring scheme under Singapore's updated debt restructuring regime, which will be completed if the restructuring plan is approved by shareholders and creditors.

site_title: Asean needs to embrace fourth industrial revolution
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) is set to celebrate its 50th anniversary at its upcoming summit in the Philippines, focusing on "Inclusive, Innovation-led Growth". The region aims to address the challenges of the Fourth Industrial Revolution (4IR) and its impact on job losses, economic inequality, and regional integration. Asean leaders will discuss measures to increase trade and investment, integrate micro, small, and medium-size enterprises (MSMEs) into global value chains, and develop an innovation-driven economy. Embracing the 4IR and inclusive growth is seen as crucial to securing another 50 years of peace in the region.

site_title: DBS misses profit target as O&G inflicts fresh deep wounds
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a quarterly income of S$3 billion, a high for the bank, despite missing its profit target due to a 25% decline in Q3 gain to S$802 million. The bank's oil and gas support services exposures led to a near doubling of bad loan charges. DBS chief executive Piyush Gupta emphasized strong business momentum and digitalization efforts, refocusing investors on the bank's operating performance.

site_title: Eurozone PMIs point to Q4 GDP growth of 0.6-0.7 %
summary: The eurozone's economy is expected to grow 0.6-0.7% in Q4 2017, according to IHS Markit's PMI survey, with solid growth in Germany and France but slowing in Italy. Firms are passing on costs to consumers, with pricing power increasing and output prices rising to a seven-month high. The survey also showed robust growth in the service sector and a jump in employment. This robust growth and increasing price pressures are expected to be welcomed by the European Central Bank, which took steps to wean the eurozone off loose money last month.

site_title: StarHub and ST Kinetic roll out laundry robots in hotels
summary: StarHub has partnered with ST Kinetics to introduce laundry robots, Aethon TUG robots, to hotels in Singapore as part of its "Connected Building" initiative. The robots can automate the laundry process, reducing it from seven steps to three, with minimal human error. The first deployment will be in three hotels next year, with several others expressing interest. This is part of StarHub's effort to provide IoT solutions to boost efficiency and productivity in workplaces.

site_title: Trump's Asian tour an opportunity to boost US engagement with the region
summary: US President Donald Trump's 12-day Asian tour is an opportunity to reassure anxious Asian leaders of the US's commitment to the region. However, Trump's administration has left many observers puzzled with its handling of trade and North Korea issues. Trump plans to focus on free, fair, and reciprocal trade with China and Japan, but lacks a coherent policy towards North Korea and South-east Asia. The US is relying on China to rein in North Korea, but Beijing's limits are clear. Trump's tour offers a chance to reverse the narrative of a US administration less than fully engaged with Asia, but substantive proposals are needed to achieve mutual benefit.

site_title: US: Wall St open flat
summary: Wall Street opened flat on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 8.59 points, or 0.04%, to 23,530.6. The S&P 500 lost 1.81 points, or 0.06%, to 2,586.03, while the Nasdaq Composite added 0.52 points, or 0.01%, to 6,764.95. Investors focused on a potential tech merger and President Trump's comments from his Asia tour.

site_title: Advocates for sustainability
summary: Three Singapore-based companies, Frasers Centrepoint, Sembcorp, and FrieslandCampina Hong Kong, prioritize sustainability. Frasers Centrepoint aims to reduce its environmental impact through greening hardware and software. Sembcorp invests in renewable energy, with over 2,000 megawatts of capacity globally. FrieslandCampina Hong Kong promotes healthy lifestyles through initiatives such as the "Drink & Move" program. These companies demonstrate their commitment to sustainability, reducing their environmental footprint and promoting well-being for users and local communities.

site_title: Institutionalising sustainability
summary: Sustainability has become a norm for corporate institutions, with various frameworks and standards such as the Global Reporting Initiative, Sustainable Development Goals, and Carbon Disclosure Project creating cohesion in assessing economic, environmental, and social data. This shift recognizes the evolving form and purpose of companies, seeing them as part of the community they operate within. By adopting sustainability standards, companies can establish common rules of conduct and improve their overall performance.

site_title: Softbank CEO has hard choices to make on Sprint after failure of merger talks
summary: SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son has ended merger talks with T-Mobile US Inc to combine Sprint Corp with the US wireless operator. The decision comes after Son began to have second thoughts about the sale, citing concerns over giving up control over Sprint, a company he sees as central to his vision of the future. Sprint, which has not had a profitable year in a decade, carries a debt load of $38 billion, with half due in the next four years. Son will need to find an alternative partner or dig into his own corporate pocket to pay for liabilities and network investments.

site_title: PSA to cut Opel models, curb discounts
summary: PSA Group plans to reduce Opel's model lineup and curb discounts, aiming to return the German carmaker to profitability within three years. Under the turnaround plan, Opel will focus on engineering and electrification, using PSA's own technology and vehicle platforms to cut costs and reduce emissions. The move is part of PSA CEO Carlos Tavares' efforts to replicate a similar cost-cutting deal implemented at the French group during a European auto-market slump. Job cuts are also expected as a result of the integration process.

site_title: Caution sets in after US dollar's best weekly rise
summary: The US dollar rose to an eight-month high against the Japanese yen after posting its biggest weekly rise this year due to concerns over US tax reform and a surge in oil prices. Investors took profit amid caution over market expectations, but held back from selling aggressively ahead of the US tax bill's passage this week. Despite a brief spike, the dollar steadied against a broader trade-weighted basket, closing flat at 94.912, and narrowed bond market spreads, which warned of a potential late-cycle rally in the US economy.

site_title: S'pore corporates need more innovative boards
summary: Singaporean corporations need more innovative boards to address the challenges posed by technological disruption. The Monetary Authority of Singapore notes that the financial sector has reached a tipping point, and banks require diverse skillsets, including finance, technology, strategic planning, and human resource management. The United Overseas Bank's recruitment of new directors with diverse expertise, including former deputy prime minister Wong Kan Seng and former HSBC banker Alexander Hungate, is seen as a timely move to equip the board for future growth. However, experts warn that boards still need to go beyond personal networks and gender diversification to remain effective.

site_title: Indian shoe retailer Khadim's 5.43 billion rupees IPO subscribed 1.9 times
summary: Khadim India Ltd, an Indian footwear retailer, raised up to 5.43 billion rupees through its initial public offering (IPO), which was subscribed 1.9 times by the end of the sale period. The IPO, led by bookrunners Axis Capital and IDFC Bank, marks a record year for IPO sales in India, with companies raising over US$9 billion in 2017.

site_title: Trump to Japan: Buy US arms to protect yourself
summary: US President Donald Trump said Japan could protect itself from a nuclear-armed North Korea by buying billions of dollars of American military equipment. Trump made the comment during a visit to Japan, where he met with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. Trump criticized Japan's trade relationship with the US, stating that Japan imports virtually no cars from the US but exports millions to the country. Trump also hinted that Japan's failure to shoot down North Korean missiles that flew over Japanese territory could change if Japan purchases more US military equipment.

site_title: Cosco Shipping Ports to build container freight station in Abu Dhabi
summary: China's Cosco Shipping Ports has been awarded a contract to build a 275,000 sqm Container Freight Station (CFS) in Abu Dhabi, set to open in Q1 2019. The facility will provide various services and connect with Khalifa Port's container terminals. This project follows Cosco's 2016 concession to build and operate a container terminal at the same port, with an initial investment of over $700 million. The new CFS is expected to boost volumes and investor confidence in Abu Dhabi's Khalifa Industrial Zone.

site_title: Vallianz posts more than 400% jump in Q2 earnings to S$5.2m
summary: Vallianz Holdings reported a net profit of US$5.3 million (S$7.2 million) for the second quarter, a 402% increase from the same period last year. Revenue dropped 24.8% to US$41.2 million, mainly due to the completion of one-time vessel management projects. The company's core chartering and brokerage services accounted for 90% of its revenue, with operating profit rising 32.9% to US$5.2 million. The company's shares last closed at two cents and will be issued at 1.6 Singapore cents after a revised rights-cum-warrants issue.

site_title: Singapore stocks get the blues
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.46 point lower at 3,381.85, mainly dragged by banking stocks, with DBS and OCBC reporting losses. DBS's earnings fell 25% to S$802 million, while OCBC's earnings declined 23% to S$822 million. However, Venture Corporation's shares surged 14% to S$21.99 after releasing stellar third-quarter results. The index was also influenced by anti-corruption news in Saudi Arabia and the impending retirement of US Federal Reserve President William Dudley.

site_title: S Koreans hope for revival at China's biggest trade fair
summary: South Korean businesses are optimistic about reviving their presence in China's massive consumer market after a year-long dispute over the Thaad US missile system was shelved. Small-scale exporters, such as Jeoung Young-min's startup Toyoyo, are hoping to break into China's giant economy without trade restrictions and a de facto boycott of their goods. China is South Korea's largest trading partner, with over $246 billion in bilateral commerce last year, and manufacturers are expected to shift towards consumer goods such as household items and skincare products.

site_title: Dangling 30% raises, European banks are hiring from US rivals
summary: European investment banks, including Barclays Plc and Deutsche Bank AG, are poaching personnel from American rivals, offering pay packages as much as 30% higher and guaranteed bonuses in some cases. This move is a reversal from past years, when European firms fired traders and pared balance sheets. The competition for talent may put pressure on all banks as they set year-end bonus pools. European institutions' regulations limit bonuses to twice a person's salary, making them an attractive option for traders.

site_title: Vallianz Holdings' Q2 net profit soars more than 400%
summary: Vallianz Holdings reported a 400% surge in Q2 net profit to US$5.3 million, driven by higher operating profits. Revenue dropped 24.8% to US$41.2 million due to one-time vessel management projects completed in 2016. The company's core chartering and brokerage services accounted for 90% of revenue, up from 68%. Net asset value per share increased to 4.3 US cents.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.36 points to 1,742.29 on Monday, with a trading volume of 3 billion lots worth RM2 billion. The market saw a higher closing price but had 451 losers compared to 429 gainers.

site_title: Strong belief in building customer rapport
summary: Pee Bee Management Services, a Sri Lankan company, has built a strong customer rapport through its focus on understanding consumer needs and delivering satisfaction. With a 60% market share, the company has achieved Superbrand certification and has received various awards. Despite challenges, Pee Bee continues to innovate, doubling production capacity to meet increasing demand. The company measures brand performance using metrics such as market share, brand value, and quality perception, and has implemented below-the-line campaigns to enhance purchase frequency. With over 150 products, Pee Bee aims to remain a market leader in Sri Lanka.

images.alt_text: Mr Kishore Surtani, managing director, Pee Bee Group.The company recently doubled production capacity to meet the increase in demand for its products.

site_title: Trump says Japan could shoot N.Korean missiles "out of sky" if it bought US weaponry
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that Japan could shoot down North Korean missiles "out of the sky" if it purchased US weaponry. This stance is a departure from Japan's previous reluctance to take action. Trump reiterated that the era of strategic patience with North Korea is over, and the US and Japan are working together to counter the country's "dangerous aggressions".

site_title: Softbank Q3 profit tops forecasts; its US Sprint unit faces uncertainty
summary: SoftBank's Q3 profit topped forecasts, with operating profit reaching 396 billion yen (S$4.7 billion). However, its US unit Sprint Corp faces uncertainty after talks to merge with T-Mobile US Inc collapsed. SoftBank's founder Masayoshi Son plans to find a new way to secure Sprint's long-term future, amid a struggling company and a need to fund new investments.

images.alt_text: Operating profit was 396 billion yen for the period ending September, more than the 322 billion yen average of analysts' projections. SoftBank's shares, which are up 28% this year, fell 2.6% to close at 9,945 yen on Monday.

site_title: Abu Dhabi solar plant 'well on track' to start in 2019
summary: The world's largest photovoltaic solar plant in Abu Dhabi, 1.2-gigawatt, is on track to start operating by April 2019, according to Jinko Solar's managing director. The project, developed by Jinko Solar and Marubeni Corp, received a record-low bid of 2.42 US cents per kilowatt-hour. Solar energy prices in the Middle East have set records, with Saudi Arabia receiving the world's cheapest offer for solar power at 1.79 US cents per kilowatt-hour. Improved technology, land availability, and financing have contributed to the reduced costs.

site_title: Malaysia's MBSB agrees to buy Asian Finance Bank for 645m ringgit
summary: Malaysia Building Society Bhd (MBSB) agreed to acquire Asian Finance Bank (AFB) for 645 million ringgit, gaining a banking license in the process. The deal, valued at 1.3 times AFB's book value, will allow MBSB to emerge as a full-fledged Islamic banking franchise in Malaysia. MBSB has sought to become a full-fledged bank since 2014, after previous merger talks collapsed. The acquisition is expected to leverage MBSB's business strength and AFB's banking license.

site_title: London Stock Exchange denies CEO being forced out
summary: The London Stock Exchange has denied claims by TCI, a leading shareholder and activist hedge fund, that it was forcing out CEO Xavier Rolet. The exchange stated it followed a proper governance process and that Rolet was helping pick his successor. TCI had requested Rolet's contract extension to 2021, citing concerns about his departure damaging shareholder value. Rolet will step down at the end of next year, amid a critical period for the exchange as it bids to win a slice of Saudi Aramco's IPO and navigates Brexit's impact on financial trading.

site_title: Gold edges down as firmer US dollar, Fed rate hike concerns weigh
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,268.61 per ounce as the US dollar strengthened after upbeat US economic data, raising concerns of another Federal Reserve rate hike in December. The dollar index reached a three-month high, putting pressure on gold prices. Analysts expect a 90.2% chance of a rate hike, which would boost the US dollar and increase the opportunity cost of holding gold, weighing on prices.

site_title: High Court grants Swissco Holdings an extension of judicial management order
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted Swissco Holdings an extension of its judicial management order until September 18, 2018, allowing the company's judicial managers to comply with the Companies Act requirements. The extension includes a new deadline for a creditors' meeting and statement of proposals, now set for May 14. Additionally, Swissco Offshore's judicial management order has been extended to May 18, 2018, with a new deadline for compliance set for January 17.

site_title: World Class Global sinks into red with Q3 loss
summary: World Class Global Limited reported a net loss of S$1.7 million in the third quarter, down from a net profit of S$2.9 million in the same period last year. The loss was mainly due to increased employee benefits, higher holding costs for properties held for sale in Malaysia, and lower foreign exchange gains. The loss per share was 0.20 Singapore cents, compared to 0.36 Singapore cents in the previous year. The group did not record any revenue from the sale of development properties in Q3 2017.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares recover to end flat
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index closed flat, down 0.02% at 28,596.80, after recovering from morning losses. In contrast, Shanghai's benchmark index rose 0.49%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index climbed 1.18%. The markets largely ignored China's central bank chief's debt warnings.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust's Q2 DPS up 2.9%
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust reported a 2.9% increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) for the second quarter, driven by lower net finance costs. The quarterly DPS rose to 1.42 Singapore cents, up from 1.38 cents last year. Lower net finance costs contributed to a 3.7% year-over-year increase in income available for distribution, reaching S$16.1 million.

site_title: Citigroup faces Saudi setback as billionaire backer is arrested
summary: Citigroup's efforts to rebuild its Saudi Arabia business may face new obstacles after billionaire shareholder Prince Alwaleed bin Talal was arrested in an anti-corruption drive. The arrest, along with former HSBC head Mohammad Al Tuwaijri, raises concerns about the bank's ability to operate in the kingdom. Citigroup had recently secured a new license in April after losing its Saudi investment banking license in 2004. The development could impact the bank's plans to expand its presence in the kingdom as other international lenders also look to increase their foothold.

site_title: Jervois Green up for tender with S$48 million asking price
summary: Jervois Green, a 27,356 sq ft freehold development, is up for tender with an asking price of S$48 million, or S$1,373 per sq ft. The site can be redeveloped into a 43-unit project with approval. Held under single ownership, this allows for a quicker turnaround time for developers. The tender closes on Dec 5, following a similar transaction for Jervois Gardens, another nearby freehold development sold en bloc for S$72 million.

site_title: Rare bomb threats in Japan as Trump kicks off Asia tour
summary: US President Donald Trump began his Asia tour in Tokyo, Japan, despite a rare string of bomb threats. The threats, which were extremely uncommon in Japan, were received by ferry companies and a train operator, but no explosives were found. No arrests were made, and the threats were deemed to be hoaxes. The threats took place far away from the capital and did not disrupt major events during Trump's visit. The incident highlighted the heavy security measures in place during Trump's tour.

site_title: ASL Marine Holdings issues profit warning for Q1
summary: ASL Marine Holdings Ltd announced a Q1 2018 net loss due to weaker operations, citing higher impairments, lower revenue, and poorer margins in the global marine industry. The company warned shareholders and investors to exercise caution when dealing in its shares. This is the second profit warning for ASL Marine in recent months, following a Q4 2017 loss of S$62.4 million. The company's shares closed at S$0.11 on Monday, down 4.3%.

site_title: Growing a global enterprise
summary: Scott Smith, CEO of Singapore-based precision manufacturer Beyonics, has over 30 years of experience in the technology sector. He joined Beyonics in July last year, bringing vertical integration expertise, which he believes is a key differentiator in the industry. Smith aims to grow the company's four core segments by 25% and increase revenues by 40% through expanded client base and merger and acquisition opportunities. Under his leadership, Beyonics is investing in modernizing its manufacturing facilities, utilizing automated processes, and developing a new website to showcase its capabilities. Smith emphasizes the importance of empowering staff, creating a collaborative culture, and aligning interests between employees and customers.

images.alt_text: Mr Smith has empowered his people by allowing them to decide on the core values they want most at their workplace, which is an uncommon practice in organisations.

site_title: Zero growth for car and motorcycle population will not majorly affect COE prices
summary: Singapore's plan to reduce car and motorcycle population growth to zero from February 2018 is unlikely to significantly impact COE prices, according to Senior Minister of State for Transport Lam Pin Min. The COE supply is mainly determined by vehicle scrapping and de-registration, and investments in public transport services will help alleviate the need for car ownership. Eighty new bus routes and 1,000 new buses will be added to the roads by the end of the year, and the government will maintain the existing 0.25% growth rate for commercial vehicles until 2021.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS Bank likely took all oil-and-gas provisions in Q3, its chief stated. Singapore's tourism spend grew 10% in H1, reaching S$12.7 billion. The car and motorcycle population growth plan won't significantly impact COE prices. Swissco Holdings received a judicial management order extension until Sept 18. CNMC Goldmine completed a carbon-in-leach plant, expecting an output boost. StarHub and ST Kinetics partnered to deploy robots in hotels for laundry automation. The STI closed 0.01% lower at 3,381.85.

site_title: Hi-P International's Q3 profit up 24.9%
summary: Hi-P International Limited posted a 24.9% increase in its third-quarter net profit to S$38.4 million, driven by operational efficiency improvements and a 6.2% rise in revenue to S$411.3 million. The company's gross profit margin expanded to 16.5% from 14.1% a year ago, and it expects higher sales in Q4 2017. Hi-P also appointed Yong Inn Nam as chief operating officer to oversee operational efficiency and drive sustainable growth. The company's stock closed at S$2.06, up 7.6% from the previous close.

site_title: Europe: Equities stable at open
summary: Europe's stock markets held steady on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 and Paris's CAC 40 indices flat at 0.1% decline. Frankfurt's DAX 30 index also fell 0.1%. Asian markets were largely flat due to US President Trump's comments on trade practices and China's central bank chief's warning on excessive debt. Despite a weaker yen and positive commodity markets, the twin warnings offset gains from Wall Street's new records on Friday.

site_title: Trump greets Japanese emperor with a handshake and nod - but no bow
summary: US President Donald Trump greeted Japanese Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko with a handshake and nod, avoiding a traditional bow. The meeting took place at the palace in Tokyo, where the four chatted through interpreters. Trump's gesture was seen as a nod to previous criticism of former US President Barack Obama's bow to the emperor in 2009. The meeting marked a significant moment in Trump's visit to Japan, where he is meeting with Akihito, who has spent his reign working to heal the wounds of World War II.

site_title: Dalian iron ore rallies 6% as output curbs lift steel
summary: Chinese iron ore futures surged 6% to their strongest level in two weeks, tracking firmer steel prices after Hebei province exceeded its annual steel production capacity reduction targets. The province plans to limit steel and iron output by 50% in major cities to curb pollution during winter. This move, along with China's output restrictions, is expected to tighten supply and push up prices of raw materials, including iron ore and coking coal. Demand for steelmaking raw material is expected to pick up after the curbs end, according to commodity strategist Daniel Hynes.

site_title: Singapore shares close with STI slightly lower
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended slightly lower on Monday, closing at 3,381.85, due to losses from banking stocks. The benchmark index lost 0.46 points, or 0.01%, amidst mixed trading. Turnover was 2.7 billion units valued at S$1.3 billion.

site_title: Broadcom offers $105 billion for Qualcomm in landmark deal
summary: Broadcom Ltd offered approximately $105 billion to acquire Qualcomm Inc, a 28% premium over Qualcomm's stock price. The deal, valued at $130 billion on a pro forma basis, would make Broadcom the third-largest chipmaker and the default provider of mobile phone components. The combined business would supply components to over a billion smartphones sold annually, surpassing Dell's $67 billion acquisition of EMC in 2015.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Monday with a 1.05% loss, shedding 299.36 points to 28,304.25. Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.06% to 3,369.69, while the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.02% to 1,976.31.

site_title: Texas shooting due to 'mental health problem', not a gun issue: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump attributed the Texas church shooting to a "mental health problem" rather than a gun issue, stating that the gunman was "a very deranged individual" with "a lot of problems." Trump noted that someone else's gun fired in the opposite direction, mitigating the damage.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close flat
summary: Tokyo stocks closed flat on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.04% to 22,548.35, while the broader Topix index fell 0.08% to 1,792.66. Buying was driven by strong corporate results, but selling occurred to lock in profits.

site_title: Genting Singapore's net profit up 35% in Q3
summary: Genting Singapore's net profit surged 35% year-on-year to S$143.79 million in Q3, driven by a 8% increase in revenue and a 24% rise in operating profit. The company's attractions business saw a 5% growth in daily average visitorship, while its hotel business maintained a 93% average occupancy rate. Adjusted Ebitda rose 37% year-on-year, underpinned by improved operating margins and lower net impairment on receivables.

site_title: Australian realtor McGrath warns on profit as new rules douse Chinese interest
summary: Australian realtor McGrath Ltd issued a profit warning due to a sharp pullback in Chinese buying interest for new apartments, resulting from higher taxes and restrictions. The company's shares plummeted 26% after the warning, with earnings forecast to fall 25% below previous estimates. The slowdown is attributed to new measures in Australia, including increased taxes on foreign property transactions, and China's efforts to curb capital outflows. This underscores concerns of an apartment glut and the impact on developers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Monday, rising 2.80 points to 1,743.73. Volume was 122.6 million lots worth RM26.76 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 134 to 42.

site_title: Australia shares inch down as banks drag; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% to 5953.8, weighed down by Westpac's disappointing results and lower-than-expected net profit. The lender's shares dropped 2.2% after touching a month-low. Other "Big Four" banks also declined. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.1% as consumer staples and IT stocks declined. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to hold interest rates at record lows to support a slowing economy.

site_title: StarHub, ST Kinetics to roll out laundry robots at hotels
summary: StarHub and ST Kinetics partner to introduce Aethon TUG robots at three hotels in Singapore, starting in 2018. The robots can reduce the laundry process from 7 steps to 3, using RFID tagging and smart carts, minimizing human error. The partnership aims to streamline laundry processes and alleviate manpower crunch, as part of StarHub's Connected Building initiative.

site_title: Hot stock: Venture Corp up almost 14% after Q3 results leave analysts in the dust
summary: Venture Corp's shares surged 13.83% to S$21.97 after its third-quarter results exceeded consensus forecasts, with a net profit of S$111.4 million and revenue of S$1.06 billion. Analysts raised their target prices, predicting a record year for the electronics services provider, with DBS analyst Carmen Tay setting a new target price of S$26.

site_title: Trump dines on steak in Tokyo, sending restaurant chain Ukai's shares up
summary: US President Donald Trump had dinner at Ginza Ukai Tei in Tokyo's Ginza area on November 5, accompanied by Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and their wives. The dinner at the upmarket restaurant, which serves teppanyaki, included a "special menu" featuring grilled scallops, the restaurant's "best quality" steak, and a chocolate sundae. This led to a 7.3% surge in Ukai Co's shares, making it a standout winner in the Tokyo stock market.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump and his wife Melania with Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and his wife Akie at Ginza Ukai Tei.

site_title: Novartis seeks European approval of cell therapy
summary: Novartis has submitted an application to the European Medicines Agency for approval of its cell therapy Kymriah for two forms of blood cancer: acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in children and young adults, and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) in adult patients ineligible for autologous stem cell transplant. The therapy has been approved in the US for pediatric ALL and is expected to generate up to $1 billion in annual sales.

site_title: Bulls bet banks to push Australia stocks to post-crisis peak
summary: Australian stocks are poised to reach a post-crisis peak as financial and commodity companies drive gains. K2 Asset Management and Eight Investments Partners are betting on earnings recovery amid global economic growth and improving commodity prices. The S&P/ASX 200 Index is approaching its highest level since 2008, with profits expected to grow 6% in the year through June. Despite some market volatility, analysts see the index reaching 6,040 by the end of the year, with some predicting a 9.2% advance.

site_title: Indonesia to probe Subianto, Suhartos over Paradise Papers
summary: Indonesian authorities are investigating former presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto and the children of ex-dictator Suharto for potential tax law breaches, following the release of the "Paradise Papers" leak. The tax office will scrutinize Subianto's financial disclosures against the leaked documents, which revealed his involvement with a Bermuda-registered company. The investigation may impact Subianto's 2019 presidential bid, but analysts say it may not significantly harm his electability.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall, won up
summary: Seoul's KOSPI index fell 8.56 points, or 0.33%, to 2,549.41 at 6:30 GMT, while the won rose 0.1% to 1,114.18 per US dollar. This followed a mild gain in US stocks. The Asia-Pacific shares index dropped 0.20%.

site_title: Lotte gets approval for China property project as bilateral tensions ease
summary: Lotte Corp announced that its major China property project, worth 1 trillion won, received approval from local authorities to start construction, amid easing bilateral tensions between South Korea and China. The approval comes after Seoul and Beijing agreed to mend ties last week, following a dispute over a US anti-missile system. Lotte's retail outlets have been affected by the tension, with many shut down in China, but shares in key units have climbed on hopes of better earnings. Construction at another Lotte project remains suspended due to fire hazard concerns.

site_title: SoftBank profit tops estimates as Sprint merger talks end
summary: SoftBank reported quarterly profit of 396 billion yen, topping analysts' estimates, despite Sprint's merger talks with T-Mobile ending due to control issues. SoftBank's founder Masayoshi Son believes Sprint will secure funding on its own, citing improving finances. Son also addressed concerns about Sprint's future and the $100 billion SoftBank Vision Fund, which aims to invest in technology startups. SoftBank shares fell 2.6% despite a 28% year-to-date gain, and investors will scrutinize Son's strategy for Sprint's future.

site_title: Singapore tourism spend grows at faster pace than visitor arrivals in H1 2017
summary: Singapore's tourism spend grew 10% year-over-year to S$12.7 billion in the first half of 2017, outpacing visitor arrivals, which increased 4% to 8.5 million visitors. Chinese travelers were the largest spenders and source market. Hotel room revenue declined 1.6% to S$1.6 billion, but average occupancy rate rose 1.2% to 85%, offsetting a 1.2% decline in average room rate. Tourism receipts for the second quarter were up 5% to S$6.4 billion.

site_title: 15-year-old girl among Japan 'serial killer' mutilation victims
summary: A 15-year-old girl was among nine people mutilated by suspected serial killer Takahiro Shiraishi in Japan. The victims, including high school girls, were lured by Shiraishi via Twitter, who then murdered and dismembered them. Police found a "house of horrors" with dismembered bodies and bone parts in his apartment. Shiraishi allegedly hanged victims after giving them alcohol or sleeping pills, and may have continued to kill if not arrested. He was arrested after a woman claimed to have arranged a meeting with him, fearing she may have been the next victim.

site_title: Yellen's bequest: A healthy economy but questions over future policy for Fed
summary: US Federal Reserve Governor Jerome Powell will inherit a healthy economy and consensus on monetary policy when Janet Yellen's term as Fed chair ends in February 2018. However, he will also face unresolved questions on inflation, financial market conditions, and recession preparedness. Powell, a 64-year-old lawyer, will have to draw insights from the Fed's network of talent to shape policy, and his decision-making process may be influenced by his Republican affiliation and the current economic landscape. The Fed's near-record economic expansion may last another four years, but policymakers are concerned about persistently low inflation and the potential for a recession.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda says has confidence in strengthening economy, price outlook
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressed confidence in the economy's growth momentum, citing the expansion's sustainability and inflation reaching the 2% target. The central bank closely monitors the effects of prolonged ultra-easy policy on financial institutions and is aware of potential risks, including low bond market volatility. Kuroda's remarks support the dominant view that the current policy is sufficient to achieve the inflation goal, countering calls for further easing from board member Goushi Kataoka. The BOJ's policy framework, including zero-interest rates and bond purchases, will be reviewed in the future.

site_title: China's shadow banking halts as regulation bites, Moody's says
summary: China's shadow banking sector, valued at $25.25 trillion, stopped growing in the first half of 2017 due to declining issuance of wealth management products, according to Moody's Investors Service. This marks the first time since 2012 that China's GDP growth surpassed shadow banking assets. Moody's warns that high debt levels, with government, household, and corporate debt reaching 260% of the economy, pose latent risks. Despite regulation, core shadow banking activity continues to expand, and Moody's believes the formal banking system may not fully replace shadow credit.

site_title: Indonesia's Q3 GDP growth at 5.06% y-o-y, below expectations
summary: Indonesia's Q3 GDP growth came in at 5.06% y-o-y, below expectations of 5.13% in a Reuters poll. This marks a slight slowdown from the first and second quarters, where growth was 5.01%. The government's target for this year is 5.2% growth, while the central bank forecasts a range of 5.0-5.4%.

site_title: Asia: Shares stumble from decade highs, oil hits 2-year top on Saudi purge
summary: Asian shares slipped 0.7% to decade highs, while oil hit a 2-year peak after Saudi Arabia's crown prince's anti-corruption crackdown. The US dollar rallied, with oil prices rising 23 cents to $62.30 a barrel. US President Trump's Asian tour, including meetings with Japanese and South Korean leaders, and his planned visit to Beijing, will influence near-term sentiment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1% on Friday, while Asian shares fell despite gains in Wall Street.

site_title: Death toll from Vietnam storm nears 50
summary: A typhoon in Vietnam has resulted in at least 49 deaths and 27 missing, with nearly 2,000 homes destroyed and over 80,000 damaged. The storm, Typhoon Damrey, made landfall on Saturday and brought heavy rains and floods to central Vietnam, where the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit is set to begin on Monday. Despite the damage, the summit's schedule remains unchanged, with US President Donald Trump and other leaders scheduled to attend. The country is prone to destructive storms and flooding due to its long coastline.

site_title: Tomorrow's petrol station will charge car, feed you in 10 minutes
summary: Circle K in Norway is introducing a futuristic petrol station with rapid charging capabilities, allowing electric cars to charge in under 10 minutes. The station also offers made-to-order food, including burritos, as part of a pilot project to adapt to the growing electric vehicle market. The move is part of a larger European-wide push by carmakers and retailers to transform the industry, with plans for residential charging stations and expanded food services. The goal is to keep customers loyal as electric vehicles become more popular, with Norway leading the way in electric vehicle adoption.

site_title: Taiwan hopes to find 'natural way' to engage with China's Xi at Apec
summary: Taiwan is seeking a "natural way" to engage with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the upcoming Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit in Vietnam, according to Taiwan's envoy James Soong. Relations between Taiwan and China have deteriorated since President Tsai Ing-wen's election, with China viewing Taiwan as its sovereign territory. Taiwan hopes to find a constructive dialogue with China, while China has suspended a dialogue mechanism and increased military drills around the island. A meeting between Soong and Xi is not guaranteed, but Taiwan's participation in APEC as a separate economic entity allows for engagement.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Monday; DBS falls
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Monday, with the Straits Times Index dropping 0.85 points to 3,381.46. DBS Bank fell 28 cents, or 1.22%, after announcing a 25% drop in Q3 earnings. About 71.9 million shares changed hands, with gains outpacing losses 83 to 42.

site_title: Oil hits highest levels since 2015 amid tightening markets, Saudi purge
summary: Oil prices reached their highest levels since July 2015 due to tightening markets, with Brent futures hitting $62.44 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude reaching $56.00 per barrel. Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's anti-corruption crackdown, which included high-profile arrests, has consolidated his power and driven oil prices higher. Ongoing signs of tightening market conditions, including a decline in US drilling activity and an Opec-Russia production pact, have also contributed to the price increase.

site_title: GIC and Australia's Vicinity Centres to swop stakes in mall properties
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC and Australian property group Vicinity Centres have agreed to a property swap. Vicinity will exchange a 49% stake in Chatswood Chase Sydney mall worth A$562.3 million for a 50% stake in GIC's Sydney CBD Centres, worth A$556 million. The deal, set to be finalized in early 2018, will see Vicinity assume management of the Sydney CBD Centres, while GIC will retain management of Chatswood Chase. The transaction is considered strategically significant for Vicinity, gaining exposure to high-quality Sydney CBD centers.

site_title: Qatar Airways to buy 9.6% of Cathay Pacific for HK$5.16b
summary: Qatar Airways has agreed to buy a 9.6% stake in Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd for HK$5.16 billion, becoming the airline's third-largest shareholder. The deal, completed on November 6, 2017, will give Qatar Airways access to mainland China and help the Doha-based company gain a foothold in the region. Cathay shares fell 4.9% following the announcement, with analysts noting the deal may not lead to significant changes in the airline's operations. The investment is part of Qatar Airways' strategy to expand its presence in Asia and capitalize on the growing demand for air travel in the region.

site_title: Australia: Shares dip slightly as Westpac weighs; New Zealand falls
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing at 5,957.8, after Westpac Banking Corp posted a weaker-than-expected net profit and flagged challenging conditions ahead. The bank reported a 3% rise in annual cash profit, but narrowly missed forecasts, leading to a slight dip in financial stocks.

site_title: DBS says likely all oil-and-gas provisions taken in Q3; allowances nearly doubled
summary: DBS Bank's CEO Piyush Gupta stated that the bank likely took all necessary provisions for its oil-and-gas portfolio in the third quarter, with specific allowances for bad debts nearly doubling to S$815 million. Despite a 25% decline in earnings to S$802 million, Gupta expressed confidence in the bank's ability to maintain strong loan growth and income growth, with projections of 7-8% loan growth and 3% income growth this year. The bank's housing loan market share rose to over 30% and total income increased 4% to S$3.06 billion.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, BreadTalk, Yoma, CNMC
summary: DBS Bank reported a 25% decline in earnings to S$802 million for the third quarter, driven by a significant increase in specific provisions for bad debts. BreadTalk Group saw a 22.2% rise in third-quarter net profit to S$4 million, despite a 2% dip in revenue.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher tracking gains in US
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, tracking gains on US Wall Street and brisk corporate results from Japanese companies. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.35% to 22,617.09, while the Topix index gained 0.21% to 1,797.76. The US stock market, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, also reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, supporting the Asian market's rally.

site_title: Most EU firms plan retreat from UK suppliers: survey
summary: Most European companies, 63% of non-British firms, plan to cut back orders from UK suppliers due to slow Brexit talks progress, up from 44% in May, according to a Chartered Institute of Procurement and Supply survey. This move could disrupt British manufacturers with EU clients. British firms are also struggling to secure contracts beyond March 2019, with a fifth of businesses facing difficulties. The lack of clarity in Brexit negotiations has raised concerns among executives, with the UK's finance minister urging a transition deal by early 2018.

site_title: US trade with Japan 'not fair and open' : Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized the US trade relationship with Japan, stating it is "not fair and open". Trump cited massive trade deficits with Japan, which the US has suffered for many years. He expressed a willingness to negotiate trade with Japan in a friendly manner, following a meeting with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. This comes on the second day of Trump's Asian tour, where trade is a key agenda item. Trump's comments follow his decision to pull out of the TPP trade deal, which has unsettled Japan and other signatories.

site_title: New York Fed's Dudley reported to soon announce retirement
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of New York President William Dudley is close to announcing his retirement, potentially leading to a significant overhaul of leadership at the US central bank. Dudley's departure would leave the Fed with three open positions, including the vice-chairman and head of the New York Fed, which could impact monetary policy decisions. Dudley has been a strong defender of the Fed's gradual approach to raising interest rates and has expressed support for reappointment of Janet Yellen, who is set to step down in February.

site_title: SGIX sets up additional point of presence in tie-up with Keppel T&T unit
summary: SGIX, a Singapore-based internet exchange provider, has established a point of presence in Keppel DC Singapore 1, enhancing network connectivity in the country. This partnership aims to reduce latency and operating costs for customers, while providing high-speed global connectivity. SGIX's fourth peering point in Singapore, the move brings additional value to Keppel's data centre services and increases its membership base. The partnership is expected to have no material impact on Keppel's net tangible assets or earnings per share.

site_title: South Korea imposes sanctions on 18 North Koreans, a day before Trump visit
summary: South Korea imposed unilateral sanctions on 18 North Koreans, barring financial transactions with those sanctioned and South Koreans, as part of international efforts to curb North Korea's illegal cash flows. The individuals are affiliated with North Korean banks and have ties to the country's nuclear and missile development program. The sanctions were announced a day ahead of US President Donald Trump's visit to South Korea, but officials denied a connection. This brings the total number of North Koreans sanctioned by South Korea to 97.

site_title: BreadTalk Q3 profit up 22.2% on fivefold increase in core F&B earnings
summary: BreadTalk Group reported a 22.2% increase in Q3 net profit to S$4 million, driven by a fivefold increase in core F&B earnings. Revenue for the quarter dipped 2% to S$154.3 million, while group revenue for the first nine months declined 2.6% to S$449.5 million. The company attributed its success to its dual-pronged strategy of consolidating underperforming operations and focusing on high-performing markets. An interim dividend of one Singapore cent per share was recommended for the quarter, to be paid on Dec 21, 2017.

site_title: Trump says he's 'open' to meeting with Kim Jong Un
summary: US President Donald Trump stated he would "certainly be open" to meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un, contradicting months of fiery exchanges between the two leaders. Trump's comment came after a letter from the US Defence Department suggested a ground invasion to locate and secure North Korea's nuclear sites. This reversal follows Trump's previous Twitter message dismissing Rex Tillerson's attempts to negotiate with Kim. The meeting would mark a significant shift in US-North Korea relations, with Trump's next stops including Japan, China, Vietnam, and the Philippines.

site_title: Japan's smaller banks, desperate for new revenue, turn to dealmaking
summary: Japan's smaller regional banks are turning to mergers and acquisitions (M&A) to boost revenue as rural population shrinks and profit margins are squeezed by low interest rates. Many small business owners in rural areas struggle to find successors, prompting lenders to suggest selling to outsourcing agencies or other companies. Regional banks are now actively engaging in M&A deals, with some aiming to double their revenue from the division to 1 billion yen by 2020. This trend could lead to consolidation in the regional banking sector as banks seek to expand their reach.

site_title: Noble Group to release Q3 results on Nov 9
summary: NOBLE Group will release its Q3 results on Nov 9, warning of a potential loss of $1.1 billion to $1.25 billion. The company's hard commodities division is expected to incur net losses of $50 million to $100 million for the quarter, following a recent sale of its oil business to Vitol Group. Market observers anticipate a potential debt restructuring of over $3 billion. Noble Group has already started talks with lenders to extend a covenant waiver until Dec 20, 2017.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC, RHB to review call on DBS on poorer-than-expected results
summary: Brokerages OCBC and RHB are reviewing their ratings and target prices for DBS after the bank reported a 25% drop in third-quarter earnings to S$822 million. This is below expectations, with core net profit representing 18% of RHB's 2017 earnings forecast. The drop is attributed to one-time items, excluding an ANZ integration cost. The review of DBS's rating and target price may impact the bank's stock performance.

site_title: 26 dead after gunman opens fire on Texas church service
summary: A gunman opened fire on a Baptist church in Texas during Sunday morning services, killing 26 worshippers and wounding 10 others, including the shooter. The motive was not immediately known. This incident marks the latest mass shooting in the US.

site_title: Gold miner CNMC completes carbon-in-leach plant, expects output boost
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings, a Malaysian gold miner, has completed its carbon-in-leach plant at the Sokor project in Kelantan, allowing it to process higher-grade gold ore. The plant, which can process 500 tonnes of ore daily, is expected to boost gold production and optimize overall gold output. The facility will enable CNMC to process higher-grade ore with better yield ratios, surpassing its current heap leaching facility's limitations. Commercial production is expected to begin once operational processes are fine-tuned.

site_title: Sprint, T-Mobile call off merger after months of talks
summary: Sprint and T-Mobile have called off merger talks, leaving Sprint to engineer a turnaround on its own. The two US wireless carriers had discussed a potential combination, but were unable to agree on mutually beneficial terms. The cancellation of the talks may help keep wireless prices low, as the four major US carriers continue to compete for budget-conscious customers. Analysts say Sprint needs to invest more to grow, while T-Mobile is in a better position as a standalone company, with a strong basis for growth in the upcoming years.

site_title: NYC tower builder Moinian seeks up to US$500m in EB-5 funds
summary: NYC tower builder Joseph Moinian is seeking up to $500 million in EB-5 funds to build a $2 billion skyscraper on Manhattan's far west side. He aims to attract investors from China or India, following the federal program's dominance by Chinese investors.
