The company's free cash generation potential will aid deleveraging, with net debt at 155.9 billion rupees and cash reserves at 402.1 billion rupees.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end firmer despite China slowdown concerns
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.3% to 28,603.61, despite concerns over China's slowdown, as investors were relieved by the appointment of US Federal Reserve head Jerome Powell. US equity indexes also gained, offsetting a weak China services sector survey. Most sectors rose, with an IT index gaining 1.4%. The Hang Seng index was up 0.6% for the week, while the HSCE lost 0.4%.

site_title: Cockatoos cost Australian cable company
summary: Australia's $36 billion broadband network, plagued by poor service and slow speeds, faces a new challenge: cockatoos chewing through cables. The birds' voracious appetites have already cost NBN Co $80,000 to repair, with the bill expected to rise. Yellow-crested cockatoos, common in Australia, are attracted to cables, possibly due to their color or position. NBN Co is installing protective casing to prevent future damage, but the issue highlights the ongoing struggles of the national telecommunications infrastructure project.

site_title: Halcyon Agri back in black, records Q3 net profit of US$7.3m
summary: Halcyon Agri has reported a Q3 net profit of US$7.3 million, reversing a net loss of US$12.1 million from the previous year. Revenue increased 157.7% to US$482.1 million, driven by higher natural rubber prices and larger sales volume. This growth was attributed to newly acquired assets and existing operations. The company's discontinued operations incurred a loss of US$469,000.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate, SPH boost their stakes in Chinatown Point
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings and Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) have signed a sale-and-purchase agreement to acquire 5.49% and 3.33% of Perennial Chinatown Point LLP's partnership interests, respectively. The partnership owns the Chinatown Point retail mall and four strata office units. Charles Quay International, owned by an unnamed Chinese individual, is selling off his entire stake in the partnership. This deal marks a boost in stakes for Perennial and SPH, with the acquisition expected to enhance their presence in the Chinatown Point development.

site_title: Singapore shares end week up nearly 2 points
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.81 points to 3,382.31, a 0.05% gain, despite a weak week overall. The gain was driven by expectations of a better non-farm payroll and unemployment data from the US. However, local earnings were weaker, and growth remained modest in China's services sector. Thin trading turnover occurred, with 211 gainers beating 207 losers.

site_title: SIA Engineering Co posts 7.3% rise in Q2 bottom line
summary: SIA Engineering Company reported a 7.3% year-over-year increase in Q2 net profit to S$38.1 million, driven by a 3.7% rise in revenue to S$274.7 million. Earnings per share rose 3.4 Singapore cents. The company's H1 17/18 net profit declined 68.2% to S$74.3 million, but would have been 1.1% higher without the one-time gain from the divestment of its Hong Kong Aero Engine Services stake. An interim dividend of four cents per share has been declared.

site_title: Cosco Shipping Int'l makes voluntary cash offer for Cogent at S$1.02 per share
summary: Cosco Shipping International made a voluntary cash offer to acquire all Cogent Holdings shares at S$1.02 per share, valuing the deal at S$488.07 million. The offer, which represents a 5.2% premium, is intended to gain control of Cogent, a leading logistics service provider in Singapore. The acquisition is expected to leverage Cosco's existing logistics business platform and capitalize on the "Belt and Road Initiative".

site_title: Exxon spending US$1b a year to research green energy
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is investing over $1 billion annually in research for environmentally-friendly technologies, including algae biofuels, biodiesel, carbonate fuel cells, and process intensification. The company aims to reduce its reliance on fossil fuels and is collaborating with universities and smaller companies to develop scalable solutions. While commercial breakthroughs are at least a decade away, Exxon's efforts suggest the company is shifting its focus towards a future where fossil fuels are less dominant.

site_title: Metro, Lee Kim Tah Group tie up with Indonesian group for 1.99 trillion rupiah investment in Bekasi project
summary: Metro Holdings and Lee Kim Tah Group's Shawco have signed a master agreement with Indonesian group PT Trans Corp to develop five 32-storey residential towers in Bekasi, Jakarta, worth 1.99 trillion rupiah (S$200.4 million). This investment aligns with Metro's strategy to expand into East Asia and Southeast Asia. The project will be undertaken by PT Metro Bekasi Investment (MBI), which is 90% owned by Metrobilt Construction and Shawco.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index climbing 0.1% to 7,560.95 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index advancing 0.2% to 13,476.53 points, and the Paris CAC 40 rising 0.1% to 5,513.47 points. The increases were driven by gains in the mining and healthcare sectors.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge up, won wobbles
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 2.04 points or 0.08% to 2,548.40 at 0102 GMT on November 3, 2017. The Korean won rose to 1,112 per US dollar, while bond yields fell. This brings the KOSPI up 25.7% so far this year and 7.89% in the previous 30 days.

site_title: Venture Corp delivers blockbuster earnings; net profit up 135% in Q3
summary: VENTURE Corp delivered a blockbuster earnings report, with net profit soaring 135% to S$111.4 million in Q3. Revenue surged 50.5% to S$1.06 billion, driven by a 65% increase in revenue from products designed by Venture. The company is focusing on technology-based activities and building partnerships to drive growth. It also announced plans to establish three centres of excellence in Silicon Valley, China, and Malaysia. The company is guiding a net profit margin of 6-10% in the mid to long term, with net cash of S$535.1 million at the end of Q3.

site_title: Manulife US Reit's Q3 payout matches expected yield from newcomer Keppel-KBS
summary: Manulife US Reit has announced a Q3 payout of 1.6 US cents per unit, matching the expected yield of Keppel-KBS US Reit, a newcomer set to list on November 9. The Reit's year-to-date distribution of 4.83 US cents surpassed projections by 8.5%, driven by its acquisition of 500 Plaza Drive in New Jersey. If the Reit maintains its pace, it would imply a yield of 7.1%, comparable to Keppel-KBS.

site_title: Kampong Glam to become 1st digitally enabled neighbourhood under Retail ITM
summary: Kampong Glam, a Malay enclave in Singapore, is set to become the country's first digitally enabled neighborhood under the Retail Industry Transformation Map (ITM). The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) will co-develop a digital roadmap to enhance digital capabilities of merchants and transform the visitor experience, with a focus on user experiences and tangible outcomes for retailers. The digital roadmap is expected to be completed in three months, and will include solutions such as improved outdoor wireless connectivity, augmented reality-enabled maps, and a collaborative marketing platform.

site_title: IPhone X resellers make a quick buck on the streets of Hong Kong
summary: In Hong Kong, resellers are capitalizing on the iPhone X's global release, selling the phone at significantly lower prices than its retail value. Card tables and touts are setting up shop along Argyle Street, selling the 256-gigabyte iPhone X for HK$10,300 to HK$10,500 and the 64-gigabyte edition for HK$8,800 to HK$8,900. This is in contrast to Apple's retail price of HK$9,888 and HK$8,588, respectively. The high demand and limited production have led to long queues outside stores worldwide.

site_title: Singapore, China securities regulators to strengthen supervisory cooperation, capital markets development
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and China's Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) strengthened supervisory cooperation and capital markets development through their 2nd MAS-CSRC Supervisory Roundtable in Singapore on Oct 31, 2017. The roundtable aimed to enhance information sharing and regulatory frameworks for derivatives markets. The agreement follows President Xi Jinping's 2015 state visit, which emphasized regular high-level dialogue sessions between the two regulators. This cooperation aims to promote greater understanding of regulatory frameworks in a more interconnected global capital market.

site_title: UOB shareholders' faith in Wee Cho Yaw strong
summary: Singapore's UOB bank chairman Wee Cho Yaw is retiring after 6 decades of service, but will remain a significant influence as chairman emeritus and honorary adviser. Despite his retirement, Wee will continue to shape the bank's direction, with his son Ee Cheong serving as CEO. New chairman Wong Kan Seng, a former deputy prime minister, will take over, but his banking experience is limited. Shareholders remain confident in Wee's leadership, with one investor saying, "I do not see much change."

site_title: Carmakers launch pan-European charging network
summary: A pan-European charging network, IONITY, has been formed by major German carmakers BMW, Daimler, Ford, and Volkswagen to create 400 fast charging stations across Europe by 2020. The network will enable quick charging for electric vehicles, addressing range anxiety, and offer digital payment capabilities. The first 20 stations will open in Germany, Norway, and Austria, with expansion plans for 100 stations in 2018. Each station will have a capacity of 350 kW and use the Combined Charging System, making EVs more appealing to drivers.

site_title: Beijing, Hanoi reach consensus on managing South China Sea dispute
summary: China and Vietnam have reached a consensus on managing their dispute in the South China Sea through friendly talks, with both sides agreeing to uphold the principle of friendly consultations and dialogue to jointly manage maritime disputes. The agreement follows a summer spat between the two communist neighbors, with Vietnam emerging as the most vocal opponent of China's claims to the majority of the regional sea. The meeting between Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi and senior Vietnamese officials aimed to get relations back on track ahead of a state visit by Chinese President Xi Jinping next week.

site_title: BOE ties its rate path to Brexit after first hike in decade
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) has tied its next interest-rate shift to the success of Brexit negotiations, marking the first time the rate has been linked to the outcome of the talks. Governor Mark Carney stated that the UK's divorce from the EU is the main risk to the economy, potentially slowing growth and affecting investment plans. The BOE raised interest rates for the first time in over a decade to 0.5%, with officials indicating the possibility of further increases if the UK leaves the EU in 2019.

site_title: Central bankers on the move, but where's the inflation?
summary: Major central banks, including the Bank of England, have raised interest rates for the first time in a decade, but inflation remains a concern. Despite the decision, the majority of economists argue that the lack of inflation pressure is due to higher import prices and cheap labor, rather than wage deals. The global economy's lack of inflationary drift and the rise of online shopping are also contributing factors. Central banks face the challenge of persuading the public that rate hikes are necessary to control inflation, while powerful disinflationary forces, such as consumer bargain-seeking, remain in place.

site_title: Apple CEO Cook breathes new life into old iPhones
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook has breathed new life into old iPhones by stopping the company's practice of rapidly phasing out older models, a move aimed at addressing its heavy reliance on the latest flagship iPhone and lack of affordable offerings. This change allows for the continued sales of older iPhones, providing budget-conscious buyers with options to join Apple's ecosystem. The move is seen as a strategic shift to boost sales and profitability, particularly during the holiday shopping season.

site_title: Australia shares finish near 2-1/2-year high; NZ falls
summary: Australia's shares ended near a two-and-a-half-year high, advancing 0.5% to 5,959 on the S&P/ASX 200 index. Materials and financials sectors led gains, with metals and mining index rising 1% to its highest since August 2014. Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton rose 1.1% each, while Westpac Banking Corp gained 0.8%. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.22%, led by a2 Milk Company's 3.2% decline.

site_title: Jerome Powell, Trump's multi-millionaire pick for Fed chief
summary: US President Donald Trump has chosen Jerome "Jay" Powell, a 64-year-old former investment banker, to replace Janet Yellen as the head of the Federal Reserve. Powell's profile is unusual, as he's not a trained economist, but has a background in finance and has voted with the majority of Fed members since his appointment in 2012. He's seen as a centrist, unlikely to pursue steep rate hikes, but his appointment represents a departure from precedent and may signal a shift towards deregulation under the Trump administration.

site_title: SocGen raises provisions for legal disputes
summary: French bank Societe Generale (SocGen) has increased its litigation provisions by 300 million euros to 2.2 billion euros, following discussions with US authorities over two ongoing disputes. The bank reported a 15% fall in third-quarter net income to 932 million euros, below analyst estimates of 1 billion euros. SocGen expects to resolve the disputes within weeks and months, but the increased provisions are seen as a precautionary measure.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Friday, tracking Wall Street after the nomination of a new US Federal Reserve chief and Republican tax reforms. The Hang Seng Index gained 0.22%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 0.16% and 0.06% respectively. The gains were attributed to the market's reaction to the developments on Wall Street, with investors maintaining a positive outlook despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on financials, materials; NZ down 0.2%
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Friday, driven by gains in financial and material stocks, with the S&P/ASX 200 index reaching 5,966.20. Westpac Banking Corp led the financial index, while BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto benefited from rising iron ore prices. New Zealand's benchmark index slipped 0.2% due to a decline in dairy company a2 Milk.

site_title: Global smartphone sales keep momentum: IDC
summary: Global smartphone sales rose 2.7% in the third quarter, reaching 373.1 million units, according to IDC. The top five vendors, Apple, Huawei, Samsung, OPPO, and Xiaomi, all saw an increase in shipments, with Samsung leading the market with a 9.5% rise. New flagship models, such as Apple's iPhone X, are expected to drive sales, but IDC forecasts growth in the fourth quarter to be less than 1%. The industry's growth is considered low, but analysts see it as a sign of momentum.

images.alt_text: Apple's new iPhone 8 models helped its third quarter shipments climb 2.6 per cent to 46.7 million, and on Friday the California technology giant was releasing a new flagship iPhone X model with a starting price of US$999.

site_title: China's services sector sees modest growth in Oct: Caixin
summary: China's services sector saw modest growth in October, with the Caixin/Markit services purchasing managers' index (PMI) rising to 51.2, up from September's 21-month low. This suggests a subdued expansion in activity and new orders, contradicting expectations of a stronger start to the fourth quarter. The services sector accounts for over half of China's economy, with rising wages giving consumers more spending power, but manufacturing may face a sharper slowdown due to government measures to cool housing prices and reduce air pollution.

site_title: NTU, NUS to unveil Singapore Energy Centre in 2019; ExxonMobil to be first founding member
summary: The Singapore Energy Centre will be launched in 2019 by Nanyang Technological University (NTU) and the National University of Singapore (NUS) in collaboration with ExxonMobil. The centre aims to explore innovative energy ideas and develop talent to meet future energy needs through interdisciplinary interactions among local universities and industry. ExxonMobil signed a Memorandum of Understanding to become the first founding member of the centre, addressing global energy consumption and production challenges.

site_title: Powell knows as Yellen did how Fed moves can rock Asian markets
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, Trump's pick, is expected to reassure Asian investors with his dovish approach to tightening monetary policy, similar to his predecessor Janet Yellen's. Powell has emphasized the importance of considering global interconnections in monetary policy decisions, citing the interconnectedness of the US and other nations, including emerging markets. His comments suggest a gradual and measured approach to tightening US monetary policy, which is likely to reassure Asian financial markets, according to economists.

site_title: Oil prices steady near 2-year highs as market tightens
summary: Oil prices steadied near two-year highs on Thursday, driven by Opec-led supply cuts and declining inventories. Brent crude rose 0.2% to $60.61 per barrel, while US light crude increased 0.2% to $54.43. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries' (Opec) supply cuts, which aim to tighten markets, have contributed to the price stability. Analysts expect the Opec meeting at the end of November to discuss extending the supply cuts, which could support prices further.

site_title: Broadcom moving headquarters to US from Singapore: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that chipmaker Broadcom Ltd is moving its headquarters from Singapore to the US. Broadcom CEO Hock Tan stated that "America is again the best place to lead a business with a global footprint." This move is seen as a significant shift in the company's operations, with Tan expressing confidence in the US business environment.

site_title: Singapore's retail digital plan to help Kampong Glam merchants go omni-channel
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has announced plans to digitally revitalize the Kampong Glam neighborhood, the first of many neighborhoods to undergo transformation. The Retail Industry Transformation Map (ITM) aims to empower merchants to go omni-channel, improve IT infrastructure, and enhance the visitor experience. A digital roadmap is expected to be completed in three months, featuring solutions like e-commerce platforms, sensors, and artificial intelligence to deliver richer customer experiences. The initiative is part of Singapore's effort to restructure its economy.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise on Federal Reserve pick and Apple suppliers
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday, driven by the Federal Reserve's non-controversial pick of Jerome Powell as its new chair and Apple's strong earnings report. The Dow finished at a fresh record, while Apple's profit climbed 19% to $10.7 billion. Apple suppliers in Asia, including Hon Hai and Cowell E Holdings, saw their share prices rise. Meanwhile, Alibaba reported a 132% increase in net profit, and Chinese e-commerce giant Tencent's shares rose in Hong Kong.

site_title: US job growth seen surging after storm-related disruptions
summary: US job growth is expected to surge in October after hurricane-related disruptions depressed employment in September, with nonfarm payrolls likely increasing by 310,000 jobs. This rebound would reinforce the Federal Reserve's assessment of a solid labor market and could lead to an interest rate increase in December. However, wage growth is expected to slow due to the return of lower-paid industry workers, with average hourly earnings forecast to gain 0.2% in October. The unemployment rate is forecast to remain at a 16-1/2-year low of 4.2%.

site_title: Apple's Asia suppliers rise on forecast of strong holiday sales
summary: Apple's Asian suppliers, including Hon Hai Precision Industry Co and Wistron Corp, rose after the company forecast strong holiday sales and revenue of $84-87 billion for the quarter ending in December, beating analyst estimates. The 10th anniversary iPhone, supported by resurgent iPad and Mac sales, is expected to drive the revenue growth. Apple shares also rose 4% following the announcement. The company's efforts to fix supply problems with the iPhone X are seen as a positive sign for the holiday period.

site_title: Trump agrees to pick up 90% of Puerto Rico rebuilding costs: aide
summary: President Donald Trump agreed to cover 90% of the costs for Puerto Rico's rebuilding efforts following Hurricane Maria, up from the typical 75% share. The plan, agreed with Governor Ricardo Rossello, allows for faster and more flexible funding, with third-party advisers to estimate project costs and spending. This move comes as Puerto Rico faces a $72 billion debt crisis and only 30% of its power grid has been restored six weeks after the hurricane.

site_title: US sends supersonic bombers over South Korea
summary: The US Air Force conducted an exercise with Japanese and South Korean warplanes over the Korean peninsula, featuring supersonic B-1B Lancer bombers, on November 2, 2017. The operation, part of the "continuous bomber presence" mission, took place days before President Donald Trump's visit to the region. North Korea condemned the drill as "blackmail," amid heightened tensions over its ballistic missile and nuclear programs. The exercise follows a previous "show of force" in October and comes as Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un have exchanged threats and personal insults.

site_title: Baby bottle maker Hegen is first Singapore brand to be featured in Alibaba Singles' Day extravaganza
summary: Hegen, a Singapore baby bottle manufacturer, is set to participate in Alibaba's 11.11 Global Shopping Festival, marking the first time a Singapore brand has been featured in the event. Co-founder Yvon Bock will join other executives from global companies in a live broadcast, promoting the brand and its proprietary square-shaped baby bottle. The participation aims to boost sales in China, where Hegen has been selling its products since 2016, with a target of moving over half a million bottles in 2017.

site_title: Police said to examine Goldman role in 1MDB deals
summary: Singaporean prosecutors and police are examining Goldman Sachs' relationship with 1MDB, a Malaysian state investment fund at the center of global money laundering probes. Investigators have interviewed current and former Goldman Sachs executives who worked on bond offerings from 1MDB, looking into the firm's links with financier Low Taek Jho and the alleged siphoning of billions of dollars from the bond proceeds. Goldman Sachs earned $593 million in fees for arranging the 1MDB bond deals, drawing scrutiny from Malaysian politicians. The investigation is part of a broader probe into fund flows related to 1MDB, which has sparked probes in Singapore, Switzerland, and the US.

site_title: MOT, CAAS seeking proposals to develop solutions for unmanned aircraft systems
summary: The Ministry of Transport (MOT) and the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) have issued a call for proposals to develop solutions for unmanned aircraft systems (UAS) suitable for Singapore's densely populated urban environment. Proposals are welcome for navigation capabilities, sense-and-avoid technologies, fleet management, and UAS Traffic Management solutions to enable beyond-visual-line-of-sight (BVLOS) operations. The successful proposals will be co-funded up to S$1.5 million, and the deadline for submission is January 5, 2018. The goal is to explore the possibilities and test-bed the solutions robustly to enhance productivity and transform urban work and living.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.64 points to 1,744.69 on Friday, with 132 gainers outnumbering 63 losers. The opening was higher due to a strong trading session.

site_title: US: Dow ends at record as Trump names new Fed chief
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached a record high of 23,514.81 after President Donald Trump nominated Jerome Powell to lead the Federal Reserve. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also saw gains, despite some declines in tech stocks. The tax proposal unveiled by congressional Republicans was met with resistance from small businesses and homebuilders, but analysts viewed the nomination as a non-controversial choice that won't drastically change monetary policies.

site_title: 8Telecom to issue 18.74m shares via placement at S$0.054 each
summary: 8Telecom International has entered into two subscription agreements to issue 18.74 million new ordinary shares at S$0.054 each, totaling about S$1.01 million. The shares represent 16.66% of the company's enlarged share capital. The subscription price is a 10% discount to the volume weighted average price of S$0.06 per share. The net proceeds will be used for operational expenses and other trade payables.

site_title: AI key in Singapore's infocomm and media transformation map
summary: Singapore's Infocomm and Media (ICM) industry transformation map (ITM) highlights artificial intelligence (AI) as a key technology for growth. The government will support AI enterprises, train professionals, modernize regulations, and build infrastructure like a National Speech Corpus. AI is one of four frontier technologies to drive the digital economy and Smart Nation vision. The government will also strengthen ICM professionals, facilitate co-innovation, and provide support to tech startups and SMEs. The Accreditation@IMDA programme has been re-branded as Accreditation@SG Digital to support more companies.

site_title: UK sex scandal deepens after defence minister resigns
summary: UK Defence Minister Gavin Williamson was appointed by Prime Minister Theresa May after the resignation of Michael Fallon, who stepped down amid allegations of sexual harassment. Fallon had apologized for touching a journalist's knee in 2002, but further allegations were reported, including that he made derogatory comments to a female MP. Williamson, a trusted ally of May, has limited experience in the defence portfolio, having asked only seven questions on the subject since 2010. The appointment has raised questions about May's judgment and the whips' office's involvement in preparing a dossier on ministers.

site_title: US cuts off Chinese bank over North Korea ties
summary: The US has excluded China's Bank of Dandong from its financial system, citing allegations that it helped North Korea evade financial sanctions to launder funds. The move was made despite China's reluctance to push its neighbor to stop nuclear efforts. US President Donald Trump will discuss the issue with President Xi Jinping during his upcoming Asian tour. The ban on Bank of Dandong is part of a broader effort to pressure North Korea and China to reconsider their strategy, with the possibility of re-designating North Korea as a "state sponsor of terrorism" also being considered.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB, CIMB split on CAO after profit slips for first time in 10 quarters
summary: Analysts at RHB and CIMB are split on China Aviation Oil (CAO) after the jet fuel supplier reported its first net profit decline in 10 quarters. RHB cut CAO to "neutral" with a S$1.80 target price, citing weakness in trading. CIMB maintained its "add" call and a target price of S$2.08, arguing for exposure to a booming market. The split reflects differing views on the company's performance and prospects.

site_title: Pimped-up pedicabs a tourist hit in Malacca
summary: Malacca, Malaysia, has seen a resurgence of three-wheel trishaws, known locally as pedal-powered rickshaws, as a tourist attraction. These rickshaws, once phased out by cars, have been revamped with flashing lights, cartoon characters, and loud music to appeal to tourists. The 30-minute rides around historic buildings cost around RM25. The colorful trishaws have become a part of the city's experience, providing a romantic atmosphere at night. Malacca's unique trishaws are a testament to the city's colonial past and its efforts to adapt to modern times.

images.alt_text: Decked out with flashing lights and cartoon characters, with loud music pumping, rickety bicycle rickshaws have become a hit with tourists visiting the historic Malaysian city of Malacca.

site_title: Gold comes off highs after US House Republicans propose tax cuts
summary: US House Republicans proposed tax cuts, slashing the corporate tax rate to 20% and reducing individual tax brackets, causing gold prices to pare gains after touching a two-week high. The dollar fell and US 10-year Treasury yields slid to two-week lows, making gold more attractive to investors. The choice of the next US Federal Reserve chair also influenced gold prices, with investors anticipating a dovish approach. Gold prices settled up 0.1% at $1,278.10 per ounce, despite being expected to test the current October low.

site_title: Outgoing Twitter worker responsible for Trump account outage
summary: A Twitter employee on their last day took down Donald Trump's account, resulting in an 11-minute outage, before later admitting it was a prank. Twitter initially blamed "human error" but later confirmed the account was intentionally deactivated. The employee's actions sparked speculation about the account's status, but the outage was later resolved, with Trump resuming tweeting. The incident was not related to Trump's official White House account, which remained unaffected.

site_title: Manulife US Reit to pay 1.6 US cents per unit, 9.6% above projections
summary: Manulife US Reit announced a 1.6 US cent distribution per unit for the third quarter, beating projections by 9.6%. This marks an 8.5% increase above projections for the year-to-date distribution. The Reit attributed the higher distribution to its maiden acquisition of 500 Plaza Drive in New Jersey. The company's year-on-year numbers are not fully comparable, so it benchmarked its results against announced forecasts.

site_title: Singapore shares open up on Friday
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.75 points to 3,382.25 on Friday, driven by the appointment of Jerome Powell at the Federal Reserve and US tax cut plans. Gainers outnumbered losers 80 to 40, with a total of 56.1 million shares traded worth S$56.8 million.

site_title: Europe: Earnings drag on shares, Credit Suisse shines
summary: European shares declined 0.5% on Thursday due to disappointing earnings reports from companies such as Coloplast and Playtech. However, Credit Suisse's strong earnings and Danske Bank's better-than-expected results limited losses. The FTSE 100 index rose 0.9% as sterling dropped after the Bank of England raised interest rates for the first time in over a decade. Despite mixed results, nearly half of European companies have reported earnings beats, with industrial, financial, and tech sectors performing well.

site_title: Massive queues greet iPhone X launch at Singapore Apple store
summary: Hundreds of people lined up outside an Apple store in Singapore on November 2, 2017, a day before the launch of the iPhone X. The first in line was Madam Ila Ahmad, 52, who arrived with her son, prepared with sleeping bags and food. The long queue was a testament to the device's anticipated popularity. The event marked the highly anticipated launch of Apple's latest flagship model, with many eager to get their hands on the device.

site_title: mm2 Asia's profit more than doubles to S$4.6m for Q2
summary: mm2 Asia reported a net profit of S$4.6 million for its second quarter, more than doubling from S$2.02 million last year, driven by revenue growth of 45.4% to S$31.4 million. The company's core business of producing movies and TV/online content contributed 40% of the revenue. The significant increase was largely due to the contribution from UnUsUaL Limited, a subsidiary acquired in 2016.

site_title: UOB Q3 profit rises 12% to S$883m as net interest income, fees, commissions climb
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 12% increase in net earnings to S$883 million in Q3 2017, driven by higher net interest income and fee/commission income. Net interest income rose 15% to S$1.41 billion, while fee/commission income grew 12% to S$551 million. Operating expenses increased 6% to S$973 million, and total allowances rose 6% to S$221 million. The bank's loan-to-deposit ratio remained healthy at 85.8%. UOB's CEO attributed the strong performance to a pickup in the global economy and its diversified banking franchise.

site_title: Apple delivers higher profit as iPhone X launches
summary: Apple reported a 19% increase in net profit to $10.7 billion in the fiscal fourth quarter, driven by strong iPhone sales. Revenues rose 12% to $52.6 billion, with iPhone sales climbing by about 1 million units to 46.7 million. The company's fiscal year profit rose 5.8% to $48.35 billion, with revenue increasing 6.3% to $229 billion. Apple's new iPhone X launched on November 3, with a starting price of $999, marking the 10th anniversary of the first iPhone release.

site_title: AT&T still sees approval for Time Warner deal
summary: AT&T remains confident that its proposed $85 billion takeover of Time Warner will be approved despite a report suggesting the Justice Department is considering a lawsuit to block the deal. The Justice Department has not made a final decision, and AT&T is in settlement talks with the department. AT&T argues that the deal is a "vertical" transaction that benefits consumers without removing competitors, and that similar deals have been approved in the past. However, a lawsuit could delay or block the deal, with some companies withdrawing mergers in the face of regulatory opposition.

site_title: Investors parse impacts on multinationals from House tax bill
summary: A US Republican tax bill, unveiled on Thursday, offers multinational companies more benefits than drawbacks, potentially freeing up extra cash for investments or dividends. The bill slashes the corporate tax rate from 35% to 20%, and imposes new taxes on foreign subsidiaries and payments from foreign businesses operating in the US. While some companies, such as General Electric and renewable energy companies, may face increased costs, technology companies like Apple and Microsoft are expected to benefit from the repatriated profits tax rate. The bill's passage is uncertain, with investors and analysts weighing the potential impact on companies and the overall market.

site_title: US Republicans unveil tax cut bill, but the hard work awaits
summary: US House Republicans unveiled a 429-page tax cut bill, aiming to deliver deep tax cuts to President Donald Trump's first major legislative victory. The bill slashes corporate tax rates to 20%, cuts tax rates on individuals and families, and ends certain tax breaks. However, provisions will hit taxpayers in Democratic-leaning states hardest, such as rolling back deductions for state and local taxes. The bill faces a ferocious lobbying battle and fierce opposition from Democrats, with a vote in the House expected soon.

site_title: Sing Hldgs, Wee Hur to launch Parc Botannia next weekend
summary: Sing Holdings and Wee Hur Holdings will launch Parc Botannia, a 99-year leasehold residential project in Sengkang, Singapore, next weekend. The project features one to five-bedroom units with sizes from 431 sq ft to 1,679 sq ft, selling at an average S$1,280 psf. With a total of 735 units, Parc Botannia will be completed by end-2021, offering a range of amenities including themed gardens, a 50-m lap pool, and a fitness clubhouse. The launch comes as other developers are holding back on projects amid anticipation of further price growth.

site_title: Pampering mind and body
summary: Three luxury wellness resorts in Asia offer retreats to recharge the mind and body. Ananda in the Himalayas, India, combines yoga, ayurveda, and vedanta for holistic wellness. Fivelements Bali, Indonesia, features holistic Balinese healing rituals and traditional therapies. Fusion Maia Danang Resort, Vietnam, offers unlimited spa treatments and a complimentary Natural Living Programme. Amatara Wellness Resort, Thailand, is known for its Thai Hammam, a unique spa treatment combining traditional Turkish bath and luxury Thai spa. Each resort offers various wellness packages and customizable programs.

images.alt_text: Amatara promises the best coastal view in Phuket, with a 180-degree view of the Andaman Sea
Fusion Maia Danang offers its guests unlimited spa treatments, or a guaranteed minimum of two sessions a day.
at Fivelements, therapies are guided by the wisdom of holistic Balinese healing rituals and administered by traditional healers.
Ananda's wellness programmes rest on three pillars: yoga; ayurveda (a traditional holistic healing system) and vedanta (a philosophy of life).

site_title: US jobless claims near 44-½ year low
summary: US jobless claims fell to a near 44-½ year low of 229,000, supporting expectations of a sharp rebound in job growth in October. The number of Americans receiving benefits after an initial week of aid also decreased, indicating diminishing labor market slack. Worker productivity increased at its fastest pace in three years, 3.0% annually, and unit labor costs rose at a 0.5% pace. The data suggests the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates in December, despite tame wage pressures.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, China Aviation Oil, Manulife US Reit, StarHub, Sembcorp Industries
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

Several Singapore stocks are expected to be watched on Friday, including UOB, China Aviation Oil, Manulife US Reit, StarHub, and Sembcorp Industries. UOB reported a 12% increase in net earnings to S$883 million in the third quarter, while China Aviation Oil's net profit fell 8% to US$21.4 million due to lower trading gains. The bank also announced the retirement of Wee Cho Yaw after 60 years on the board. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower amid a fresh tariff salvo by President Trump on Canada. Singapore stocks, however, have had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Shell takes Exxon's cash-flow crown as profit beats estimate
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has surpassed Exxon Mobil Corp as the top-performing oil major in terms of cash flow, generating $28.38 billion in the first nine months of 2017. Shell's CEO Ben van Beurden aims to overtake Exxon, but the company still needs to reduce its net debt and cover its entire dividend with free cash flow. Shell's net profit adjusted for one-time items was $4.1 billion, an increase of 47% from a year earlier, beating the average analyst estimate.

images.alt_text: Mr van Beurden has already said that his main long-term goal was overtaking Exxon to become the best-performing oil major.

site_title: Britain's May replaces defence minister in growing harassment scandal
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May appointed Gavin Williamson as Defence Secretary after Michael Fallon resigned due to a sexual harassment scandal. The scandal has prompted calls for an end to the "locker room" culture in parliament. Williamson, a rising star in the Conservative Party, has no former experience in the armed forces, raising concerns about his suitability for the role. The scandal has damaged May's government and has led to further calls for resignations, including against her deputy Damian Green.

site_title: DBS, with eye on competition, doubles down on APIs
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, has launched a large-scale banking API (application programming interface) developer platform to boost collaborations with third-party players, such as corporates and fintechs. The platform, which has 155 APIs launched across 20 categories, enables developers to access a breadth of services, including funds transfers and peer-to-peer payment services. DBS aims to create mutually symbiotic benefits from partnerships, partnering where it can compete and not competing where it can collaborate. The bank has already partnered with companies like Grab, McDonald's, and PropertyGuru, and plans to expand its API offerings in India and Indonesia.

site_title: Asian shares mixed as Fed stays put as expected
summary: Asian shares were mixed on Thursday as investors digested the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates unchanged, largely in line with expectations. Markets rebounded in the morning but ended on a more muted note, with Tokyo rising 0.5% to a 21-year high, while other regional bourses declined. Analysts expect a December rate hike, citing a "solid" economic outlook, and are watching US President Donald Trump's proposed tax bill and Jerome Powell's nomination as Fed chairman.

site_title: New business hotels and the low-cost long-haul way to fly, in BT Weekend
summary: Business travelers in Singapore have a range of new hotels to choose from, offering luxurious amenities. Meanwhile, low-cost carriers are increasing competition in the long-haul flight market, potentially benefiting consumers. However, the sustainability of the low-cost carrier model is uncertain due to price wars and overcapacity.

site_title: Jerome Powell - a worthy successor to Janet Yellen
summary: US President Donald Trump has appointed Jerome Powell as the new Chairman of the Federal Reserve, a move seen as a continuity of policy and operating style. Powell, a 64-year-old investment banker, shares dovish views on interest rates with previous Fed Chairs Janet Yellen and Ben Bernanke. However, he differs from Yellen on banking and financial regulation, leaning towards deregulation and questioning the necessity of certain regulations. A Powell-run Fed is likely to prioritize financial stability and a gradual approach to interest rate hikes, which may please the markets and Trump.

site_title: China to cut tariffs, lift financing to boost imports: officials
summary: China plans to lower import tariffs and increase bank financing to boost imports, aiming to reduce its massive trade surplus and alleviate its citizens' enjoyment of national wealth. The move comes ahead of US President Donald Trump's visit to China, where trade relations are expected to be a major topic of discussion. China will also speed up talks over the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership and increase imports of advanced technological equipment.

site_title: Tesla stock falls on Model 3 delays, biggest-ever quarterly loss
summary: Tesla's stock fell nearly 5% after reporting its biggest quarterly loss ever, $619.4 million, due to delays in production of its new Model 3 sedan, which is expected to take about three months longer than initially planned. The company also reported a 30% increase in revenue to $2.98 billion. The Model 3 production delays pose a crucial test for Tesla's growth strategy and may exacerbate the company's cash burn, with shares down 17% from their 12-month high.

site_title: Being a woman got even worse in 2017: WEF
summary: The World Economic Forum's Global Gender Gap Report 2017 found the gap between men and women's achievements and well-being widened for the first time in 11 years. The report states it will take 100 years to achieve equality in four areas: political empowerment, economic participation, health, and education. The US ranks 49th, down from 45th in 2016, while India ranks 108, despite high rankings in women's political empowerment. Countries like Iceland and Canada are making progress, but the report highlights a general slowdown in progress worldwide.

site_title: Chinese food dressed up in all its finery
summary: Shang Palace, a restaurant at the Shangri-La Hotel in Singapore, has unveiled its new menu offerings to coincide with Chinese New Year. The upscale dining experience features refined dishes and premium pricing. Despite the hotel's lobby undergoing renovations, Shang Palace has maintained its traditional Chinese cuisine, leaving it relatively untouched. The restaurant is open daily for lunch and dinner, offering a unique dining experience for guests.

site_title: Volkswagen sales bounce back in US
summary: Volkswagen US sales have rebounded after a decline due to the diesel-emissions scandal. In 2017, the company's image was severely damaged, leading to a decline in sales. However, the brand has since regained its footing, with sales bouncing back. This recovery is attributed to efforts by Volkswagen to address the scandal and improve its reputation.

site_title: Cultural chameleons among companies more likely to succeed abroad
summary: Companies more likely to succeed abroad by adapting to local cultures and addressing cultural differences are more likely to succeed. Research from Nanyang Business School found that companies must adapt to local consumers' habits and cultural expectations, and also manage cultural differences between their host country and home country. Companies that foster cultural harmony among local workers and expatriates are more successful. Multinational companies such as Nike, IBM, and Toyota Motor have set up operations in Poland with international organisational cultures that have attracted top Polish talent.

site_title: FireEye gives weak forecast for Q4, shares drop
summary: FireEye, a cybersecurity firm, has issued a weaker-than-expected forecast for the fourth quarter, citing shorter contract lengths. The company expects adjusted losses of $0.03 to $0.01 per share and total revenue of $190-196 million, below analyst estimates. Shares dropped 14% after the announcement. FireEye still targets non-GAAP profitability by year-end and expects positive free-cash flow in 2017. The company attributed the revised forecast to larger committed subscription deals with shorter contract lengths.

site_title: US dollar slides as investors take profit
summary: The US dollar declined 0.2% against a broad basket of currencies, falling to 94.71, as investors took profits after the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged. The decision was in line with market expectations, and uncertainty around the next Fed chair, Jerome Powell, also contributed to the decline. The Fed raised expectations for a year-end rate increase, citing solid economic growth and a strengthening labor market, but the shrinking interest rate differentials between 10-year and two-year Treasury yields suggested the dollar may be peaking.

site_title: Mueller probe another instance of the US' rule of law
summary: The US is considered one of the world's greatest success stories due to its adherence to the rule of law, which is enshrined in the US Constitution. This principle, established by the Founding Fathers to escape British tyranny, ensures that everyone, regardless of position, is subject to the same laws. The ongoing Mueller probe into Russian collusion is a demonstration of this commitment to the rule of law, with its investigation providing a fundamental check on the abuse of power by President Trump.

site_title: Tesla's solar installations fall but more people opt to buy
summary: Tesla installed 109 megawatts of energy-generation systems in the third quarter, down from its SolarCity unit's 243 megawatts as an independent company. Despite this decrease, more people are opting to buy solar power, indicating a shift in the market.

site_title: Security for the Internet of Threats
summary: The Internet of Things (IoT) has created a new landscape for hackers, with an estimated 70% of IoT devices having serious vulnerabilities. As the number of connected devices grows, security risks increase, posing threats to financial loss, personal safety, and business reputation. The lack of proper configuration and security measures by end-users and manufacturers has contributed to this issue. Governments and organizations must work together to create end-to-end secure infrastructure, and individuals must be aware of the threats to minimize risk.

site_title: Kraft Heinz misses sales estimates as US demand weakens
summary: Kraft Heinz Co. missed US sales estimates in the third quarter, with net profit coming in at 83 cents per share, marginally better than expected. The company attributed the weakness to US demand, particularly due to emergency stockpiling of its tinned goods ahead of Hurricane Irma. This will likely hinder sales in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Fourth Avenue GLS residential site launched for sale by public tender
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a public tender for a 1.9-hectare residential site at Fourth Avenue in Bukit Timah, Singapore. The site, which can accommodate 455 housing units, has a minimum bid price of S$448.8 million and will close on December 5. The site is well-connected to major arterial roads and the Pan Island Expressway, and is near several schools and the Sixth Avenue MRT Station. This is part of the URA's Government Land Sales (GLS) programme, which also includes a nearby site at Jiak Kim Street.

site_title: Michael Kors wants you to feel like you met Michael Kors
summary: Michael Kors Holdings Ltd is revamping stores and training sales associates to deliver personalized style ideas, aiming to win back customers with experiences. The company is reducing its reliance on department stores and increasing its product catalogue, with a focus on adding personalized recommendations to a new mobile app. The turnaround plan, which includes closing underperforming stores, is expected to boost sales and revenue, with investor interest rising and shares increasing by about a third since August.

site_title: China metal tycoon who built two empires faces Xi's new era
summary: China's President Xi Jinping's supply-side structural reforms are reshaping the country's basic industries, including steel and aluminium. Hongqiao Group Ltd, the world's largest aluminium producer, has been forced to shut nearly a third of its capacity to comply with government edicts. The company's shares jumped 32% after resuming trading in Hong Kong, with tycoon Zhang Shiping facing a new challenge in the battle for control. The reforms have led to a shift in power, with state-owned enterprises (SOEs) pushing private companies out of the market, and Hongqiao's ability to generate cash and repay debt now in question.

site_title: Facebook, Google's huge profits buoy Wall St, bring backlash in Washington
summary: Facebook and Google's record-breaking profits have bolstered Wall Street, but policymakers in Washington are growing increasingly concerned about the tech industry's dominance and potential for invasion. Despite this, tech companies are committing to cut down abuse on their platforms, with Facebook and Google pledging to prioritize security over profits. This move is part of a broader effort to manage the backlash against Silicon Valley's growing influence, with lawmakers pushing for greater transparency in political advertising and regulation to address concerns about censorship and the industry's impact on democracy.

site_title: An opportunity for the WTO
summary: The World Trade Organization's (WTO) 11th Ministerial Conference in Buenos Aires this December is expected to be a challenging meeting, with the US actively stoking trade tensions. The conference will focus on updating the WTO's "special and differential treatment" (S&D) provisions, which benefit developing countries, and improving consensus-building within the organization. However, given the current intransigence and denial of reality among WTO members, the meeting may not yield significant results. The WTO needs to address its inability to adapt to a changing international environment and establish an independent office for evaluation to ensure its effectiveness.

site_title: Brokers take
summary: Analysts from Credit Suisse, DBS Group Research, and OCBC Investment Research have updated their stock ratings and target prices for First Resources, OUE Hospitality Trust, and Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust. The updates reflect the companies' performance in 2017 and their expected growth prospects in 2018. First Resources' rating was downgraded to "neutral" despite a target price increase to S$2.30, while OUE Hospitality Trust and Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust maintained their "buy" calls with revised target prices of S$0.85 and S$1.22, respectively.

site_title: Portrait of a true Renaissance man
summary: Walter Isaacson's biography of Leonardo da Vinci, a true Renaissance man, delves into the artist's multifaceted life, but lacks intimate personal revelations. Isaacson's enthusiasm for Leonardo's works is admirable, but he overcompensates with copious analyses, sometimes adopting an oracular tone. The book shines when analyzing Leonardo's scientific and innovative endeavors, showcasing his perfectionism and tendency to abandon projects. However, the conclusion falls into clichéd platitudes, disappointing readers. Despite this, the book remains a testament to Leonardo's enduring legacy and his indifference to glory.

site_title: Wee Cho Yaw to retire from UOB board; new chairman named
summary: Singapore's UOB will name Wong Kan Seng as its new chairman in February, succeeding Hsieh Fu Hua. Wee Cho Yaw, who led the bank for six decades, will retire from the board and retain his chairman emeritus title as honorary adviser. Wee, 89, will relinquish all board responsibilities in April after a 60-year career with the bank, where he owns over 18% of its shares. The bank's leadership renewal process began in 2007, following Wee's retirement as CEO.

site_title: Seminar to discuss 2018 business prospects
summary: A seminar titled "Outlook 2018" will be held on November 21 to discuss the business prospects for the upcoming year. The event, organized by The Business Times and supported by Canon Singapore, will feature experts discussing the implications of geopolitics, technology, and global economic trends on businesses. Speakers include professors and market experts, who will share their insights on the potential impact of AI, digitization, and the unorthodox diplomatic approaches of world leaders on the business world. The seminar aims to help small and medium enterprises make better decisions in uncertain times ahead.

site_title: Swiber's diversification plan will need to quell many concerns
summary: Swiber Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore construction company, is seeking to restructure its liabilities and diversify into power generation through the acquisition of Western Australia-based Interlink. The company's judicial managers aim to raise up to $200 million to fund the new business, with the goal of generating stable, sustainable cash flows. However, creditors are questioning the benefits of this move, as the restructuring may lead to significant debt relief for them but substantial dilution of existing equity holders' interests.

site_title: Far East H-Trust Q3 DPS down 8%
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (Far East H-Trust) reported a 8% decline in its distribution per stapled security (DPS) for the third quarter, down to 1.03 Singapore cents, due to softer performance from its hotel and office portfolios. Gross revenue fell 2% year-on-year to S$27.46 million, with a decline in master lease rental from hotels and serviced residences. Despite this, the trust's management expects portfolio performance to improve in the near future through asset enhancement initiatives and accretive investments.

site_title: Landed home sales headed for best showing in 5 years
summary: Landed home sales in Singapore are on track to be the best in five years, with 1,513 units sold between January and October, a 50% increase from the previous year. Prices have fallen by 16% since their peak in 2013, making them more attractive to buyers. Consultants attribute the surge to the recovery of the overall housing market and the easing of prices. Demand for landed properties is driven by Singaporeans, with foreigners requiring government approval to own a landed home. Experts predict further price growth, with Savills forecasting a 5-7% increase by end-2018.

site_title: Earn your drink at these incredibly hard-to-reach bars
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

A list of hard-to-reach bars around the world includes SubSix in the Maldives, Albatross Bar in Tristan Da Cunha Island, Three Camel Lodge in Mongolia, Faraday Bar in Antarctica, Christian's Café in Pitcairn Island, Camp Kalahari in Botswana, The Old Forge in Scotland, The Irish Pub in Nepal, Lost Bar in Russia, and others. Each location offers a unique drinking experience, often requiring long journeys or extreme weather conditions to access. From underwater restaurants to remote pubs, these bars cater to adventurous travelers seeking a one-of-a-kind drinking experience.

site_title: Selangor state's royal council urges sedition probe on Mahathir
summary: Malaysia's royal council urged authorities to investigate former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad for sedition over comments at an opposition rally last month, where he allegedly described Prime Minister Najib Razak as a "Bugis pirate". The remarks have sparked criticism, with Mahathir, 93, being sharply criticized for the insult. The royal council's call for a probe comes after weeks of sharp criticism of Mahathir's comments.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng terminates sales contracts for Tower Melbourne project due to protracted litigation
summary: CHIP Eng Seng Corp terminates sales contracts for 556 units in its Australian residential project Tower Melbourne due to protracted litigation, which has stalled demolition works for four years. The company is exploring viable exit options, including a sale of the property. The decision allows buyers to exit the transaction earlier, with the return of deposits and interest accrued. The litigation has delayed the project's completion, with Chip Eng Seng citing the uncertainty as the reason for the termination. The company will continue to contest the legal proceedings.

site_title: October was strongest month for eurozone factories in almost 7 years
summary: Manufacturers in the eurozone experienced their strongest month since 2011 in October, with factories adding staff at the fastest rate in 20 years. The Eurozone's manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 58.5, its highest since February 2011, as demand surged and backlogs built up. Robust growth alongside increasing price pressures will be welcomed by the European Central Bank, and German manufacturing activity also expanded at the fastest pace in 6½ years, suggesting the sector will contribute to an expansion in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Three Singapore-listed companies reported financial results for the third quarter. Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) posted a 4.8% increase in gross revenue and 4.7% rise in adjusted net property income. Raffles Education Corp called for an EGM to vote on the removal of its founder and chairman, while Citic Envirotech reported a 154% jump in net profit. OUE Commercial Reit saw a 12.9% decline in distribution per unit and a 3.5% decline in net property income. Meanwhile, China Aviation Oil and Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust reported mixed results, with China Aviation Oil seeing a 8% decline in net profit.

site_title: The Mountain Between Us and credibility
summary: A romantic film, "The Mountain Between Us," based on Charles Martin's book, tells the improbable story of two strangers, a photojournalist (Kate Winslet) and a neurosurgeon (Idris Elba), who become stranded on a mountain top after a plane crash. Despite their differences, they form a bond as they try to survive the harsh environment and eventually develop romantic feelings for each other. The film, directed by Hany Abu-Assad, is criticized for its sappy and unbelievable plot, but the chemistry between the leads makes it somewhat watchable.

site_title: V3's HK IPO journey not smooth sailing for Osim founder
summary: V3, a Singapore-based company founded by Osim's Ron Sim, had announced its intention to relist in Hong Kong in April but seems to have fallen off the radar. The company's repackaged massage chair and lifestyle products group had initially listed in 2017. The reason for its withdrawal from the Hong Kong stock exchange is unclear, with no recent updates or statements from the company.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit sees strong acquisition pipeline over next few years
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit has a strong pipeline of assets worth over US$670 million that it may consider for acquisition over the next few years. The Reit's IPO portfolio spans 3.2 million sq ft of net lettable area across various US cities, with a majority of assets in suburban areas and a high proportion of Class A properties. The Reit's distribution yield for 2018 is estimated to be 6.8%, with an expected distribution yield of 7.2% for 2019, reflecting a total return of 12.6%.

site_title: TransferWise to muscle in on S'pore SME market
summary: TransferWise, a fintech firm, plans to launch a Borderless account for small businesses in Singapore, allowing them to manage overseas transactions involving multiple currencies. The service, which already offers similar features in Europe, will enable SMEs to hold nearly 30 currencies and make payments in four currencies without incurring fees. The move aims to challenge banks in the corporate space, with TransferWise already moving $700 million annually in and out of Singapore. The company has raised $280 million in funding and plans to expand into India, with a valuation exceeding $1 billion.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies and their implications for Singapore
summary: Singapore is monitoring the rapidly evolving cryptocurrency market, with its central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), keeping a close eye on the risks and potential implications. Despite the current lack of regulation, policymakers recognize the need to understand and potentially harness the benefits of blockchain technology. Singapore is taking a cautious approach, with its "Project Ubin" initiative exploring the use of a digital version of the Singapore dollar to facilitate interbank payments. The country aims to become a Smart Financial Centre and is collaborating with industry players and other regulators to navigate the complexities of fintech and cryptocurrencies.

site_title: With polls looming, Jakarta is expected to go into holding pattern with reforms
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo's reform efforts may slow as the country approaches regional and presidential elections. Despite recent praise from investors and analysts, the government will focus on implementation rather than new reforms. The World Bank's Ease-of-Doing-Business Index ranked Indonesia 19 places higher, but progress in tackling corruption and red tape is uneven, with some regions rebelling against Jakarta's rules. The government has arrested over 2,400 officials for bribery and seized assets, but more work remains to be done to harmonize rules and curb corruption.

site_title: Sembcorp Q3 profit down 38% on lower revenue and higher finance costs
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 37.7% drop in net profit to S$33.6 million in Q3, mainly due to lower revenue and higher finance costs. Revenue fell 15.5% to S$1.81 billion, while finance costs rose S$36.1 million. The company also wrote down S$56.3 million on its utilities business and S$25.8 million on steam boilers. Despite this, the renewable energy business and its thermal power plant are performing well, and the company expects to deliver a better performance in its urban development business.

site_title: Makeup, millennials drive Estee Lauder sales surge
summary: Estee Lauder's shares reached a record high after forecasting strong holiday-quarter sales, driven by demand for its recently acquired makeup brands popular among millennials. The company reported better-than-expected sales and profit in the first quarter, with 18% and 20% sales growth in the Asia-Pacific and Europe regions, respectively.

site_title: Auckland's house-price drop ends Kiwi property boom
summary: New Zealand's housing market has seen its first annual decline in six years, with Auckland's house prices dropping 0.6% from the previous year. The decline, along with a slowdown in national price growth to 3.9%, is attributed to a decrease in foreign investment and a return to normal market activity. The government has announced a ban on foreigners buying existing homes to make housing more affordable for first-time buyers, and plans to build 100,000 dwellings over the next decade to address a shortage.

site_title: Violin mentor and protégé set to thrill
summary: Classical violinist Min Lee and her 12-year-old protégé Samuel Tan will perform in a benefit concert titled "String A Legacy." Lee will play Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto In E minor, a piece she first performed at age 9, while Samuel will perform Wieniawski's Variations On An Original Theme Op 15 and Sarasate's Introduction And 'Arantelle Op 43. The concert aims to showcase their musical talents and support a good cause.

site_title: Failed M&A deals hit 8-year high in 2016
summary: Failed M&A deals worldwide reached an 8-year high in 2016, with 7.2% of announced deals failing to complete. The Asia-Pacific region had the highest failure rate, at 13.2%, followed by China, Australia, and Singapore. Factors contributing to deal failures include uncertain political and economic environments, high seller expectations, and external financial shocks. The study analyzed 78,565 M&A transactions between 1992 and 2016, identifying predictors of deal failure, such as target termination fees, acquirer size, and external financial shocks.

site_title: A bombshell that could rewrite the script
summary: President Trump's planned week of legislative and policy achievements was derailed by the release of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's first charges stemming from his probe into Russia's meddling in the 2016 US election. Mueller unveiled a 12-count indictment and a guilty plea, targeting three former Trump campaign officials, including Paul Manafort and George Papadopoulos. The indictment did not prove collusion between the Trump campaign and Russian officials, but aimed to send a message to other potential players in the scandal. The Mueller investigation will continue to distract attention from the White House's agenda, making it difficult for President Trump to regain his political standing.

site_title: KTL Global CEO resigns, is succeeded by brother
summary: KTL Global has appointed Tan Kheng Kuan as its new CEO, succeeding his brother Tan Kheng Yeow who resigned due to personal reasons. Tan Kheng Yeow had been under investigation by the Monetary Authority of Singapore regarding possible offenses under the Securities and Futures Act. He had surrendered his passport after being interviewed by the MAS. Tan Kheng Kuan, who has been with the group since 2003, will take over as CEO effective Thursday.

site_title: Banking, consumer staples weigh on STI
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 11.11 points, or 0.33%, to close at 3,380.50, led by losses in the financial and consumer staples sectors. OCBC and UOB were the main drag, with the benchmark index down 11 points. Turnover was 2.3 billion worth S$1.1 billion, with losers beating gainers 285 to 170, indicating weak trading.

site_title: CDL's China unit ties up with China Vanke
summary: CDL's China unit, CDL China, has tied up with China Vanke Co through a partial divestment of interests in two projects in Chongqing for 986 million yuan (S$202 million). CDL China partially divested 70% of Chongqing Huang Huayuan and 50% of Eling Residences to China Vanke's subsidiary. The projects will be jointly developed and managed by CDL China and China Vanke, with CDL retaining 30% and 50% equity stakes respectively for "future upside". The deal is part of CDL's strategy to recycle capital for expansion plans.

site_title: National Australia Bank axes 6,000 jobs as annual profit jumps
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) announced plans to axe approximately 6,000 jobs as part of a restructuring effort to automate and simplify its business for a digital future. Despite this, the bank posted an annual net profit of A$5.28 billion, with 2,000 new jobs expected to be created. The restructuring aims to reshape the bank for a more efficient and competitive operation in the face of changing market conditions.

site_title: Bombardier wins new C Series deal to end 18-month sales drought
summary: Bombardier Inc. won a major sales deal for its C Series jet, securing an order of 31 planes with options for 30 more from an unidentified European customer. The deal marks the first major sale of the aircraft in 18 months, following production delays and cost overruns. Airbus, which will take a majority stake in the partnership, aims to cut production costs and win thousands of new orders. The deal is seen as a brighter outlook for the C Series, which has faced significant challenges, including a cut to this year's delivery target and a complaint from Boeing over unfair pricing.

site_title: Precious metals retailer Degussa closing outlet in S'pore
summary: Degussa, a European gold and precious metals retailer, is closing its outlet in Singapore due to margin pressures and a slow retail market. The store, which opened two years ago, will shut down by the end of November. Degussa cited a lacklustre retail market and increased competition as factors contributing to its decision. The company will continue to sell its products in Singapore through other retailers, but will retain allocated storage services for its customers. This marks the first exit of a major precious metals retailer in Singapore, as the market experiences a slowdown.

site_title: mm2 Asia expands footprint with S$230m Cathay cinema deal
summary: mm2 Asia acquired Cathay Organisation's cinema operations in Singapore for S$230 million, including the Cathay Cineplexes brand, to expand its presence in the movie theater business. The acquisition, expected to be completed by November 24, will give mm2 Asia its first set of Singapore cinemas. The deal includes a management fee to ensure a smooth transition and the intrinsic brand value of the Cathay Cineplexes brand, estimated at S$24-30 million. This move is part of mm2 Asia's strategic growth plan to diversify into the downstream value chain of film production.

site_title: Lenovo's revenue beats estimates as global PC market stabilises
summary: Lenovo's revenue exceeded estimates with a 5% increase to $11.8 billion in the third quarter. Despite a 11% decline in net income to $139 million, analysts attribute the boost to accounting gains. The company also announced plans to acquire Fujitsu's client computing division for $212 million. Lenovo's PC business remains stagnant, but the global market is showing signs of stabilization. The company is exploring ways to rejuvenate its PC business under new leadership.

site_title: SIA takes on rivals with US$850m bet on A380 cabin makeover
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has invested US$850 million in a major cabin makeover for its 19 A380 jets, aiming to boost competitiveness and customer demand. The revamped cabins will feature upgraded suites, business class, and economy seats, with a focus on premium comfort. The enhancements are expected to improve yields and load factors, particularly in the premium cabins. Analysts predict a competitive edge for SIA, but also note that the airline faces intense competition from other carriers, which may impact revenue and yields. The revamped A380s will be deployed starting December 18, with the entire fleet expected to be refreshed by 2020.

site_title: Valuing a business via its income still preferred in Asean: study
summary: A joint study by the Institute of Valuers and Appraisers, Singapore and Ernst & Young found that 88% of Asean business executives prefer valuing a business via its income, with Ebitda being the preferred yardstick. The majority (45.5%) also prepare multiple scenarios for cash flows due to significant uncertainty. Disruptive technology is expected to have the biggest impact on business value, according to 47.1% of respondents. The study emphasizes the need for continuous research and upskilling in business valuation to adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: Global air passenger traffic demand up 5.7% in Sept -IATA
summary: Global air passenger traffic demand rose 5.7% in September, the slowest growth since February, due to hurricanes in the US. Despite this, airline capacity increased 5.3% and load factor rose 0.3 percentage points to 81.6%. The growth was expected to taper, with hurricanes Irma and Maria weighing heavily on results.

site_title: French Film Festival returns
summary: The French Film Festival is returning to Singapore from November 9 to 19, featuring 16 works spanning various genres, including drama, comedy, and thriller. The festival showcases French cinema's diversity and eclecticism, with highlights including the big-screen adaptation "Seuls" and director Cédric Klapisch's "Back To Burgundy". The festival also includes a special screening of Jeanne Moreau's classic films and a partnership with Shaw Theaters for extended releases of select films. The festival aims to promote French cinema in Singapore and encourage cultural appreciation and exchanges between the two countries.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing expands for 14th straight month on broad growth across segments
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector expanded for the 14th consecutive month in October, with a 52.6 purchasing managers' index (PMI) reading, the fastest pace in eight years. This is attributed to broad-based expansion across most sectors, with manufacturing employment also recording its second straight month of growth. The electronics sector saw a slight dip in growth, but overall, the sector remains strong, with economists expecting a 15.5% expansion in manufacturing for the year.

site_title: Tesco CEO kept in dark over accounting issues
summary: Tesco CEO Dave Lewis was not informed by UK managing director Christopher Bush about possible problems with the company's 2014-15 half year accounts, despite opportunities to do so, a London court heard. Bush, Carl Rogberg, and John Scouler deny any wrongdoing and have pleaded not guilty to fraud and false accounting charges. The trial of the three former senior executives continues, with the outcome uncertain.

site_title: World's biggest pension fund, GPIF, adds 4.5 trillion yen as stocks rise
summary: Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF), the world's largest pension fund, posted its fifth-straight quarterly gain of 3% or 4.5 trillion yen, increasing its assets to a record 156.8 trillion yen. The fund's investments in domestic equities rose 1.8 trillion yen, while foreign equities increased by 2 trillion yen, driven by the euro's strength. GPIF's portfolio allocation remains steady, with 24% in domestic shares, 24% in overseas equities, and 15% in foreign bonds, as the fund manages assets from a long-term perspective.

site_title: Razer launches smartphone with gaming-centric specs
summary: Razer has launched its first smartphone, the Razer Phone, a gaming-centric device with high-end specs. The phone features a 5.72-inch 2K Quad-HD screen with a 120Hz refresh rate, Snapdragon 835 processor, 8GB of RAM, and a 4,000mAh battery. It runs on Android 7.1 and is expected to receive an Android 8 update in 2018. The phone is priced at US$699.99 and will be available in several countries, including the US, Canada, and Europe, on November 17.

site_title: Ford leads boom in pickup sales as total US vehicle sales rise
summary: Ford's F-Series led a surge in US pickup sales, with deliveries rising 16% in October, the best October since 2004. Total US vehicle sales also beat analysts' estimates, driven by strong demand for pickups and vans. The positive sales indicate a boost for carmakers' profits and the US economy, with employment in the construction industry reaching a decade high. Companies are boosting discounts and benefiting from consumers replacing vehicles damaged by Hurricane Harvey, contributing to a surprise uptick in total US car industry sales.

site_title: StarHub's Q3 profit falls 11.5%
summary: StarHub reported a net profit of S$76.2 million in Q3 2017, down 11.5% from the same period last year due to lower takings from mobile, Pay TV, and broadband services. Higher depreciation and amortization expenses also contributed to the decline. The company's bottomline was dented by the addition of 4G spectrum and other assets.

site_title: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust posts flat DPU for Q3 at 0.86 cents
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) reported a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.86 Singapore cents for Q3, driven by 5.5% higher revenue and 7.1% increase in net property income. The 9-month DPU rose 3.9% to 2.64 Singapore cents. The counter inched up 0.5 Singapore cents to close at 44 Singapore cents.

site_title: US:Wall St opens flat ahead of tax bill, Fed chair pick
summary: US stocks opened flat on November 2, 2017, ahead of the unveiling of a tax bill and President Trump's decision on the next Federal Reserve chair. The Dow Jones fell 0.35 points to 23,434.66, the S&P 500 lost 1.62 points to 2,577.74, and the Nasdaq dropped 6.51 points to 6,710.02. Investors are bracing for the tax bill and the potential impact on the economy, while also awaiting the Fed chair pick.

site_title: Ralph Lauren's quarterly revenue, profit beat estimates
summary: Ralph Lauren Corp's quarterly revenue and profit exceeded Wall Street estimates, driven by cost-cutting and increased sales of full-price apparel. The company's adjusted gross margins rose 3% and revenue per unit sold rose 5% in the second quarter. Net income rose to $143.8 million, beating estimates of $1.89 per share. Revenue fell 9% to $1.67 billion, hurt by a pullback from department stores and factory outlets. The company raised its 2018 operating margin forecast to 9.5-10.5%.

site_title: BOE raises interest rate for first time in more than 10 years
summary: The Bank of England raised interest rates for the first time in over 10 years, increasing the benchmark rate to 0.5% from 0.25%. The decision was made by Governor Mark Carney and the Monetary Policy Committee, who voted 7-2 to increase rates. The move aims to combat inflation, which is expected to reach 2.2% in three years. The decision removes emergency stimulus introduced after the EU referendum and implies that two more quarter-point increases are not imminent. The bank also warned of "considerable risks" to the outlook due to Brexit.
