images.alt_text: Bank of England policy makers raised interest rates for the first time in a decade, yet showed concern for Britain's Brexit-dented economy by indicating that another increase isn't imminent.

site_title: US jobless claims near 44-1/2-year low
summary: US jobless claims fell to a 44-1/2-year low of 229,000 in the week ended Oct 28, supporting expectations of a sharp job growth rebound in October. Worker productivity increased at its fastest pace in three years, strengthening the case for the Federal Reserve raising interest rates in December. The data contrasts with wage pressures remaining tame, despite a tightening labor market.

site_title: China Aviation Oil Q3 net profit falls 8%
summary: China Aviation Oil (S) Corp reported a 8% drop in Q3 net profit to US$21.4 million, mainly due to lower trading gains and supply disruptions. Revenue rose 33% to US$5.2 billion, driven by increased trading volume and oil prices. Earnings per share fell 8% to 2.49 US cents. The counter fell 0.8% to S$1.76.

site_title: Nestle to use cage-free eggs by 2020
summary: Nestle, the world's largest packaged foods company, aims to use only cage-free eggs by 2020 in Europe and the US, and by 2025 elsewhere. The change will affect tens of millions of chickens, following similar pledges by companies like Kraft Heinz and McDonald's. This move comes as governments consider laws to protect laying hens, with California already requiring cage-free eggs. Nestle's decision is part of a growing trend among foodmakers to address animal welfare concerns.

site_title: Thai economic growth close to 4% this year
summary: Thai economic growth is projected to reach 3.8-3.9% this year, with the full potential at 4-5%. Finance Minister Apisak Tantivorawong attributed the growth to the country's efforts, stating that 4% growth is a target. The July-September period's growth is estimated at 4% from a year earlier. This marks an increase from the previously forecasted 3.6% growth and follows a 3.2% growth rate last year.

site_title: CDL's China unit ties up with China Vanke through partial divestment of two projects
summary: CDL's China unit, CDL China, has partnered with China Vanke through a partial divestment of two projects in Chongqing for 986 million yuan (S$202 million). CDL China divested 70% of Chongqing Huang Huayuan and 50% of Eling Residences to Vanke, retaining 30% and 50% equity stakes respectively for future upside. The move is part of CDL's strategy to recycle capital for expansion plans.

site_title: Homebuilders drop as new buyers see US tax break cut in half
summary: Homebuilders are experiencing a downturn as the Republican tax plan reduces the interest deduction for newly purchased homes to $500,000, down from the current $1 million cap. This change is expected to limit the attractiveness of buying a new home. The SPDR S&P Homebuilders exchange-traded fund has seen its largest loss in a year, reflecting the impact of the plan on the industry.

site_title: Now, that's suite
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is investing $850 million in a major overhaul of its Airbus A380 cabins to compete with rivals. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow Airport is considering increasing fees for its $10 billion upgrade. Tesla has expanded its robotaxi service to California and Arizona, while FedEx is partnering with Singapore's QuikBot to deploy robots for deliveries. Delta Air Lines has offered a positive outlook on travel demand, boosting its shares. Japan's carmakers have cut export prices to the US to offset the impact of tariffs.

site_title: BOE hikes rates for the first time in a decade
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) raised its benchmark interest rate to 0.5% for the first time in over a decade, reversing an emergency cut made in 2016. The decision, voted 7-2, aims to combat inflation and reverse the effects of the Brexit vote. Sterling fell sharply following the announcement, with the central bank predicting only "very gradual" further increases over the next three years.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit registers IPO prospectus
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit has registered its prospectus for a US$553.1 million initial public offering (IPO), offering 262.77 million shares at 88 US cents apiece. The Reit's initial portfolio comprises 11 freehold office properties valued at US$829.4 million in seven US growth cities. With a distribution yield of 6.8% in 2018 and 7.2% in 2019, Keppel-KBS US Reit aims to grow its fund management business and tap growing demand for attractive US real estate investments.

site_title: Low-cost and Lufthansa bring winter cheer to Frankfurt airport
summary: Low-cost carriers Ryanair and Lufthansa are expected to drive growth at Frankfurt Airport this winter, boosting passenger numbers by around 5% this year. The airport operator, Fraport, has agreed to discounts for Ryanair, angering main customer Lufthansa, but CEO Stefan Schulte believes it was the right decision to open up to low-cost carriers. Lufthansa is using a larger 747 jumbo jet on the Frankfurt-Berlin route, and EasyJet may soon feature on Frankfurt departure boards. Passenger numbers rose 6.3% in October, taking year-to-date growth to 4.8%.

site_title: StarHub's net profit falls 11.5% in Q3
summary: StarHub reported a 11.5% decrease in net profit to S$76.5 million in Q3, down from the same period last year. Revenue fell 0.8% to S$580.4 million, mainly due to lower service revenues from mobile, Pay TV, and broadband services. Total service revenue remained stable at S$545.4 million. The company declared an interim dividend of 4 cents per share, down from 5 cents last year.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries' Q3 net profit down 38%
summary: Sembcorp Industries' Q3 net profit plummeted 37.7% to S$33.6 million, largely due to higher finance costs and lower revenue. Revenue fell 15.5% to S$1.81 billion, primarily due to reduced marine division contributions. The company also wrote down S$56.3 million on its utilities business and impaired assets worth S$52.4 million. Despite this, the group's urban development business is expected to deliver better performance, and it has secured new contracts in India and other regions.

site_title: AutoNation to maintain, repair Alphabet's Waymo vehicle fleet
summary: US auto retailer AutoNation Inc has partnered with Alphabet's self-driving car unit Waymo to maintain and repair its vehicle fleet, including the Chrysler Pacifica hybrid. The deal, which will expand to additional brands, aims to support Waymo's growth as it adds new brands to its fleet. AutoNation's shares rose 4% following the announcement, which is part of a series of recent partnerships Waymo has formed. Fully self-driving vehicles are expected to hit the market by 2020, with General Motors and Ford also planning to sell them by 2021.

site_title: Singer Neil Young to auction model train collection
summary: Rock singer Neil Young, 71, is selling over 230 model trains from his collection, valued up to $9,000, through an auction in Los Angeles in December. Young, a model train enthusiast for over 20 years, designed remote control devices to help his son with cerebral palsy. A portion of the auction proceeds will benefit the Bridge School in California, which his ex-wife Pegi Young co-founded. Young is also selling some of his classic car collection, including a 1953 Buick Roadmaster Skylark convertible with a pre-auction estimate of $200,000 to $300,000.

site_title: Singapore shares lose 11 points on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares fell 11.11 points, or 0.33%, to close at 3,380.50, following losses in OCBC and UOB. The benchmark Straits Times Index retreated ahead of the US tax reform and President Donald Trump's expected replacement of Janet Yellen with Jerome Powell. Thin trading resulted in 285 losers to 170 gainers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish lower
summary: Hong Kong shares finished lower on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.26% to 28,518.64, amid caution from increased Chinese bond yields. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the latter falling 0.67%. The losses were attributed to concerns about China's economic growth.

site_title: Failed acquisition deals worldwide hit 8-year high in 2016: study
summary: A new study by Intralinks and the University of London's Cass Business School found that 7.2% of M&A deals worldwide failed to complete in 2016, the highest rate since the global financial crisis in 2008. The Asia-Pacific region had the highest rate of failed deals, with China, Australia, and Singapore topping the global list of deal failure rates. The study analyzed 78,565 M&A transactions between 1992 and 2016 and identified factors contributing to deal failure, including sector, target type, and macro-level financial factors.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets dip at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the open, with London's FTSE 100 falling fractionally, Frankfurt's DAX 30 dropping 0.1%, and Paris's CAC 40 slipping by around the same amount. The Bank of England is set to announce its first interest-rate rise in a decade, expected to increase the key interest rate to 0.50% to tame high British inflation. Meanwhile, the US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, solidifying expectations for a possible rate hike in December.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks hit fresh two-decade peak
summary: Tokyo stocks reached a 21-year high on Thursday, closing at 22,539.12 on the Nikkei 225 index. Despite concerns about overheating, Honda's 5% gain after raising its annual profit outlook boosted the market. The broader Topix index also rose 0.41%. The rally comes as investors brush off US trade threats, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 2.88 points to 1,741.05, closing lower on Thursday. The index saw 2.9 billion lots worth RM2 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 518 to 339.

site_title: OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust's DPU for Q3 slips 13%
summary: OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (OUE C-Reit) reported a 13% drop in its distribution per unit (DPU) for the third quarter, slipping to 1.15 Singapore cents from 1.32 Singapore cents in the same period last year. Revenue fell 2.1% to S$43.3 million due to lower retail rental income and higher property tax expenses. The company's nine-month DPU dropped 12% to 3.53 Singapore cents. No dividend was recommended for the period, and the counter closed 0.7% lower at 72 Singapore cents.

site_title: Wee Cho Yaw to retire from UOB board
summary: Wee Cho Yaw, a veteran banker who led United Overseas Bank (UOB) for six decades, is set to retire from the bank's board in April 2018. He will relinquish his board responsibilities and retain his chairman emeritus title, while also being appointed honorary adviser to the board. Former Deputy Prime Minister Wong Kan Seng has been nominated to succeed Chairman Hsieh Fu Hua, who will retire next year. UOB has praised Wee's leadership, which expanded the bank into a major regional player and guided it through financial crises.

site_title: World's biggest pension fund adds US$39b as stocks rise
summary: Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) reported its fifth-straight quarterly gain, with a 3% return of 4.5 trillion yen (S$53.6 billion) in the three months ended Sept 30. The fund's assets reached a record 156.8 trillion yen, driven by global stocks advancing to new highs and a weakening yen. GPIF's domestic equities added 1.8 trillion yen, while foreign equities increased by 2 trillion yen, boosted by the euro's strength. The fund's president, Norihiro Takahashi, stated that assets are managed from a long-term perspective.

site_title: Shell beats Q3 expectations with 50% rise in profit
summary: Royal Dutch Shell reported a 50% rise in underlying net profit for its third-quarter earnings, beating analysts' expectations. The net income attributable to shareholders came to US$4.1 billion, up from US$2.72 billion a year earlier. This surpasses the company-provided analysts'consensus of US$3.62 billion. The profit increase is attributed to various factors, including higher oil prices and efficient operations.

site_title: Credit Suisse CEO sceptical about Bitcoin "bubble"
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Tidjane Thiam expressed caution about Bitcoin, citing its anonymity and anti-money laundering challenges, making it unappealing for banks. He believes the current interest in Bitcoin could eventually subside, as it is driven by speculation and the definition of a bubble. Bitcoin reached a record high of over $7,000, a sevenfold increase since the start of the year, driven primarily by speculation.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: mm2 Asia agreed to acquire Cathay Cineplexes' Singapore cinema operations for S$230m, with the deal set to close on Nov 24. DBS launched the world's largest banking API developer platform, while SIA invested US$850m in new cabin products for its Airbus A380 fleet. In other news, Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: South Korea's economic recovery not strong enough to be felt by many people yet: minister
summary: South Korea's economy is expected to grow 3% this year, but its recovery is not yet strong enough to be felt by many people, according to Finance Minister Kim Dong-yeon. The economy saw the fastest growth in seven years in the third quarter, but it remains concentrated in export sectors, with tourism and retail growth lagging. The country's economic recovery is also not yet widespread, with external risks easing but still posing a challenge.

site_title: Citic Envirotech's Q3 net profit jumps 154%
summary: Citic Envirotech reported a 154% jump in Q3 net profit to S$58.8 million, from S$23.1 million in the same period last year. Revenue doubled to S$273.9 million, driven by increased takings from its engineering business. The company expects growth from new business segments, including water investment and environmental services, which it attributes to the Chinese government's environmental protection push. Shares closed at 78 Singapore cents, one cent down.

site_title: Indonesia jails tax dodgers in race to meet budget goals
summary: Indonesia is cracking down on tax dodgers as part of a national crackdown to meet a 1,473 trillion rupiah tax revenue target. Dozens of people, including foreign nationals, have been jailed for unpaid taxes, while hundreds more have been banned from traveling overseas. The government has also seized luxury cars and questioned individuals about unreported purchases abroad. The strategy, described as "gijzeling," is a last resort but has been effective in increasing tax compliance, with 60% of the target collected as of September 30.

site_title: Sing Holdings, Wee Hur to launch Parc Botannia in Sengkang next weekend
summary: SING Holdings and Wee Hur Holdings are set to launch Parc Botannia, a new residential project in Sengkang, on November 11. The 70:30 joint venture clinched the site in a state tender in September last year for S$287.1 million. Despite anticipation of further price growth next year, the developers are launching now, citing an improved economic showing.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall, snap 4-day winning streak; won steady
summary: Seoul's KOSPI index fell 10.11 points, or 0.40%, to 2,546.36, snapping a four-day winning streak. The won was up 0.1% against the US dollar, at 1,113.09 per dollar. Foreigners were net sellers of 1,631 million won worth of shares. The KOSPI has risen 26.2% this year and 8.07% in the previous 30 days, with a current price-to-earnings ratio of 12.10.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index losing 0.21% to 28,533.66, and the Shanghai Composite Index slipping 0.13% to 3,391.65. The decline follows a previous day's rally.

site_title: Tesla's solar installations fall but more people opt to buy them
summary: Tesla installed 109 megawatts of solar energy systems in the third quarter, down from 187 megawatts in the same period last year. The decline is attributed to a shift in focus towards residential systems, with 46% of installed systems sold rather than leased, up from 13% a year earlier. Tesla expects cash sales to surpass 50% this quarter and plans to ramp up textured-glass solar roof installations at its Buffalo factory.

site_title: US Fed likely to raise rates in Dec amid more upbeat economic outlook: analysts
summary: The US Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates in December, with analysts citing a more upbeat economic outlook. Asian shares reached a 10-year high on Thursday, driven by the Fed's optimism about the US economy. Despite core inflation remaining soft, the Fed acknowledged that recent hurricanes boosted overall inflation. Analysts predict a fifth rate hike of this cycle, with a probability of over 80% attached to a December hike. The decision is expected to be made amid the announcement of a tax bill from Republicans in the US House of Representatives.

site_title: Valuing a business via its income still preferred in Asean: study
summary: A study by the Institute of Valuers and Appraisers, Singapore (IVAS), and Ernst & Young Solutions (EY) found that 88% of Asean business executives prefer valuing a business via its income, with Ebitda being the preferred yardstick. The market approach was the second most preferred, with revenue coming in second. Executives identified estimating cash flow projections as the most challenging task, and 45.5% would prepare multiple scenarios to account for uncertainty. Disruptive technology is expected to have the biggest impact on business value, requiring adaptability in valuation processes.

site_title: Australia shares end lower after NAB earnings; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares closed 0.1% lower, reversing early gains, after National Australia Bank (NAB) reported restructuring charges of A$500-800 million and plans to shed 4,000 jobs. The materials sector rose 1.9% due to a surge in iron ore and nickel prices, with Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton reaching new highs. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.4% led by consumer staples.

site_title: Japan 'serial killer' said to be quiet child turned sex trade scout
summary: A 27-year-old Japanese man, Takahiro Shiraishi, has confessed to murdering and dismembering nine young people in Tokyo, with as many as 240 bone parts found in his apartment. Shiraishi, who was once a quiet schoolboy, later worked as a scout for sex parlors and was arrested in 2017 for recruiting a young woman into prostitution. He was handed a suspended jail sentence and reportedly told investigators he killed his victims "as soon as he met them." Authorities found evidence of strangulation, choking, and dismemberment in his apartment, and he has been charged with multiple counts of murder.

site_title: Remittance startup TransferWise raises US$280m in latest fund raising
summary: TransferWise, a London-based remittance startup, has raised US$280 million in its latest funding round led by Old Mutual Global Investors and IVP. The company, valued at over US$1 billion, plans to expand its services in Asia, particularly in Singapore, where it has set up an office. The new funding round brings the company's total funding to US$397 million. TransferWise aims to roll out a "borderless" account for companies, allowing them to transact overseas in local currency, and plans to grow its staff in Singapore from 25 to 50 by the end of the year.

site_title: Beyonce, James Earl Jones set for live-action remake of The Lion King
summary: Beyonce, James Earl Jones, and John Oliver are set to star in a live-action remake of Disney's "The Lion King". The film, directed by Jon Favreau, follows the storyline of Simba's journey to become king after his uncle Scar's betrayal. The cast includes Donald Glover as Simba, Chiwetel Ejiofor as Scar, Beyonce as Simba's love interest Nala, and Alfre Woodard as Simba's mother Sarabi. The film is expected to hit US theaters on July 19, 2019.

site_title: Fujitsu, Lenovo agree to PC merger
summary: Fujitsu and Lenovo have agreed to merge Fujitsu's struggling PC business, with Lenovo holding a 51% controlling share. The deal will allow Fujitsu to focus on its profitable IT services operations while cutting 3,200 jobs. Fujitsu had previously explored a merger with Toshiba and Vaio, but those talks failed. The move is part of Fujitsu's restructuring efforts, which come as Japanese firms face stiff competition from lower-cost rivals overseas.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall after NAB results; NZ up on consumer staples
summary: Australian shares were nearly unchanged at 5,937.2 due to gains in the materials sector counteracted by losses in financials from National Australia Bank's results. NAB's annual cash profit rose 2.5% but expects A$500-800 million in restructuring costs. The country's trade surplus widened to A$989 million in August. In contrast, New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 Index rose 0.2% due to gains in consumer staples.

site_title: Asia: Markets edge up on US growth forecast
summary: Asian markets edged up on Thursday, driven by strong US growth forecasts, with Tokyo shares adding 0.2% and Hong Kong rising 0.1%. The US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, solidifying expectations for a December rate hike. Apple and Alibaba are set to release earnings, while the Bank of England is expected to deliver its first interest rate increase in over a decade. The US dollar strengthened, lending support to Asian exports, and traders await President Trump's announcement on the Federal Reserve's new chair.

site_title: Raffles Education sets Nov 29 for EGM; tycoon Oei wants chairman removed
summary: Raffles Education Corp will hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on Nov 29 to vote on the removal of founder, chairman, and CEO Chew Hua Seng. Shareholders will also vote on resolutions to disclose the identities of those who received new shares and appoint an independent director as non-executive chairman. Tycoon Oei Hong Leong, who holds a 12.88% stake, has asked for Chew's ouster, citing no reason for his move. The EGM will be held at the Novotel Singapore Clarke Quay.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi makes first visit to crisis-hit northern Rakhine
summary: Myanmar's leader Aung San Suu Kyi made her first visit to conflict-battered northern Rakhine State, a region that has seen most of its Rohingya Muslim population forced out by an army campaign. The visit comes as the international community pressures Myanmar to provide security for the Rohingya and allow them to return home. Suu Kyi's trip has been criticized for not addressing the humanitarian crisis, with observers saying she has chosen not to criticize the army to avoid a backlash from a powerful institution.

site_title: Anger wells in New York suspect's shocked Jersey town
summary: In the New Jersey town of Paterson, where Uzbek terrorist suspect Sayfullo Saipov lived with his family, residents are outraged and fearful after Saipov killed eight people in a terrorist attack in New York. The community, largely Muslim, feels betrayed and angry that Saipov, who had lived among them for a year, carried out the attack. Neighbors describe Saipov as a quiet and unassuming individual, and many express their desire to be accepted in the US, which they see as a country of opportunity. The attack has sparked a mix of shock, fear, and anger in the community.

site_title: Goldman jokes, takes 'bites' out of pizza to attract US borrowers
summary: Goldman Sachs hosted a comedy event to promote its new personal loan platform, Marcus, which charges principal and interest, but not fees. The event featured comedians and menu items with "bites" taken out of them, portraying rival lenders as taking a chunk out of consumers' pockets. Marcus aims to court Main Street borrowers with debt, aiming to destigmatize debt and attract credit card borrowers. The platform offers loans from $3,500 to $30,000 with lower interest rates, targeting those struggling with debt.

site_title: Two dead in shooting inside suburban Denver Walmart
summary: At least two people were killed and one wounded in a shooting inside a Walmart store in suburban Denver on Wednesday. Police in Thornton, Colorado, confirmed the fatalities and took a woman to a local hospital, but no further details were given about the circumstances or the shooter. The investigation is ongoing.

images.alt_text: At least two people were killed and one wounded in a shooting inside a Walmart store in suburban Denver on Wednesday, police said.

site_title: Far East H-Trust posts 8% drop in Q3 DPS on softer performance in hotels, offices
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (Far East H-Trust) reported an 8% drop in distribution per stapled security (DPS) for its third quarter ended Sept 30, to 1.03 Singapore cents, due to softer performance in its hotel and office portfolios. Gross revenue fell 2% year-over-year to S$27.46 million, primarily due to lower master lease rental from hotels and serviced residences. Net property income slipped 2.3% to S$24.77 million. Despite the challenges, the trust's CEO expects the situation to improve in the near future.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as Honda revs up
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on November 2, 2017, as the yen fell against the dollar and Honda's shares jumped over 3% after the company raised its annual profit outlook. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.38% and the Topix index increased 0.31%.

site_title: Amid soaring profits, Facebook vows to curb abuse
summary: Facebook reported a 79% profit increase in the third quarter, reaching $4.7 billion, despite rising costs and slowing ad growth predictions. CEO Mark Zuckerberg emphasized the company's commitment to preventing abuse on its platforms, stating that protecting users is more important than maximizing profits. The company's investment priorities include video content and security measures, and it reported 2.07 billion monthly active users, a 16% increase from last year. Facebook also faced criticism for allowing Russian entities to spread misinformation on its platforms, with the company disclosing 120,000 Russian-based Instagram posts seen by some 20 million Americans.

site_title: DBS launches world's largest banking API developer platform
summary: DBS launched the world's largest banking API developer platform, boasting 155 APIs across 20 categories. The platform allows other brands to access services like funds transfers and peer-to-peer payment services. DBS has had 50 successful collaborations, including with McDonald's, which introduced the PayLah! payment option. The move aims to enable fintech-like ability and platform-like inclusiveness, giving DBS an edge in the digital banking space.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Singapore's shares opened flat on Thursday, following overnight gains on Wall Street, as the Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged. The Straits Times Index was down 0.19% at 3,385 points, with 62.8 million shares traded.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB recommends 'buy' HRnetGroup on expected acquisition spree
summary: Brokerage firm RHB recommends a 'buy' rating on HRnetGroup due to its strong cash flows, superior net margins, and expected acquisition spree. The company has a war chest of S$280 million and no debt, fueling the acquisition strategy. RHB forecasts the takeovers could add S$20 million to HRnetGroup's net profit. The company has stable growth, superior margins, and is the market leader in recruitment in Singapore. The target price is set at S$1.14, representing a 33% estimated return.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 0.49 points to 1,744.42, driven by a gain-to-loss ratio of 125:73. Volume reached 96.04 million lots worth RM33.78 million.

site_title: Stocks to watch: mm2 Asia, Oxley, FLT, Far East H-Trust
summary: Stocks to watch on Thursday, Nov 2, 2017, include mm2 Asia, which proposed acquiring Cathay Cineplexes' Singapore cinema operations for S$230 million. Oxley Holdings unveiled a dividend policy of paying at least 25% of its profit. Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust posted a 8.6% increase in DPU to 1.77 cents. Far East Hospitality Trust saw a 8% decline in DPU to 1.03 cents.

site_title: Duo get much heftier fines for unauthorised share trading after MAS appeal
summary: The High Court of Singapore has increased fines for two individuals, Mr. Wang Boon Heng and Ms. Foo Jee Chin, for unauthorised share trading. Wang's fine was doubled to S$150,000 and Foo's fine was increased to S$75,000. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) appealed the original fines, stating they did not adequately reflect the severity of the breaches. The duo must also pay S$21,000 in legal costs and S$58,636 in previous costs, totaling S$79,636. The fines stem from Wang's unauthorised share trading in Foo's accounts between 2007.

site_title: UK minister quits as sexual harassment scandal deepens
summary: British Defence Secretary Michael Fallon resigned amid a deepening scandal over sexual harassment at Westminster. Fallon quit after allegations surfaced about his past conduct, including a 2002 incident where he put his hand on a journalist's knee. Prime Minister Theresa May has called for tougher rules on MPs' behavior and is set to meet with other party leaders to discuss the issue. The scandal has led to investigations into other politicians, including a former MP accused of sexual assault and a junior trade minister under investigation for asking a former secretary to buy him sex toys.

site_title: FLT posts Q4 DPU of 1.77 S cents, 9% above forecast
summary: FLT, a logistics and industrial trust, reported a Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.77 Singapore cents, 9% above forecast. Gross revenue and adjusted net property income increased 4.8% and 4.7% respectively. Distributable income was 12.1% above forecast, driven by contributions from recently acquired properties and insurance claim recoveries. FLT's portfolio value rose 1.9% to A$1.91 billion, with a valuation uplift of A$35.5 million. The trust's total distributions for the six-month period will amount to 3.52 Singapore cents.

site_title: Oxley unveils dividend policy on favourable market conditions
summary: Oxley Holdings has unveiled a dividend policy, committing to pay at least 25% of its consolidated profit after tax for FY2018 and FY2019, taking advantage of favourable market conditions. The policy aims to provide clearer guidance to shareholders and aligns with good corporate governance practices. The developer reported a 146% increase in revenue for the first quarter, driven by a nearly sevenfold jump in net profit to S$48.7 million. Dividends will be paid on a half-yearly basis, subject to the board's approval and shareholders' consent.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks fall, won down on Thursday
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.01% to 2,556.13, with the won also weakening to 1,112.89 per US dollar. This marks a decline in the market, following mild gains in US stocks and a rise in Japanese stocks. Despite the drop, the Kospi has still seen a 26.2% gain this year and an 8.07% increase in the previous 30 days. Foreigners were net buyers of 55.016 million won worth of shares, while the benchmark 3-year Korean treasury bond yielded 2.121%, lower than the previous day's 2.14%.

site_title: The perks for being excellent
summary: Organisations adopting the Business Excellence framework have reported benefits such as cross-industry interaction, improved decision-making, and enhanced human resource initiatives. DBS, Jumbo Group, and Sheng Siong, among others, have achieved Singapore Quality Awards and Class recognitions, citing the framework as a guide for management processes and innovation. The framework has helped organisations identify strengths, improve performance, and stay resilient in the face of disruptions.

site_title: Gold holds gains after Federal Reserve says it will leave rates unchanged
summary: The Federal Reserve announced it will keep interest rates unchanged at 1-1.25%, allowing gold prices to advance. Gold prices rose 0.4% to $1,276.37 an ounce after breaking through its 100-day moving average, driven by positioning reversals and anticipation of less hawkish monetary policy under new Fed Chairman Jerome Powell.

site_title: Europe: Shares start November on a two-year high
summary: European stocks reached a two-year high on November 1, driven by strong company earnings and record highs in world stocks. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.4%, led by gains in Germany's DAX index, which hit a fresh record high. Despite concerns over Catalonia's independence bid, the European benchmark has enjoyed its fifth straight day of gains. Top performers included British drugmaker Indivior, which soared 8%, and Volkswagen, which rose 4.8% after its diesel emissions scandal losses were wiped off.

site_title: Trump told Fed's Powell he was picked to replace Yellen: WSJ
summary: President Donald Trump informed Federal Reserve Governor Jerome Powell he is the pick to replace Janet Yellen as Fed chair, according to the Wall Street Journal. If confirmed, Powell would take over in February. Trump chose Powell as a middle-ground option to depart from the Obama era, while markets preferred continuity with Yellen. Powell is seen as a centrist unlikely to pursue steep rate hikes, making him amenable to the Trump administration's deregulation agenda.

site_title: Sina embroiled in proxy fight as US investor pushes for change
summary: US investor Aristeia Capital is engaging in a proxy fight against Sina, a Chinese Internet company, to push for change on its board. Aristeia is lobbying shareholders to back its two candidates in a bid to improve corporate governance and increase shareholder returns. Sina has called Aristeia's efforts "self-serving" and accused it of being naive about China's Internet sector. The proxy fight highlights the limits of foreign ownership of Chinese Internet companies and the need for greater corporate governance protections.

site_title: mm2 Asia to acquire Cathay Cineplexes for S$230m after failed Golden Village bid
summary: mm2 Asia has entered into an option agreement to acquire Cathay Cineplexes' Singapore cinema operations for S$230 million, set to close on Nov 24. The acquisition will add an additional source of recurring income and growth for the group, following its diversification into the cinema management and operations business. Cathay Cineplexes' eight cinemas across Singapore will be retained, with employees and the Cathay name to be protected by mm2 Asia's executive chairman Melvin Ang. The deal follows mm2's failed bid for Golden Village cinema business in Singapore.

site_title: Tighter environmental curbs impact China PMI
summary: China's PMI fell to 51.6 in October, down from 52.4 in September, due to weaker domestic demand and stricter environmental measures. This is expected to intensify and weaken growth momentum. The country's GDP growth is also set to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: SIA launches new cabin products worth US$850m in investment
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has launched new cabin products worth US$850 million for its Airbus A380 fleet, including a refreshed Suites section with 21-inch-wide swivel chairs, full-flat beds, and 32-inch HD monitors. This is SIA's first upgrade of its Suites, launched 10 years ago, amid increasing competition from rivals like Qatar Airways, Etihad Airways, and Emirates. The first new A380 will enter commercial service on Dec 18 on the Singapore-Sydney route, with existing A380s to be retrofitted with the new products.

site_title: Fourth Avenue residential site triggered for sale with minimum bid of S$448.8m
summary: A residential site at Fourth Avenue, under the Reserve List of the 2017 Government Land Sales programme, has been launched for sale by public tender with a minimum bid price of S$448.8 million. The site can build an estimated 455 housing units and spans 1.9 hectares in Bukit Timah. The tender closes on December 5, with the URA not disclosing the identity of the applicant who triggered the land sale.

images.alt_text: A residential site at Fourth Avenue under the Reserve List of the first-half 2017 Government Land Sales (GLS) programme has been launched for sale by public tender on Thursday, the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) announced.

A residential site at Fourth Avenue under the Reserve List of the first-half 2017 Government Land Sales (GLS) programme has been launched for sale by public tender on Thursday, the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) announced.

site_title: US cars sales offer mixed picture in October
summary: US car sales declined 11% in October compared to the prior month and 1.3% compared to October 2016, according to Autodata. Despite financial incentives and relatively flat new vehicle prices, some carmakers, including Ford, Nissan, Honda, and Toyota, posted gains, while others, like General Motors and Fiat Chrysler, saw declines. The seasonally-adjusted annual sales rate remains above forecasts at 18.09 million units, suggesting a strong market despite not reaching a record pace.

site_title: Bitcoin futures are next after being offered as swaps, options
summary: CME Group plans to introduce bitcoin futures by the end of 2017, allowing institutional investors to buy the cryptocurrency. This move follows Cboe Global Markets and startup LedgerX, which already offer swaps and options. Regulatory approval for exchange-traded funds (ETFs) is expected to take 6-12 months, paving the way for more institutional investment in bitcoin.

site_title: There's affordable luxury in France: here are the tips
summary: France, known for being an expensive vacation destination, offers affordable luxury with expert tips from Joelle Kolich. Ditching rental cars and opting for the high-speed TGV train system can save money. Exploring lesser-known restaurants and neighborhoods, such as the Bastille, can also reduce costs. Visiting cities like Bordeaux, Lyon, and Rennes instead of Paris can be up to 30% less expensive. Skipping hotel breakfast and opting for local cafes instead can save up to 35 euros per person. By following these tips, luxury seekers on a limited budget can enjoy a luxurious yet affordable vacation in France.

site_title: New Zealand will stay relatively centrist despite change of govt
summary: New Zealand's newly formed coalition government, led by Jacinda Ardern's centre-left Labour party, has vowed to remain relatively centrist despite the change in government. The administration aims to implement tighter restrictions on immigration and foreign purchases of real estate, but these policies are expected to be incremental rather than radical. The government remains committed to fiscal sustainability, with plans to run operating surpluses and reduce net public debt to 20% of GDP over the next five years. This approach is expected to maintain New Zealand's relatively centrist stance in an international context.

site_title: Signs of closer Russia-China ties belie limited progress
summary: Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev concluded a multi-day trip to China, where he met with President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Keqiang, highlighting growing bilateral dialogue between Beijing and Moscow. Key areas of cooperation include regional and global issues such as the Korean nuclear stand-off and the Syrian conflict, as well as economic partnerships and energy deals. China and Russia have also been working on alternative financial institutions and infrastructure projects. Despite limited progress on economic projects, the visit marked a boost to bilateral cooperation, with both sides seeking to strengthen their strategic coordination on key issues.

site_title: Deadly US naval collisions in Pacific 'avoidable': top admiral
summary: A US Navy report finds that two deadly Pacific naval collisions were "avoidable" due to "multiple failures" of those on watch, including leadership issues and sailors not paying attention in busy shipping lanes. The report, from Chief of Naval Operations Admiral John Richardson, highlights preventable causes rather than technical failures. The incidents resulted in 17 sailor deaths and underscore the stresses of frequent deployments across the Pacific region.

site_title: China's iron ore market structure goes into contango
summary: China's iron ore market has shifted into contango, a rare market structure where May deliveries are now more expensive than January deliveries, due to speculation about demand recovery after China's steel production cuts. This reversal has pushed the May price above January's price, with futures prices currently trading at 457 yuan, a premium of 23.5 yuan. Analysts expect significant pent-up demand to emerge after winter, driven by relaxed curbs on steel production.

site_title: Oil slips, erases gains as US crude draw shy of API report
summary: Oil prices slipped on Wednesday, erasing gains after the US Energy Information Administration reported a 2.4 million barrel crude stock draw, exceeding analysts' forecast of 1.8 million barrels. Despite this, oil remained near its highest levels since 2015 due to lower global supply and expectations of Opec production cuts through 2018. Brent futures settled at $60.49 a barrel, while US crude settled at $54.30 a barrel. Analysts expect Russia to stick to its agreement to curb oil output by 300,000 barrels.

site_title: US approves US$1b Qatar arms deal despite Gulf crisis
summary: The US government has approved a $1.1 billion deal to service Qatar's F-15 fighter jets despite the ongoing diplomatic crisis between Qatar and its Arab neighbors. The decision comes as the US seeks to maintain a strong military presence in the region. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson had been working to broker an agreement to ease tensions and counter Iranian influence. The deal includes improved cyber security services and will be used to maintain Qatar's defense capabilities.

site_title: Deutsche Bank looking for another large office in Frankfurt ahead of Brexit: Source
summary: Deutsche Bank is searching for a large office space in Frankfurt to accommodate hundreds of employees as it prepares for Britain's departure from the EU. The move aims to consolidate secondary locations and house an expected increase in local headcount due to Brexit. This is part of Frankfurt's growing office property market, which has seen a 20% increase in office space rentals over the past year due to Brexit uncertainty. The bank has not specified how many jobs it plans to shift from London, with estimates ranging from 2,000 to 4,000.

site_title: Federal Reserve keeps rates unchanged, remains on road to December hike
summary: The Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, citing solid US economic growth and a strengthening labor market. The decision, made at the central bank's policy meeting, suggests the Fed is on track to lift borrowing costs again in December. Fed Chair Janet Yellen's term is set to end in February 2018, and President Donald Trump is expected to announce his nomination for the Fed Chair position on Thursday.

site_title: Many roads ahead for Spore's insurance industry
summary: Singapore's Deputy Chairman of the Monetary Authority of Singapore, LIM Hng Kiang, has unveiled plans to modernize the country's insurance sector and tap into emerging trends. The industry is facing challenges in keeping pace with new risks such as cyber, supply chain, and reputation risks. To address this, Singapore aims to develop alternative risk transfer mechanisms like insurance-linked securities, which can generate innovative offerings and create new growth opportunities. The country also plans to modernize its infrastructure and upgrade its processes to stay competitive in the global market.

site_title: By George, it's been rough for men named Papadopoulus
summary: A US man named George Papadopoulos is facing unwanted attention due to sharing a common name with a disgraced former policy adviser who pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI. The real estate developer and others with the same name are experiencing ridicule from colleagues and reporters. The situation has led to a Twitter hashtag #notmyGeorge, with Papadopoulos' fiancée pushing back against the negative attention. The name is extremely common in Greece, but the US media's focus on the other George Papadopoulos has caused confusion and amusement for those with the same name.

site_title: US charges New York suspect who 'felt good' about attack
summary: A 29-year-old Uzbek immigrant, Sayfullo Saipov, has been charged with federal terrorism offenses in connection with the New York City attack on Tuesday. Saipov, who yelled "Allahu Akbar" after the attack, allegedly felt good about what he had done and began planning the strike approximately one year ago. He was inspired by Islamic State group propaganda and deliberately chose Halloween to inflict maximum damage. Saipov waived his rights during a hospital interview and requested to display ISIS flags, and investigators recovered evidence including a black bag, cell phones, and a stun gun.

site_title: Airbus' legal troubles grow amid inaccurate US arms trade filings
summary: Airbus has uncovered inaccuracies in its US filings for arms technology sales, drawing the US into a scandal over alleged misconduct. The company warned of potentially significant fines resulting from existing bribery investigations in the UK and France. The internal investigation, triggered by the US filings, is examining the use of middlemen in jetliner sales. Airbus has not specified the extent of the inaccuracies or the potential fines. The company is facing growing legal troubles amid these allegations.

site_title: Artivision shares jump on potential entry into fintech through proposed RTO
summary: Artivision Technologies Ltd shares jumped 23.53% to close at 2.1 cents after its trading halt was lifted on a proposed acquisition of Mobile Credit Payment Pte Ltd, a pioneer of omni-channel and omni-payment solutions in the Asia-Pacific region. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move into the fast-growing fintech business, with the potential for significant growth. Artivision will acquire MC Payment's entire issued and paid-up share capital and convertible bonds for at least S$80 million, with the controlling shareholder agreeing to redeem outstanding bonds and options.

site_title: A roadmap to superior performance
summary: The Singapore Quality Award (SQA) 2017 honored six organizations, including Neo Group, Select Group, and SP Services, for their superior performance using the Business Excellence (BE) framework. This framework, launched in 1994, helps enterprises strengthen management systems and transform businesses. Since its inception, the BE certification program has certified 112 organizations, with an average of 130 companies attaining certification annually over the past three years. The BE framework provides an internal roadmap to build solid business fundamentals, enabling organizations to stay competitive in a digital economy and venture abroad.

site_title: New York attack probe expands to Uzbekistan
summary: US investigators are expanding their probe into the New York attack to Uzbekistan, focusing on the suspect, Sayfullo Saipov, a 29-year-old immigrant from Uzbekistan. At least eight people were killed and 11 injured in a Halloween attack on a Manhattan bike path. Saipov, who was wounded by police, had declared allegiance to the Islamic State in a handwritten note found in his rental truck. Uzbekistan's President Shavkat Mirziyoyev has pledged to help with the investigation, which aims to determine whether Saipov acted alone or had connections to wider militant cells.

site_title: Added power from digital technology
summary: SP Services, a Singaporean utilities provider, is transforming itself to better serve customers through digital solutions. The company has launched a mobile app to track energy consumption, make transactions, and receive timely reminders. Additionally, SP Services has enhanced its customer service centers with the SP Kiosk, allowing customers to manage their accounts. The organization aims to deliver a seamless, unified experience to customers, anytime, anywhere. This transformation is driven by in-house experts who develop digital solutions to bring greater convenience, help customers save energy, and enjoy a high-quality, sustainable lifestyle.

site_title: Stock market needs whistle-blowing procedure
summary: The Singapore stock market lacks a formal whistle-blowing procedure, leaving complainants vulnerable to reprisals. In contrast, developed markets like the US have systems in place, such as the Securities and Exchange Commission, which encourages public feedback. Implementing a similar system in Singapore could help detect wrongdoing and improve market integrity.

site_title: S'pore shares rally on strong global growth
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index surged 17.53 points, or 0.52%, to close at 3,391.61, its highest level in over two years, driven by optimism on global growth. Banking stocks and shares of Keppel Corporation led the gains, while heavyweights from the Jardine group chalked up losses. The rally follows strong US economic data, rising oil prices, and earnings reports. Investors expect a potentially strong US jobs report this Friday, which could influence the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates.

site_title: Redesigning for superior results
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore has implemented the Business Excellence Framework to redesign its products and services, achieving significant results. The ministry has simplified customer-facing processes, reduced waiting times, and improved customer satisfaction. MOM has also adopted Agile Project Management Framework and re-designed its corporate website, resulting in a 34% improvement in its satisfaction score. The ministry recognizes the importance of its people and has implemented a culture of continual improvement, including employee engagement and wellness programs. MOM has won several awards, including the Singapore Quality Award, and will continue to progress on its Business Excellence journey.

site_title: Oct's share buybacks shrink
summary: Share buybacks in Singapore decreased in October, with 15 listed companies repurchasing 8.3 million shares for S$22.6 million, the lowest monthly amount since April. This represents a 33% drop from September and a 13% decrease from last year. The decrease in buyback consideration was attributed to a decline in global market sentiment.

site_title: Private banks in Asia shifting the game towards advisory
summary: Private banks in Asia are shifting towards an advisory model, driven by client demands for long-term investment views. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's efforts to grow the financial sector into a global force is contributing to this change. Technology is helping private banks meet clients' broader needs, moving away from a traditional brokerage model. This shift is expected to continue as clients increasingly prioritize long-term investment strategies.

site_title: DMX Technologies uncovers new findings from probe
summary: DMX Technologies, an IT solutions provider, has uncovered new findings from a probe into former management and unauthorized payments. The company has lodged a report with Hong Kong's police and intends to cooperate fully with the investigation. In April last year, DMX Technologies sued four former executives and several companies for irregular accounting practices. Unauthorised payments were made to Mozart and Tacoma between 2008 and 2012. The company will issue further announcements as material developments occur.

site_title: Why huge rally in aluminium prices may have further to run
summary: Aluminium prices have surged 28% this year, driven by rising raw material costs, particularly alumina, which has jumped 56% since August due to China's shutdown of some production. Producers face increased costs, but companies that produce both alumina and aluminium are benefiting from the rally. Analysts warn that the high ratio of alumina to aluminium prices may not be sustainable unless prices increase or alumina retreats. China's environmental reforms and production cuts are expected to continue putting pressure on the market.

site_title: QExit, whatsit, whodunnit?
summary: Central banks are expected to stop buying government bonds and start selling them, marking the "exit" from quantitative easing (QE) by the end of 2018. The European Central Bank has already announced its plans to wind down bond purchases, and the US Federal Reserve has made similar announcements in the past. Despite market concerns, bond fund managers remain calm, citing a strengthening global economy and improved underlying economic conditions. Experts predict that the tapering of QE will be calibrated to allow private sector and financial institutions to take over credit expansion, reducing the risk of a sudden liquidity vacuum.

site_title: US dollar climbs against yen before Fed decision
summary: The US dollar climbed 0.4% to 114.06 yen, nearing a 3.5-month high, ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy decision later in the day, which is expected to leave interest rates unchanged. Investors are also watching President Trump's tax reform plans and the potential nomination of Jerome Powell as the next Fed chair. The New Zealand dollar rose 1.2% to a one-week high after data showed a nine-year low in the jobless rate, while the dollar index added 0.1% to 94.680.

site_title: BOE may up rates amid strong manufacturing PMI
summary: British manufacturers reported robust growth in October, with the manufacturing PMI rising to 56.3, exceeding forecasts and fueling speculation of a Bank of England (BOE) interest rate hike for the first time in a decade. Inflation pressure also rose, with headline consumer price inflation reaching a five-year high of 3% in September. Economists expect the BOE to raise interest rates to 0.5% on Thursday, amid concerns about growing inflation.

site_title: Got £100m to spare? London mansion with a very special view could be yours
summary: A 248-year-old London mansion, Doughty House, with a protected view of the Thames, has hit the market for £100m (S$180.8m). The historic property, built in 1769, features 10 bedrooms, a spa, car museum, and bowling alley, with renovations scheduled to start in 2018. The estate, once owned by Britain's third-richest man, Francis Cook, boasts 38,000 sq ft, 48 chandeliers, and a Roman-era mosaic gallery. The property's new owner will have the option to customize the plans.

site_title: Sony revives pet AI project with updated aibo robot dog
summary: Sony has revived its pet AI project, aibo, after more than a decade of inactivity, aiming to rebuild its reputation for innovation. The updated robot dog features new sensing and movement technologies, advanced AI, and cloud computing to develop its personality. Sales begin in Japan in January for 198,000 yen, and Sony plans to sell at least as many new aibo as the original. The firm sees AI as a future pillar of growth, investing in start-ups and establishing a venture capital fund to build partnerships in AI and robotics.

site_title: Swiber JMs eye equity injections for new power generation business
summary: Swiber Holdings, a Singapore-listed offshore and marine group, is seeking to acquire Western Australia-based Interlink Power & Energy Holdings Pty Ltd, a private-owned player in the gas-fired power generation business. The proposed acquisition aims to unlock new equity and revenue streams, paving the way for the restructuring of Swiber's operations. The deal is part of Swiber's efforts to diversify and secure new investments to sustain its business, with a focus on emerging economies such as Indonesia and West Africa.

site_title: S'pore firm Novoflex could turn making of SIM cards on its head
summary: Novoflex, a Singapore-based company, has developed a groundbreaking technology called Secure Authenticable Identification Laminates (sAiL) that can revolutionize the production of SIM cards and IoT devices. This novel process embeds integrated circuit (IC) chips in SIM cards, redefining the manufacturing process. The company's innovation has the potential to transform the industry globally, offering a more secure and efficient method for chip embedding.

site_title: Going green the smart way
summary: Industrial packaging company Greenpac developed innovative solutions for a customer transporting live ornamental fish and a medical instrument weighing 12 kg, resulting in a 20 kg weight reduction. The company's "smart packaging" solutions won the Excellence Award at the 3R Packaging Awards by the National Environment Agency (NEA). Greenpac's innovative approach demonstrates its commitment to reducing environmental impact while driving business growth.

images.alt_text: When a packaging assignment is received from a customer, sales managers and engineers of eco-friendly packaging company Greenpac will meet with the customer multiple times to gain a deeper understanding of their requirements. This focus on working with its partners distinguishes Greenpac from competitors.
"Innovation is a necessity; a requisite for progression, not a luxury. Being in a 'green' field requires us to constantly innovate and transform to make a difference." - CEO Susan Chong, Greenpac

site_title: Embarking on a new journey
summary: Watson EP Industries, a Singapore-based contract manufacturing firm, adopted the enhanced Business Excellence (BE) framework to focus on people development and innovation capabilities. The company received the Capability Development Grant and developed a strategic roadmap to build innovation capabilities. Managing director Seow Poh Eng attributed the BE certification to improved staff morale, stronger team bonding, and a more robust business model. The company now aims to pursue bigger dreams and continue to build upon the framework with best practices.

site_title: Boosting standards with technology
summary: Neo Group, a food-catering company, has implemented technology to automate processes and enhance customer experience. The company developed an in-house IT system, including a Buffet Catering Management System, which integrates sales, procurement, kitchen, and logistics information. This system enabled Neo Group to hold the Singapore record for most buffet caterings in a single day for five years, ensuring high-quality products and services consistently. By leveraging technology, Neo Group has addressed manpower challenges and improved productivity.

site_title: Glencore's HK exit sends message to Aramco
summary: Glencore's departure from Hong Kong's stock exchange marks a shift away from the island's listings, following other companies such as Coach and Fast Retailing. The move sends a message to Saudi Aramco, which may no longer see Hong Kong as a necessary listing. Glencore's initial dual listing in 2011 aimed to attract Asian investors, but the strategy appears to be ineffective. The company's decision is a reminder of the challenges faced by companies seeking to list in Hong Kong.

site_title: Succeeding through tripartism
summary: Singapore's tripartism, a key competitive advantage, is fostered by the Ministry of Manpower's collaboration with the government, labour movement, and employers. This cooperation has led to the formation of the Tripartite Alliance, recognized by the International Labour Organisation, and partnerships with ILO, including the MOM-ILO partnership agreement and the International Forum on Tripartism. Tripartism underpins Singapore's economic competitiveness, harmonious labour-management relations, and strong employment outcomes, making it a unique model for global reference.

site_title: Google Docs glitch locks out users; puts spotlight on privacy concerns
summary: Google Docs experienced a glitch, locking out users who had created or shared innocuous documents due to violating Google's terms of service. The issue was caused by a code push, which incorrectly flagged documents as abusive, prompting users to be automatically blocked. Google apologized for the disruption and stated that a fix is in place to prevent similar incidents. The incident highlights concerns about surveillance and the use of advanced machine learning technologies to analyze vast amounts of user data.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore banks see loan growth picking up, with domestic lending growing 5.1% and 6.2% year-over-year in August and September, respectively. Interest rates are expected to rise as the US Federal Reserve hikes the Fed funds rate in December. Analysts also highlight positive earnings from Sembcorp Marine, which received a US$500 million payment and expects initial orders for its Gravifloat technology. Meanwhile, Cache Logistics Trust has resolved a dispute with Schenker, clearing an overhang on its share price.

site_title: Christie's HK to auction 14.93-carat pink diamond for US$42m
summary: Christie's Hong Kong is set to auction a 14.93-carat oval-shaped pink diamond, "Pink Promise," for US$42 million on November 28. The diamond is considered one of the most valuable pink diamonds ever sold due to its exceptional color and clarity, making up only 2% of colored diamonds produced annually. The auction comes amidst a surge in high-stakes bidding in Hong Kong's auction houses, with a recent Sotheby's sale of a 1,000-year-old Chinese bowl reaching US$37.7 million.

site_title: Grab launches GrabPay to eateries and retailers
summary: Grab launches GrabPay, a mobile wallet service, to select merchants in Singapore, allowing users to pay at participating hawker stalls, restaurants, and retail outlets. The service, which includes QR code payments, will be expanded to hundreds of hawkers and small businesses in the coming weeks. Grab aims to onboard 1,000 merchants by the end of 2017 and launch the service across South-east Asia in 2018. The move is part of its goal to help cash businesses go cashless, following the launch of its peer-to-peer payments service last month.

site_title: Why S'pore is renewing focus on private markets
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced a renewed focus on private markets as part of its industry transformation map (ITM) to achieve annual growth of 4.3% in the financial sector and create 4,000 additional jobs. Private markets have grown significantly over the past 20 years, with the global private equity industry increasing from $300 billion in 1999 to $4.7 trillion in 2017. Private markets offer higher returns and lower volatility compared to public markets, and companies are increasingly opting for private ownership over public listings. MAS aims to leverage its external fund management programme to anchor deeper asset management capabilities in Singapore and build private market funding platforms to enable growth companies to access capital.

site_title: AI can oil financial markets, but call goes out to manage risks
summary: The Financial Stability Board (FSB) warns that the use of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning in financial markets can bring efficiency and interconnectedness, but only if risks are properly managed. Financial institutions are already using AI for credit assessment, pricing, and automating client interactions, and it can also aid in regulatory compliance, surveillance, and fraud detection. However, the FSB notes that AI can create "black boxes" in decision-making, pose monitoring challenges, and lead to new systemically important players outside the regulatory perimeter. Adequate testing and oversight are crucial to mitigate these risks.

site_title: Alibaba leads US$335m funding for Chinese car site SouChe
summary: Alibaba has led a US$335 million funding round for Chinese car site SouChe, valuing the company at between US$1 billion and US$2 billion. The funding will help SouChe expand its car-financing business and prepare for a potential US IPO. The company sells used cars from dealers and provides financing for customers to buy new vehicles, with over 50,000 cars sold through financing. SouChe expects to hit 150 billion yuan in gross merchandise volume in 2017.

site_title: Drugmaker Mylan's woes get worse with president engulfed in vast probe
summary: Mylan, a leading drugmaker, faces further troubles with its president, Rajiv Malik, being accused of colluding in a conspiracy to prop up prices. The company has faced increasing pressure from regulators over price hikes for its EpiPen allergy shot and generic drugs. Malik, who denies the allegations, is one of two senior executives named in a 45-state lawsuit alleging price and market fixing. The company's shares have dropped 6.6% to $35.71, and the investigation may prove damaging to the industry.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

TSky (Jervois), a subsidiary of Tiong Seng Holdings, has exercised its right to rescind the option to buy two freehold sites in Jervois Road due to redevelopment restrictions. DYMON Asia Capital Ltd has become a substantial shareholder of IFS Capital Ltd, while SMRT has ceased to be one. China Jishan Holdings is facing a legal claim by Shanghai Jintumu Real Estate Co over the purchase of a developer and manager of residential and commercial properties. Uni-ASIA Group has acquired a second-hand bulk carrier for approximately US$13.5 million. KTL Global's CEO has been questioned by the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Healthy economies need a healthy Mother Earth
summary: Asean's economic growth is projected to reach 5% annually, with nearly half a billion population expected to be middle class by 2030. The region is set to become the fourth largest economy in the world by 2050, according to IMF projections. However, few businesses consider the impact of environmental sustainability on their operations and profits, despite its potential to affect their success. The failing health of the planet is a critical trend that should be taken into account by businesses to realize Asean's full potential.

site_title: Former Falcon banker's appeal against industry ban thrown out
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has dismissed Jens Sturzenegger's appeal against a lifetime ban from working in the city-state's financial and services sectors. Sturzenegger, a former private banker at Falcon bank, was convicted in the 1MDB case. MAS upheld the ban, which bars him from working in the industry due to his alleged links to Malaysian financier Low Taek Jho. The regulator also issued permanent prohibition orders to two other individuals involved in the 1MDB case, bringing the total to six individuals banned from working in the industry.

site_title: Where innovation and clarity dictate the success recipe
summary: Select Group, a Singapore-based company, has aligned its staff towards a common goal of achieving superior performance through innovation and clarity. The company has created innovative concepts, such as self-ordering kiosks and personalized experiences, to woo customers. With a clear market segmentation strategy, Select Group has achieved six awards at the Marketing Events Awards in 2016 and 2017. The company prioritizes employee development, offering 30% more training hours per employee than the national average, and has been recognized as the Most Supportive Employer Award by Workforce Singapore.

site_title: Big EU fund managers on collision course over the pound
summary: European fund managers are divided on how to trade the UK's potential interest-rate increase, with some betting the Bank of England won't signal further policy tightening due to lingering economic and political risks. Allianz Global Investors and Fidelity International expect a 25 basis point rate hike on Thursday, while Aberdeen Standard Investments sees scope for more than one increase. Analysts expect sterling to rally or slump in value, prompting fund managers to adjust their positions accordingly.

site_title: Abe begins new term with vow to increase North Korea pressure
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has pledged to increase pressure on North Korea to force the country to the negotiating table, following his re-election. Abe vowed to use a strong mandate to squeeze the regime with tough diplomacy, which could persuade Pyongyang to ask for negotiations. The US President Donald Trump's visit to Japan, starting Sunday, will be dominated by the threat from North Korea, and Abe will spend time analyzing the latest North Korean issues and discussing ways to deal with them.

site_title: Everyone has a critical role in journey: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of everyone playing a critical role in Singapore's future economy. He identified four levels of participation: national, industry, enterprise, and individual, where the government, business associations, and individuals must work together to spur growth and capability development. Heng highlighted the need for collaboration and digitalization, citing the launch of Industry Digital Plans to help SMEs adopt impactful technologies. The government will maintain macroeconomic stability and build deep capabilities, while business associations will lead sector-wide initiatives and cooperate with one another.

site_title: Front runner in Fed race - the good and not-so-good news
summary: Jerome Powell is likely to be nominated as the new Federal Reserve chair, ensuring a seamless transition and continuity in monetary policy. However, his appointment has been criticized as less-qualified compared to Janet Yellen, who had nearly two decades of experience in monetary policy. Powell's background is in law and investment banking, lacking a strong foundation in economics, which may make him more susceptible to staff influence. Despite this, his familiarity with Fed policy and consensus approach may provide stability in the short term.

site_title: Hong Kong home sells for HK$1.1b
summary: A luxury home in Hong Kong's Peak neighbourhood sold for HK$1.16 billion, setting a record price per square foot of HK$126,813. The 4-bedroom, 9,178 sq ft house features a swimming pool, lift, and unobstructed views of Hong Kong and Victoria Harbour. The sale follows a 11% year-over-year increase in secondary residential prices in Hong Kong, putting the city at risk of a real estate bubble, according to the UBS Global Real Estate Bubble Index.

site_title: MAS offers funding help to boost issuing of catastrophe bonds
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will provide 100% funding for the upfront costs of issuing catastrophe bonds, aiming to boost the issuing of these assets to quickly provide financing in the aftermath of regional disasters. This move is part of Singapore's efforts to develop alternative risk transfer mechanisms, such as insurance-linked securities and government pools, to enhance its disaster resilience.

images.alt_text: As a start, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will fund 100 per cent of the upfront costs incurred in issuing catastrophe bonds - assets that pay insurers if they suffer cataclysmic losses - out of Singapore.

site_title: Giving an edge to S'pore's defence
summary: The Defence Science and Technology Agency (DSTA) of Singapore is investing in its capabilities to bolster the country's defence and security. DSTA has successfully leveraged the Business Excellence framework, winning awards such as the Singapore Quality Award, People Excellence Award, and Innovation Excellence Award. The agency is focused on nurturing and motivating staff to embrace innovation, with initiatives like the iLEAP Framework and a cross-disciplinary Digital Hub. DSTA's work contributes to the Ministry of Defence and Singapore Armed Forces' technological capabilities, making a difference to the country's defence and security.

site_title: Brexit threatens 10,000 finance jobs: Bank of England
summary: The Bank of England predicts up to 10,000 UK finance jobs could relocate abroad on the first day of Brexit, with a total of 75,000 possible job losses. This is based on a pessimistic Brexit scenario, where Britain leaves the EU with no trade deal. The 10,000 jobs represent less than 1% of the sector's total jobs in the UK. Negotiations between Britain and the EU are set to resume on November 9, with EU leaders considering a transition period and future partnership agreement.

site_title: Strong Asia sales drive up Honda profit forecast
summary: Honda Motor Co Ltd raised its forecast for full-year operating profit by 2.8% to 745 billion yen due to stronger car sales in China and growing motorcycle sales in Asia. The company expects to sell more cars and motorcycles this year, with cost reductions and a weaker yen boosting its bottom line. This is the third time Honda has increased its operating profit forecast for the year to March.

site_title: India's aviation ministry proposes rules for commercial use of drones
summary: India's aviation ministry proposes new regulations for commercial drone use, requiring users weighing over 2kg to obtain a security clearance, operating permit, and remote pilot license. The rules, which are expected to be finalized by the end of the year, will ban drone use near airports and certain areas, and charge violators under the Indian penal code. The regulations aim to encourage the drone industry, allowing e-commerce companies to use drones for deliveries, and will be overseen by the Directorate General of Civil Aviation.

site_title: Macau casino revenue hits 3-year high on post-holiday gaming rush
summary: Macau's casino revenue reached a 3-year high in October, with gross gaming receipts increasing 22.1% to 26.6 billion patacas (S$4.5 billion). The surge is attributed to a post-holiday gaming rush, with many high-stake bettors and recreational players visiting the world's biggest gambling hub. Analysts attribute the increase to the absence of any significant crackdown on gaming, alleviating concerns among Chinese VIPs. The gains come as major casino operators, including Las Vegas Sands and MGM Resorts, prepare to introduce new properties to attract casual gamblers and tourists.

site_title: Factory activity index eases off 13½-year high in October
summary: US factory activity eased to a 13½-year high in October, but remained strong, as hurricane-related disruptions faded. The Institute for Supply Management's index dropped to 58.7 from 60.8 in September. Private sector hiring surged, indicating job growth rebounded in October after being depressed in September. Manufacturing and labor strength likely keep the Federal Reserve on track to increase interest rates in December.

site_title: MAS requests KTL Global CEO to surrender passport
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has requested KTL Global CEO Tan Kheng Yeow to surrender his passport following an investigation into possible offences under Section 197 of the Securities and Futures Act. The company has stated that it will make further announcements as necessary. The investigation is related to the CEO's involvement, but no further details have been provided.

site_title: Growth in US manufacturing eased in October from 13-year high
summary: US manufacturing growth eased in October to 58.7, down from a 13-year high of 60.8 in September, according to the Institute for Supply Management. Despite this, the industry remains solid, with readings above 50 indicating expansion. The steady growth is attributed to consumer spending, business investment, and a rebound in exports due to a weak US dollar. The ISM's gauge remains above the 57.1 average for the year, indicating a firming-up in the industry.

site_title: China Jishan sued by buyer over agreement involving proposed disposal
summary: China Jishan Holdings is being sued by Shanghai Jintumu Real Estate Co for 485,973 yuan (S$99,965) over a supplemental agreement on the purchase of a developer and manager of residential and commercial properties. The purchaser is also seeking to withdraw the agreement and freeze assets worth up to 780 million yuan. China Jishan claims it has complied with SGX listing rules and applicable law, and will vigorously defend the claim and seek to unfreeze assets. The company is seeking legal advice on the matter.

site_title: Network of lockers, cargo-space platform part of logistics plan
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has launched the Industry Digital Plan (IDP) for logistics SMEs, aiming to enhance the country's e-commerce ecosystem. The plan includes a network of common parcel lockers, a platform to sell unused cargo space, and a self-assessment checklist for digital readiness. Pilot sites, Punggol and Bukit Panjang, will test the "Federated Lockers" and "In-mall Distribution" initiatives, with plans to expand the locker network to 760 across the island by 2020.

site_title: Hong Kong's CK Asset to sell office tower for record HK$40.2 b
summary: Li Ka-shing's CK Asset Holdings Ltd is selling its 75% interest in Hong Kong's 73-storey office tower, The Center, for a record HK$40.2 billion to C.H.M.T. Peaceful Development Asia Property Limited. The sale is expected to generate a gain of about HK$14.5 billion, with proceeds used for general working capital purposes. The deal follows a surge in Chinese firms' expansion in Hong Kong's property market, with several buyers expressing interest in acquiring the office tower.

site_title: Scottish tenants take on tycoons in island tussle
summary: Scotland's five island residents aim to buy Ulva Island from its aristocratic owner, Jamie Howard, with the help of a £10 million Scottish Land Fund. The island, with its pristine beaches and lush hills, is currently on the market for £4.25 million. The residents, who face a deadline of June 2018, are invoking a newly passed law that gives them first right of purchase. The community purchase of land is seen as a way forward to preserve the island's way of life and protect it from potential outside buyers.

site_title: OUEHT Q3 DPS rises, bolstered by hospitality business
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust (OUEHT) reported a 10.6% year-on-year rise in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.36 Singapore cents for the third quarter, driven by stronger hospitality business. Gross revenue rose 5.4% to S$34 million, with master lease income from hotels increasing 6.7% at Mandarin Orchard Singapore and 10.7% at Crowne Plaza Changi Airport. Net property income and income available for distribution also increased. The trust attributed the growth to higher RevPAR and banquet sales.

site_title: Oxley's Q1 net profit jumps nearly sevenfold
summary: OXLEY Holdings reported a nearly sevenfold jump in Q1 net profit to S$48.7 million, driven by revenue recognition from property sales and rental income. Revenue rose 146% to S$310.6 million, with total unbilled contract value at S$2.3 billion. Earnings per share increased to 1.67 Singapore cents from 0.24 cents a year ago, but no dividend was recommended.

site_title: Foreign home buyers back in Vancouver
